reviews.review:
good to see. we have reached to the palace by using Tunnel from near Sishane metro station to Karakoy, then by a tramway to Kabatas station. by 5 min walking you will reach to the palace.
Only buy the ticket to visit main Palace and Sultan's wives Palace not more.

A Turkish Versailles . You can get there on foot from Taqsim sq if you enjoy a pleasant walk through nice and quiet area and don't mind some steps through a park down toward the palace .The entrance fee was 40 Turkish lira per person to visit the whole complex however you can choose to visit the main building only and pay less.The main palace was kept and maintained in a very good condition. Beautiful interior design and architecture all over the main palace, magnificent candelabra and ornaments were placed every where. the Haram area ( residential part for king's mother and his wives) was not that much interesting except in few rooms ( reminded me of Kensington palace! ) The entire visit was arranged by a mandatory tour guide with option for English and Arabic speaking guide. Our English guide for the main palace was very nice and funny man. He was knowledgeable and tried to interact with different group of visitors. In contrast to him a lady guide for the haram was not that much good, she briefly talked about the whole thing and let us to visit the rest of place by our own. It is not possible to visit the main building by your own, photography is not allowed inside of any buildings. The camli kosk which looked like a posh conservatory was very average , there was a long corridor from the main palace to there which was blocked for visitors but we had a sneaky look through the closed doors. It was interesting! The watch museum was very average nothing very special. The was an aviary near the building with few birds which we felt there were a little bit neglected in their cages as the area was very smelly.There was cafe outside the exit door of the haram with no view. So if you prefer a nice view by the sea there is another cafe just outside the main entrance door. We really enjoyed our visit and definitely recommend it. You won't miss out that much if you visit only the main palace.

A mini Versaille. Your not sure when you walk up to the security point what you will find. However, once you have passed the main gate you immediately see a fine estate which was created by many craftsmen. The details in architecture and design are truly everywhere. The Ottoman Empire brought some very fine skills and capabilities.

Highlight of Istanbul Trip!. This was the highlight of Istanbul. The decoration is worth seeing. We joined a tour with an english speaking guide who was very knowledgeable of the details in the palace. The palace has a marvelous view on the Bosphour. It is a huge palace. It is very easy to arrive from Taksim square by taking Funicular F1 to Kabatas then can walk to the palace in around 10 mins. A must see place in Istanbul. You have to buy tickets for the main palace and another ticket for the Harem. In my opinion the Harem is simpler and there's nothing much to see so you can skip it.

Incredible detailing of the interior. A "must visit" if you are planning to visit Istanbul and interested in history and architecture. A visit of the interior of Dolmabahce Palace is always accompanied by a guide of your preferred language, therefore you will have a better understanding once you have finished with the tour. Unfortunately they do not allow picture taking.
Disappointed. The palace was beautiful, but they don't allow you to take photos, so what's the point? Also, the tour was way too short and overpriced.
Wow Wow wow. One of the most impresive palaces oin the world. Go straight to the oficial quarters tours and skip the Harem and museum. Nothing to compare in other countries in Europe ,

Impressive building. Walk inside and you forget you are in Istanbul, not Paris, in this Baroque-like palace. We joined a tour being led by English speaking guide. Although knowledgable, he was less than enthusiastic as he hurried us through the rooms. Despite this we did enjoy the visit.

Amazing castle . This castle are so amazing in view and location. Still have the same furniture and sultan accessories. Also you will find many painting for Sultans and their family. You will find the luxury of sultan live. The gardens of Castel also so beautiful. I advise all persons visit Istanbul visit Dolmabahçe castle.

Unexpectedly impressed. The combination of architecture styles from Europe and Turkey was impressive. Theg guided tour in english was also very good. Although not a must-see in Istanbul, we really enjoyed being there.

Dolmabahce Palace. Nice place to go 👍🏻👍🏻👍🏻
the staff at the counter not friendly (8 October 2016@11am) we pay 💰 not ask for free 😏
Price: 40TL per person for all entrance / access ie painting museum, palace etc

Collectioneur of kitch and poor tours . With the current low in tourism the queues are gone. It doesn't make the palace more attractive. The tours are recited in poor English and the palace is a huge but inconsistent and pompous building. Worth a visit to get an understanding why ataturk wanted to get rid of the sultans.
If you're short in time in Istanbul skip this.

Astonishing view of The Turkish culture. The structure of the palace is amazing with different building each with special history. When the gids starts the story with:"Dolmabahçe Palace is a palace in the Beşiktaş district of Istanbul, Turkey. It was the main administrative center of the Ottoman Empire from 1856 to 1922. Construction of the palace started in 1843." You feel like you are in the scenes in 1870.

A beatiful palace!. Dolmabahce Palace has three museums: the Palace, Harem, and Art Galleria. it is cheaper to buy combo than separate tickets. Every 20 minutes the Palace offers free guided tours in different languages. You will not be able to take pictures inside the Palace.
Dream palace. It is dream palace each part tell you history . Majic place you feel history in every room Romantic palace

Ottoman opulence at its best (worst?). Very impressive although this was built at a time when the Ottoman empire was running out of money. Kind of a last hurrah before they called it a day and got exiled. You can only visit as part of a guided tour but its well worth it, even though you may feel a little rushed sometimes. The guides make sure you don't linger too long. I don't like the "no picture" policy and quite a few tourists seemed to be blatantly ignoring the guide's pleas to not use cameras. The room where Ataturk died is in the palace. The grand finale of the palace tour is the HUGE ceremonial hall - I believe its larger than 20,000 square feet! Worth visiting and after you've seen the main buildings, venture out to the back where there is a little clock museum and a duck pond.

*****. Dolmabahce Palace is located in the Beşiktaş district on the Europian side of Istanbul....Dolmabahce Palace built in 19 th century is one of the most glamorous palaces in the world.....Dolmabahce served as the main administrative center of the Ottoman Empire from 1856 to 1887 and 1909 to 1922.....Has to be visited.....

Beautiful paalce. The entrance fee is 40TL per person. Beautiful architectural specially the big gates that opens at the Bosphorus strait. And very good location , you can catch a cruise later from kabatas station . Also very near Takism squire you can take funicular to kabatas station and cross the road. Only drawback is they only let you inside the palace and Harem in groups at fix times. So there is much of waiting there.
An astonishing display of wealth.. The whole site has to be seen to be believed. I almost thought I was in Buckingham palace. It had a great array of rooms, architecture and even radiators.

Marvelous. It is the last palace witch is remained from osmanies, Ataturk has lived there and it is very nice with big yard near the sea. A lot of rooms for harams and cute window opening to the sea. We liked it.
Opulence . We were shown the amazing opulence of the last phase of the Ottoman Empire by the excellent Istanbul Guided Private Tours. The grandeur and and ornate interior were truly awesome.

First Ottoman Palace in Western Style. This is a great museum to see different architecture and also how the Ottomans lived. Many rooms still set up the way they were. You can explore this palace on your own. Groups are led by a tour guide once inside and the guide was very knowledgeable and pointed out some interesting facts. Take the time after the tour to walk behind the palace and explore the rest of the grounds.
Extravagant place. If you want to see the fanciest buulding in all of Istanbul, that is the best place to go to. Amazing palace, full of history and extravagant items. It's a must visit for sure.

Extraordinary architectural and historical gem on the Bosphorus!. The Dolmabahce Palace complex is an absolute must-see in Istanbul that can too easily be overlooked. Make time for it! The last home of the Ottoman rulers and the home of Ataturk when he founded modern Turkey, the Dolmabahce Palace is impressive in every way. The palace affords visitors a glimpse into the architectural splendor that surrounded the Ottoman royal family. The palace also affords visitors a chance to walk through history, to see the rooms occupied by Ottoman royals as well as the rooms where Ataturk, the Father of the Republic of Turkey worked and died in 1938, with the palace's clocks stopped at the time of his death. For sheer beauty, there are few sights comparable to the elegant Dolmabahce Palace on the edge of the Bosphorus between European and Asian Turkey. A must see!

Wonderful place. Shame about the poor manners of of the visitors, though.. Perfect setting on the Bosphorus with beautiful grounds as well as the palace. 5 minutes easy walk from the end of the T1 tram line. It's compulsory to be led by the tour guide. Some of the large group we found ourselves in had poor manners - taking photos even when told not to (several times), touching things on the way round, talking so we could not hear the guide. At least a few of the group were trying to "shush" the culprits. Perhaps many couldn't understand English - it was an English-speaking guided tour. There seemed to be just English and Turkish tour choices at the time we were there.

Pricey for what it is. We went on a Wednesday morning and it was quiet.You get an English guide assigned for a big group, walked around the palace with the explanations of the guide that makes the visit interesting.We bought a simple ticket but we were not allowed to enter anywhere else.Many rooms of the palace were under reconstruction so were closed.Ticket is a overpriced for what it is.

Dolmabahce at its very best. Dolmabahce Palace's architecture is just outstanding, this is a must see place in Istanbul its location is just awesome besides Bosphorus strait , it looks amazing from Bosphorus , it seems it just opens it flood gate of delight for Bosphorus. It is the best Ottoman palace by far.Lots of picturesque location you can easily get here. I truly recommend this place by heart .

Must in the things to do in Istanbul . One of the most beautiful places in Istanbul... its a must place to visit if you take the big bus tour you can take a drop at the Dolmabahce place.. if you go there o would suggest once free from the place visit do explore the area by walk
Dolmabahce Palace. Dolmabahce Palace is a place full of history that cannot be missed if you are in Istanbul, great architecture! Absolutely impressed by this Palace!

Beautiful palace. This palace is truly beautiful and magnificent. We were awed by such grandeur. The garden surrounding it and the steps leading up to the palace to the inside of the palace, everything was beautiful. Loved looking at the pretty chandeliers and the beautifully crafted ceilings. An unforgettable visit!

Old Is Gold. amazing palace very well maintained organized and clean - there is a tour guide taking you around each and every section in the palace you can see a lot of things additional to the beautiful garden outside the place.

Well worth a quick visit. Wonderfully appointed with classic decor of the era from the Sultan (who died here - and you can see the room/bed were he passed away), including the famed Baccarat Crystal staircase, bearskin rugs gifted from Russia, as well as other international gifts from years gone by. The grounds are also well kept and worth a stroll along the waterfront.

Luxury place. Very nice place, so luxury, the harem section is a must.
guides are so professional, it's forbidden to take photos.

Beautiful historical place, must see. I really recommend Dolmabahce Palace to everyone that visits Istanbul. There are lots of different rooms in it to see. You can examine the end of Ottoman empire and start of Turkish republic here. You can also feel Ataturk, his life style and his taste. Must see.

Grand . Spectacular entrance, beautifully manicured gardens. Fantastic interiors. Lit up at night adding to the glory. Ample parking space available close by. Entry fee applicable. Unfortunately no credit or debit cards accepted. Must see, highly recommended.

what a beautiful !. you have to visit all the palace departments
I like it more than TopKapi Palace because all their real things still there , beds , tables .. etc
and what a great artists who designed !

A must see museum. In Istanbul, there are so many things to do and see. But there are two that are absolutely must-see places. Topkapi palace was the seat of the old sultans, and this "European Style" Dolmabahce palace became the seat for later sultans. It's also great for understanding 19th Century Ottoman architecture. It's also the where Ataturk passed away and is therefore significant for The history of the Turkish Republic. Its gate and clock tower are landmarks of Istanbul. Must see !!
Grand Palace. Its a grand palace by the Bosphorus, a great setting. After we did the Bosphorus Cruise, we decided to see it. You can see its panoramic grandeur from the boat

Beautiful palace. The location and beauty of this palace makes this a must see. This palace is very easy to get to by using the tram and worthwhile seeing. We choose this palace as part of a guided tour (with Ahmet, who I would recommend) and were not disappointed. The only criticism is that it is hot and not airconditioned.

Incredible architecture - a peek into the lives and wealth of Ottoman rulers. We took the tram from Sultanahmet to get here and a short walk later we were at the Palace. It looks so grand from the outside itself that we didn't mind the half hour wait to get in (you have to enter in groups with the guide).The architecture and history related to this palace is really inspiring and walking in to each room takes you on a journey through time to a place and era you can only read about otherwise.You aren't allowed to take photos here (perhaps to preserve the thrill of seeing everything first hand when you take the tour rather than seeing it online). Though a lot of people still took photos, I followed the law, and honestly, don't waste time taking pictures of the place. Absorb the view with your eyes, not your LCD!Definitely a must visit!
Great Experience!. This was my first time visiting a palace, but it worth the shot. This palace explains the luxurious life of the previous Sultan who lived in it. The tour will take about an hour.

Incredible views from the Palace. This is a guided tour with an entrance price Of 30 Turkish lira per person.
the tour itself led by a English speaker was basic but to be honest the place speaks for itself. beautiful rooms full of grandeur and opulence; perhaps the content of the tour itself could be improved but overall can't fault the place at all

Beautiful. We visited Dolbahce Palace on our last day in Istanbul. The Location is near Kabatas Tram Station. We waited for approx. 20 minutes to enter the palace. we had an English guide tour (free of charge). the architect in this palace is second to non in my opinion. the only drawback is that its not allowed to take photos (but we did :P) I advise this place certainly. its a must see place in Istanbul

The last palace of Ottoman empire. This palace was the last palace built in Istanbul in the era of the Ottoman Empire. It is built on the Bosphorus. It was very modern for its time - with electricity. Size is much smaller than the Topkapi Palace, but is stylish, modern, beautiful, with a European look. It is worthwhile to consider. Enter in groups for a fixed time (not alone) and must guide tells you. Then you can stroll around the garden or enjoy the beautiful views of the Bosphorus indefinitely.
Beautiful. This is my second visit to this palace and i was impressed as if it was my first! it has a part that looks like opera garnier in paris

Breathtaking!. Dolmabahce Palace vas built in late 19th century and it was palace of ottoman sultans, and first president of modern Turkey Mustafa Kemal Ataturk (he died in one of the bedrooms in palace). Everything in this palace is glamorous, even the heating radiators are gold plated! This is the definitely a must see place when visiting Istanbul!

Lovely palace. Dolmabahce is most interesting for its setting right on the Bosphorus. It is also famous as the place where Ataturk, founder of the Turkish republic, died. Because of that, there is always an honour guard. Go in if you like to look at imperial gifts given to the early Republic. But only if you have time. Seeing it from the water during a Bosphorus Cruise is all you really need.

wonderful view front the Bosfor sea. amazing palace with a wide beatiful garden.this place showing you the point of transformation between the old living days and the new modern days.MUST SEE.spectacular views can be found in each corner of this palace.dont forget to book the full activity ticket, to enjoy all the palace views.ticket for a person may cost 30$. but it worth it.enjoy !

The modern palace. Contrary to Topkapi palace, Dolmabache Palace was build like more like the western palaces. It tells us a story of extreme wealth. one is stunned by the great staircase and the great ceremonial halls. just amazing.

The Turks just don't see it. I had visited Istanbul and done all the “important” sites but really wanted to visit Dolmabache – the setting of this palace is absolutely stunning, the building is itself a work of art. The interiors are amazing and the crystal staircase must have looked stunning when it was installed – I say “must have” as it looked to me that it had not been cleaned since the day it was installed, the whole purpose of it would have been to stun visitors with the shimmering stairs but sadly the whole palace smelt of dust and dirt and clearly none of the wonderful treasures had ever been cleaned. Here you have an incredible palace built to underline the Sultan’s power at a time when it was waning with incredible contents all presented in a rather poor and uninspired manner – the threadbare carpets (the ones specifically put down for you to walk on) alone show the lack of interest in this building and the fact that less than a third of it is open to the public is another indicator. The Turks are really missing a trick here, where the treasures of Topkapi, the blue mosque and Hagi Sophia are wonderful, Dolmabache is on an equal footing and certainly needs considerable more attention to presentation. You do need a guide with this palace to get inside, there were a number of Asian tourists all trying to tag on to a tour as they found having purchased a ticket they couldn’t actually go inside without a guide – my guide was very firm in telling them that it was a private tour and they could not be admitted as part of it. I’m not really sure what the rationale behind it is and perhaps it should be made clear when purchasing the ticket but certainly best to book with a guide if you want to see the inside. Also no photography is allowed and one of the guards was most emphatic and quite aggressive to another tour group when one of their members took a photo. All in all really worth the visit

attractive, charming. starting from the way up to reach there it's a different experience. the view outside ( all around the palace) is charming, inside is like using time machine ,the more you walk in the more you enter the past with all your senses. unforgettable visit.

Wonderful palace . I have visited this lovely palace with my family and it was a great experience. We have joined the tour guide where they explained the different parts of the palace and the history of Ottoman Khaliph who lived in the palace.
Wonderful location

Amazingly beautiful. . This place is beautiful! So much crystal and gold. Photos are not allowed inside the palace itself but you can take pictures outside in the gardens. There is a fee to enter. Having a guide was nice to learn more of the history. One of the most beautiful places I have seen in my life. It is located near the cruise port.

Its a palace after all. Everyobe said it's a must see. Its located in a magnificent location. Go there just to see the beatiful grounds and exterior of the palace. The painting museum wing exhibition was impressive as well. However, the harem portion of the tour was a joke. If youre waiting for the timed English language tour...youll be accompanied by masses of locals and non English speakers ( it was a weekend visit). Youll be moved through the castle interior in a fast cattle like fashion with only 2 or so brief English speaking explanations. Everything is basically roped off lijiting access but you will get a glimpse into various rooms which are obviously dated and not kept up because no one has lived there since President Attaturk has passed away there in the 50's. I would also not really bother checkibg out the crystal exhibition ( very limited and primitive) and the clock museum ( unless you're really into that type of thing).
A Must visit place in Istanbul. I have been to Dolmabahce Palace one can be amazed to see it the Legacy of Ottoman caliphate words can not express the beauty of Dolmabahce Palace
One of the best palaces in Istanbul . When you are in Istanbul this palace is a must visit . Great palace with fascinating views . This is the palace of the last Sultan in Turkey .
True Greatness . What can I say ? This palace is someplace where you MUST go to when Istanbul. No words can describe it. You have never been to somewhere similar, that's for sure.
Impressive . I recomend everyone visiting turkey to visit this place.It is the castle of the old ottoman sultans and they were live there
Amazing . Like this city. Nice place with grate atmosphere. Interesting excursion in English, turkish, German languages... Have small cafe..

Magnificent Palace. Very beautiful and well-preserved palace where you can see and feel the power and wealth of the Ottoman Empire. Usually, it takes about an hour to enter, because of the long queue, but it is definitely worth of seeing.

perfect. perfect building and tools all around the palace.perfect building and tools all around the palace.
perfect building and tools all around the palace.

Trip to Dolmabache. The palace was well maintained like everything in Istanbul. An important structure of Turkish history. The wealth of the Ottoman families was breathtaking. The Palace where Ataturk lived and died. Worth the visit.
Magnificient. Wonderful place, wonderful palace, full of history of the Ottoman Empire and last years of Ataturk. Must to see.

stunnig. A wonderful palace to visit, the wealth of the ottoman families was breathtaking! The opulent rooms with the furniture is truly outstanding. It was very interesting to hear about the history of the palace and the family who used to live there.

La meilleur journée de ma vie. Super super super❤❤❤❤❤ le palais de dolmabahçe is absolutley wonderfull the visit worth every cent u put in there...it's the most expensive palace in tje world and the most beautiful defntly if u visit turkey without seeing it than u did nothing
last era of the Ottoman Empire. so you've visited Topkapi Palace and old town? that was the early era of the Empire. you need to visit Dolmabahce to have a complete idea.

Underwhelming but still interesting. If you've seen European palaces or paintings, this palace probably won't 'wow' you in the same way others have, but it was interesting nonetheless. The chandeliers are truely stunning and the furniture you walk by (very briskly) is also beautiful. There are many dark carved chests inlaid with mother of pearl designs. You can only go through on a guided tour, and they are offered in English and Turkish. The most interesting part of the palace to me was the Harem side, which is where the royal families lived. The setup of each wife having their own apartment is fascinating. I wish that we had been able to see a full unit, with the kitchen and servants quarters as well, to get a feel for how they actually lived in their space. The exteriors of the palace are worth the ticket price alone, as it's a beautiful location right on the Bosphorus, you can imagine the royal family accessing the property by boat after an excursion to the Black Sea.

THE PALACE WHERE ATATURK DIED. If you are in Istanbul and do not visit this Palace I think it is a big mistake. You will travel in time and see the room where Mustafa Kemal Atatürk the founder of modern Turkey died. It is a 3 floor palace with about 285 rooms but most of the rooms are closed for public.

Baroque Europe in Turkey. All of the luxury of empirial europe in one building, with a a bit more than a hint or Arabesque influence.Really nothing less than remarkable! Visiting the city without its grandest palace is a misstake!

Trip to Dolmabache. i liked the way the palace was maintained like everything in Istanbul, it was quite a great tour as if you are travelling back in time. the design, the lighting and how clean the place is was amazing. for me i will visit the place again if possible. i just wish i was able to take some photos
Turkısh history. 3 floors, 285 rooms, 43 rooms available. There are 250,000 m2 area. An important structure for Turkish history. Atatürk eternal journey from here out.

the best in Istanbul. beautiful palace, there are two parts to the palace, the first one called Slamlek, it's the formal building, where they greet the ambassador , and the second section is the private one, its called Hramlek, where the sultan's family live , and it's the amazing section, there are another sections called the crystalpavil, it's not recommended and the painting museum , it's a very impressive museum. the ticket for the whole palace is 40 Turkish lira . for conclusion, it's high recommended attraction.
Powerful Empire. We visited Dolmabache Palace which so Huge with multi story building and saw all the Historic Part of it , and the largest Chandler ever made in the world at that time
Just one word: Wow!. One of the greatest palaces I have encoutered in my travel experience.Not to be missed when in Istanbul.

Amazing architecture & interior design. On one hand Topkapi palace represent traditional old turkish architecture, whereas dolmabahce palace is a modern palace built on western style & is a place of residence of last few sultans. The building, the courtyards & the interior are marvelous & beautiful. All things in its original state. Tons of gold used in its interior design which are still there. It has world's heaviest FANOOS in the main guest lounge, which still used by turkey government for hosting foreign delegations.However, one can feel sympathy with the offsprings of ottoman empire, as this is their ancestors property but they can't get any benefit from it, instead the govt is earning money from it, ie the ottoman empire is still feeding the turkey. The visitor are strictly prohibited from taking photos.

History. This is also a must see this was the second time i visited as I had visited this place 20 years ago and had forgotten how elegant and Royal it is. This has a lot of history in it didnt get time to complete my tour as had to go to the airport but next time I visit Istanbul will definitely visit and keep half a day for that.
amazing place. a charming place , you need to spend a full day to see all rooms of the palace . a living legend of a sultan life.

Palace fit for a Sultan(a). Well worth paying to get in, absolutely beautiful palace, with excellent English guide/tour. Very informative, every question answered and enormous. There are 2 guided tours, each takes about 45 minutes.

Fascinating unforgettable Dolmabahce Palace. A visit to Dolmabahce Palace is a must and makes a fascinating counterpoint to the Topkaki Palace, but don't try to do both on the same day. Whereas Topkapi shows the Ottoman royal culture during its peak, Dolmabace is the palace where the royal family moved to towards the end of the empire and is modelled on western design. The interior is fabululous and the location is right on the waterfront and has great views across the Bosphorus. The gardens are also quite beautiful. It is easy to reach by metro and after the visit you can take the funicular to Taksim square and then stroll down the famous Istiklal Avenue right down to the Galata Tower. Highly recommended!

The most amazing palace I've ever seen. Dolmabahce Palace simply just amazed me! I've seen few other palaces around europe, but this one is the best one. I regret so much, that taking picture inside it's not allowed, but memories will stay forever!

Two eyes are not enough to handle the beauty! . Even though there were renovations in some areas of the palace, it was still a pleasure looking at literally all kinds of art. Two eyes aren't enough to absorb the beauty of this palace! Beauty as far as the eye can see!

Stunning interior. The palace has an amazing interior. I was so awed by their ceilings and the columns. It is a pity that they do not let you take pics of the place. Due to security issues there is no personal guide tours allowed now. Only 40 minutes tours escorted by the palace appointed guide. It was a short trip. We could not spend much time trying to indulge in the aura of the place. But still it was worth it. If visiting during July-August, keep a hand fan. It was pretty hot inside.

felt as home town. rich and cultured but u cant stay for long coz it breath keeping.walking inside is done with lot attention you dont want to miss the small details,the garden is beautifully charming .

The very famous palace . The Dolmabahçe palace is located in Beşiktaş area and you can arrive to the area by taxi which only costs 15 TL or by walking from taxim 25 mins downward to the Bosphorus, the palace closes on Mondays and Thursdays, and on other days it opens from 9 A.M to 16 P.M, don't miss the tours in the parts of the palace (selamlik & Harem) plus don't miss the Bosphorus view in the cafe or in the cafés in Otrakay near the palace 2 km around and you can go to it by the bus. Don't miss the pazar in ortakay and the kumpir and try to go to the palace first and take the rest in ortakay before sunset the view will be magnificent.
Beautiful Palace. Dolmabahce Palace is beautiful palace on sides of Bosphorus. There is a clock tower outside it and a beautiful garden which has free access.

Dolmabahce Palace. Dolmabahe palace kept in it original state since the last occupants is another must see during your visit to Istanbul. The grandure and history as well as the location where you can experience the views and imagine how the residence must have lived and kept themselves warm in such a vast palace.

Unforgettable palace. We were in Dolmabahce Palace on tuesday August the 9th. We discovered a very astonoshing place with a lot of masterpeaces and highly decorated rooms. The door of the palace is very amazing, something I can't forget.

Nice palace. The palace itself is stunning but you are really rushed through your visit and do not get a decent time to enjoy its beauty. The English tours are not that good and are not informative enough.

A good placw to visit if you have time. To be honest its the not the most important place to visit in Istanbul im not a big fan of antiques if you are a fan of old stuff you will enjoy the visit, but its annoying that you have to wait for groups as a guide will take you in a tour as you cant enter there on your own.
Amazing. A must see fantasy palace, no pictures allowed inside though! The gardens are amazing, this place is so well kept, it was impressively clean!

Interesting palace & art museum. This is a great find. Very different from others Istanbul's attractions. Palace and Harem worth to see but not to everyone taste (not to mine) . But garden is a top. Also painting galery is surprisingly interesting and pleasant place. Be aware of waiting times at the entrance of each museum. They a collecting groups at certain times so you have to wait in the sun, sometimes a while. No unaccompanied visitors are alowed inside. Also it could be quite staffy inside as no airconditioning is installed.
Magnificent Piece of Art. It is really worth its name. well maintained and organized. a place to discover the greatness of the last ottoman sultans. Just organize your visit to avoid waiting time.

Loved the ceilings. This is an enormous palace with alot of history. We had the experience of a tour guide who did a good job in explaining the history behind everything about the palace, from the chandeliers from Queen Elizabeth 1 to King Louie's fireplace tiles! The garden is also enormous which has been kept so well, there was a lot of renovation going on but managed to see the important rooms including the ceremonial hall. The only down side was we were not allowed to take any pictures!

Another extravagant house. Beautiful views of the sea, elaborate palace but a bit run down compared to other palaces in Europe that are better maintained. I do like that they include a tour guide with the price of entrance, as it helps understand where to go and what you are seeing, but there are very few details provided,and only a portion of the palace is open.

Great visit!. As is the way with Palaces this one is on the banks of the Bosphorus too. It's relatively new, mid 1800's and built in a neoclasical roccoco style. There are well appointed gardens with some interesting statues. The Palace was used as a home in addition to becoming an administrative centre. Ataturk was the last occupant and he died here in the early 1900's using the Palace as a summer residence.Its very oppulent with lots of gold and crystal and holds one of the worlds largest crystal chandelier weighing over 4.5 tonnes! There is a horseshoe shaped staircase with crystal brass and mahogany which is a sight!As you would expect there are some huge turkish carpets on view along with collections of oils.The main entrance was closed when we visited so it was a little out of synch with what you would expect.

What a heritage . Amazing place worth the visit, Regret to have missed the tour. We were thrown out in the middle of the tour in a humiliating manner by one of the staff. (tickets purchased & not refunded, Bad experience in a captivating place. ) Don't miss. Good Luck

Chandelier Heaven. I just wish they would let you take pictures here....The glass work in the chandeliers , and the floor lamp chandeliers is unbelievable. This palace should make all others embarrassed to be called palaces.

Amazing place. We booked the tickets in advance because we knew that this is something that we can not miss. It is an amazing place full of history, art and culture. I recommend visiting this place with a guide because it is so big and you can miss a lot of really interesting stuff.

A beautiful palace and great view of Busphore.. A beautiful palace,great view of Busphore and amazing garden. isn't open all days we went there twice but it's close. they denied take pictures inside the palace

MAJESTIC PALACE. A majestic palace with a splendid garden all around,its garden looks on Bosphorus,what an amazing view.TherE are HARIM section ,selamlik section and a museum .There will be a tour guide speaking English that will be included in entrance fee you pay,the tour in harim and selamlik section will take about one hour.Most things I liked was selamlik section with the THRONE HALL,The wonderful Crystal Chandelier and the Crystal Stairs,when a draught of air entered, the crystal pieces will give a sound like a music ,I loved it.The description we got from the guide was good .You had better visit this palace and enjoy the garden views.
amazing. one of the greatest places i have ever visited in Istanbul,, but i wonder why cant we take pictures there :S ,,

Regal!. Actually visited in May 2015 where the weather was a bit hot but tolerable. I would suggest you visit this attraction in the morning since crowds gather around afternoon. There is a small entrance fee to pay but really affordable. The palace is regal with a very rich history. A 45-60 minute tour also takes place inside the palace where a guide tells you more about the interior, structure & past leaders of Turkey that have stayed there.

Delightful Palace. This beautiful palace with amazing gardens , lets you see how the Ottomans head of government lived. Unbelievable. The gardens are also beautiful, so do walk them and you have an amazing view of the Bosphorus

Beautiful. This is a really beautiful place and anybody going to Istanbul should see it. Keep in mind that the visit is quite long and it closes early. Do not go there at 4 PM.One little disappointment though : The first guide was really too fast.
You should visit. Amazing palace.... You need at least 4 hours to see everything They have tour in English and another tour in TurkishAlso they have museum for Watches, museum for drawing

My trip to Istanbul. I been there in August 2016...well I read a lot about this Palace but when I go in...I was shocked what a wonderful architecture...nothing can describe what you will see there...it's not so far from Sultanahmet area, if you go by Tramway you stop in the last station Kabatas then you can walk for 10 minutes to arrive...don't take a taxi as it's expensive and so crowded the traffic...but walking is much better as you will see a lot near it...well the bad thing that' you can't take pictures inside the palace but anyway it's steak in my mind every part of it

Worth the trip!. Having just come from Munich, where the palaces seemed very stylized and rather cold, this Palace was just so, well, livable! They were not subtle, to be sure, but they maintained a beauty and sensuousness that I find to be rare in similar museums. Be sure to take the tour of the formal rooms (the Harem and the clock museum were not as interesting).

Best highlight in Istanbul. Truly surprized not to see this one on the first place in Istanbul ratings. This place is really amazing from inside, and definitely at par or exceeds with kings palaces in Vienna, Budapest or Saints Peterburgh.Go and see it, you wont be dissapointed. Taking pictures is not allowed but dont be upset- you can either download them from government website, or buy a disk.

The absolute luxury. I travel a lot, I have visited a lot of countries and a lot of monuments and palaces but this was the first time that I saw this luxury and this exaggeration in gold, crystals, precious stones and precious fabrics everywhere around me. From the floor, to the ceiling, wherever you look, you see wealth.The cherry on the top, is the huge crystal chandelier of 3,5 tons, the biggest in the world, which is located in the main hall (the throne's hall) and it just leaves you with the mouth opened.We paid for both the main guided tour and the tour at the harem and it was nice because at the harem we saw also Ataturk's bedroom and we were very lucky because at that time, generally in Istanbul, there were not many tourists so we didn't have to wait at all.Photos inside are not permitted.
Gorgeous!. One of the best palaces to visit! So much money spent in it and is very well maintained. A must visit!

Full of history. This plaice is wonderful. It is very luxury. The guides inside were very polite and knowledgeable too. We did not make a wrong decision choosing this palace of many in Istanbul.
Great experience!

The new palace is worth it.. We ended up here as the last stop of a Bosphorous cruise, which are well worth it. This palace is modeled after more modern European palaces and is more spectacular than most I have visited. You have to pay a bit to get a pass to take pictures inside the palace. If you want some pix of beautiful rooms and furnishings, it is worth it.

Come Prepared. I think the Dolmabahce Palace is stunning, but one must know that you can only take a private tour with a specific schedule, meaning you can't just show up and expect to tour the palace on your own. Keep in mind that photography is NOT allowed inside (exterior shots are ok though). Beautiful landmark nonetheless

11 July 2016. Wow.. that is my first remarks. Dolmabache or Topkapi? very difficult to priority. I should say both. Wonderful location. You will love the Harem, clock Museum, Administrative building. 40 TL to enter. No photography.

The Dominating Dolmabahce. When in Turkey a walk down into the Ottoman Empire is a must. Hence when in Istanbul take a trip in the past to the Ottoman Era and visit the 19th century's most glamorous palaces in the world Dolmabahce Palace! In our visit last year we give the Palace a miss simply because it was not on our guided tour itinerary which is surprising since after witnessing the opulence of the Palace in our recent private trip it's a must visit. Although we think the reason is that the other sites in Istanbul like Ayasofya, Topkapı Palace, Blue Mosque & others are relatively cheap ticket wise as they have a package deal but Dolmabahce for one is located at the far end and it is in an up market area of Istanbul plus the ticket price is steep so to include it in a tour package might be heavy on an average tourist. All said we do recommend the traveller to visit the Palace simply because it is magnificent. The sprawling gardens, the European coastline of the Bosphorus stretching from miles and miles, the grandeur of the exterior grounds of the palace and once inside your jaw will certainly drop because all that glitters is gold! One is not allowed to take pictures of the interiors but it is a guided tour so you may get lost in the opulence of Dolmabahce but its historical importance and facts are not lost in translation.... (English translator available who was quite a jolly good fellow).

Must Visit. Here you will find the other face of the ottomans..You will see how Europe affected them with its style. It is very different from Topkapi.From another point of view you will see the gape between sultans life and the normal people life at that time.Be careful..it is very hot inside so you might bring a hand fan with you....

the most beautifull place. You should visit Dolmabahce Palace for sure. This is one of the largest palace in europe. it is still very much intact . you feel it's appeal the moment you step inside. It is huge with so many beautiful decorations . I saw the death bed of the founder of the turkish republic here. ıt holds so many great and appealing historical designs and treasures.

it really worth it going there!. If you go to Istanbul, people will talk about Topkapi, which is really amazing. But Domabahce palace is beyond that especially the last room where the palace's tour ends, there you will see a lamp you never imagined it exists. I recommend for the whole palace about 4 hours visit all together. It is easy to go there, just take the tram and walk maybe 100 meters. When I went there they didn't accept credit card for the tickets (which is really annoying!)

Very wonderful day . It was a nice trip i go with a group and i love it but the castle is one of the richness place ever i seen there is a tuff rolls but because its a historic place no pictures not allowed. But i recommend for any one love the history to see the rich in old picture

It represents true ancient Royalty. This is one of the largest palace in europe. it is still very much intact . you feel it's appeal the moment you step inside. It is huge with so many beautiful decorations . I saw the death bed of the founder of the turkish republic here. ıt holds so many great and appealing historical designs and treasures. ıt is a treasure of Turkey

Impressive Museum. Visited Dolmabahce Palace which is situated by the banks of the beautiful Bosphorus Canal. There are royal guards at the front entrance. Admission fee applies. There was security check outside the palace. It was raining on the day of visit. There are beautiful fountains in front of the palace. The Palace do not allow photography inside the palace museum. Tour guide will escorted us introducing all the various exhibits from downstairs to upstairs back to downstairs at the rear palace, before exit. The exhibits in the Palace showcasing the various rooms, halls, library, bedrooms, kitchen, etc. The lavish furnitures, antiques, paintings preserved over long period. Also find many clocks, and all stopped, stagnant at 9.05am. It's the golden hour where their modern founding father died. Rich in history.Interesting beautiful place. Need to be carefully explored with an experienced guide. Really enjoyed the 1.5 hours visit.

An impressive and stately palace. Must-see during you stay in Istanbul. Located 5 minutes walk from Kabatas tram station (Tram 1), is a magnificent and stately palace. Entry into the State Apartments and the Imperial Harem, done with a guide. Other attractions are visited individually. Photography during visit in the palace rooms is not allowed.Indoor garden is very beautiful and neat, with panoramic views of the Bosphorus, offers a quiet and pleasant ride.Entrance fee 40 TL (long visit)

Historical palace. It was a beautiful experience, we saw the palace and it was white and beautifulBesides the maramar river makes this place more interesting and visitableIf u come to istanbul, then visit this place for sure.You can also see this place by taking a bosphuros tour too.

A visite to be remembered. Once you enter this palace you will feel that you in diffrent era!!I like the organization ang the toure guide and how they are take care of the palace historyI realy enjoy it

Breathtaking and Eye Candy Interior, A Must See. From the exterior, it seems like another palace in any big city, However, the interior decor is simply STUNNING and out of this world!! We have seen many palaces and this is by far the most impressive and breathtaking inside.Very unfortunately, though understandably, this is a guided tour only, which means you can't take your own sweet time to soak in all the beautiful paintings, furnishings and details of everything in each of the halls and rooms. For us, the pace of the half hour tour was way too fast. Also photography is not allowed and the lightest book we saw there in the shop had very poor photo reproductions. Check on amazon to save carrying the large book back.

A real visit. Live in the past and walk between the rooms of Sultans. Last 6 sultans or Khalifas - rulers- used to live in here. Salamlek for men and the other side Haremlek for Ladies. Amazing architecture with beautiful view to the Bosphour and the garden. Extraordinary life. Photos are prohibited inside.

Must see. You should visit Dolmabahce Palace for sure. It takes around half day and it is located in the city center. Easy to reach by public transportation. You should prefer to get a tour guide so that s/he can tell you the history of the palace and the people who used to live in it!
Beautiful. Dolmabahce is more than a fairy-tale palace in my opinion. You have to visit it outside and inside!! Really beautiful!

Breathtaking Palace and View . A must visit spot when you go to Istanbul, it is breathtaking. Don't miss it when you go there...just be careful of Taxi drivers they might charge you too much.try to take the tram or bus.

Interesting, ceremonial Hall is best. . The palace as a whole is huge. Kind of dull honestly as it is by today's standards nothing special but considering it was built so long ago (late 1800s) it is something to ponder. The ceremonial Hall at the end of the tour is the one that took our breath away.

Don't miss this amazing palace!. This palace of the last sultan is not to be missed. Simply breathtaking. You must go on an organized tour with the crew that works there, but it is really worth it. The grounds are also amazing and beautiful, lending themselves to tons of photo opportunities. The only thing about the tour was that it appeared to be a memorized script...not even really sure the guides quite understood what they were saying...but it did not detract from this experience!

A real surprise . Across from our hotel, the Ritz Carlton, we decided to visit it on our last day. It was like crowing our vacation to Istanbul. No words do it justice. It's a must see. The tour guide treated us with a finale when leading us into the biggest official governmental hall in the world; where the Sultans conducted the annual celebratory functions greeting ambassadors and dignitaries of other nations: INCREDIBLE.
Mesmerizing palace!. Beautiful piece of art! Well maintained palace. do not miss. Just on the bosphorus river. Get a panoramic view of palace from the bosphorus river cruise

Lovely building right on the water. This is a massive building with thousands of rooms. You only get to see a few of the main ones used by the sultans. You have to have a guide and are herded round in a group and hurried though, Our group was so large the people at the back couldn't catch up before the guide started to speak. However well worth a visit and don't forget to spend some time in the grounds. Also try and see it illuminated at night.

Domalbahce palace wow. Beautiful and magnificent place.Fantastic garden and view on sea.I was fascinated with the chandelier in the sultans reception room.Harem is nice but its not so big like in Top kapi palace.Its fantastic place to see.You wont waste time or money if u decide to see this palace.

Must see & make a day of it!. Visited 15th July 2016 - It's clear why the last sultan lived in this Palace, as the design combines eclectic elements from the Baroque, Rococo and Neoclassical styles, blended with traditional Ottoman architecture to create a new synthesis. Dolmabache is a must-see attraction to learn about Turkish history, design and also admire the beauty of the palace and it's surrounding garden (there is also a Bird aviary). I recommend getting there early between 9am-10am, to avoid the queues and herd of tourists. Also there is cap on the number of guests/visitors the palace can host per day & consider the palace is closed every Monday and Thursday to avoid disappointment. The Palace is divided in two parts: Northern (Harem) and Southern (Selamlik) Wing which offer guided complementary tours in English and Turkish. Note no photos are permitted inside these wings. Prior to venturing in the palace, I recommend enjoy a tea or snack at the Dolmache restaurant as it is worth the visit not only for the views of the Bosphorus but for menu & the value for money. Don't feed the cats or seagulls!

Its kind of a must see so.... We visited in July. You have to wait on line outside before entering with a tour guide in your language. Its not covered or anything, so be prepared for dealing with the weather while you wait, but the waits are not too long. You can only enter via these guided tours, but its understandable given the maze of the palace and the priceless antiques. Go ahead and get tix for both tours, the main palace and the harem rooms ($40TL). Note no photography of any kind is allowed inside. The whole of it really comes down to the harem room where Ataturk died and the jaw dropping main hall, which was as impressive as it gets. Also, as far as one can make comparisons via the rearview mirror of history, I think the last sultans and rulers made a mistake going with the modern Dolmabache Palace, because I prefer Topkapi Palace by far.

Must go. Yes yes yes..you have to go there. Experience the grandeur of this palace. Take the tour to the palace as they show the internal areas with a guide only included in the ticket which you get. Amazing architecture..decor and feel. There is a painting museum in it which has to be seen.:)

beautiful palace. It's definitely a very impressive place to visit, very lavish and beautiful. My only draw was that I didn't know that individual visits are not allowed, you can only be a part of a tour, which could be inconvenient if you don't have much time or you only want to skim through the palace. Please respect that photos are not allowed, I could notice that people didn't respect this rule and that it was driving the guards crazy!

you must see . Breathtaking place to visit, it's a very big palace little bit tiring because it's huge and divided into sections, that day me & my sister lost our ticket once we entered but big thanks to the staff there, they let us enter the sections and believed us without booking new one. The first guide to the section was a nice girl and explained well to us but the guide of harem section was bored and was just moving and we are following him with no detailed explanation. we enjoyed taking lot of photos.

Ripping off foreigners....... Boycott. This Palace is very nice to visit, but the tour during my visit was very short and did not provide enough to make the visit so interesting.We had a family member in a wheel chair. He was unable to see most of the tour as it is completely inaccessible to wheelchairs although there is a chair lift at the entrance to the steps. These only allow access to the ground floor.My very big issue with visiting this Palace should visitors not be of Turkish nationality is that Entry costs for Turkish Citizens is 20tl and entry for Foreigners is 40tl. At all other tourist attractions that I am aware of in Turkey the entry cost is the same regardless of nationality, religion, colour etc. This is the way it should be. Everyone equal.Surprisingly this Palace is not operated by the usual department for Culture & Tourism, but is in fact a Government run attraction. They need urgently correct this overcharging and discriminatory behaviour.Until such time I recommend to boycott this attraction & find alternative Palaces to visit. There are many.
Excellent Detail. A great stop and very close to the ferries to get to Princes Island. Beautiful views, fantastic details inside and one to add to the list
Palace tour. This tour was led by an English speaking tour guide. It was about 45 minutes of walking through the palace. No photos allowed.

Nice Palace - Spend More time in the Gardens. This is another Beautiful European Palace. It has all the adornments you would expect in a palace: Huge crystal chandeliers, mural ceilings, walls made of gold, and gorgeous woven rugs. The tour guide spoke english very well. The tour was very thorough. While there is lots of history inside the palace, I would say the more memorable part of the visit was exploring the gardens. The fountains, gates, and landscaping are all beautiful. The gardens are also still home to a few species of exotic birds, including some strutting peacocks. A few notes- much like other historical sights and museums, there are different prices for foreigners and Turks. Also, when I was there the palace was not open on Monday and closes early on other days; look up the times before you go!

Rawan . It's very beautiful palace with a lot of rooms and amazing decor.Also it got a beautiful furniture.I don't recommend for families with kids because they will get tired.No photos allowed inside the palace.There is a free guide speaks English.

Disappointing. Not much of it was accessible on our tour and to make matters worse one of the palace "guards" kept rushing out guide along even though there were no crowds at all. If you can't do it all, skip this one!

Beautiful Palace. Absolutely beautiful palace with guided tour.A great palace with lovely grounds to visit. the guided tour is really informative and helps you understand how the palace was used.Worth the entrance fee.
ho hum. if you have seen one opulent palace that is a testament to the gluttony of history, then you seen this one as well.

Gorgeous Historic Palace. Despite the drawback of not being able to take pictures inside, this palace is incredible! Very detailed and intricate in design with a manicured garden full of roses. There are all sorts of exhibits within the palace filled with calligraphy, tapestries, and carpets. My favorite part of the palace, however, was outside on the walkway along the water - great views of the Maiden's Tower and the Asian side of the city of Istanbul. A must see!

Dolmabahce Palace Experience. This is the Turkish version of Versailles, minus the massive gardens which were downsized to make room for the population growth of Istanbul over the years since the fall of the Ottoman Empire. The tours are conducted in small groups and led by a guide, which is very informative; however, be aware that no one is allowed to wander the palace on their own and photography is prohibited.

Beautiful, but no photos allowed!. I really liked the garden area, the fountain and the views of the Bosphorus. But I went the for the palace itself, and having to go on a guided tour and not being able to take pictures inside was really annoying. Having said that, the interior is really beautiful and you definitely have to visit.Make sure you arrive early, so you can buy the two tickets to visit both parts of the Palace.
GO. This was my second favorite thing. Cisterns was most interesting. This palace is UNBELIEVABLE. This is included in the MUZE pass.

Dolmabahce Palace. The palace is very near the cruise port. We walked about 8 blocks from the cruise port to the palace. It wasn't a hard walk. The palace itself has a large garden and the structure is huge. The guides take you room to room explaining the uses of the rooms and how they lived. Also there is the bedroom where Ataturk died. He was the father of modern Turkey and beloved by everyone there.
Excellent place. A mix of Asia and Europe, this wonderful palace will bring to your memories both oriental fairy tales and european tales...

Dolmabahce Palace. Our first attempt to visit this location had to be aborted as it was close. Need to check what days it is open. Although heavy rain started after our arrival and some what spoilt our day as there is little to no shelter. Once inside on the guided tour we appreciated the wait and the weather did not spoil our experience, it was terrific. This Palace was the last built by the Ottomans The last Sultan built it to show the Empire was not fading. No expense was spared the Chandaliers were magnificent, the largest weighed 4 Tonnes. Cost to enter was reasonable I think it was less than $20.00 Australia. The guided tours were done in English or Turkish, we were in a large group so it was necessary to keep near the Guide to hear what was being said. It has an advantage over Versailles as it was not looted after the Sultans were moved out. A must see in Istanbul, Security was high

Must look palace. its a very nice palace & lot of the king luxury and power is seen. the guided tour is very good in english and turkish. the palace has a speedy wifi. in total you will need 3-4 hours for complete visit.
The new Ottoman Palace. Beautiful palace in İstanbul. If you visit the city, you must see this palace. Lovely place by Bosphorus.

Huge and opulent palace right on the Bosphorus. The Dolmabahce Palace replaced the Topkapi Palace as the home of the Sultan. Dolmabahce is much more Western in its architecture and it is very grand and opulent. Dolmabahce has great water views because it is right on the Bosphorus. The interior is stunning, with lots of gold and the most amazing chandeliers. Sadly, they don't let you take pictures inside. Besides the main palace you also have the Crystal Pavilion (small but neat), a small clock museum (neat) and the paintings gallery (not that hot in my opinion). The Swan Fountain is lovely. Lots of birds running around and a tiny zoo by the Crystal Pavilion too.Getting in: 40 TL combo ticket for Selamlik and Harem. 9-3:30 daily but CLOSED MONDAY AND THURSDAY. We had to wait a few minutes to get an English-speaking tour, but I think it helped that we got there shortly after the Palace opened for the day. The wait would surely have been longer if more people were there.

Alan and Joanne Willins. Fabulous palace we saw from the Bosphorus cruise, huge sprawling palace with interesting guided tour. We already knew some of the history relating to the Sultans, harem and the fact that Mustafa Ataturk also lived there. Interesting armour and swords as well as ceramics and gifts to the Sultan.

Opulence of the Era. The size of the palace is astounding! The decor and chandeliers are amazing - like stepping back in time to a grand age. The sultan's bath and ballroom are highlights. It's a very busy location and we were somewhat rushed through by the staff, but it appeared there were many tours walking through at the same time (several ships had docked that morning). The gardens are exceptional also.

Amazing!. I thought that the Sultan Ahmed Mosque and Hagia Sophia are the most amazing attractions to visit in Istanbul that before I visited the Dolmabahce Palace! The Palace is on a high level of luxury and sophistication and full of beautiful small details! With a large garden and a wonderful flowering overlooking the sea as well.Also there is an art museum featuring original works of Orientalism painters such as Jean-Léon Gérôme. If you are an art and history lover this place is a must to visit!

Sparkling Palace on the Bosphorous. We visited this Palace in the morning before the crowds arrived and enjoyed the gardens to ourselves. It is important to understand that the tickets include a guided visit in either English or Turkish. When you line up at the entry to the Palace you will be advised when the next tour begins. Protective covers are provided for your shoes and no photos are allowed inside. The tour lasts for about 45 minutes and takes in many of the rooms. If you wish to visit the Harem you need to purchase this as either a separate ticket or combined with the Palace.
Great place!!!. If you like history then you should visit it. I like the palace and their collection. You can't take picture inside the palace.
Superb . Such a nicely maintained and lovely place. One of the nicer places to visit, similar to the experience you get in Alahambra. The Islamic relics are superb.

Must see. If you are in Istanbul, you have to see this palace from inside and outside, for me and my friends it took around 4 hours to visit, because it's a place which you don't want to leave, but of course it is possible to make it faster. There is a discount with isic, so show it, if you have. Everything inside looks like from the picture or from the movie - golden walls, doors, furniture, big spaces. There are guides who talk in turkish or in english, so they are explaining the meaning of rooms and pointing out the special items. You don't have to pay extra for that.The view from the palace and from the garden is amazing, you must see it.

Loved The Palace. One of my favorite in Istanbul. The main gate, the clock tower and the garden just in the front of The Bosphorus, must be seen.Don't forget to visit this attraction, not close from Sultanahmet (The Blue Mosque), but very important.You will see something very special.
Worth visiting. To get a good understanding about the Turkish culture, it's really worth visiting this place! One of the must see places of the city!
Museum palace. The great museum and palace with magnificent architecture and view. I spend over three hours in this palaces and surrounding specially the painting museum and heram part

Fantastic over the top & great value. Love the separate areas - main tour / hareem / art & gardens to die for. Just go. Loved it. Buy the full ticket - 20 lire great value - easily accessible by tram - stop at Kabatas ...enjoy - go early allow 1/2 day minimum!
SO Beautiful!. I loved this palace! It wasn't too big and gaudy like Versailles but beautifully decorated throughout. It's small but definitely worth a look!

Disappointing visit. Waited 20 minutes for the English tour. The palace was extraordinary but our guide kept telling us to hurry up so we felt quite rushed. Halfway through the tour he got upset because we were talking about what we were seeing. He clapped his hands loudly, described the room and told us we could finish the tour on our own. We were in a group of about 30 people and all were frustrated.

Dolmabahçe Palace tour is dark and gloomy. We just went to the Dolmabahçe Palace where you have to take their guided as you are not allowed to go inside alone. So we took their last tour at 4:05 and was sadly disappointed. The tour guide will walk you through roped areas, most which are dark and gloomy in the lower floors. The exhibits are not well lit and the palace smells musky in the lower floors. Then you get to the top floors and there is more light. Please note that if it is a hot day outside, it's going to be even hotter inside in the upper floors as it is stuffy and there is no A/C. As this was the case the day we visited. The tour guide mentioned this was a "winter palace" for the Sultan. Wish I knew this before we decided to visit. It wasn't worth the 30 TL.

Wonderfullll. Dolmabahce is a musttt when u r visiting turkey. The ticket for the whole palace is 40 lira then u can see the official court, haram, clock museum, painting museum. The tour guide spoke realllly well the first person in turkey who actually knew how to speak English. U must go to kabatash station and walk for 5 minutes to visit this palace

The most beautiful palace in Istanbul. Even this palace has no to many stars in different travel guides, people do love it. The garden full of flowers, the Bosphorus shore, alined near the garden, makes you a good impression from the very beginning. And after that, the guided visit in the Palace is absolutely immpresive. The power and richness of an empire can be found there. You will certenly like the glamour of the rooms, the furniture, the chandelabres.

Over the top extravagance. This palace tops most of those in Europe for Baroque ornamentation. It is a huge palace and the tour takes you to quite a few rooms fully decorated in period pieces. Unbelievable chandeliers, crystal staircases and painted ceilings make you think youre back in France somewhere. A good value visit.

Dolmabahçe Palace was ordered by the Empire's 31st Sultan, Abdülmecid. Dolmabahce Palace : Last Historic Days of the Ottoman EmpireOut of all the sites to see in Istanbul, the most intriguing has to be the grand and impressive Dolmabahce Palace. Home to the last six sultans of the abolished Ottoman Empire; it portrays everything that was right and wrong about their rule and reign for over 600 years. While it is easy to be in awe at the architecture and historical tales of their conquered lands, I simply had to wonder if any ruler, person or family deserved to live in such luxurious and wealthy surroundings.Dolmabahce Palace was built between 1843 and 1856, at a time when life for the average person in Istanbul or the rest of the Ottoman Empire, was not easy or comforting.

Amazing!. Beautiful!!!!! I love it I guess because it's very different than what you see in palaces in Europe and it's located just by the water which is great on a sunny day. You should definitely visit it!
Manzara. It's great location, beautiful place and smell of the history.. If you like the historical place, at least one time to visit..
Dolmabahce Palace. This wasn't recommended by many people, I am glad we didn't listen and seen this fabulous place. Aware of that palace is closed on Monday and Thursdays

Delicately beautiful. Unfortunately, Dolmabahce Palace was closed for cleaning the day (Monday) that we went to see it. The Palace and courtyards looked quite lovely, but we were only able to see them from the street and from the Bosphoruson a ferry boat ride.
The best. One of the best places to visit in Istanbul! I've been here for first time but it was wonderful. I was surprised!

Make sure you see the Haram and the treasures. This could take a whole day to see properly. Make sure you see it all and don't scrimp on seeing the Haram. It is well worth it. I wish I had gone to see the jewels and treasure first, as I was so tired by the time I saw it, I just wanted to sit...

Architecture at its finest........but a very poor tour guide. Everything about this place is amazing to see, from the landscaped gardens to the magnificent buildings. We were shown around the buildings by a very rude tour guide who managed to upset one of our party by shouting at her in front of the whole group, his English was terrible so he was very hard to understand when explaining the history of the Palace. Lots of renovation work being carried out on the Palace so be prepared to find lots of the main rooms in the buildings closed. Outside the buildings there are lovely views across the Bosphorus.

Great Trip Out of the Heart of Istanbul. On a very hot day we took the "hop on hop off" ferry up the Bosphorous to the Dolmabahce Palace. It was a great escape from the heat and the traffic and congestion of the center of town. The art was uber modern, so not to everyone's taste, but the restaurant (although expensive) has fantastic views and was one of our best meals in Istanbul,. Would definitely do it all over again,

This place is amazing. There are several palaces in the area, and I've been to many more in other countries, but this is exactly what you might expect (if you could imagine it) from Ottoman opulence mimicking European style, and it is scrumptious. If you've liked ANY European palace, put this on your travel schedule, pay whatever fee, and give yourself half a day to wonder around with and without tours. I spent probably 3 hours, and didn't see everything.

Historic and Ornate!. I liked this palace more than Topkapi in terms of the aesthetics and because it still contains actual possessions and decor (chandeliers like you've never seen). It is also the palace in which the 1st president of Turkey (Ataturk) spent the last of his days. There were 2 guided tours here which took about 30 mins each. The first was of the Official area of the palace and the second tour explored the personal rooms of the leader and his family.

Beatful palace. Dolmabche Palace is worth visiting, this one is better than Topkapi in terms of visiting actual decorated rooms. Part of palace is guided tour which is included in ticket. Very well decorated and maintained room which resembles to Roman architect.Art gallery is also within vicinity of palace which is free of cost and worth visiting.Ticket price is 40 lira how ever if you are accompanying with kids, please keep passport with you since they may allow children free of cost under 10 years of age.Don't get in trap of guided tours as they provide half hours slot which is very little to visit palace.

Oppulance of days gone by. Beautiful Palace kept in pristine condition with original furnishings and decor. Such a treat to see. One has to put covers on ones shoes before entering. Wonderful to be able to see this preserved treasure of a time gone by.

Don't miss this Palace. Dolmabahce Palace is located on the European coastline of Bosphorus strait. This palace was built to impress. Once entered inside Dolmabahce Palace please continue to breath. I was very impressed. Don't miss this attraction if you travel to Istanbul.

The masterpiece of Ottoman Empire. Is the palace made to compete Palace of Versailles. With incredible number of rooms, tons of gold in facades and lots of other stuffs to see. I strongly recommend this place
top!!. This is a MUST see on my point of view!!!!! amaizing inside!! it is a guides tour and they explain every room!!!! one of most amaizing palaces I visit so far

What opulence in days gone by. An absolute eye opener to see with what opulence the rulers lived in days gone by. A great experience to go through the harems and palace and see the furniture and fittings still treasured. Thoroughly enjoyed the tour.

A palace like no other. Its a must see palace walking through its a whole another story it is such a fairytale place. I've seen many palaces but this one its unique and like no other in the world the history of it just speaks for itself. The chandelier inside is the world largest one it just jaw dropping. The piano that you get to see was a gift from napoleon to the sultan. Its not allowed to take pictures inside but you can take beautiful pictures outside at the park.

Magnificent Palace. Visiting the Palace was truly the highlight of our last trip to Istanbul. We almost skipped it because I thought (from looking at the website) that it was too gaudy and over-the-top. Well, yes it is but it's also stunningly beautiful when you see it all in person. So worth the visit!! The grounds are lovely especially in the spring and summer with the roses in bloom. The art museum holds many beautiful paintings so be prepared to spend some good time there. And the experience of sitting on the lawn at the gates the overlook the Bosphorus Strait is something to be treasured forever.

Amazing palace on the waterfront. I just had 1 day in Istanbul and decided that this was a place worth spending around 4 hours at! You have 2 guided tours for the main 2 parts of the palace! You have to wait for about 20 minutes for the tour but the garden is so amazing that you will even want to wait more so that you can take all the photos you want!!! To visit the entire palace, it costs 40 turkish lira, this includes the other museums within the palace area! Loved it!

Amazing Place!!. If you ask for one of the few mesmerizing places in Istanbul, this place is going to definitely be on the list. The place couples history with so much of architectural charisma that one simply cannot give away to it. Must visit place for history and architecture lovers!

Magnifique place. It is an incredible palace! Impressive rooms and garden. I was a great pleasure to visit it. You should put on the top attractions in Istanbul. You need at least 2 hours to see all things inside and around. Don't miss it! Even on a rainy day it is good.
A grand Palace. more influenced by European styles than Ottoman. not as opulent as the Topkapi, but just as grand. Must see if in Istanbul to compare and contrast the 2 palaces.
Impressive palace. The only thing Versailles has on Dolmabahce are the gardens- other than that it's just as magnificent.
Palace with a view. This place is full of so much history and so much to see. You get a show even before you walk in with the guards outside. Its definitely a must see when in istanbul

You have to see it!. Well, this was the highlight of the visit! Very neat and guided tour of Palace! Guide explains you all the important bit of information that you should know about this palace! Grand Ceremonial Hall is the highlight which has the largest chandelier in Europe! 4.5 Tonnes!!!!! and the tall pillars and the huge hand woven carpets will make you say WOWWWW!!!!

Simply bonkers and over the top - great!. Unmissable. Annoyingly, no photography but then the souvenirs are nothing special - so loads of people just take photos on the sly anyway. A sign of the outrageous wealth of teh old rules. Make sure you see this one.
Amazing palace. One of the most wonderful places at Istanbul.You will enjoy the nature, view, architecture and arts.You will see a different kind for luxury life.

The opulence of the sultans and the recency of this palace make it a must visit. Opulent, well preserved and gives you a good look into the luxuries of the life of a sultan and later, in the life of the first President of the Turkish Republic. Tours are given in batches.We waitied for the English tours to begin both at the Harem and the other Hall and got the whole history. Carry umbrellas as you may have to wait in line without a roof over your head until the tours begin. We visited in late May.
Amazing. This palace has much of the original interiors, carpets and the most amazing chandeliers. The artwork and carpets were amazing,

Very nice palace in Istanbul. The palace is located on the Bosphoros side, the place Historical and was the Otoman palace.There is so many room that no to jump and when you make tour , Take the long one, its about 1 hour, outside there is nice Resturant
Amazing. A must see, you cant take photos but you can buy a book at the end. 40tl for the Palace and Harem. You get a guided 35min tour of the harem then a 45 min tour of the main palace.
A must. A beautiful palace in a superb location Worth going to the nearby cafe for amazing views of the Bospheros
Number one. This palace is the most wonderful place in Istanbul I'll visit it every time I'll be in Istanbul , full of gold , full of history , an amazing and wonderful palace
G-R-A-N-D!!!. We had a very nice visit to this palace. The highlights for us were the chandeliers made of Baccarat crystals... biggest one being 4.5 tons!!

Gorgeous. I looooved all the palaces we visited during our trip, but Dolmabahce was amazing. Unfortunately, you can't take pictures or videos on the inside of the palace (that applies to all of the palaces), but there were people secretly taking pictures which I can understand. Obviously they are tourists so why wouldn't they want some sort of memory. The issue we had with the palace visits is that you have to go in with a group tour which means you have to wait for the tours to start. So if it's sunny outside like it was when we went you have to stand in line for about 20 minutes. Dolmabahce is closed on Monday and Thursday and is open the rest of the week from 9-4. The fee to go in is 30 TL/ $10 for the official/administrative part of the palace and 20 TL/just under $7 for the private chambers. You can buy a combined ticket for 40 TL wich is about $13.3.

Stunning. This palace is an amazing place to visit as it represents the European influence of the Renaissance. Stunning chandeliers and Irish crystal banisters and Limoges fire places and bigger than Versailles all set on the edge of the Bosporous.

Gorgeous inside! . This palace is truly beautiful once you find your way in. There are no signs, and you are not even sure where you are going, so staffing is poor. They don't explain well to you what areas are available to visits don't give you options on what to buy, and there are no maps! So, here you are... keep Looking and ask -ing when you get in. They sadly don't know how to manage the visitors, so their Khailfe or Soltans must be looking at them with a bit of disappointment!

best spot to picture this palace is from the boat cruising Bosphorus strait. I was so lucky as I stayed in Ritz-Carlton, so it's just 5 minutes walk down the road to visit this palace. the palace is so beautiful but for me if you want to take picture of it, the best angle would be from the boat cruising the Bosphorus strait. there are many tour operators offering the boat trip nearby the palace. take the boat tour and snap a picture of this palace as you go cruising.
