" Amazing Palace and beautiful gardens ". This palace has an importance in Turkey history. You will like the amazing art work, chandeliers and teh belongings of the Sultans. The Palace garden are beautiful and a must visit Palace in Istanbul.

Amazing Palace. This was one of my favorite palaces I've ever toured. It was right on the water and had a nice breeze. There was beautiful landscaping, and even peacocks in one section. It's right on the water, so they could easily travel by boat! There was a painting museum in the palace that we toured. It was fine. Then we went into the Palace Haram, which was the living quarters. So many people lived in the palace! There were 9 apartments: 1 for the Sultan, 1 for the Sultan’s mother (she had the best place with the best balcony looking over the Bosphorous, then the Sultan’s wives. It didn’t like bad to live there!

Luxurious . It was just a amazing tour of 45 minutes, make sure to buy 40 TL ticket so you can see all and can avail the trip inside the palace, (they don't allow you to take pics as its still used for government meetings) the English tour guide was a lovely lady with scarf gave us great information about palace trust me if you like amazing art work and chandeliers this is your place to visit, so beautiful belongings and apartments of Sultan so much informative inside out so many interesting areas keep it on top of your list also
Grand!. The rulers of Turkey have poured their wealth into building of this palace. One is awed by its opulence. a must visit preferably in mornings.
Magical place. You can't visit Istanbul without passing by Dolmabahce Palace. It's an amazing palace that will introduce the history of Turkey.

Tried to be Fancy. First of all this palace is not well administered by the staff. From the entrance into the palace the foreign visitors were left out in the waiting area without helpful guidance. Finally when the English guide came to lead us through the palace his English was less than desirable, and we could barely make out his explanations. The palace definitely has its share of importance in terms of history and the opulence of its rulers. The palace gardens were nice and we took many good photos. If possible visit Topkapi Palace first before visiting this site.

Gaudy, well maintained. No photos allowed.. I felt the collection of paintings was not nearly as nice as other collections we have seen recently. The clock collection was also not as good as Topkapi Palace collection.The main building and harem were interesting in their opulence. It was nice to see that the overthrow of the Sultan by the modern country of Turkey (under Ataturk) preserved history rather than destroying it.As an avid photographer and blogger, it is always disappointing to see large collections with large entry fees prohibit photography, mostly so they can sell their own books...

Its woow. If you are interested to see the sultans how they used to live, and all the old fancy furniture... The ticket for each is 40TK and it gave u accesses to the two palaces the one which the sultans used to welcome their ambassadors and the presidents from the other countries and the one which was private and just for his wives and mothers...
It should be Top One!. Must visit as Istanbul's Top Attraction. We went there on our last day in Istanbul and it was heavily raining but was worth it. Amazing. Buy the full tour it is worth it

Breath taking!. If u are into historical places just like me, u need to see this place. It's great... very big and inspiring! You can feel the history in the palace..u can imagine the kings, greatness and the power!

Worth the money. You are not allowed to walk alone around the palace, however, the tour is short and gives you interesting fun facts rather than long detailed history. The art museum is not too long and has some great paintings. The only thing I would suggest that could be skipped is the Harem since its only apartments of previous residents.

Huge !. The palace is covered as the facade is being restored You have to go on ( badly ) guided tours but good to see the opulence and clash of eastern and western styles There is the harem The art gallery was interesting And the gardens on thr waterfront are lovely

Wow!. Truly palacial! This palace can be viewed only through guided tours. There are 2 if them... one for the selamlik, the other for the harem. Though the harem sounds more exotic, i personally enjoyed the former better. It's more 'grand' ! The other one gets a bit boring...seeing bedroom after bedroom. If you want, you could do both tours in the same visit. Tours are held in both Turkish and English. The grounds of the palace too are lovely
Amazing. Amazing! We attended here as part of a boat tour and is highly recommended.Inside is amazing and tour guides very formative

Nothing special. One of the "must to be visited" sightseeings, but haven't impressed me much. Everything is huge, location is nice. Palace itself contains only chairs and lambs, everywhere. The art gallery was nice though with some interesting paintings

Another must see!. This Palace is on the Asian side so you must cross over the Bosphorus to get there. We took a tour which included the Palace and a Bosphorus cruise; money well spent. While you don't get to see the entire palace you do get a feel for the vastness of it. It is well maintained, the grounds were lovely and we had some time at the end of the tour to walk around on our own. It is located right on the water so the views of Istanbul were impressive from here. It does require walking and I don't remember it being wheelchair friendly.

Unbelievable. This palace could be the most beautiful place you go to in istanbul. The architecture is very different than traditional monuments in old istanbul (topkapi for example). The last room is really overwelming, drawing on the walls and colors with furniture and antiquities all combine to give a unique view. A must visit in my opinion

Impressive. The palace is great inside and I absolutely recommend to anybody interested to see fantastic interiors. It is right that the tours could take longer to give visitors more time to appreciate all the beauty . Staff was OK, no reason to complaint and
the cost of ticket is just reasonable for such a beauty.

LUXURY. Most luxurious place I saw in Istanbul. I mean those Sultans must have loved slavery because this thing is just so beautiful and huge. And the views are just.. DOWN SIDE: you can not take any pictures inside of the palace not even without flash..
The artwork inside is just.. No words
A must see. We have visited the Dolmabahce Palace on a couple of occasions and it is well worth the visit. Fascinating.

Royalty at its finest. Dolmabahce Palace exudes luxury, royalty and finery.Thee most beautiful palace I have laid my eyes on. You first step foot into a stunning garden and think could it get better than this? But wait until you go inside.Go for the early guided tour of the palace (I think it was at 10 or 11am). It's shocking how comfortably and expensively people lived back in the day. Feast your eyes on humongous chandeliers, velvet carpets, golden threaded everything and, well, just plain beauty.Don't forget to pose for a picture outside! I was hell bent on moving into the palace after my tour. Love love love!

Royal excess.. If the Sultans had paid more importance on the health anid education of their subject as the Hapsburg did in neighboring Austria, Turkey wouldn't have been the sick man at Europe's door. The opulence has a redeeming feature as a tourist money-maker.

Amazing!. Didn't think this place would be that cool but it turned out to be an amazing palace! the Haram is by far the coolest part of the whole thing because its still exactly as it was, and hasn't been touched. They let you walk all about it. Recommend all the way! there is also a great restaurant for lunch or breakfast

Fantastic Palace. We spend half a day in this beautiful garden, palaces and museum.Inside the palaces photography is forbidden.It's about 500 meter from Kabatash Station.For a good visit inside the palace it's better to go with small group and a tour leader.
Spectacular . This palace is incredible with beautiful gardens, views and decoration. It is really easy transport you to the past!!!
Grand. Beautiful a must visit. A good walk in the gardens , make sure you grab a book and read about it before visiting...you will imagine and see it alive and will become far more memorable.,

Dolmabahce Palace should be on your list of places to visit. Located outside the Sultanahmet district, the palace is on the Bhosphorous Strait. The views of the Strait are excellent.The palace has tried to retain the original furniture and furnishings, and has largely succeeded.‎ The furniture and furnishings have been kept in their original rooms or, if not possible, in an appropriate room.You're not allowed to go round yourself but are given a guided tour. There are two tickets to purchase: one for the state palace used for state visits; an optional one for the harem used as the personal living quarters.I would suggest going on both tours. Both tours are brief (only about 30 - 40 mins) but very informative. You definitely get sense of the history of the palace in an enjoyable manner.‎You will be required to put on plastic slips on your footwear to protect the flooring. I used the Hop On Hop Off bus to get to the palace.

What a huge amazing place. I can't tell you how much you will be amazed by this huge loaded with gold palace. The structure, the architecture; the drawings, paintings, furniture.. everything is simply unique and breath taking. If you are in Istanbul YOU SHOULD GO THERE NOW. OMG.

The Dolmabahçe Palace. Dolmabahçe Palace was built in the 1840s and 1850s for Sultan Abdül Mecid I, who tired of residing in Topkapi Palace and decided to move to another palace on the shores of the Bosphorus. Dolmabahçe, being constructed in the 19th century after the heyday of the Ottoman state and its architecture, is much more clearly influenced by European styles than its predecessors. It is largely in the Baroque style, and is as much defined by right angles and rational, even divisions as the earlier Ottoman structures are characterized by curves and extravagances. The Palace does still incorporate aspects of traditional Ottoman architecture, but these influences are much more prevalent in the organization of the house and the manner in which it still accommodated a traditional Turkish, rather than Western, lifestyle. It was furnished with Western chandeliers and furniture, but still had a rich collection of Turkish rugs. The Palace was used by the royal family as its official residence until the proclamation of the Republic in 1923, when it became the Presidential Summer Palace and a residence for Turkey’s first President, Kemal Atatürk. It was here that he died in 1923. It is now a museum that is open to the public.

Worth the visit for the chandelier alone!. Home of the final sultans of the Ottoman empire, as well as Attaturk, this lavish European style palace can be visited with guided tours of A) the public/state rooms and B) the private/harem rooms. We opted to see just the state rooms. They offer short guided tours in various languages. As we lined up there were two tours about to begin, one in English and one in Turkish. The tour was quick moving and lasted about a half hour. Don't miss (not that you could) the massive 4.5 ton chandelier in the huge ballroom. The palace sits right on the shores of the Bosporus and has beautiful grounds, as well as separate clock and crystal museums (included in the price of admission. It is a very short distance from the embarkation point for some of the Bosporus cruises. Before we visited the palace, we enjoyed a 90 minute cruise that goes up the Bosporus to the second bridge and return. It made for a nice day's outing.

Luxury at it's best. It was something you have to see and be inside to feel the opulent way of life that they enjoyed in those days. Right on the Bosphorus water side makes it the best located palace in Istanbul. It is worth a visit, alone or guided, as it it nos that big and very walkable.

A palace still in original shape. Sultan before moving to Topkapi palace lived here & the palace has been preserved in original shape. Going through it you can live through history. The Grand hall with its chandelier gives a special feeling as does the paintings of the ceilings & organisation of the palace.
A Turkish Versailles.. Usually long lines for tours. Go early and be one of first tours in your language. After tour you will understand why Ottoman Empire collapsed. Breathtaking extravagance.

Spellbinding Architecture. One word to define it: Awesome! The outdoors are serene and beautiful, the inside is magnificent. talk of grandeur, opulence, style and comfort.... you can see it all. Made of wood from the inside, everything is symmetrical in this palace with many of the decorations in pairs! You see it and marvel at the lifestyle of the Sultans. The room of Kemal Ataturk is very well preserved. Must see!

Excellent palace. It is not in the old city, but you can get there by tram too. Just not a very "historical" attraction, it was built in the 19.th century. But the richness what you see there, can give you a little insight what acrually the Ottoman empire was.
Impressive. Good view, beautiful territory. Make sure that you visit not only the palace but also exhibition (last building), you will find Aivazovskiy and many other beautiful and amazing art works.

Must visit this palace.. Better than any other palace in Europe. Sorry, can't take pictures.
Guided tour only, make sure you join English language group.
Not covered by the museum pass, separate ticket is needed.

Fantastic. A wondeful peek into a past era in Istanbul. The palace is well maintained and preserved through the condition of guided tours and protective covers for shoes. The final room of the visit is spectacular. Fantastic tour guides are in both Turkish and English.

Dont miss out! Rich extravaganza on display.. This is a must visit for people who visit European side of Istanbul. Firstly the architecture is so european - The tower itself resembles Big Ben of London. The gates and the pillars resemble french and greek type architecture. Once you enter the place, immerse yourself in super-rich artistic beauty, infrastructure of the palace. Do take a guided tour and see how Sultan lived his life and harem section. This palace is also a must visit for architecture buffs who would be interested to know how lighting was taken care of in the palace when there was no electricity. Adequate mirrors to reflect sunlight to other rooms and so on. Since it is located on sea-side, amazing photo opportunities. Lastly they also explain how Ataturk stayed in the palace after Ottoman Empire. PLease give yourself atleast 2 hours to visit this palace.

Amazing beautiful scenery. The opulence of the palace was amazing but the grounds were spectacular. We were not allowed to take pictures inside the palace but the views of the Bosporus outside of the palace made up for it!
The best !. Its a must see palace , one of the best attractions in turkey .Its really very rich palace . your need an hour of your time to finish it as there are a lot of things to see .

Dolmabahce Palace, must see in Istanbul. Second to Palace of Versailles, this is most beautiful Palace in the Muslim world. Most impressive work of art, beautiful Chandelier, hand made carpets, gold leaf ceilings, would not miss this attraction. Only peeve is separate entrance fees to see Haream.
amazing. it is very nice palace the tour they organize is well organized and the guide is informative try to explain in more than one language they palace itself is awesome

Wonderful visit.. Large compound around the palace. 40TL for both official visit and the harem. 30TL for official visit of the palace. The inside of the palace is majestically beautiful. Listen to the tour that could last up to 30 minutes each session. It has English and Turkish language tour. Strollers are not allowed during the tour. So we had to carry our lil daughter while on the tour.

Visit on our own . Straightforward to get to by tram and a 10 min walk as suggested by the website. The chandeliers and crystal light stands alone are worth the price of admission. Guided tour is quick but mandatory if you are not in a group. The harem section must be seen also. Crystal building not worth the time.

Beautiful. We visited after the TOPKAPI Palace. Its the newer palace , European influenced. Super impressive. Visits are guided , so you just have to buy your ticket and wait for the next group. Guide was very good and we enjoyed her explanations. We did this on a rainy winter day.
Dolmabahce Palace Reiview. This is a not-to-be-missed palace. We spent six hours here. It gives great insight as to the opulence and lifestyle that the sultans and their families had.

See How the Sultan Lived. This is a great place to begin your visit of Istanbul. This guided tour gave such insight into the workings of the daily live of the Palace, the Sultan and his wives. I would recommend becoming familiar with the Topkapi Palace Museum Guide before visiting the palace.
Fascinating review of late ottoman period. Gave insight into the late Ottoman period and transition to Attaturk. Guided tours are knowledgeable although be prepared to wait. No photos allowed

Beautiful. We took the English tour and had a wonderful time. Single tourists are not allowed. You must join a group. The guide was very informative. The palace was just beautiful. Exquisite glass chandeliers, furniture and opulent furnishings. The grounds are worth touring about. Be sure to walk over and view all he birds. The harem was subdued by comparison, like a female bird. It as interesting viewing the apartments. Perhaps do this first and palace second.

Unbelievable! The most glorious rooms which get bigger and grander as you go to the different floors. Check out the fabu. I would not have missed this! The size of the building was awesome. Getting there and back on the tram was another highlight. Great fun!

Best Part of Our Trip! . My favorite part of the three days we spent in Istanbul. We were not planning to visit here, but after taking the Big bus Tour we decided to get off at this stop. It was well worth the trip! Amazing palace with lots of history and beautiful decor. You are taken in a tour group, which was nice and informative. You can't take pictures with is devastating!
Amazing. Truly an amazing place. Beautiful gardens, amazing indoor areas. I visited the Palace as one of my stops from the ferry A must in Istanbul!
Beautiful . Beautiful palace and garden.To bad it is forbidden to take photos inside the palace. All tours are guided and about hour long. Really worth half-day visit

Just Amazing. Don't miss this palace. It is magnificent. While its gardens aren't as impressive as Versailles or Peterhof Palace, this huge structure contains amazing rooms and treasures. Take the Bosporus Ferry and make this one of your stops. It's amazing.
Masterpiece.. I didn't have to wait too long in a line. This place is a true masterpiece od architecture. I liked this place so much, I decited to go there twice! Definetely worth seeing.
architectural designs. im still in awe remembering how people from the past produced their crafts (carpets, embroideries, wood carvings etc) all can be seen in this beautiful palace
A beauty with the view of bosphorous.... Its a must visit place for any kind of traveller who is going to travel istanbul. The scenic view of bosphorous is splendid in a word.

My first royal palace. This was my first royal palace which I visited and it stayed the more beautiful one that I have ever seen. Even compared to the palaces of Versailles and Madrid I don't find it less beautiful. Only its localization speaks of the uniqueness that it has!

Amazing Palace. I won't write a lot about this Palace, just want to say that if i go again to istanbul I'll definitely try to find time to visit it again.
PS: it need time, so it's not recommended for the ones who don't like historical locations
Too expensive. I saw in the net some of the content but in the end the entrance was too expensive just to see the palace, you can see the outside only...

Beautiful...maybe not handicapped accessible . Beautiful, staff very helpful, just a lot of stairs that are difficult to avoid in the one building I visited. There may have been lifts I wasn't aware of. Don't let it stop you from seeing what you can.

Witness of transforming the Ottoman Empire in modern country. After visiting Topkapi, where you could see the Middle-Ages of the Ottomans, it is a good idea to follow the historical journey into the modern times of this Empire. Inspired and partly made by Western artists and craftsmen it still preserves the oriental flavour. Luxurious saloons, amazing chandeliers, and many fine pieces of art and craft. A bit off the most popular tourist paths but worth a short tram ride or a bit longer walk.

Feeling ATATURK. Knowing that ATATURK has died in there, it is a very sad place, but at the same time being present at the very place he used to walk around and breath...I feel fortunate.He is the main point in modern Turkey, comparing to Washington, Charles de Gaulle, or so on. That is something. Also, the building and decors are amazing too. Very nice view of Bosphorus. Enjoyable palace.

A beautiful summer palace.... This palace was built on the water's edge in the mid-nineteenth century on the important and beautiful shores of the Bosphorus. The Sultan and his family lived here and Mustafa Kemal Ataturk (the founder of today's Turkisk Republic) ended his days here. The royal family abandoned Topkapi Palace to move to this relatively European home, but it was still huge and magnificent, and, even now, you can see the Russian bearskin rugs, the enormous crystal chandeliers, the English clocks and the grandiose marble staircases.

Real palace . Remarkable palace full of antiques, you must visit it but try to avoid the crowds by buying your ticket online if any, the palace is very huge, unfortunately, no one can take a pics inside it.

Palace with beautifull interior and atmosphere. This palace is very well preserved. Together with its original and beautifull interior it makes a great visit.You can only visit the palace interbnally via guided tours in either english or turkishIt consists of two parts: the palace itself and the harem. The palace is the most beautifull. The guide at the english tour however gives limited and poor information. And the guards try to prevent you from making photo's (although most people do it secretly!)The harem however gives you the most intriging view on the life of the sultan and his woman. The guide here also gives good stories and explanations
Really big and beautiful Pallace. Plan 3-4 hours to spend there. There are a lot of thing to see, and also big garden to walk around. There is also a place to have rest and cofee

Must see. This palace has beautiful gardens, a furnished palace with the largest crystal chandelier in the world, and timed guided tours throughout both the official and harem buildings, right on the Bosphorus.

Get lost in history and opulance. This was one of the highlights of my trip to Istanbul. It's a guided tour which is great because the guide was very informative but I prefer to be left alone to wander.
I have never seen such beauty!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. This Palace is full of beauty and wealth! It was so rich and beautiful that you feel one visit is not enough to perceive the majesty. I love this place <3
Worth seeing. There are rooms in the palace which are stunning. Worth seeing while in Istanbul. You have to join a tour from what I remember.
Interesting palace of Sultans and Attaturk. Very nice palace with a lot of history. We have a hard time envisioning Harem life, but it's interesting to learn about it.

OMG . OMG, what a amazing place to visit. Must must visit this place. We were amazed to see this place. State of the art facility.Decriptiom given by the guide was very informative. We missed the bedrooms of Sultan.

Best palace in Istanbul. It is a it out of the old town across the river, but the tram goes there. Get a ticket for the Palace and Harem as the interiors of both are fantastic. As it is on the river it is nice to walk around the outside as well. A must do in summary

Charming Palace.... Dolmabahce Palace built in 19 th century is one of the most glamorous palaces in the world. It was the administrative center of the late Ottoman Empire with the last of Ottoman Sultans was residing there. Dolmabahce palace has 285 rooms, 44 halls, 68 toilets and 6 Turkish baths, 14 tons of gold were used to decorate ceilings in gold leaves. the crystal chandelier sent by Queen Victoria of England as a gift to the palace is the largest chandelier in the world with its 750 bulbs and weights 4.5 tons.

Dolamabachce Palace..Very good place to visit Istanbul..!!. This palace shows the wealth of previous Ottoman empire.
The chandeliers were mindblowing.
Golden tables, chairs and crockery were beautiful.
All were surprisingly symmetrical.
One of must do in Istanbul

Good Place to visit. Nice place to visit. you can see the place where the old ottoman empire families were living, how their life was, and the place where Ataturk died. The bad thing is that there are no photos allowed inside the buildings of the palace.

Mindblowing Opulence. The palace really brings to life the wealth of the Ottoman empire. The chandeliers are incredible (one has 660 lights), the tables, chairs, vases and crockery are beautiful even the heaters are decorated. The palace is huge and the surrounding gardens are well maintained - the position is also pretty special. You are only allowed to take your memories from the interior though because photos are banned and remember flat shoes because you do have to wear plastic overshoes to protect the flooring.

A look into the grandeur of the sultans. A breathtaking walk into the grandeur of the past and a real taste of the way the sultans lived. Worth the visit but plan to spend half a day just going through the grand palace and grounds.

Luxurious palace and beautiful park !. This palace was built to replace Topkapi palace. The sultans used to live here this is why this place is full of luxurious furniture, carpets, chandeliers and gold antiques. The place has an Europian style (similar to Versailles Palace - France). The parks are amazing, we visited during tulip festival so the park was multi colored and tulips of all colors are there ! no photos or videos are allowed inside. You will have to wait for the "English tour" where you will join around 25 more persons with an assigned guide. The Harem section is nice also. Dolmabahce is a must seen attraction.
Beautiful park. we visited during the tulip festival.... free to all. There is also a lovely terrace restaurant serving a varied menu and reasonably priced

One more great place to visit!. Give yourself ~3 h to visit Dolmabahce Palace. I suggest you buy full ticket, so you can see it all, the ticket price 40 TL. Best time to come during week. No photos are allowed inside.

Great Sight, Bad Management!. I've visted Dolmabahce Palace on a high season (august) where you would assume they would amend their working hours/ tour hours to be tourist friendly. However, it was completely the opposite.. there was no sign nor timetable to show the different tour visits (they have Turkish sessions, school sessions and international ''English'' sessions) we literally had to wait for 2 hours in the smearing sun without any notice not to forget the rude replies from the sight staff when approached.
A highlight. This just has to be visited. The crystal chandeliers alone are stunning, beautiful carpets, furniture, it's an amazing place.

Touring Istanbul. A very interesting palace with very unique rooms and history. Ataturk died here and therefore it is a very important place for the Turks. In addition, it is the meeting place for state gatherings and official events. And it is beautifully restored. Well worth going out of the way to tour.

European Palace. This palace replaced the Topkapi Place and is built with styles and architecture from all over Europe. Be sure to arrive early and tours are offered in various languages, so be looking at the schedule for English, Turkish, etc. No photos are allowed inside but the palace grounds are tremendous and the inside is unbelievably beautiful.
Another palace. Interesting and the tour guides were multilingual but it was a little rushed. No photos(though that stopped few)

Dolmabache palace . Absolutely amazing palace to visit. We chose to just visit the sultan's palace which also included the harem. We were pleased that we had not chosen to see everything on the grounds as we wanted to see the harem and palace which exceeded expectations. We did not think we missed out by not buying the more expensive tickets. From sultanahmet if you like to walk head over the galatea bridge. We followed signs towards the university and it wasn't far from there . It is a good hour walk. Otherwise take the tram from sultanahmet to kabata for 4turkish lira (for a jeton or token)
Istanbul holiday. This is palace worth visiting . seeing is believing, full of worldly riches gives an insight to the living of the Kings.
must see place in istanbul. lots of rooms decoreted with marble, gold, silver and precious stones. biggest hall of europe. I highly suggest you to visit...

This is The Most Amazing Palace I have Seen in 65 Countries!. Oh my goodness, I loved this Palace. It will take you 3 hours to appreciate the Palace and Grounds. Your eyes are in for a feast of beauty and elegance that is unimaginable. The level of wealth of Sultan must have been unlimited. Wow!

Long tours. Unable to see on own.. So you have to take the official tour to view the palace and then a separate tour for the Harem. The official palace is a magnificent building. The Harem is certainly not worth paying it though - the tour is long and extremely repetitive. The apartments look very similar.

Palace, museum, art gallery - all in one. Allow at least 4 hours to see it all. We were most impressed by clock museum, variety of chandeliers, quality of paintings, cleanliness throughout, well cared for artifacts, grounds and security.

Spring Break Istanbul 2016. The palace is immaculate and over the top. It has some of the largest chandeliers in Europe. You are forbidden to take any pictures. There are two types of tours, one for the regular palace and the other is for the Harem, I recommend taking both. If you plan on getting there early, do not arrive before 9am, because the first English tour starts at 9am even thought the doors open at 8:30. You can't look around by yourself, you have to stick to a group which they will assign. I highly recommend visiting the Topkapi palace prior to the Dolmabache Palace. You can also check out the Aviary and a small clock museum on the way to the harem in the complex.

Our visit to Dolmabahce Palace. Of all the sites we saw in Istanbul, although not the most historical by any means, this Palace was truly amazing. The chandeliers alone are worth looking at as they are over 10 feet wide and 20 feet high and made out of Bacarat Crystal. To see how the Ottoman Sultan's lived in the late 1800's and early 1900's was an eye opening experience.

If you're European, you've seen it all already. There is very little of the Islamic feel or art inside. For this palace, the Sultans copied the European classic style, so nothing new for those who visited any old European capital. It is all Baroc and Rococo there, nothing spectacular in the Harem side either, and all feels old and dusty. The grand hall is indeed spectacular, but all in all you don't get a feeling of how those people lived, there are not many personal items there except the furniture. Too expensive for what it is.

Worth every penny. The palace and the ground looking over the Bosphorus is lovely. Go early and do both yours tours the Harem and crystal staircase is stunning. They don't let you take photos which is a shame but I can understand, would recommend doing this.

From the Boat is amazing. Just by taking a look at it from the Ferry youll see the beautiful construction and luxury the dolmabahce offered long time ago, its far away from all other things to do in istanbul, but still if you are interested in turkish old constructions, a place to see.

True grandeur. The Dolmabahçe palace is a perfect example of the state of the Ottoman Empire in the mid 19th century. You would think that this grandeur is a display of the wealth of the empire but no. It is what is called a mirror-move. The empire is falling apart and to conceal this, the Dolmabahçe palace was built. The reason that the sultan of this time, Abdülmecid I, built this palace was because the Topkapi palace (also worth visiting) was no longer suited for modern, 19th century government. Besides, the sultans were living at Topkapi for the last 400 years.Take a good look at the three chandeliers in the palace and also at the detail on the walls. It is absolutely marvelous. The ballroom was to me the most astonishing thing the visited, unfortunately you are not allowed to take pictures. Prices for adults are about 30 lira, or € 10. It is totally worth it I tell you. Be sure to get a tour, which I think you are obliged to do. Note: your museum card is not valid here.
Just like many other palaces. This tour was crowded by tourist and very strict. There were multiple people in our group attempting to take pictures and were scolded by security.

Astonishing and beautiful roses. It located right on the European coastline of the Bosphorus strait and it displays the richness and abundance! Perfect for people of all ages! It's not only famous in Istanbul, furthermore it is one of the most glamorous palaces in the world.

Its okay. Overall I preferred the outside grounds of the palace to the inside. Nothing really stood out to me about the palace (maybe a couple of the chandeliers and the Grand Hall). Also no photos were allowed.

The grand Palace which made the country bankcrupt. DOLMABAHCE PALACE (SARAYI) Ticket 40 TL .Opening time: 9.00 am to 4.00 pm. Closed Mondays and Thursdays. Photography not permitted. Visitors are shown the palace in groups. Guides are helpful but not essential. Domabahce Palace was constructed in the reign of Sultan Abdulmecid (1839-1861). The Palace has been inhabited since 1856 by six Sultans. After Turkey became republic Mustufa Kamal Ataturk stayed in this Palace for 4 years. The Hereke carpets, the Baccaret and Bohemia crystals, the severs and yildiz porcelain gilts, gifts by various leaders and paintings by western artists are quite imposing.It is a site highly recommended and not to be missed.

I wish I could have taken photos. An astonishing 19th century palace right on the Bosphorus and a perfect contrast with the Topkapi in the old town. Make sure you get there early to avoid the crowds and make sure you do both tours as the harem has some stunning rooms are part of that as well. Highlights are the crystal staircase, the ceremonial hall, and the sultan's hamam. If I was going to have a hamam in my house, I would model it on this one!

Breathtaking. A must see in Istanbul. The place is amazing inside and out. The gardens are wonderfull and well maintained. If you want to go insede the palace you'll have to pay for a guided tour, but it's worth every penny. The guide did a great job at presenting the most important "rooms" in the palace, and he gives you enough time to look at everything, and trust me, there is a LOT to see, especially gold. There's gold everywere from the floor to the ceelings there are details of gold.
Love it. Very nice place... must visit this place.. love the environment.. good explanation about history of Dolmabahce...

Taking pictures not allowed. It was good to see the palace from inside. Unfortunately it is not allowed to take pictures inside, so I forgot a lot of what I saw. One thing I remember is the room where Atatürk died.
I preferred the Topkapi Palace to the Dolmabahce Palace. In the Topkapi Palace taking pictures is allowed.

Magnificent . There's much to see in this magnificent palace, and it gives you a great insight into the lavish lifestyles of the later Sultans. The two main parts of the palace, i.e. Selamlik and Harem, can only be visited with a tour guide. You need to put on plastic covers on your shoes and can't take any photographs. Other attractions include an art gallery, a clock museum and a pavilion. The palace grounds and the view of the Bosphorus sea are also lovely. I would recommend planning 2-3 hours to explore the whole palace.

Absolutely breathtaking. Even for men(",). One cannot visit the Dolmabahce palace alone. One has to be part af a guided tour. You get plastic covers for your shoes. No pictures allowed. It was so beautiful inside and out. It could compete with Versailles. This is a must as tourist attraction. But I absolutely do not recommend visiting Topkapi palace after Dolmabahce. I was a little dissapointed since that was exactly what I did.

Just a regular palace. Outside I interested on this place and went to visit. But I didn't find it very special inside. There are many newly repaired items and places in it. Might be more interesting for Turkish people. Do not join a local group of visitors that make your visit boring and wastefull.

A must-visit when in Istanbul. You should not miss it. Take into account the opening times. You can't walk around on your own, but guided tours (included in the ticket) start approximately every half an hour. With an ISIC student card the fee for both the palace and the Harem is just 5 liras! (regular combined ticket is 40).

A view of ancient history!. Dolmabache is a place not to be missed! This historic palace holds stories of ancient Sultans and gives an incredible peek into the traditions of Turkish history and the pomp and circumstance which surrounded this era. The beauty and magnificence of this place is not to be missed. It's a must see for every visitor to Istanbul.
Impressive palace. This palace is one of the charming palace I have ever seen. It is possible to see western European figures inside it. I loved it so much.

Impressive!. This palace might not be as old as the Topkapi or Aya Sophia, but it's no less grand and magnificent! Definitely worth going!!!! Start early to avoid the long lines. We actually had to skip the Topkapi because the lines were way long!
Love it. When your in town you should definetly visit the dolmabahce and specially see all of it specially the house of the sultan not only part of it

Great! Just make sure you catch the last tour.. It not explained at the front door, which building to visit first. When you walk in you maybe taken aback by the line in front of the place and will continue on to he other let's first. The entire compound is quite large and consist of a few museums the painting gallery, the palace, the harem, the clock museum. We went there around 2 pm and off season no one is let in after 16:30. At 17h you are kicked out. Its all good,if we were told that we need to see the palace first and that the last tour was given at 16h (4pm). So we saw everything else but didn't go inside the palace, as the harem tour ended 16:20. The 3 points are for the lack of instruction and info at he front door. We even asked the lady at the painting gallery and she told us about the garden closing time, but nothing about which tour should be taken first. The Harem guide was great, he spoke English and German prefect. I am sad not to have caught his name. Defiantly buy the ticket including everything (40tl). As I will come back to Istanbul, I didn't mind leaving one or two stops for next time.

Visit is a must. one of the most amazing museums palaces that you must visit, for sorry pictures is not allowed inside, also it's very bad that you must follow the tour guide who is working there, it is bad just because he take you in a "fast track" that you can't enjoy the place, like a school trip in some place telling you short story.at last you will like what you will see.I consider the tickets are pricey just because of the fast track and no pictures allowed.garden and view of the palace from outside is very nice, but it's for free you don't have to pay for it.

Beautiful palace. AMAZING! Well preserved palace, lot of luxury. Gives insight how Sultan lived. You can feel like you're back in time of the sultans. Gorgeous. Inside and out. View at the see is faboulous. Tour guide is also amazing. Stunning beauty that lives you speechless.

Just a palace out of the bottle. Nothing special about this palace, just a long walk round n round. The decorations and exhibits lack history. Stuff like sofa and carpet are modern, yet the rest of the furniture and paintings are claimed to be from the old days. It is just about your casual stroll in the park. Choose it on one of your easy days.

Beautiful . This place is amazing and beautiful. I had never been inside a palace before and this did not let me down. Beautiful chandeliers hang in almost every room. I think it's definitely worth going to. remember though no pictures of the inside at least that's what they tell you. You may get away with taking pictures on your phone but no flash and no big cameras.

Very Colourful!. I'll say this Palace is very colourful and has very beautiful interiors. I have been to the Palace of Versailles in France and I couldn't stop myself from comparing the two of them. These two Palaces are very similar yet different. The Islamic Calligraphy and paintings were very prominent in this Palace which we loved! Each hall and room were differently decorated and were very beautiful.

Must Go. Since the tour was completely guided, so it was great.Specially the view from Dolmabahce is very nice. Here you see the glory of Ottomans and simplicity of Ataturk Mustafa Kamal in a same place. Appreciable Place and must go

Glad I saw It. Didn't really have any interest of this place. Mostly excited to see the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia but it's included in the tour that I booked... and WOW! Glad I saw it. It is such an amazing place. Gold from floor to ceiling. It's wonderful!To bad no photos allowed. Our guide said you can't go there without a guide. Don't know how much that is true. Anyway, just for some information.
Quite the place!. It's a little over the top. Hard to imagine someone actually living there. It is by guided tour only with no photos allowed.

Enchanting!. You are required to wear plastic sheaths to cover your shoes upon entering the Dolmabahce Palace. You go in groups of around 20 - 25 on a fixed route within the Palace. A guide accompanies the group and explains the significance of certain rooms or fixtures in English (guides proficient in other languages are also available, I believe). Highlights include the crystal chandeliers and crystal staircase, the spectacularly huge Turkish carpets and the stunning view of the Bosphorus. No photography is allowed inside the Palace, unfortunately.

i loved this palace. ticket price is bit high in my opinion, but i liked it. spl for its cool location and the history. it has some nice coffee shop inside it and u can have a cup of tea and enjoy the cool breeze from the sea.
Beautiful palace . Amazing palace with incredible history. Largest chandeliers in Europe. Shame about the rude English speaking tour guide who rushed us too much.
Palace. it was very average, it looks a little bit like a western european palace but is pretty average compared to them, worth it to see but a little bit disappointing

Impressive . This has to be the most beautiful and impressive palace I have visited. If you are interested in architecture and history you should definitely visit the Dolmabahce Palace. We had a group tour with a guide where you were able to hear a lot of historical background information. It was very interesting and the inside of the palace as well as the Harem is absolutely breathtaking. The gardens, fountains and the view outside of the palace are amazing as well!

Beautiful palace. The palace is beautiful, the mandatory tours are useful and help make sure that you don't miss anything. On a sunny day, the view and the park are lovely. Expect to queue for 10minutes minimum

Most important palace. This is the one of the place that you can feel the change of Turkish culture from Ottoman empire to new republic. Here is the right place to observe both of them at the same time. A must see!

Incredible. This structure is beautiful as is the location around it. It is simply breathtaking and full of history. I could have stayed here forever just taking in the amazing work, there isn't an inch of the palace that isn't detailed. Take your time here, it isn't huge but you will want to see everything!

Most beautiful palace of Istanbul. For 14 Lira (€13) you get an entrance in this beautiful palace and its harem. You are not allowed to walk through it by yourself but you get an English tour which lasts about an hour. The palace itself has an European style and is beautiful! A lot of gold, big rooms and especially the last room was huge and impressive. Also interesting to see that the clocks inside are all at 09:05, the hour that Ataturk, who lived here, died in the palace. The harem was an half an hour tour but was less interesting. It's a pity that you are not allowed to take pictures inside. Still you can make some nice pictures on the outside. There is also a view of the big river, a small clock museum and a clock tower. Recommendable and I liked it much more than the Topkapi palace.

Palace. We walked to the palace from the Sultanahmet district where our hotel was. The walk was interesting and not too far. Once we arrived the reason for walking was apparent as the palace is wonderful. The time and effort sent on it was amazing and this is a must see sight of Istanbul. Particularly impressive was the huge room used for state banquets. There is also a very reasonable cafe by the clock tower with great views over the Bosphorus.

palace. Its propably one of the most beautiful palaces i have ever seen,and thats because of the position and the architecture.its a mix of the ottomans and the west civilisation,its a lovely palace,with beautiful gardens,fontains,statues,and theview over the gulf,is amazing

Magnificent. It was the second time i visited the palace and i must admit that it cut my breath like the first time. Enormous and luxurious, reflects the magnificence of a big empire. I read some bad reviews before my second visit and i have to say the following: a)considering the size and the maintainance costs of this monument, the ticket of 12 euros is more than decent., b) a palace is a palace. If we expect to see something different, this cannot caracterize a monument as a tourist trap, c) the organisation of the staff is very good. But the visitors are so many that it is impossible not to wait until you enter. Happened exactly the same to me in Taj Mahal and Empire State Building. For me, this palace is one of Istanbul jewels and worths it to visit it!

Fantastic view. This Palace is a must watch situated near Boshphorous. This is the one made lately by the last Turkish Emperor. The entry is chargeable but worth it. It is a guided tour for an hour almost. You are not allowed to click pictures inside. A beautiful decor. A real snapshot of how luxurious life was lead by the Emperors . Extremely good for photography from outside

Gold and crystal. For the passionate of gold and crystal is the appropriate palace to get lost. At least 4 hours are needed to see it and take pictures outside the palace, crystal museum and clock tower.

Guided tour. It was not our first choice among all the attractions in Istanbul, but at the end of our stay we had some time to spent and decided to go to Dolmabahce palace, since it was close to our hotel.We were very positively surprised, because this is one of the best attractions in Istanbul. For 40 TL (aprox. 12 EUR / 14 USD) you get 2 separate english guided tours of the palace and the harem (together 1.5h). In addition you get entrance to a clock museum and you can walk through a beautiful garden.The palace is beautiful and the guides are very informative and willing to answer al your questions.Highly recommended!

Beautiful place with ugly attitude from the staff.. I went with my wife to see this historical palace. We paid for both part the salamlik and haramlik. When we reached the main gate I was really annoyed by the attitude of the staff. They arrange visitors in groups. We were in the English speaking herd!. We were rushed to catch up with the rest. More than 50 visitors following the guide. Very low voice and faraway from you. You could never hear any information.the lady in the salamlik was better than the male guide in the haramlik. He will point to an area and say e.g this is the princess private room and then he will take you to the next stip. place contents was amazing. Luxury at it,s most. Huge beautifully color coded lounges for different occasions. Crystal chandeliers from the best bohemian crystals in huge frames hanging. Damascus drapes and silk carpets in huge sizes . Outside gardens were will maintained. Souvenir shop worth visiting.

Incredible place. I love this place. One of the best places to visit in Istanbul! Very beautiful and well maintained. The garden is very beautiful as well and the view on the Bosphorus. The excursion was very interesting. Would like to go there again.

Absolutely beautiful. This is definitely one of the most beautiful palaces i have visited! Absolutely gorgeous. Unfortunately no photography is allowed in the palace. I don't think they allow individual visits, only tour groups with a guide.
Put this on your must see list . Make sure you visit this palace with a guide. This is more impressive than any palace in Europe I have seen. If those walls could talk ! A memorable experience
Grand and well kept. Grand place, well kept and clean. The tour guides are included in the price although they do tend to rush one through.

Gloriously over-the-top. This 18th century palace is at the end of a metro line with a short walk. There are two tours (in English) and your ticket entitles you to both. I was too tired to do the Harem tour but the Official section tour revealed the magnificent opulence of the palace. A mixture of Baroque, Rococo, Victorian and Turkish. Never seen so much gold and crystal. And the final room was amazing in both its size and splendour. There is also an art gallery , cafes and a wonderful promenade between palace and Bospherous. The only downside is that the tour is a bit rushed so you don't get a lot of time in each room. But this palace is not to be missed.

Stunning palace, but the tour feels a litte rushed. It's a mandatory escorted tour. It feels a bit rushed, but this place is incredible. The grounds are awesome and don't forget to visit the Harem. It's "not as fancy" which still means pretty opulent.

Breathtaking . We visited dolmabahche palace and the Harem palace over the weekend. You have to buy tickets , 40 liras per head for the official palace and Harem. You can not enter on your own as you have to have an official guide take you around the palace. You are not allowed to take pictures or touch the objects. The palace hosts one of the biggest chandeliers in the world. The Harem palace has to be accessed and toured separetely. This attraction is a must to visit.
A great experience. Don't miss Dolmabahce Palace during your visit in Istanbul. You will enjoy it very much and will experience a great time.
Fantastic place. The most sumptuous place I have ever seen. So worth looking at even though one has to join a tour group and photos not allowed inside.

Never ending Opulence... This is a full day event. Start very early, else it will end up being a rushed excursion. And yes, those lounges may look all the same but for the colour. They are, however, beautiful in own right. Ottoman Sultan must have been a very popular person, with all the lounges for his visitors... Cameras are charged for.

Top Site! . Hands down one of the most beautiful sites I visited during my trip to Istanbul, the grandeur and beauty of this palace is breathtaking. Make sure you go, it will not disappoint. To those wondering, this palace was also completely different to the Topkapi palace (also really beautiful) and I personally felt it was worth it to see both!

Woth it. Be prepared for a guided tour - there are no self guided tours inside - but good English speaking guides - they do do in other languages - absolutely NO photography inside - beautiful grounds.

What a stunning palace. It is up there with Versailles and Schonbrun. With a professional guide, you will be taken through the majestic halls of this great palace. As the tour moves on, we will learn more and more about the last days of the Ottoman Empire. The gardens outside are lovely as well.Highly recommended 9/10

I love with it. It's the second time I visit Dolmabahce Palace and I'm impressed each time I see it. The history of the Ottoman empire has always fascinated me and by visiting this palace you will learn a lot on the life style of the emperors as well as their customs and traditions. Beautiful gardens as well, Nothing compared to Schonbrunn though :)
Amazing palace . Great place to go to amazing to see the life o sultan and all the wealth must visit Many rooms to see a mazi gardens next to the vosporous.

Perhaps the last great Turkish Palace. It is pretty clear why building this palace really drained the treasury. We were told that it is decorated with two tons of gold. It is smaller than Topkapi but still massive, and an architectual gem.
Wow!!!. This was an amazing place to visit!! So much opulence and history. For us it was number 1 place to visit on our trip to Istanbul.

An amazing palace. A beautiful palace. Unlike more ancient Topkapi palace it looks modern and european (but has unique oriental features). Gates on the Bosporus shore are really amazing, especially in the fog. The Clock museum is interesting - very good collection.

Refreshing experience . Beautiful architectural structure. Amazing history. Home to the founder of the Turkish Republic, which makes you feel walking and touching a very important part of world history due your visit!
Kitch beyond belief. Entered history as the palace that ruined the Ottoman Empire. In reality the empire was already on the brink and the palace is more amazing as a monument to bad taste.
Magnificent Palace. Beautiful architecture. Very well preserved. Even more beautiful than the palaces of Versailles in France. Takes you back in time. Magnificent chandeliers!

The height of the otoman empire. A huge palace, no expense was speared building it so you get to see the insane wealth the otoman empire had at it's height. The place is basically bast in gold and silk, definitely worth a visit if you want to get a complete feel of the history of turkey.

Amazing Historic Place. This is the one of the most important places of Ottoman and Turkish history. Ataturk died in this palace so you may found the deep information about Turkish Republic establishment info here. Strongly recommended to visit.

I will go back again ♥. The ceiling paintings, the carpets, the collection of wares used by the first king, the sections of the palace (male and female), the rich history (I can't forget how our guide elaborated that the guards are castrated males). Put this as number one in your list if you visit Istanbul. You need a paid guide to enter this palace and got time limit per group. Don't touch anything as the guide (Oscar) said the building is too old. The souvenir shop sell cheaper tea set with better designs compared to those sold at The Bazaar.

Magnificent . A place that worths to see. It takes at least 1h30 to see both the palace and haram lek, you will benefit of the tour guide there , the architecture and the old design is awesome, it takes you centuries ago, quiet very clean palace , and well organised .

East meets west. Visited this palace late last year on a weekend during one of my many business trips to Istanbul.I actually enjoyed this palace more than Topkapi, but that may be due to my English perspective on life.You tour in groups with a guide ( choice of Turkish or English naration) and it takes a bit less than an hour. I think because it was winter I got the full tour for just 30TL and it wasnt crowded Even so I had to wait for about 30 minutes to join a tour.The palace was the last one built by the Ottomans and was the home of the last Sultan until the role abolished in 1922 and he was exiled. It is located by the side of the Bosphoros with views over to Asia and back towards the Old City with his previous palace in view.It is a mixture of eastern and western cultures, the Sultan clearly influenced by what was fashionable in western Europe, yet still clingimg to his traditional roots. Sometimes you feel you could be in yet another English stately home and othertimes back in the harem of Topkapi. The palace you go around, including the state or public room section and the harem is huge. Many fabulous chandeliers, pieces of furniture, art and other objects on display.The palace complex has many other buildings , some of which you can visit as well. Just walking around the outside of the buildings was extremely interesting and gives you the full feeling of how vast it is and explains how costly it was to build.If my wife accompanies me on a trip to Istanbul I will defineitely take her here.

Great escape in the past. Our tour guide was amazing and we learned a lot from him about the Otoman empire. The palace is magnificent, very beautiful , it is a history treasure. Amazing view of the Bosphoros

I nearly cried. This palace is simply BEAUTIFUL and worth a few hours of anyone's time. The crystal staircase nearly had me in tears. It's like something from a fairytale. Honestly. And the rooms are so luxurious and have real gold shimmering everywhere. Even the outside is like something from Disney. A little lake with swans and tall pillars. If you know what the Polly Pocket castle is, from the 90s- that's what this palace reminded me of. Lovely place. I would so like to go back one day.
Magnificent Palace. You need one good day to have wonderful experience of Royal living of Turkish Emperor & his family. It is quite big and worth to visit as dreamy experience of living.

loved it. this palace tour was very informative about the history of Turkey, we learned a lot. an English speaking guide will explain to you everything, you only pay the entrance fees. Do not miss it...

Most LAVISH Palace EVERY Built. Must see when in Istanbul. Tickets are pricey but you get to see how the Sultans lived. The interiors of the palace is way too lavish. Still much better than any 5 star resort or hotel.

Perfect!. I was very surprised by the view. You can go inside of the palace only with guide. You can not take pictures inside of it. Despite all these facts it is one of the best things to do in Istanbul.

Majestic grounds and palace - Guided tours compulsory. The Palace is situated adjacent to the Bospherous Strait and is easily accessible by way of the metro, tram or ferry which stops at Kabatas.Entry fees are steep and a Museum Pass is not accepted. You can either opt for the adult Selâmlık at TL30, the Harem at TL20 or a joint ticket at TL40 which gives you entry to the Palace, the Harem plus the Painting and Clock Museums. Children under 7 years may enter free of charge.The gardens are beautifully maintained and the large fountains and statues are exquisite. Access to the Palace itself is by way of a guided tour which takes place every 10 - 15 minutes in the high season and approx. every 25 minutes in the low season. On entering the Palace visitors are issued with shoe covers and are asked to stick to the carpeted areas only.The tour takes you through the Sultans Administrative apartments where the country's affairs were discussed, which is fairly plain and gloomy; the Privy Chambers better known as the Imperial Harem, which is very large and masculine and the Grand Ceremonial Hall which is sensational. It has exquisite art work on the domed ceilings and walls and a chandelier that will make your jaw drop. Apart from the main palace, there are several other buildings in the complex such as the imperial kitchens, the Crown Prince rooms, Glass Factory, Smelter, Aviary, Stable, a foundry, Clock tower etc.Once you have completed the tour, you are able to wander around the Painting and Clock Museum at your leisure. There are also several caffe's on the grounds at which to rest your feet and have a refreshment or meal.OPENING HOURS09:00 - 16:00 except Mondays and Thursdays, January 1st, and on the first day of religious holidays. TICKET OFFICEAs the daily visitor quota is limited to 3,000 people, the ticket office may close earlier than the time stated.PHOTOGRAPHY WITH CAMERA, MOBILE PHONE AND VIDEO CAMERA INDOORSNot permittedWEDDINGS AND BANQUETSThe Ceremonial Hall and gardens are available for private receptions

How you can go to the Dolmabahce Palace? How much ticket price? Something you need know about that?. * Dolmabahce Palace is so great and best view of sea.First step: how you can go to that of taksim square?1-walking: if you wanna see street while walking you can spend just 15 minutes.2-Funicular Metro (F1 on the metro map): you can take a Istanbul card (just 6 LT) and charging that, then get Funicular to kapatas destination. This means transporting has just 1 station and after receive to kapatas you have to walking just 5 minute to Dolmabahce Palace. * How much ticket price of Dolmabahce Palace: *for 1 visitor: 40 TL for SELAMLIK+HAREM*You can't take a photoraphy inside SELAMLIK and Harem*first point: if you go to inside other there first you have to take plastic cover for your shoes and then you can go inside. I try collecting useful information of this place and please attend to my photos.

One place, world history!!. The grounds are massive covering a large area. We are greeted by a tower right behind the walls which then lead to the main palace. Behind the main palace are a number of houses that hold various attractions or are used as museums for particular items (highly suggest the clock museum). Each area is majestic in its own way. However, if you truly want to feel like royalty, it is highly suggested you take a guided tour of the main palace. You will understand just how great their empire and what importance it held for trade and diplomacy.The main palace tours are timed, so I would suggest that you do that first and then roam the grounds freely, especially if it would be a sunny day.
Very beautiful palace. When in Istanbul, definitely visit this palace. It worth it. One of the best places I visited there.
Dolmabahce Palace ok ok. Dolmabahce Palace istanbul near seaside , a great architecture but with expensive tickets and no photos allowed inside

Also a must see. Istanbul has many mosques and many really many things worth seeing.
This is also one of them.
The decor and equipment are really something amazing. I mostly remember the bearskin rug which is really huge!!!
Very quaint. Located along the Bosphorous Strait, this was a real beauty. The overall appearance and overall looks were amazing

A Western Palace!. This is the ostentatious, over westernized palace built in 1856. You can see elaborate chandeliers, staircases and western decorations here. These trappings show that the later Sultans were immensely influenced by the European culture. You can also see Kamal Ataturk's study and bedroom here. The changing of the guards parade outside it very interesting.Tip: Go with a tour if you do not have prior booking as the wait is extremely long as they allow a fixed number of people inside and the tour groups are allowed to enter before the other people.

Western Style Ottoman Palace. The Palace itself is great, an example of how the last 6 Ottoman emperors lived the life. Dolbamahce is western style of palace with British/French furnitures. Tour guide accompanies tourist at all time within this building.The other reviewers who gave 1 star complained about service of tour guide or ticket office. Use museum pass, and lower your expectation, then you will enjoy this palace learning how living large could lead to the end of an empire.

Great tour.... Wandering through the vast staterooms and long corridors of the Dolmabahce Palace you get a real feel for a bygone era with glimpses of the opulence that once existed. It's hard to believe Turkey was once the 'sick man of Europe'..... The trip was slightly tarnished by a prohibition on photography.
Amazing! Breathtaking!. Dolmabache Palace is one of the glamorous palaces in the world! Recommend to take a full tour through the palace including Harem.

Amazing place, dreadful staff. Firstly the positives, this is an incredible building. The main room towards the end of the tour is stunning, others equally as good, fantastic building and as wonderful as most others I have seen around the world.Now the reality. We arrived early, it was quiet, it all went wrong when the staff at the ticket office indicated they could not be any less interested in us.You cannot wander freely around this palace, you must take a tour. Unfortunately our tour was regulated by the guides Facebook account...We walked in, were given a brief history and plan and were then walked very quickly along a long corridor of interesting looking rooms. I assumed we would be back to see them but, no, that was it. We were then forced around a few darkened rooms of uninteresting crockery before waiting for the rest of the group and again being marched off past more interest to more crockery. The guide spent the whole tour on his phone looking at his Facebook account, the content of which regulated the speed of our journey.To say I was disappointed is an understatement. The whole idea of what they are doing is obviously to get more people through the place but I'd have paid double to have been left alone and allowed to wander. Some of our group complained, they were ignored.The Harem was slightly better, different guide, same idea but not quite as bad. It is okay to take your time in the grounds thankfully but the real interest is within.It's one of these places you have to visit but if they made they effort to sort it out it would be the No 1 attraction. Right now you'll only get annoyed.

Great experience, huge palace, long queue, but worth it. Most people would miss this palace after visiting Topkapi Palace but it is so worth it. Too bad you cant take pictures inside apart from being warned if you do. It is simply breathtaking! The main reason that bankrupted the Ottoman Empire was building this palace!

Great 3 hour experience. Well worth the price to get the full access tour including 2 separate guided tours to the main palace and separate Herem tour.
No need for private guide for this attraction.

The splendor of the architecture. Splendor of Ottoman architecture and luxury. only a portion of the palace can be visited although you feel awe while watching every corner, the materials, the lights, the paintings... every single piece or place !

You just have to see it!. Beautiful inside and outside. You cant miss this attraction. If you are not going with group, dont worry, there are organized tours with English speaking guide. Make sure you come in morning (I think tour start at 10 am), its less crowded. Its not allowed to take photos inside.
impressive palace. it's strange that dolmabahce is kind of underestimated as a sightseeing spot. imho, its must-visit place

Symbol of the magnificence and decadence of the 19th-century Ottoman Empire. Huge and sumptuous, with 285 rooms, 43 large salons, a 4000 kg (4-1/2-ton) Bohemian glass chandelier, and a Bosphorus-shore façade nearly 500 meters (1/4 mile) long. It's the grandest of Ottoman imperial palaces.

Best place to see in Istanbul. It would take 2-3 hours easily to explore this place well. Every minute would be worth it. I really enjoyed seeing the beautiful palace, different rooms along with their purposes. It takes you back in time and gives you a lovely nostalgic feeling. A must see,

exhilarating ottoman kitsch. Designed for Sultan Abdul Mecit in 1856, Dolmabahce Palace is among the most extraordinary residences of Europe. Although the Ottoman Empire was already in decline at the time of its construction, no expense was spared, thanks in part to loans from Continental bankers that ultimately bankrupted the Ottoman treasury. The architect for the palace had cut his teeth designing sets for operettas in Paris: The result is a camp pastiche of a European palace. You can visit the palace only by taking one of two guided tours. One covers the men's section, staterooms and the vast ceremonial hall, and the other visits the harem section, including the living quarters of the Sultan. If you can take only one tour, visit the fabulous ceremonial hall—designed to hold 2,500 people—and note the superb decoration of the dome and the English chandelier. Also check out the main bathroom, or hamam, the walls of which are fitted with splendid Egyptian alabaster and solid silver taps. Attentive visitors will notice that all the clocks in the palace read 9:05 am at all times. This is because Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey, died in his bedroom in the palace at 9:05 am on 10 November 1938. On Tuesdays during the summer, the Turkish army band, dressed in the costumes of the famous Janissaries, performs traditional music outside the Imperial Gate.

Located at the bank of the Strait. You can see this palace on a ferry ride. It looks nice outside and represents how Turkish people viewed themselves as European. This is not as grand as other European palaces but it has a place in Turkish history.

A must-see!. While not as familiar to most foreigners (Americans) as the Topkapi Palace, Dolmabahce is a must-see on any visits to Istanbul. It is located some distance from the main historical areas, but it is right at the end stop of the tram that runs along the Bosporus, so very easy to get to. And it you are staying near the Taksim Square area, it is straight downhill (a VERY STEEP downhill!)The palace was the residence of the Sultan and his family from the mid-1800's, as well as the residence for Ataturk after the Ottomans fell. It is very European in style...largely baroque-ish. But grand in every respect. The phenomenal chandeliers and ornate decorations give a clear feel for the era. Do spring for the Full Ticket, which include the Harem (private family quarters in the back of the main palace. Just interesting to see how the family lived...not so good to be wife number 3 or 3, but Mother of the Sultan, was clearly a pretty good deal...if you didn't mind ever leaving the Palace!

Looks European doesn't it?. After visiting the Anatolian Top Kapi you can easily tell the difference of the way the last Ottoman Sultans tried to declare their turn to more western ways. The palace itself is glorious, built on Bosporus with really really great views and stunning decoration. What is funny is that all these palaces were built when the fall of the empire started and the enormous expenses that had to be made to built such a place. On the downside the rush of the guides to give you a strictly 40 minutes tour.Pictures are not allowed

Worth a visit despite crowds and no photos rule. Easy to visit, right near our hotel, some really really spectacular rooms, sort of an Ottoman 'Versailles'. Photos not allowed. So-so tour you have to take. No independent wandering

Exquisite building. This magnificent building is located on the shores of the Bosphorus and should be on every visitor's 'to do' list. The gardens are fabulous and, when you get inside the palace, you can see in the detail why it took 13 years to build. The guided tours (compulsory and included within the ticket price) are good and informative but they do tend to hurry you through a bit. It would have been nice to do the tour then go back through and wander on our own, taking in the opulence. Unfortunately no photographs are allowed inside.

Favorite venue in Istanbul. This palace is magnificent. Be prepared to put on paper booties and perhaps wait in line. The grounds are lovely, The inside is opulent beyond belief with humongous carpets and chandeliers. Do not recommend the haram add on as you will see some of the haram rooms on regular tour.
A must to see. A must to see for visitors of Istanbul.The palace of the last Ottoman sultans.Also the view of the Bosphorus from the garden is beauriful

Dolmabahce PALACE. A historic beauty that must be seen in Istanbul. It is located next to Besiktas Vodafone Arena which called as the best view stadium in the world. Tour and travel time takes about 2-3 hours. The palace was built in the 19th century for the construction, 18 tons of gold to be used, it has 200 rooms but %30 available for guests. Atatürk's room in the palace as well. Also magnificent great hall. But the most beautiful and fascinating side views of the palace. You will see the meaning of the Istanbul whenever you Dolmabahçe Palace.
Stunning Palace. This palace oversees the Bosphorous river so has an excellent venue. They give the for parties and weddings thus becomes an excellent venue

Stunning. You have quite a few ticket options, one grants you the garden only (stunning views) or a full tour for 40 Turkish Lira. The architecture is breath taking and the gardens are well maintained and just a pleasure to stroll through . You can easily get here by Tram and have a 5 minute walk to the ferry station. Your Istanbul trip would not be complete without seeing this site!
Luxurious . The last palace of Othman emperor, showing the luxury style with gold plated door handles and crystal chandeliers. Very beautiful exterior also.

Stunning place!. If you need only one reason to go I'll give you one....The Main HalI! You need another reason? The Crystal Staircase! 2 are not enough? The location and views! The ticket is not the cheapest you will find in Istanbul but you have the choice to go full for 40TRY or 20TRY will get you into the main palace only (so missing the Harem and the other museums such as the Clock Museum and the Painting Museum). The visit is guided (45mins for Main Palace + 35mins for Harem if you do both) or basically you can't go wherever you want to use better words - which is for me the only downside and why it doesn't get my full marks.

historical lover must go. historical lover must go there. There is two option to buy ticket for palace. interesting things there is group tour guide there. and you can find unique thing related to Ataturk.

Nice visit. Visiting this place is not a must but if you have time give it a try. We had a private tour so I dont know the enteance fee. You can see that even at that time their people were suffering but their emperors were spending millions to build this place influnced by european architecture. Some parts were closed so we did not see all of it
Incredible. Stunning. The main hall completely blew my mind and was worth the admission just for it alone. My only wish was that the public guided tour went for at least an hour!
Instanbul. It's a building with a interesting story. The guide was explained how and from who it's made. The palace have a great view and garden
Amazing. Take your time and look at every detail. The chandelier at the entrance is magnificent and so as the floor wood works.

Amazing. It's an amazing palace with the biggest "lustre" in the world and many rooms and bathrooms.....A palace that makes you dream.....Inside it, you can admire the furniture and the spacious luxurious rooms....The view on the Bosphorous is just gorgeous!

Just see this one. You can´t leave Istanbul without missing this one out.It s wonderful palace. Probablz the most stunning one in Turkey+ Middle East. But I heard that the pm has an office around that area. Just make sure you wallet is safe.

Interesting place, but not for small kids!. Big and beautiful old palace, but many rooms are off limits!The guide was a lovely girl who gave us a brief history, but occasionally, her accent was difficult to understand.The Sultans personal items behind glass cases are opulent and beautiful.The grounds are good for kids to run around, but not inside the palace, as kids will find the tour boring and they must stay with the group at all times.

Pre republican era of Turkey. This Palace reminds me ends of Ottoman Power. Guides explains it very good. Crystal stairs, king size red carpets, prince and princess's woeful rooms all things in the palace are cold and tells you only about sad stories. By comparison The Topkapi Palace is more authentic and warm than Dolmabahce Palace
Ashtonnishing. Learning about the Caliphate and the history behind this wonderful construction will keep you coming back to Istanbul.
Worth a vist. Great place and great tour guide take time to walk outside in the gardens and along the water the scenery is magnificent

Imperial splendour. This palace is very lavish and sumptuous - so much that photos are not allowed - just to preserve the splendour. I guess its fine to get an idea of imperial life, the harems and so on, however for me seeing room after room of lavishness quickly gets boring, especially when you can't take photos. But that's me

Interesting tour. The tour was nice. Approx. 30 mins. Informative and interesting. The tour guide was very knowledgable. There was construction/restoration in parts but it didn't interfere with the tour.

Amazing Palace. This palace is astoundingly beautiful and has a rich history, culture and heritage to it. It’s also is a prime example of Modern Ottoman architecture, and it features not just classic Ottoman designs but also some European traits. The gardens with the Bosphorus view were amazing, and the open cafe in the palace premises gives a good view of the Bosphorus, as you munch on sandwiches over cups of Turkish tea.

Allow time for guided tour, we did not. We thought we had allotted ample time to see this palace but did not realize that the tours were guided. We only got to see the first twenty minutes because we had to be elsewhere. What we did manage to see was utter opulence. Trying to manage life in the palace back in the day. And because of our time limitation, we joined the Turkish speaking group because the English speaking group was not scheduled until later.
Grand!. The amazing chandelier! Not to be missed. some wonderful insights into the country's recent past and not to be missed.

The most impressive sight I've seen in Istanbul. Quick tips: arrive early in the morning at 9 or 10 am. It gets crowded around noon and closes at 4. Also the Harem is a must-see if you're there. The palace and harem each offer a mandatory tour by some programmed guides who do not speak English that clearly. However you don't really need all the knowledge to enjoy the spectacular wealth put into this. The busier it is, the more rushed the tours are. Also you have the clock museum, kristal pavilion and paint museum which are all worth your time. In total I spent 3.5h by myself at this place and thought it was well worth the 40 TL entrance fee.
