This palace definitely left a permanent impression on me. I'm not sure it's a hate or love thing if you see the amounts of money the sultan's put into it, but it makes a great museum.

AMAZING!!. Dolmabahce Palace is a MUST see attraction in Istanbul. We took a guided tour and were given the palace's beautiful history. Pictures aren't allowed inside the palace and that gave me a chance to enjoy every detail.
Beautiful. Missed this on my first visit. So glad I went on my second visit, it's fabulous and the crystal chandeliers are stunning, and there are so many of them. I would say a must visit

Breathtaking. Dolmabahce Palace is a considerably younger monument in Istanbul having only been built in the 1800's. The grounds are free to enter but entry to the main palace is 30 lira, a separate charge for the harem; the grounds on its own are impressive, with only a gate separating it from the Bosphorus which makes for stunning views. We were quite lucky to have visited on a sunny day despite it being a cold January; I would imagine there would be a considerable risk of flooding since the Bosphorus is literally on its doorstep.The main palace is a definite must-see; the opulence and riches of the Ottoman sultans is embedded in all 260+ rooms of the palace, with lavish chandeliers and towering ceilings. The grand ceremonial hall in particular is absolutely awe-inspiring. It is a pity that photos are not allowed and you can only explore with guided tour, but perhaps it is an ideal opportunity to take in everything with full attention rather than behind a camera lens. Definitely worth a visit.

Incredible . Most spectacularly well preserved palace in Europe. The tour is very good and informative and give you plenty of time to take in all the sights. Each room has its own wow factor. Definately go to this if you come to Istanbul.

Beautiful palace to visit. Beautiful garden and view, nice architecture, located in Sultan Ahmet are, a great place to visit.
Nearby other sight seeing places and palaces.

Wow!. This palace is very rich and European. There is gold and crystals everywhere. More than 200 rooms and the Ball Room is the highlight with the largest chandelier, throne and carpet. This palace is breathtaking.

Exquisite palace. Very beautiful Palace. Definitely worth your time and money. The guide was nice but did not speak very good english. The weather was not very good on the day I visited (visited in winter). Like everybody else has mentioned already, you are not allowed to take photos, but the place is so beautiful that you will remember for a long time
Beautiful. The Dolmabahce Palace is one of the most beautiful palaces in the world and is full of art work and history. The gardens are amazing.

Grand Palace!. We visited the Dolmabache Palace on an early morning tour. Had to wait outside the palace for a bit as we were probably a little early, but the palace architecture is beautiful so we didn't mind just waiting outside while soaking it all in. Once inside we were given a tour in English by one of the designated tour guides. It was just so beautiful to be here. The palace was the last palace of the Ottomans and one can see that it is more new than the other palaces. Really enjoyed visiting this place. Definitely one of the best palaces in Istanbul.

Magnifisent!!. Is one of the places you shouldn't miss! The toor is guided so you have the opportunity to get to know the history of the building! It's beauty is incomperable! Photos are not allowed indoors but the memories remain indelible! One should sit on the benchs by the sea and gaze upon Bosporus and definately have a turkish coffe or tea and a meal at Dolmabahce restorant by the Clock Tower!

History all around you and you are part of it!. Its understandable why there are only hided tour. There are so many museum exponats around which do not have a price. We went on English group tour. Please, don't leave this place strait after your tour. Go and explore around. What an amazing Ayvazovski painting in gallery! There are so many places around this palace. Yes, you have to wait long at que ti get inside, but it worth it.
Luxury!. Being the pasha residence, its exciting to learn a bit about how people used to live and traditions. Incredible chandellier!! Pitty pics are not allowed
Very Impressed of the Palace. Amaizing place to visit. I was impressed by the architecture, interior the view and everything. I advice to visit it with guide to learn about the history.

HORRIBLE VISIT !!!!!!. To run to visit such a place... !!!! A nightmare. Followed by unpleasant guards. A terrible experience. About the Palace itself , quite incredible to have such an horrible taste but what a work !!!

Best Sight in Istanbul. This was my favourite sight in Istanbul, and one which I hadn't planned on seeing.Taking a walk along the shore of the Bosphorus, seeing the palace ahead, decided to take a closer look and glad I did!We bought tickets for the English tour, only had to wait about 10 mins, put the covers provided over our shoes, and were amazed at the beauty and opulence of the palace from the moment we stepped inside!Each room we passed through was immaculate, and although the guide struggled slightly with her English, the stories she told and history she gave us were interesting and well worth the ticket...loved hearing about the Sultan, his mother, and his wives who all lived there in their own wings of the palace.The only downside was the lack of photography allowed, although a few people snuck some pics in - I would have loved to have looked back on the impressive chandeliers, each one larger and more elaborate than the last.The gardens are also beautiful, and worth a walk on your way in or out!

Incredibly romantic, interiors filled with art and furniture. (Not like many chateaux in France - there is much to see.) Yes, there is a guide - very helpful. Stunning and fascinating exterior, interior, you can read lots about this site. If you are wondering whether it is worth the bother, please don't hesitate - it is !! You don't need me to describe the palace. You need me to tell you if it's worth the visit.... the site on the Bosphorus is exquisite as well...

interesting but... It was beautiful inside but the tour guide wasn't speaking english well. Not allowed to take any pictures inside, only outside. After few minutes it starts getting a bit boring and annoying because of not understanding the tour guides talk. I liked the outdoors area. Nothing special.

A surprise in Istanbul. This palace was included in our full day tour and we loved it, it's really beautiful and with amazing views of the riverside. Inside is very luxurious and all the information about this place was very interesting.
It was nice, but.... I really didn't enjoy the place as much as it was advertised. I didn't really like it much. It was just an average museum

Bizarre combination of East meets West. Glad we had a guide to help us bypass the lines because it was crowded. Immense clear glass chandeliers everywher. This is the only place I've seen clear glass newel posts holding up banisters; the effect was strangely awkward and pleasing at the same time. I far preferred Topkapi Palace, but it was interesting to see the combination of the European and Eastern aesthetics. Lovely gardens too.
The Turkish sultans really knew how to live.. The palace is an architectural marvel with beautiful architectural elements in each room. Crystal, ceramics features in every room.

Excellent compact palace . Had a chance to visit this place as the militiary museum was closed . The location is beautiful set at the Bosporus. Huge lawns with fountains and reasonable gardens. The worksmanship is excellent and marble Exteriors set up the tone. The office areas done up very well and extravagance shows ( unlike topkapi) . This palace has a European feel . The crystal staircase and wooden floors are special. The hammams are huge and although a lot is not seen it is worth a visit. TryTo spend time getting views of the Bosporus. Have a cay in the restaurant and take in the views.
OMG. this is one of the most beautiful palaces i have ever visited in my lifeeverything inside is amazingthe decor the colors the gardens
Great . Very beautiful place to see. Gardens and aea view are great and relaxing. It only needs the guides to pay more attention to convey the information to the visitors.

Luxury. I visited this palace during January 2016. It was snowing, and the garden, the palace and the sea looked like from a Disney story.
This palace has a lot of luxury in its interior and exterior, and is definitely worth visiting. There are travel guides who will guide your through the palace in smaller groups.

Really worth a visit . Stunning palace that carries a historical significance . Don't miss out if you are travelling to Turkey. If will be a half day out which you will find relaxing , rewarding , interesting and in overall cool!:-)

One of the most stunning buildings I've ever seen. We were originally going to skip Dolmabache because we had read some reviews that said it was garish. It would have been a huge mistake. This building is AMAZING, from the crystal staircase to the ballroom and chandeliers, you have to see this. It may not be the most traditional building in Istanbul, but it will still take your breath away.

Must see. You should see this palace. I liked this better than topkapı palace. This palace is closed on monday and thursday and it works different from the others. Once you buy your ticket , you should wait for an english speaking local guide in themuseum. You are not allowed to walk on your own.

Beyond amazing. Do not miss this palace under any circumstances. It's one of the most beautiful palaces in Europe. It can be seriously compared to Versailles with it's beautiful interior and breathtaking location right on the shore. I recommend buying a full ticket, for only few euros more you get to see the impressive Harem. Be sure to leave more that 2 hrs for visiting since you have guided tours that are boot about 45 min plus few other stuff you can optionally visit like the clock museum(quite impressive collection of vintage clocks)

Excellent trip to istanbul. Istanbul is just so beautiful n all the places like dolmabahche palace,blue mosque,Sofia hagia,Galata tower,bosphorous ride .I just loved Dolmabahche palace.love to visit Istanbul many times...

Fantastic deal for students and my favorite place in Istanbul!. Definitely show your student ID to buy a student ticket for palace & harlem. The palace area is huge with many small museums/sites to see. I suggest spending at least an afternoon admiring various buildings and wandering by the gardens. Painting museum is free for ticket holders and lovely as well. Important to note: the tours in the main palace and harlem are guided tours only.

Palace brilliant, disappointed by the tour. As a number of other reviewers have said, you can only visit as part of a tour. This would be all well and good, but the tour itself was rubbish. I don't want to criticise the bloke's English because my Turkish is only a few words, but the whole thing was far too quick. You'd enter a huge room and he'd say "here's this painting, here's this furniture, over there you can see this piano, ok next room." And off he went. There was far too little time to look at any of the objects in any detail and, because you're part of a tour, there's a chaperone at the back to make sure you're not falling behind. The palace itself is beautifully preserved, wonderfully extravagant and, with an Isic card, only TL 5 to enter! But I would be hacked off if I had paid 40 lira for what was provided.
Wonderfull place. Magnific historical place, perfect architeture, luxuos, fantastic, its like you back to pass and live in time of sultans...
Excellent place!!!. Beautiful place full of history and magic atmosphere. I definitely come back there at some point of my life.

Amazing. This place is completely over the top. It is insane, take the tour and just marvel at the fact that they have a chandelier that is bigger than a truck. Its was an easy walk from the hotel I was staying at as well.

Closed Monday and Thursday. Very disappointed that no one told us this. Take a tram to Kabatas and then walk the remaining 10 mins. Note that even when closed the main security gates are open for you to see the massive entrance. The cafe there gives a good view of the Bosphorus.
Modern Ottoman Architecture. This palace is one of the examples of Modern Ottoman architecture. It not only features classic Ottoman structure but also some European traits.

You should be aware when its opened. When I was in istanbul , I decided to visit Dolmabahce with my family ; wife and two kids but I found it closed , so you should be aware when its opened ; I think its opened all the week days except Monday , Thursday ; but we had a walk beside its walls which is vey high , beautiful , took pictures beside one of its gates , had a walk behind it in the front of the sea which is very very interseting .

A truly wonderful palace. This was my second visit in three years and enjoyed it all over again. It is luxurious, informative and beautiful. One would require around 4 and a half hours to see the palace, the Harem, the Crystal Museum, the Painting Museum and the treasures. Well worth it.
Palace. This was not on our list to visit but our tour guide recommended it. It was close to our hotel so we toured it late in the day, just before closing. It was worth the visit.

Well worth a visit!. I am glad we did not skip visiting this palace! The whole place is impressive, the gardens, the ponds the Bosphoros view next to it! The interior is mindblowing the least. All the gold and ivory you can imagine is the decor of this palace! One great thing is that all visits are guided (included in the ticket) actually you cannot visit the palace on your own. The guide gives information about the various venues of the palace and this helps the audience to better feel the atmosphere of the Sultans that once lived there. We also got tickets for the Harem which was also a guided visit. I must say that although it was not a bad experience you will not miss anything if you do not include the Harem to your visit, at some point it felt like a repetition! There are also a couple of of side museums to the palace located in its walls, there is a clocks museum and a paintings museum - we did not visit them though!I suggest you put Dolmabahce in your must see list if you visit Istanbul!
Winter vacation . Spend some days not forgetful chill weather with snowfall and beautiful architectures experience at that time when not such facilities available as now.

Absolutely astonishing!. There is no palace in the Europe like this one and it's a must see place in Istanbul! If you go there don't save the money,buy the whole ticket and visit Harem, you will not be disapointed. When inside,do not rush,but enjoy every room. The only flaw is that I visited the palace in January 3rd,the wind and cold were cruel,which is why I need to come back in summer and enjoy the garden as well. P.s. every chandelier is a like a fairytale!

Well worth seeing, but the mandatory guided tours are a drag. The Dolmabache is certainly well worth seeing, stylistically very different from the rest of Ottoman Turkey.However, in order to control the crowds, guided tours are mandatory. I can understand the need to control the number of people entering, but the guided tours mean that you cannot see the place at your own pace. Spoils the experience somewhat.

I could live there!. The sultans knew how to live for sure... Amazingly beautiful palace, left with my head spinning by the ornate decor, decadence and awe. I was getting upset when looking at the most beautiful paintings on the walls and cupolas of this place...because I thought Italy had the most astonishing art...until I saw this palace ! (I'm Italian and proud!) but then the tour guide said the palace had been painted mostly by Italian artists...and felt much better :) I heart Istanbul! Most fun awesome place I've been since Bali. Turkish men are handsome too, which doesn't hurt!

Pretty impressive. Have read many things about the excess of this palace. It is amazing in it's own right. Very impressive both outside and inside. We did notice that the outside was much better preserved from bosporus point, not so much on the other side.

mind blowing modern palace. we went there on a tram from the sultanhammet to kabatash and two minutes walk.ticket price around 30TL (only bought the offical section Tickets), its a beautiful place with an amazing sea view, there was guided tour for english speaker includng in the price...you were not allowed to take photo inside the palace but lovely scenery outside to take plenty of pictures, there is a cafe and a offical shop in the premises which is actually well resonable.

Nothing says over the top like the largest crystal chandelier in the world. When the Ottomans left Topkapi it was to move to the Dolmabahce Palace. Topkapi had become old and worn and was out of fashion for the times. All the Iznik tile was just so Medieval and Early Modern. And well, we just couldn't have that.Nothing says you're a Sultan in the mid 19th century quite like 45,000 square feet, 285 rooms, 46 halls, 6 hamams, 68 toilets, and the world's largest Bohemian Crystal Chandelier (a gift from Queen Victoria, who was a relative) weighing in at a mere 4.5 tonnes. And that's not going into details about the Baccarat crystal lamps, or the other chandeliers (yes, numbers 4, 3, and 2 are also there) or the Hereke carpets, the alabaster, porphyry marbles, the Marmara. Let's just say, it's FANCY.You go through here with a guide. Tours are given in Turkish and English and possibly Arabic but I couldn't work that out despite the number of people asking for tours in Arabic whether that actually was an option. There are no pictures. You will take away all that is gaudy and extravagant in your head. If you hate this kind of bizarre Rocco, Baroque, Neoclassical love child you will not enjoy this. But if like me, you find this kind of absurd moment in a monarchy when clearly it is all falling apart, but that just at that moment, then is when they decide to build the piece de resistance, that monument to their utter downfall, then you will love this. And of course, Ataturk's room is in there as well, where he died and that is actually quite moving because he must have been an amazing man, really, to bring Turkey out of the Ottoman period and into the Republic. So go for that if you must.

European Imperial Splendour on the Bosphorus. Topkapi is fascinating but Dolmabahce is magnificent. Built to rival the great palaces of Europe, Dolmabahce has 360 rooms, a 4.5 ton crystal chandelier that takes 4 months to clean, and a grand reception room which takes 4 days to heat. It is right on the Bosphorus and it is where Ataturk died. Don't miss it.

Impressive . After 45min your your eyes are still trying to get used how huge and fancy something could be. Definite dolmabahce one of the most impressive place I've been visiting. For me, the number one touristic place in Istanbul
Beautiful!. Very well organized museum. There are tours in english and the landscape is beautiful. With 30 TL you can see the main Palace and the appartments of the Harem.

Awesome display. This palace is mind blowing-ly beautiful. MAKE A TRIP HERE. In comparison to some of the key palaces in Europe this is astoundingly beautiful, well maintained and has such a rich history, culture and heritage to it. The grandness of the entire palace is absolutely mind blowing.

that view. i wasn't so impress of the inside of the palace, but the gardens and the sea view was amazing. it was a little expensive to visit the both, his place and his wife also, but for 12 TL you can just walk around the gardens.
Visit the past. There are lots of rooms there but some of them have a good architecture. Most of the rooms are so simple for a palace.

must see old time palace. if you feel like taking a trip back in time and get to know the ottoman emperors fancy lifestyle you should definitely pay a visit.
very well preserved indoor luxury furniture.

Over the top grandeur. We visited Dolmabahçe Palace on a cloudy day, rather late in our two week stay in the city, so my perception might be affected by a bit of sight-seeing exhaustion. Overall, I found the palace very interesting to visit, but not my favorite attraction in Istanbul. The tour guides herd you through quickly (they have to, because it's huge!) and many rooms are cordoned off. The whole thing is incredibly over-the-top. Some people in my family found it amazing. I found it to be too much. Highlights include the show-stopping Ceremonial Room at the end of the tour, which made all our jaws drop.On a clear day that really allows you to enjoy the waterfront location, I might have enjoyed this attraction more. Keep in mind that there is a ferry terminal in walking distance, so you can plan to arrive or leave by boat, which would make it fun.

Not worth the money. It is disapointing to see how the Ottomans gave up on their values and beauties to let the European values in. It is an interesting palace, but you can see Schonbrune or Versailles for the same price and really feel the luxury of a palace. This did not look anything like that, although really luxurious, large and stuff... Still, this is only my personal opinion and I do realise that I prefer the traditional Ottoman buildings to this one. Seeing it as a palace, outside of the context, it is not bad. Has some things that are really "wow" (piano, staircase, chandeliers, etc.), so if you have extra money and want to see how they lived after leaving Topkapi, go for it

Overpriced. Don't get me wrong, it's an amazing place but price is really high and the fact that you have to be guided through was never stated. Even if it was stated i never understood it before i paid the price. If someone really likes to see a "semi" modern palace and get guided really fast through the rooms... oh well it's great but if you are like me and you don't want these types of rushed guiding through a place i don't think you will find your (30-40TL / person) worthwhile
Spectacular palace. You must see it at any cost. The palace has great architecture, design and construction. We really enjoyed it.

Wish we had more time to spend here. We did not plan well enough to spend as much time here as we should have, but I wish we could have stayed longer. You can book tickets for different parts of the palace, or one ticket for almost everything. The ticket for the main palace includes a guided tour that lasts about 45 minutes, because you are not allowed into the palace on your own. You have to wear plastic show covers, and photos inside are not allowed. The tour guide was very informative, but for the number of people on the tour, he maybe could have been a little louder to be heard in the back of the group. Overall the tour was a great experience.We did not have time to go see the haram or other parts other than the main palace, but if I'm ever back in Istanbul, that will be first on my list of things to do.

Beautiful palace. the architecture and history behind this palace are fascinating! Make sure to pay attention to your tour guide if you have one because they will tell you some very interesting stories that have to do with the palace.

Puts Buckingham palace to shame. Modern day Istanbul is all about cashing in on it's Ottoman history. The places, the food, the souvenirs - everything dates back to the glory days of the Sultans. And nothing depicts it better than the Dolmabahce Palace. Just off the Bophorus strait, the building is the epitome of extravagance and great design (admittedly most times, useless). Boasting the biggest chandelier of its time, it surely is worth getting in line of a guided tour for. No photography allowed inside which is a shame. Overall, worth the visit.

Glittering Excess. This Palace is a wonderful building situated right on the water's edge. It is one of the better attractions in Istanbul and well worth then two hours it will take to see both the main palace and the Harem. The glittering crystal is everywhere to be seen in the main palace, including on the beautiful staircase. In contrast the Harem is less lavish but by no means less interesting. You can buy a single ticket and just see the main Palace or a ticket which allows both visits. All tour are guided and in a number of languages including English. If you want to hear what is said try and stand near to the guide and listen very carefully as they talk very quickly. It does not seem to be the practice to tip the guides.

Impressive how rich the Sultans were. Although Topkapi palace is the number one Istanbul attraction in many travel guides, I prefer the Dolmabahce palace. The location is great, the garden is very nice, and the decorations inside really impressed me. So much gold, painted ceilings and signs of wealth! The guided tours are not the best. I have been here twice and one time I had a great guide who was telling a lot about the history and the difference rooms. Another time there was a guide who was trying to finish the tour as quick as possible. I guess you have to be a bit lucky with that. The harem section is also worth a visit (10 Turkish Lira more expensive), although it feels less luxurious. In this area Ataturk lived and passed away.
Great!. No individual tour, visitor need to follow tour provided by the museum and there is long queue for English tour. Make sure you come early! Taking photos are prohibited in the building.
must visit place. this is must visit gorgeous palace. influence by the European design , the tour we waited very long time but worth it .. not all the rooms you can permitted to see and access .

Should be Rated Higher. We spent a week in Istanbul and put the Dolmabahce Palace off to the end of the week since it was not as highly rated on Trip Advisor or in the guide books. We agreed after seeing the palace that we would have been upset to find we had missed it. We have been to many of the palaces and historical homes of Europe and Dolmabahce ranks right up there with the best of any we have seen. We took a guided tour and perhaps that made the difference. At any rate it is absolutely worth the 2 hours spent visiting.

Thenest attraction in Istanbul!. In my opinion, the best attraction of Istanbul if you consider the internal architecture. There are only group guided tours which can take longer to get inside but is very nice to have someone explaining the history of the place.

Fantastic Sea View Palace. Had a great visit on January 2nd 2016 and although it was heavily snowing had a great time. Both the main and the harem sections are really worthy to visit. Do not miss the main ceremonial hall and the room where Kemal Ataturk passed away.
NIce views. We saw this palace in lights while taking the Bosphorus tour. Didnt visit from inside but looked amazing from outside

It is still an official residence !. Dolmebahce Palace housed the Sultan and his wives..much of the glorious splendour remains intact. Sadly no photographs allowed , but one has enough time to view, absorb and be impressed by the opulence and vastness ... The place is still used by the President and Diplomats...

Magnificent. The tour is a little bit too rushed and the no photo policy is strictly enforced inside. Some of the rooms are simply breathtaking. If you are in a rush you can skip the Hareem section which is a separate tour and not as impressive as the official side of the palace.

Stunning. Simply stunning and everything inside is beautifully showcased. The line was very long to go inside, luckily for me, i was with a guided tour group and we passed through the line with a breeze.
Nice but no Versaille. Nice, a little pricey, very few rooms visited on tour. The chandeliers are great as are the rugs. Nice one time visit.
So much History. I strongly suggest to visit this place , i am a personal admirer of Atatürk from Slovakia , if you like history , you will get shivers when you enter this palace.
Fantastic palace. Beautiful palace that will amaze you on a sunny day. It has a very interesting story of the Sultan and some of the objects are mind blowing.

Fascinating, but could be better. This place is amazing--and breathtakingly beautiful--but it could be so much better. Our guide was a young woman with a hoarse voice from yelling about the tour--a good sign the tour was too large. She rushed us, and while she said the tour would take 45 minutes, it was more like 32. There are no gossipy tidbits or interesting stories here, just the facts. We even sprang for the expensive ticket for the Harem, but even here we were led through a few rooms, and then pointed toward the rooms--with so much history and so many fascinating details--it could have been more interesting!

Boring. The line was way too long, the English speaking group was way too large and the information was superficial to say the least. Worst visit in years.This is the trick; you have to line up until an English speaking tour starts, no chance to take an individual visit: there is no limit to the number of participants and the corridors inside are long and narrow. Chances are that your guide is probably explaining something tens of yards away from you, as the line crawls its way on the tourist path into the rooms of the palace which are all, with some rare exceptions, free of items of some particular interest (but then again, coming from where I come from you tend to be a little demanding when it comes to history, art and beauty).

Brilliant Architecture. you will get to see well conserved palace. it also has the world's biggest crystal chandelier. the might of the OTTOMAN empire can be seen in the palace. they also have change of guard and other ceremonies picturing what it would have been in the beginning of the 19th century. Lovely gardens and Fountains are in the palace campus.

Amazing Palace. We visited the palace on our second day in Istanbul. This is NOT included in the Museum Pass so you have to pay separately for admission. As soon as you enter the grounds, you are greeted by gardens that have been kept immaculately clean and wonderful. We arrived past 3PM and so we could only visit the Palace and not the Harem (separate admission). The tour of the palace is guided and we were lucky that we got there five minutes before the start of the tour. You are required to cover your shoes with blue plastic covers to protect the floor. The guide said the tour would run an hour but it was closer to 45 minutes (I checked the time). The guide was very informative and again, like most architectural attractions in Istanbul, everything was jaw-dropping amazing. There is a lot to see in the palace that the guide would point out. This tour is comparable to Versailles and Schonbrunn Palaces but what made it unique was its location beside the Bosphorus. Visiting it at dusk lent a more mysterious feel of the place. Tip: If you wish to visit both the palace and the harem, be sure you're there before 2PM.

History lesson. Among many touristic attractions in Istanbul this is the most interesting. It explains a lot of Turkish history. Simply it can't be missed. Go earlier in order to avoid long waiting in a line.

Nice to see but a bit long with young children.. . Nice to see but a bit long with young children.. the tours are guided so you can't control time.. you are only allowed to walk with the tour guide in the castle. .

The best I liked in Istanbul. It really a palace. But not a normal palace very luxury palace. I can say they cannot built a palace like this in this time. Ataturk died here. You can see this room still. Take time and visit it.

Good Palace Tour. We when on a semi rainy day in December, lines were short and we got in in about a 1/2 hour. Only tours allowed no self guided walks. Our guide was very good and we tours the impressive palace. I would recommend you go if you have the time

Lovely palace. I know it's hard to compare ot with Versailles but for me it's Istanbul Versailled :)
Make sure u visit the main hall & the harmlek (the ladies place), beautiful chandeliers & carpets
Magnificient place. Must visit this place. The gold plated interiors, Ottomen empire furniture, antique collections and lots of things to see.

Over the Top. Splendor and ostentation is the password, dear guests, and you gaze in amazement at this renovated 19th century palace on the Bosporus. NO photos allowed. Prepare to be in a large assemble, sorted by linguistic preference. Your complete ticket also entitles you to see the painting building: go, it is worth it.

Great!. It's not as facinating as Topkapı Palace but Eurpean style palace of the Empire. You need to follow your leader during your visit. You can't have a break or spend more time in the rooms. Topkapı is more Turkish than this palace!
Everything is gold and too exaggerated. But it's nice anyway!

It was closed on Monday. This was the first thing I wanted to see and when I reached at the gates of this palace it was closed. Security guard told me its closed on Monday and I spent 35 Turkish Lira from old town to reach there. Some suggestions: * Taxi drivers are not honest here.Their priority is to rip you off.* They will never tell you if place where we are going is opened or closed.* Taxi drivers here are expert magicians - They ripped off my wife and we were so angry that day. Always make sure you take meters taxi and this guy who ripped us had a tampered meter. It was running very fast. Also when my wife took out money to pay for travel, he said its 53 Turkish Lira. When she started handing out money this expert magician taxi driver changed 50 Lira note into a 20 Lira note. Im not joking they have cheated many people like this. I was later on told by hotel reception - these taxi drivers are just behind your money. Disgusting.

My favourite palace in Europe. This Palace was overwhelmingly beautiful! Unfortunately you aren't allowed to take photos inside, but the gardens and the grounds itself were amazing also. We travelled by taxi from the old city, so it was a little difficult traveling back in peak traffic. May have been better to head there on a tour. Definitely a must see if you're in Istanbul.

Favourite Palace in Istanbul. This is a MUST see when in Istanbul: Easily one of my favourite attractions! Though understandable, it is unfortunate that photography inside the palace is prohibited. I was stunned the whole tour from all the gorgeous details in this building's architecture. It's unbelievable to think that such a masterpiece was created in the 1800s. I visited this site with a guided tour and highly recommend you do the same during your visit - there's a lot of history to learn and appreciate. According to the brochure given out in the palace, it "open every day between 9 a.m. - 4 p.m. except Mondays and Thursdays." Even if you miss out on seeing Topkapi Palace, you need to ensure you see the Dolmabahçe!
amazing. Really a beautiful palace inside and out. I recommend going early to beat the rush and no photos are allowed inside the palace.
Best part of Istanbul trip. Visit to Dolmabache Palace was undoubtedly best part of my visit to Istanbul. Truly royal and magnificent!!

visit historical places. it very nice with lots of different trees and flowers around,it 's very big and interesting to visit and see,with very good guide .it is historical place and it cost to see this place.

283 rooms of history, massive wealth & historic opulence. If you take a ferry around or drive across the Bosphorus, you cannot miss this magnificent palace with its beautiful gates, gardens and a display of visible wealth. Individual entry to this palace especially during the summer months must be quite different but in December, we arrived with a tour and had a tour-reserved entry so there was no wait (I hear the lines during summer are crazy). The inside of the Palace is quite protected by a number of guards/guides, there is STRICT order of NO PHOTOS inside and they are watching your every step. I did not dare to take my phone out and take even one sneaky picture! I like and enjoy tours of castles as much as anybody else, I come from a historic country so I am used to certain historic interiors so there were 2 points of truly unbelievable WOW: 1) The Ambassadorial Hall at the beginning of the tour where foreign dignitaries and diplomats were received by the Sultans. This 'room' is unreal! Gold on ceilings, magnificent entry staircase with Baccarat balustrade - yes, crystal pieces of staircase(!), and the huge massive hanging crystal chandeliers and huge massive standing candleholders are sight for sore eyes! I cannot imagine Vikings or English diplomats arriving here and not being in immense awe of the 14 tons of gold used in this palace almost everywhere and on anything, not being blown away by the 283 rooms, or by the 80 meters long corridor (hallway) connecting the male quarters (aka the Palace) with the women quarters (aka the Harem). It is something! ...And the second WOW is:2) The Ceremonial Hall in the basement with its sheer size, out-of-this-world beautiful blue dome/ceiling and massive tall columns that are actually not there for structural support but are hollow(!!) and were used as central heating system with heated air from a near-by kitchen is something that you just cannot even comprehend.

What a Palace. Amazing in all means, every inch in this palace is still furnished with the sultans furniture, the bathroom of the sultan is overlooking the bosphour. the ball room is huge and the chandelier weighs massive 4 tons,131 handmade silk carpets, the ceiling is decorated with 14 tons of gold.Very important place to visit , it was the residence of the last 6 sultans of the othman empire.

The time for visiting is not good . It was good experience to see the history of sultans. We paid full ticket by 40 TL but unfortunately we visited only one part because other part was closed due the time is finished. I think this is not good way to pay without no service and they do not inform us about the time of closing. Please be informed that the camera is not allowed and the visiting with tour guide.

A palace that equal the elegance of the Winter Palace in Russia. Everyting is beutiful , but sad to say , no pictures allowed . The ceiling , the chandeliers the crystals used is a site to behold . Just imagine 14 tons of gold was used in that palace ! The staircase is similar but in smaller scale to that of the winter palace in Russia . If travelling in Istanbul , be sure NOT to miss going inside the palace . Its a must for anyone visiting Istanbul .

You can spend all day in there . Dolmabahce is the great palace. With beautiful architecture, it also has many interest part inside the palace such painting museum (don't forget to see Turkish Mona Lisa) and clock museum.you can see beautiful landscape of Istanbul from this palace.I can say that it is value for you money every cent.

giant palace. at empire times big building was equal to power. thats why this palace has incredibly big doors, garden gates, windows everthing. 2-3 hurs is not enough to visit but take a guide tour to better understand the history
We stayed with opened mouth.... 14 tones of gold.... upon your head ... it was amazing. The guide were very carefull and a good english speaker.

Beautiful palace on the Bosphorus. Beautiful palace located on the Bosphorus in the Besiktas district. We walked here from Taksim Square. Closed Monday and Thursday 30TL each for entrance. They will provide you with an English speaking guide who will take you round the palace for a 45 minute tour. Home to different Sultans. Very lavish with crystal chandeliers. Also beautiful gardens to visit.
Palace with incredible history . Movie like scenery. Crystal stairs. Golden walls. Great way to see the inside of how the kings lived and lives.
The Palace with the gates on the Bosforus. Modern mixture of European and Islamic stile PalaceSpectacular gardensCristal Pocelain Paintings and Sculpture

Mid Week Break. We took the BIg Red Bus tour from Sultanahamet in Gulhane Park and stopped at the Palace. Fantastic piece of history the opulence of the day is shown in magnificent detail we spent hours here then caught the Big Red Bus back to close where we were staying. My advice here is to be vigilante as there was a terrorist attack here some months ago, however we felt very safe indeed and the local people could not have been more friendly,
Interesting History. The palace and grounds were beautiful. It doesn't take long but they do put you in groups so it can be difficult to see at times. I don't think most children would enjoy this.
Amazing. Amazing historical place.Have to visit this big palace.You can feel the history.Really amazing.......

The gate to the Bosphorus.... the whole scenery: having the palast directly at the water and this gorgeous white opened gates that let u take stunning photos. id consider u to go through every single building. everything was interesting at its own way! chekc the strict opening hours! ;)
Beautiful palace. Beautiful palace. The guided tour comes along with the ticket of the palace, so it is good to know about the history of the palace.

for art / painting lovers. If you are interested in art and painting - this place will have some good surprises for you. It has a huge collection of Ivan Aivazovsky (famous Russian painter) paintings. A great place to relax and enjoy the candid art pieces
The French VERSAILLES!. Very beautiful palace. It is 30Turkish Lira to visit (about 10 USD) You have a guide (English or Turkish)

Do not miss!!. This place is the highlight in our trip among all the attraction that we went in Istanbul. Yes, we went to all, literally all attraction that everyone suggested but Dolmabahce palace is definately our favourite. Its not cheap, 40 lira for entrance including Harem section but trust me its worth it. And the bed where Atartuk rest in peace located in Harem section. U cant simply go inside and wander yourself like in Topkapi palace. You'll be following scheduled guided tour either in english or turkish language. Its beyond words to describe how beautiful and majestic the interior of the palace. No picture or video allow in the palace and yes dont touch anything and you only allowed to walk on the red carpet. It seem too much restriction but once youre there you'll understand you in old palace where everything still in original place. The tour guide will stop at certain section and explained the history of the palace. Giving chances if i ever comeback to Istanbul i'll definately visit this palace again compare to all other attraction.

UNPROFESSIONAL PERSONNEL RUINING THE WHOLE EXPERIENCE. The palace itself is really magnificent and really worth a visit. However, the personnel working inside the palace is UNACCEPTABLE. The guided tours in english and turkish are obligatory, so they divide you in groups according your language. Then the tour starts. The guide responsible for the english tour spoke so bad english with such a terrible accent, so no one could understand what she was saying. Apart from her, our group was accompanied by another person who made sure that no one could observe any item more than 2 seconds, being extremely rude with us, crying costantly with bad manner: "Μove, move, move" as if we were sheeps escaping the flock. Very unconfortable situation. It ruined all the experience for us. We didn't enjoy the beautiful palace at all.

Beautiful Palace. We were very impressed by the grounds and palace. Everyone suggested we visit the Topkapi Palace, but this one is so much more impressive. The admission includes a guide tour through the palace, and it was worth every cent. (Jan 2013)

Most unique palace . We've been to many palaces around the world, but this one tops the list!
It's very unique in its design and furniture.
It has antiques from around the world
It's very spacious
Nothing is like it!
It's a must visit

Sumptuous Palace!!. The European Palace of the Sultans constructed in the middle of the 19th century is simply marvelous. It seems like every room was simply done over-the-top with antiques, ornate furniture, textiles, chandeliers, you name it. It is all rich, gorgeous and excessive.The entrance fee is 40 TL for a combined ticket to the main Palace and the Harem. The visit is only done with a guided tour. The tour provides some basic information on the most important rooms. Moving from one room to the next simply felt rushed, with little additional history or information and there was just too much to see with no time to pause and admire. We tried to explore a little more on our own which basically meant we were always behind and often were rushed by other staff to move along quickly.Once you left the Harem you were on your own to explore other parts of the gardens and grounds.The Crystal Pavilion was an additional little jewel.

A master piece of delicacy and aesthetic sense but. The fine details, beautiful art work, collection of chandeliers and carpets and use of marble makes the place a master piece of construction. However, it also is reflective of one of many reasons of the fall of Ottoman empire. These guys were busy building their dynasties and legacies rather than doing any good for the people.

Exceptional Palace. One of the most beautiful Palace visited, unfortunely inside pictures are forbidden, so a visit becomes a must. Free english guide is provided and tours takes places every half an hours. The lenght of the visit is around 45 minutes. Purchase the entire palace tickets (the price is 13 Euro, 3 Euro more then only the palace) and you will gain acces also to the Harem section and the Paint museum.

It's a beautiful and amazing place in palace many have great rooms and great decoration. It's a beautiful and amazing place in palace many have great rooms and great decoration. I'm very very pound to seem it. And want to recommend to all

Exceeds your wildest royal Ottoman fantasies. Get the full ticket, and be sure to leave a few hours to see it all. The palace, harem, crystal house and painting museum are each well worth the price of full admission. Just stunning.

Sultan palace !!!. Once you enter the place you will feel how much power the Sultan had at that time , the size ,decoration ,art,paint carpet , every things is out standing .You must see this place Thanks

Can't get over the grandeur of this palace!. Lovely guided official tour in English made it definitely a better experience than looking on your own. The main ceiling took 3 years to make! The chandeliers are just so huge and mind blowing! With such a huge estate with so many rooms and so much art - paintings, sculptors etc it was just an unbelievable experience of seeing and admiring such a massive display of everything. All the clocks are kept at 9:05 to respect the death time of the 1st president Ataturk who died here. ( I wonder how they are winded and maintained). This palace is so well maintained and the display is so beautifully done and the overall visiting experience is so complete that you don't mind spending many hours here!

Not ot be missed!. Beautiful palace, right on the Bosphorus with gorgeous furnishings, paintings, porcelains. Do not miss the Harem section. Istanbul Museum Pass is not valid here. Admission is 40 Turkish Lire, a bit on the high side but well worth it. Entrance includes the Painting Gallery on the grounds.

Very impressive and well preserved!. Tourist should really visit this palace! It's a MUST! Get a ticket which you will have a full access to the palace (40 TL). You will be mesmerized with the whole palace, the design, the crystals and all....
charming ..easy to reach. a must see palace ..elegance and beauty with the biggest chandeliers i have ever seen .. the palace smell takes you back in time

Dolce & Gabbana palace. Wow o wow. This palace is a real beaut! Easily the most elegant place I have ever seen in person. Entry is priced at 40 lira for the full tour which is just over £11 in "real money". This might seem steep but it is well worth it. Magnificent, 10/10 and attractive are just a few words and phrases I could use to describe the tour guide that took us round for the first part of the tour. From the biggest chandelier in Europe (if you know what I mean ;)) to the sculpted cheekbones of our guide the tour was both informative and pleasing on the eye.

Dolce and Gabbana Palace . We walked here and went to see the besiktas stadium on route, very cool. I didn't know much about this place before hand but when you see the gates and continue into the courtyard you begin to appreciate the architecture and decadence of this palace. The tours are well worth the money, they are very informative. The decoration in the palace is refined however the curtains didn't match the rugs, if you know what I mean. Our tour guide was very intelligent and answered any questions, one question I was scared to ask was "where is the sultanas tv kept?" it must be a decent size, at least 32 inch but it would need some surround sound...the acoustics weren't great in the great hall, ironic. She did explain to us that her rug in the great hall is bigger than her entire house.

Must do!. Magnificent palace and really worth a visit. Only a pity that they are not allowing individual visits, so you have to join a group with English or Turkish guide. Those guides kinda rush you through the palace, but they are open for questions.
Wonderful..!!!. Wonderful and Amazing Palace..Must Visit attraction in Istanbul.And the Boshporous view from the palace is Amazing.Very Big palace..kind of tired :)

Wonderful Palace. Dolmabahce palace is very well maintained and a must visit palace in istanbul.we went with private tour and spend around hour inside the palace seeing various rooms and designs.Palace huge and look very luxury.Cameras are not allowed inside the palace but we can take picture from out side excellent garden view and sea view.

Beautiful but rushed tour !. The palace itself is beautiful and worth the visit, however it is a shame thatthe tour you have to take pushes and hurries you through the palace in a rushed20 -minute tour ! You have to keep on walking with no time to really appreciate thebeauty and grandeur. We had to really pay attention to understand the poor Englishof the official guide and his very short explanations.We regret not having had more time to enjoy it.We visited last week of November and the crowd was so thin the rush was not justified at all.
So much to see. --Very nice attraction.--Very crowded.--Try to take your time and enjoy. It's a lot of walking.--The tours are okay. I think it's the only way you can see inside.--Lots of photo opps.
Like thousand and one night. Don´t miss it - take a good guide to listen all the things you never can imaging for your own. It needs minimum a half day to visite the palace.

Condescending Guides, Little Supporting Information. The tour guides were useless. A young woman and middled aged man took turns leading the group. The group was too large, the pace much too fast and the information superficial at the very best. Few bits of information were offered, few objects were highlighted, and what was mentioned was told as if the guides were asleep. The man's English was so poor that few people bothered to listen. Then, he took off like on a race to complete the tour path. Photographs are not allowed in order to sell more books, or to for whatever reason. There were few signs to explain rooms, or anything else. Wall posters to explain in the painting section were written in a very awkward English. Overall, the place is quite lovely, but the presentation gets an F. Study in advance so that you will be able to recognize the highpoints as the guides don't seem to care. Oh, an areas that were open to the public in years past are now closed. It was a disappointing visit. There is also a cafe on site with a very limited selection of treats, and the one in the painting museum was a few bottles of pop and a young guy who made a very small to tiny cup of turkish coffee for a high prices. Take your own food and beverages.
Must not miss. Felt like being at Buckingham Palace. Was amazing inside would go again for sure. Do not miss if you are thinking

The History of Ottomans. Great palace the shows the history of 6 emperors of Ottomans. It is really amazing and awesome. The 3rd painting on ceiling is really wonderful and amazing. It is a most visit place for any visitors of Istanbul.

sultan summer palace that is extraordinary. Do see especially if you are doing the Bosphorus river cruise. Very exorbitant palace from the time that the empire was doing well. Be sure to do the back part of the grounds for a different view or two

old world elegance. When you just look at that archway going out to the Bosporus you can't help but imagine what it would have been like to sail up in your boat and disembark onto this beautiful property. The grounds are pristine, the Palace is magnificent! The crystal chandeliers are mind blowing!!!! Not to be missed!

Nice palce!. Dolma Bahce palace is one of the most well-known sightseeings in Istanbul! It is a good chance for all visitors to admire its architecture and, in parallel, to have the possibility to walk next to Bosphorus! Do not miss the chance to visit it!

A must see if you are here for longer than a couple of days. An interesting insight into life in the Sultan's palace! Amazing chandeliers and a wonderful domed hall with a four and a half ton one, a gift fro Queen Victoia apparently. The building of this, according to our guidebook, hastened the end of the Ottoman Empire. You can only see it on a guided tour, and there are two of these, though you can opt only to see the male quarters or the female ones, but you really need to see both to get the full picture. However you have to hang around a bit in between as the timings are not coordinated.

Lovely palace - well organized tour by English speaking guide. We purchased our ticket and joined a long queue for English speaking guide and thought we were going to be disappointed. But then our Guide appeared and conducted the entire tour so well - and added well-timed humor in the commentary to keep the group engaged - that the experience was the best we had of all the attractions we visited in Istanbul.

Don't forget to visit!!. Even though all this wealthiness is not my style, i can say that it was one of the most impressive things that I have ever seen. I recommend it to all my friends visiting me and they all have the best of impressions. Many years of history pass in front of your eyes, and they stop with the clock in Kemal Atatürk's death room which stopped for ever at his time of death. Really impressive, don't even imagine to visit the city as a tourist and not visiting this place

Ottoman lifestyle. While on the Bosphorus cruise, I espied this beautiful palace amongst other beautiful villas and learnt it was the famous Dolmabahce Palace, that was home to many Ottoman rulers as well as the first President Ataturk. Having a Museum Pass really helped as one doesn't have to wait in line to buy a ticket. My visit was on a Friday, which coincided with the visit of a local school. It was a crazy sight, to see so many children being herded in groups. I was happy to have had the sense to buy the museum pass. You are herded in groups of English speaking and non-English speaking groups and photography is strictly forbidden. It takes away the pleasure somewhat, as you are hustled along by your guide. But it still is the most stunning place I have seen in all my travels, rooms awash in luxurious furniture, and the view of the sea lapping peacefully alongside....How lucky must have been those people who lived there to live in such a gorgeous palace, right next to the sea was my constant thought. The Harem was the gem of the palace in my opinion, the queen mother's chambers, the little rooms for the ladies in waiting etc. The crystal banisters and the huge chandeliers of the reception hall were an equally enchanting sight.

Unique luxery place . Only reason for not visting this oalace is due to the long long que to get in and but a ticket...it deserves tobe visited..u shouldn't miss this place in istanbul... WOW and open eyes will be your companion in this trip..it needs more than 3hours to go throught it...and they will give u a packs of naylon shoes to wear them...wear...go in..enjoy

Wonderful European Style Palace with Amazing Chandeliers. We spent the major part of the day at the Sultan's magnificent European style palace and it was my favourite attraction in Istanbul. We did the tour of the harem first, which had the most amazing red and clear glass chandeliers, unfortunately you can't take photos and there were no postcards or books with photos to do them justice. We left the main palace until last and encountered a big queue, so go here when you first arrive. The palace is quite amazing, although the guides don't give much information. The art gallery is well worth having a look around and the grounds are beautiful, with gates out onto the Bosphorus, but it was too rough to venture right to the shoreline the day we were there. Check out the impressive huge gates on the roadside too. The clock museum and crystal room was closed due to the low season, but the palace, art gallery and grounds more than justified the visit here. There's a lot to see so do try and give yourself 4 hours to make sure you see everything.
Historical Place. It was a great chance to visit such a wonderfull and historical palace, and see where the Othmani Sultan's were living before.

Beauty no boundaries! Amazing showcase of prosperity . One of the highlight of Istanbul. Heard so much about it prior to visiting yet amazed by the place. Atleast 3 hours required to view the public and private areas. Also the paintings collection area is worth a visit.Have read mixed reviews about the guides. But our guide was very nice. Her English was quite nice, voice loud and sharp and good knowledge about the place.

Could be very interesting but visitor experience needs radical improvement. Out of season we stood for a long time queuing for ticket and then entrance in damp weather, then were herded around the interior in too large a group at far too fast a speed. The guide's English was hopelessly indistinct or inaudible. Information provided would amount to a couple of small paragraphs on a pamphlet. A frustrating and disappointing experience. The management should visit other extremely popular sites to learn how it should be done.

A wonderful palace in a beautiful setting.. The Dolmabahce Palace is a gem with its extraordinary blending of Ottoman and European architecture set on the shores of the Bosphorus.Touring the interior of this wonderful building with its displays of opulence one can almost feel as though it was indeed a defiant 'last hurrah' as the end of imperialism drew closer.The 20th century history of the building is also of interest as it was Ataturk's Istanbul base in the early days of the republic.The palace is well worth a visit and it is very easy to get to being only a short tram ride across the Golden Horn and then a couple of kilometres to the Kabatas terminus where several commuter ferries leave from as well as Bosphorus tour boats.

قصر دولما Dolmabahce.. المكان جدا جميل لاكن مواقف السيارات قليله فتاكد من حظورك في اوقات خارج الذروهالمكان قريب من معالم اخرى كالساعة ومسجد ومتحف وحديقتين. تاكد من وجود خريطه المكان في متناول اليد. يوجد مواقف لسيارات. تاكد ان تستخدمه حيث ان المكان مزدحم ولاتوجد فيه مواقف مناسبه.Make sure to have the map of the area ready since this masterpiece is sounded by other historical spots, and two parks. Just make sure to utilize pay as you go parking spots since the place is so crowed

Absolutely stunning!. Puts English stately homes and palaces to shame! Very reasonable entrance fee plus knowledgeable English speaking guide included in the price (don't bother to do organised tour, just book on the door but go early).

One of the best . There is a little of palaces like this..Grand, unique, beautiful, a lot of history and a wonderful park around and all of that just on the shoulder of sea..Cafés there are good and prices are acceptable
A Ali . Nice have to check it out if you ever go Istanbul, place where the king used to go hunting and rest after hunting

History in one place. A must see attraction in Istanbul, morning prefered with a lot of ottoman empire architecture and lovely old furniture and carpets, you can also see the room of Kamal Ataturk where he spent his last minutes

Grand and beautiful ! . Unlike the other historical places in istanbul , this palace is quite different it its own way . Made if white marble it looks amazingly fresh with the river flowing behind make it looks more scenic !
wonderful place. this is one of the must see place in Istanbul. english speaking guide was extremely good, kept me interesting throughout the journey.
Impressive . The Palace is very impressive . When you understand that you aren't in France nor Italy ,it is amazing.

Dolmabahçe. Dolmabahçe Palace is best accessed from the final tram stop, and a short brisk walk along the ferry wharves. Early fall meant trees turning their best colors out. Pity we weren't allowed pictures. Be sure to visit the paintings museum and harem for a fuller experience by taking a ticket accordingly from the gate. Amazing chandeliers and well educated guides lead groups of visitors. On the shores of the Bosphorous. Afternoon visit highly recommended to catch a different skyline past 5 pm

next time, be early!. This is an amazing palace - even from the outside. It is located at the Besiktas area. As the seat of the Ottoman administration in the late 19th and early 20th century, this is a massive place to visit. Be sure to be there early as this is one of the top destinations and lines can be VERY long..we could only visit the grounds..
Stunning!. But it was a shame we weren't allowed to take any photos, the whole place was amazing! The chandeliers were absolutely out of this world!

A Palace Well Worth Visiting. In Istanbul you can easily get tired of visiting the many mosques, museums and palaces, but Dolmabahce is definitely a must-see. Located on the Bosporus and relatively new by Istanbul standards, it was the residence of latter day Ottoman sultans and, eventually, the residence of Ataturk, the father of modern Turkey. A good guide makes the tour all the better - our was good, but not excellent.

An intriguing palace, weak tour. If i were rating just the palace and not the whole experience, this would beca five star event. However, one is required to enter through a tour either in english or turkish unless one pays extra for an outside tour group, which many do. My preference however us to visit places on my schedule and pace rather than that of someone else. Getting there via most tour groups is to simply sit in the bus or van. On your own the choices are taxi and public transportation. To get there via public transportation is not difficult: take the t1 tram line to the last stop in Asia istanbul and then walk down the street (in the same direction as the tram was going) and you will be there in a few minutes. Once there you will need to buy either a main house ticket, a harem ticket, or both. Warning: the harem is Not out of Scheherazade, but rather a series of rooms as in any residence. The main house is clearly more impressive but there are some interesting rooms in the harem. If you buy both together you get a 10 tl discount. You should probably get both. After you get in line they run a tour every 30 minutes or so. You have to put plastic wraps on your shoes and wait for the tour. In the english tour you may get many people who speak any language except turkish: english, Spanish, french, arabic, and German were in our group. Our guide was late so we started late. Sometimes guides are inspired people who revel in the property they present, but our guides had memorized speeches in English who were clearly happy to get through each spiel. The only time i saw them animated was when they talked to other guides in their native turkish. I am sure they were good people but this was just a job. We were hurried past many rooms, with longer stops at the big three rooms. The palace was very impressive more in a european than turkish style (as intended when it was missed) but the need to hurry through did not allow one to see or appreciate the details and fully take in the grandeur. No questions were allowed until the end, apparently so we did not interrupt the planned speech lest the whole thing be lost. By the end i just wanted out and couldn't remember the questions. Leaving this part of the tour one then walked halfway around this very large building to the harem where we waited for another twenty minutes for that tour as the tours were not coordinated. That one was shorter and less impressive but still interesting. However, the tour remained stale and flat and the information they gave is already in any competent travel book. Also no pictures were allowed. I understand no flash but not no pictures. We are charged to enter but cannot keep any reminders or remembrances. I do not know if this is to make money from the gift shop or just to keep the tour moving quickly. Topkapi palace is much more tourist friendly in all these regards. Overall i am glad i saw it and 40tl is not an excessive charge. But the whole thing could be better presented: more enthusiasm if nothing else. If i wasn't so cheap and on my own schedule i would consider visiting this with a personal tour guide but not with another large mixed group which simply cost more money. If you are in the city for more than a day, though, try to see this site.

Beautiful palace but some disappointments . Tours are required, which would be great if they provided more historical context for those without extensive knowledge of Turkish history. The highlight of the tour is the largest chandelier in Europe, but disappointingly it wasn't lit up. Also, this appears to be a favorite of school groups. On the upside the views of the water are great and the gardens are pretty, even in Nov. The on site cafe had good deserts to enjoy with tea.

A visit to this palace near Taksim Sqaure and on the Bosporus was well worth it. Easily accessible by the tram we spent a morning visiting this palace built by a sultan in the middle 1800's it rivals any western European palace visit. Ataturk lived here when the Turkish republic was established in 1923. All tours are guided and are included in the ticket price, however our guide spoke English with such an accent it was quite difficult to understand her.

Palace . This is my third time there. I visited it only for being kind to my friend, who had never been there before. This time I visited as an individual. 3 hours.... 3 hours for a tour... Wait in line for the next English speaking group to walk you around the visitors area, go to another line, wait again for another group to take you to the harem area and then go to the next building to see the paintings... It was really tiring and for some reason I think that I haven't seen as much as I saw the other times, maybe I underestimate the painting gallery but I was really tired when I got there

A must visit place in Istanbul. Save 2 or 3 hours to visit Dolmabahce Palace and the garden along the Bosphorus.You may wish to also visit the harem and the glass room but for me it was not that impressive
Amazing !. Great piece of local history, a must see during your next trip to Istanbul. It refreshes your day and relaxing views.

beautiful, even though unauthentic... . As an architecture student, I am not a huge fan of baroque, rococo and all ornamental styles but the grandeur and aristocracy of this Palace is not as intimidating as I thought. Looks like it would fit better in a roman context rather than Ottoman Turkey. The interior is beautiful even though unauthentic.  Our guide was not an architecture expert but overall it was a pleasant trip through the palace.
nice. it is another nice places of istanbul.this palace is vary beautiful and nice.it is good to go and visit this place
Gorgeous. Istambul is a magical place, has a lot of attractions and Dolmabahce palace is one of the mos beautyfull of them. Just go and don't forget to respect the costumes of the local.

Ottoman Empire's pleasure and luxury. Dolmabahçe Palace is one of many examples that gives one an insight into the Ottoman Empire's pleasure and luxury lifestyle. It is located on the European shore line of the Bosphorus in Istanbul and is very easy to spot. Very eye catching for any tourist. I had only viewed the outside of the palace during a ferry cruise on the Bosphorus , but it is indeed a  symbol of the magnificence and beauty against the shoreline.

Gr8 Place to visit. what a palace ! just on the Bosphorus. you see Luxury inside.they let you enter by group, and there is a guide all over the visit. very interesting. But a queue will be waiting for you before you enter !

It is out of this century - must go palace. If you ve ever been and liked the Schonbrunn or the Versailles you will love Dolmabahce. Its not as big as the mentioned other two palaces but it is grand and awesome. The gardens are great ... with in the palace there are guides that take you on tour in groups - you can not roam about by yourself. I love all the glamour and old school class... Check it out but you cant go inside with young children there was an age limitation / no beverages allowed... Mondays closed

A gorgeous palace. The inside of the palace is beautiful, one of the few monument I visited which contains furniture! (certainly because it's still running as a admnistrative building)The gardens are very nice too. The doors to the sea are impressive!

Great Palace. We walked to this from Sultanahmet area. The tram was shut down for the marathon. It was about 4-5 km. Nice walk and easy to get to. The palace ground was very nice. The palace had a guided tour in English. The group size was pretty large but the palace is so big it didn't feel very crowded. The tour it self took 30 min. We paid for the palace tour which includes couple of other sites and the Haram. Haram was also a guided tour for the first 10 min and then you were on your own. No pictures in these are but that didn't stop some of the tourist. What asham.
Not as great as Topkapi. No concerns, it's very luxury palace, beautiful interiors etc. But it looks too posh and I can say the owner hasn't taste.
Luxury european palace !. It's a luxury palace built in European style,with golded walls,crystal chandeliers,marble,fountains,and a lot of paintings,it must be seen !
Beautiful view from the cafe. Cafe at the entrance is good beautiful view. They are closed on Monday. So plan your visit accordingly.

Toured while staying in the Taskim Square area. This took the greater part of half a day. It is a beautiful palace with an incredible history. Do not miss if you are in the newer side of the city. It was not high on our list and it should have been. Great guides make sure you take the English tour if that is your spoken language.Of course there is a place for the wives and concubines.

A Sultan's delight. Absolute splendour. Really well laid out. You get a great feeling of what a grand life the Sultans lived. The place is topical as President Ataturk stayed there until his death. We happened to visit during the anniversary of his death.The halls are magnificent. This compares to some of the grandest palaces I have visited. A must-see in Istanbul
wonderful. most place i love in Istanbul you must visit it  and have nice gardns and harem hous . it`s great Turkish palce

New Palace. I am a little regret that I did not go there in the morning or earlier afternoon. I think I was there around 3 p.m. They just sold me the ticket to see Domabahce Place, not Harem or other gallery (e.g. photo museum?). Pity that I did not see the president or other ambassadors. Pity that I can not dance on the floor. LOL!

Amazing Palace. We went there because it was part of an excursion that included a cruise down the Bosporus, but were very glad we didn't miss this. It was one of the most opulent places I've ever seen, with gifts from many heads of state to the Sultan - the gifts were in duplicate since he liked symmetry. We were able to see part of the harem, although not the bedrooms, and could imagine what life was like there. The gardens and access to the sea were also extraordinary.
Stunning step into the history of a Harem. Magnificant interior. Jaw dropping splendor . Opulence and Grandeur -amazing. Fascinating history into the Sultan's Harem and how they really existed.

Nothing special. Waiting in line from entrance to first steps in palace took nearly an hour. . In palace you enter only with a large group and with unimpressed guide who is bored of his job and hates tourists. It was difficult to understand what the tour guide was saying, he had a very strong Turkish accent. Also you are not allowed to take pictures insides for security reasons. I was in July there, the weather was hot and the palace was with out any air conditioner.
Very beautiful. We like this very much . Very very good location . Every place that we visit had good guide who explain about it very helpful .

Mrs kour . Absolutely lovely The security is very high at the Palace Which is expected just be careful if you have children On my second visit a 3 year old touched the rug in the ceremony hall and was yanked up by a guard and shaken and abused It was very abusive and disgusting to see this grown man attack a baby So make sure you don't touch anything Even as you go up the crystal stair case with the plastic bags they make u wear and u almost slip off Don't hold onto the barrister You will get told offIt is beautiful But the abuse you occur while being there and the redness from staff is something u need to prepare for And make sure you do not even attempt to take photos They have security cameras everywhere, I had to Google pics to show my family of the inside palace .This palace can only be visited with a tour guide in a group It is the way the keep track of guests
Must do. You must see this place in order to understand the role of the Ottoman Turks in history. Best seen during the "Shoulder season" when crowds are less

You must put this on your list of attractions to visit in Istanbul. While the majority of tourist attractions are on the other side of the Galata Bridge, a visit to the Dolmabache Palace is a must. We are conveniently located at the Four Seasons Bosphorus and our hotel made a reservation for us as they only allow 3000 visitors per day. While you can still try your luck and queue, I like some certainty in my day. The Palace sits on the Bosphorus and was built after the Sultan moved from the Topkapi Palace. It is majestic. Clearly minimalists would not enjoy living here - the furnishings are ornate. The chandeliers are spectacular. Wait until you get to the end and you are presented with the formal room with the amazing dome. This place is up there with Versailles. And it is worth buying a ticket to include the Harem so you understand what their living quarters were like compared to the to the formal areas in the Palace.
Stunning. I couldn't actually believe my eyes when I saw this palace..It was magnificent.. the colours the decor .. everything was stunning. Regal and royal.. wouldn't mind living in there lol

Blown away, very unexpected. This was a fantastic experience. The opulence and attention to detail throughout the palace just boggles the mind. The main atrium or hall is outstanding. Definitely a must.

Beautiful Palace. The palace is really beautiful. As photography was not allowed inside it, we could just capture it in our memories. You are not allowed to roam around inside the palace on your own, you need to join the group tours starting every 15 mins. The furniture, carpets, chandeliers etc. are in a very good condition and well maintained.We loved the Café / restaurant in the garden of the palace. I can spend hours sitting there and enjoy the amazing view of Istanbul.

A great place to visit.. What a human may astonshed by is the huge amount of gold that has been used during construction . Some says that they used about 8 tons of gold.Also you can realize the high ceiling which is full of a wonderful painting graphics, and graet seens of the sea through the palace windows.Don't miss to visit the oclocks museum near the palace.

On my top 3 Istanbul things to do. This is a place you definitely have to go to. Guided tours are mandatory (English and Turkish) but you don't have to wait too much (10mins). We would recommend going to this palace rather than the Beylerbeyi palace in Uskudar (if you're limited on time).

Disappointed. I must first start by saying I am so surprised by everyone's reviews of the Dolmabahce Palace after touring the grounds. The Palace and grounds itself is very splendour, the views of the Bosporous River and the grand decor within the Palace. The only way to tour the Palace is by guide only available in Turkish and English. Also keep in mind there is no photography anywhere but outside the Palace. Everyone queues up outside the Palace until you escorted inside. The guided tour was a bit dated and the Palace was in need of historical refurnishing and a good cleaning to preserve the Palace. The guided tour provided minimal history and our guide was similar in personality to that of a robot. The Palace is only about 159 years old, and showcased the Sultan's and the first President. The Palace furnishings and decor was absolutely amazing however it was very difficult to see everything through all the dust sitting on the surfaces. The chandlers were our favourite part. The Harem was also guided and in Turkish or English with another queue to wait in. The Harem guided tour was a joke with zero history and would not acknowledge the true history of the Harem. If you are wishing to visit the concubine dormitory you are out of luck, the only part of the Harem tour you are allowed to see is the upstairs royalty tour. The entire admission price per person with the Harem is 40tl: Palace Tour 45 minutes, Harem 30 minutes. If you want a guided history lesson this isn't your place. If you compare this to Versailles you definitely slept through that tour. Good luck in whatever you choose.

Didn't disappoint. The main was really grandiose and you could see why the palace almost bankrupted an empire. No photo was allowed inside but it was hard to fight the urge to take out the camera. Nice visit, real contrast with Topkapi. Could see why the sultan wanted to build a new one.
An Adventure in Turkeye. This a palace from the sultan era, full of history and gorgeous furniture, chandeliers, staircase, hand made rugs.
the Versailles of Istanbul. The sultan knew how to leave then. It is an incredible Palace. together with the Harem, not to be missed. Beautifull Painting gallery too.

Amazing excess, but over the top.. Constructed to emulate nineteenth century European excess, this extensive structure still serves ceremonial purposes of state. Do not miss the museum of state paintings.

the finest palace i have visited so far.
