I Have visited several palace around the world, but this one took my breath away..The ceilings carved with gold was magnificient..The whole palace is so elaborate and has several crystal chandeliors esp the 4.5 tons chandelior in the ceremonial hall...all the hall that we visited were mesmerizing.please dont miss this one..you would be in awe with this palace

Must see. Don't miss this highlight attraction. Absolutely beautiful and amazing.We visited all the major Istanbul sites, and almost didn't get to this because it was a bit further from our hotel. It turned out the be our favorite of them all.

over rated, expensive but a magnificent place. this should be amongst the most grand and beautiful palaces in the world. I visited it in 2004 and this year. I felt that the price has increased a lot and the time you spend in the palace is a lot less. It is very expensive and the cafeteria outside is also expensive. on the positive side as stated above it is a very nice place with a lot of history in it.

Choose Carefully!. By any measure Dolmabahce is one of the most visited historic sites in Istanbul and it shows. The crowds are enormous, lines are long you must take a guided tour which are very poorly organized. These guided tours can have upwards of 100 people on them, making them very disorganized. In addition, much of the palace has been allowed to become very drabey, such as the carpet that you walk on during the tour. I would definitely not due the tour again. Nonetheless, the grounds of the palace are splendid and you can access some of them without having to pay the tour fee.

Highlight of my trip to Istanbul. Step inside Dolmabahce Palace and let it transport you to the late 1800's to see what life was like for the Ottoman Sultans. This palace took our breath away on more than a few occasions. The gold and crystal interiors were absolutely stunning! Seeing the rooms where Ataturk spent the last days of his life were also a highlight. Do not miss the opportunity to see this and don't skip the Harem either :)

A must see if you visit Istanbul . WOW is the best way to sum up Dolmabahce Palace. You can't take photos inside only of the gardens and the outside of the building, which it totally understandable when you see inside. It's stunning, so big, the crystal, the carpets, the decor and furniture. We decided to do a full day tour, doing the cruise on The Bosphorus and The Golden Horn first. So we traveled past the Palace before we visited in the afternoon, giving us a total outside view of the Palace. Though it didn't prepare us for the splendour of the interior. Well worth every penny spent for the day.

Crossed another one off the bucket list. Firstly, there are a number of options you can buy as entrance tickets. We would recommend that you save a little and buy the Palace only ticket as this is the main attraction and well worth seeing. Downside is you cannot take any photos inside and they do have security inside patrolling the crowd to ensure this. However, the opulence of the palace will leave you with a wonderful memory of a place from time gone bye, truly beautiful. Some of the best photo shots are from outside the Palace, just walk around the grounds, the Bosporus is a great backdrop for some of your photos. They have a nice little coffee/dessert café close to the Harem which is great for a break, non smoking indoors. During the summer months when the gardens are in full bloom it must be even more spectacular.

The palace is huge, and servers as a museum since the 1930s. This is a very beautiful and imposing building, both inside and out. As per our guide, the name means this is a structure built on water (ie reclaimed land). It is well worth a visit,
A must see in Istanbul. Absolutely spectacular opulence on a grand scale, beautiful architecture, lovely gardens and a magic settling on the banks of the Bosphorus

Not to be missed in Istanbul. Dolmabahce Palace ended up being one of my favorite attractions in Istanbul. The guided tour was informative, and it was fascinating to see the rooms of the last Ottoman rulers. The grounds were stunning and hearing the history of the building and its excesses was simply incredible.

Interesting Palace!. This was my second visit to Palace although my previous visit was many years ago. Visits are now by guided tour only and we had to wait some time before the tour started. What we saw was worth the wait although progress round the Palace was slow due to the large number of people in the tour.
Victorian era Sultans palace. This is actually much more interesting than Topkapi as its rooms are huge and impressive. A real wow factor. It is well worth a visit.

Grand 19th Century Palace. This grand 19th century palace was the home of the last Sultans and includes some impressive interiors, most particularly the Crystal Staircase and the Ceremonial Hall. Unlike many palaces in Western Europe, the Dolmabahce retains much its original furniture and decorations. Unfortunately, visits are only by guided tour (which are rushed and take too many people in each group) and photography is no longer permitted inside. Visits in the morning are recommended as the number of visitors permitted each day is limited. The palace’s front façade is best viewed from a cruise on the Bosphorus.

WOW- Unbelievable Splendour!. We toured this palace as part of a shore excursion on a cruise. It is one of the modern palaces and is ornate, but gorgeous and though "over the top" is still so beautiful and important in Turkish history. Wish that more rooms were on display. There is much to see, the grounds are also beautiful so try to take your time. Unfortunately , photos are not permitted in side the Palace. My memories will have to suffice. Highly recommend to see .

If Hollywood built a palace set for a movie, it would be the Dolmabahce Palace. Istanbul straddles Asia and Europe. The Topkapi palace is an excellent example of opulence the Asian side has to offer. But, enter the Dolmabahce Palace, and you are transported to the over-the-top best that Europe had to offer to those who constructed this place! The most opulent palaces in Europe have nothing on this place.
Amazing views. This was an extrodanary visit. Beautiful palace. Lots of history. Pitty you cannot take pictures but will still recommend it.

The versailles of Istanbul. Gold, marble and royal living. Excellent gifts. Impressions, psychological mind games played by use of light and colors.
Guide included in the ticket price

Beautiful Architecture. Lovely Palace - furniture and accessories amazing - so much of effort, time and intricate - a must see. Lots of history. No photos allowed inside. Lots of walking and lots of stairs. Lovely Paintings.

A great palace worth the entry fee. Although the palace is in Istanbul and right next to the Bosphorus it seemed to not fit with other main attractions in Istanbul. The palace seemed so very European and less Turkish somehow. Plus you were forced to go with a tour group that was too large and went through the palace too fast. Despite all that it is an incredible palace with lots to see. It is a short walk of maybe 1/2 mile from the end of one of the tram runs so easy to get to despite the fact that there is not much else to see around there except for the Bosphorus.

Unique European Style Attraction. This palace reminded me more of European design and architecture than the other sights in Istanbul, so in that way it was a nice change of pace. The palace has some remarkable elements, such as the huge chandelier and original furniture. However, it was very crowded (even in the off season) with tour groups. Also, you had to enter with a tour and follow the guide around, so that you could not explore at your own pace. The information that the guide provided was interesting, but the tour was large so it was hard to hear him sometimes. Also, I couldn't get a great look at things before we had to move on. Still, I would check this place out! You can explore the grounds and art gallery on your own, so that provides a more leisurely time. In the process of the tour you will also learn a bit about the life of the last royal family in Istanbul.

Marvellous . It is a kind of tour you try to imagine what it was look like sultan life.if you went there try to leave yourself for imagination about the luxury life .Especially the harem section where it was a special window for each one to share in ceremonies.

Could have been a better experience . Although I was looking forward to seeing dolmabache palace, I was let down by the forced guided tours. It was difficult to understand what the tour guide was saying, he had a very strong Turkish accent. Also you are not allowed to take pictures insides for security reasons.

Give yourself enough time. I really enjoyed the Palace ad all the furnishing. Very beautiful and allows you to get a glimpse of the graduer. The admission includes the tours of the Palace, Ladies area and a painting museum. So give yourself enough time (3 hrs) to enjoy what you paid for.Interesting note. It i still being used to host gatherings

a modern palace..... a must go if you are intrested in history , palaces, etc. there are guided tours inside the palace so you wont miss any items , but you are not free to roam around and have a look has to be with the group that you go. the chandliers are worth a sight.
Just amazing. It's the perfect place to see how the last Sultans lived. A lot of luxury. If you travel to Istanbul you MUST visit this place. It is closed on fridays.

GORGEOUS PALACE NEXT TO BOSPHORUS. It worth visiting even for the location itself. The main attraction is very nice and I would say enough, since my only concern is for being offered a full visit ticket (4 places) but able to do just two.

Great way to see how the Sultan's lived. We visited the palace as part of a tour organised through our hotel. The guide was very knowledgeable and gave a great insight into family an official life of a Sultan.

A Bit of France in Turkey. A pretty new building in the scheme of things for Istanbul and only used for a short period by the Ottoman Emperors till the collapse of the Empire . Modelled on French Castles it is an impressive & large building in beautiful grounds on the rivers edge. Well worth an afternoon visit.

Pure Opulence. Well worth the visit just to see the pure opulence of the palace. There is no wonder why it put the empire into bankruptcy. We only had time to tour the Selamlik area. Once again, very popular so arrive early.
enjoyed the visit. This 19th century palace has beautiful gardens and an impressive interior. Admission includes a guided tour that is very interesting and informing.

Dolmabache Palace. Being the relatively newer palace (in use only after mid 1800s; before that Topkapi was used) Dolmabache looks more like a modern European palace than Turkish. Its huge and the entire tour will take maybe an hour. A highlight is the crystal chandeliers which are still displayed. They have a compulsory guided tour which is actually good as the guide will explain the significance and history behind each section. It's located by the sea and has some great views as well.

It must be on your list "THINGS TO SEE IN ISTANBUL". Great point to learn something about the history. You need at least 4 hours to see everything. Every visit inside buildings is in group with guide, you can not enter alone. If goup is too big it is good to walk close to the guide to hear what he says.

Amazing!!. A must visit place in Istanbul! You are speechless infront of this beauty near bosporus..It is very close to taksim square.You can take a taxi but be aware about the price.Ask before you go in because they can cheat on you.

Elegant but crowded. The palace is very beautiful, full of luxury items and history. However you will need to visit it in a group lead by guide. It is good in a way that you'll get some background of the place but you'll need to walk at their pace and you'll get little time to spend in admiring it. Plus, the group size is big, it feels quite crowded. Oh also, they don't allow photo taking inside.

What a place!. We went in early to get ahead of the tour groups. The system is very efficient, you are grouped together and given a guide. Unfortunately my hearing is not 10/10 so I missed a lot of what was said. I would have preferred to have been given the option of renting a set of headphones. What really got to me were the East Asians insisting on taking pictures which are not allowed. Is this what 'new money' makes you feel you are entitled to or is there something go there that we do. To know about? I am not referring to Chinese, my confrontation was with a Japanese group who flaunted the rules and commented on I amongst themselves. Where has the pride and cicipline of this deeply embedded culture gone. The Palace is an absolute MUST on you visitors list. We have over the years spent more than a month totally in Istambul and still there are new discoveries all the time. With Trip Advisor prompting and probing for new reviews we see items and places we never knew existed - good work Trip Advisor, you are opening a new world to us. Soon Trip Advisor will,become the travel handbook of society. Here we see what other have experienced, not what a journalist have written. You have created a great filter in the ever changing world of travel. Just a great pity you are 20 years too late. If it was then I would have had a totally different experience.
O M G!!!. Stunning, awesome, breathtaking,unbelievable, words simply can't describe the magnificence of this building

A Beautiful Palace. The problem in visiting Dolmabache is the queue to get in. During the holidays you can expect to wait 2 hours in line before you get in. The best time to go is when it is freezing cold and there are no tourists :) This time it wasn't cold but the line wasn't bad. Don't miss this palace! Visiting it will make you feel that you've transported in time.

The most impressing toursite to visit. Dolma bachche is the most impressive and for sure the toursite that none should miss visiting when visiting istanbul. It was the sultans house for years and its all made from wood which is quite impresive. The floor its all covered with caprets and it has very nice feeling walking through. Υοu will be very impressed to see how the sultans used to live and the view is impresive. Dont miss this site!!!
Don't miss it. Having toured several palaces this fall from Vienna to Istanbul, this one is not to be missed. Actually the most impressive of all in certain respects.
I would live here!. Definitely my favorite palace. The sultan's entry from the Bosphorus is fantastic. Really enjoyed the morning we spent here and our tour guide was fantastic.

Breathtaking!!!. This was not on our list of places to visit but it was pouring rain so we decided to have a look. The tours start every 30/40 mins but they are not good at explaining this when you are waiting but oh was it worth the wait. I have travelled to many places around the world but this was the most luxurious place I have ever seen. The crystal chandeliers were the size of a small room. They are very very strict about not taking photos & if you do they will insist they are deleted. Beautiful grounds to see too.

The Sultans nod to Versailles. After visiting Versailles, the sultan decided he needed an opulent palace. Over 300 rooms, the tour takes you through the main areas. The only drawback for us, was the large crowd they take through on the English tour. Most of the people did not speak English and were quite rude, so we could not hear the young lady making the presentation. It is a beautiful palace and worth the visit.
One of the most beautiful palaces ever seen. It's our second visit. It's so beautiful that you feel the urge to visit it again. Everything inside is opulent and luxurious. It's simply amazing
Worth visiting. We had a fantastic guide who was explaining everything in details. Visit only possible with a group o guide. Worth going!!!

A true sultan palace. Dolmabahce palace was built in the 19 century when Topkapi palace no longer was suitable to show and represent the big power and wealth of the Empire and of the Sultan....a mixture of Oriental and Western art, an impressive palace, and the last room of the tour can compete with any of the most representatives in the worlds palaces...

Emotional experience... Palace of beauty. When you step into the palace it takes you straight back into history. The amazing architecture, interior of the palace blows you away.
The room where Kemal Ataturk died was highly emotional for me. It is definitely worth a visit.
Good place to visit. a really good place to visit, quite a lot to see so come with plenty of time. We got the bus here and walked back to Taksim square. Would recommend a visit if you have some time!

Beautiful!. This palace is well worth visiting! Apart from the pure grandeur evident in the furnishings and chandeliers, the tour gives you some insight into the workings and culture of the Sultan's government during the later Ottoman period. Also, take the Harem Tour which shows the apartments and living quarters for the women living there, ie the Sultans wives and mother. Also, saw the room in which Ataturk died.The tour is always organized and guided by someone already there for you, so you can just take the tram and then walk a short distance along the Bosphorous to the palace. The tour of the main palace was very good but the Harem tour guide's English was not so good and his descriptions were fairly brief. I came away wanting to know more about the Harem culture but will have to pursue that on my own, I guess. Overall, well worth seeing---beautiful palace and grounds.

History an Today. First of all, the palace is located just near bosphorus, thus you gonna see a beautiful view while waiting for entering into the palace. Before you go the place, check the entrance hours otherwise you may miss the entrance hours. It is recommended to see all the palace but if you have visited harem part of any other Ottoman palace, it would be the same concept for you.
Amazing Palace. The structure was wonderful and had lot of history to each of the rooms in the palace.you definelty need a guide here as one needs to understand the palace well.

Rococcoooooooooo.... Love It.. Too Much is an understatement. But I love it.This is a palace in the whole sense of the word.Okay. So there are bigger and richer palaces in the world, but this one is homogeneous from start to finish.Everything fits together - well maintained.And the guides are very well learned - very informative.

Palace of closed doors. Waiting in line from entrance to first steps in palace took nearly an hour. But that's OK. In palace you enter only with a large group and with unimpressed guide who is bored of his job and hates tourists. Palace itself is a huge meh. You can not take pictures inside as they tell you, but if you are sneaky enough and find something worth photographing you can take a picture or two. I thought they don't allow to take pictures so you don't destroy reputation of this palace as something special when it's not. Halls are coverd in dust, dirt and bad design. Lavish, oh yes, bit without taste and passion. Mostly without passion of those who take care of the palace now. Harem is almost the same as main palace. Maybe a bit better. Garden is really beautiful and view to Bosphorus strait. That's it. Good part: with ISIC you can enter for 5 lira.

Nice place.. This a nice place to see, especially on a rainy day as it is indoors. A very nice old building with sprinkles of history but not something as heavy as Top kapi. Palaces like that can be found all over Europe with a much more interesting strory to tell. Here you can acknowledge the great gesture Ataturk did to Europe by trying to make Turkey a european state. If he had failed, no one knows how the world could be today. Not more than 100 years ago, in this very palace, women could not attend celebrations together with men. You will hear the story in the big room where the biggest chandelier of Europe is placed!

Worth a visit, but is in the European style. This palace is built way after the Tokapi Palace, modeled after the styles of the European palaces. Its decoration is very luxurious and it witnesses the last days of the Ottoman Empire. However, if you are looking for the traditional Ottoman stuff, this may not be the best place. The views by the Bosphorus are very nice. Entrance tickets are expensive and entrance is not included in the Istanbul museum pass. Its entrance includes free guided tour (in fact you must follow these tours to see the interior), which is informative, but rather crowded.

Rainy day. The palace itself looks a lot better if you take the bosphorus boat tour. There is no slowing down the influx of tourists, so it´s hard to really enjoy this Palace without being pushed around by tourists.

Best place we went during our visit. It became the palace of the sultan after 1856 and remained as such until 1922/23 when the Empire fell. It is a beautiful location on the Bosphorus and the rooms ans contents are terrific. We saw it the same day we went to Topkapi and it is a great combination. Unlike Topkapi, Dolmabahce is a real palace.

Beautiful gardens, historical value. this is a great place to visit if you have an extra day in Istanbul and have seen all the other recommended sites. the building itself has interesting historical value and the gardens and the view of the bosphorus truly makes it a worthwhile excursion, particularly on a nice day. Warning, huge crowds in peak season from April to October which means waiting in long queues to get in, but it's worth the wait.
Nice place to see.. Note that this place is closed on monday and thursday.and if the place was too crowded they don't allow more visitors to enter in.

Worth visiting. If you are visiting Istanbul, Dolmabahce Palace is a must. Magnificent gardens which you can visit without paying the entrance fee. The fee to visit the palace and the Harem is 40TL expensive but well worth it. It has a rich decor and very classy. Listen to the guide carefully to enhance the experience of visiting the palace. Take notice of the chandelier.

Beautiful Palace, Mean Guides and Guards. We had heard this palace was quite stunning inside and out with European inspired architecture and gardens. This was definitel the case. And while visitors were free to roam the grounds, you needed a ticket to get inside the main palace, plus a separate add on ticket to visit the harem. We got both tickets and needed to join a tour in order to go inside. On this particular day, there were at least 50 of us on the tour. The guide spent a significant amount of time yelling at people "no photos" and I'm pretty sure security followed up with those breaking the rules ensuring they deleted the photos. What irritated me the most was the hypocritical guard, Mr. Koruma, allowing certain individuals to take photos when he thought no one was looking. They just happened to be young, pretty girls. When I caught him taking photos of the girls in the harem, I couldn't resist the urge to yell "no photos!" Lol

Opulence Extraordinaire. This is the palace beyond your wildest dreams. Not only is it huge, but it is located in one of the best spots on the Bosphorus and the interior is so lavishly decorated that it is hard to believe. It makes Buckingham Palace look like a shack.

Breathtaking. The level of detail and intricacy in the architecture was absolutely fabulous, and the tour was very informative. We were taken through huge, stunning rooms, stuffed with original features and furniture, by a very informative and concise tour guide. It was utterly inspiring, learning about the different types of crystal used in two of the world's biggest chandeliers. While you can't explore the inside of the Palace yourself (for obvuous reasons, I wouldn't trust myself let loose among all those delicate,beautiful vases given as a gift by Kaiser Wilhelm either) you can wander round the lush, green grounds, which is worth it.

Dolmabache Palace. Amazing preservation of the opulence that the Sultans lived in. The crystal staircase and Chandeliers are outstanding and the furnishings have been well preserved. The location and the gate are beautiful. Agree with those that said to skip the Harem tour...Long wait for a tour that just shows you more of the same unless you are a history buff and want to see where Aataturk died.Well worth the long trip in the rain we took

One of the best experiences in Istanbul.. During my full-day private tour of Istanbul, I had a choice of visiting the Spice Market or the Dolmabahce Palace, and I am glad I chose the latter. Having a private guide gave me prime and immediate access to the interior. The staff does a wonderful job of staggering tour groups into the Palace; no overcrowding is allowed. As I walked through with my guide, many times we appeared to have the place to ourselves. All the rooms and furnishings show their age but are in great condition. Even though much of the inside is closed off from the public, what can be seen is amazingly authentic and beautiful and resembling the modern European style of the period. From the outside, one can see how grand the Palace is and appreciate its location on the Bosphorus Strait.

French influenced palace of the last sultans of Turkey. The palace is huge with giant chandeliers from England and lots of French style furniture. The ceilings were magnificent with many floral insets and lots of carved wood and gypsum. The view of the Bosphorus was gorgeous and the gardens very serene. You can see why the family moved from Tokapi Palace.

Beautiful historical Palace complex. The Palace is not open every day but definitely worth a visit. The interior is well preserved and breathtaking. The compulsory guided tours unfortunately are crowded, the guide did not speak good English or loud enough, and there is no time to really stay and look at the amazing decorations. Take the tram to Kabatas, the Palace is close by.

Awestruck into Silence. For now I have the synonym for extravagance and that is Dolmabahce Palace. From the facade to the interior of the palace, I was amazed on the wealth of the Ottoman Empire. Upon entering the main building you will face a large reception area where the tour guide will wait to gather his group. We had to cover our shoes and been warned that taking photos is prohibited. The ceiling was decorated in gold (it's not real but gold plated) while the staircase was lined with crystals. The carpets, furniture, and decorations were all part of the ottoman era and were all well-maintained. The ballroom was really huge with the impressive 10,000-bulb chandelier hanging in its center. The guided tour was a nice touch in order to give explanations to all the rooms and also to organize the visitors which will minimize any tampering inside.Entrance is not free and it's a bit expensive. However I think they needed all those fees in maintaining the huge place.This is an attraction one shouldn't miss in Istanbul.
Fabulous crystal chandeliers and staircase.. It has a lot of the original furniture and decorative porcelain as well as an out standing staircase with crystal balustrades.

Loved every bit of it! . The luxurious interior decoration will amaze you! You get a guided tour which is very pleasant and interesting. I really loved the combination of architectures. Small piece of advice though, do not go for the "all palace" ticket, the harem part of the palace is not that different from the administrative part which makes it less enchanting. Also, the guide was not that informative and spoke very bad English which made it difficult for us to understand.

Dolmabahce Visit. Situated along the Bosphorus , Dolmabahce Palace is one of the largest palaces in Turkey. The interiors are well preserved and usually the tours are guided. It's quite far from Sultanahmet area and one must reach early to avoid long queues. However it's definitely worth a visit, as one gets to see a blend of Baroque and Ottoman architecture along with the breathtaking interiors.

Very beautiful, but....... A majestic 19th Century Palace, comparable to any in the rest of Europe. To control the number of visitors, the Palace offers guided tours only. Groups are large and tours are far too short, offering no time to linger in any of the magnificent rooms. Better a 50 minute tour than none at all, I suppose. But I shall not be back

Utter opulence. The most modern and European of the Sultan's palaces, it excels at opulence. The lovely facade, the size and number of reception rooms, the crystal chandeliers, the grand staircases, the huge rugs - its all designed to impress. Its setting on the Bosphorus is perfect, and the gardens are lovely.

Beautiful palace!. This palace is at par with the other royal palaces I have seen in Europe. It provides a very interesting insight into the transition of the the Ottoman Empire into the modern era. The grounds and structures are very well kept. This attraction should provide you with a very pleasant 3 hour experience atleast.
Pleased. A beautiful palace , closed on Mondays and Thursdays . There are cafes just at the banks of the sea with beautiful views..

ASTONISHINGLY AMAZING. This has to be the highlight of my trip to Istanbul. It's in my eyes the most beautiful palace in Istanbul. The mesmerising location on the sea with open gates and fences that makes it possible to view the view. We got tickets for both the palace and the Harem, it was 40 turkish lira. Although it's relatively alot, and you can go to one section and not the two. I really advise buying the combined ticket and going to both. The first section was where the issues of the country were dealt with and the second section is the Harem which is the house of the Sultan. The palace is special with all its decorations that are made of gold and real english crystals. The palace was designed by french designers (one that desgined the paris opera) and other english and italian designers. The tour inside is only done through a guided tour, and we had to wear plastic bags on our shoes (provided at the gate). The guided tour turned out to be at a great advantage, the guide had great english and explained very well everything important in the palace. The tour was also paced perfectly, wasn't too long or too short. I really recommend this palace.

Great tour. A must see to understand the Sultans progress into western world. The palace is a wow experience and the tour done by the palace is very informative. It gives you a good perspective of life in the palace

Beautiful, but expensive. It's a really wonderful palace, but it's expensive and photos are prohibited. It's worth the visit, though.For me it's an accurate picture of Istanbul. The main historic sights (such as the walls, churches, etc) were almost abandonned while the sultan palaces grew in gold and beauty. I'm sad about all the history that is being lost, but I recommend the visit to this palace to better understanding turkish culture.

Gaudy Opulence. Compared to the beautiful mosques,Topkapi Palace and other landmarks here in Istanbul, I found Dolmabahce to be somewhat garish. No wonder the masses revolt when their leaders spend so extravagantly to feed their egos!!! Loved the gardens and waterfront views of the Bosporous. Be prepared for long lines and slow progress thru the palace as you are included in large tour groups .

I wouldn't miss it!. This is the 'newer' palace and as I wrote I wouldn't miss it. It is very different from the Topkapi palace and the added benefit is that it has some furniture and it helps you to imagine life there.

A great visit!. This is a guided tour of the palace only, you can't wander around yourself. But the tour was very informative, even if a little rushed because we were the last tour of the day. The tour lasted about 45 minutes. The decor was stunning and well worth the visit.
What a palace. Every single detail in this place is beautiful. The entrance, the stairs, the rooms, chandeliers, and all others details emphasize the glory of its makers.
Great palace, always eager to see it gain. We had the palace and the harem tour, maybe it could be longer but still a great place ti see over and over again.

You may like it, but it wasn't my cup of tea . Of course the palace is very amazing and everything, but i didn't enjoy my time there I visited the Topkapi palace before visiting dolmabahce palace So there were always a comparison between them in my mind And of course the Topkapi palace wonThe main hall of the dolmabahce is magnificent it's the best part of the palace And also al the sea view us wonderful **don't pay for the total ticket there are nothing epically about it **photography is forbidden inside it

Spectacular Ottoman Palace on the waterfront. The spectacular Dolmabahce Palace is well worth a visit. The history, architecture, chandeliers, carpets, furniture, staircases are stunning. The tour first takes you through the front public/ business/ entertaining area of the Palace, and the second through the private quarters. It is worthwhile to visit the paintings area as well, as this gives an interesting insight into life in the Ottoman Empire. Also stroll around the bird aviary area, amazing looking hens and birds.

Palace with lots to see and right by the eBosphorus. Allow plenty of time for visiting the palace as there is so much to see. You have to queue for a number of the areas in the palace ,so you need to allow lots of time for your visit. However it is a site not to be missed.

Grandiose and a passage back into Ottoman time. Not to be missed when visiting Istanbul. The Palace is magnificent and enchanting and I was very impressed by the largest chandelier (in the world) presented by Queen Victoria. The ablutions are also very interesting with their protective cage to save the Sultan from being stabbed in the back.

Jaw dropping luxury. The Dolmabahce Palace is the last nugget created by the Ottoman Empire. Here you can see the sultan's perverse luxury and it will take your breath away again and again. Expect slow lines as they have to guided tours every 20-30 min (Turkish or English). Our first guide had a strong and firm voice and polite attitude. The guide in the Harem part of the palace was the complete opposite.
Awsome. Great guided tours and superb craftsmanship from across the century's from all over the world. Only downside is that it is so popular, get there early.
Nice Palace. Compared with with Top Kapi much more rich decorated inside and outside. Very good location on the Bosphorus. Highly recommend to visit.

Disappointing!. Personally, I am a massive fan of original Ottoman or Seljuk Architecture, and this palace was far from that.... Baroque! Topkapi palace was much more interesting. Security is no joke. If you cannot speak Turkish be prepared for rude security personnel who have no patience. Oh and no photos!@instagram

Magnificant architectue and artistry. It was not wonder the Sultan ran out of money and had to complete this palace in stages. It was amazing! Truly a work of art in many ways including the paintings, chandeliers, floors, marble details as well as wood working. In today's terms, it seems to be impossible to reproduce and worth the visit.

Unbelievable Palace. This palace is incredible! We were going to skip this palace because we weren't familiar with the location and it wasn't part of our tour. However, we decided to book a second tour that included this palace and I am so glad we did! It was easily my favorite attraction in Istanbul, and we pretty much saw them all. The palace's size is beyond comprehension and it is super extravagant. A must see!

Top Istanbul Attraction in my books. Really beautiful palace and grounds. Too bad no photos. And don't forget to visit the Painting Museum (look out for the Turkish Mona Lisa) and the Crystal Pavilion.

Badly organised tourist attraction, but still a must do. We loved visiting the palace, it was breath taking. For the main portion we had an excellent tour guide who showed us the main parts and gave us time to see everything. The second part, in the harem, was hugely rushed with a very disengaged tour guide. He told us that there wasn't space to stop and we were practically running! Would recommend going at the back of the group so you have more time to look at things, since the tour guide doesn't have anything of value to say!

"No photographs!". This was the frequent cry from the guides are large swathes of tourists were guided around this historic building. It's interesting, a bit shabby, and does involve a fair bit of trekking along corridors between rooms in the Palace. But please remember "No photographs!" or you will be shouted at by the guides and security staff.

All that glitters is in this case, gold.. Everything about this palace is grand, opulent and glittery. It is interesting to learn about the rich lifestyles of sultans and their families, The opulence was shocking to me but I think it is worth a visit. Going with a tour group is mandatory so it requires a bit of patience. Queue for tickets alone took more than 30 min. Then again you queue for English or Turkish Tours. I think the tour had just the right amount of infomation but groups should be smaller. Room after room, you will see so much history and luxury. Glad to see that the Palace is well maintained but makes me wonder how many people need to be employed just for housekeeping.. Those massive chandeliers!!!! I don't want to be the cleaning lady here. Highly recommend this attraction.

Nice palace, pity about no photo policy and very short explanations by the museum guides. A new sultan's palace with a European twist built in the 19th century displaying incredible wealth of the Ottoman Empire. The excursion is split into two parts with separat access and separate guides plus a long wait if you miss your every 30-min entrance. Only allows tourists in groups and a No Photo policy which is a shame as the official guide book to the palace contains poor photos. The groups are enormous and not everyone can hear the guide's explanations. I think the museum should invest in more guides and make the explanations more interesting. They did not say anything one cannot read in the average guide book which is a shame. The museum forces tourists to wear plastic overshoes which is not understandably why as nobody us allowed to step aside from the main carpeted tourist trail anyway. The palace is closed on Mondays and Thursdays.

An Occidental Palace in an Oriental Country. Built in mid-19th century by ottoman armenian architects Balyan , although this palace looks european, it retains also elements of traditional Ottoman Palace life, and also features of traditional Turkish houses. This is where the founder of modern Turkey Mustafa Kemal Ataturk died in 1938.

History on the Bosphorus. Dolmabahçe Palace located in the Beşiktaş district of Istanbul, Turkey, on the European coastline of the Bosphorus strait, served as the main administrative center of the Ottoman Empire.A visit to the Dolmabahce Palace begins at the Medhal Hall. Rooms leading off the Medhal are towards the sea and the land. The rooms facing the sea were used by the leading Ottoman officials, the Grand Vizier and the other state ministers, while the rooms facing the land were used by various administrators of the palace and the state.The entrance fee is 30 TL and the are open from 9 am - 4 pm. Mondays and Thursdays they are closed but you can visit the gardens. The view from the palace over the Bosphorus is beautiful and worth a short trip
What a view. Visited the palace years ago and ate there as well. The views of the Bosporus are breathtakingly beautiful as the palace itself is

A must see!. One of the most beautiful attractions in Istanbul.The arranged tour is very organized.The guides are very nice and willing to answer any questions**It's advised to take the full tour; the palace and the Harem (for 40 TL only!)

Dolmabahce Palace. This is a 3.5 - 4 hour visit. There is a café and restrooms and there is high security at the entrance.Arrive early (it opens at 08:45hrs) to beat the crowds and be sure you g into the main palace first on your guided tour - the Harem part of the palace doesn't open until 10:30 hrs so you can use your time well if you view the main palace first.The site overlooks the Bosphuros - really really great views from the window of the palace so be sure to take some photos.There are 250 rooms in the palace but the guide will take you around 20 of them or you would be there for a week is you tried to see all of them.Ataturk died in this palace and you will be shown the room where he died.The palace is very well preserved and gold adorns every room. The crystal chandeliers in many rooms in the main palace are nothing short of amazing - British crystal by the way.The Harem is quite bare compared to the main palace and the guide who will take you round is very well informed.This tour is excellent value at £10 per person, you won't be sorry that you took this trip.

Beautiful place, poor tour service. 1. Waiting until enough people present for a tour to start2. Can only visit on a guided tour, but the numbers were far too large to hear what the guide was saying, they gave little information and NESB travelers kept talking amongst themselves so those of use who actually wanted to hear the guide couldn't3. Guide in Harem had such a thick accent I good barely understand what he was saying (I'm a native English speaker)4. You move through the palace so quickly you don't have much time to appreciate the opulence and beauty5. Pricey for the low quality of the tours6. They should provide audio guides and people go through at their leisure

Great, amazing,lovely!. I love this palace. I have been twice there. Great architecture. It is so beautiful, i can't find words to discribe it. You must see it!! When you get in, it's like you get in a fairytale. There is the largest chandelier in the world.It's important to know that is forbidden to take pictures inside. There are cameras everywhere and you may have big problems if you try to take a picture. I liked the most the palace garden and the view to Bosphorus. Amazinf experience!If you have to choose between Tokapi and Dolambahce, visit Dolmabahce :)

So Grand! A Must See. Absolutely loved Dolmabahce Palace, it really is beautiful. For 40TL you can see the main palace and the harem. It really is breathtaking and cannot be described in words.. don't think I could do it justice. You have to see it to believe it. We took the tram from Sultanahmet to Karakoy and it is just a straight walk to the Palace. There is a guide for both the main palace and the Harem but like a previous reviewer mentioned, you do not get time to savour the glory of the Palace. I guess they have to do this otherwise it would get overcrowded and too congested. I still think it is worth a visit. Should be one of the top things to do when visiting Istanbul (in my humble opionion ;o)

Extravagant, Opulent, and Decadenet...a must see!. Our guide book did not have much to say about the Dolmabahce Palace even though the 6 last sultans and president Ataturk all resided here. It is a truly amazing palace with very ornate decorations to say the least. A few warnings though: 1. Don't go too late as there is a daily quota of 3000 entrances2. Absolutely no photographs allowed, even without flash3. Guided tours are included in the price and mandatory. They are only offered in English or Turkish. You can hire a private guide at your own expense though.Definitely worth a visit.

Must see Destination !. Not far from Taksim Gezi Parki, around 10 mins walking. A Huge Palace on the sea Shore. This palace cannot be well described. Amazing interior and architect, very rich with its antiques and chandeliers. Guided full tour is recommended, make sure you take the english version not the turkish one if you are a tourist. No photos allowed inside but you can still try.
worth seeing. baby notification: cause of lack air condition, in summer it is too hot and in winter it too cold and it can not tolerated by babies.

Beautiful palace. We took a tram to the Kabatas station and walked approximately 300 meters to the palace entrance.We visited on a Saturday morning and arrived at 10am and there was no queue.We selected the standard tour and the harem tour. Both tours are not Pram and wheelchair friendly and we left our Pram at the palace entrance. However, our 4 year old was fine and able to walk the tour. Each tour is approximately 40 minutes long.No photos are allowed at all - which is a huge pity. The palace is absolutely beautiful. And you have to enter with a guide. We were lucky to have a great guide whose voice projected so it was easy to hear him, however, the tour was very rushed. You weren't given any opportunity to marvel at the rooms. And the groups are very big.The harem tour was a bit disappointing because we couldn't understand the tour guide - his English dialect wasn't great; and after seeing the grand rooms in the standard tour - the harem tour was a bit of a let down. So if you are rushed for time then give this one a miss.

Up there with Pieterhoff and Versailles. Amazing living quarters. Elegant palace . Very beautiful. Just as important to see as Topkapi The furnishing and exterior grounds were beautiful beyond my expectations.
Dolmabahce Palace. This really an amazing palace its deserve to visit you will see the professional engineering that built it nice place on the Marmara sea you will enjoy the ornaments they made it
Historical visit. Another must see. I thing a guided tour is worth paying for as you learn so much. The interior can not be photographed and is out of this s world. The extravagance has to be seen.
Excellent. This amazing palace, near thr sea, is going to blow ur mind. No photos allowed but its for the best as u concentrate on what the guide has to say. It's a Must visit.

A european palace in Istanbul. This is an overwhelmingly large palace in the european style, to which the royal family moved from the Top Kapi palace. It is easy to see why they moved. This gem of a building contains all mod cons. At first gaslit, later electric, centrally heated, with cascades of presence rooms and waiting rooms for ambassadors and roaly visitors, it extends for seemingly miles of corridors. Many oil paintings of battle scenes and associated military personnel litter the walls. The huge chandelier in the ballroom was the gift of Queen Victoria. Everywhere are crystal-encrusted flambeaux, and one staircase has crystal balusters. The furnishings are plush and rich in colour. If the palace lacks reserve, it makes up for this in an opulence scarcely matched anywhere else.

Crazy levels of Opulence. If you have ever visited the Doge's palace in Venice then you will have appreciated some pretty high levels of opulence. This palace takes it to new levels and is worth seeing just to know what is possible!

Nice. The palace is nice very huge. But sad to say it is not well maintained. If you have not been in some palaces in Europe. Then you will appreciate dolmabache palace. But if you have gone in the palaces in Europe then you will feel sad that such a nice palace but not well maintained. But it is still worth going.

Impressive place. I really enjoyed my visit to Dolmabahce Palace (beautiful location, buildings and halls), but there is one thing that annoyed me - the number of people in English spoken groups. It was difficult to hear a guide and even fit with him in the same room. In the end of the tour I felt sick. I truly believe that restriction on number of people in a group should be put.
One of the nice palaces. This Palace is not included in the tours. It is extraordinary. A must in Istanbul. You must check the days it is opened. And it close at 4:00 pm
Fascinating. Pompous palace at the beautiful Bosporus side, right next to Besiktas. Well worth the visit, plus tours are interesting.

Amazing place. The Dolmabahce Palace is another landmark you cannot miss. The luxury, the authenticity of the palace, with all its original pieces, you can just imagine the sultans walking around. I would advise for the whole palace ticket, it costs 40 lira and it's totally worth it. Also, the tour is guided, the individual visits are not allowed.
Beautiful Palace. Stunning place, with even better location. Once home to Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, built with all the Ottoman style, worth every waiting hour in line....

A piece of Western Europe in Istanbul!. This palace isn't much different from many you'd see in France or Germany or Austria, but it was a nice change from the Eastern buildings. The gardens and water view were calming.
Amazing . Charming place to visit or just walk around, it costed 35 tons of gold to be built. It worths all the money, if you reach Istanbul you should visit it.

Beautiful, interesting. The fact that the palace is furnished makes it more interesting to see. You have to wear slippers over your shoes so be careful as the floors and stairs can be slippery. Our guide gave us details on the daily life of the sultans which made the tour even more interesting. The gardens were interesting as well.
Dream palace. If u visit Istanbul must to bisit this palace You will be shockedLuxury place, you will see the history and you will smell it tooVery good experience will never forget

History!. Huge area and loads to see. I think its too expensive tho! Be there early because the line will be insanely long! Had to wait 1 and a half hour. Would never do that again. But the buildings are absolutely worth seeing and the view on the Bosporus is amazing!

Wow place. Amazing. Jaw dropping palace.
It was one of the most beautiful palaces I've been to.
Just wish that they allow us to take some photos...

Dolmabahce . Its certainly a must seen place its one of the most beautiful palaces u will ever see The location of the palace its self is so magnificent and breath taking place . U can buy the ticket there its a guided tour with english and turkish speaking guiders Its a group guided tour only .U will wear a shoe cover before entering. No photo allowed inside the palace Inside u will see the 2nd largest chandelierIn the world .

Disappointing could have been better. Only accompanied tour no advise of this when you buy entrance ticket. The guide English was hard to understand due to accent and the size of the group made it difficult to hear. Tour limited to small part of Palace and you stopped at about 6 points not to hear the guide. Worst visit experience of two holidays in Istanbul. Would not rush to visit this. Also staff in general urgently need customer service training they did not appear to care whether you enjoyed your experience or not. The restaurant just outside was just as bad, all gathered around chatting whilst their customers waited and waited! The whole place needs an overhaul in terms of getting the customer experience right.

Place to add to your Itinerary. Not one we had heard of before but we were so glad we just happened across this Palace. Stunning decor, furnishings and the chandeliers are something else. Largest 4.5 tons!

Stunning luxury . What a fantastically luxurious palace, beautiful chandeliers wonderful sweeping staircases and lovely gardens. It is difficult to pick out our best place from the many we visited but this has to be high on anyone's list. If you are in Istanbul make sure you go and visit the Dolmabahce Palace. But go early as the crowds can be very large later on.

Great place. Will take time (individual tours not allowed). Use the metro to get there. The palace is amazing! The frustrating thing is there are NO individual tours, so you have to wait till enough people gather and a tour starts with a tour guide.Use the Istanbul metro to get there (get off the Kabataş station) and beat the traffic. Near the blue mosque you will get on the metro at the Gülhane station.
Excellent palace. Excellent palace with a very good indoor tour.i advise to get complete ticket because haram (inside and private part of palace) is very beautiful.dont miss that.

Great !. Dolmabahçe , a great and historic palace , the 6 latest sultans and the first president of Turkey : Ataturk lived there.It's built on the Bosphorus to have a direct access to the sea , extern and intern architectures are great , 15 tons of gold are used in this palace ! Wonderful.

Beautiful memory. Excellent place to visit ,apart from a long time you have to spend in a long queue for ticket which might take around 1.5 -2 hours , but when u go inside the palace you can enjoy the unforgetable sceneries.

19 century opulence. built mid 19 century used by 6 sultans and 1 caliph the place where Mustafa kemel ataturk died combined European/ottoman in design split into 2 main parts palace and harem which can be visited on combined entry ticket no individual tours allowed all tours conducted by palace guides which are a bit regimental smaller rooms art work ect can be visited solo closed mon/thurs

Gret era. Great Era.....when you enter the Palace u feel the secret power of this place...so many beautifull items to c, the history it includes and in conclusion...a rich and well preserved magnificent structure to visit again and again

Built during Ottoman Decline. Built during the rise of the Victorian period and the decline of Ottoman rule, this palace is unlike other Ottoman stately homes and borrows a lot from Victorian culture, so that wallpaper (and other Victorian trappings) was preferred over the rich ornate indigenous ceramic and tile heritage. A sad statement on the change of taste at the time. But very interesting to visit and to learn the history of this palace and its place in late Ottoman history. In a scale of top 10 things to do in Istanbul, this would be a 5. It can be done in an afternoon but may take all day. Compared to all the other visit-worthy places in Istanbul, this one isn't as essential as some of the others.

Dolmabahce luxurious Palace. In one word , LUXURY . To know the real meaning of luxury , you have to visit this palace . Nice outdoors and gardens too . You can walk around while imagining the luxurious life of the sultan and his family and dependents .

A Beautiful Palace on the Bosphorus Shores. I was initially put off by the need to take a mandatory guided tour through the palace, but once inside, I understood why. The place is fully furnished with old furniture and immense crystal chandeliers. The history that goes with it is also fascinating.

Summer 2014. One of the best palaces in Istanbul. The architecture is unique, right on the Bosporus. The gardens are fantastic but unfortunately the day I went the inside was closed to the public but friends told me it is incredible.

WOW and WOW again. This is one of the most magnificent places in Taking photos is not allowed in the palace but it is ok to take photos in the garden. The only word you will keep saying all over the tour is WOW. The tour is guided by a tourist guide. there is to queues to enter the palace: one for the groups and one for the individuals. It is one of the must visit places in Istanbul
Not on my A list. This Palace is quite contradictory.Neither the building nor contents are"Ottoman". I never warmed up to it.

Grand palace. The Dolmabahce Palace was built on the orders of Sultan Abdul Mecit in the mid 19th century (1856) along the Bosphorus waterfront in the area we know today as Besiktas.The palace was designed by Armenian architects.The design of the palace was a complete change of style from the earlier Topkapi Palace where they had smaller buildings in various courtyards. Here, more in European style the palace was one large imposing building. More than 30 tonnes of gold was used to decorate the interior of the palace which has almost 300 rooms. Of these the Ceremonial hall is a huge room which is said to be able to hold 2500 people. The chandelier in this room is one of the largest in the world.You usually enter the palace through the Imperial gate. In front of the palace, just after the gate is the Swan fountain. There are two other gates, the Treasury gate which is very pretty, and the Bosphorus gate through which the Sultans boarded their boats along the Bosphorus.In the palace is a set of rooms used by Mustafa Kemal 'Ataturk' where he spent his last years. Many clocks here have been stopped at 09:05, the time at which Ataturk passed away.In the garden is a cafe where visitors can sit outdoors and enjoy a snack by the Bosphorus, however it gets crowded and by the time we got ant service there was only enough time to have a lemonade and leave.There is also a beautiful 4 story clock tower in the garden (reviewed seperately) and the Dolmabahce Mosque just outside the gate which is also worth a visit.Photography, though permitted in the garden and outside the palace, is NOT allowed inside which is a pity.
Dolmabahce. A great palace, situated on the banks of the Bosphorous, where the great leader Ataturk lived and died.

A good 19th c vision of the ottoman sultan's life. Interesting. It isn't fantastic baroque as one will see in Europe. Its a mid 19th c pastiche and fairly kitsch. That said, it is well worth seeing. The big chandelier weighs 4 tons. Amazing. The place was built to impress when they had nothing.

Beautiful Palace!!. One of the great historical palaces, you will see beautiful architecture and decoration and old furniture that will take you back to centuries that passed. I did not like the tours system though, you don't get a chance to see everything and take your time. I hope that will get improved

I Wish Photograph indoor is allowed. There are probably more opulent palaces out there but this one worth a visit if you have spare time. Easy to reach from tram stop just walk for 10 minutes.Nice decors with lots of details plus a mandatory group guide which will provide you with all the information necessary about this historic place. Worth a visit.

Fabulous visit. The dolmabahce palace is well worth the visit with the opulent furnishings and buildings all on displayThe crystal staircase and the chandeliers and standing candelabras makes this a spectacular site to visitYou can only get into the main building and the harem via guided tour so it pays to check the times these runThe grounds and other buildings to visit including the crystal pavilion are lovely

Stunning collection. Very well preserved palace! Stunning collection of furniture, artifacts,carpets and other possessions of the erstwhile Sultans and a vivid description of their Harem. Without doubt, the Number 1 attraction in Istanbul!
My favourite place in Istanbul!. Love it! Its very beautiful itself and just beside the sea with an amazing view. The tour was guided.

This completes your Istanbul trip. Probably one of the most beautiful castles around - I would actually compare it to the Palace of Versailles in Paris or the Al Hambara in Granada, but much smaller in scale. You must do a trip to see the beauty and grandeur. Love how it is next to the Bhosphorus which makes the entire place so magical.
East meets West. The Sultans thought they would be "modern" (read European) when they built this. Interesting mix of East and West.
History talks. memories that cannot be forgotten. visiting Dolmabahce is one of the must do on your trip to Istanbul.

Huge. To get in you must go with a tour, however, as I was with a private guide, they allowed us to go by ourselves. The palace is huge in size with lots of rooms and items exposed. However, it looks to be in full decline.

Worth a visit . Stunning place an position against the Bosphorus, amazing decor, the place must have had millions spent on it. A great place to visit, but you do feel a bit rushed on this and no photos allowed although we sneaked an odd one.
Dolmabahce Palace. This is really a western palace with the touch of the east. Again well worth a visit but not see easy to get to by public transport.

worth the trip. This is on the other side of the bridge but worth a trip, It is a palace in the modern sense of the word, Very pretty grounds and the crystal stair case is something, need to open more rooms though

Must see opulence. A must see in Istanbul...and allow some extra time to stroll around the spectacular gardens perched beside the beautiful Bosphorus. There is also a restaurant / café on site, with gorgeous water views, which is reasonably priced. Viewing the interior of the Palace is only by a guided tour, done at intervals in either Turkish or English and takes approximately 45 mins The guide was knowledgeable about the building & the history around it and moved the tour along at a fairly quick pace. You have the opportunity to buy a combined ticket at the gate to both the Palace & the attached Harem which is also worth a visit. You are also then able to visit the nearby Painting Museum at your own leisure.. You are unable to take photos within either section but there is a souvenir shop available to purchase mementos. The Palace is stunning inside, filled with quite unexpected opulence & examples of the extravagant lifestyle that the Ottoman era enjoyed.

A real Palace fit for a King...or Sultan anyway. An amazing palace showing such wealth and grandure. If you like bling, you'll live this place. The shandaliers in here were incredible. The tour was good, if a little rushed and with quite big grups so not always easy to hear what is being said, but so much to see and take in...our favourite tourist attraction we saw on this visit.

A witness. Dolmabache is a the residence of the last sultan's as well as the residence of Ataturk. the place is amazing and have lots of rooms that describes the way the sultans and the president lived and managed the country.there is also a harem which is considered the private residence . Not suitable for young children, you can walk freely in the gardens but you can't move inside the palaces except with the guided tours. There is also a cafe' by the phosphorus and they are not expensive.

Most Ornate Palace - Don't skip it!. One tour book had this listed as a "1-Star" attraction. In reality this is a "5-Star Plus" attraction. We visited Dolmabahce on the last day of our stay in Istanbul and enjoyed every moment of it.Relatively, this can be considered a modern palace. Decor is simply amazing. Standing at the entrance steps, waiting for our guided tour, one can't help imagine how grand this must have been when it was an actual residence. Tour guides are very seasoned and their narration reflects pride of Turkish heritage. There are many sections of this palace (art museum etc. each with a separate ticket), but the main tour and the harem are a must see. There are benches facing the Bosphorus where you can relax and watch Eastern Istanbul.Photography is not allowed inside the palace, but you will see many tourists abusing this request. Tour guides and security constantly remind and reprimand people - "Lady I can see your flash" - and yet people keep their cellphone cameras running. There is a museum store that sells picture postcards of the Palace interior.This palace is definitely worth a second visit - don't skip this.
Miss. Dirty, run down and just plain boring. Walk around the outside if you have time to kill while in Istanbul but there are too many other attractions worthy of the time.

Photos are forbidden inside - please be respectful!. My only reason for the 4 stars is that you must be part of a tour - either reserved in advance or provided by the palace on the day - to see inside. Which means you cannot wander at your leisure and rather unfortunate given the beauty and opulence of the palace interior. The tours last approximately 45 minutes and much time is wasted reminding people photos are not allowed. Very frustrating!!

Only for lovers of late Ottoman architecture... which I am not.... You can only go round this on one of the tours, which you do at vast speed. Outside is very pretty with magnificent views of the Bosphorous. Inside is, in my opinion, hideous. Not my bag at all - all suffocating opulence and gold leaf. Give me the beauty and serenity of the Top Kapi Palace any day.This attraction is not covered by the Istanbul Museum Card and I would recommend getting there early as the queues can be VERY long with no shade.
A must-do in Istanbul. It shows a lot about history and its a place with an wonderful architecture! Superb furnishings and art work .
Stunning!. I haven't seen anything prettier than this. The guide made it incredibly interesting to go through the whole palace. IT was brilliant. A must visit place!

Worst service ever. We liked the palace really, but really terrible situation happened before we got there. If you want to see the palace you should wait for 100 people buy the ticket, strange that there is no machines with it like in other Turkish museums. So we waited for 1 hour on the sun in +30. When we reached the ticket offfice, they said that visa and mastercard is not accepted. We asked if they accept Euro they said yes. 60 TL were counted as 18 Euro, which was okay acording to change office price 3,4TL for 1 Euro. I gave 20 Euro and got back 2 TL ( insted of 2 Euro or 6,8 TL). So I said in ticket office that it must be mistake and the price is 3,4 TL for Euro, The ticket-seller gave me more 1 TL. I said that it is wrong again. So he took my ticket back and threw in my 20 Euro with words :" you not gonna enter museum today". This small man who works on governmet not only cheated me, he also humiliated me. I said I would not move from the place I stand untel I get my ticket (there were 100 people behind me standing on hot sun). So after 5 minutes he gave me my ticket and 3 TL (cheated me again). We went to polis and told them everything, I hope they did somethiing and that man lost his job, but I am not sure about it, because can you imagine how many people he cheated? He is a thief who works on government, this is really big shame for Turkish Government, not any country allow such cheating in legal ticket office. The most terrible serive ever. For the record we visited it 26.09.2015 on 13,30 (1,30 pm)

Stunning - an ostentatious & ornate Palace. Really glad I took the time to visit this place - one of the highlights of the sites that I saw in Istanbul. I had thought about taking a tour to get there, but then decided to do it on my own and found it was very easy. I was staying near the Blue Mosque so just jumped on a tram heading in the direction of the Galata Bridge and stayed on the tram until the end of the line. Got off at the last stop and walked just a few minutes further down the main road to the Palace. The grounds of the Palace are beautiful, with statues, lovely lawns and flowerbeds, fountains and ornate gates opening out onto the Bosphorus River. To go inside the Palace you must join a tour (they leave every 15 minutes to half hour and are run in a number of different languages). While the tour is rather rudimentary and feels a little rushed, the Palace is jaw-droppingly splendid & for me the Ceremonial Hall was the jewel in the crown.I only spent about 2 hours there as my time was limited - did the main tour, the Harem and walked around the gardens. If you wanted to do the clock museum and the art museum you would need a bit longer. There is a café within the Palace gardens so you could easily spend half a day at the site. I went early in the morning (as was recommended to me) to avoid the crowds of the afternoon. NB: the site is not included in the Istanbul Museum Pass. The ticket for the Selâmlık (the main part of the Palace - the section with the most gold and crystal!) is TL30, the ticket for the Harem is TL20; however if you get a joint ticket for the Harem and the Selâmlık it is TL40. Highly recommended.

Great location but palace visit is a little oppressive..... Entry to the palace costs 30TL and a further 10TL is charged for a visit of the harem. The museum card is not valid for this site.On the day of our visit the queue was endless..... However, the grounds of the palace (no fee for seeing these) are very pleasant and well-maintained. The spectacular swan fountain is its crowning glory and the side gates lead to the banks of the Bosphorous. Worth spending some time here.After purchasing our tickets (we were not informed that we had to be on a guided visit!!!) a large group assembled in front of the palace gates and we had a long wait before we were allowed in. Once inside it was hot, oppressive and there wasn't an opportunity to take in the exhibits. Of particular interest to us was the crystal staircase - spectacular and the ceremonial hall. On the whole , much too ostentatious and ornate and yet steeped in history...... Given the choice, I would have skipped the viewing of the palace and spent time enjoying the pleasant grounds.Please note that photography is not allowed inside the palace. Surly and unhelpful palace attendants.
Nice Palace. I Was Wondered for all this Room inside with A gold made . Its was Crowded with people . i like it but i Buy Some Sevanior and i lost it outside
Nice palace next to the river. This is an interesting tourist attraction in the heart of Istanbul. Located next to the river bosphorus nearby other tourist attraction.

Dolmabahce Palace. Dolmabahce Place is a must see. It was built in the 19th century and is in a European style. It's an exercise of excess. The huge amount of money that was spent on it's construction and furnishing is almost obscene especially at time when the Ottoman Empire was at decline.
Stunning building to visit.. The Domabahce Palace is a place of great history to visit. Well preserved and a must visit. Can be done on own steam. No tour needed.

RUDE TOUR GUIDE!!!!!. The palace itself is magnificent and the grounds just as good, but what really got to me was the tour guide! First of all you cant go around unless on one of the guided tours! Ours was plain rude! No manners and quite condecending, hence the three stars. Still worth a visit if you can put up with your tour guide!!!

Far more impressive than Palace in Old City. Wow. Our guided tour focused on the Old City (Topaki Palace) but our favorite sites were here and the Chora Museum. We view this Palace as a must see. Beware that is was closed on Mondays and Thursdays when we were in Istanbul (September). Crowds also build and it is close to the Hop & Go cruised so it is likely most crowded around the time they start and let off (just before noon and late afternoon). Still, the details are astounding and the architecture was fantastic. No pics allowed unfortunately--just means visitors will be pleasantly surprised.

The most impressive palace in Turkey!. A stunning palace which is extensively decorated with gold and crystal. Mustafa Kemal Ataturk lived and passed away in the palace and later on his death it was converted into a museum. The garden around the palace is beautiful and has spectacular view to Bosphorus!

Impressive place but the guided tours are a let down. Beautiful building in a great location, with decorations meant to impress. The actual palace was built in the 19th century and is decorated in a rather eclectic style that uses elements completely foreign to the Ottoman culture (likely in a deliberate attempt to break with tradition and look modern).The palace manages indeed to impress but at the same time disappoints as it seems out of place in the history of the Ottoman empire (perhaps in itself a sign of the deepening crisis in the empire at the time).The way the visits are organized is not great (it actually reminded me of the museum visits I had in primary school... :)) - a guide takes close to 100 people and whizzes them through some of the most relevant rooms stopping every now and then to deliver a pre-approved and well-rehearsed speech that very few people can actually hear. The groups are too large and there is a lot of noise from other groups and also from individuals that simply give up trying to follow the guide (very difficult indeed under the circumstances, so they're not to blame). You are not allowed to visit at your own pace nor to take photos (not that all people listen and then you have embarrasing situations when security people start raising their voices in a more or less successful attempt to become convincing etc.)We visited on a Sunday (early afternoon) when everything else (Harem, Clock museum, Cafe) appeared closed - we weren't told at the entrance and were let to discover that on our own so that was again dissapointing. To sum things up, Dolmabahce palace is impressive but I would recommend a visit only after seeing the other main attractions in Istanbul (and perhaps reading a bit about the last Turkish sultans and Attaturk).

Feel like being invited by the Sultan. This Palace is amazing. The most extraordinary thing is that the furniture and accessories are genuin. It was like being a guest in the Palace. It worth leaving you time to just walk in the garden and enjoy the Bosporus from here.

Fantastic. We skipped topkapi palace to go here and boy we didn't regret it. Fascinating architecture and splendour with the gold gilded roofs, chandeliers as well as other high quality works, one can easily understand there was no cutting back in terms of expenseFor Turkish locals, this place is extremely significant as it was the here were Ataturk spent his last days and eventually passed away. Things to note:- location is 5 mins walk from kabatas tram station- tour lasts approx 1 hour- it's a guided tour although it's hard to follow what the guides are saying- they have a limit (not sure how many) to the number of visitors in a day. After this, they reserve the right to close the ticket hall even before the day has ended- no photography is allowed which is a shame- you can take your pram in although it isn't pram friendly. At a certain point you will need to lift them up a flight of stairs to go the top floor and similarly back down

The center of empire. Istanbul has a lot of historical places to visit, but this palace and Topkapi palace are the top ones. Those are the sultans palaces, the centers of Otomans empire, where everything merge and controlled from.
Dolmabahce Palace. This palace is very beautiful. I want to go there again and again and again...Go there! And you can love it!!!♥♥♥

Epitome of Ottoman excesses. This amazing palace is so over-the top it is surely a MUST SEE when visiting this wonderful city. It was built in the 19th century by Sultan Abdulmecid, and was an attempt to outstrip the best that Europe had to offer. To say that the result is excessively sumptious is to undersell it! The resources needed to build this place helped to bankrupt the Ottoman empire finally. Apparently Abdulmecid's successor hated the place so much he built a new palace! After the empire fell, the palace was occupied by the great Kemal Attaturk until his death. I am not sure why a man of his character and background would want to live here! But he did.It's not possible to wander round on your own, only as part of an organised tour, of which there were a great many. Not ideal, too much congestion and hold-ups, and at times it was hard to hear what the guide was saying. Also, photography is forbidden, this is a shame as there is so much to photograph! Also, the gardens are delightful. A highly recommended visit.

Visit the Haram first. You have to go with a tour guide for both the Haram and the main palace (unlike the Topkapi palace where you can rent an audio guide and walk around by yourself). I recommend going to the Haram first because it is less glamorous - so you end the palace visit on a high note.Also plan to have tea/coffee/meal at the palace cafe. It has the best view of the Bosphorus!

A mini Versailles in Istanbul . This was the best place we visited in Istanbul. First of all they allowed photos in almost all areas of the palace. The architecture is very beautiful; the last sultans really started to live in a less Ottoman - like atmosphere. The Wealth required to build this jewel of istanbul is incredible.
Nice place to visit. Impressive palace from the ottoman times. Well preserved. Worth to spend half a day in this place.So many rooms in the palace with nice paintings.

Very good. The palace is situated right next to the Bosphorus and is very big. It houses many art pieces as well as many state rooms which is still being used today. The unfortunate thing though is that there are too many groups going through the palace at the same time and then it makes it difficult to hear the guide. I think that they need to streamline this aspect better. If you are into old buildings and history then this is one you must see

Photo not allowed - put cellphone on silent. Long lines first for security, then for ticket purchase, then for entering in groups (no individual access allowed). But worth it.Photography also not allowed, but if you put your smartphone on silent to mute the artificial shutter sound, you can manage to sneak in a few snapshots.

Very nice . The palace of located in the side were to galata tower is and you can go there in public transportation really easy ( the ticket of the public transport costs 4TL). When you get there, you have to play 30 To which include the entrance to the palace and a guided tour. When you get there, there are 2 tours one on English and another one in turc, when I went I had to wait like 10-15 minutes for the tour to start. The palace is really big and beautiful it is very well decorated. The bad news is that you can't take pictures inside. The tours takes about 40 minutes and they take you around one small part of the palace. The lady that gave us that tour had a good English so you can understand the explanations.
Beautiful.. Its a beautiful palace. It has breathtaking views and the tour guides are polite. Its totally worth going to.

Great place. A place that you should visit but only with the tour guide. A bit long queue to get the tickets. Do come early since they allow only 3000 persons per day to enter the palace. You will be amazed with the chandeliers and the ceilings. The view of the Bosphorus river from the palace is so beautiful.
Nice Visit. I wish they allowed a little more freedom inside the castle. The guided tours were very helpful but a little haphazard for my taste.

Don't bother - everything else is better ( and better organised). I have walked through the Tower of London, Buckingham palace, the louvre, the Vatican, any number of museums galleries and palaces -all over the world. Almost all of them are really well organised, with information where you need it.Not so this place. Queue for security screening. Queue for tickets. Queue to get in - "guided" tour only - English on the quarter hour, Turkish on the hour/ half hour. Absolutely unnecessary if the usual information had been given in a brochure and/or in plaques in the various rooms.The guide was not useful anyway.It took a long time and was ok - but there are many better ways to spend your time and lira.

Waste of Time; Go to Topkapi instead. After a delicious day exploring Topkapi Palace, we thought to visit Dolmabahce as well. What a disappointment! One can only visit the palace in a large group--too large to keep up and hear what the seemingly-bored guide had to say about this Europeanized dwelling. No meandering to see the details, which paled in comparison to the jewel-like interior of Topkapi. Imagine Versailles as conceived by Donald Trump and you have some idea of what the palace contains.
