Great history in a beautiful location. Dolmabahce Palace is a great contrast to the Topkapi Palace. The history is rich and the interior opulent. We were told to make note of the incredible crystal chandelier that was a gift from Queen Victoria. We had fun looking at the incredible chandeliers and trying to figure out which one was the one from Queen Victoria. Make sure you take the time to see the harem quarters. You have a great view of the Bosporus while visiting the palace.
Takes a full day. Allocate a full day in order to hear the stories and see everything.. Magnificent things you will see.. Strongly recommended..

Nice day out from the centre. We got the boat here from Uskadar, then visited Ortakoy for lunch.You can only visit the palace and harem by guided tour. This is included in the entrance but you have to queue each time. We did not wait for too long and enjoyed seeing the magnificent buildings. One of the tour guides was much better than the other. The gardens were pleasant. I am very pleased that I made the visit

Best Palace in Istanbul!!!. I highly recommend making the effort to go see this palace, it's stunning. It's a real shame you can't take photos because the inside is so beautiful. Try get there early as thy only let in 3000 people per day and you have to go in as a group of 50 or so. We got there at 9am and pretty much went straight in. It's just so beautiful, similar but more beautiful than the Palace of Versailles our tour guide told us (I haven't been to the Versailles one but I intend to!!).Highly recommended!!!
Great Garden and Interior!. Great Garden and Interior! Must see if you go to Istanbul. The waiting line was not very long. English speaking tour guide inside the palace.

The worlds most expensive palace. 68 tons of hold to decorate it...Home to king of the kings in the world..gifts from worldwide kings and queens...a beautiful view of bosphorus ftom yhe palace..its like you are in a fairy land...no photos as u r not allowed to take them

Great piece of architect and craftsmanship of Ottoman era. One of the best palace I have visited and its in pristine condition. The detail and the craftsmanship are truly admirable the staircase is a masterpiece you must have to see it to believe it. This place has the biggest chandelier in the world weighting over 2 tonne and it truly is grandest of things you will see. We really enjoyed the tour. Guide is a must. Only downside is you can't take pictures. A must in Istanbul.

Elegance. This Palace is right next to the Bosporus. Its a great example of Ottoman life and is worth the trip. You can get there by public transportation. I saw a lot of people on tour. Honestly its great to just go and wander - enjoy yourself, read about it online is my recommendation.
Reminds u of another building bck hone?. If u dnt hav tym or livibg in the othrr part of town u can see it well externally while on a ferry crossing or going to the islands
Part of History. its a great place to visit but it is very busy & you need to plan your journey to arrive early or late afternoonthe only draw back is the guided tours & you have no choice

Do not miss this!. Stunning palace with spectacular rooms and gardens. Not to be missed!Ignore any negative reviews, have a great visit by planning properly.The palace suffers queues - avoid them by ARRIVING EARLY (always good advice for istanbul attractions). Be there at 9 - certainly well before 10 - & you'll get straight in.No need to buy a half-day tour to go there, just take the T1 tram to Kabatas & walk 5 minutes.There are 4 areas to see, 2 with obligatory free guided tours. Sure the tours could be longer (2 hours?!) but you can always pay and go round a second time IF you feel the need.Main palace tour (Selamlik) in English starts every 10 minutes, big group, lasts 40 minutes. Simply fabulous superb interiors, good explanations by the guide.Harem tour in English lasts 30 minutes. Ideally you would visit harem first as it is much less spectacular than the main palace, so it can be disappointing if seen after. And the "guided tour" is merely a walk through the building, glancing into rooms for a few seconds as you pass them, so pick whichever language queue is shorter!Much more impressive than those of the harem are the interiors of the paintings museum - formerly the Princes Palace. It also has a charming (& quiet) café with cheap prices (5TL soft drink)And don't miss the dramatic Crystal Palace situated in the spectacular grounds.
Full of history. We went here with a tour and really enjoyed it. We loved hearing about the history and the information about the rugs, chandaleres, rooms, etc. I reccomend going here with a guide.

A Wasted Visit. This palace is clearly beautiful and fascinating BUT - you have to go in a guided tour - each English tour is about 100 people and you are rushed from room to room. The guides speak pretty poor English and with the noise of the group and the crowding you really cannot enjoy this attraction. My advice would be to buy the guidebook before you go - and let the tour do its own thing while you look around!

Truly Majestic and Magnificient. This palace is truly remarkable and a must see on one's visit to Istanbul. The architect of the building is very impressive and the detailing work carried out in its ceiling, artifacts, staircases, chandeliers out is truly remarkable.....

The best palace to visit in Istanbul . Palace from the modernisation ages of the ottoman empire, full of European influences -barock, rococo, located in the Besiktas area. Built in mid 19th century. Comprises of 3 parts- administrative, private and princes courtyard. Offers Excellent views to Bosphorus. Again not organised in the best way. Be aware that tickets can be bought in cash only. You are not allowed to visit on your own - only guided tours, so you end up running through in a group of 50. No photos allowed. Closed Thursdays and Mondays. Still worth visiting

Spectacular but Crowded Display of Excess. The palace is amazing, especially the use of crystal throughout, even as spindles on the staircase. However, the tours are unnecessarily and ridiculously crowded. There is no reason for this; they could easily host more frequent, smaller groups.

Extraordinary opulence and beauty. When visiting all the "must sees" of Istanbul, don't just do the obvious, like Topkapi Palace. This palace is very different and its magnificence and splendour will not fail to impress. The visit to the palace itself is by guided tour, but there are other things worth seeing in the beautiful grounds too. This sight is exquisite and has to be seen to be believed.

Beautiful building. This was the palace which housed the last sultan of the Ottoman Empire and was used by Ataturk as well. We were mainly surprised by the very different style of the building compared to the mosques we had seen. And the location right at the Boshporus is just amazing.

take turkish liras to enter this attraction. Do not make the same mistake that i made - we were not able to enter the palace as we did not have Turkish Lira - the ticket desk do not take euros or cards! We took a few pictures on the grounds leading to the palace. the cafe bar was not particularly welcoming. we gave up waiting for someone to serve us.
Fantastic. The most beautiful historical place I've seen in Istanbul. Fantastic paintings on the wall and roofs of building, cristals, valuable things.

Well worth the visit.. Well worth a visit when in Istanbul if you have time. The only way to visit the palace is on guided group tour, but the guides are excellent & you get a lot more from the visit to hear their information.

great palace. Lovely palace, but beware - it gets rather hot inside and there is no quick escape from the guided tour. No aircon inside obviously. Takes about 1 hour to get tickets, than another 40 minutes waiting for your guide tour (you can't go wondering around on your own) and the guide tour for another 1.5 hours. All in all it is worth it. A lot of history here.

Worth visiting. I enjoyed visiting this palace which is a palace! not like Topkapi, a museum!There is a guide there, you are not allowed to take pictures inside, gold, crystals pretty much everywhere. The last room near the exit is the most impressive room I have ever seen. Unfortunately like all palaces around the world, only a few rooms are for visiting.

Opulent!!. If you like Palaces don't miss this one. The scale reminded me a little of Versailles. It is very grand and opulent. Crystal abounds, even the pianos have crystal legs!! You have to go with a tour but they seem to leave fairly regularly. Go early to avoid the crowds. Take a tram to Kabitas and you have a 5 minute walk.

Highly recommend. Beautiful, no photos allowed inside, which is actually good as you're not distracted but people taking selfies everywhere!Go straight to Palace Entry from gates to see when next English or Turkish tour is on, same for Harem afterwards. Grounds also very nice, leave a couple of hours for visit

Beautiful Modern Palace, a must see. Beautiful modern palace along the Bosphorus. Go early to get your ticket (limed to 3000/per day) or purchase online day of visit. Visitors are escorted through the Palace in groups of 15-25 people except when you are part of a group/bus tour.
great palace. very nice historical palace. but to noisy. nice view in place. the ticket was expensive.the guider man gave best information for tourism

There is a camera fee payable and no flash photography so high speed film or high tech equipment is required for good p. The last home of the Ottoman Sultans and the Palace where Atatürk, the Founding Father and First President of the Republic passed away is not to be missed. Filled with antique furniture, fine ceramics and beautiful works of art the white building sits on the shores of the Bosporus amid carefully tended gardens.
Dolmabahce by the sea. This is a huge, luxurious palace, with beautiful architecture and grounds, where I spent most of a day trying to see it all.

Fantastic Palace. We visited this great palace on a self guided tour from our cruise ship whish was berthed just a 15 minute walk away (turn right as you come out of the cruise terminal and walk strait ahead and you can't miss it). It is located just a 100 yards further on from the Dolmabahce Mosque and alongside the Bosphorus. The gardens are super and the furniture and works of art inside even better but photography is not allowed. If you have been to Istanbul before and visited the normal tourist spots, then this is definitely worth a visit.

Nice but no photography . It is fantastic place but not be able to take pictures for security reasons.... come on ..... hate this. And it is very hot inside no airconditioner . But the round guide was good and give excellent information
Time & Money. I think Turkey is an amazing place & I wish I had more time & money to explore it. There were some real craftsmen in those days !

WoW. Simply .. Jaw-dropping ! The palace's design is unique and outstanding.
No one should miss it ...
Flaws: They need to figure it out how to organize groups better. The number of people per translator is a lot, especially without microphones. So only people in the front heard him/her well.
Wear your most comfortable shoes always !
Magical. Dolmabahche is probably the most beautiful historical palace that should everyone see when in istanbul

Great to see but not a must-see!. We spent our last afternoon in Turkey here as it was close to our hotel - the queue was very long (about an hour's wait) and it was hot as we had to queue in full sunshine, but it was good to see inside the Palace. The guide's English was a little unusual but once we worked out how he said certain words we could follow everything he said. If you have limited time put the other big sights first, but if you have the time it is interesting to visit!
A beautiful palace in a stunning setting. This Palace is an absolute must see. It is full of beautiful rooms, wonderful ceilings and tiling and was the outstanding visit we made in Istanbul.

Fantastic Palace. What I can say about this masterpiece? it is perfect but you will be tired as it is very large but it deserves.Recommended to everyone please don't leave Istanbul before visiting this palace.

Impressive palace, formal tour required. You must join a tour to visit this palace, as individual visits aren't allowed, and may have to wait for a group in your language. We had this included in a day-long tour of Istanbul, which is an efficient way to see the palace (as well as a cruise on the Bosphorus, and several other sites). We had minimal waiting time and no problem hearing our guide's commentary. At the beginning of the tour you will be required to don foot covers over your shoes to protect the floors, Also, be aware that no photos are allowed. The size and finish of the palace attests to the wealth and prestige of the sultanate, even as its power and influence were waning. Definitely worth visiting after seeing Topkapi, the original palace of the sultanate. The grounds are very nice, too, if you have time to linger.

Great palace,go visit. This palace is simply gorgeous. The chandeliers in the ball room are amazing and the crystal staircase was outstanding. No photos are allowed, and the staff are a little efficious about this, however I did manage to sneak a few in. You are not allowed to wander the palace on your own, its by guided tour only. Bit of a shame, as I would have liked to spend more time in the palace. It was 35 degrees outside when I visited, so extremely hot inside also. Its worth to see both the palace and the harem, where you get a true sense of the family's life. Well worth a visit.
Citytour. Visited the sites and find the marvelous art work and perfect civil work which show the value of art lovers

Worth a look.. Amazing place. You are shown around the palace and the harem in groups with guides for various nationalities. This means you can be waiting for up to 30 minutes for a guide speaking your language, in a queue, in the heat. You are not allowed to explore the buildings on your own but you can do as you please around the beautiful gardens.

Beautiful government wing, boring family harem wing.. Wish we could have done JUST the official government/entertaining wing as a tour. That section was impressive. Amazing amounts of gold leaf and crystal! The tour guides have huge groups, are hard to hear, and don't really tell you much history or archetectual information. Because of the large group, it moves slowly. But the family/harem wing is very even slower and we had even less information from that English speaking guide. The family wing is mostly quite plain. Be aware that no pictures are allowed. Getting to the palace on the Big Red Bus tour was a bad choice because of traffic delays. Took hours and hours to and from. Take the Istanbul ferry instead. Then th tour was so slow that the entire process took 5 to 6 hours. If you are only in Istanbul for a couple of days skip the Dolmabahce and stick with the Older Topkapi palace in the central location near Hagia Sophia.
Lovely gardens. Very interesting neo-Baroque palace, lovely gardens, a very interesting art gallery with nineteenth and early twentieth century Turkish paintings.

It makes French Palaces seem humble. The only purpose of the palace was to impress. Especially to impress foreign dignitaries. And it works even today. Because of the magnitude, the materials used from all over Europe and also because of the details. Take your time at the clocks collection and in the Ambassadors hall where credentials to the sultan were presented.

An opulent palace. The opulence of the palace has to be seen to believe. The interiors can only be viewed when led by a tour guide, the time is restricted and no photos are allowed. It is much better than the free-for-all way adopted by other venues where you can't move without walking into a blessed selfie stick!!

Beautiful Palace. As a Turkish person I have to say it is one of the places to visit if you are in İstanbul. Right on the bosphorous, Very very richly decorated beautıful old palace. The founder of Turkey Mustafa Kemal Atatürk spent his last days here and died here. You can also visit his quarters. Wwords are not enough to describe the place.
Full of history. The palace is located in a great place. Nice view and huge territory. Love the palace and it one of those must things you need to do when you are in Istanbul
Outstanding. The must place to go if you are in istanbul.beautifull view excellent place.the palace is magic and the stuff is very helpfull.beware of the cues that are very long

Don't go in the summer!. This palace is lovely and the history is very interesting. It is home to the largest chandeliers in the world. The furnishings are decadent and i highly recommend seeing it unless it is above 90 and humid. The guides also yelled at the patrons for taking pictures during the tour (which we were asked several times not to do). It was just too hot and stuffy to truly enjoy 3 floors of luxury living and it's historical significance.

amazing. if come to istanbul you shoul come here first and if you want to come with public transportation from taksim square I recommend you to come with "funikuler" then walk for 200 meter and also you should pay for visiting for officials but there are some extras that you can see for more money I recommend you too to see every where and if you want to see every where you should go in the morning not afternoon. cause we went in the afternoon and we couldn't see extras. they also don't let take a pocture inside but it's soooooooo amazing and unbelievable

A must see. I would just give 5 stars for this palace it's more than gorgeous. It is one of the most exciting things to do in turkey. Don't forget to buy the ticket by which you can see the whole palace (40tl). Finally go early as much as you can to avoid queues

Large. Hard to comprehend that the Sultans had all this living space....shewww. beautiful antique pianos and massive original paintings to see. Please do with a guide it is helpful to have the dialogue of history that goes with each area in the palace.

A Pleasant Way To Spend An Afternoon. Dolmabahce Palace is within easy walking distance from Beyoglu. It is maybe 3 km max along the water. Purchasing tickets can be a bit time consuming. I would suggest purchasing tickets for the harem as well.We took two tours while there. The price of the tour is included with your admission ticket. Both tours were very informative and provided historical insight. The English skills of the guides were also very good. You are free to wander the grounds. You can visit the art gallery, have a cup of tea or lunch or just sit and watch the ships go by on the Bosphorus. Surprisingly we found that we enjoyed the Palace for almost four hours. I suspect that some days can be crowded but the whole grounds are quite spacious.To return to the city centre you can get a tram, bus or taxi. I would suggest a return walk along the water. There are lots of pleasant cafes along the way.
Historical Palace. Dolmabahçe Palace located in the Beşiktaş district of Istanbul, Turkey, on the European coastline of the Bosphorus strait, served as the main administrative center of the Ottoman
Beautiful palace. I really enjoyed visiting this palace. The building is well preserved, it’s very big and the ticket includes guided tour.
Sultan's palace. Excellent place to get knowledge about Sultan's life of Ottoman Empire. It totally worth of that money.
almost half day plan ..... It is worth to been visited , you can access it after waiting in the line not more than 20 mins , not far away from Istiklal street .

Firing at Dolmabache Palace. We decided to go to Dolmabache Palace on the first day of our trip (19th August) & witnessed so much panic. We wondered what it was, until we were told that 2 gunmen were firing outside the palace. We couldn't go beyond a point, but saw on the news that nobody was injured. So we just saw Dolmabache from outside, it was beautiful!

Domabache guided tour : very lareg group. We followed the Dolmabache guided tour ...it was the last group of the day hence more of a bunch of stragglers than a planned tour. You can only see the Palace in their groups...and our experience was that the group was far too big to hear anything being said.The first part of the tour was presented and guided by a very enthusiastic young woman who had a great command of English, but could not handle the group. When we did the second part, the Harem section, the group grew in size and the guy conducting the tour did not have great diction nor did he had a powerful voice and he came across as a slightly Turkish version of the Rain Man..interesting.The palace is wonderful and huge and there is a lot to take in. Amazing paintings and Crystal chandeliers buy our high speed tour did not do it service. It would be better in a smaller group?
Nice place . It's was a really nice place to visit I enjoyed my time there and took breath taking pictures.. Unfortunately the section of sultans wives was a different ticket so I couldnt see

Beyond belief! . From the swans in the fountains to the wrought iron gates leading in to this 19th century palace is amazing. Built on the water. Can't use your museum pass but well worth the visit the history inside on the guided tour which is inclusive in your entry price is fascinating. Well worth getting off the big bus tour for this. Try to go first thing in the morning to avoid crowds and look all around the property not just the main palace.

Nice!. Very interesting, sumptuous and nice.
Too hot inside and forbidden to take photos.
I recommend it after main places in istanbul like blue mosque, topkapi.
nice historical place. very beatiful historical place which is located near sea in the habatash harbor and also grate place for taking picture

Outstanding not to be missed. Worth waiting in the queue, this attractions does not fail to deliver...outstanding location, the tour allows an up and close personal view on life as a Sultan and life in the harem....

Mesmerizing,.... I loved everything about this place,... there were a lot of waiting around,... you get e tour guide and you can not wonder about which is quite the standard for palaces,... this was an amazing places with a lot of exquisite things to look at,... the guide was excellent,... the gardens though small were beautiful and a great place to take pictures,...

Not as wonderful as people say. The palace is nice but cannot compare to Schonbrun or other Western palaces. Your jaw will not drop, maybe only in the grand hall which is indeed beautifully painted and adorned. However, the experience is ruined by the fact that you are in a big group, noisy, people trying to take photos even if it is specifically mentioned not to, then the guards yell at those people making it even noisier and then you are being rushed down the halls with few or irrelevant explanations (the guides were almost magically boring) then bye bye. The nicest things about the palace are the view over Bosphorus and the painting museum section outside the palace. Oh, and also the Turkish coffee price which is 5.50 tl, instead of the outrageous 13 tl in the touristic area. Overall, not worth the price (40 tl for full visit, including harem).
Sumptuous. Not as big as Topkapi but still impressive. Glass cut balustrade and incredible chandeliers. It is looks European but not quite It has an exotic feeling that is unique.

Wonderful palace, the guided tour is a bit short. The gardens and the palace are trully thrilling. Since all the furniture is left in place, you can easily imagine what living inside would be like. The place is really worth seing despite the fact that you have to take guided tours where the guide does not explain much and you will be in a group. Don't miss the harem and the museum, the paintings inside are beautiful and relate very well the life in Turkey on the 19th century.

Great amazing palace. this was the greatest palace I have ever seen the sealing finishing was unbelievable, I have never seen such a piece of art and history like thatthis is a must see place in Istanbul

Breathtaking palace. Great way to spend an afternoon. It was great to see this after visiting Topkapi Palace because it gave better context about the history of modern day Turkey after Ataturk. Truly exquisite!

Must see. After Hagia Sophia that best should visit in Costantinople.Architectural interesting, luxurious, large and with incredible collections in, worth the money and time to go.Adequate the tour made means. Can you combine and other destinations in the region

Don't miss it!! . I really enjoyed the palace in each part of it. It is really amazing to see how was the Sultan and his family living and their rooms.Taking pictures is not allowed at all inside. To buy the ticket you have to wait in a long line. It took me around 15 minutes in the line to buy the tickets. But it worth it to wait.

A stunning palace with crystals and bling to make your jaw drop. Such a beautiful palace adored in only the finest crystals and chandeliers and ornaments. What makes it different to other palaces is that they have fully furnished it so you get a really good sense of the opulence of the time and how they lived. The guided tour is so useful because you get to go through in enough time to understand the history but not too much to make you feel over whelmed with information especially at the end of a good day of sightseeing in Istanbul

Amazing Dolmabahce Palace. The Dolmabahce Palace is truly amazing. It really is like nothing you have ever seen in your entire life. It will truly blow you away with it's grandeur and beauty. If you are in Istanbul, don't miss it!

Extraordinary .  Dolmabahçe palace is so beautiful and  extensively decorated with gold and crystal. It served as the main administrative center of the Ottoman Empire from 1856 to 1922.A must visit place in Istanbul.
Nice sea view. Did not enter to the palace due to a long waiting line. But had a coffee at the cafe just beside the palace with an amazing sea view.

richness and beauty of the orient. the first thing that impress you when coming to Dolmabahce Palace is the scale and the beauty of the building and the gates that lead you there...but when entering it you are simply dumbfounded by the richness of room decorations, by its library,halls, and of course the handmade carpets and unbelievable chandeliers... so when walking through the halls of the palace you realize that the main reason of building this magnificent palace was to impress you, to make you feel tiny . to see the whole Palace you have to pay 45 TL for individual visitors...special beauty of this palace is its garden with gates opening the way to the sea...and it costs you nothing)))

Worth a visit. We visited here with a half day tour. It was a freezing cold day but provided you are rugged up for it the walk around outside while waiting to enter the Palace was OK. Once inside th ePalace it was a very informative tour and interesting to see all the furnishings

Would you like to better understand the Harem. I recommend only the Harem section of it especially to those who want to understand that the harem was just a kind of family. But not only, also a genetic& intellectual laboratory. For this second wait for my blog post on blog.foodieleons.com

Dolmabahce Palace Tour. The palace is worth a look and the cost is not outrageous. The 35 minute tour gets your through the place but the guides are not the best. Our tour had a large number of people 80-100. The guide was at the head of the group and those at the read couldn't hear. It wold be better with a self-guided tour and audio recording, but they want to control the access more closely. They require plastic footies to keep floors clean, which is great. There is no photography allowed and you might be better off buying tghe picture book which is pretty good and is readable.

The palace where Ataturk passed away. The Dolmabahçe Palace was built in the name of Ottoman sultan Abdulmecid in 1843 and he became the home of six last Ottoman sultans as well as their official residences. It is one of the must places of Istanbul to be visited by travelers in Bosphorus area. The founder of modern Turkey Atatürk used this palace as the summer house during his stay in Istanbul between the years 1927 and 1938. He also passed away in this palace on 10 November 1938 so Turksih people would like to pay a visit to respect Atatürk once in a life time. The most striking part of this palace is the dancing hall covering 2000 square meters with 56 columns. It has been a museum since 1984 under the directotare of Turkish Grand National Assembly.
Beautiful Palace by the ocean.. Its a place worth visiting during a journey to Istanbul. Its picturesque location , artefacts, layout and location is stunning.Travelled in Dec 2006.

Mixed Review. I've been to Istanbul a few times and never was able to see Dolmabache Palace. Finally we were able to visit it during our day long stopover. I must say of all the places I've been to in Istanbul, replete with history and artifacts that they are, Dolambache was a disappointment. Compared to European museums it's not very well kept and you can damage from dust and elements all around. I think the palace aptly depicts Turkish rulers' desires to leave their past behind and embrace western sensibilities which they considered new/modern. The outcome, at least to the extent of what remains of this palace, is a bit of confusion that one finds hard to enjoy in or relax. Nonetheless one can argue that it's part of Turkish historic trajectory which somehow doesn't appear to have settled just yet. The palace grounds on the other hand are beautiful with sea views that are wonderful.

Organized, beautiful, must-see. I believe that Dolmabahce Palace was my favorite place to see in Istanbul, closely followed by the Basilica Cistern. To get there you take tram T1 until Kabatas and then you have to walk for 10-15 minutes. When we got there at around 9.30 AM the queue wasn't long and we waited no more than 10 minutes to buy our tickets. This was finally a well organized place, there are guided tours both in the palace and in the harem and therefore the number of people entering is limited. The harem section is beautiful, but I believe the Topkapi harem is more beautiful and if you only want to see one harem you should see the one in Topkapi. Lovely view over the Bosphorus strait.

Dolmabahce Saray. The best place ( ever ) in Istanbul !!!!! It is NOT alowed to make picturesc inside. In my opinion is better than Topkapi Saray ( wich all the rooms are empty. )The organization of the tour is OK ( even you are not with a guide , you will have the saray guide in english ).You wil spend more than 3 hours here. Enjoy !!!!
Great Palace. Greate palace, but most of them is hidden from tourists, you can see only part of them. If have time, you can stay to wach Bosphorus longer

extensive grounds. Have been twice Always crowded Extensive grounds and generous sitting areas. Visit at least some of the display rooms. Weapons and jewels are among the best. Enough trees to make it cooler than most areas.
Mohamed, Egypt . Away from old city with mosques and palaces. Must see with a tour guide or rent a voice guid . Can be visited with other places or arrange the visit with a pisphour tour.

Gigantic Palace!. 45 mins tour but need to get there early in order avoid the long wait. Very western styled compared to Topkapi Palace. We were given the plastic covers for shoes. The place had no places to sit but luckily the palace was worth it!

A must see. One of the most beautiful palaces of Istanbul, Dolmabahce Palace. over 200 rooms and one cannot finish in one day. Simply divine and gives the idea of how the Sultans of the Ottoman Empire lived. A must see in Istanbul.

Beautiful Euro-Ottoman extravaganza. This is a huge palace that boasts rococo art from various European countries mixed with Ottoman architectural structures.We enjoyed the tours that are included in the price.We recommend to book in advance as the lines were horrendous.Do not expect to take pictures as they do not allow it inside the palaces at all. Also, the people at the ticket entrance were rude and unpleasant, perhaps because of the huge crowds and lines, so it was a bit of a weird start to a beautiful visit.It is worth seeing the 4.5 ton chandelier in the main hall. Very impressive.Would recommend this, for the art of not for the way it is dealt with (unpleasant staff and no pictures allowed at all).
It was interested!. This ottoman palace is a gorgeous place! Recommended to visit in Istanbul. An example of turkish prosperity in the past.

Superb! An excellent tour is included in the entrance fee.. In my opinion this is the most impressive sight in Istanbul The vast immaculate gardens are a riot of colour and of course, what a setting... on the bank of the Bosphorus. Your ticket includes a hour-long tour of the interior (no photos). All very efficiently run - like clockwork! Never seen so much chrystal in my life ..... even chrystal ballustrades!

Long lines to get in.. Long line to get in. The tour is guided but hard to hear with the large group and large spaces. Worth it to see how the Sultans lived at the end of the Ottoman Empire. Has beautiful furnishings. Worth the visit. Buy a guidebook about the place if you want to understand what you are seeing.

Don't go with high expectations. A lot of people compare the Dolmabahce palace to Versailles, and that tends to highen expections before visiting it. While its beautiful and grandiose, it's not Versailles. But if you're in Istanbul, you have to see it.

Always get a Reservation at least a Dayin Advance. Our guidebook said a reservation was necessary, at out hotel we were told it was not. As a result we waited in line, the hot sun for more than an hour and a half. Even the wait did not detract from the experience.A guided tour is required, one can not go alone, but we move as a group ( there are group tours, and individuals, who are not with a group, are combined with others like themselves). The tour takes about 45 minutes, you walk in stages. The guides are pleasant and informative, and by the end, you have the feeling of having seen much tat is important, and have a sense of how the Sultans lived once they moved from Topkapi. Do then, walk through the grounds to the crystal room. it is far less spectacular, but the walk through the grounds gives a good feel of the location.
Royal taste. Outside view will offer many turks architecture with outstanding material used for the construction... worth of time to stop by...
Beautiful palace. Loved this place top to bottom, beautiful rooms, chandeliers, rugs, floors. U will enjoy it if ur an art lover, definitely a must see in istanbul
Glory of the Ottoman period. Relive the peak of the Ottoman empire period, take in the grandeur of the palace and be thrilled by the sure size of the palace

Great sites to see. The most beautiful gem of historic Istanbul. The wait to get in is worth it believe me. If you only see one historic site on your visit here, make it this one. Amazing beautiful decor and even furniture.
Check out the chandeliers in the rooms. A newer castle compared to Topkapi. Beautiful chandeliers and interesting to see and learn about the life in Harems.

Long wait in the sun . The Dolmabahce Palace is very grand, but not worth the long wait in the sun. It was ridiculous - there was a huge line of people and only one ticket window open. To view the inside of the palace, you had to take part in a guided tour, which took about 30 minutes. My tour group was very large and the guide was difficult to understand. I do appreciate why people are guided through the palace, rather than left to run amok inside. The gardens are not as nicely kept as Topkapi.

A milestone in the trip. I joined a tourist group just to hear what is told to foreign people, instead of the local visitors. It was shockingly different, while the locals were told about how mighty the Emperor and his strength had been, the foreigners were listening to the limitations in the daily life of Harem etc, not even to mention the very first rights were given to Turkish women by the founder of Turkish Republic, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk. The palace is enormous and cannot be very efficiently ventilated, so you might find yourself getting all jackets on your hands. Some regions inside cannot be illuminated too much, to protect the furniture or walls, so keep in mind that no fine photography is going to be possible. When out, give a treatment to yourself at the cafe inside the garden too.

A little sad. You come to Turkey for many things - second grade European knock-off chateaux should not be one of them. While the palace has a few beautiful touches, it's a little sad to see the Turks having disposed of their national heritage to build this knock-off.

The outside is MUCH BETTER than the inside. As this is one of the most publicized attractions in Istanbul I expected to be deluded as usual. Well, this place is very well kept, and even if questionable in terms of style it is a masterpiece in its own sense, at least from the outside.What is really annoying is the shape and the visit of the inside. The halls and rooms, except for the formal ball room you visit at the end of the tour that is really impressive in size, are very ordinary XIXth century halls. You are forced to wait under the sun and then to follow an enormous group of people inside with a guide. There is no air conditioning inside and the visit lasts 45 minutes.The visit to the harem really doesn't add to the picture, the highlight of it the room where Ataturk passed away. The guided tour (compulsory) takes 30 minutes, and no, there's no air conditioning.So it's really better from the outside, where you can take photos with a wide lens of the facade and the Bosphorus. If you want to go inside be prepared to queue up and to a boring and uncomfortable visit. And just don't visit the harem, it doesn't add much to the experience.

Must see. It is kept fully original. This is the last palace of ottomon empire Also Ataturk used a while , then became muesum. All meubles are original, super decoration, it reflect one period of history

Very Grand. Beautiful palace, not very old, but very interesting. The tours are every half hour in Turkish or English. The only negative thing is that you can't explore it on your own, only with a tour, still don't miss it. Also they have a small clock museum you can visit.
Sultan's feeling. Unbelievable is what you will see inside, extrem luxury all around, no ending rooms, carpets with more than 100m², giant hanging lamps...to visit this palace is a must.
Interesting. Tour guides is necessary if you are interested in the history, there are Qs and the entrance fee is 30 Turkish lira , approx $11 per person, 2hrs min is required

Awesome palace. It is must see place in the itinerary. A very traditional place with lot of splendor.. The ceremonial hall is the highlight. Would re mend to visit on your own instead of taking a tour group. This gives time for walking across the grounds and enjoying the surroundings...

Expensive, but may be worth it if you get a good guide.. There are tours in English and Turkish every half hour and you have to take one of these tours to see the palace.Although I really loved the place, my experience was spoilt by some rotten tourists. You aren't allowed to click pictures in the palace and they just wouldn't listen until the tour guide actually had to walk away and end the tour!Also, the tour price of 40TL is pretty expensive, as much as I paid for the entire tour of Epesus!

Captivating. I left the place in awe.. The palace is adorned with breathtaking items and drawings. I can't describe what it has for it will be a spoiler. Put aside the extravagance of the Ottomans, the palace reflects human's glory in art!
Boring. It's for history geeks and the tours are not up to the price, if you pay 40 liras 16 USD ... You expect the tour guide to speak more( for none English speakers, forget it)

Worth the wait in the queue. We had to queue for an hour and a half in the hot sun to get into the palace on a Friday in August. There are guided tours only and the groups are rather large, but the guides speak very clearly and loudly. The palace is opulent and has an interesting history. You get to see a lot in both the administrative building and in the harem building. The Ceremonial hall is a highlight as is Attaturk's modest bedroom.
Great palace . It's the most important place you can visit in Istanbul, I enjoyed every single part of it.Highly recommended to be visit in turkey.

Dolmabahce. Dolmabahce Palace is something very different from Topkapı Palace. While the Topkapi is in Ottoman style, Dolmabahce Palace is more European. You have to see both. It's very easy to reach Dolmabahce. Go by tram to the station Kabatas, walk a little and there you are. Ticket costs 40tl (Harem and Selamlik). In both parts there are guides who forms groups in English and Turkish. The entrance to the Harem and Selamlik it's not possible without guide (Of course, it's included in price). Garden is the most beautiful there. You will enjoy. It's allowed to make photos outside, but no inside (you can make some photos, lot of people don't respect this).Palace is closed on Mondays and Thursdays. Be sure to go there before 9 am, later is a big crowd. My advice to all visitors: visit Dolmabahce (and Topkapi, Hagia Sophia, Galata tower...) on your own and without the agency because it is cheaper and the best is when you can manage your time on the way you want. Have fun!

Beautiful . A stunning palace in lovely gardens and with a mix of history. We did one of the tours and it was very informative and a good way of seeing the whole palace. Two of us paid a little extra to enter the Hareem, and to be honest it wasn't worth the extra cost.

Palace Like A Dream. Really once you enter from the gate I was no expecting the butty of palace starting from location near the sea with the green and sounds of birds every where with the flowers smell then you will see the clock tower which is amazing then you get inside the palace which was very big with many details you will see when you cameYou should come

A Must See.... We had no idea about visiting the spectacular palace, luckily we had a tour booked on our last day in Istanbul, so we were fortunate enough to visit this breathtaking peace of art and architecture. I strongly recommend all who love their art, history and architecture to not miss this magnificent palace.

Do not miss it despite the struggle to get inside. Pro: Absolutely outstanding interior, wealth, well preserved historical site of a declining empire, do not miss it!Con: Shameful ticket policy (one desk open, queing on the sun for at least 1 hour, no communication, online ticket sale not working), english speaking guides not really good at english

Beautiful Site. This palace was built in the early 1800's and has a much more European style to it than Topkapi Palace whose style is more middle eastern. I would recommend going to Topkapi Palace first since that was the first palace used by the sultans then they built Dolmabache Palace where the sultans lived from the early 1800's forward. This palace is unlike Topkapi in that you can't go into the actual palace without a guide, you can't just roam around. You can roam around the palace grounds and gardens by yourself though.
More extravagant than Topkapi. Pretty to look at. You can't take pictures inside and you have to accompany a guide to the Harem and Selamlik so you have to wait for a group to form.

Unbelievable size and beauty. What a huge building, and it is incredible to think that the furnishings, ceramics and crystal are all original. The colourings are beautiful and the furniture sumptuous. I suggest that you get there as early in the day as possible, as by 11 am the queues were very long and it would have been tiring standing in the sun. Well worth the effort.

The most beautiful palace . We have visited this palace in august. .its the most beautiful palace i have ever seen. ..it has palace section and Harem section. ..There is only guided tour from the entrance of the palace,which is nice and helpful. Outside garden is very beautifully set.Huge crystal chandeliers weighing tons are there in the palace...a must visit place if you are in the istanbul

Ottoman Extravagance at its Best. First off, if you plan to visit during peak holiday periods, be prepared for the queues. In saying that, the Palace is worth the visit if not just to see how the building of this palace and its extravagances contributed to the downfall of the Ottoman Empire. All access into the palace is as part of a tour (No Free Ranging) and you get to wear those attractive plastic booties. And NO PHOTO's inside. Beware the camera police. The Palace and its gardens are impressive and worth the visit.

Worth to visit if you have enough time. I recommend to you if you have enough time, because maybe I visit during the summer time, it took me almost 1 hour in line in the sun to buy the entrance ticket. It's not allowed to visit by your own, so you need I wait for another 15 min for the English tour The tour is about 40 min, Inside the palace is very beautiful, especially the ball room, but it is NOT ALLOWED to take pictures inside the palace and it was really hot.

The beautiful palace that made the whole country broke financially......... One of the most beautiful palaces in the world. Don'y miss the tour with the gardens as well. The Dolmabahce mens the wow as a word, so should be the palace....... Could you imagine living in such a palace. OMG!

Worth a trip, if you have time!. Set apart from the Old City in Istanbul, the Dolmabahce Palace complex is but a short tram-ride away from the city centre.We arrived early to avoid queueing in the sun, which is to be recommended, especially as this is not part of the Museum Pass so no skipping the queue.The main palace is spectacular inside, although the lack of breeze can make it slightly stuffy. In addition, wandering solo through the palace is forbidden, so you may have to wait for the tour to begin. Try and stay near the front or hearing the guide can be tricky. Also it is a requirement in all the indoor areas to wear overshoes, so get used to them.The harem had a similar vibe to the larger palace tour, and it included rooms from the life of Ataturk. Our personal favourite was either the black/gold themed sitting room belonging to the Sultan's mother, or the blue and gold, French style motifs in one of the larger rooms.If you're buying the complete ticket, be sure to visit the Painting Museum, as it has an enjoyable collection of art from both Turkish and European painters (although the still life drawings are somewhat inferior to everything else).If you're feeling adventurous, head further up the coast to Ortakoy mosque for some filled jacket potatoes in the streets nearby.
Eclectic beauty. A testimony of lavishness and declining Ottoman Impire, this eclectic palace will take you a half of a day to visit and explore.

Largest Palace in Turkey. Dolmabahçe Palace located in the Beşiktaş district of IstanbulIts the largets Palace in Istanbul.The design contains eclectic elements from the Baroque, Rococo and Neoclassical styles, blended with traditional Ottoman architecture to create a new synthesis. The palace layout and décor reflect the increasing influence of European styles and standards on Ottoman culture and art during the Tanzimat period. The exterior, in particular the view from the Bosporus, shows a classical European two-wing arrangement which is divided by a big avant-corps with two side avant-corps.

With so many beautiful sights in Istanbul don't waste any time here. There's a long queue and it's definitely not worth the wait. The palace seems tacky in comparison to the beauty of the Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque and the guide spent so much time focusing on the heating system of the palace in the first room that we didn't bother waiting to hear what he had to say about the rest. Enjoy the view of the exterior from a boat on the Bosphorus but don't venture any deeper.

Well worth a visit; enjoy the gardens and don't miss the flooring!. The Persians coined the term 'paradise' to describe a walled garden in their brown and dusty land; well, Turkey has its own paradise with this palace, open to public view. It wasn't so much the spectacular ceilings and mirrors and chandeliers and furniture that got me; it was the beautifully-laid out gardens with a wide selection of trees, the location right on the banks of the Bosphorus, and... the amazing inlaid floors! Take careful note of the parquet floors inlaid with ornate patterns in dark wood; gorgeous. I would have loved to take photos: but that was not permitted indoors, and the guidebooks and postcards on offer at the end really didn't share my idiosyncratic enthusiasm, so I'll have to trust to my increasingly unreliable memory to verify these delights. Well worth a visit but (a) take a water bottle and (b) there's a lovely cafe at the end with cheap and highly- appreciated lemonade...

Get a private tour. Our travel agent didnt get us the ticket for this palace for some reasons. The line for the tickets were very long. But luckily a guide approached us to take us in a private tour and to skip the lines. He took 75 TL per person including the tickets which we were told later that it's more expensive than the normal price but we didn't bother to be honest! The private tour wont take you everywhere so make sure you go around the palace even if it's over
Interesting. Impressive building. Fascinating history. It is best if you have a guide to explain the details of how the building was built & used

A must-see Ottoman Landmark. Recommended for travelers who are looking for exploring the historical side of Istanbul during the Ottoman Empire. A symbol of the extravaganza, luxury and splendor life style of the Ottoman Sultans.

You won't regret. It was amazing seeing all that architectures, high ceiling rooms, ancient furniture and the charming paintings. What i didnt like it was the bad atitude of the tour guides they were very rud and hurry

Stunning palace, but inefficient crowd control. Go early. We waited in queue for a very long time since they only bothered to open one ticket counter to enter the palace. The gardens are very beautiful! If you want to enter the palaces, you have to put on those blue plastic bags around your feet to prevent you from damaging/ dirtying the place. Personally, I can get why they want guides to accompany you through the whole palace, but it's sometimes not done in an efficient way. Our guide had a very thick accent which made it sometimes very difficult to understand what he was saying. Of course this can still be ok if the number of the group of tourists wasn't so high. They assigned one guide to a group of 70-80 people. It would have been a more enjoyable experience if they could have lowered the number of people per guide. Most of the times the people tailing right behind the guide could hear what he was saying. You also cannot take pictures in the buildings.But apart from that, all the buildings are amazingly beautiful. The throne room was just stunning!! I would recommend people to see this place, but do not expect guides to add any value to your visit.

Built by two Armenian architect brothers, Nikoghos and Karapet Balyan.. It seems like it used to be a wonderful place. However, we waited in a line for more than an hour under the sun to get the tickets. After that we had to line up for entrance to the palace. After the 20-25 minutes running guided tour, we had to take yet another line for Harem. We skipped the rest, as this seemed ridiculous.
Excelent location. I recomend to visit the well decoeated palace that combine the old and new turkey and be sure to visit all zones

Incredible. A must see.The Dolmabache is lovely from the architecture to the furniture to the history behind it.I visit it every time I go to Istanbul! The first time they allowed me to take pictures and videos. Now that isn't allowed.
Dolmabahce. it show when Othman Empire start loosing the identity and began following the European countries I do not like

A Must Visit. This Palace from the Ottoman period is a must visit according to me. Like Topkapi this Palace also has two section with separate tickets and also you can buy a combined ticket, time permitting.We visited the Harem section which is actually the rooms and common places used by the royalty. The other section has the halls and places where guests and dignitaries were entertained. Again a huge place and you spend about 45 min in each section with a guided tour. No photography inside the Palace building.Located on the Marmara water it is a great place to spend time outside and at the cafe which has great snacks, coffee etc.A must visit according to me.

Speechless. Anyone who visits Istanbul, he should enter Dolmabahce, but to be honest I enjoyed the gardens more than the inside, standing next to that gate "the one in the picture" and watching the birds flying everywhere with all the green behind you, the sea in front of you, and the sound of Ships sailing .. oh dear, will never forget that moment.

Westrenization and Fall of Ottoman Empire. - It is a must visit to understand history, life and art of the last days of the Ottoman Empire. I went there walking from Istiklal street, I enjoyed early walk on the Bosphorus till the Palace. You must go early as possible, entrance only in guided groups so you wait until a tour ends to start your guided-tour, so try to be in the first one. - Dolmabahçe Palace (Sarayı) (Filled-in Garden) is the largest palace in Turkey (285 rooms, 46 halls) on a bay on the Bosphorus. It was the main administrative center of the Ottoman Empire from 1856 to 1922, it was home to six Sultans until 1924 where Mustafa Kemal Atatürk, the founder and first President of the Republic of Turkey, used the palace as a presidential residence during the summers. - The palace layout and décor reflect the increasing influence of European styles and standards on Ottoman culture in contrary to Topkapı Palace. Rarely you will find Versus of Quraa'n or arts of Arabic writing or mosaic or Islamic décorations. Even clothes had been changed from Arabic koftan to European styles in moda.- Atatürk section has a separate ticket, he spent the last days of his life in the palace and died in his bed at 9:05 a.m. November 10, 1938, in the former Harem section of the palace. All the clocks in the palace were stopped and set to 9:05 after his death.- The Harem (women) section is a exact example of a fully Western Palace in contrary completely to Harem section in Topkapı Palace. - Photography is not allowed inside the Palace.- Beside the palace, there is an interesting Art Museum, enjoy it ......Best of Luck, do not miss

Tourist trap. The palace in itself is very nice you can feel the mixture of different cultures within its architecture and how it was furnished. However, this was not worth all the trouble.The line to enter the palace took at least 1h (1h in the sun of course). Once you are in the palace, we had to queue another 1h in the sun to enter the palace for a 45 minute tour (everything is visited as a tour, you cannot go on your own). The tours themselves are not that interesting, not a lot of information is given I felt. It's very superficial. Moreover, the groups are of course packed as much as possible so you end up walking as a huge mass trying to hear what the guide is saying. Not very relaxing.We also visited the Harem. Another 30-40 minutes of queue in the sun for a 20 min visit. Clearly on for this one, the information the guide gave was quite poor. Nothing giving value to a guided tour.Moreover, the museum closes at 4pm so you end up spending half your day queuing the rest fighting to hear what the guide says.And of course, photos are not allowed. But you can however buy the CD at the museum with the photos.... Great...To conclude, I would not put this palace as a priority on your list unless you are visiting Istanbul outside of the touristic season.... And even if that's the case, I felt the palace is quite expensive for what it has to offer (or at least what is offered to us, clearly the palace has potential to be much more interesting).
Atatürk lived and died here. Our great leader Mustafa Kemal Atatürk lived here for a short time and died here..He was a lovely person and wonderful leader..He was a great soldier!

Beautiful but not recommended at all for people interested in turkish culture . This building is fully influenced by European design. No need to waste your time on it if you are not spending a lot of time in Istanbul.

What a view!. This palace, located adjacent to the Bosphorus Strait, was built in the mid-19th century. It must have been gorgeous back then. It still is today, more than 150 years later. The clock tower and the view from the Bosphorus are not to be missed.
Magnificent Palace. Simply amazing. The grand hall takes your breath away as does the crystal staircase. Worth the visit.

Very long queues. The line for buying the tickets took around 1 hour.Each group has more people than the maximum that allows to convenientely listen the guide. People visiting are not very civilized and don't respect the guidance.The palace is similar to any european one. The last room is huge and beautiful.It wasn't possible to visit harem, even though we arrived at 13:30. There are less than 2 english visits per hour.

Go if you're really interested in history. A gorgeous building with lots of memories(which are of course important for Turkish only)Long lines every where. Buying tickets, visiting the palace and ...Don't go there in the summer as there is no air conditioner and windows are closed.Nut enough information given by the leaders.No photography allowed.

some thing unbelievable. it was so so so amazing, I loved it and i'm ready to go there again and again just look for the pics in google. the bad thing was the queue was so long to buy tickets we were sin the queue for about 45 minutes and inside you have to wait because there is a guide will be with you inside the palace
a place worth seing. beautiful, make you feel like you go back in time.amazing gardens really worth seing...i would definetely go back

Simply magnificent. I am extremely well travelled but do not believe I have visited anything as opulent, magnificent or beautiful as this palace. it was stunning and quite jaw dropping at times. An absolute must to visit.

Great Palace, average tour guide. The Palace is a bit away from the city but well worth it, the architecture and location both excellent. However, they force you to get into a tour group with local guides, and ours was average, especially because she had to herd about 40 people along. That was a spoiler in an otherwise perfect setting.

Beautiful Palace. Well preserved Palace with amazing Chandeliers. No photos allowed and they are strict about it. Unfortunately we went through with a large group and at times it was difficult to hear our guide. Had to queue for about 20 minutes for tickets but worth the wait.

nice grounds , shame about the palace. You cannot tour the Palace individually but must take a provided tour in plastic overshoes with a less than fluent English speaking guide. A hideous hotchpotch of awful, tasteless rooms awaits. Interesting only as a a train wreck.

Dressed to impress. Sultan Abdul Mecit I built this palace in an attempt to outdo the crowned heads of Europe. It's beautiful and must surely have cost a ton to construct, but Topkapi is far and away the lovelier of the two palaces. Still, Dolmabahce rates a visit, if you have time. And while you're there, be sure to enjoy the grounds.

Mind-blowing!. We didn't expect how powerful the Ottoman Empire was even if it was towards the end of it until we saw this palace. Perhaps it's the most beautiful and luxurious structure I have ever seen in my life, and I was so glad that I came here as part of the Bosphorus cruise. You must visit here when you come to Istanbul, and find out what humans can achieve when the power is given.

Amazing. Quite the most stunning place visually, ever. Highlights. - the pure alabaster ( I think) of the sultan's hamam, the crystal staircase up to the waiting and audience rooms, and the way the tour gradually does a great reveal by the weight of the chandeliers. I wanted more historical context - for instance there is a room full of pictures that Kaiser Bill sent of himself. The pomposity made me laugh but I'm not sure it was appreciated / understood because it was such an ethnically diverse bunch.The tour guide did a great job on controlling the group who could be rude on occasion. The harem is entirely missable - especially if you are short of time.

Guided tour. The palace itself is beautiful, but the guided tour that you have to join takes away something from this place as you move around in a large group. I think the experience depends on your group, ours was noisy and we could hardly hear the tour guide over people talking, which was a shame. There's also lots of queuing involved and in the August heat that was difficult.

Amazing Architecture at Dolmabahce. Due to our tight schedule we were unable to spend much time here at Dolmabahce, but only had a glance at this amazing structure as we were on the Bosphorus Cruise. Amazing-looking palace, a must-visit the next time I am in Istanbul. Don't miss it!

Magnificent Palace. Out of all the chateaux, castles, palaces we visited in France and Turkey this trip, the Dolmabahce Palace certainly stood out. We had to do a conducted tour and they do these in several languages. It is a most stunning building and the Muayede Lounge with its domed ceiling placed on 56 columns was just beautiful. The height of the dome is 36 meters and there is a magnificent chandelier of nearly 5 tons and the largest one piece carpet in the world. The ornamentation throughout the Palace had to be seen to be believed. Definitely the most impressive Palace I have seen anywhere. There is a security check (similar to that at an airport) before entering and the cost was 30 Turkish lira. The Palace is right on the Bosphorus and looks magnificent from the water too!
Great Place to Visit, Dolmabahce Palace. The Dolmabahce Palace is great place to visit, and if you are planing to visit Istanbul add this to your wish list, please. It is worth to visit.
Sultan comes home.. After 100 years of exhile the Sultan returns home to see the beuty of the palace he once graced with his presence.

must see.... This palace is one of the most ornate palaces I have ever visited. The largest crystal chandallier in the world (given as a gift to the Sultan from Queen Victoria), stair case sides made of crystals, palace size ivory, serves vases, amazing clocks, original silk curtains, hereke rugs - we can go on and on. When you choose a tour guide, make sure they will show you everything of the place. Too bad that our tour guide just showed the palace. But there is more too it. There is the harem section, crystal dome etc.... InsaAllaah we hope to cover them in our future travel to Turkey. It is a place I feel in love with...

Beautiful Palace on the Bosphorus. The Dolmabache Palace was the residence of the Sultans after they moved out from the Topkapi Palace. The location is in the Besiktas district and was originally a bay which was reclaimed and became a garden. The name Dolmabache means "filled in garden".The palaces was built between 1843 and 1856 and was the residence of the Ottoman Sultans till 1924, when it was transferred to the state. It is the largest palace in Turkey and has exquisite decorations of gold and crystal. There are a lot of Hereke carpets and the worlds largest bohemian crystal chandelier 9weighing nearly 4.5 tons). The palace was the official summer residence of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey. He passed away in the palace on 10th November 1938.The entrance fee includes a tour guide and you are shown some parts of the palace and harem.This is a must see in Istanbul.

Great location. A true wonderful experience especially the stunning view to the strait and colourful gardens near kabatas pier where you can go to princess island and other attractions worth to visit.

Huge Palace. You will love this palace. It is not like the european palaces but you will love it nonetheless.My personal opinion: do not pay for a private guided tour inside the palace. The guide will talk and talk and talk about uninteresting and trivial things and just wait your complete time inside the palace. Just read about it the night before (30-45 minutes) and go there om your own and you will enjoy it tenfold.5 stars.

Wonderful and Breathtaking Palace. My husband and I visited Dolmabache at 9:30 and found long lines. We started enjoying our time from the front gate. My husband loved the cat in the palace garden it acted like a queen. Inside it's an amazing furnished palace that real royals used to live there it takes you back in time feeling you're from the royals.

The New Ottoman Palace.Museum on the Water. This museum was a disappointment - it was expensive to get in, and in many areas of the grounds, only a tour experience is permitted so you need to wait for a group to assemble. The tour guides are not very good, speak in low voice (if at all), and pictures or videos inside the museum are not allowed. Room after room, the layout is very similar, and there is not much historical context presented. I would suggest other museums - particularly ones in the old town as being better investments of time and money.
Regal. This was the old abode of the sultans. By the Bosphorus, it is worth going to to view the beautiful rooms and soak in the regal atmosphere

Favourite Site in Istanbul. I would have this as a must see in Istanbul. Interesting to see where the later Sultans lived. Extravagant furnishings throughout and some nice views. The Harem is also worth a visit.A couple of annoyances though - the tour groups are way too big. We were lucky to be beside the tour guide most of the time but if you're not then you're not going to be able to hear them. Also, no photos are allowed inside.

In need of re-think. Without question, this is a fine building packed with history and a magnificent Great Hall.Sadly this is largely wasted by the bizarre insistence that you join over-large guided tours (Turkish and English only) by a bored and irritable tour guide motivated only to herd his group as quickly as possible, imparting the bare minimum information and taking no questions. Self guided audio tours, in major languages, would be much more suited to this but are not available. Truly about the worst guided tour of a tourist attraction that I have experienced and it's not clear why the museum authorities adopt the current approach.

Turkish Empire. Magical! Beautiful! Historical!This place should be on your list of places to visit in Istanbul. The Sultans and Mustafa Kemal Atatürk lived in this palace approximately 100 years ago. The furniture still remains as is from the Sultan days! Magical experience
Lots of history and bosphorus views . Nice. Tour a little fast. For more history I highly recommend the archaeological museums and for science the Rahmi M. Koc Museum!

Wowzers. Such a spectacle with all the intricate luxury it was intended to showcase for that period. Guided tours brief but informative. Small cafe - useful in the sweltering heat as there is not much shade to retreat to.

SUPER- a precious gem for whatever taste or standard. The last place where the Sultans lived and - likewise - the last address of Turkey's National Hero Mustafá Kemal Ataturk is a super extraordinary palace that everyone visiting Istanbul should pay a visit.The views, the artifacts, the history of the place - you see, taste, smell history everywhere.I've been both in Topkapi and this one and though both are indispensable visits and Topkapi is older and with more rare artifacts, I do like this one a bit more. It is my 3rd visit now and I believe I will come back. Every time I learn something newA MUST

Nice Palace. Our first of many lovely palaces in Istanbul. Glamorous is an appropriate word for this lovely palace next to the Bosphorus. The rooms and furnishings were very symmetrical and contained a lot of lovely gold and crystal.

Old world charm. If you love chandeliers and staircases, you won't want to miss this mid-19th century gem. Once the modern world took over in the Ottoman Empire, they moved the administration from Topkapi Palace to Dolmabahçe Palace. Keep an eye out for all the stopped clocks!
Beautiful palace. Personally I prefer this one over the topkapi palace.its smaller and much more well done up. It's beautiful and God sum good history behind it.

the first place to be visited in IST. This was my first mission to do in Istanbul as its awesomeness attracted be outside the building along the way. It is very recommended to go there before 9 (it opens at 9). The fee is 40 TL for an adult and the entrance is by guided tour only. There are tours in English and Turkish by the museum staff. If you know Turkish it is very recommended as you will be few people and get more information. The palace itself just A-MAZ-ING. All the crystal stuff and golden ornaments, etc. If you buy all palace-Selamlik+Harem- 40 TL ticket, you will have free access to Watch, Painting museums and Crystal Palace. The security guide in painting museum showed us some magnificent 3D paintings which dated a long back and this is the advantage of knowing the local language :)

Amazing!. Amazing architecture and beauty surrounded by awesome view of Bosphorus. Definitely a must see in Istanbul. Too bad they don't let you explore it on your own pace since you must join the guided tours. I could have easily spent another few hours. It closes at 4 pm. So go early if you want to see the whole thing.

A must to see palace. One of the most beautiful pallaces in Istanbul, which is located on the Bosphorus. Palace of the late Ottoman Sultans and has one of the best preserved harem. A must to see. Beware the long ticket que.

An attraction that could so easily be perfect..... Dolmabahce Palace is beautiful! No if's and's or but's!!!!! However you will spend at least an hour in lines (unless you get there early) and if you arrive at 1:00 you will probably not be able to see structures like the Harem and the Clockwork Museum due to the very early closing time of the Palace being 4:00 (at most museums internationally it's 5:30). The price to get in for an adult is 40TL but students it's 5TL. Once you actually enter the palace it is magnificent but it is not Versailles or the Catherine Palace. In fact if you have been to the Breakers and seen the mansions in Newport Rhode Island built around the same time you won't be missing much. The tour guides rush you in and out and you have no time to explore or take in the beauty of the building. also you are not allowed to take pictures and several people on the tour were forced to delete their photographs by security in plainclothes. I found this strange considering the fact that the palace was built in 1857. This leads me to believe that the strict no photo policy is strictly for marketing. While I would recommend this to Early Modern Turkish History buffs, I would not advise this for people who visiting Istanbul for just a few days. spend the extra hours at Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque. Or visit the Deniz Museum next door and see the Sultan's Pleasure Boats. If the hours were better, the prices were cheaper and there was a more relaxed photo policy along with self guided tours this attraction would easily be 5 out of 5.

Just another palace.. I suppose if you have seen one palace you have seen them all. This one is not all that different. You must take a guided tour. There is no other way to do it so you are among a fairly large crowd of people--30 to 50 anyway-- and there is no opportunity to linger. You are hustled along. It is somewhat north of town, but right on the tram line so it is not difficult to visit. This is a very large palace. There are several museums included but for some odd reason none were open when we were there.

Worth a visit but bring your patience. Tip: closing time is 4pm ( 16:00) so if you don't get your ticket before 3pm they will only sell you a half price ticket and you must choose between two tours. Tip: there are two tours to choose from. Don't pick the harem tour. It is less interesting, and depressing unless you really want to see where Attaturk died. Tip: you must be lead by a tour guide. You are not free to explore at your leisureTip: they are extremely strict about not allowing photos. There are several guards watching you at all times and security cameras watching youTip: be prepared to stand in several long lines in the hot sunTip: the palace is gorgeous and worth putting up with the lines and tour guideTip: toilets are the squat type and they smell even though there is an attendant constantly cleaning them Tip: if you are a student tickets are 5 tl. $40tl for everyone else. cash

Breathtaking!. With all the palaces and castles all over Europe that I've seen, this has to be the most opulent. You are required to go with a guide and about 5000 other people through a 45 minute tour of only certain parts of the palace, where you are not allowed to take pictures; with all that being said...still worth doing. It is unbelievable the scale of grandeur that this place is on. We did the harem, as well; you can definitely skip that. The grounds are also worth mentioning in their own right. Dolmabahce is out of the way from Sultanhamet, but it is right by Taksim square, so maybe combine the two?

WORTH the VISITTT!!. It took me about an hour to go inside the palace and it worth it. It is really nice place to see. Historical with luxury touch. Really worth the visit. The only think that I didn't like is that you will not be able to go inside alone you have to be as a part of a group with a tour guide. they offer it for free as a part of the ticket price (30 Turkish Lira) but still I would enjoy it more if I go inside alone not as a part of a group so I can spend what ever time I want in each section.

Total awesomeness!. We visited DB Palace as a part of a guided tour. Told we were not to take photos while inside the palace itself.OH BOY! what an awesomeness ! How have we managed to skip this place on our earlier trip to Istanbul! I mustsee piece of history, both beautiful inside and outside. A historical gem.Our tour didn´t include a visit to the private living area in the palace, so we only saw the public areas. That did do for us.

The highlight is the view and nothing else. This attractions is hype on the internet but a very disappointing visit for as the palace is almost at ruins with cracking floors and the history isn't much except the residing place for Sultan. Not worth a visit.

Not worth the amount of time spent in queue. When we visited the palace we arrived at around half ten. The queue was already ridiculously long but we waited and entered around 45 mins later. The grounds where nice but packed full of people. When we wanted to enter the palace itself we had to queue again for around 15 mins. When the guide came to take us round he just briefly told us what rooms we would be walking through with no actual interesting details about the palace. The walk around the palace lasted around 15 mins as we where just herded around quickly as part of a large group.

A DO NOT MISS AND EASILY ACCESSIBLE BY TRAM FROM CRUISE SHIP OR SULTANHAMET. Once you've seen the Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia and Topkapi head to this wonderful palace. Hop on the Tram at Sultanhamet and get off where it ends (past where the cruise ships dock) - cross the street, turn left and you are there. If you are on a cruise ship this is very easily done on your own. The Tram is right there and its a couple of stops.I had read some so/so reviews and was actually shocked some people seemed unimpressed. Don't listen to them! It is absolutely breathtaking and I spent the afternoon there totally enthralled. The gardens overlooking the Bosphorous are stunning as is the interior. So glad I went. You won't be sorry

Nothing super special. Perhaps if we had never been to St Petersburg or Versaille, we may have been far more impressed but we have been to those places and consequently found the Dolmabahce Palace to be a bit of a pale imitation. Also, as another reviewer commented, they tend to rush you through in very large groups from room to room and we found the guides difficult to understand as well. Not good value at 40 TL per person.

Beautiful. We visited this palace after our tour on the Bosphorus. We viewed the palace on our cruise earlier in the day. The palace gardens were beautiful and the palace is large and elaborate and is amazingly positioned facing the Bosporus.

Rich palace. We took a tour of the Dolmabahche palace. That is the only way to see the palace. The palace is outstanding. It is maintained well and the garden is great too. It is right on the Bosphorous strait. A must see in Istanbul.
Beautiful. Beautiful palace next to the Marmara sea and close to Istanbul Modern - an art museum - it is a must.

We loved this place!. Very interesting to see and hear about the history of this palace. Beautiful interiors and unique set up. Well worth a visit when in Istanbul. It will show you how the old sultans really lived.

Beautiful!. Don't miss it! During the spring, when the tulips are blooming, the palace is absolutely lovely and perfect backdrop for pictures. And, the fact that it sits just along the Bosphorus Strait gives you a stunning backdrop for pictures of the Dolmabahce Palace :).

Looks like Sultans are still there.... Dolmabahce Palace is maintained so well that you might think Sultans are still living inside. Every single things are kept clean and polished. The chandeliers are so big that I have never seen before (may be in Dubai recently a larger one is made). The crystal works are so beautiful that unless you see it, you can not describe the beauty. The story as described by the guide was fascinating, specially the story of Harem and Sultans' way of life....
Fantastic. My favourite part of palace was the garden, the buildings and museums were good but the garden was sth extraordinary.it was like a piece of heaven, i really loved it.

On the other shore. Everyone visits Topkapi, Sofia and the Blue Mosque, but many miss this amazing palace. It reminds me of St. Petersburgh. Beautiful views of the sea and the other shore. Ornaments of the full palace are superb. Very interesting to understand how the sultans lived and even Ataturk. The harem is not very worth it except to understand the power of the sultan's mother. 40' guided visit. Last space breath taking.
Dolma Palace. it is beautiful must visit. the atmosphere , ambience, history , cultural. it was one of the beautiful thing visited by us on the tour. istanbul is very attractive.

Definitely worth a visit. A sumptuous, relatively modern, palace on the Bosporus. From Gulhane we boarded the T1 tram and got down at its last stop: Kabatas.
