From there it was a short stroll along the Bosporus to the gates of the palace. The grounds are lovely. The palace has two sections, neither of which you can stroll through on your own. You have to join a group. Our English speaking guides were succinct and I guess could have been more interesting/interactive - but that would i guess lengthen the duration of the tour. Lots of beautiful things to see,

If only they let you enjoy it. This palace could have been anywhere in Western Europe. It was designed by a French architect and has a short but interesting history. It's where Mustafa Kemal Atatürk ran the government from and spent his final days. The downside are: no pictures and the guides group you into large tours where you are quickly explained every room and led as fast as possible through each. You get no time to enjoy it. It is very pretty inside and the outside is picture worthy, but I would skip it unless you have lots of time.

Beautiful palace along the Bosphorus. This gorgeous palacel was located close to our hotel along the Bosphorus- the grounds are breathtaking as is the palace. Unfortunately, you do have to take a "guided tour" provided by the palace and the tour guides are not the best! No pictures are allowed to be taken- which is silly, in my opinion! It is beautiful inside!

Modern" Ottoman Sarai. Dolmabahçe Palace (Turkish: Dolmabahçe Sarayı, IPA: [doɫmabahˈtʃe saɾaˈjɯ]) located in the Beşiktaş district of Istanbul, Turkey, on the European coastline of the Bosphorus strait, served as the main administrative center of the Ottoman Empire from 1856 to 1922, apart from a 22-year interval (1887–1909) in which Yıldız Palace was used.The site of Dolmabahçe was originally a bay on the Bosphorus which was used for the anchorage of the Ottoman fleet. The area was reclaimed gradually during the 18th century to become an imperial garden, much appreciated by the Ottoman sultansIt is Magnificent and An amazing building in a beautiful setting.Easily reached by tram from SultanAhmed or Taksim.I enjoyed when i visit this place , i can describe how this place is unique . Moreover,there are many museums in this palace.the bad thing there are extra fee for each museum inside this palace.you can also enjoy in Bosphurus insde the palace .

Favourite palace in Istanbul. So glad that I saw this palace. Went as it was recommended to us by a friend's mother, who also loved it. It is very interesting from both an historic and aesthetic point of view. General info and personal recommendations- different tickets are available for different parts of the palace, definitely get the full ticket for 40lira if you don't have the museum pass- Main areasThe main palace is very grand and interesting. The harem was more personal as it was the family home for the sultan and his wives, concubines, his mum and children. You also see where Ataturk, Turkey's national hero, lived and the bedroom where he passed away. - Other areas to see The clock museum, the painting museum and the Crystal section are 10 lira each if you don't have the full ticket. We enjoyed them. - Toursyou cannot access the main palace or harem on your own, there are guided tours in English and Turkish, alternating every 15 minutes. The other areas can be accessed on your own. - FYIDON'T take photos inside any of the buildings, people on our tour were noticed on the cctv and a security guard came and made then delete the photos. You must wear plastic overshoes inside the palace. Wear shoes that you can comfortably cover. People with flip flops on our tour found them awkward.

The "Modern" Ottoman Palace. The Ottomans built this palace to be able to compete with the European architecture and be seen as more modern. I think they might have succeeded to some extent. While impressive it doesn't have the same appeal as the Topkapi palace.

Magnificent. An amazing building in a beautiful setting. Easily reached by tram from Sultanahmet (just go straight to Kabatas, the last stop, and it is just a few more metres away). Entrance is by tour only and no photographs allowed. It is magnificent, as are the grounds.

Royal all the way. Unforgettable experience. The palatial grounds are huge and the views towards the Bosphorus amazing. The architectural splendor both inside and out is one to experience. The guided tours inside the palace are well worth the money paid for the entrance tickets.Unfortunately photography is not allowed inside. One just has to etch in ones memory the grandeur of the place as well as the lavishness. Both the official part of the palace as well as the residential areas( Harem) need to be seen. To avoid huge crowd and the heat inside go in the early morning hours. Also the taxis right outside ask for ridiculous prices for any destination and it is best to walk a few hundred feet to take a cab.The entrance with a beautiful fountain and garden full of flowers with a backdrop of the palace is a great place to take some amazing photos, as is the Bosphorus side.Interestingly Mustafa Kemal Ataturk passed away in one of the rooms in this palace, which was his residence, and last occupied by him, and this room is on display as well.
Such opulence!. This is a continuous jaw-dropper. There are several tickets available, but the basic one is adequate for most, in our view. Don't miss it.

Unforgettable experience. The most amazing building in Istanbul..it will blow your mind! Placed on beautiful Bosphore, the exterior is what has really moved me.. amazing garden and gate that takes you to the sea..it can't be described with words

Feel like the Sultans. Imagine yourself being a Sultan or Sultana. Enter proudly and enjoy every room you walk through, with all the details around. Try to visualize yourself in the period during which those sultan lived and how they lived. The you'll double enjoy the experience. The architecture and location by the "Bosphore: are awesome.

dont miss the interior. One of the most beautiful places in Istanbul, located at on the European coastline of the Bosphorus river. Although it has a wonderful garden and a view to Boshphours, the interior is maybe even more beautiful, so don’t miss to visit it.

Amazing. I have been to many of the great palaces in Europe but this is the most beautiful of all.
The gardens, architecture and enormity place it in a class of its own.
This is a must see in Istanbul behind the bazaars and great mosques

Turkish gem. Amazing palace, takes you back to the old days. Very nice art pieces and chandeliers. Make sure to to visit the ladies harem which is also breathtaking and watch the change of the guards in front of the palace.

Luxurious living. We have seen many palaces around the world and this one certainly ranks high above the others. A mixture of old and modern day fixtures make it easy for us to co-relate things of the past and recent times. The chandeliers are awesome and intricate. The view of the sea from the palace is excellent. The wall and ceiling decor are opulent. A must see place if in Istanbul

Last hurrah. We spent our last day in Istanbul here. We took the T1 from near our hotel to the last stop. Short walk to the palace. They control the number of visitors and you have to go through with a guide in a group. Also important to know they only take cash, but there is a nearby ATM. We took time to see the art gallery, which we enjoyed, as well as the palace and harem. Also the clock museum was worth a quick visit. Highly recommend a visit.

Tops every other European Palace. I have been in just about every palace all over Europe, but this one takes the cake. Relatively modern (lived in until the 1920's), but the opulence is overwhelming. Required to take a tour, which is good to learn all about it. Gorgeous setting right on the Bosphorus Straits. Lovely gardens. An event!
Make sure it's on your list.. By far one of the most elaborate and intricate palaces in all the world. It is an easy train ride from the Old City and so worth it!

Fabulous Palace. A must visit place. Real opulence. The place is epitome of luxury and throws light into the fabled leaving style of that era. The reportedly 7 ton heavy chandelier is awesome. Glass stair case and the general settings in t he palace are fun to watch. The outside gardens are also nice. The palace right on the sea front has an old world charm.A must see place

Lovely Palace, Different Experience that Topkapi. This palace is much different than Topkapi palace and that is why I love it. It is unexpected and truly majestic. While no where near as large, the gardens and the palace are both quite large and shows the excess in which the Ottoman Empire became accustomed to. You also get to see Ataturk's office and final resting place. The gates facing the river make for wonderful photos as well as the lion fighting the alligator (my favorite). You must take a tour, you cannot just roam freely through the palace. In addition they do NOT allow photos and are very strict about it to the point if they catch you they will ask to see your camera and force you to delete pictures from your camera and escort you out. Some of the highlights here are the amazing chandeliers, the crystal staircase and enormous rug.

Beautiful Palace with vast showmanship of excesses. Its a beautiful palace which is well preserved. The guided tour makes it easy to understand and you get through the whole palace in around 35-40 minutes depending on the size of your group and the guide ofcourse.The Harem is not really worth visiting unless you are interested in watching the death bed of Ataturk and some palacial bedrooms.Overall a must visit place even if you are on a short 2 day trip (as I was). Should ideally visit aftet visiting Topkapi Palace/Museum to see the upgrade in lifestyle.
Don't miss this lovely Palace. Beautiful Palace and Gardens, Knowledgeable guides, great location on the Bosphorus. The waiting time can be annoying, though, come early
Wonderful palace. A must see for sure. When i first stepped i had the WOW impression!! One of the best things that i saw in Istanbul. It is like you are doing a tour in a movie site.

Victorian excess.. Lots of very fine pieces, but, unless you're a student of the Victorian era it is basically an example of the overdone nature of that time.Don't make it a priority. Go to the Hagia Sophia twice, instead.Also: no photos allowed, so no memories.
Wonderful. The Summer Palace is in excellent conditions, the floor coverings and most of the furnishings are original. It is truly Palatial
Structural masterpiece. Amazing palace with tasteful finishings and furniture. Beautiful gardens. Amazing chandeliers. Lovely views of the strait. Everything is a beauty to behold

Wonderful. A must see for every visitor to Istanbul. A wonderful 'modern' palace, with grand rooms and halls, delightful crystal, and the most amazing chandeliers. The gardens alone are something special. .

Shouldn't be a priority. It was my second Istanbul visit so I checked out this palace that can onlybe visited by unenthusiastic guided tour...being rushed through it was hard to really appreciate anything here...guides simply were human tape recorders spitting out memorized explanations...not really worth the 2 hours...

A bbeautiful palace spoilt by stupid rules and procedures. One of the most beautiful palaces we have ever seen, rivals Versailles and St. Petersburg. Beautiful design and elegant finishes. Totally spoilt because no photography allowed. Even had to delete a shot I had reallly wanted. No reason for this stupidity. Books available do not show great interior photos. Compulsory guided tours wastes time, and you can't hear guide anyway. Great building but an awful visit and experience, unlike anything else in Istanbul

AMAZING!. It was wonderful, Do not miss this unless you simply don't enjoy history and art. For 40 TL, they whisk you in and send you on a tour -- Turkish or English -- Everything looked absolutely stunning! You go in with a guide and although the groups could be a bit smaller, the tour was very interesting! Please follow the rules and dont make any photos or videos inside!

AMAZING !!!!. I have been to many palaces/museums in my time but tis place had me speechless. It was grande it was vast and it was easy to get lost in. If your ever in Istanbul you must pay a visit. Its a great way to get a real taste of the ottoman empire and what it was.

Last room is AMAZING! Gates, Gardens.. Bosphorous. We walked down from our hotel to see this palace. The gardens are beautiful. The large white gates to the Bosphorous are gorgeous. The palace is enormous! You do however have to buy tickets, tiny line but then they only allow you in on a guided tour of about 30 so we had to wait. It is very pretty inside, our guide was quick which we liked. We kept bumping into the group ahead of us which was slow. Very pretty ornate stairs and chandelirs and tiles. Worth seeing. We had to cut out early so quickly followed the path.. when we got to the end there was a BIG AMAZING room with a fabulous gigantic chandelier and extremely high domed ceilings. I was in AWE! That last room was worth it all. I would have liked to stay in that room for a while!! We did not go into the 'harem' b/c it was a separate tour I believe and they only let you see a part of it anyway. Harem is just the living quarters I believe.

Beyond AMAZING!. This magnificent complex left me in awe. Too bad one can't take photos inside but otherwise the photos will be left alone in the memories of the tourist who witness this awe-spiring structure with its delicate and impressive details plus the furnitures. When in istanbul dont miss this place! :))

beautiful but not a must.... if you are fond of palaces,this is one of the many palaces of the city...a typical european palace , it is worth if you have time..2 things inside , they are in the guinness book of records ; biggest hand made carpet and heaviest crystal chandelier.

Fantastic place!. The palace situated in the beautiful giant park near see side. It has lots of beautiful flowers ,trees, fountains and ponds. The palace inside is very reach and beautiful, lot of rugs, crystal chandeliers telephone .It has 68 washrooms. The second building Harem is also very nice. Great experience!

FROM TOPKAPI TO DOLMAHBAHCE. DOLMAHBACE is the alternate sultan s option,to mark the 18 century changes.It has a lot of french an italian elements.It is believed that the palace was so expensive that the OTOMAN EMPIRE had debts for him during his building.MUSTAFA KEMAL ATATURK has died here at the age of 57,I think and they stopped the clock at 5 to 9,or 15 to 9 in the morning which was the time that KEMAL died,in order to pay theirs respect to the ruler,to his achievements.

Awe inspiring. A truly amazing place constructed across the waterway from the Topkapi area. It is immense in size and definitely worth visiting. From the 35 tons of gold leaf used throughout the palace, the world's largest chandelier, the paintings on the walls, furnishings, and the murals on the domed ceilings, it rivals any palaces throughout the world. The intense colour of the murals is awe inspiring and to realize that it was lived in just 90 years ago, complete with radiators for heating it, as well as its magnificent furnishings helps one to realize fully how the sultans lived here before Turkey came into existence in 1922.It is best to go with your own guide or you are gathered together with about 140 other people and taken through at their pace, etc. Note that there are no photos allowed inside but there are lots of opportunities to photograph the outside and great gardens.

Good alternative for Topkapi!. We were planning to visit Topkapi first before we come to Istanbul before friends advised us to visit Dolmabahce Palace first! they said it was worthy and they were right!This palace has a long and very interesting history from the Othmans' era. This was the winter place for Mustafa Ataturk and where he studied and died.There is no complete visit to Istanbul without visting this palace. The only two things we didn't like was the poor English of one of our guide and the lack air-conditoning. It is pity that photographing is not allowed.

The most beautiful palace in Istambul!. Definitwly visit this palace when in Istambul!!
Christal staircase,christal lights,luxurious furniture,the pictures...You don't see that very often..
Also...the garden is amazing!!Take the time to sit under the tree and enjoy the view.

Museum/Palace in Istanbul. We walked from our hotel ( Surmeli) as it wasn't on our tour. We waited in line for 2-21/2 hours and then if you wanted to be with an english interpreter it was another 45 min- 1hr wait. It was certainly worth the wait however I would suggest getting on a tour as they can get you in faster & I believe the tour guide would be better at describing the structure etc. It was built during the Ottoman Empire consisting of 3 parts -men's section(administrative), grand hall and of course the harem ( where the members of the royal family lived). It has a crystal staircase and a crystal chandelier weighing 4.5 tons and having 700+ candles given to the Sultan by Queen Victoria. If nothing else this is worth seeing!! The view to the Bosphorus is fantastic.

Grand Palace. The palace has got a quota on visitors so make it early so that u get to see it. The palace itself was full of grandeur. The guide downstairs on the day we visited was good. But the guide upstairs was too brief. He sounded as if he wanted us out of the was as soon as possible.

AMAZING!. Breathtaking palace, amazing décor, art work and furniture. highly recommended. By the Harem ticket as well (the building attached to dolmabahce) to see when there Sultans and Ataturk lived.
Amazing!. Loved visiting the palace, although i would suggest using a guide to appreciate the full extent of the palace. Visiting the harem costs extra, but definately worth it!

Hideous Palace, amazing location . This palace is the 19th century palace for the ottoman sultans who moved there fro the Topkapi in the second half of the century. It's architecture and design speak a lot about the cultural and political decline of the Empire and it's constant confusion about whether it's an eastern or more western power. The palace is very tacky in a late 1800s sort of way. The swan fountains in the garden are all too much. The location is fabulous. Just on the Bosphorus, with a wonderful view of the old city and Asia. Strolling there on a sunny day is quite something. One can even forgive the palace design and see why it has an appeal. I reccomned not focusing too much on the inside and enjoying the gardens more. 45 mins is sufficient time.
historical mysterious palace. it's located sea side and have mysterious beautiful view with historical background. you will found special feeling after visiting this palace and it's garden.

Interesting palace. Beautiful palace and gardens next to the water. Obviously as a palace built to copy European styles it doesn't have strong Turkish influences but is worth a trip nonetheless. Just a note, the ticket to see the harem family area is extra and probably not worth it. The main palace has some stunning areas, the harem, not so much.

Great place but make sure you check out the guide. The palace was a great place to visit. Arranging the tour was very difficult. We tried to buy tickets to the palace online, and couldn't get it done. Therefore, we bought tour tickets from a tour company. That company, She Tours, was disappointing. The group size was very large. Although the guide knew his material very well, he didn't project well to a group that big. We were rushed through. Then, the tour ended with a trip to a leather manufacturer. After a fashion show there, we were giving the "opportunity to shop" and kept waiting in the store for far too long. Conclusion- we found the palace is a great place to visit, but regret that we went with She Tours.

Dolmabahce. The most beautiful palace in Turkey . In this palace you will see part of the history .in this palace lived the last khalifa of Ottoman Empire . The first President of Turkey (Mustafa Kamal Ataturk ) also lived and died in this palace .The visitors can visit all the private areas in the palace and see the furnitures, beds. tables , carpets , the largest chandelier in the world ( 4.5 tonnes) in their original places .
Tour guides too large and fast . You have to go with a tour. It is a shame because I would have liked to have spent more time in there. Instead you are rushed through in a very large group.

The best of all. Out of all the mosques and palaces I visited in Istanbul, this one was the best. Great view, nice chandeliers and amazing halls and furnitures inside. Good thing was that you don't need to get audio guide. There are tour leaders who guide people and explain the history and all the details of palace. It was really good and everyone could hear them.I just had the Sarayi ticket and it was great. I think Harem is nice as well and I regret it now! There is also a nice restaurant outside overlooking water. We had coffee there. It was a good rest.

Elegance and luxury. Beautiful historic palace, made up of many different architectural styles.Amazing green gardens with flowers, designed in a French style, the working flower clock!Very elegant in design and has ultra luxurious interior!Must visit!

Great compliment to Topkapi palace. Enjoyed seeing a furnished palace and the tours were just the right amount of information to give a flavour of life at the time. Also has interesting Ataturk connection.Great views too and lovely gardens. Check out the Ottoman clock face on the tower.

Wonderful palace, nice gardens. Very nice palace lokated near Taksim square. Huge gardens and buildings, I recommend visit both - palace and Harem. There is a huge discount for students with valid ISIC card - just 5TL. Lovely both interiors and exteriors but for Europeans common thing :). It can be a bit crowded during day so plan your visit rather in the morning/or evening - 2 hours are just ok.

A must see!. Do not miss out on a tour of the inside of this amazing palace! Each room got better and better as we went through. The crystal stair banisters are a treat to see, as is the beautiful Limoges fireplaces, carpets and the 3 huge crystal chandeliers (largest weighs 4.5 ton !!!!!!)

Beautiful palace with an impressive ending.. This is a palace by the water, not too far from the beautiful Ciragan Palace hotel (also beautiful, check it out).It has timed tours only so it's easier to see the place with getting explanations and not feel overcrowded. The marble arches and facade are pretty, as is the small garden area outside.You'll join a tour of the stately rooms and be told of the palace's history and also relevant historical figures, and it's nice to see the grand decor and facilities installed. There is a lovely staircase and other rooms that are rather impressive. My favourite part was the end: the largest chandelier I've ever seen, housed in an equally impressive grand hall that dwarfs many European palaces.There is an additional tour you can take for the harem but I'd recommend you save money and skip it - after seeing the main palace, this was FAR more lackluster and it's better to leave on a high.This is a much better palace than the disappointing Topkapi palace (more like a fortress). I HIGHLY recommend this as a place to visit.

Spectacular Lamps!. This palace is not to be missed... You have to take into account the following:1. No pictures inside2. You Have to go with a guide, they will provide one for groups without a guide.3. You will have to wear plastic covers on your feet (they provide them).4. The security opens at 8:30, the ticketing at 8:45 and the palace doors at 9:00 am.Once this is known, we had the very good fortune to have a knowledgable guide, Mr. Murat Cicekli... We joined his group.... He was both good and to the point! His email murat@contactturkey.com ... He will make this tour a breeze! The palace itself is large and well maintained... There are still renovations on the way, but we had the chance to see the soectacular chandeliers... There were tons of them and one more beautiful than the orher one... Also very impressive, the stair handrails were made by Baccarat!!! Around 11 euros per person and 45 to 50 minutes to complete....
Mesmerising palace. I have never seen such a wonderful, mind blowing beauty in while my life. Every lover of historical places must visit this palace and enjoy it's beauty.

Skip this overated attraction. Large group of visitors will be herded into, in our case, English speaking tour group. The group was quite large and we only manage to catch snippets of information from the tour guide. There is absolutely no chance of leisurely view of the once overly luxurious rooms which now look a bit on the shabby side. You will be herded from hallway to hallway featuring the various rooms which after a while is getting a bit boring. Draconian rule of absolutely no photography inside the palace which is a shame because the main hall is quite stunning with the huge crystal chandelier and 3D ceiling mural. We also visited the Hurem which was the private quarters of the royal family. Again, we had to follow the tour guide. Quite a challenge trying to hear her when the group is large. The bedrooms were surprisingly small, not what I had expected it to be.The furnishings were, not surprisingly, quite worn out by now. You also get the privilege of seeing the royal loos. The gardens were very nice and you can take as many photographs as you want. Overall the exterior of the palace was very nice, more refreshing than the interior. If you only have a few days in Istanbul, this is one attraction you can skip. Only a limited number of visitors is allowed daily so it is best to get there early. It is about 500m away from the last tram stop in Kabatas. Btw there are several flights of stairs to manouver, so if you are physically challenged, more reason for you to skip this place.

Magnificent but . . .. Maybe we picked a bad time, early Sunday afternoon? It was busy but even so, the way this beautiful palace is 'policed', ruins the whole experience.1. NO PHOTOGRAPHS. Once inside this ruling is so strictly enforced, you daren't raise your hands above waist height. If no flash is used why not? The interior is beautiful but there are no state secrets here? 2. Understandably you are instructed to wear plastic covers over your shoes and only walk on the red carpets. The way the attendants shouted at anyone who strayed slightly off the carpets was so aggressive.3. You are herded around in a large control group from one stopping point to another, the following group always just behind. All you get are fleeting glimpses of the 'treasures' you pass as there is no allowance made for slowing down never mind daring to stop. When you do stop with your guide he gives a brief, hurried explanation in broken English which you try to hear before the group behind appear with their inevitable talking. No, writing this review is bringing back the whole horrible experience. Such a pity. If it was managed and organised more sympathetically and sensibly as so many places now are, it could be a great place to visit. Yes, it is a magnificent palace, but the visitor experience is utterly spoilt. Enjoy the beautiful gardens, at least you can relax here, take yor time, take photographs, reflect on what you are seeing, and not be shouted at!

NOT FREE & EASY. Visitors must follow scheduled English-speaking tours of the Palace (45min) and the Harem (30min). This means over 50 people following one guide around. You can hardly hear the guide or have time to marvel at the opulent chandeliers. There was little ventilation in the crowded spaces. Overall, it was not a comfortable tour. Go only if you have the time. You might want to give this a miss if you have seen other European palaces on a grander scale and housing more treasures.Do note: No indoor photography is allowed.

Impressive on the outside. I did this yesterday as part of an all day, and while I wanted to like it, I would have rather spent the hour outside on the grass looking at the sea.There was no air conditioning. Our tour guide had to repeat his presentation in Russian and English which caused the group behind us to crowd in. I can't remember much of what he told us except there were lots of ambassadors and Ataturk died there. The harem areas and the ballrooms were interesting, but might have been more so if I could remember their importance.No pictures are allowed inside.If you are a Turkish history or Turkish politics wonk, this place could be something for your to see list if you have a few days in Istanbul.

Wear comfortable shoes. First thing, you cannot take pictures inside the Saray or the Harem. That's a bummer and that is not posted until you get inside. It goes to the extreme that they have people that follow you around making sure you don't take photos. The sights outside are awesome. Take baby wipes and napkins because they only have 1 toilet in that place. The rest are turkish toilets

Beautiful, but I'd prefer to wander without a tour. The palace is lovely, had a great view and so many rooms you could get lost for days.Unfortunately, you aren't allowed free reign to wander the halls at your own pace. The English speaking tour groups were large, so we didn't always know what was going on. Over all a good experience, but personally I prefer my own speed and the ability to look into rooms not just shuffle past them.

Go if you like to see royal residences. This is a "modern" palace (think early 1900s), with a little dated and faded furniture and wall hangings. If you can get over the annoyances of the place (have to go on a tour with a guide with a large group, so that the second half of the group can't hear what the guide is saying anyway). The last site on the tour makes it worthwhile - the main ceremonial hall is huge, with a dome that is close in grandeur to the Hagia Sophia with a huge chandelier hanging down the bottom.I also visited the Harem here, as I missed it in Topkapi Palace. It was interesting to see the number of rooms in the Harem, but these are "modern" day rooms rather than the mysterious Harem in history. Worth going to if you have the time.In the back, there is a small aviary and pond, which would be fun for kids. There were guinies, ducks and ducklings, and peacocks! One warning - there was a creepy attendant in the Crystal Pavilion who was offering ladies to take a picture of the piano, but then he would grab them and give them big hugs and kisses on the cheek. One last thing - about 15 minutes away, near the Shangrila, there is an area called Besiktas. It is a very local shopping area with fast fashion cheap women clothes, a lot of restaurants, some food prep shopping (meat stores, supermarkets, etc), some dollar stores. I liked it because it felt very local, and I found the pomegranate syrup I had been looking for.

Spectacular. Huge, lavish rooms with gold and crystal accents. Frame photos of your family under the gates that open to the Bosphorus. Sadly, no photos are permitted inside the palace. Unforgettable, huge chandelier and various gifts from visiting Royalty. Not to be missed.

If you like palaces and castles, then visit. It took 13 years or so to complete the palace and they did a great job. If you like palaces, then take the time to visit. It is a short not too hurried group tour. I can't adequately describe the palace except to say go visit - you won't be disappointed. Try to get there early because the do sell out of tickets. They are not open on Monday and Thursday. Don't bother with the art museum ticket. The clock museum exhibit was also interesting if clocks are your thing. It takes about a solid 1 - 1.5 hours to see the palace and the grounds.Rindge Leaphart

The Ottoman Empire at its finest. First be sure you get your tickets in advance. This tour fills up and for good reason.. Here is where the history ends for the centuries old Ottoman Empire- 1856. The Dolmabache Palace is the last desperate attempt to impress Western Europe culture to be recognized as relevant.....it was built with the finest architecture, artisans and material - 280 rooms all with Crystal and porcelain chandeliers - the one in the entrance is the largest in the Western world.

Not accessible to disabled persons. I took my parents to see the palace, which I had seen before. As we approached a security guard directed my parents to use disabled access and told them they did not have to pay. I bought tickets for myself and aunt and mentioned my parents. Got to main entrance of palace which had stairs leading to door. Noticed a lift on the side but it did not work. Called the guy at the door and he said he would help my parents get up the stairs. After walking around the ground floor for 5 mins we were confronted by a grand stair case which my parents could not manage so we had to leave. We wasted 40tl on the two tickets for myself and my aunt. They should have informed us of the stairs and we would have not bothered to buy tickets.

Worth a visit – just about – if you have a spare ½ day.. Built on the shore of the Bosporus, a palace built to impress and on first impressions that what it does. Built in the European style which makes it stand out from the other sites in Istanbul. Best way to get there is by tram to Kabatas and a 10 minute walk along the sea front. Closed Monday and Thursday and not included on the museum card, no photography allowed. No solo entrance only as part of a group guided tour, these tours in English and Turkish last about 45 minutes for each section of the palace. Which means waiting in line outside the building for 20 to 60 minutes (in the sun or rain) for a tour to begin and this queuing applies to both parts with a separate tour for each. Before entering the palace, you put plastic overshoes on to lessen damage to the palace floors but as you follow a carpeted route this seems a bit pointless. The tour rushes past rooms which may be of interest to you and concentrates on the main rooms. The marble columns are not marble but wood and plaster painted. The picture galley on site is worth a visit and if you are there in the late afternoon you can see the bird round up as they try to get the peacocks, golden pheasant, chickens etc back into their pens for the night.

Great place. Do not miss this unless you simply don't enjoy history and art. It's a great palace and I have visited many all over the world. Yes, it's rushed and you can barely understand the guide, but this is a must see if you have the time. For $5 they sell a book with pictures and information about the palace and rooms. This will help you learn more as you don't get a lot from the guides. Make sure that you don't miss the picture museum as well. It has some really outstanding rooms. I was very impressed with everything. If you are on a cruise ship it's an easy walk to the right as you leave the cruise port. Just follow the water down past the tour boats.

Do not miss this beautiful palace. We did this palace as part of a Bosphorus cruise with biocriuse.com and can highly recommend them. The palace is probably one of the most beautiful palaces I have seen all over the world. You can only enter the palace as part of a guided tour so don't just turn up and think you'll be able to go in. The guide we had was brilliant and I am so glad that it was part of a tour. This really was my favourite sight in Istanbul do not miss it

Put this on your must see list. We did this on the last of 4 days in Istanbul. It should have been much higher on our list of sights.. What makes this palace even more impressive is that most of the rooms are furnished as they were originally from the period. It is absolutely worth seeing. If you come individually (not in a group with a guide) be prepared to wait a little until they do the next group of individuals. The group has to be escorted by a guide they assign. They post the time so you will know. Groups with their own guide go straight in ahead of you. Keep close to the guide once inside or it may be difficult to hear what he/she is saying during the tour. Book through a tour if you want to avoid the wait.

The Hidden Gem of Turkey. The grandeur of this palace is beyond comprehension. It is a delightful "European" palace, where no money has been spared to make this the grandest palace in the world. Blenheim Palace in England pales into insignificance when compared to Dolmabahce. Other reviewers have said "unbelievable" and "jaw dropping", it is no exaggeration. We did a small group tour which was fantastic, no queues. You must visit this palace, and is very close to the centre of Istanbul.

Disappointed with quick in-and-out tour. I went to the Dolmabahce Palace -- the Western designed palace that's a good counterpoint to Topkapi -- and was very disappointed with the routine. For 40 TL, they whisk you in and send you on a tour -- Turkish or English -- with about 50 other people. You just about race through the palatial wonder while the tour guide offers a very perfunctory dialog with the 10 or so people in front. Why can't you just wander through on your own? Tip: The outside gardens with a swan fountain and setting on the Bosporus are beautiful. Also the newly opened art gallery in the back. Note that when you enter, everyone has to cover their shoes with plastic booties, and there as NO photos as the entire interior is made of gold leaf.

Unbleviable. It's like a western palace but includes special parts called harem for sultan's women, books from France and Persia, the palace has a English Tour, Ataturk used this palace as a presidential Palace,

Jaw dropping. One of the most impressive pieces of architecture I've ever visited. The chandeliers, the decor, the massive rooms and the location on the Bosphorus make for a very amazing visit. Worth the trip to see it.

Wish I'd never gone. We went by ourselves and not in any group. Everything seems a queue job so you grind your way slowly forward. A group comes either a local guide or of a ship and walk straight in - they get priority. It was bad enough that this happens but the whole thing is just disorganised. What little we say was wonderful but the effort to see it isn't worth it. It's also shut on a Thursday and if you try to go the guards are not very polite

Extraordinary and amazing Ottoman tour. This is the largest palace in Turkey where the Ottoman sultans lived for 66 years after living in the Topkapi Palace. The last royal to live here was the sultan Caliph Abdul Majeed Efendi. It is a very luxurious European style blended with Ottoman-architecture palace overlooking the Bosphorus with fascinating views and very well organised beautiful gardens. The Sultans and their harems lived a lavish life here and it has the worlds largest chandelier which is made of crystal and located in the center Hall. We found furniture covered with light or thin gold, some corners and pass ways and steps made of marble, chandeliers made of crystal. It was just amazing to walk with the tour guide and listen to the Luxury lifestyle the Ottoman sultans lived in the different rooms, offices and halls.It was the Turkish leader Kamal Ataturk who first changed this palace into his home and later he turned it into a museum.The palace is separated into two main sections; the men section (selamlik) reserved for public action. And the women section (haremlik) which is a private section for the sultan's harems or family and it shows how much luxury, money and gold was spent decorations. We noticed so many crystal chandeliers all over the palace specially the famous crystal staircase. The beautiful collection of carpets were fascinating and it takes a long time just watching them. Don't miss out on the museum of paintings. This has a huge collection of amazing and extraordinary art work of oil paintings of nearly 200 ones. The paintings were done by different artist who were guests on the sultans. Just visit the museum and enjoy every piece of artwork and it may take you two days to be satisfied with the work.

Amazing!. The Dolmabahçe Palace was simply amazing! Everything looked absolutely stunning! You go in with a guide and although the groups could be a bit smaller, the tour was very interesting! Please follow the rules and dont make any photos or videos inside! The reason that the guides can seem a bit moody is that so many people dont care about the rules and make photos from everything they see. Please respect thale rules and you will have an amazing visit. You will see how the daily life was in the palace. Absolutely a must see, in my opinion its must better than Topkapı!Note: closed on monday and thursday!!

A different taste than many places in old town. If you are going to visit Istanbul for 3 days, I strongly recommend you to spend one day to visit this Palace in the morning, and in the afternoon take the hop-on-hop-off cruise (just 5 minutes walking distance away) and late afternoon visit the Glata tower.The best time to visit Dolmabahce Palace is the early morning, you should arrive 30 minutes before it opens to avoid long lines from tourist groups. All visitors are group to different groups (depends on their language) and follow their tour guides, you are not allowed to walk around in the Palace by yourself nor to take picture in palace, but outside the palace are free to stay as long as you want. The palace is on the Bosphorus strait, If the weather is good, the view is beautiful.

Beautiful on the outside but terribly organised.. The outside of the palace is stunning . However to visit the harem we had to wait 20 minutes to walk in with a group of about 80 people. The guide weirdly would get annoyed because the people at the back with kids were talking and wouldn't listen. It was not stated at the entrance that to visit the palace entailed going in a huge group, The harem was disappointing. The main palace was more interesting but once again the large group experience was bad. And we had to walk through together for 40 minutes.it kind of ruined the experience for me. I agree with someone else's review that it was just looking at some dusty old furniture. The entrance fee is high so feel free to skip,the harem.

Awe-inspiring and interesting. Dolmabache Palace is the modern palace located by the Bosphorus. It's amazing to see from the inside because of its luxury and magnificence. This is one place where the historical and modern Turkey converges. It is awe-inspiring, but the sad part is that they don't allow you to take photographs. There is also a ticket worth like 30 TL but it is totally worth it.

So beautiful. Topkapi Palace is done in the Oriental and Turkish style, but Dolmabahce Palace is Western European style, reminiscent of Versailles. It's really beautiful, but can get crowded. It's also disappointing that they don't allow pictures inside due to security reasons, since the palace is still sometimes used for state functions. You can take pictures of the grounds though. If you take a boat tour on the Bosphorous, you can also get some pretty great photos of it from the water.

Amazing Dolmabahce. Dolmabahce Palace is an amazing place to vist in Istanbul. The architecture and it's gardens are beautiful. It has a beautiful view of Bosphorus. They provide an English speaking guide in the palace. It is better to buy a full ticket wihich is 40 TL, because with buying a 30 TL ticket we didn't get to see Ata Turk's section.

The picture I flew 10,000 miles to take. Comparatively, Dolmabahce is a bit out of the way considering that most of the must see sights are in Sultanahmet. It is easily reachable by tram as it is a short walk from the Kabatas stop. The walk allows a good look at the Dolmabahce mosque and the clock tower. The palace and the harem are well worth the price of admission which comes with a mandatory tour so it feels a little crowded. I am more of a wander on my own kind of girl. For me the grounds were the most enjoyable part of my visit and the gate that opens to the Bosphorus is the photo I flew 10,000 miles to take. If you did too, wander over to the gates further down as the main gate is both crowded and obstructed. The others, while not open, are less crowded and free of staged clutter. That area is a great place to sit and watch the boats on the Bosphorus. I know many reviews advise against it, but instead of taking the tram back, I jumped on one of the hop on hop off boats that allowed me to see Dolmabahce from the water as well as the Rumeli fortress, the Asian side of the Bosphorus, and hopped off as I wished to explore.
One of the best. The palace is really beautiful. It worth the visit. The garden is veryyyyyy nice and lovely. you gonna take lots of pics.

Definitely worth a visit. We did a full day tour with She Tours that started with the Dolmabahe Palace. Our guide was so knowledgeable without being boring. This is a great place to see but if you can get on this whole day tour that includes lunch and a boat cruise on The Bosphorus, then do it, well worth the cost of 70 euro.

great palace. I visited this place twice and I think it really worth seeing. if you're not with a tour there is a guide there that will explain each part of the house in English and that's so great. the outside is also as great as the inside you can sit there and eat and enjoy the view of sea and also garden of the house.

Not to be missed. Built in the 19th century was an administrative centre late in the Ottoman empire. The palace is very well appointed. Believe to make the most of the visit you should visit the Harem building first and then move around to the main building later. Mustafa Kemal Ataturk used the palace as a residence including late in his illness and passed away at the palace on 10 November 1938 at 9:05 AM, as a mark of respect all the palace clocks are stopped at this time.

Another Fabulous Site to Visit in Istanbul. Within walking distance of the hotel we stayed at in the business district. Grand rooms and a glimpse at what life was like in the palace for men and women. A great waterfront site.

It is worth a visit but not my favourite site in Instanbal. We visited the palace in November and even though the park around was not flowerful I liked the fall atmosphere outside and the way it was built. The palace is not only surrounded by a park it is also right next to the Bosporus and offers stunning views of the city and the traffic on water. The only way to discover the palace from inside is with a guided tour. The were long queues at the entrance and large groups were dragged under time pressure through the palace. I did not really enjoyed that part. Our guide gave some small details about each section in Ok English but I felt the tour was to rushed. The palace from inside is actually not fairy-tale like more as I had expected. It is more like similar palaces in Europe at the beginning of the 19th century. Be aware of this to avoid to be disappointed.

Amazing palace, disappointing tour guide. The palace itself is astonishing, with all the crystal and the architecture. The tour, however, is totally disappointing. We were gathered in a group of more than 50 people so it was basically impossible to hear something from the story. The guide did not wait until all the group is gathered at the same room, but was just telling on the story. Absolutely disappointing as a visitor!
Not really worth it. Compared to Topkapi palace, this is nothing. It is just an old building with old english/french furniture in it. Its full of dust and is not really representative of turkey.

Nice. the palace is nice, it is worth to visit. I have to admit that i like the inside gardens more than the palace itself, in which i discover a beautiful landscape of the sea and in the back one a lot of birds and cats :). the palace is an impressive building in which the politicians are organizing their international meetings. the harem is very modern, the rooms are full of chandeliers and gold. photos are not allowed.

Very European. The palace is beautifully located on the banks of the Bosphorus with stunning view of the river. Very European and slightly over the top in décor. But the Harem and the visiting rooms make it typically Turkish. Very ornate and the chandeliers weighing more than three tons make is worth a visit. Just browsing around shows the grandeur of the place and the way the Ottomans lived.

My favourite :). I absolutely loved it here! On the shores of the Bosphorus. The grounds were stunning when I visited. The inside is wonderful, and, if you have a good imagination, you can carry yourself back in time.The hidden gems inside are breath-taking from jewels, to art work, to furniture - you are immediately taken to a time gone by.This was where Mustafa Kemal Atatürk (the founding father of modern day Turkey) died, so there is an overwhelming atmosphere here.If you are interested in Turkey's history please do not miss this.If it were possible; I would visit Dolmabahçe Palace every time I went to Istanbul.

If you've seen a European palace... You don't need to go in. As long as you've been to a European palace before, then you've already seen the inside of this one. On the plus side, they have a choice of tickets: palace grounds, main palace, harem or all access. We went for the harem and you can only enter by tour. We jumped in on the Turkish tour so as not to wait, but would have preferred to go solo.The grounds are beautiful, with fountains, birds and roses. Really calm and manicured with a perfect Bosphorous view.

Excessively ornate. Get to the palace by taking the tram to Kabatas which is at the end of the purple tram line. From there it's a 5 minute walk. In order to see inside the palace you have to take a guided tour which lasts about 35 mins and no photos are allowed. On my tour the group was very large - approximately 50 people and our guide was not that enthusiastic or insightful but this was not helped by people constantly taking photos despite the reminders not to! The highlight of the tour is the Great ceremony hall which has a 4.5 tonne chandelier in the centre which was a present by queen Victoria. The rooms you pass through are extravagant and ornate. The cost to build the palace was $1.5 Billion in today's money! The outside gardens are nice but nothing special. A couple of hours is more than sufficient after which you can take the funicular train over to Taksim square and a stroll down Istikal street.

Almost missed it. I missed this place the first time because i was there at 4.02pm (close for tix at 4). Make sure to go there early. Everybody must joy the group provided by the museum (either in english or turkish). In May 2015, each group starts every 20 to 30 minutes.I can say that this is my second on the istanbul fav place. The palace is so beautiful. The stairs, chanderlier, decoration pieces,etc are preserved well and so beautiful especially the last ballroom which is incredibly beautiful. The garden by the sea is chilling. If you have a chance, take a ferry to see outside the palace. Must go there!!

Another amazing site in Turkey!. I've visited Dolmabache with family and had an outstanding experience. The palace itself is an amazing testimony to artistry and luxury. The amount of gold and crystal used throughout is breathtaking.

Worth a visit, although.... I had the opportunity to visit this place within 20 years and it still amaze me, even today. I just remember the times when you could take photos inside for free (glorious times!), also the times when, for a small fee, you also could take pictures or even film inside. It's not the case anymore... Besides, the time of the guided tour is year after year much shorter, you cannot visit anymore some of the rooms (just take a glimpse at them from the somehow distant central aisle) and the English language of the guides is poorer and poorer. Still worth 40 TL... But for how long?

A charming place. Last time I visitd this palace was 29'years ago.This was my second time.It is becoming more organized now but visitors are kept away from the displays and from entering the rooms.The palace is still charming but there are long ques.The so called guided tours are not efficient but you are forced to follow as you can not enter on your own.I also can not understand why photography is not allowed.It is worth visiting this place.You can feel some of the charm from the Ottoman period

Near our hotel. You can only enter the palace as part of a guided tour. There are no photos allowed inside. We caught the last English tour of the day. I wish it was a little more informative, but I'm grateful to have gotten an English-speaking tour. The chandeliers were quite impressive! I wish we had time for the Harem tour as well. I liked this better than Topkapi Palace, but with no photos and only certain rooms accessible, I thought perhaps it is a little overpriced. Though it was the usual 30 Lira like most tourist sites. The swan fountain, gates, and view of the Bosphorous are beautiful!

The billion dolars palace. Some says that the harem stories took place in the Topkapi palace, however I think those were actually happening in Dolmabahce palace. This is the most luxurious palace in Turkey which cost 35 tonnes of gold to be built (everything is gold plated in the palace) and contributed, by its cost, to the collapse of the Otoman Empire. It nicely combines Baroque, Rococo and Neoclassical styles with Otoman architecture and some parts looks really amazing. It can only be visited with a guide (included in the entry price), but there is a tour at every 10 minutes. Don't forget to buy a ticket for the Harem section too (it costs extra 10 lira) which is visited separately also with a guide. After the visit spent some time on the gardens near Bosphorus, it is really refreshing and you might feel a little bit why they were much appreciated by the Ottoman sultans,By the way, get some cash before visiting the palace. Credit cards payments are not accepted (I was quite surprised about this, because credit cards are accepted to pay the entrance to Topkapi palace, but for Dolmabahçe you must pay cash in Turkish lira)

Not interesting. This is a very large place in size but not in interest. It isn't really pretty except for the grounds, and it isn't interesting either. You are led around in large groups of 30-45 people. The only good thing was we picked up a ferry to Princes Islands near here and that was very fun.

Not too pleased. OK, the outside looks great, the gardens are manicured and gorgeous seaside view. But so well. Inside just some dusty furniture and carpets, you were not allowed to walk alone had to stay with the group. Pictures were not allowed to do (not what you had), Chinese plastic handles on doors, radiators gold. It was a big disappointment for me.

Must see in Istanbul . Dolmabache palace was built by Sultan Abdul Mageed. It was the residence of Turkish sultans and used by Attaturk the first president. It consists of two parts, salamlek for sultan daily activities and Hareem section for his wives and childrens. Very luxuries palace and must see during the visit to istanbul.
nice place. I love this place. It has a nice view and beautiful architecture. the tour guides are good and they explain everything. dont miss this place.

Gorgeous Palace near the Boshporus. Near the Boshporus,gorgeous palace...Not forget to visit Glass Chalet,exceptional
Very crowded since it is very touristic.You can enjoy for some refreshments at the cafe ,reasonable price

Beautiful sight needs better organisation. Let's be clear- the palace is stunning (though very new compared to the city's historic sights) with beautiful gardens and other subsidiary rooms. However it is expensive (remember that- 40 lira for palace +harem ticket). That's fine- we know that. However the problem is bad treatment- preferential treatment for tour groups so independent travellers have a longer wait.Moreover, no photography allowed inside, each guided tour is a huge group and that takes time. Also the tour timings are not coordinated properly- after our 45 min guided tour of the palace, we had to wait 30 min for the next harem tour. All these details need fixing.

Debunked a lot of myths about Harem!. Good tour guide for harem, only followed by better guide for Palace itself. very wducational, interesting facts about the sultans, caliphate, and Ataturk. Would definitely recommend as a good start before overdose of Sultanahmet.

I would give five stars more. Amazing place that I would never expect in Istanbul, breathtaking rooms with big chandelliers.Entrance fee for both parts together 40 TRY (office and harem); closed on Mondays and Thursdays; we came on the public holiday and the entrance was free of charge; guided tours only; taking photos and videos strictly forbidden.

French inspired palace, built in the 1856 (Recent). In 1856 the royal family moved from Topkapi to Dolmabahce. The ruler was a great admirer of the Versailles and built one of his own. There's a huge difference from the Ottoman style buildings to Dolmabahce, which is purely European. Most impressive: it's positioned right on the water side, beautiful view. Huge 5 tone chandelier in the main ball room.

One of the most beautiful palaces in Europe. This is one of the most beautiful palaces in Europe. The grand ballroom is incredible. Puts a similar one in Buckingham Palace and in the Madrid Palace to shame. Its the last stop on the tour. Budget about an hour for the tour and its best to buy in advance. Very friendly and knowledgeable guides

Great ballroom and architecture . The architecture was nice. The final ballroom was impressive. Other than that, I didn't get much out of the tour or other rooms. Getting there early helps to avoid the wait times. We got there at 9:30 and only waited about 20 minutes total to get inside as part of a tour. Our tour guide was good - she seemed interested in answering questions and even asked another tour guide to move ahead so those in her group could hear better. The groups are very big - perhaps 50 or more people.
Magnificent. A very big and well decorated castle, the dome is amazing. Furniture was not that great compared to other european castles. Photography is not allowed.

Should be in the top 5!. My husband and I nearly over looked this place and glad we didn't!We paid 40 TL each ($20 AUD each) and this included a guided tour of Harem and Palace. I see you can join a tour group, but I do not see value in that, as you are led by an a English speaking guide for no extra cost (not lowed to roam free in these buildings)My husband and I had visited other churches and Mosques in Turkey, so this made Istanbul for us and the decorated ceilings were better than the Blue mosque!
Amazing!. Glad we went to visit this palace. It had nice gardens and the inside was just amazing. It was an easy walk after getting off the Bosphorus half-day cruise.

Grand palace with Western style but Eastern feel. Very close to Kabatas (T1 tram terminus) makes this palace easy to visit by public transport. It's close on Monday and Thursday. Make sure you come early to beat the queue. The visit can only be done on a guided tour (provided free with entry ticket). The harem section is worth a visit, so buy the ALL PALACE ticket upon entry. The palace itself is a western style palace with no depiction of human/animal to comply with Islamic rule. It is grand, opulent and vast. A must see in Istanbul

The grandeur of Dolmabahce palace,seen to be believed. A day's trip to Dolmabahce palace was a unique experience.The queues were long.Myself and my elderly partner had to rough out the long queue for hours.They say you are better off if you book a guided tour before hand.All tourists were to wear disposable shoes over our own before entering the palace.There are English speaking tours and Turkish tours of the palace.The guide was patient and spoke with clarity.Only a selected number of tourists are allowed to enter the palace in batches under guidance of guides.This palace is the first palace built by ottoman sultan Abdul Mecid between 1843 and 1856 in European style,for residential,partly administrative and entertaining foreign guest ,ambassadors etc.It is decorated with opulent pillars,magnificent chandeliers,Masterpiece paintings,ancestor portraits,.The symmetry and perfect harmony is eye catching .The meticulous detailing in craftmanship of furnishings is so aesthetically pleasing.The gilded pillars,The plaited curtains,the Victorian era fabric of sofas,the candle bras,the fountain,the fireplaces are a common man's distant dream stuff.The carpets are beautiful and you have to walk only on the red carpet assigned to the tourists.You are not allowed photography.The apartment of the Sultan,his mother(Valide Sultan)apartment and identical four ( relatively modest ) apartments of four wives were interesting. There were bedrooms with beautiful fabric,meeting rooms,living room,study ,bathroom or Hammam throwing light on the past life.Atta Turk resided here too and the bed where he breathed his last is also seen.In short it is a dream house for all those who desire ultimate luxury and grandeur in life.I also saw the Tombs of Sultans two days later on,near Sulaimanya mosque where it was a level field for all sultans,Huram sultan et all,a marked contrast with the palace.Everything equalised in death. Dolmabahce palace is an interesting study of history and human achievements to full fill personal desires of grandeur..Strongly recommended for people who want a glimpse into dream lands.Bon voyage.

Beautiful palace with a great sea ciew. This historical palace hold up to the expectations.There was a proper tour in English and everything was well conserved.The outside is good but the interior is just phenomenal and mesmerizing.I recommend that none misses out on this visit.They should allow to take pictures inside though :)The fairy rides to princess islands and Bosporous are at a walking distance so you should plan a visit to both on the same day.

More beautiful than Versailles!. I was soooo surprised by this palace.. I wasn´t expecting much from it, and since it´s a little far from the other major attractions, I almost missed it.. thank God I didn´t!It has the same french style than Versailles, and some books say it was inspired in Versailles.. but is sooooo much prettier! The only downside is that you can´t take pictures inside.. you go on a guided tour that was a little rushed, and sometimes you wish you could stay a little longer in some rooms. But still, you can´t miss it.
Amazing. A beautiful place you have visit and see, with great views and Amazing antique furniture. you never get bored watching

Entry price Paid but Very Little Time to Take in the Granduer. There are lengthy lines of sightseers before the palace site opens - tour groups in one and individuals in the other. Tour groups are given priority over individuals. Individuals are "grouped" and taken around by a tour guide. One group follows another through roped areas with little time to take in the opulence of the room settings. The tour of the palace is over in 45 mins. "Grouping" by spoken language (Turkish or English) occurs for the tour of the Harem building. 30 mins to tour the Harem. There are other sites (eg clock rooms) on the grounds where you can spend time moving through them.

Top 5 Must See in Istanbul!. We had done two days in Sultanahmet and we're ready for something for a bit different- we were staying near Taksim so we did a walk through Taksim Square and walked to the Palace. In late May on a Tuesday we didn't have any lines but there are no individual tours- so we had to wait for an English Guide through the Palace. The work is amazing and they really have left it just the way it was so you can get the full experience- so visitors get to wear blue plastic booties through the tour to avoid tracking in dirt. I really think kids may like the gardens (breathe taking) but they were all crying though the inside Palace tour- there isn't much area for them to wander. Overall I found the Palace beautiful with lots of history- we splurged for the harem tour as well and that was a great bonus. I think this could be a half to full day thing. Afterwards we are at a very reasonably priced restaurant outside next to the water- great way to rest your feet after all that standing and walking!

Beautiful palace - but expansive and restricted access. The palace was totally stunning - have visited many European palaces and I would say this was superior. The grounds are really lovely too.However in comparison to other sites in Istanbul it was very expensive. I understand that preservation is an issue and they are therefore limiting numbers of entrants (which limits profits) but I wasn't expected to have to visit the palace under supervision of with a guide and in massive group. Also the militant no photography rule and repeated treats to have people removed from the palace for taking photos is ridiculous. It is the age of smart phones, no flash = no impact on artwork and interior.

Pure Opulence. We took the tram from the European side and for 4 TL it is well worth it. A ten minute walk from the terminus and you are there. As with Topkapi and all the sites there will be long queues, but again they are well managed and a trip to the harem is a must, a thirty minute guided tour is provided in the ticket price and although it may feel a bit hurried it gives as much of an insight into Royal life as you are ever going to get.

Amazing architecture and size. If you are in the old part of Istanbul take the tram and walk about five minutes. I would suggest you get their around 10 so the entrance lines are not too long, Even if they are it will be worth the wait. Go for the palace and harem ticket.

Beautiful palace and grounds!. In my opinion, Dolmabahce Palace is more impressive than Topkapi Palace. The only way to see the inside is through a guided tour (separate for the palace and harem), which I think is a fine idea as you don’t have to pay for an audio guide. I was concerned as many reviewers have said the guides were rude and if you’re standing near the back, you can’t hear them. I thought our guide was very professional, he had to be very strict and paused the tour a few times to tell people off from taking snaps of the palace, but if tourists respect the rules then it shouldn’t be a problem. I’m guilty of taking snaps myself – but just be smart about it and turn your camera/phone on silent and make sure the guide isn’t watching! Definitely walk around the grounds especially along the gates looking over the Bosphorus river (absolutely amazing) and the Crystal Palace. I would suggest allowing half a day to thoroughly enjoy the palace and grounds.

Must Visit. My friend and I stumbled upon this place and while it's not in the main touristy area, it is only like a 10 minutes tram ride away. This palace is beyond beautiful and was simply breathtaking. To anyone visiting Istanbul, you must come check this place out! (Harem cost extra money, it's a 50/50 if it's worth it or not; just depends on you as a person)

Unexpected grandeur in Istanbul. An absolute must to visit. Get the full ticket so you can see the harem and painting exhibition as well. The Ceremony Hall is astounding; it ceiling is 36 metres high and the Waterford crystal chandelier weighs a hefty 5 tonnes.

Amazing Palace. Went through both the Palace and the Harem building. They were both amazing in beauty and size. We arrived earl, about 8-55am to be there before the crowds. This was the third time that we had tried to get into the palace. this time we were successful. we queued for 10 minutes so our bags could be scanned; we then queued for 15 minutes for our tickets; then another 20 minutes to wait for the English speaking guide provided by the palace. We went in as independent travellers, so needed to queue on the right of the steps leading into the palace. You are only allowed through the palace and harem with guides. It was worth the wait. Photographs are not permitted to be taken inside the palace, but there are just stunning views outside as well as truly magnificent architecture.

Absolutely incredible!. I was lucky to visit the Palace on a national holiday so freeentrance! Arriving early I only had to queue for about half an hour, when I left the queue was massive! What an incredible building! Absolute perfection, a mixture of East and West and both with exquiste taste. Pity one can't take photographs inside.

one of the stops on a city tour. This is an impressive palace on the waterfront. You can take some nice photos from any boat cruise that passes it and from within the palace grounds. However, no picture taking is allowed inside. It takes about 30-60 min to visit and the interior has really just been left as is to be viewed in its majestic and decadent state. Visited as part of a full day city tour.

A most impressive 19th Century Imperial Residence. The palace successfully combines traditional Ottoman Style and cultural elements with Western arts such as Baroque, Rococo, and Neo-Classic styles. Its location gives first class views of the Bosphorus and its gardens are well worth a stroll. Separate tours are available to see the beautiful Ceremonial Suites and the less spectacular Harem. It is best to go during the week to avoid the crowds.

Marvellous..a must visit in Istanbul. We visited in May 2015, and reached there at 10 in the morning.. still had a long queue and waited roughly for an hour to enter main palace.. I would highly suggest to visit this palace in the morning as they have a quota/number of visitors per day which once reached the palace will be closed for visitors on that day.. we bought a full ticket which included 2 sections of the palace, .. the well kept palace has pretty view of sea with beautiful gardens, stunning wooden flooring and original antique pieces treasured in palace.. the lavish rooms, ballrooms are very impressive... their are guided English tours included in the ticket price roughly every 20 mins from entrance itself..Overall a very beautiful Luxurious palace and must visit during your stay in Istanbul

this palace has a clock from Queen Victoria!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! fabulous place to visit.... My most favourite Palace has to be Dolmabache...A white description of elegance and charm if ever I saw one...The staircase alone was breathtaking.....the rooms..chandaliers and ornamental displays are a delight...the room where Kemal Attaturk last slept before passing away is still as it was all those years ago....a place of wonder...truly magnificent...an absolute must if ever you are in Istanbul....trust me you will not be dissapointed!!!!!
a must visit!. amazing place to visit while in Istanbul. amongst top 5 of things to see for me. the tour guide gave details information if asked. very impressive architecture!

A must visit when in Istanbul . A good way to understand and have a view of another culture and race is having a glimpse of their history, and the Tour inside Domabahce Palace was the right thing to do as it was the home of 6 Sultans and the founder and the first President of their Republic has spent his last days in this palace. The guided tour was very informative and it's good to note and see that the biggest and heaviest Chandelier weighing 4.5 tons is inside the palace halls. It was well worth spending a few hours there during my trip in Istanbul.

A real masterpiece. The garden, sea view, the clock tower, doors, even the simplest stones of the yard seem luxurious when you leave the main road behind and step the palace. Its wonderful architecture accompanied by all other details such as carpets, statues, tables, beds, ... fascinate the visitor and move him/her back to Ataturk era. The best thing I liked is the big hall hosting Ataturk body after his death for public farewell. Generally I enjoyed it.

The embodiment of luxury. The more modern sort of sovereign's palace in Istanbul was built at the decline of Ottoman empire. It was so luxurious that sultan did not move in for years, not to cause anger among the citizens. The tour is well organized, although the guy leading the first part of the tour in English could have a much better accent and clearer speech. Anyway, you'll be impressed with the surrounding park, with the entrance gates, With the exterior of the palace itself, with the sheer size of the thing, and also with the style, both from the outside, and from the inside. The luxury is almost decadent. All the banisters in the main staircase (which itself is huge) are made of English crystal, for example. The same fact stands for lamps and chandeliers. There are 40 metric tons of gold used to decorate the building (at least I thing that's what I think the guide said). Impossible to convey the impressions by the means of text, I advise you to go and take a look.

Breathtaking Palace, surpassing some westerb european best palace. Didnt expect that the ottoman can build such a beautiful palace. This is a whole different level above the humble Topkapi palace. Very elegant in design and has ultra luxurious interior. Although its not as big as the versailles, I think this palace is more beautiful.
6 star rating. totally worth every second of visiting this beautiful place , highly recommended ,, and the tour guide was really good explaining everything in detail ,, A MUST IN ISTANBUL

A new and luxurious Palace – in European style. Go in the morning.. Very beautiful palace from outside with good see view and the interior is marvelous. We stayed near Beyazit so took the tram T1 from there to Kabatas and walked a little bit to reach the palace. Obeying the reviews we reached there by 8.30 am and there were only around 10 people before us. After there was a rush of different groups. We took the harem ticket as well which made a 30 TL + 10 TL per person. To protect the carpets we had to cover our shoes with a plastic blue cover they gave. All the tours were guided and we were not allowed to wander around since all the things inside the palace is original. Around 9.15 am the guided tour started since we got into a big group by 15 minutes waiting. Since our baby buggy was small they allowed it inside. However, taking it up the stair and down was the only problem. The tour was almost 45 min. And then the harem tour was at 10.45 am. So in the meantime we visited the Clock museum there and took beautiful pictures from the courtyard. The palace interiors were stunning especially the chandeliers and the surroundings too. They do not allow photography – that’s what I didn’t like but some were clicking in the harem area since no guide was there after the brief description. I clicked some too. This palace was built towards the end of the ottoman rule and hence it was done in a completely different and modern architectural pattern unlike most monuments in Istanbul which had adopted ottoman style. Overall , I liked it.

Magnificent Architecture. The architecture looks like a modern European design. It looks magnificent from the outside. The entrance fee is 40 lira and it doesn't include in the Muzeum pass. The palace is closed on Monday and Thursday. Keep in mind that they don't allow individual tour into this palace. You have to join the long queue and wait for the English tour before you can enter the palace. Taking photos are also prohibited.To go to this palace by public transport, take a tram to Kabatas (the final terminal) from Gulhane. Once reached the final station, cross the road next to the Marmara sea. Then just walk straight until bypassing the jetty (Bosphorus tour). Then you will see Dolmahbace Cami. And the palace is just less than 1km from the cami.Make sure to visit the art museum beside this palace. You will see a lot of beautiful paintings. Worth place to visit.

Worth to wait that huge line. I actually found Dolmabache Palace more interesting than Topkapi Palace. Of course that huge line in front of the entrance is scary, but it is definitely worth waiting. Very beautiful palace but you cannot take any pictures. However you can catch up with photographs in palace garden. English speaking guide was interesting to listen.
Just about OK...... Hire a tour guide..... You might want to learn about the Ottomans history in a more detailed manner.

Keeping up with European royalty!. An example of the Ottomans trying to keep up with the other European royal families, a grand palace to rival those on Paris and Vienna. Tours are given in groups so make sure you know when to arrive in the entrance of the palace to take an English or Turkish language tour. The admission fee is in cash, no credit card accepted and there is an extra fee for other building. The view of the strait is breathtaking!

Beautiful Palace. Former sultan palace. Worth visiting, especially the outside. They sell 3 kinds of tickets (15 euro for the full package) so if you only want to see the outside and gardens (+nice Bosporus views) buy a cheaper ticket. Go early, after 10 o'clock crowded and long waits. If a certain number of visitors are in they just can close it.

Be prepared to queue. Visited here with our tour group. They conduct tours only in groups - you are not allowed in as individuals. No photography allowed. Be prepared to queue at various stages before you reach the palace. You are rushed through in my opinion - not enough time to look properly. Reminded me of an English stately home.Have seen more equisite buildings in Romania.

The Europeean style in Ottoman culture. You will not beleive that you are in the heart of Istanbul. The Dolmabace palace is a piece of Europeean culture. The impressive chandeliers made with England, Bacarat, Bohemia and Murano christals are impressive and the tour (40 TRY including the Harem) is guided in english. The views of the Bosphorus are also great. It worth every penny.

Huge Mosque. The specialty of this mosque is that it is really huge. You can see it from outside from the Bosphorus cruise. It wont be easy to capture the entire mosque in one frame its that huge. Although tourists are not allowed to see all rooms but the rooms we saw were nicely built and huge. Must Visit

Dolmabahce Palace visit. I liked the gardens, the fountain and the Bosporus view from the garden and rooms. The palace is very luxurious, it takes you back to the era of the Sultans. However, the tour was very long though very informative, and the guide was a very knowledgeable person.

Boring - magnificent building however not worth visiting. Over priced. This is a lovely building however, what should be a great visit but is spoilt mostly by the rude and officious staff.You are expected to follow a tour and the english guide could barely speak english and accent was so bad you couldn't understand most of it amongst the echoes. Rude and officious staff push you along to keep up with the crowd so you can't enjoy anything and they don't allow photos inside for no good reason other than wanting to sell pictures in the over priced gift shop.Overall, I would avoid - the queues to get a ticket, then join a herd takes hours and so not worth it. Visit the grounds only.

Amazing. Again be prepared to queue - but well worth the time. The floors were amazing, and different areas of the palace are more lavish than others. Sometimes the guides can be in a hurry and very pushy!

Modern palace. Interestingly enough, this is one of the most modern palaces of the kings in Europe. I think.
