I should visit more palaces, but the fact, that it has been built just 180 years ago, makes it very young. Interesting fact. Plus, the good thing about it, you can not go individual, the guides will be waiting for a crowd to accumulate and lead you in. Giving a short, but very informative lecture. In good English. Do it, you will not regret.
Wow. It was a great experience to see this amaizing palace, which took us back to the Othmani time.Very huge, amaizing fine details in the walls and roofs.Very nice gardens outside the palace.

Would love to have taken photos inside. The exterior is nice, but not really special. The inside is much more interesting. While those with iPhones quietly took pictures at will, those with cameras (not using flash) were barred on the first click.

Go early in the day. The populace of the many palaces is staggering. The chandeliers are striking.The line to get in can be staggering. Be there at 9:30 to get in early or be prepared to be in line for hours.

Beautiful palace!. The entrance fee is quite high (40TL for full palace with guide) and the queue took me about 30 minutes, but you get something in return! While waiting in the queue you can enjoy the view of the gardens, bosphorus and the beautiful palace exterior, once in you have to stick to the guided group which is not ideal of course, but just ignore the group and look your eyes out. You'll be surounded in extreme wealth, feeling like you're in some disney movie, a palace full of gifts to Sultans from kings, emperors and tzars. Make sure you stick to the guide because the information is essential, every room has it's story. So yes, definately worth a visit when in Istanbul!
Dolmabahce. Well, when you go to turkey, istanbul, First thing that you need to do is to go to Dolmabahce palace, don't miss it.NB: no photograph in it!!!!!

The opulence . This palace really is unique. It's not the biggest or the fanciest , but I just love how they blend the east and the west. Seeing an opulent French marble desk right next to a simple wooden Chinese cabinet is interesting to say the least. It really reflects the uniqueness of Istanbul
facinating. This is a must see when in Istanbul. The palace is impressive and it so opulent.Love the tour but would maybe prefer a longer private guided tour to appreciate this beauty even more.

Glorious Dolmabahçe Palace. The Dolmabahçe Palace is one of the important must-see historical buildings in Istanbul. Its prestige architecture will impress and leave you speechless as soon as you see it. Unfortunately, the rows in front of the ticket office (only two cash desks) were rather long and I suggest calculating 1.5-2 hours for visiting (without harem) and at least 30-45min for waiting. The number of visitors during the day is limited so as not to damage the Palace by too many visitors. My advise will be to come earlier in the morning as soon as the Palace opens at 9h. We bought a ticket for visiting the inside of the Palace (Selamlık-Tour), which included a ca. 30min guided tour with a group of 50 other visitors and costs 20 lira. The tour was informative and interesting, but quick and a little bit pricey for that short time. I only wished the staff would have formed smaller groups and let us enough time to see everything. Besides that I highly recommend visiting Dolmabahçe.

Wow!. Such opulence and beauty! The English speaking guide provided by the administration was most helpful during the carefully guide through-out the Palace and the Harem building. Do respect the instruction to NOT take photos in the guided buildings as by doing so, the whole experience of viewing the rooms will be even more educational and mesmerizing!

I couldnt get in- queue was too long!. I cant judge on the inside of the palace- I never made it in, because of the huge queue. It is unacceptable that such a big palace has a 2h queue to pass through metal detector, then 30min queue to buy the ticket and then again a queue to get through the entrance. I just refused to do it and I rather enjoyed the city with a nice walk or Bosphorus cruise!
Check opening times. Went on a Thursday and they were closed. Apparently there's a daily quota as well for the tickets sold so be early. Such a pity we didn't get to go inside.

Stunning in its Opulence. Clearly influenced by the western European leaders of the 1800s this palace has lots of ostentatious fittings! The main central hall at the end of the tour has the Wow factor in spades - 36 columns and 4.5 ton chandelier make it impressive! Gardens worth a stroll, and the Crystal Pavilion is interesting.

Impressive place, could be better organized . The palace is magnificent and definitely recommend a visit, but the organization of visitors could be better. There are forced tour groups and takes long waiting time if you visit during mid day. A audio system would have been much more efficient.

Impressive Grounds, Can Have a Better Tour. It takes very little time to understand the grandeur and beauty of the palace grounds and building exterior, both of which are stunning. An appreciation of the historical significance will certainly help one enjoy the guided tour of the palace interior as interesting facts about the Ottoman empire are shared by tour guides. The last stop on the tour, the grand chandelier, is quite impressive. However, there is opportunity to improve the tour as multiple large groups of people are herded around a specific path from room to room. The large groups make it difficult to hear at times and the lack of freedom to explore takes away from the experience. Towards the mid-end of the tour, you can't help but feel like cattle being shown another small room that looked the same as the other small room you saw 15 minutes ago as the guide routinely explains again that "this is how a room could have looked back in those days."

Spectacular and opulent. Don't miss the opportunity to visit this wonderful palace. Most people tend to go to Topkapi which in my opinion is not a patch on this and not worth visiting, The grandeur and opulence of the place is magnificent . It is a guided 40 minute tour and access to some not all rooms are permitted. It's situated right on the banks of the Bosphorus and a great way to enjoy the views of Istanbul and soak in the atmosphere. You are not allowed to take photos inside but the gardens and views of the river are wonderful.would highly recommend a visit, not to be missed
Perfect place. What a beautiful palace and a great place to visit.Very relaxing grounds and o lot of things to learn about the history and the glory of the place.

Impressive. The garden outside, and furniture, decoration, architecture, etc. are definitely worth a visit. A guide will show you around in this immense palace, which is of course nice to get some background information about the history, but due to the large groups, it's difficult to hear the guide properly.

grand palace. We did a guided tour of this palace, I have seen Versailles, Windsor, and the royal palace of Madrid, nothing compared to this grandee palace, opulence, decadence ,the lofty ceilings ,stupendous crystal chandeliers, huge oriental rugs, the artwork,woodwork,trimmings ,a bit too much in some Case, but really magnificent and the view of the Bosporus is truly amazing, lovely gardens ,worth a vist.

dolmabachtse palace. visiting hours 9 to 4 .except mondays and thursdays.in the area of besiktas and very interesting palace to visit and there is a tour hourly and it is great to see the grand ceremonial hall and so many other rooms.

European palace of the Ottomans. The palace was constructed and decorated during the period when the Ottomans attempted to imitate Western Europe and catch up to it. There is a lot of splendor, somewhat in bad taste, like in other European palaces that were intended to project power and prestige and show how wealthy the royal family is.There was a line outside of the palace to get in. We didn't go to the harem and saw that there were long lines to enter that part of the palace.Oh, and you're not allowed to take photos inside to speed up the tour.

Over the top. A spectacular palace of gaudy decoration. A worthwhile sight as an attempt to match the excess of European monarchs. Falls far short of a Versailles but still impressive. The Harem tour portion was disappointing.

Disappointing. Long lines not worth it. The guide that you are forced to use has poor English and the group they put you in is too large so you have a problem at hearing properly. The palace is a collection of British and French replicas. Forget about getting in line for the harem...completely not worth it

Not reasonable for young children . The palace itself is incredible (although you quickly realize that this was a futile and costly attempt to project power and wealth by the Sultan as his/their actual influence was in decline) but they should do a better job of informing those visiting with children in strollers that the strollers are NOT permitted in the palace meaning you'll have to carry your child the entire time (not easy if not an infant or newborn).
Amazing. one of the best places. Lots of details. You will take a lot of pictures around the palace.enjoyed our visit very much.

Interesting comparison to Topkapi. This palace is much more akin to Versailles than Topkapi palace, so it is interesting to compare and contrast the two. It is quiet beautiful inside, and much more impressive than it initially appears from the front entrance. The tour guide was not the best, and you are required to wear plastic coverings over your shoes to protect the carpets, but it is still definitely worth a visit if you have even an extra morning in Istanbul. Bring cash for admission as they do not take credit cards.

Arrive by boat is the best. Absolutely gorgeous as you approach by water, the palace is a masterwork of design and engineering. Not as touristy as some other sites which is good. Many more locals come here. Queen Victoria gifted the world's largest chandelier inside. There are public tours and you can arrange a private tour which I did.

Wow ! However, not baby-friendly !. It is a magnificently built palace - especially the main gold hall or whatever its called which you have to see to believe. But you only get to see it through a guided tour. And if you have a grumpy baby, know that your tour and the tour of all the other people in your guided tour group may well be ruined ! Plus, prams aren't allowed.

Wow.. In awe. Originally was not part of our tour visit but i'm glad we stop by this magnificent structure and the beautiful courtyards and gardens in spring. Our tour guide told s that the palace was built last based on the garden set up.

Discovering Dolmabahce's Splendour. Unlike its popular Sultanahmet's counterpart, Dolmabahce Palace is considered a local treasure. Tucked away from the crowds, the Beşiktaş' waterfront palace was the Ottoman Empire's central port and provided an opulent administration center. Featuring the world's largest crystal chandelier weighing in at 10,000 pounds, (a gift from Queen Victoria) entering the grand foyer offers only a teaser of what's to come. Although I enjoyed touring the Topkapi Palace, if I had to choose, I would visit the Dolmabahce instead.

Amazing experience. I am usually not a big fan of museums but this was an amazing experience especially with the guide who keeps explaining every details of the palace. The interiors, chandeliars are a piece of art and loved all of it...except the entrance fees which is kind of steep. But will recommend to all tourists.

One of the best treasures in Istanbul. I loved this place. There is a lot of history hidden in this gem starting from 17th century and then flourishing in mid 19th century. Please note to buy tickets which include visiting the palace. There are guides who will take you through Dolmabahce (included in the ticket price). Please note Museum Pass is not valid for this place.

magnificent. This palace is magnificent. i have visited the palace twice (2010 and 2014) and i was amazed from the glory of the place the second time even more than the first. If you have the time get both tickets (the palace and the Haramlik )... and if like me, little reading about the sultans of the Ottoman Empire before the visit will make your trip even better. You have to visit this amazing place.

French Chateau in Turkey. This palace sticks out amongst the more classic structures. It was like going to a french chateau or a German castle. You cannot take pictures inside and the tour groups clog the walkways (the guards do nothing to keep a path clear). The best advice I can give if you visit is to get there when they open as by 10 there is a steady stream of visitors and the security checkpoint is backlogged...

Amazing. It's a must-do in Istanbul. It's beautiful and has a mix of architecture from various eras. The guided tour is a must so you understand the significance and the detailing of each aspect of the palace.

What a palace. This is definitely was a luxury back in the 19th Century. the palace is huge, full of history & memories. Full of fantastic pieces of arts. The palace really gives you the feeling how civilizations are changing, and how that change is the only unchanging fact of the universe.It also gives you an idea how ALLAH is capable of taking away the kingdoms of the kings when they are not taking care of their people, or when corruption hits such kingdoms.Really amazing place to be, but be prepared for the long waiting queues in there. The fees varies as per which parts of the palace you want to visit. I recommend that you take the full ticket.

Be prepared to queue and then queue some more. We went about 12:10pm, so almost peak time and we had to queue 40mins to get in, then once inside you have to queue again to get into the palace (~25mins). Yes, the inside is very lavish and worth seeing, but only just worth it. The English tour could have been better also.

Great potential. The place the beautiful. However, it still needs renovation and much more care.Be aware that guided tour is compulsory, guides shared repeatedly inaccurate and superficial information. A pity.
Very luxurious place. The palace are very good to visit. Its have a wonderful view to the strait. The interior are very luxury. Some are gold plated!! There is a chandelier 4 tons weight!!

amazing. very beautiful and amazing palace.but there was no audioguide(electronic equipment),only a lady s guidance.poke in English without any loudspeaker.If you are not Turkish or English language,there would not be any

Excellent! Not to be missed!. If time permits (could take 2.5 hrs) then buy the full ticket for 40 TL as this includes the clock museum, painting museum and crystal pavilion. All equally delightful (the clock and painting museums were fantastic) besides the basic tour (I think 24-25 TL) of the main palace and harem. We preferred this experience to the one at Topkapi.

Very long queue to get in. Its nice once you get inside, but, honestly, it wasn't worth waiting for almost two hours to get it.Its a sultan's palace with most of his rooms exposed. Doesn't feel right knowing that someone was living such a luxurious life and destroying millions of others at the same time.

Getting in is not easy. The palace is easily one of the most expensive places in the city to visit and even so the queue for tickets and the admittance and the security…all takes its toll on your patience so you might want to have a whole lot of time in your hands while visiting the Palace. The opulence of the place is blinding but it is only limited to the front phase. Each piece is magnificent and was placed to show the power and status of then rulers. There are so many other such stories to this place and you need a guide along with you to explain it as the palace in itself is short of helpful information

Opulent!. It was my first time to see a real palace so opulent and well-preserved! Our Effendi guide did well in taking us through its history, we appreciated every nook and corner. It was an amazing insight into the life of the royalty one can wonder how it was living in such wealth. I'm glad photos aren't allowed so there was no distraction during the tour. The queue was long but well-organized.

Well.... Palace itself is nice place, but tour was very brief and very fast. If I will take a fact how important it is this place for Turks, they really could to do much better job. Guide was running thru this place and did not care about tourists left behind. I was quite disapointed about their attitude.
SPECTACULAR . Having seen Versailles and Fontainebleau, I didn't think I would be impressed, but I was! Spectacular fusion of East and West...Definitely worth a visit.

Must-See. Dolmabahce was built just as the last sultans were losing all of their money and influence -- so it's pretty amazing to see how this was used as a display that they "still had it." The fronts and public spaces are extravagant, while the back is plain stucco and private spaces are very sparse.This is a great glimpse into a pretty specific moment in history for the Ottoman Empire.

Deserving of its reputation. Dolmabahce was the first palace built with an European-themed design. The entire palace complex is so huge, we overstayed our visit there (what was intended to be just 2 hours easily turned into 6). Plenty of things to see and despite being one of the attractions with the highest admission fees, it is well worth it. Smaller exhibits such as the aviary, Crystal Palace and Clock Museum add to the experience of being here.

A night mare!. If you have 5 or 6 hours of which you are willing to spend 4 waiting in different lines (security check, to buy super expensive ticket, to enter main gates and then to enter every single attraction separately) go ahead and visit this place. We gave up after 2 hours of waiting, and went on Bosporus cruise instead.
Worth to visit. It takes about 2 hours for this. It worth to visit very beautiful place and I fall in love with the bueaty of its architecture and furniture.

Very opulent.. You have a compulsory tour which is well organised and informative. Guide spoke good English. The grandeur and scale of this palace is amazing...very happy to see that all the crystal chandeliers were English! Strictly not allowed to take photos though. Go early to avoid queues plus they limit how many visitors per day.

Extremely Popular, rightly so. Get the Kabatas/Besikta tram and walk a bit along the shore and you will find his magnificent palace and gardens. So much to see but you get put on the clock as all tours are set schedule.Believe it or not, you cannot take photos inside and that is so disappointing because the palace is spectacular. I would not want to be there in high season, crowds would be horrible, it was busy in early December but so glad to have spent the morning there.Afterwards just get the metro up the hill to Taksim for some lunch and shopping.

Go Early - Worth the Line Up to Get Tickets if you Don't Reserve in Advance. We visited this European style museum after having visited Topkapi Palace and really enjoyed the visit. Allow about three hours to see the whole palace, including the harem. Our guide was informative and make the visit interesting. It is not possible to visit independently so you must join a guided tour. Unfortunately no pictures are allowed during the visit inside the palace or harem, but it was interesting nonetheless.

No pictures? Are you kidding me!. This is a magnificent place to visit! Now the bad news, it's very pricey, $20 euro, AND you cannot take pictures of any kind!! We went in with a group of about 60 English speaking people and the guide was do far ahead that you couldn't hear him as he rushed us through. I fully understand the no flash policy, that is totally acceptable but let tourists do what they do best, take pictures! People see my pictures and they say, " Hey that's a place I have to see!" But this place hasn't grasped this concept! I'm want to take pictures without a shutter sound, without a flash and without disturbing anyone else, you charged me an arm and a leg, let me take pictures. THE most expensive non picture taking place I gave encountered in the world!! Save your money, check out other people's pictures on the Internet! Better yet, go to the Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque where they let you take pictures and avoid this place!! So so mad!!

Fantastic - but be early. Visited the great palace today and had wonderful time. Such a huge palace with unbelievable amount of money spent on. Many people here wrote bad things but probably they arrived late, in Istanbul always expect huge queues if you arrived to such a touristic attraction by 12pm !.We arrived by 9:15 and we did not waste minutes on any line. English tour started 9:30 and was very nice with well educated and polite guide, tour is around 45 minutes but you don't feel it as a rush. Harem was also very nice. Book both the tours for 40 liras.Dont try to take photos or brake the rules, just enjoy what you see. It is a must see attraction. You wont take more than hour and half if no lines

Worth a visit, but tour is disappointing. Hopped off the "Hop on, Hop off" bus to see this palace and its beautiful grounds, right under the Bophorous Bridge. Waited 30 minutes for "English Tour" which whisked a small group thru a dozen or so rooms in about 15 minutes. Too fast, not enough history. Nice cafe on the grounds outside. No bathrooms in palace and a lot of stairs!

Nice and veeeryyy flashy !. if you like versailles you ll love the place and these palace is near the sea !! amazing !! ok its too much of all ... crystal carpets colors etc etc but thats Turkey ...... visit the harem is a must see!! !!!! the nr of groups participans are huuuugeee !!! u hardly hear sth and u cannt have enough time inside ... too little of informations .... ;-( the greatest chandellier was not my favorite but all of the theme hanging all over ;-) . visit also the painting museum ...great collection. personel Does NOT speak English ;-(( very Bad ! some of theme not even basic !!! and that in the bookstore!! my tip get there early get a private guided tour i did this couple of years ago and was superb !!!! go on spring time the garden is beautiful ......

Beautiful must see but staff need to learn some manners. I visited this palace this afternoon with my family. It is very beautiful. It has large grand open areas and very beautiful spaces that one can only imagine how the Sultan and his family lived. The place is in an excellent condition and is very well maintained.The problem that we experienced is that there were no marked areas inside the first section to enter. This is where you present your ticket to the staff, the staff will scan and then you will enter.So what happened today is that people started to walk in without presenting their tickets and the staff at the door of the palace started to scream at tourist and create such a scene. Many people don't understand English and I actually felt very unsettled as the staff member went on a complaining session for a few minutes after that. She was complaining with hand gestures and high tones. My kids were asking me why was she so angry and this really was not acceptable. This set the tone of the tour and a tourist asked one of the guards a questions and in a very rude way he said " I don't Know" and walked away. Secondly, please correct me if I am wrong but I did not see any signs that said no photography. This was only mentioned to us after a staff member shouted at a lady and then the tour guide mentioned the rules.Thirdly, the guided tours are too big and there are too many people that are in each tour so when the guide speaks , if you are at the back, you cannot hear. There was such good information that we could not hear properly as people kept talking. Maybe the guides should have a PA system that would enable them to be heard properly.The Harem tour is another separate tour and on this side of the palace the vibe was so much more lighter. The staff were so friendly and assisted tourist with any questions. The male guide controlled the crowd and it was really a lovely guided tour. I enjoyed this part of the visit much betterAll in all if you can you must visit this site as its really worth the time.

Romantic historical place - definitely worth to spend several hours. Full ticket, including all parts of the palace with 4 museums, cost 40 TR. I advise to read a little bit of the historical background about the palace in advance ( http://www.dolmabahcepalace.com ). There are allowed only guided groups ( you will have to join a group of about 30 person to go inside). But the excursion is very short - mostly you just walk through, the guide speaks very short. We had the problem acoustically to understand the guide in the Harem. I loved also the Painting museum - the same ticket valid. Still is worth a visit - would love to go again.
Woooooow. Do not miss this place. What a luxury life they were living. Join the tours and listen to the tour guide carefully if you are interested in history. It in closed every monday and thursday.

Worth it!. I love it Even though my friend and was kinda lost for a while before reaching the palace and it was drizzling. ... but I wouldn't trade the experience for the world. Love the history and the architecture. The guides are fountain of knowledge. The only downside is some of the tourists just don't know how to shut up so I couldn't hear some of the information imparted.

Beautiful. Another must for Istanbul. Please listen to the staff and do not take pictures. People amaze me trying to sneak and take pics when you are strictly forbidden. Beautiful palace. Architecture blew us away.

Opulent!. The Dolmabahce palace is quite impressive! Although i find that not a lot of tours include this in their itinerary, it should be visited if you have the time. It is worth taking the 40 lira ticket for the whole palace. There are no individual visits allowed, and they organise tours in english and turkish at regular intervals, with a knowledgeable guide inside the palace to show you around. The decor is ostentatious and stunning. Unfortunately, they don't allow pictures and there were some places where I felt the tour was a bit rushed ( I went towards the end of the day so maybe that was the reason).

Amazing!. I had come here as part of an externally booked tour so did not have to wait for tickets but did have to queue up outside as they only let a certain number of people in at once. We were one of the first groups there and the queues very quickly built up behind us. You have to put on these blue plastic bags over your shoes before you can enter. Once you’re in prepare to be impressed. I was stunned by the ostentatious décor – seriously beautiful. I loved the chandeliers and was in awe with each stunning room. Our tour guide was knowledge and shared the history behind each room/significant object. Sadly the tour was over very quickly! It would have been nice to be able to wander around inside or even take photos but unfortunately none of that was allowed. I still think it was worth the money to see this wonderful palace. The gounds are lovely.

Impressive Inside & Out. Very impressive palace and grounds. Tour was short and not particularly informative. Felt very rushed.We were not allowed to take photos. Also, everyone must wear plastic covers on their shoes, which is not easy to apply when surrounded by massive groups. They need to re-think the approach to letting in tourists....

Grand Palace on the river. This Palace shows how the Sultans modernized their living style. The grounds are what you would expect when price is no object. The finest displays of craftsmanship applied to home furnishings as interpreted by the artist of that date are well presented. No pictures please. 2 hours are well spent. Popular attraction. Tours are available in English

Well worth your money. If you like to see how rulers wasted their money on ostentation this is the place to go, crystal stairs, huge chandeliers , really a a great display of wealth. The only downside i found the visit a bit short but I would do it again.

Beautiful palace but not an enjoyable visit. Dolmabahce is a beautiful and eccentric palace.Some rooms in the inside have more gold than Versailles and the Baccarat chandeliers are the most amazing chandeliers I have ever seen. However be ready for long lines even in MArch... (maybe after lunch is not the best time). Then once you get inside you are packed in groups with a guide who can't care less and doesn't give much explanation, even if you can hear or understand him. Maybe buying the booklet about the palace BEFORE you go inside is a good idea (we bought it after).

Just Perfect . Really a clear picture about the Sultan's life and the approaching end of the Empire. Views and architecture is just brilliant, in a best of breed style of mid 19th century. Definitely visit Harem and clocks museum, which is the real piece of art. Very nice views of the Bosphorus. Queues will start from about 11 o'clock, so in case willing to skip the Queues, the you are free to come about 09.00. There are tours in English, Turkish and I met the one in Russian as well, though I have seen guides in Spanish and Italian as well. A must visit place!

Not the most pleasant experience. Long wait. First at the main gate, then at the ticket office, and then at the entrance to the palace - it took me about an hour. The last queue is particularly annoying (and not because it was raining/snowing/sleeting today) because that's when you realise that there are no individual visits, only groups. Hence you wait for the next guided tour to start. Turkish speakers are let in first (there must be a lack of English speaking guides or it could be a lack of local visitors). When they finally let you in, the crowd makes a dash for the door - if you didn't manage to put on blue 'shoe condoms' while waiting on the slippery stairs you miss your turn.Once in, you and about 40 other visitors are accompanied through the palace by a guide. The guide doesn't speak much - he spends most of the time telling off visitors for taking photos. Yes, photography is not allowed (for no apparent reason). He also rattles off names of various sultans (without elaborating on who they were or what their significance was); genuinely insightful comments are delivered in broken, sorry! - global English ("the sultan has four womanS and 38 childrenS").On a more positive note, the Harem is worth extra 10 liras (YTL40.- instead of YTL30.-). Despite what the name may suggests, this part of the palace is related to the more recent Turkish history (Ataturk's life and death).In sum, it's not clear why visitors cannot just wander around by themselves and need to be taken in groups.

Simply WOW!. Tickets are 30 TL per person for the palace, but are justified with the tour inside. An english speaker guides the tour which takes about 45 minutes. Amazing ceilings and furniture. One of the best interiors of historical buildings a person can see. Gift shop is poor though (prices and content).

Gives You A Vivid Sense of How the Sultans Lived. For comparison, you'd have to thin Versailles. But the setting of the Dolmabahce Palace, right by the Bosphorus with STUNNING views, is unmatchable. The palace itself, with hundreds of rooms, many of them much larger than an "ordinary" McMansion's footprint, and ornate carvings & decorations, isn't the sort of place I would enjoy living in. It apparently killed many of the sultans who succumbed to tuberculosis from the chilly winters. But before they bit the dust, they certainly lived in sumptuous luxury. You can easily imagine the receptions with ambassadors from all over the world, the family meetings, the Turkish baths, the soirees in one or another apartment in the harem. We enjoyed the visit.

Glamorous. I have been to this palace many times and each time I go, I admire with this Barok style palace. I like the glamour, fanciness, symetry. Those crystal lamps are magnificent. I think every visitor if Istanbul mist see this place to see different arcitectire and starting of modern Turkey thanks to Atatürk ;)

No pictures allowed inside the harem:(. But palace itself from outside is amazing with breathtaking views of Bosphorus so many extraordinary pictures can be taken anyway. Me and my husband after visiting harem ( guide tell u a bit story about sultan and history of harem at first and then all group walking around exploring different rooms. All takes around 40 minutes) just wondering around making pictures. Unforgettable experience ! We stay in European side so to get to the palace which is on Asian side we took tram. Last stop takes u literally 5 min from palace. The easiest way is to buy travel card from local shop and top up next to tram stop. Is very cheep way to travel especially if u stay in Sultanahmet or any other place on European side. Card is valid for metro and busses a swell.Have fun exploring:) Must see while in Istanbul :)

Great place/ Bad Staff and touring . The place is certainly wonderful and beautiful. The first part was the guy at the entrance buying the tickets. I asked for student discount and he said: "Student discount is only for TURKISH students, it's 80 TL only cash NO cards" the poor guy was having a bad day or I guess had a bad night. And what kind of discrimination is that. AREN'T WE ALL STUDENTS? The other story was the tour guide. The girl was giving instructions and information in a terrible English and like a proper recorder. Seriously a bad experience, although the place is beautiful. Please avoid going to the Cristal Pavilion it's just crap.... btw if you think the world is wasting plastic just wait to get there. You will to use plastic shoes covers every minute.

If you've seen one ornate European palace you've seen them all. Istanbul has two major palaces; this one, dating from the 1850s, is just like any other palace in Europe, with lots of ornate gilded chairs, fancy carpets and big chandeliers.There are certainly some things worth seeing here - the 'crystal staircase' which has glass balusters supporting the handrail, and the massive 'Great Hall'. But most of it is just a succession of fancy rooms.You must go on a guided tour, you're not allowed wander, and there are two separate tours - one does the State Reception Rooms and the Great Hall; the other does the Sultan's private quarters where he and his family lived. If you have time for only one, pick the Reception Rooms one. Also included in the entrance fee is a small clock museum. If you pay for both the guided tours you can also see a rather mediocre 'paintings museum'.
Amazing. Within walking distance to the shangri la .good value for money.guided tour inside the palace very good 45minutes.

what a great place to visit.. Very beautiful and big. you must visit this nice palace. The view is breath taking beside the bousfur sea. The entrance includes a clock tower which is really great. The ticket price is 40 TL for all palace included Herem but if you Dont want to visit Herem it would be cheaper . They have English tour guide which will explain every detail about this palace. Therestaurant is a painting museum which is really great and has really great paintings. The ball room in palace main building is one of the best I have ever seen. Do not miss this place in istanbul. You can go easily by using kabatash metro line from taksim sq and then walk about 5 min to palace.unfortunately photo taking is forbidden inside the palace.

Its the real Palace...worth a visit. It really give a feel like viewing something like palace.... Very well managed tours inside .... well maintained.... Huge palace.... very very classy Paintings, Jars, Decorations, etc... many more.... Should not miss this place... entry fee 30 TL is worth to spend,,, It may take min 2 hrs ....

A satisfying morning in an opulent place. A great overview of the opulence with which the latter Ottomans basked in, and where Kemal Ataturk spent his last days. A neo-modern interpretation of 17C French excesses, we were taken through room after room of decadent and plush rooms by a very competent English speaking guide (came with the ticket) who filled us in on the history and the personalities who inhabited this vast space.The harem is visited separately, and the guide there was a less good. Also the clock museum displayed a few very gaudy creations, and there were other bits and pieces to make for a satisfying morning across the Bosphorus from old Istanbul. The painting museum was very good too. The restaurants, one inside and one outside, provided surprisingly good fare and rest for aching feet after the trip. On the whole, the visit was a good contrast to the Topkapi which ante-dates this by about 2 centuries, and shows its age.

Spectacular, but marred by poor service! . The ticketing staff actually told us they had no change for 200lira. They didn't offer any alternative or help to us. It is such a shame that many fabulous museums and attractions are tainted by poor service. It does affect the overall experience of the visit. Poor signage is also a common problem that should be rectified.

Wonderful and often missed by foreign tourists. This is the successor to the Topkapi Palace, and was built in the 1850s, right on the Bosphorus. It is easy to get to by the T1 tram, but is on the other side of the Golden Horn from most of the other main tourist spots. I suspect that most tourists don't get to it, and that is a mistake. You actually get a better idea of how the "modern" sultans etc. lived than you do at the Topkapi Palace. At least when we were there, there was quite a wait for an English language tour, but it was worth it (and you can't go into most of the buildings except with a guided group). There is also a guided tour of the harem, also worth it. The whole thing takes several hours, so be prepared to spend some time.

Don't miss out on this!. This seems to be missed by most people but it is so worth the ride out on the tram. So easy to get to. Tour of the Selmlik was excellent lots of information, the one around the harem not so good but still worth a look around. We had to queue to get in and this was February so may need to leave plenty of time in the summer.

Elegant. We visited the palace on our third day. We were at the entrance before 9am and we were one of the first visitors inside. outside the main gate there's a clock tower and a small mosque which were also as beautiful. the palace's interior have been delicately preserved over the years with a great number of artifacts. no photos were allowed to be taken while inside. the chandeliers were among the biggest in the world according to our guide and were in fact donated to Istanbul by the Queen of England. You will surely leave the place gawking in awe. at the backyard, you can enjoy the view of the Bosphorus river. Across the street there's a huge football stadium that's being built for Besiktas Club.

Must see in Istanbul. Take one day to see the entire palace,it was build as a replica to Versailles.See the watches-all stoped at the hour Mustafa Attaturk died !Have a long walk arround the gardends,admire the beautiful gates to the sea, have a coffee and feed the numerous cats !Be aware-no photos in the palace !

Only comparable to Versailles!!. A magnificent palace that astonishes with its decorative details! Huge and impressive! It gives to the visitor a very good idea of the high living standards of the royal family and the life habits.

A very beautiful palace. We visited this wonderful palace about 2 days before. There are different tickets for visiting different parts of palace. Family part, domestic part or ...I advise all pasengers to buy full tickets, because you should return about 1 kilometer again to prepare other ticket. You can not take a photo in palace, but you are surprizing when you see beauty of arts and painting on the roof and walls.do not have any doubt about the visiting this palace.

Do not miss this amazing Palace. This Palace is simply amazing and should be on all visitors must see list when in Istanbul. The opulence and grandeur really will astound you. Visitor numbers are now limited to 3000 per day so get there early and after your tour slowly walk around the beautiful gardens and soak it all in. Those Sultans sure enjoyed a luxurious lifestyle.
Just beautiful. Full of amazing details in the structure. It tells the of luxury and grandeur of the Ottoman empire. Visiting one can just relivethe history

just amazing. Just amazing place, seems to go back in a luxury past, the only problem could be the touristic guides, if you go alone and you don't understand english or turkish you'll just watch around without knowing the history of the building.

A must see when in Istanbul . A must visit attraction when in Istanbul. Full of history and grandeur as befitting the last home of the Sultans. Limited numbers of visitors are admitted each day so get there early

Skip Topkapi, this is the real deal!. As grand as Topkapi palace is, it is nothing compared to Dolmabahce. Dolmabahce was built after the Ottoman sultan decided that Topkapi wasn't good enough for him. I'll say nothing about it as words may never describe its grandeur. One thing I'll say though is that the grand ceremonial hall was like nothing I've ever seen in my life, not even in movies!Dolmabahce makes place like Chateau Versailles and Buckingham Palace look like housing projects for the poor!

Beautiful historic landmark. Dolmabache Palace is the modern royal residence in Istanbul. The grounds are very well maintained and the building itself is kept in pristine condition. Entering the harem (living quarters, where Ataturk's room is exactly the same as the day he died in 1938) costs 20TL, the official section is 30TL, and both is 40TL. Everything is a guided tour, so check the timing before hand so you arrive for a tour in the language that you speak! Getting here is easy, there are several buses that connect it to Sultanahmet, Taksim etc.

In stead of Topkapi palace! . A fabulous palace where Atatürk had his residence before dying. Well preserved and most interesting to visit. A perfect & better alternative for the very crowded Topkapi Palace.
Golden looking Palace. It is Western looking Palace, It only take 40 Lira cash for ticket, it is guided tour only. it is worth the trip to see it.

Dolmabahce Sarai, you must admit, is beautiful.. This palace is so beautiful outside, and what would it be like living right on the same level as the Bosphorus, at least in the summertime. Perhaps not so much when it's snowing. Inside is also beautiful, but the tour set up is not so good, too expensive lines too long, waiting time too long, too many people in each tour, rushed through. It is annoying, but it also is beautiful.

Beautiful palace. The palace is beautiful, really worth a visit. The fee is 40 TRY (15,00€) for palace and harem. You should buy the combined ticket, because it gives you the view of the whole palace. The negative part of my visit were all the guides. I was on English tour but it is really hard to understand the English they are speaking. The second problem is that the group is quite large so if you stay in the back you will miss most of the guide explanations. TIP: Stay with the guide and listen carefully.

A different view of Istanbul. We visited Dolmabahce palace after visiting the Topkapi Palace. While not so impressive as Topkapi, it is well worth a visit, with a guided tour being part of the entrance fees.This palace lets you see a different side of the royalty life and how it changed with more European influence, since this palace is made in a continental style rather than a typical Islamic style.It is also in very good shape and well preserved with many precious and original artifacts on display.

Beautiful European style palace. Beautiful palace set on the banks of the Bosphorus in lovely gardens. You must go round the palace in a guided tour which leave on half past the hour. The palace rooms are magnificent especially the huge chandeliers and the beautiful ceilings often painted in gold leaf. Give yourself a good two hours or more to go on both tours of the palace and harem.

wonderful palace. There is lonely one word to describe this palace.. Amazing! We've been there with my family and I loved this palace but on my last visit was not happy without the tour becausei still waiting like 30 minutes just to buy the tickets but my friends tell me we been the palace with tour it was without any problem

This is a MUST!. There is lonely one word to describe this palace.. Amazing! We've been travelling around Europe for the last 2 months and this is by far the most impressive palace. There is so much detail from the painting on the ceiling to the gold plated radiators in the corners of the rooms. The chandeliers in each room are jaw dropping! You cannot buy a ticket and walk through the palace individually. There are scheduled tours which takes groups at a time (I think it's every half hour). You have to do this if you're in Istanbul!

Splendid palace. I love this palace but on my last visit was not happy with the tour. We were quickly showed around and always told to catch up. Not enough time to see the paintings which adorn the walls. Having to pay for the experience was not what you want.I have on previous visits wandered at my own speed. This time also there were parts of the palace we were not showed. Felt they wanted you in and out as quick as they could. Ask how long the tour will take before you pay.

Beyond awesome. It is required to be part of the official tour of the Palace. Tours are available in Turkish or English. Assuming you move reasonably quickly, budget 3 hours to see everything within the palace grounds. Neither still nor video photography is permitted and security staff enforces this rule strictly. Some people make a nuisance of themselves all the time by trying to break the rule.Situated on the Bosphorus with huge lovely grounds and gardens, it is a combination of European and Ottoman architecture with a rich history. It rivals many of the palaces in India and definitely puts European palaces in the shade. Home to 6 Sultans and Kemal Ataturk it has a mind boggling decor – varying from room to room. The Pink room and the Blue Room stand out as fabulous in this extraordinary palace. The regal front entrance, indoor fountains, the crystal stairway make one stand still and admire the grandeur in awe. A must see.

Review for Harem only.... We only bought a ticket for the Harem as we were very pushed for time and I really wanted to see the rooms occupied by Atatürk. You can't look around alone and are forced to join either an English or Turkish tour. You also can't take pictures which I found very annoying. However, the history of the place is truly breathtaking. Seeing the parlour where the many women of the Sultan would sit was fascinating. The interior is outstandingly beautiful such as the ceilings and the chandeliers. The real emotional part for me as a Turk was the bedroom of Atatürk and seeing the bed where he died. Unlike today's Turkish prime minister, it it so humbling to know that out of all those hundreds of lavish rooms he chose to use only 3 modestly furnished ones as his living room, bedroom and bathroom. Unfortunately we couldn't look around the grounds as by the time we came outside there was a snow storm going at full throttle!! Do not leave Istanbul without visiting this Palace.

Kar altinda muhteşem❄❄❄. Istanbul her yani muhteşem bir şehir. Ancak kar altinda sanki daha da mükemmel. Resmi biraz önce motora binmeden çektim. Mutlaka İstanbul'u ziyaret edin. Cok sey kazanırsınızI have just taken this picture while I was on my way home.It's snowing heavily right now but the scenery is Magnificent, isn t it?? Visit İstanbul admire the fascinating life

285 Rooms, 68 Toilets - and cost 35 tons of Gold. Atuturk's Death Bed.. I visited most of the magnificent sights in Istanbul, but the only one I really recall is Dolmabahce! - one of the most beautiful palaces in the world - Often called, "The Gold and Crystal Palace."Completed in 1856 and the home of the next 6 Sultans, until the ending of the Caliphate in 1924, then occupied by Atuturk until his death.Beautifully situated on the Bosphorus - firstly I loved the grounds and the gardens. The Palace, a combination of European and Ottoman architecture, is a very pleasant change to view than the Continental Palaces, which after a while all start to look the same.I loved the front entrance , the spacious, uncluttered effect, the indoor fountains, the Blue Room, the Crystal staircase, and most of all the 'Pink Room' - which is red.Yes, you can view the bed on which, 'the great man' died, but I think it is still illegal to speak ill of him - so 'take care.'Brian, from Perth. Western Australia.

Buckingham palace eat your heart out.. I literally couldn't get my wife out of there, she felt in love with it, the art, the carpets(rugs), the chandeliers the history. It's a must do if you ever go to Istanbul.

Splendours. Visited February in the morning for the first english spoken tour. You must join official tours in either Turkish or English. Our group of about 40 was mixed nationalities and some had difficulties understanding. No photographs are allowed in the palace but some in our group just ignored this which was rather annoying. Security eventually stopped these individuals and shadowed them for the rest of the 45minute tour.

Excellent.. This was our favourite place of all in Istanbul and the one we new least about. Yes we enjoyed the others but this was a complete surprise. It cost 40TL each to do the whole tour. You have to do the guided tour; you cannot just walk around by yourself. The palace and all its contents are in excellent order. It was home to 6 Sultans 1 Caliph and it was where Mustafa Kemal AtaTurk died. The guide in the Selamlik (administrative) part of the Palace was very informative. This in my opinion was the best part. The Harem, the Sultans private quarters, was good but not as opulent. The gardens over look the Bosphorus and in the summer I should imagine it is very pleasant walking around outside. But it was snowing when we were there and very cold. When we finished the tour of the Selamlik we walked around the outside of the palace to take the Harem tour only to be told that we would have to wait for 30 minutes for the next tour but we could get some refreshments in a conveniently located cafe! A bit cheeky. If you are going to Istanbul definatly put this on your places to see list.
better from outside. nice building, but better from outside, the interior is like many other palaces in Europe, and not cheap

In Instabul, be sure not to miss it. We take the full tour. And it really wirth while. The palace, the harren, clock museam, cristal pavillion, gardens, exteriors and interiors everything is fabulous. The guides point out the most significant things and are not boting at all. Buts everything is asolutly fantastic. Really be sure not to miss it and take a lot of pictures in the gardens and beatiful facades...

Breathtaking Beauty. Dolmabahce Palace is extraordinarily beautiful. The Palace itself is extravagantly decorated - crystal banisters & heavy chandeliers dripping in jewels. However, you're not allowed to take pictures. They offer free tours there & it's a fabulous experience to wander around & really understand what it would have been like when the Sultans were living there. You can also purchase seperate tickets to look at other things & small museums which are all around the palace. I definitely recommend this as a place to go. It's a stunning palace, serene & with views of the sea.

Worth a visit. This palace set on the shores of the Bosphorous has wonderful grounds and a beautiful exterior with great views of the Bosphorous. The tour was a little disappointing. For some reason no photos are allowed though the palace hasn't been used regularly for many years. It is certainly a monument to excess, from the 1.5 to the 4.5 ton crystal chandeliers to the alabaster marble to the endless rooms with endless chairs. The tour is $30TL for the palace and an extra $10TL for the harem. I would skip the harem, the private quarters of the Sultan and family as it is just more of the same after the main palace. Once you have seen the Great Room, with the huge chandelier that apparently is like a sun when lit but wasn't lit for the tour, and the Crystal Staircase it gets a little repetitious and everthing is getting a little worn. Well worth a visit.

don't go on Monday. Looks beautiful from outside. We came on Monday in the heavy shower, to hear from the guards at the entrance that it's a day off for the museum, of course our own fault. Fortunately museum cafe was opened and price for tea was reasonable :)It's possible to get there by funicular from Taxim(looks like another subway line) instead of half hour walk.

Stunning building , Great and amazing interior. GO GO GO and look it.. I been to this place few months ago and i was very nice surprice with the rich interior of Cristal , gold and carpets. The most interesting building i see in my life.You have to vizit this place . 25 TL tickeet
Beautiful Palace. You can't visit Istanbul without having seen this Palace. It is a typical tourist attraction, so bring your time and patience with you! This would be my biggest advice to you.

Not worth three long queues!. First slow queue is for a security scan. No cover or shelter so prepare to get very wet or very cold or very hot. Next queue (again in the open) is for tickets,the Museum Pass is not accepted. Then you queue on the steps to gain entry as admission is time allocated. We had a guide with limited English who walked us through the rooms with very little to say. Then he confounded us by attempting to liken the separation of the public and private rooms to borderline personality disorder! A waste of money and time.
Nice. This itself is a big place with a few buildings to visit. There will be guided tour. The place is well preserved and kept as original as possible. Well worth a visit.

Stunning palace. Really remarkable and stunning palace located in Beşiktaş - not so far from Istiklal cad. Entrance fee was about 10 TL in april (we are students) and didn't have to pay additional fee for harem. The garden of palace is beautiful and the inside of palace more than amazing. You are not allowed to take photos inside the palace but what you see there is more than any pictures.

Eye catching. After a fairly lengthy queue I was shuffled along to remove shoes and allocated a guide as you are not permitted to see the interior alone. The guide had a strong, clear voice and was very knowledgeable, moving us along quite rapidly. No photography allowed inside which was disappointing but they give you a free brochure with many pictures of the highlights. The grounds are beautifully landscaped with views of the Bosphorus.

Grandest of All European Palaces. I stumbled on the Dolmabahce Palace by accident looking for Taskim Square. The palace is situated on the Bospherous Strait and just a couple of stops on the tram from the Galata Bridge.The palace is beautiful, it grand, it's what you expect a palace to be and more. The grand ballroom took my breath away without exaggeration - I have never seen such a grand room in all the palaces I have visited in Europe. The chandelier is 4 tonnes in weight and made of crystal, the ceiling is hand painted and an impressive 36 meters, the palace of Versailles does not come close to this grand old lady. It's welll with a visit.Now the bad part, the entrance fee is exspensive - 40 Turkisk Lira for that you get a guided tour, no one is allowed into the palace without a guide. Well this is not really a guided tour, the guides rush you through, are impatient, and in the Harem, the guide left us and disappeared and we did not get to see the 3rd floor where the concubines lived. To his credit the guide in the Harem was much more knowledgeable and informed than the guide in the palace administration area.When you buy your ticket you can buy one for the Palace and Harem, but after the Palace tour they tell you the Harem tour is every 20 minutes, 20 minutes Island time, more like 40 minutes.Don't plan on racing down here as a last minute stop before you race onto something else, the bureaucratic nonsense that occurs between the officials who run the palace is a joke, anywhere else in the world these people who be sacked for incompetence

Remarkable Palace. A wonderful palace built by the Balyan family, the construction of the Dolmabahce palace virtually bankrupted the Ottoman empire. Adorned with gold leaf throughout, baccarat crystal chandeliers and the famous crystal staircase, the interior of the palace can only be viewed as part of a guided tour. Ataturk died in the palace, and his bedroom clock is still stopped at 9:05 am, the time of his death.

An experience.... It was an interesting experience. But... the palace tour was disappointing, as long as our "guide" was constantly moving forward, we had no time for at least observing details. Clock museum was closed.

Take a tour. I've never been a fan of tours, but for this place, it's your best option. You'll avoid lines and guides who scream yet aren't heard by the mobs trying to listen. We had a good tour guide and a small group. We could hear and see everything.The palace itself is fairly interesting and the grounds are fantastic. I wouldn't say this is a must-see, but it's worth the trouble and time.

A must visit in Istanbul, Turkey. A must see! Go early or book ahead with a travel agent because Dolmabahce Palace limits visitors to about 3000 each day. Take the tram to Kabatas & walk north or take a taxi from Sultanahmet for 20-25 Turkish Lira. If taking taxi, I recommend you agree to a price before starting. There was a 20 minute long line for entry tickets when we visited in Dec 2014. Amazing palace.

Great palace to visit. It is very intersting indeed. The english guide was mothertongue but due to a big group I couldn't hear him very well. The palace is very well kept. Must visit the harem as well. The waterfront park is also nice to walk through. Enjoy it

Must see site of Instanbul. An incredible 2 hours spent admiring the new palace. Very well maintained and the sheer scale and beauty of the palace is breathtaking. The guide explained the importance of different areas of the palace very well. A trip worth making
Beautiful luxurious old palace. This is a place that you should really visit when you are in Istanbul. It is very beautiful and quite luxurious.

I loved it!. This palace is special. It looks amazing. You need to visit it! Palace and garden are really beautiful. Things that are inside are gorgeous. You can learn a lot about how life in Turkey used to be.

The Turkish Versallie. Dolmabahçe is the largest palace in Turkey. Dolmabahce Palace is one of the most glamorous palaces in the world. With its charming garden.. After your visit you can enjoy the nice view of the Bosporus in the coffee shop just outside the garden
Amazing Palace. Is my second favorite Palace after Versalles, is just amazing, the decoration, and the history that it has is impressive!

"the best Palace". .Inside the hereke is a compley of different departments , carpets decorate the walls and the floor, the bohemia cristal, the beautiful porcelain and painting by Western artista to t. the furniture, and more. The Palace have two floor, every were is luxury, but very different from the ladys room.If you go to Turkey- Istambul don't forget to give a visist to this great Palace.

Distracted by the Cold. I visited Dolmabahce in the winter, which I do not recommend. The lady giving the tour kept talking about how one of the sultans put a modern central heating system in place, but none of the heaters were on :((((( At the end of the tour we went down this long hallway, where icy wind blew in our faces, because someone had left the windows open (why???). The tour was very big and so it was hard to truly see much. While it may be true that the best time to view this palace is in the summer, it shouldn't be so bad in the winter that it ends up being miserable.

Favorite attraction in Istanbul. We are fortunate to have gone to this palace on our short 3-day trip to Istanbul on friends recommendation. Ended up being our favorite attraction in Istanbul followed by Galata Tower, Hagia Sophia, and walking down the streets and cafe's around Galata Tower.

A Great Palace to Visit. Not in Sultanhamet and requiring a tram ride (easy - 4TL) - You must go. The palaces and sites in Sultanhamet get deserved coverage but it would be a shame to miss the place where Ata Turk lived. Interesting and historic in its own right it's worth the effort - combine it with a boat trip or a visit to Taksim square.

Not too impressed. We bought the all-inclusive 40 TL tickets. I consider myself well travelled and I did not find this palace all that impressive. Some of the details like the quantity of gold used in the construction and the humongous chandeliers etc are interesting. Otherwise, very average. You can only enter the palace as part of a guided tour (which are available in various languages and included in your ticket price). You can't take any pictures. Our guide's English was so poor that some people in the group joked they might as well have gone with the Turkish group. In certain areas, both groups were present in two corners of the same room and boy it was fun when the Turkish and English guides spoke at the same time. I felt the guides gave out minimum information. There was a collection of paintings which I liked. All in all, keep your expectations low.

Rich, sparkling and impressive. Prepare to wait in a queue for the X-ray check first followed by a ticket check. Taking photos inside is not allowed, so take care. The palace inside is impressive. It is massive and rich. Furniture is mostly baroque and looks European. However, you cannot see where they slept, only the daily living quarters. The view of the Bosphorus is great. There is a toilet facility near the entrance/exit.

The best sight in Istanbul. This palace is overwhelming. It is by far the best sight we have visited in Istanbul. A lot of rooms, stories, and gold/cristal to be seen everywhere around. It is a display of architecture and wealth you have never seen in your life before.

Very Beautifull. It was the kind of palace i was seeking.After visiting Topkapi Palace we headed the next day to Dolmabahce Palace ( you have to visit them in this order becauseyou understand their history better this way).It was what i was looking for...you could see the way they lived, their bedrooms ( the apartments for men and harem place for women), the reception rooms.Everything is well preserved and the tour guide gives you allot of information during the whole visit.

a rip off. I so wish I had read the other reviews before I made my decision to visit! I used the hop on hop off bus (that's another story) - the palace is of historical significance - ornate over the top and in a sense bizarre - but that's part of the history of the Ottoman empire. the cost is high, you are force to join a group tour - almost 100 people in our group - you couldn't hear at the back, the guide was disinterested, no info at the many interesting pieces of furniture, art etc, The 20lira for the hamman is a laugh, given the info given, and the inability to see into the many side rooms. Look at a brochure or book on the palace, It is more helpful. the tourism board needs to get the act together.the snow showers today didn't help

crowds, lines, poor arrangement but a beautiful palace experience. This palace and its buildings if worth a see- but be prepared for ridiculous lines that are poorly managed. You first have to go through security screening to enter to buy your ticket. Then you have to line up and wait for the tour- you are not premitted to enter on your own. Then you line up again and are rushed through the buildings stopping only when your guide pauses to give information about the various rooms. no photos are permitted anywhere, so that is disappointing although I did find a very nice book of photos for a reasonable price in the gift shop in the painting museum nearby. Check out all of the outbuildings- paintings, crystal, etc.

The most amazing place - organised so incredibly badly!. This place is only 150 years (ish) old and was built in the dying embers of the Ottoman Empire. They were still rich and built palace which is better than any i've even seen on TV. This place is absolutely spectacular...But. We stood outside for nearly an hour in the driving snow...We got inside and were corralled into a tiny holding area with a few hundred people waiting for an english tour which was expected to be 20 minutes later (we eventually went with the turkish tour). The main building is sufficiently impressive that with decent signs it would be enough for you to walk on your own (the signage is very poor).The "Harem" really did need a bit of explanation but all you got was a 2 minute chat. The current Turkish government seems intent on erasing the memory of Ataturk and this was painfully obvious here where a few small signs were all you saw about the place where the founder of the Turkish republic met kings and world leaders and ultimately died. An astonishing place, but a dreadful experience. I couldn't in good faith recommend this as a place to visit until the tours have been entirely reinvented.

Top luxury, gold, silver, crystal and ...eclectic. Dolmabahce Palace (Dolmabahce Sarayi) is the palace where sultans lived from 1856 to 1922 in European top luxury. With its 45 000sq.m it is the largest palace in Turkey. You can visit the palace only with a guide. There are two queues - for guided group tours and individual tourists. The latter can join guided tours only in English and Turkish. Tours show the waiting rooms, offices of the Grand Vizier, the central hall, the luxurious apartments etc. and attract your attention to the gifts from foreign heads of state, among which the world’s largest crystal chandelier (5 tons), considered until recently a gift from Queen Victoria. Some years ago a receipt was found certifying that the chandelier was actually bought. At the time of our visit some rooms were closed for visitors, incl. the imperial bath. The Mosque which is now outside the palace complex has perhaps the tallest minarets in the town.The eclectic style of the palace is not my favorite one but the view to the Golden horn is beautiful. I am sorry for not using the time to visit a museum in the historical peninsula instead of Dolmabahce palace.

Majestic. First, you should consider spending 2 hours at least in many lines. First line for security scanning, second for ticketing and third for palace entry.There are two main sections in the palace: selamlik and harem.The selamlik makes you forget the pain of waiting in lines. Its very very very majestic and luxurious. No words could describe it. The harem is nice to see, but incomparable to the palace selamlik. Visiting the selamlik alone is 30 TL. Harem alone is 20 TL. Both are at 40 TL.

Beautiful palace. This amazing palace is something you need to really see, they have used 90Kg of gold to decorate the palace. Wonderful furniture and great architecture and most of all rich in history.

Not worth the wait. First of all, if you plan a trip to Istanbul between Christmas and New Year, don't. Unless you love tense crowds... And budget travelling brought an inordinate number of tourists who have no couth and no respect. I am all for democratisation of travelling but people first learn some manners before leqving your country. And no, not everyone speaks french or english, so learn some basics of other language than yiur own. The visit of the palace is not worth it during this period. We were rushed through, little information was given, and you have to take the tour. There was sometimes two groups in the same rooms which made understanding your own guide difficult. The queues everywhere are long, we waited an hour to get in, and in some seriously bad weather and with uncouth tourists, being rushed through the palace with little info was a truly horrible experience, the worst in my three visits in this wonderful capital. Wait off season and get a guide who will actually give you a wealth of information and who will be interested in answering your questions with relevant information and not just touristic crap.

Bigger than White House!. This palace belongs to Kamal Ataturk, who used to run Turkey long time ago. To start, the place is very beautiful with a view of the sea. Once inside, I was mesmerized with the amount of the space that they have inside cause it doesn't look that big to me from the outside. Worth the visit and made me realized how ugly my house is. T-T
Impressive Palace. Although not very Turkish looking, this is a very impressive palace. The guides are for the most part excellent.

Ok to visit, but you won't miss much even if you don't. We reached the queue to enter the palace at 11. Lots of kids and tourists. I think it is better to arrive at 9 to avoid the people, or simply avoid the Christmas/new year period where there's an upsurge in volume. They make you wear plastic bags over your shoes before entering. There are 15 to 20 mins wait for each compulsory, scheduled tour to start, so you need to be patient. Other reviewers said to get to the front of the line in order to hear what the guide is saying because he is so soft and there are so many people. Now I think that is just silly advice. For these reasons:1) the guide in the main tour doesn't speak good English anyway . . . Most people could not make out what was being said and 2) the information revolves just around years and names and what room this is. Unimportant stuff that you are not going to remember anyway. My advice is just quit the jostling to get to the front, walk slowly and enjoy the sights of the opulence in the palace. However, after the first few room, every room starts to look the same, especially with a robotic and bored looking guide.By contrast, the harem tour has lesser things to see and much less opulence, but the guide was waaay better at explaining and really loud and enthusiastic. We suspect the better guides get sent to the harem, since it's more exclusive, and the lousy ones are assigned to the main tour. If you are here, recommended to take the harem tour. If you have other sights to see and do not have time, it's ok to give this place a miss. Takes about 3 hours including wait time for queues.

Very well spotted. We took the T1 tram and it was only 5 minutes walking timeThe price of a full entrance (palace and harem) was 40 TL and it is guided. This means that you need to stay in line in order for the next group to be served. So you need to have patience.You went in both tours and we actually loved it.Our ticket was also due for a painting collection but we didn't do that.Be aware that if the visitors exceed 3000 daily, the ticket booth closes...Also don't visit on Thursdays. It is closed

Stunning Palace - Terrible Terrible staff. The palace is one of the nicest in Europe with all the oppulance you can imagine. The staff are a whole different story. -The security staff (step 1) are terrible and shouting at people. -The ticketing staff (step 2): doesn't get more annoying: absolutely disenchanted and grim and made u feel like you were an annoyance, not to mention literally throwing the tickets at you. -Coat check (step 3): I was shouted at and thrown out of the coat check area because I wasn't understanding Turkish! -The guided tour (step 4): an absolut nightmare (idio) who shouted at people for not walking too fast, who made fun of people because they asked questions and who eventually left someone behind because they didn't want to wait! All in all terrible. -The guided tour of the Harem (step 5): An educated, interesting, passionate, funny and smiling gentleman. But what's the use - the visit was already botched! Terrible terrible staff - We felt like in a military airport in Kandahar. They really ought to learn some manners and hospitality!

Gorgeous palace but, huge crowds distracting. The only way to visit is via a tour so, be prepared to queue and move slowly in a huge horde of people. We estimated there were over 60 in our group but, this is the only way in. Rooms were impressive but, try to visit off peak and reserve ahead of time.

Breath-taking! . A definite must-see when visiting Istanbul. Breath- taking and opulent. The English tour guides move quite quickly through the palace. Read up on the history and eye catching pieces before visiting.

Disappointing and rushed. The palace complex is beautiful but the only part you will enjoy is the painting museum - which is the only building that does not have a guided tour. The Harem was not as impressive as I had hoped however it was more memorable than the one at Topkapi. They should consider allowing tourists to have unguided tours of the harem and administrative buildings so that visitors can truly appreciate the history. Consider audio guides as the two short speeches given at the harem were a true waste of time.Sadly another landmark in turkey that tourists are herded like sheep and miss a lot of detail.

amazing. make sure you keep time to visit this amazing palace. the interiors are amazing and its a great feel to be able to spend time here.great views from the grounds. the palace is in the heart of the city so easy to get to.

No individual visits. Be prepared to queue. You can't visit by yourself but have to book a tour. Also, be clear when buying the ticket if you want "just" the palace or the harem tour as well. If you don't specify, they sell you the combined ticked. You will have to wear plastics over your shoes which is a bit annoying as you are shuffling over carpets and losing the plastics. Group are too large for my liking, couldn't understand a thing.

Wow! Now that's a Palace!. This palace puts the whitehouse to shame! Built in 1843 it is extremely lavish and beautifully decorated. Lonely planet guidebook said not to miss this and BOY WERE THEY RIGHT! I only wished I had allowed more time so we could see the Harem area. We got a peek and it looked even more regal than the other parts! Don't miss this!

the real definition of speechless.. the place is wonderful. it left me stunted. i cant remember any piece pf art that even match this place. every thing is wonderful. and the ceremony hall is the most amazing.the only thing i dont like is the fact they prevent photography.

Will NOT recommend . this was such a waste of money! over priced .. and they take groups as large as 50! and not to mention other agents doing the same meaning u'd even find trouble walking because of the people in there! besides no guide can yell out loud all the facts eh? guess Topkapi should be the only palace to visit!

BEST of the Istanbul Sites. The Dolmabahce Palace is the Best of the Istanbul Attraction in my opinionThe exterior gardens and the entrance gates to the Bosphorus strait are rich in beautyThe Best part of the Dolmabache Palace and its adjacent Harem is that they are fully furnished in the style of the Sultan.The gorgeous chandeliers are eyepopping!!The only negative is that the Guards strictly prohibit ANY Photography. It is a shame since the furnishings are so vivid.I Strongly recommend buying the combination ticket to the Palace and Harem. The Dolmabache Harem was so great, that we did not feel the need to pay extra for the Harem in Topkapi Palace

Quite deceiving tour.... The palace can be accessed by tram with an extra 200m walking...It is closed on Mondays & Thursdays..The fees vary according to the parts to visit with 40L for the full guided tour..The palace is really interesting & I think it is worth the full tour although the harem section needs quite a renovation compared to the Salamlik section...The gardens are really nice & well maintained..However, the real issue was the tour organisation & content itself; first, you'll have to wait (in some cases under the rain) for a good 20 minutes to access the lobby, starting point of the tour, english in our case..The number of persons for the tour was impressing & you should always stay next to the guide in order to hear her speech...which was really deceiving!!!!No interesting information..& revolving about the purchase of the next tour ticket!!!.. Not many stops during the tour, so you'll pass many rooms without any explanation...In brief, should the tour be mandatory, the guides' speech should be reconsidered, number of persons reduced with better organisation..Quite a pity as the palace is a gem...

My #2 favorite place in Istanbul. I think this is much nicer than topkapi palace. Don't miss it. We went there two times since it's near our hotel Conrad. It's a romantic walk from the street to the palace. I'm glad we did enter the 2nd time we went there.

Great. Great bilding in Istanbulit shows you how Last Sultans was livevery luxurious many rooms6 turkish hammamthere are tow sideone for works of sultan wich name is "slamlik"another one for privte life of sultan wich name is "harmalic"ther is a man take you inside the palacis talk English

Fusion of styles. This palace reflects the fusion of European styles was constructed between 1843 and 1856 and designed by Karabet Balyan, architect to Sultan Abdulmecid and of the prolific Balyan family of architects who served Istanbul. Topkapi palace the main palace of the ottoman sultans was abandoned after the construction of the Dolmabahce palace was completed.
Great Palace. Need to go with the Palace guide. Make sure you have cash to purchase tickets if going on your own - Credit cards are not accepted. Long lines so go early

Tour is not great -- go anyway. Even in November, there were long lines waiting for the next English tour. The staff seemed disorganized, but in the end, we all fell into line and off we went. The Palace's public spaces are designed to impress, and they are gaudily overwhelming, with gigantic crystal chandaliers in room after room. More interesting to me were the private living quaters (harem) of the sultan and his family. For most of us, this lifestyle is far different from what we're accustomed. It was fascinating and worth the price of the expanded admission. When else will you have a chance to experience a place like this?

Fıne European Paıntıngs In Istanbul. I am wrıtıng thıs about my recent experıence ın the Paıntıng Museum of the Dolmabahce Palace.I enjoyed ıt very much.It reflects the conservatıve tastes ın Art of the last Ottoman Sultans and Kemal Ataturk.It had a large collectıon of wonderful paıntıngs by Russıan Master,Ivan Aızavosky,ımcludıng hıs fıne seascapes and cıtyscapes.Many paıntıngs ın thıs art museum have Orıental themes.Personal favorıtes were Seyrıt Dag's. "Interıor of Hagıa Sophıa,Istanbul",Osman Nurı Pasa,s"Landscape",Felıx Zıem,s"Venıce",Gustave Boulanger's"Interıor Vıew of Pompeı",Jean Leon Gerome,s"Coffee House ın Egypt"Ivan Aızavosky's"Vıew of Egypt"and Theo Van Rhysellberghe's fıne Poıntıllıstıc "Galata Brıdge".The staff of thıs art museum was very helpfull and enthusıastıc.Photography ın thıs art museum ıs forbıdden.

An enormous palace, with lovely grounds, but with poor guided tours.
