The Dolmabahce Palace is a 19th century creation, a European fantasy built by the later Ottoman sultans in a effort to appear more modern. It is essentially mid-19th century French in its style, with the tendency to go for maximal opulence at the expense of actual beauty or taste, but it is impressive, nonetheless. However, the tours on which one must be taken in order to see the palace are poor, giving little insight into the history or the architecture of the palace, and given in English by personnel not especially fluent in the language. One must also wear plastic overshoes when touring the place (they are provided at the entrance).

Beautiful palace, but terrible tour. If we had known the tour group would be more than 70,including small children, &see would be walked through, with no opportunity to look at our leisure,we would it have bothered. Could have done a tour on YouTube!! Group guides gave little insight to how they lived.

Impressive . It's an impressive castle to visit in Istanbul. Come early and Give it time. First for entering (long lines to get in) and then for visiting. All visits are guided visits. It totally deserves the wait and the visit.It's really different from Topkapi palace. It is built with European style not ottoman. Don't miss the gardens at the entrance and then the one on the bosphore at the end of the visit.
Beautiful I like. U can beautiful palace The furnitures inside was so niceAlso u can see the bed that attaturk died on it.It worth it

Dolmabahce Palace. Dolmabahce palace it's an impressive tourist attraction in Istanbul. We pay 20 Turkish liras for entrance which covered the entrance in the gardens and tour of the "Harem". We loved the clock museum! If you are staying in Taksim square it's around 15 min walk.Worth a visiting.

Beautiful, but very hurried tour. The palace is absolutely beautiful, and on par with European palaces, but the guided tour is very hurried with the guide barely being heard at all beyond the first few people in the main palace. For the entry fee charged, I would have expected the guide to either have organized tours in smaller groups given the narrow hallways, or at least repeated himself or been louder. Also, if taking small children, do note that the tour is quite hurried and the organizers fussy and unhelpful to the point of being rude while hurrying you on, so the kids (and you!) may not appreciate the same. The harem guide, however, was much clearer and led a lovely tour. She also entertained questions and did not hurry people so everyone had a chance to absorb everything. There was a lot of confusion regarding when and where the harem tour would start, though and we were made to walk up and down the colossal grounds three times by the museum staff. No place to sit down for a minute except for one cafe. Overall a must see in Istanbul.

the last sultan's palace. the most beautiful attraction from Istanbul in my opinion.Here lived the last sultan and the parent of modern Turkey Kemal Ataturk.You have a guide for tour in english.I recommand to visit both tours the palace and Harem.

Not enough time to view.. Impressive and preferred to Topkapi the only downside is that you have to go on a conducted tour. Whilst you would like to stop & look for a few minutes you are moved along fairly rapidly , the tour only lasting about 45 minutes which is a shame. This though is one of the must see places to see, it is very impressive.

Opulence.. In my opinion this is a must see if you visit Istanbul. Dolmabahce Palace is a Magnificent Palace with a great deal of History. To be honest there is nothing that I disliked about it. Walking through you got a sense of the power of the Sultans who resided there and the opulence in which they lived. Wonderful.

Must see!. Dolmabahce palace it's an impressive tourist attraction in Istanbul. We pay 20 turkish liras for entrance wich covered the entrance in the gardens and tour of the "Harem". We loved the clock museum! Worth a visit.

Such great history and worth a visit. We arrived early in Dolmabahce Sarayi in a cloudy morning. There weren't much queues yet so it was great. We paid at the entrance because it wasn't included in the Museum Card. Anyway,it was okay nonetheless because it was a guided tour when you get in the palace. However, I barely understood what the guide was saying because some of the tourists were quite noisy. But with some of the information I got, the guide was pretty informative and funny at the same time. Be wary, it is not allowed to take photographs inside the palace. So please do respect this instruction as to not disrupt the guide and the tour. Also, you will be asked to wear "plastic shoes" before entering the palace as to keep the carpets clean. All in all it was such beautiful Architecture. I wish I could have taken photos but I guess experiencing it should be enough.

unexpected jewel. A private tourist guide we hired suggested this site which, for some reason, had not been highlighted in information we had received. He fortunately was able to assist us to bypass the queues and point out the major curiosities, history and uniqueness of the site.Well worth a visit, but go early to avoid queues.

Not really impressive. Well, paying 30 Turkish Liras for a ticket to access the Palace is way too much for what you exactly see. First of all, you will never access this Palace alone. Always in a group of people. We had about 80 people in a group. A guide had to shout in order to be understood. Security gards keep an eye on you always. Taking pictures is forbidden and strictly executed. All the pieces of furtiture are covered with dust as if no one have ever cleaned them. Tour takes 30-40 minuts.Not waroth doing that at all. More you will find in the Internet.

Well worth a visit.. We found our visit to Dolmabahce Palace to be far more interesting than the TopTopkapi Palace mainly due to the fact that most of the original furnishings are in place. D.I.Y. tourists can join an English language tour of the palace (45 mins), and an optional extra (30 mins) tour of the Harem.We recommend both, but don't expect to be able to take your time, as tours are "rushed".Have cash ready for entry fees as credit cards were not acceptable when we visited in October 2014. Check local info for times of tours and days on which the palce is closed.

Tour was pitiful but sights well worth it. Completely agree, tour was terrible. But that's the only way they let you get inside so just ignore the guide and enjoy the amazing sights. The grounds were beautiful and the painting museum very very nice. I wouldn't say the harem part is worth your time unless you have some pressing need to see where ataturk died and his death bed shroud.

Beautiful. It is very beautiful place. I was required to take the complimentary group tour. The group was huge and the guide was okay. For example, when the group did enter a large room, she would begin talking without waiting for the entire group to get into the room. Some of us couldn't barely hear her... No photography is allowed inside the palace. Gift shop was okay. They didn't have any good postcard pictures. Was hoping to purchase one of the crystal chandellier postcard. Highlight of the palace are the crystal chandelier in the grand balloon, all marble baths. Getting to the palace is easy. Take a tram from Sultanahmet directly to Kabatas. From Kabatas, just walk along the river and the palace will be on your right along the river. Or you can take the furnicular down from Taksim Station.

very very nice place. i love this place
the most beautiful palace i have ever seen
and the most beautiful place of istanbul in comparison with topkapi palace aya sufia mosque

Worst Tour, Ever. Seriously, EVER!. The Domanbache Palace itself is a beautiful facility with an amazing history. However, the group tour one is forced to take is so amazingly bad that one's attention is diverted to the ridiculousness of the tour rather than the beauty and history of the facility. Our guide herded us at a fast trot through the open areas of the palace building with occasional top level cursory statements about what we were seeing. We ended up in the fabulous main reception room, where you could enjoy a good half hour just on the amazing chandelier and ornate columns and ceiling, but we got one minute on seating arrangements (no one could sit higher than the sultan) and then told "the story is over, good bye." When we continued to stand there for a second, trying to both appreciate the room and understand what we just were told, our guide said "seriously, the story is over, bye bye." Amazing. As far as the facility overall, I agree with Tom M about the deferred maintenance and the poor signage. It is too bad, this is a real treasure that is being abused. Until they fix that, don't bother with going unless you want a tour so poor that it actually becomes humorous.

it is not worth one dollar. Without doubt the worst tour of Istanbul. It is a kitsch palace building commanded by the late Sultan. All you have nice is the location, literally bathed by the Bosporus. The guides give the minimum possible explanations. Expensive ticket to visit the Harem is a scam, it is not worth one dollar. The little fountain with ceramic swans at the entry warns what awaits you. A horror. And expensive.

Highlight of our visit. I was unaware of the significance of the palace before we went. Fortunately my Father had done his research and strongly recommended a visit. We visited three parts of the palace; the main part, the Harem and the Painting Museum.We were required to take the complimentary group tour, necessary to truly appreciate the palaces history. The guides weren't especially exciting but they covered the essentials and were clearly very knowledgeable. The main palace is stunning. Important as its function was to impress foreign statesman and dignitaries. It is fascinating to see the rooms that still maintain the original furniture. Of particular importance is the most impressive final room where Atatürk officially declared the start of the Turkish Republic. His speech is written in Turkish at the side.The Harem is less impressive but also well worth a visit. Here you can see Atatürk's rooms where he lived and died. The clocks in his room are still set to his time of death. It's such a privelege to be able to visit such a private area. Many of the rooms are also available for viewing providing valuable insights into life at the palace. We finished by heading to the Picture Museum. Well worth a visit, even for those who don't know much about art. As with all historic sites, ensure you understand of the significance of what you see!

Beautiful Palace...Horrible Tour. It's really a shame that a palace of this magnitude and beauty has been done an enormous disservice by the bureaucrats and functionaries in charge of showing it to the public. It's almost as if these folks thought long and hard about how they could make a tour experience so negative that it would actually detract from the experience of the site itself.After being herded through a tiny 'security' building with a metal detector tourists meander through the front courtyard with the beautiful swan fountain and up the staircase for entry into the building. Signage is poor and so we observed numerous people moving from one side of the staircase to the other only to be told that one side was for groups. The 'security' types relaying this information were anything but courteous. The crowd on the steps was composed of various language speakers but there was no effort to group them into tours for specific languages. We finally heard someone towards the front say something about an English tour so we joined a group of what must have been 50 or more who were entering the building. We could see a tour guide walking at the head of this large group. He talked as he walked but did not turn to address the group and we could hear nothing. As the tail end of the group entered a particular room or area he was already heading out to the next place as if there was a timer for each room. When the group did get to a room large enough for everyone to fit in, he would begin talking without waiting for the entire group to get into the room and he would talk in a normal conversational tone as if he was giving the tour to the 10-12 people closest to him. Then he would rush off to the next stop. We finally just gave up trying to keep up and catch a word or two and decided to just try to see as much as we could. Again, signage and explanatory materials are absent so even a self-guided tour is impossible. What the tourism office has invested in here are a number of very zealous 'security' types who dash about yelling at anyone with a camera or cell phone who looks like they may be taking pictures (with or without flash). The interior of the building has been poorly maintained and parts are alarmingly shabby. We were finally dumped out at the rear of the building facing the Bosphorus and actually noticed a sign pointing to another adjacent building and another tour. We followed these around to the front of the building (the Sultan's family and assorted concubines lived here as opposed to the state-function oriented elaborate first building). We got in another line outside the building and had the same 'guide' experience, this time by a woman with a thin, non-projecting voice who also seemed to be under some time pressure to get through each room as quickly as possible. The group was large and once again the guide invariably started her robot-like explanation (if you do this tour 25 times a day, 5 days a week, you'd think that you'd be able to make it 'your own' with some animation and inflection in your manners and voice) before the group was in the room and quickly charged off to the next.Our overall impression was that this was an incredible, historically rich, lavishly ornate facility that had been allowed to deteriorate badly and which was horribly presented to the public. The grounds around the palace exhibit the same shabbiness (weeds, uncut grass, algae filled fountains and ponds, flower beds unplanted, etc.). We strongly advise that the visitor take the time to read about the palace and obtain a tour book ahead of actually visiting. That would allow the visitor to know a bit about the palace and fill the gaps that are not provided by the 'guides'. Having seen palaces and similar buildings throughout Europe, England, and America we know that the tour experience can be 'world-class' to match the caliber of the site. It's time to totally scrap the current 'tour' system used here and design a new, customer-centric one that does justice to the facility. We wish, too, that Turkey would increase the budget for restoration and upkeep of this national treasure.

Beautiful palace. Dolmabahce palace is quite frankly beautiful . Strolling around it's immaculate gardens may well have been wiser in warmer weather but the audio guide tour of the main building was wonderful . Rich interiors combined with the history of the place ,and it's interesting of apparently a little overindulgent inhabitants ,made for an excellent trip . Would recommend .

Worth a visit out of season only. visited the palace as part of a Bosporous river cruise.Our cruise guide was excellent in his knowledge of the building and its history. However he was not allowed to take us into the palace as we had to use their own guides. That for me was the real disappointment of the tour as we were in a group of about 100 walking around with an official guide who did not really care about the tour. As there were so many people in our group, moving from one room to another took time and by the time we reached the next section, she was already in full flow with the commentary. So we tried to move up the line to be closer to her for the next section, but it was too noisy to understand all that was being said.This is really about getting as many people through the exit doors as quickly as possible.

Not worth a visit. Palace iš not worth a visit. It just big halls with chairs. And you have to wait for an hour to get in. Painting gallery is a joke bc there are very few paintings and no turk paintings just some russians and other nationalities. But worthless.

Well worth the trip to see - makes a nice ferry ride. A real insight into the opulence of the final era of the SultansWhilst nowhere near as old as Topkapi much easier to understand the lifestyle of the family that lived hereTour group approach actually worked well for the not very well informed visitor

Spectacular Palace. A spectacular palace built on the banks of the Bosphorus to rival the best palaces of the nobility of Europe. Best to read up about this place before taking the tour. Come early as there will likely be a long line getting inside and take note that a security checked will be done before you are allowed into the palace grounds. So dont bring any drugs, firearms, explosives or your mother in law. You are only allowed to go inside the palace if you are on a guided tour. 32 tons of gold was used in its constructions and you can see it in the finer details of the palace. Some of the highlights of the palace are the crystal chandelier in the grand ballroom which is said to be a gift from Queen Victoria herself and is the biggest crystal chandelier in the world. The ballroom itself is huge and is simply magnificent. other highlights include the all-marble hammam baths (there's six) the gate of the Sultan and the treasury, gates to the Bosphorus and the fabulous Dolmabahce clock tower. No photography is allowed inside the palace.

Beautiful palace and very hungry cats that need help. The palace is in my opinion better and more stunning than the Topkapi palace. When you enter the site behind the ticket-control, there are on your right side the toilets. I turned left and in the bush there was a starving cat family (the mother and 4 little kittens). I have never seen such a hurry while eating, they probably haven´t eaten for days! So please be kind and bring them some food!

Wow Wow Wow. This was the word of the day buy all our group. it is disappointed no photos are allowed but I understand because the paintings can be damaged, I would advise to go with a local tour group as you are given the knowledge and history if you go by yourself you have to pay for a guide and wait while the local tour groups go through.

Pretty Spectacular. If you have time to spend in Istanbul, don't miss the opportunity to visit this wonderful palace. Most people tend to go to Topkapi which albeit amazing, I recommend this palace over Topkapi. The grandeur of the place is magnificient and seeing the room where the great Ataturk died is a heartfelt moment. It is a guided 40 minute tour and access to some not all rooms are permitted. It's situated right on the Bosphorus and a great way to enjoy the views of Istanbul and soak in the atmosphere.

"If you did not buy Harem ticket... You will not see Harem...". This attraction is well worth the visit, but manage your expectations in advance.I visited Dolmabahce Palace in early November 2014. In a nutshell, the Palace is worth seeing, but I could have skipped the Harem. The organization and structure of the tours is terrible. However, this does not detract from my recommendation that you visit. I attended alone and not as part of a tour group. If you have your own guide, your experience may differ.The Palace is very beautiful and is located on a prime spot on the river. Unlike many royal palaces, it retains its original contents. The Sultans spared no expense in decorating the palace and the chandeliers and gold work are completely over the top. Unfortunately, no pictures are allowed inside the Palace, but there are great photo opportunities on the Palace grounds.In order to see the Palace and the Harem, you have to buy separate tickets. The Palace is much more impressive so if your time is limited, just see the Palace.To see either attraction, you must join an organized tour. The tours appeared to only be in English or Turkish. When I was there, there appeared to be one each hour for each of the two main attractions (the Palace and the Harem). The tour provides very limited information and the group is very large. The format is more to provide access to the buildings in a supervised manner. Hopefully someday they will allow visits with audioguides and abandon this ineffective approach.On my tour of the Palace, the guide spent more time reminding people that we were not seeing the Harem and that if individuals did not have a Harem ticket, they would not see the Harem. She kept discussing what was in the Harem and then would remind us that if you did not have the Harem ticket, you would not see the Harem. It would have been nice if she used the limited time (the tour lasts 30 minutes) to provide more information about the Palace. Given the tour is only 30 minutes, it is very rushed.However, despite the limitations resulting from the approach taken to the tours, I strongly recommend seeing this attraction just to see the inside of the Palace.Getting to the Palace is easy. You can take a tram from Sultanahmet directly to Kabatas. From Kabatas, just walk along the river and the Palace complex will be on your right along the river. Or you can take the furnicular down from Taksim station. Either trip costs one token (four lira) which can be purchased at the tram stops.If you do make it to the Palace, a short walk will take you into a really nice neighborhood with great cafes and shopping. If you walk to where the W hotel is located (ten minutes from the Palace) and walk up above the hotel, there are a lot of trendy, fashionable shops and restaurants.

Palace of the Sultans. Don't miss this enormous palace in the new town...we easily took the tram from Sultahamet here on our own. The grounds are magnificent with pools, gardens and a wonderful outdoor cafe overlooking the Bosphorus to have lunch after your tour. The opulence of the Sultans' way of life is astounding and worth a look!

Beautiful Palace. Dolmabahce Palace is decorated with gold and crystalis and is really western style of Palace opposite to the other sightseeing in Istanbul. It is very Impressive the world's largest Bohemian crystal chandelier is in the Ceremonial Hall, Baccarat crystal staircase, Gate of the Sultan and Gate to the Bosphorus. Garden with statues and view to the Bosphorus is breathtaking. I suggest to everyone to see this beautiful palace, to relax in it's garden,to take a cup of turkish coffee in it's caffe.

Messy and charming. Its one of the places that I actually visited three times on different occasions and years but I never get tired of it. It is quite over ornamented and the hallways are quite small but there's something really charming in this east-meets east type of palace. I went there every time feeling excited and I would go there again just because it's the type of place that gives me nostalgia of a time I never actually lived.

Worst experience...Ripped off!!!. If you are planning to visit this place better do a favor to yourselves and stay away. It is better to spend your money and your time somewhere else in so many other beautiful places in the city to see.We don't know were to start from? The entrance fee is very expensive according to the things you are going to see. On the entrance no-one informs you and there is no sign to tell you that inside there are tours which are held on specific time they went to held after waiting large ques of visitors and organized by rude staff which barely tell you or inform you about anything also there is no notification that anywhere inside the palace or the surrounding buildings you are not allowed to take even a single picture. Only on the exterior.The staff doesn't care at all for the visitors everywhere. From the entrance till the exit. We feel being ripped off as we bought the ticket which allows you to enter in every region of the palace (40 Lira around 20 euros each) and because of the ques and the bad organization we didn't enter anywhere.Apart from this the building itself is gorgeous and a diamond of architecture near Bosporus with great views but there must be more attention and more organization.Better stay away!!!

FEAST FOR EYES. Be there at 9:00 am sharp! This place makes Versailles cute. My mouth kept getting larger! This impresses over the top! I could not believe the the world"s largest chandelier! Crystal staircase all Bohemian. Take the tram from old town.Get there early Crowds! No FOTOS!

Definitely worth visiting.. Too much history behind as any other place in Istanbul. The view is so beautiful. Theres a great cafe nearby that we sat. The view was breathtaking. Would love to visit again.

Regal. A must see in Istanbul. A guided tour inside the palace is available. I paid 40 Turkish Lira for the complete tour. No photography is allowed inside the palace. The collection of chandeliers, carpets, paintings, porcelain, drapery, crystal is truly a Royal collection. 2-3 hours should be earmarked.

1001 similar room. Huge palace that tries to copy the Western style, however all rooms are almost the same, red or blue chairs and identical chandeliers as if all was done in one factory. The setting is beautiful but the inside is just missing to show the way of life of that time. In The Harem section you rush through a simpler version of endless identical rooms, and wonder if these people were just sitting and talking all day long cause that is all you see - numerous sitting areas with no personality or meaning? If there was any thinking behind they would had arranged at least one living area fully and show us how people lived, what they used etc, where they ate, where their kids lived, their servants etc, or what the kitchen was like. Instead it is just endless sitting rooms. Very boring.

Wonderful place. If you are in Eminonu District in Istanbul and want to go to Dolmabahce Palace, then is easy to take bus no. 70KE to Kurtulus. The 7th bus station is the Dolmabahce Palace. If you are going to stay in Istanbul for few days is better to buy an Istanbulkart for public transportation. It’s really convenient. The adult fee for Palace and Harem is 40TL. For this price you can visit, also, the Art Collection. For the Palace and Harem you have guided tour – not quite helpful if you are part of a large group. The Palace is a masterpiece of art. The exterior and interior decorations are outstanding. Inside the Palace and Harem there are a lot of marvelous pieces of furniture, carpets, rugs, chandeliers. Unfortunately it is not allowed to take pictures inside the Palace. The gardens and the location of the whole complex on Bosphorus banks are impressive. I spent a lot of time here, but with no regrets.
A place you must see when you are in Istanbul. Tells you a lot about the royal family life and culture. The location on bosphorus is great. The crystals decorations are amazing

Good one. The view outside the Palace is more beautiful than the view inside. The palace is just next to the water. You will enjoy to see the stunning views and can take beautiful photos. Photography not allowed inside the palace.Need some time to go around in the palace. You are not allowed to go alone in the palace. Guided tours will be there and they will explain you all the detailed history while escorting you through the palace.

outstanding!!. Visiting Dolmabahce Palace is one of the things that leaves a good taste in your mouth. It is a beautiful place which shows a dazzling display of eclectic but luxury and comfort style with which the sultans lived in the old Ottoman Empire. To highlight, the incredible crystal chandeliers that adorn almost all the main rooms, but even more is the one found in the ceremonial hall, it's a pitty that it stays turned off all the time. The style is a bizarre mix of baroque and Ottoman architecture are but still, it dazzles with all the little details like ceilings decorated with gold leaves.. The view from the Bosphorus door is outstanding. One negative is the guided tour, imposed and included in the entry ticket. The accent of the translators is so strong and the acoustic of the place does not help; the result is a poor speech difficult to understand. Anyway, it's a must if you go to Istanbul.

In the Finest Tradition of European Imperial Grandeur. While Topkapi Palace was the epicentre of the Ottoman Empire, Dolmabahce was their 'last tango in Paris,' the Versailles of Turkey. When it comes to fine European palaces, Dolmabahce is up there with St. Petersburg, Vienna, and Buckingham. It was if the Ottomans were saying to Europe - we are as good as you and though they have been gone for almost a century, the splendour of Dolmabahce is a souvenir of past glory. Worth the effort.
under renovation. under renovation. cant capture the entrance gate of this palace. the fees is a bit expensive to me..

excellent. it's guided tour only, you have to pay 30TL for th Selamlic tour which is the basic palace and totally worth the money. the gardens are beautiful. go early in the morning to avoid the crowd.

Wonderful grand palace. The palace was built in the 1850's on a grand scale. the tours are guided in the palace and in the Harem. The palace is magnificent , with a crystal staircase huge chandeliers lovely views of the Bosporus .the harem is not quite as magnificent but it is interesting to see how they lived. It is possible to se Attaturks room where he died with in the harem building. This was my favorite place in the city. The gardens are not large but there are bird cages , fountains and the Bosporus along one side.

Very fantastic Palace. Don't miss place in Istanbul
Not allow to take a photo in the palace
Beautiful garden with it's fountain
Love this place ^^

Not to be missed. It definitely worths visiting. Although the guided tour may be a little dissapointing (probably it would be best to get an audioguide), the Palace itself is exceptionaly decorated. Its yard is also beautiful and has a nice view of the Bosphorus.
Note: you cannot take pictures inside the Palace.

European Opulence on the Bosphorus. Great stop, must do on Istanbul tour in my opinion. Right on the water, which makes the grounds even more beautiful and strolling around the outside even more relaxing. The gardens and grounds themselves are worth a nice walk, especially around the back (side near the road) where they have a bird house. Arrive early to avoid the line and actually get in as they only allow a certain number of visitors per day. Once the visitor quota is met, no one else is allowed in until the next day. You must go with a tour guide and pics are not permitted but the tour moves quickly (too quickly really) and you're in and out. Very wonderful and opulent decorations, definitely worth the stop.

Dolmabuche palace. Get here early as numbers are limited. This palace is well worth seeing. The best is saved for last. The crystal chandelier is stunning. The scale of this palace is something to see. The grounds are beautifully done. There is a lovely view of the Bosphorous. It is easy to get to on the TV tram with a short walk to the palace.

I love it!. It is a very beautiful european palace which is situated on Bosphorus. You will need at least 3 hours to see it all. Inside you will be leaded by professional guide, is not permitted to go alone. The palace has 2 parts to be visit. Also is a place where lived Ataturk.

Nice historical Palace. Dolmabace is a holy place for Turkish due to the last days of Ataturk and all the things belonged to him. For me remember the quite expensive fee, biggest crystal chandelier, old sultas' harem and nice view on Bosphorus.

How the Sultans Lived. This is most definitely a must see experience it truly rivals any palace in the world for grandeur and stunning exhibits and decor and is a wonderful showcase of the late Ottoman Empire leading into the republican takeover of Turkey and the Ataturk Years, full of wonderful decoration on such a grand scale it takes your breath away make a visit when in Istanbul it wont disappoint.
Another Wow place to visit. This is a very beautiful Palace with one of the biggest chandeliersIn the world.The rooms are beautiful with very fine carpetsYou must have a guide to,tour the Palace

Nice. It's something you have to see if you come to Istanbul.Luxury,very big,full of riches and other stuff.All you need to understand the way of the Sultan's leaving.I totally recommend it even though I would prefer a better Turing Guide.
nice place. Old place, a beautiful garden, in the palace can not take pictures, there is an entrance fee, if you come to Istanbul you must visit this palace

A real treasure. From an historical point of view it's a great place to visit. Not part of museum kart so separate charge. Be warned, gaining entrance is frustrating! Organised tours take precedence and you just have to wait ... ... and wait! We needed an English tour so waited about 40 minutes. The tour parties are large and you can't always hear what they say but there is no other way to visit. The palace is enormous and there are lots of stairs and no lifts. Not suitable for disabled visitors. The best bit is that the palace has been left as it was more or less when Attaturk died. The wealth needed to build and decorate on this scale is hard to appreciate given that they had to take loans to build it. The Harem tour is much less impressive and you do get some time without a guide to view the rooms at the end but it is frustrating that the rope barring access is at the outer door of each room and you have to strain to actually see into the rooms. The chandeliers alone are enormous, stunning and worth seeing. The Sultan's side and the great hall are possibly the most impressive I've ever seen anywhere.

Very nice. This palace is very impreessive, with all the crystal chandeliers and vases from all world. Even the floor have history on it - and design.For me, its a little to over and the sultans got lost on decoration - they tried to do something like western design. But deffenitily deserve a visit.
Amazing place but tours are hard work. Amazingly ornate. Worth a visit, but have to go on guided tour. Tour groups a little too big and some waiting, so not ideal....

Nice and very westernized!. Beautiful palace! Downside is that they don't allow any film or photos and the queues are enormous due that you must go inside with a guide! They must consider making smaller groups since we were so many people with just one guide, that was super difficult to hear him and understand what was he saying. Amazing views from the Bosphorous, though.

Crystal chandelier!!. Wow, this palace was an amazing site; the opulence was what one imagined a sultan would enjoy but it is no wonder the construction broke the bank! Our visit was enhanced by the knowledge of our own tour guide - without a guide, I'm not sure you would get the same appreciation for the palace.

Versailles in Istanbul. This is such a beautiful palace, but they don't make the most of it. There is a star case with crystal balustrades which hadn't been cleaned which was the same of two of the three massive chandeliers. They were pretty spectacular dirty so cleaned would have been amazing. You couldn't just wander around the place at your own pace, every one had to go with a guide which felt rushed. Having said that it is still worth visiting.

Beautiful. This imperial and later on presidential residence is a very beautiful place. Right on the shores of the Bosphorus, it is an amazing palace. Very well preserved. The only fault is the guided tour (the only available one), as it is very short and with very little information. When it comes to the Harem guided tour, it lasts 15-20 minutes and the information is very pragmatic and poor. For my taste I would have liked a little bit of legends of the palace to be presented.

Provides a snapshot of an Ottoman era, but the tours are a bit of a shambles. The palace provides a fascinating contrast to the earlier Ottoman historic sites in Sultanahmet.It is worth a visit. It is a real shame and a frustration that the "organisation" of the visitor's experience is also a contrast. After queuing, a foyer crush and long wait, a mass of people surged after the English speaking guide who raced through the building without waiting for her huge group to arrive at each destination before sharing a brief explanation in a voice that reached few of the group, competing as she was with yelling children and conversations of nonEnglish speakers.I would suggest some of the entry cost could be used for a microphone, or more guides and smaller groups. I read with envy the wonderful things some other reviewers admired. We didn't get time to appreciate these wonders in the 20 minute race through.
Worth the visit. Nice final Sultan palace. Take tour with guide. Only takes about an hour once inside. The palace is in great shape and has many early 20th century furnishings and appliances.

Fascinating. Dolmabahçe palace is western-style palace build in 19th century and decorated with lots of gold and crystal. Most famous are the world`s largest Bohemian crystal chandelier and crystal staircase (it`s actually only partly from crystal). The palace itself is a mixture of styles but what makes it worth a visit is a fact that it has survived intact with its original decorations, furniture, carpets and everything else. Though the formal part of the palace was very grand, I liked the more intimate harem more. Especially the blue and pink halls and sultans two bedrooms – the sultan had separate bedrooms for summer time and for winter time. And all the “guestrooms”, which were actually for harem women, because no guests were allowed to the harem.And since I'm a great admirer of Aivazovsky – the painting museum in the crown prince palace was a great pleasure.Dolmabahçe palace is close to the Kabatas tram station, no more than a 5 minute walk along the Bosphorus. Ticket costs 40 TL. And there are separate lines inside for the formal part of the palace and for the harem. You tour in groups, so you have to wait until it`s time for English-speaking group. We were lucky and our guide spoke very good and loud English.

Gorgeous palace. I got the chance to visit this attraction last summer. This palace is so gorgeous. From the beautiful entrance with the big fountain to the interior of the palace and its priceless furniture and ornaments to the amazing view, this place is breathtaking. The reason I gave this attraction 3 stars, is the poor management. We had to stand in line for more than 30 minutes to get the tickets. In other attractions, they had couple of machines where you can use your credit card and not have to stand in line but not this one. Then after that ordeal of getting our tickets, once w got inside, we had to wait for a guide. You can't tour the palace on your own. Normally, this won't bother me, except that, there was nobody there to organize the process and to make sure that whoever comes first, should go first. Once a guide was available, they open the gate, and people rush inside like a heard of cows. If you are not fit, you can easily lose your turn and get pushed to the back. And once you make it inside, the whole tour was less than 25 minutes!!! Not enough time to absorb all the beauty, wealth and history this place holds between its walls!!

Opulent. Huge. Dolmabache Palace is huge. Constructed with lot of care and an eye for excellence. Fantastic crystal chandeliers and carpets. Looks more like an European palace than one would expect in Turkey. Well, that was the aim of the Sultan when he built this beautiful palace. Even the gates facing the waters are huge and awesome. We did not use a guide, and were better off for it. One really gets to see as to how the Sultans lived in those days. Some of the rooms in the Harem reminded us of the rooms at Versailles Palace, Paris. A must see attraction in Turkey.

Exquisite Lavish Palace. Well, this one is the "cats meow" of Turkish Palaces. The crystal filled rooms, beautiful carpets, art is a must see. We even visited the room where Mustafa Kemal Ataturk died in, everything is original, just as it was when he lived there.

Nice place to learn about Turc history and Ataturk. I think there were more Turc visiting Dommabahce Palace than tourists. It is a soulful place for Turc people and visiting the Palace is a good way to learn about the turc people. The garden outside is pleasent. Inside, there are Turc and English guided tours that takes you everywhere in the palace. This is the place where Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey, spent the last days of his life.

Fantastic building, but the organised tours are too big. The Dolmabahce Palace is truly stunning, especially the Great Ceremonial Hall which is almost of cathedral-like proportions. Clearly no expense was spared in the construction, with enormous chandeliers, a crystal figure-of-eight staircase and a crystal pavillion in the grounds. You are not free to wander through at your own pace, but tours leave ever few minutes. Howver, the organisation of these tours seems chaotic with completely unmanagable numbers of guests being taken briskly around the rooms. In fact, the behaviour of some of the visitors and their children was appalling (one child just walked under the banner and rolled around on an antique bear skin - his parents were engrossed in their own conversation at the time) so it was difficult to hear the guide and must have been disspiriting for him when 80% of the people on the tour weren't paying attention to him.The tour of the harem had equally large group sizes, but was equally interesting, although nothing could compare with the wow factor of the Ceremonial Hall of the main palace. The guide for the harem did a much better job of keeping control of the group and was very clear and knowledgable.There is also a painting museum which showcases the artists brought in by the Sultans to be offical painters. To my eternal shame, I have forgotten the name of a Russian painter whose seascapes were amazing - really capturing the translucence of the water.All in all, it is definitely worth a visit, but they really need to rethink how the tours are conducted.

Impressive and Worth the Visit. The Dolmabache Palace was not more then a 3 minute walk from our hotel, the Grand Hyatt Istanbul on the European side. While we had to defer to tour groups, we did manage to get in fairly easily and pick up an English tour. You cannot take pictures inside the Palace.Although the Dolmabache is not on the scale of Versailles or Catherine's Palace in Tsars’ Village, St. Petersburg, it is very impressive in it's own right. Massive crystal chandeliers, a beautiful crystal grand staircase, detailed flooring, objects from all over the world, the palace is a breathtaking experience and at the end, you do wish you had some pictures that captured the beauty. The furnishings of the palace are all original - which makes it an even more personal experience as you are not seeing replications or interpretations. The grounds are nice and the view of the Bosphorus reminds you where you are - at the confluence of Europe and Asia. And right across the Bosphorus is the old Topkapi Palace, and of course, you need to visit both to really compare and contrast the two. In fact, it is very easy to get the T1 Tram from the Dolmabache over to the Sultanahmet section.Well worth the visit, I hope you go!!

Very good, mainly the main state room. The main state room with the huge chandelier is the party piece, otherwise it is another (very good) European palace with some Islamic touches. You have to have a guide and wear shoe covers, and its quite a walk around.
Great Palace. One of the beaitful Palace of the world you can see here history of ottoman empire and young Turkey's history. Must see place of istanbul

Dont miss it. you will see something unforgettable inside it, build in 1800 and everything in excellent condition, huge rooms and halls, you cant take a photo inside the palace. but you can take some pictures in the palace's garden

Absolutely impressive. So called the "Versailles" of Istanbul is a must see.It cost the equivalent of 35t of gold. If you are not with a group you need to wait for a guide to take you through the palace. The interiors are fascinating: an entire beautiful crystal staircase, lots of chandeliers, marbles,porphyry stones, alabaster, french furniture, the silk carpets , etc. Enjoy "the Muayede" which is the highest and the most magnificent section of Dolmabahce Palace as a large square hall of monumental proportions, over 2.000 square meters of area . It is decorated with a huge 4,5 tons of crystal chandelier. Do not miss the harem!

Excellent. Great place to visit, situated on the Bosphorus river, very well kept. easy to get to with the tram then a 5 minute walk. you can not enter without a tour guide at the site. make sure you have an english speaker to guide you.

Great palace but poorly run. It is worth going here as it is magnificent - more Versailles than Istanbul and nothing like the classic sights in Sultanahmet. It is easy to reach - just take the tram to the last stop Kabatas and walk for about 5 minutes. The issue we had was the tour. It is a guided tour round - you cannot go round on your own and it is only done in English or Turkish. Consequently there are very large numbers on the English tour - most of whom don't have English as a first language so they chatter amongst themselves. The guide we had spoke in very accented English and just reeled of facts in a rote fashion but all the chatter around us made it impossible to hear most of what he said. The groups really need to be smaller or they would be better letting people go round on their own with an audio guide. There is also a rule of no photos etc but this was blatantly ignored by some people and the guide did nothing about it. The Harem section afterwards was better - you have to pay separately to go into this bit so the group was smaller but the guide was better too so we could at least hear some of what was said. It is worth the visit but it would be better if they could look at how the tours are run
excellent. I enjoyed this travel very much. the city is hot, and historical. Everyone I met is kind and friendly, not like the movie Taken II make me feel uncertain.

This is lovely. This wonderful palace set on the shores of the Bosphorus river is really well presented. It was beautiful. The English guided tour was very good. I enjoyed this much more than the Topaki Palace. I had a wonderful lunch in the café on premises.
A Journey in History. The palace is wonderful. It is worh traveling and your money you have paid. You lose the track of time there.

Very expensive. We visited in early October and although we enjoyed the main palace we felt ripped off as they charge 40 tl for the full tour and they had about 60-70 people on our tour so it was all pushing and shoving as it appears that people in Turkey have to be at the frontor they will die, the outcome being we could hardly hear a word spoken by the guide. The numbers should be limited to 20 people per guide.Also many areas were under renovation and the clock museum was closed. I recommend going with a pre arranged tour as they appeared to be smaller in size.
Great. Liked : Great palace and so beautiful view.wonderful garden.Disliked : you must stay a lot of time in Queues.

The Best of Istanbul Palace. Nice Architectural, different from Topkapi Palace. The first European architectural palace.Every detail was perfect from the crystal stair balustrade to the painting of ceiling and the door handles, we enjoyed the place.

Really worth seeing. Beautiful palace with full furnishing and nice gardens right on the Boshporus water front.There is structured tour through the palace as part of the entry price. This is a walk through with a leader, in practice is it hard to hear the commentary however it does go through many rooms and at a slow enough pace to see.You can not take photos, and they are pretty strict about that - not sure why.Despite the minor drawbacks it is still one of the top sites in Istanbul.

Dolmabahce Palace ... Easy to get there by tram from the Sultanahmet District. Stunning! Opulence on the order of Buckingham Palace in London, Versailles in Paris, Schonbrunn in Vienna. Home of the last six Sultans and Kemal Ataturk. Easy to reach this European-style palace from the Sultanahmet District. Take the T1 Tram in the direction of Kabatas, to the end of the line (Kabatas Stop). Walk 5-10 minutes beyond the tram stop following the shoreline of the Bosphorus until you come to the gates of the palace. The English tour lasts about 45 minutes and includes both the Sultan's Ceremonial Halls, as well as the Harem, the private rooms of the Sultan and his household. Efficient and informative.

Dolmabahce Palace: Fabulous:Must Visit. Dolmabahce Palace preserved in it's entirety. Tickets to palace & harem sections, guided tours to both. Absolutely stunning with it's Victorian crystal chandeliers, huge official banquet rooms, large hand woven carpets, crystal ballistrades. Harem section also still on display with it's beautiful contents, each room decorated in different styles. Queen mum's quarters next to sultan's , matriarchal society! Sprawling palace buildings looking onto Bosphorus, fab view. Intricate fine architectural work on outside of the palace buildings, clock tower etc. Must see as the palace is on show as is with everything still intact. Well maintained, some renovations in progress but does not interfere with main tours.Well manicured & maintained gardens, clean. All of istanbul is very clean.

Top 3 places to visit in Istanbul!. Its a MUST!Visit the Harem and the Ceremonial hall (has a 9 TON Chandelier). You cannot enter the parace by yourself, there are strictly guided tours at certain hours, so I recommend you get there early so you dont have to make a big line.

Stunning grandeur. Definitely include on the list of must-see's when in Istanbul.The entrance pathway leads up to a fancy fountain and garden walkways with lion sculptures. On either side of the palace are the grandest gates (one of which opens to the bosphorus).The interior is unlike anything ever seen before, lavish with giant chandeliers, gold leaf ceilings and an air of grandeur everywhere.

Glamorous!!. This palace needs visiting if you are in Istanbul. You pay 40 Turkish Lira and you get to see the Palace and the Harem section inside it but be advised to go early as it closes around 4.00pm so if you want to see both areas the Palace and the Harem section get there by 2.00pm the latest! You can only go as a group tour here with an English speaking guide who explains the whole history, no worries if you are a solo traveller, just join a group it consists of around 30 people. The palace itself is very impressive and is very different to Topkapi Palace (where all the previous Sultans lived - only the last 6 Sultans lived here before the Ottoman Empire collapsed). It is a very beautiful building and the outside gardens are impressive too and right by the sea - however I still preferred Topkapi Palace as there was something about that which was true Ottoman style whereas this palace is more newly built and its style is less Ottoman and more Western, maybe a sign that the Empire was in decline now and had lost its once amazing legacy. Anyway, still definitely worth a visit.

Glamorous and breathtaking. When you visit Dolmabahce Palace you cannot go by yourself - when you pay the entrance fee a guided tour is included. There are two tours lasting around 45 minutes. Seeing this palace was breathtaking - so much glamor gathered in one and same place. Also the outdoor areas of the palace is worth a visit. The park with a lake, statues and flowers by the Bosphorous Strait is beautiful. Don´t miss this one when you are in Istanbul. If you take the tram going north to Kabatas it is only a short walk from there. The distance from Golden Horn is walkable if it is not too hot. The palace is not too far away from Galata Tower if you want to include both attractions into the same day.

Beautiful , must visit. This palace should be in your must visit list in your trip to istanbul. You will just go wow , looking at the magnificence of the furniture and the whole maintenance of this palace .I just loved it .Its beautiful

Go for the "ceremonial hall", absolutely breathtaking. This palace may look like just a very large old architecture building from the outside, the inside is definitely lavish. Comparing it to similar era palaces such as Versailles, in some ways this palace is even more breathtaking. Each room has its own unique decor signifying the lavish lifestyles of the sultans. The chandeliers and gold plated ceilings are a special attraction. However, no matter what you say about the jaw dropping furniture and rich tapestry and Turkish rugs and rooms bigger than your apartment, the best part of the palace is the ceremonial hall. I can't compare this to anything else I have seen. It is absolutely amazing. You can sit here for hours admiring each detail.

An attraction you should not miss it. One of the must seen attraction in Istanbul, it is a very classic hence a relatively modern attraction if you are comparing with attractionfrom 17th & 18th century. The pa lace is located near to Kabatas station, if you are staying at Sultanahmet district, the best way to go there is by tramvay which would take 20-25 min and if you are staying in Taksim area you can go by the Funicular underground.Be aware that the palace is closed on Monday & Thursday and the visiting hour is 9 to 4 PM however if the number of visitors exceeded a quota (3,000), they may close the ticket office, so try to visit as early as possible, the queue at the ticket office is a challenge, you may stand for 1 hour, there is an option to buy ticket online which I did not know till I was standing in the queue :(, you may need to check the official website for that, the ticket is either 30 TL for the Selamlik palace or 20 TL for Hareem or 40 TL for all palaces, the tour is divided to 3 part, the main palace which is the first place you see, after wearing the overshoes, you have to wait to the tour guided group, every 15 min there is a group and it swaps between a turkish speaking or english speaking guide, the second is Hareem Palace, the third is paintings museum.The overall is excellent, it is a great experiece which you can notice the mix of luxury of the ottomans with the orient touch of western style.

Wow!. This palace is breathtaking... It's at least as impressive as the Versailles and Peterhof palaces. Its dramatically over the top and beautiful and amazing to see what people could achieve. Definitely worth a visit...!

Be prepared to be dazzled by opulence. Wow, one of the most dazzling places I've visited. Considering most of the furniture and fixings have been maintained from the turn of the century, I was amazed. Guided tours (free) are mandatory and you are not allowed to roam around on your own. The first tour takes you through the highlights of the palace. Two other tours take you through the Family's apartment and another section focused on paintings (unfortunately we didn't have time for these two).

Gorgeous, but couldn't hear guide.. Very pretty palace! Pure decadence, but they only allow guided tours through the palace. Because of the size of the group, I couldn't hear the guide. Kind of disappointing, but great views.

Really nice palace!. I really enjoyed seeing this palace. There was a free guiding tour so I've learned something about palace. It's not that old and a lot was renovated so I think it lost it's beauty a bit but It's still worth seeing.
Price for everything was 40 liras

Impressive. Very nice place to visit, palace of the ottomans sultans. It is placed near the sea, literarily; you can step into the sea through one of its gates (don't do it though :)The architecture is impressive, very tall and very large rooms and hallways, lots of gold and crystals. The guide giving us the tour in English was very relaxed and funny, making sure everybody understood what he was saying. Garden is very nice as well and the view from the garden through the gates towards the sea is breathtaking.You would definitely want to see this, too bad one cannot take pictures inside the palace

Beautiful palace, situated in a beautiful area!!!. This palace was made in 19th century and was influenced by the french architecture!!!Selemlik is marvellous! It also contains the room that Kemal died!

Grand grand palace. It's a very grand palace which we got to learn about the extravagant Turkish kings and got to see many of the precious collections and great furnishings. No photography allowed inside though.

beautiful palace. I have visited Istanbul about five times till now and every time I go there I should go to the palace , a very well preserved place some times I feel I can hear the echo's of the past and the glorious parties and ceremonies of the ottoman empire. if you go there you can see the bed were Ataturk died and all the clocks shows the exact time when he passed away. I love the garden and the gate that opens on marmara sea.

Real Opulence. I would probably rank this as my second best place to visit in Istanbul. The grounds of the palace a really lovely and you can wander around at your leisure. However the main palace and harem have timed visits and you have to go as part of a tour. This place is definitely worth a visit, particular the reception hall in the palace. Big thumbs up for me.
Amazing!!. This is a not to be missed place to visit. The tours are guided so please allow yourself lots of time.

Crystals galore. Fabulous. But: The tour is too short, photos are not allowed, and it's very hot inside. Everything is desperately in need of a major cleaning, layers of dust over everything. Even so, it's a beautiful palace and worth the admittance.

Beautiful place - well worth a look!. On entering the looming majestic gateway, this palace is something to be seen. With lush green gardens surrounding the palace, the path leads to stunning mass of a building. This sultan's palace is my one key recommendation for Istanbul! Personally prefer it to Topkapi. The queues get a bit long as you wait for the guided tour included in the price on either English or Turkish. Probably recommend going earlier to avoid the queues, perhaps as the attraction opens at 9. One of the more expensive attractions to enter, 40TL for the palace and the Harem, but I think it's pretty good value for money.This palace is a stones throw from Kabatcas tram stop, just past the mosque, a short 5 minute walk away.Go and see it for yourself!

Topkapi's Son. It is a fascinating building, because it shows the Ottomans desperate desire to westernize. It was built to in a wave of modernization and westernizing to try to say it was a western power. It is amazing due to the fact it shows you what the Ottomans thought the west was like. In the end they took it way over the top and made this huge Baroque palace covered with crystal and some of the most amazing chandeliers.The one downside is that it is only guided tours, which are not the best when you want to soak in as much as you can, because they do tend to herd you around quickly to stick to schedule

Contrast to Topkapi palace. Opulent and very western influenced. Sadly you cannot take photos inside - very strict, and you have to go round with a tour guide. Our tour group was about 40 people, so you often couldn't hear what the guide was saying, and he didn't want to take questions until the end, by which time you'd lost the will. Would have been better if they had audioguides and you could go at your own pace

excellent attraction. amazing historic palace, so luxurious ,wonderful rooms and decorations ,definitely a must visit.the tours are not long, but the queues might be a bit too long, nice sea view and nice coffee shops around
one of the top places to visit. great experience in this interesting attraction of Istanbul. well organized tours inside the palace for English and Turkish speakers.

Mind-blowing. The last throw of the Ottomans stating ‘Anything you can do in the West, we can do better’. Cost was not a factor; this is self-indulgence on a massive scale; no wonder the Ottomans died out. Visitors are limited to 3000 a day so you have to go in a party. The visit requires quite a long time queuing so get there early. The visit is rather rushed and whipped along by some women you would not want to tangle with, especially the one in the ballroom the day we were there! Opulence everywhere; grand staircases, carpets galore, furniture, the gardens, the views, etc etc. The ballroom is the highlight (it was for me, anyhow). And the views over the Bosphorus – do linger once the tour is over. No photography allowed inside the palace

Magnificent . Compare to other sites in Istanbul, this one is relatively expensive, but definitely a must see place. Can only be visited with a guided tour, and the queue is long. The interior is stunning, it used so much gold that led to the decline of the Ottoman Empire. Don't miss this place!

Some parts beautiful but...... Visited the Dolmabahce Palace today ....The palace is beautiful but unfortunately they will only show you a small part. We actually arrived there around 9:45, lots of people and they group you into very large groups so it is very hard to hear what the guide is saying. Worth the trip....maybe? Certainly would not be on my top 10 if only in Istanbul for a few days

Breathtaking. This is one of the most beautiful places we visited in Istanbul, Turkey. We never got the chance to enter but watching the place from outside is wonderful. The entrance gates are unreal. You can take a nice boat trip and be able to see it from far away to get all the architectural details.
A must see. I am so glad we came here as it is much better than the Topkapi & Blue Mosque. Definately worth a visit

Sultan's Last Stand. This magnificent palace was built by Abdulmecit I to show the Ottoman Empire was still to be reckoned with. Set in a beautiful setting on the Bosphorus, it could be called the Turkish Versailles. Especially impressive is the Imperial Hall built to seat up to 2500. Don't miss this.

Dolmabahce Palace. This is worth the visit. Get there when it first opens at 9:00 to avoid long lines. Buy your ticket for all palace around 40 TL. Grounds are beautiful but go straight to the official section first and Haram second then take in the other parts of the palace. Tours are in English at certain time slots there is and English line and a Turkish line. Be prepare to put plastic coverings over your shoes which they supply. Plan on about 2-3 hours to see everything. Cafe on site which use to be part of the kitchen. All original furnishings and crystal chandeliers like you have never seen. Along with a glass chair legs, standing floor chandeliers! The ceilings are a must so look up. Guided tours with wonderful information. Only down side no pictures inside! Nice brochure is available as you walk in with great pictures and write up. You will be glad you went!

luxurious and superb *___* but no photos and too fast tour ;(. it's in the top ten of the attractions you should visit in Istanbul. Even if you are obliged to do a guided tour, it is worth visiting this magnificient, pompous, luxiurious palace. Visiting days: every day from 9 to 4 pm. Closed on Mondays and Thursdays. You are not allowed to take photos. What a shame ;(you will be pleasantly surprised by the beauty of the pink hall, the blue hall and above all by the crystal staircase and the grand cerimonial hall. The gardens surrounding the palace have to be mentioned, too. Wonderful! The total amount of the ticket palace + harem (guided tour too) is 40 TL. On the whole, palace tour and harem tour take 1 hour. Too fast I would say ;( ;( A (not guided) tour in the museum on the back of the palace is also included.easy to get: we get the tram at Sultanahmet station (next to our hotel) and get off at Kabatas then 5 min by foot. higly recommended *_____*

Nice change of attraction scenery. Now this was fun to see. I love experiencing palaces rather than museums. Unfortunately only 25% of the palace was open but it still was interesting. We had a private tour guide for the day who told us all about the place. The chandeliers and decor are so intricate and elegant, and the size of the ballroom is amazing. The art work wasn't that old to be admired but was still mesmerizing. And where else can you see a palace that's right on the water?
Intresting. very Interesting if you like to see an old but rich of details royal palace.the only thing I found annoying is that they won't allow you to take pictures

breathe taking!. a must see! I just couldn't get enough of the Palace! We took a private tour (very expensive though as it was not included in our package) but we did not regret. Do not leave Istanbul without visiting the Palace!

beautiful place but awful visit restriction. this is a beautiful palace, the last Ottoman palace and all the Turks love this place because Ataturk spend his last days here. we bought the ticket but we didn't visit inside the palace, just walked around the garden, we had to wait at least 30 minutes to be a part of 40-50 person group to go inside, for Harem the same thing.we just gave up....

Amazing othoman castle. Very intersting castle to visit where you can enjoy the beautiful interior architecture of that period of the othman empire. Amazing chandeliers,many many luxurious rooms and reception to explore..
Really good. My best visit in Istanbul. Very impressive Palads. Unfortenaly you cannot take any pictures inside and must go with a guide. Did not go to the Harem, had to wait 25 min for next guide.

If You're Looking For Something To Do. If you're looking for something to do on the other side of the water away from the main attractions in Istanbul, than I would recommend checking out Dolmabahce Palace. It is straight 10 minute walk from the tram along shaded paved sidewalk and you cannot miss it because of the elaborate gates. The grounds are beautiful and well maintained and it is located right on the water so you get really nice views of the Bosphorus. Since the tours are grouped by language, you may need to waste some time wandering around the grounds. Everyone is required to wear covers over their shoes (they are provided) so just be prepared to walk about with shower caps on your shoes when you enter the palace. The tour itself is okay but it is definitely nice to see how the last extravagant days of the Ottoman Empire were spent. I have to say the chandelier in the reception hall is very impressive. It was a gift from Queen Victoria and is the largest crystal chandelier in the world (or so they say). We went first thing in the morning and the crowds were not too bad. Plus the weather wasn't very hot by then so it was slightly cooler.

Must see attraction. If you're in Istanbul to appreciate historical architecture, this is definitely a site to see. Fascinating mix of classical Ottoman palace building inspired by European taste. Be sure to check out the painting museum in the palace. Lots of unique art from artist from around the world. The paintings of Istanbul will show you life in Istanbul as it was during the Ottoman days.Be sure to check out the mosque adjacent to the palace as well if you go there. Take a look inside. The mosque is beautifully decorated.I personally enjoyed Dolmabahce Palace a lot more than the older Topkapi Palace.

Stunning Ottomen Palace . Absolutely stunning palace. The view was breath taking! Was taken around by the tour guide that fulfilled all information about its history. Excellent architecture. Loved it!
No photography is allowed inside the palace but everyone still got a few sneaky shots in which they turned a blind eye too ;-))

Must be visited. No matter how much you read about this place or anyone told you.. Visiting there is a different experience .. The place has a magical design , breathing moment should be come once you enter the place .. One of the most amazing place in Istanbul

Worth viewing the huge crystal chandelier in the main reception room but .... Well worth viewing the main reception room at the end of the main tour, as this room is incredible and contains the largest crystal chandelier in Turkey. However, the tours which are a requirement could be greatly improved. First, the entrance to the main palace where the tours begin is very disorganized and extremely uncomfortable. Once with your tour, depending on the language you speak, the tour guide at least in our case (English) was not good, as she was extremely difficult to understand and spoke in a very robotic manner that was unclear. Second, they very clearly state that cameras are not permitted; however, at least on our tour, many were sneaking around and taking photos anyway. Finally, the temperatures in the palace during the tour are very uncomfortable, it is also difficult to understand how this beautiful palace and its furnishings can be well preserved without some type of air conditioning. Would recommend a visit to this palace, notwithstanding these issues, including enjoying the gardens and grounds surrounding the buildings.

Looks great. that is all I can say actually :P I couldn't get in because it was closed, maybe they are doing some renovation inside I don't know, but the palace walls are very tall and are go on for a great distance, at the huge gate there were two guards who are dressed in a royal guard way :P and they stand still and don't flinch which was so cool then all of a sudden they start moving in routine and do some cool moves, that was fun to watch but that is how far I went, only from the outside and to the big gate where I saw the guards.I hope my review was of help to you

Wonderful Interior. It is one of the must-visit attractions in Istanbul but when you want to make the visit, make sure to arrive there before they open by 30 mins to avoid the long lines. Guided tours are only available and it is not possible to enter it alone. When you wait in the ticket office line, you will see that there is another line for people who bought the ticket and waiting for the palace official tour guide to come and pick a specific number of people. Therefore let your friend to stand in that line until you buy the tickets. Buy the combined ticket for Selamlik and Harem. The Selamlik tour will take only around 30 min. When you enter the palace, stay close to the tour guide to hear everything.The palace is near to Kabatas tram stop, so it is easily reachable.

Lovely palace, terrible tour.... The Dolmabahce palace was our first stop during our visit to Istanbul and was a huge disappointment. The palace itself is grand and beautiful, has lovely grounds, and is situated right next to the water however the guided tour is a painful experience. You are not allowed to walk through the palace and take it in at your own pace. Instead, you are forced on a guided tour with at least forty other people on it. The tour guide doesn't allow you to spend much time in any part of the palace, which means you don't have time to appreciate the architecture, and the tour guide cannot be heard or starts talking before all the tour participants are even in the same room. I probably wouldn't go again unless I was allowed to go through at my own pace. It's probably better to spend more time at the Topkapi palace, which has so many different parts to it.

Beautiful palace, shame about the guides. This is a magnificent palace. What a shame the guides are extremely poor, hard to hear and understand and apparently quite disinterested. It could have been wonderful with a bit more information instead of the bare essentials which we gleaned ourselves from the information leaflet. If you are visiting, make sure you read as much as you can beforehand to get the best out of it.

Beautiful historic attraction. beautiful attraction in a beautiful city. apart from the fact that you HAVE to do a guided tour and not be allowed to roam and explore this palace on your own, it was worth my time and money.

Magnificent Palace, Poor Tour. The palace is a must-visit attraction on the shore of the Bosphorus. The palace is extravagantly decorated using hundreds of kilograms of Gold and contains the biggest chandelier in Europe in the majestic ceremonial hall.Although the palace is perfect the tour is very poor. You will wait for about 30 minutes to get into the palace as the tour consists of groups of about 50 with one guide whose sound can't be heard properly. In addition make sure to get to the palace very early (9.00 AM) as the queues for tickets are very long which may last for more than 2 hours. The tour is rushed and you will not be allowed more than 45 minutes in the Palace. The harem is nice to be visited as you will know more about the life of the sultans and the deathbed of Ataturk. After finishing the tour make sure to stroll in the gardens at your own pace and get a relaxing tour in the painting gallery which contains great paintings in the previous residence of the princes.Even if the tour may seem terrible but the palace itself is a magnificent place that must be visited for its beautiful architecture and majestic gardens.

A must see. A great place where you will see a wonderful garden with very nice architecture inside and outside. A faschinating luxury in halls, beatiful carpets and huge chandeliers. Dont miss it. located in the Beşiktaş area, easy to go there. enjoy !

What a luxurious Palace!!. we visited this palace in March 2012 .at the entrance there are different types of tickets but i don't know if this system is still on. Anyway, we wanted to see everything. so the tours are always guided by a staff and you're not allowed to take photos or go around on your own. the are different partitions in the palace and it really shows you how those sultans were having such a luxurious lives when you know they lived in different palaces!! this one on its own is a masterpiece !! The chandeliers were magnificent and huge!! many things were painted with gold.. we got to see Ataturk's bed and the room where he passed on. there was that hall where the floor was hand made of 3 different types of wood that were stuffed together and took them many years to finish it as each piece of wood was smaller than the size of of one finger!! and the celebrations hall is fascinating with well painted huge pillars.. while touring the palace i imagined for a while how these people used to live and really felt i'm in a different era.
Don't miss this. This place is "must see". Go and enjoy! Beautiful. Simply beautiful, vivid, nice, with atmosphere that is not possible to forget.

frustrating. It's a huge place, no doubt about it, and on a par with topkapi, which you can spend half a day if not more visiting. And more ornate than topkapi, grander, and still containing furniture. But whoever owns dolmabache seems to want the most money for the last effort. Tour parties are huge, and it is guided only. You whistle round in 40 minutes, at almost a jogging pace, and are lucky to have 3 or 4 brief commentaries. Those at the end of the group miss half the talk because the tour guide fits not wait until everyone assembles before starting. You get the impression that they are trying to get as many people round as quickly as possible. Very very annoying.
Great palace. It's just a great palace with wonderful antiques a great paintings on the walls everything in gold really must be visited

Beautiful palace - Ordinary trip. Very beautiful palace, very different from the rest of buildings and architecture you see in istanbul. very European feel to it. However, the tour itself is quite ordinary, 35-40 mins and feels rushed. the fact that you can only do a guided tour, with these guides is a letdown. I would have liked to spend a lot more time at the palace and walk around.We had a stroller with us and had to lug it up the stairs wasn't pleasant either.

Impressive Palace. The tour of the Dolmahbahce Palace was incredible. It was almost Europeon with its décor. The chandeliers were magnificent. The state rooms where receptions were held took away one's breath. It was really interesting to see the room where Mustafa Ataturk died and the clock showing the time he died.

45 minute que to get tickets. The weather was hot and uncomfortable. Unfortunately, they herded us through in large groups, and we did not hear anything the guide said. He needed a microphone. Huge and beautiful chandeliers, crystal torchieres, and crystal balustrades on staircase (which I have never seen). Beautifully framed pictures and mirrors. Unique window treatments, round, arched ornamentation of top cornices. Otherwise, the palace was rather tired.

Fantastic Historical Attractions. Istanbul is a beautiful and fascinating city. It is full of fantasting historical palaces and museums. The scenery is simply breath taking. Istanbul is one of the most beautiful cities in the world. The people are very courteous and quite helpful. It is a very clean city and the food is outstanding.Dolma Bahce Palace is one of the many main attractions in the city. It is kept in immaculate condition. You see in it the glory of the Ottomans of old and also of modern Turkey.
Historical place. Advising to get a good package with local tour company, as the only language used in Turkey is turkish.

Go early!. The only places you need to line up and buy the tickets and potentially spend some time doing so are the palaces. Make sure you go early, then go to other places later. It's a beautiful palace, unbelievable all the gold they used!
Truly Impressive.. This oppulent palace is truly impressive. It has the most magnificent crystal chandeliers, one weighing upto 16 tons.

nice place,,, long wait!. we waited a looooong time to buy the tickets... and again a loooong wait to be allowed to visit the palace! the guided tour is mandatory. it is helpful surely! but it makes the visit loooooooooong...
dunno if its worth it!

Disappointment This Time Around. We visited Dolmabahce Palace 2 years ago and found this palace beautiful, with the palace guarded by soldiers which was part of the beauty of this palace. Currently there is quite a bit of restoration work going on so all rooms are not opened to the public. All tours whether part of a guided tour or individually must be undertaken in groups. We found the English speaking guides understanding of English a bit hard to understand (Tours only available in Turkish & English). If you are a true historian you may be let down as there was limited commentary on the majority of the tour.

Beautiful first stop in Istanbul. We stopped at this palace on our way up to Bebek and the grounds were very beautiful. We ate at a cafe on the water at the palace that was not very memorable but once we stepped inside the gates of the palace my jaw dropped. My 18 month old son was so excited to see the fountains and to feed the ducks. Very picturesque. We went on the tour of the Harem and it was really beautiful. Next visit we will go on a tour of the main palace once my son is old enough to sit through such a tour. I really really loved our visit to this palace and was completely different from Topkapi Palace. I would definitely recommend visiting both.
No pictures allowed. Stunning palace, a guide will accompany you to the rooms of the palace. I wish they allow visitors to take pictures.
