Amazing Palace but way too crowded and long waiting lines. We went to the dolmabahce palace since it is one of the highlights of Istanbul. There was already a line before the security, then an even bigger line to buy tickets. We got our tickets and had to wait in line to be taken by a guide, which you can choose in Turkish or English. All and all it took more then a hour waiting and unfortunately it drives people crazy. They do everything to get before others and there is a lot!!! of pushing when a guide takes around 50-60 people for a tour. Like they are fighting for $1million or something..... Anyway the palace itself is really cool and worth a visit. Only too bad making photos is not allowed.

Amazing Architecture. This was the best part of the tour organised by Turista. Drive to the palace , the walk around to this amazing interior all were indeed very thrilling . The Library , the section where the Ottaman king met his followers , the most beautiful chandeliers and the banquet hall. all so difficult to replay in the mind .We found a way out by purchasing the Video in English and have replayed it to relive those exciting moments of the sheer beauty of the place !

Impressive palace well worth visiting. A very popular destination so try to get their first thing in the morning. If you go as an individual you enter on the left hand side and wait inside until they run a tour in your language - well not in everyone's but the main visitor languages photography is forbidden but it doesn't seem to stop people doing so, although if you don't use flash it isn't noticeable unless you see the person doing so. The crystal staircase is impressive as is the main hall with I think it was. 4.5 ton chandelier made if Waterford ( Irish) crystal. There is also a large ornament with a message Mustafa Kemal Ataturk had written to the young urging them to beware of the military and be prepared to take action against them. Very apposite for th demonstrations in Taksim Square in 2013 and 2014. The doors are fantastic and the views across the Bosphorus very impressive.

Royalty lifestyle. An absolutely must-see attraction when visiting Istanbul. The crystal chandelier, staircase and furniture are so classy and jaw-dropping. It is easy to use your imagination to get a glimpse into the lifestyle of the royal Ottoman. You can only see the inside of Dolmabahce with a guided tour. Unfortunately this was very rushed, because of all the different tour groups that they have to get through in very limited time (every 30 minutes) to see the interior of this magnificent palace. The guards at the entrance gates looked like statues, holding their swords/guns, not allowed to move or smile, even when tourists posed next to them for photos. The palace building is on the banks of the Bosphorus, therefore also a very beautiful and peaceful setting with all the well-maintained gardens.
Must See. Elegant, amazing , unbelievable can't imagine what you will see super like, must see place take trum from old city , stop in the last station and 5 min's walkyou will arrive

Hmmm. Well i personally like Topkapi palace more, but if you are staying for a week or so then you need to visit i found the ticket a little over priced
After visiting the palace you can take a tour in the Bosphour

Amazing palace. The palace was really amazing
You will see how othmani live and the culture and how much there civilization.
It is really wàaaàaaaaaow. I was impressed by every thing the garden. The furniture and the design.
There was an English translation by museum
Definitely I will go there again

Do not MISS this Palace.. Its a gem!. When in Istanbul, please visit this palace. Its brilliant. One of the best palaces showcasing Ottoman architecture & design. The location of the palace is also amazing as it is on the banks of Bosphosrus. Do take the guided tour which is very informative & well conducted. we were very lucky to have spotted a few peacocks in the campus of the palace which added to our delight.Please note that most of the guided group tours do not cover this attraction. So do keep atleast 2 hours for this awesome attraction.The ticket office closes at 4 pm. So make sure you reach the palace before that.

Amazing. An amazing palace to visit. One of the most glamorous I have visited (and I have visited quite a few).It is interesting for those who know a bit about the history, but also to those who don't because the guides are helpful and informative.The location of the palace is excellent, right on the Bosphorus. After visiting the palace you can have some Turkish tea in the open bar close by.

Don't miss this palace while in Istanbul. Our wonderful guide in Istanbul made sure we didn't miss any of the top must-see sights plus much more. Of all the mosques, palaces, special markets, and fabulous sights, Dolmabahce Palace was our favorite. Over the top with huge Baccarat crystal chandeliers and staircase! Everything was a delight to see.

Worst ever. Bad management. . Touring this palace was one of the worst museum/attraction visits I have ever done. The palace was gorgeous and amazing but the experience was completely ruined by the total lack of control by the staff. They put so little effort into organizing the tours and the pushy and rude visitors just run with it. It was like a cattle call and we were just fighting to even get in. (That's after we paid the extremely expensive fee for just touring the palace only.) After we finally get on our tour, the poor guide could not even do his job because people were running everywhere and taking photos constantly for which we were all repeatedly yelled at for. Workers were frustrated and fed up so they just treated us all like crap even though some of us were just trying to enjoy it and follow the rules. The guide eventually gave up and just finished the tour 20 minutes before it was supposed to be over. I'm so mad we wasted our time and our money.

A Glamorous Palace. The Dolmabache Palace is open from 9am to 4pm. It is closed on Monday and Thursday. The entrance is 40 TL. We went there early by taking a tram from Sultanahmet to Kabatas and then its less than 10 minutes walk . The palace was already crowded when we reached and had to stand in the queue to get the the tickets. Once we entered the inside we had to again stand and put on blue plastic covers on our shoes. A group is made and then a guide takes you inside telling you about the history and the Palace. Our guide gave us good information. Its amazing to see how lavishly the Sultans lived.It is decorated with gold and crystal. The largest crystal chandelier, gifted by Queen Victoria is in the Ceremonial Hall. The palace is huge. We also saw the Harem where the women and the children lived. Kamal Attaturk the supreme leader of the Turks died in one of the rooms here. It was very hot inside but once you finish the whole tour you can enjoy the beautiful garden. The Dolmabache Palace is the most glamorous palaces in the world and the attraction should not be missed.

what a palace . Was just perfect. all the sections were great from the main , the harem and the painting museum. even though the palace guide his English not that perfect other than that it is a must see palace.

Must Visit. Should be higher up the IST list. I wonder why this interesting palace with its guided tour and opulence is so low down the list. Maybe because its away for the tourist district. But i would strongly suggest visiting it. How much you'll enjoy depends upon your guide - thick accents makes comprehension difficult .Photos are banned, but you can fall back a bit in the group and click away...

Opulence in the extreme - awe inspiring!. Amazing enormouse decadent palace heavy with more gold and chandeliers than you would probably have even seen before! 45 minutes in hot sunshine to buy a ticket but well worth it. Peaceful location on shore of Bosphorus and with nice garden with water fountain. You have to be guided by a tour guide and wait for English / Turkish one - at 45 minutes for the official section it is very rushed but enough to be awe inspiring. Stay near the guide at the front to hear! Well worth a visit - if you are very short of time I recommend this above the Blue Mosque and Haggia Sophia - unless of course you want to visit the Blue Mosque for worship! Enjoy.

Amazing. This place is the house of Ataturk (establisher of the Republic of Turkey). Right next to the bosphorus, great view, great things inside.It could be more interesting for locals, and tourists that want to see history. If you are more of having fun around, and spend less time in museums, I would say it's not worth it. If you enjoy visiting museums and seeing history though, it's a must see.

Fantastic place, but could be shown much better. Management & tours very poor. This a really fantastic place and a must-see in Istanbul. However the management and tours are really poor, but you will just have to put up with that as the place itself is excellent. Why don't they get the officials of the Topkapi Palace in to show them how to do it? Or if they really want to do classy, get someone over from Buckingham Palace in London for advice, direction and organisation. We got there at 8:30 (1/2 an hour before opening time). They took our money and then kept us waiting till 10:00 as they let all the organised tours from the hotels and cruise ships in first. When we finally were allowed in the guide didn't speak very good English and definitely didn't know his subject very well. After getting us through the Palace quickly in 30 minutes we then had to wait 45 minutes before a marginally better guide came along to let us into the Harem. Then when we came out (after another 30 minute tour) we wandered into the Museum of Fine Arts (signposted the Painting Museum) which was fantastic and really worth visiting (but the air conditioning was turned off). All in all a fantastic place, but the management shames Istanbul.

Nice but short. It is amazing to see how someone lived in such a palace where 90 kgs of gold were melted to decorate various walls and ceilings.It is a tour to see the Turkish design and taste of decoration.The tour says it is 45 mins for Selimlik. It took me and my wife less than 30 mins. However, the experience deserves the money.The information desk outside said there are no English guides. When we entered we found they offered English speaking guides included in the default ticket price.The guide wait till there are around 30 guys and they start the tour. You need to stand next to the guide to hear.

Wonderful palace let down by poor tour. Short walk from Kabatas ,We arrived at 8.30 to avoid the queues and were 2nd in line.security check quick but then went down hill. Tickets bought but then only organised large tour groups allowed in by the drove and no tours for English or other individuals until 9.30. Not the end of the world by istanbul queue standards but very annoying when you have tried to beat the queues! We were whisked around the palace in 25 mins by a very poor guide who hardly told us anything other than it had the 2nd largest chandelier in the world. He seemed intent on just getting the group(about40 people) through the system. We went up the crystal staircase and had we not asked after we had gone up it he wouldn't have even mentioned it! It was however magnificent and had we just wandered around ourselves and had time to take in the fabulous opulence it would have done it more justice.The harem was a better tour but again no English tours until 10.40! At the end we decided to have a quick look in the art Exhibition which was a great insight into life and culture at the time and we were glad not to have missed it.The grounds are magnificent and the cafe at the entrance a great place to have a refuel at not too great an expense considering the amazing Bosphorous view.

Istanbul's version of "The Line Ride". OK, it wasn't a great situation to begin with; August, hot, and the cruise lines in force. That being said, the line is bad. The worst part is, after standing in line for an hour or so, and paying a pretty solid entry fee, you walk into some very pretty, historic grounds. So, the line is receding a bit in your mind. Until it's time to get into-yes- THE NEXT LINE. This one is even better, cramped, crowded, and-here is where they mention you can only do group tours. And, if you just missed the English or Turkish tour, well, you can just wait for some unspecified amount of time, until the next crowded group makes it's way slowly through the rather hot and stuffy interior.Somehow, my wife and i felt the experience wasn't worth continuing at that point. Oh, and i would avoid the cafe unless it's imperative-like blood sugar, life and death imperative.If you love lines, this one's got it all.

What opulence!. I loved this palace. I got there for opening time at 0900 and didn't have to queue for a ticket and joined the first tour going around the inside. You cannot visit on your own although I took my time at the back and was able to have a good look around. The guide was informative but obviously on a schedule and moved us through quickly. I bought the joint ticket to see the Harem as well, definitely worth doing. The furnishings and decor are amazing. The ticket also included the Painting museum set in another part of the palace and you can walk around in your own time. I'm no art critic but I did like seeing the paintings of various places I've visited in Istanbul. The garden are pretty and there are places to have a rest and a drink. I bought a guide on the way out but if you can get one before it may be worth reading in advance. The whole visit took just over three hours and the queues were very long when I left.

An Istanbul Must-see!!. A beautiful palace located on the shores of the Bosphorous Strait, the Dolmabahce Palace should be visited by everyone who comes to Istanbul! It is a provides a splendid portrait of the Ottoman Empire and its power and wealth. You can see where sultans lived and carried on their daily work. You can also see Atatürk´s bedroom and living quarters. The decoration of the palace alone is reason enough to visit this palace-it´s so detailed and ornate. The gardens outside of the palace are also stunning. Make sure you get to the palace early for your visit, though, since they only allow a certain number of people in each day. I suggest making the Dolmabahce Palace the first thing on your itinerary for this reason and also because you will probably want to stay there for a few hours for the palace tour, the Painting Museum and to walk around the gardens.

My mind was blown!!. Is it hot like an oven?YesIs it crowded?YesIs it worth every second?Hell yesIf you are a person who likes history and art then this is your place!!Don't miss the painting museum, there are over 100 paintings and they are all amazing.Hands down, the best place in all of istanbul!!

spectacular. The reason i only gave 3 stars for the palace, is the tour, it is hurried and very large groups, the guides give a lot of information about the decoration of the palace ( which is pretty spectacular) and not enough about the history, the tour is half and hour, which is not much time and you don't get to see half of the palace, also what you do see is from a distance, no pictures are allowed , the museum pass does not include this tour and it's is quite expensive for admission at around 80 turkish lira for two. However you can continue to enjoy the grounds and gardens, art gallery and clock museum at your own leisure .

A must-see place!. Breathtaking palace, superb location, luxury of the Sultans! Not to miss!If you go on your own, don't worry, they organise groups according to a speaking language, they provide tour guides, excellent job!

One of the most important monuments.. The Turks hold this palace dear due to the fact the Atatürk lived and died here in 1938. The palace is massive, and was built with the sole purpose to show the West that the Ottoman empire was not gone yet, and hence the splendor shown here is rivaled only by the top palaces around the world. Make sure you enlist for the full tour (english provided of course) and that you have hours to kill. The queue can be daunting though, so arrive early, and be mindful cause it's closed 2 days a week. You have to visit this, be you a history geek or not.
Amazing Place. The palace is amazing, the gardens outside the palace are great. The bosphor view is not to be missed.

Very beautiful!. Well this palace was very beautiful and full of items from the old times! Also paintings were fantastic, very bright and colourful! We went there, and the heavy shower started, and so all park in front of the palace was under water! But nevertheless it was very cool) There only 3000 people can be at the same time. So it's better to go there not on the holiday days. This place shows the luxury life of sultan and it's harem.

Beauty and the Beast meets Disney World's lines. We waited for an exorbatant amount of time at this site. The line snaked its way for hundreds of metres, and because of restrictions to visitors, it barely moved. Even once inside, there were lines upon lines. If you have the patience to wait though, you're unlikely to find the kind of decadence you do elsewhere in Istanbul.This palace was built for Ottoman sultans tired of the more Spartan lifestyle of their ancestors. Luckily for us, they sank an excessive amount of money into this palace. Beautiful paintings, goergeous furnitures, and exquisite rugs are features of this fairy tale palace. It's almost like you're waiting for a Disney princess to waltz across the floor.If you're patient, consider seeing this palace. If you can see it from the water, that's also a plus. The only drawback is that it is fairly far from other sites near central Istanbul.

Magnificient. I would say that a visit to Istanbul is incomplete without seeing the Dolmabahce Palace. I wish we were allowed to take some photographs of this magnificent mansion so that we could relive our memories later on. It is just too huge, splendid and mesmerizing, be it the chandeliers, the staircases, the pillars, the carpets, the halls or the rooms allowed for public viewing. I was also impressed by the two guides who were with the combined group of ours and could speak English, Spanish and German to address the queries of tourist from different countries. I would however suggest that instead of booking through a tour operator, as I did, one should make this trip to the palace of ones own.

Exciting and Interesting. This palace is historical with many unique furniture and decorations. It is a must see place. One can learn they way kings used to live in that era. This place is unique in that it shows the architecture of ancient time. The wall decorations and the room arrangement are interesting. In the palace, one can see the harem and its room arrangement and the furniture which are interesting and educational. It has a museum which consists of photographs, paintings, and other historical mementoes. It is worth the time and money. The outside of the building is phenomenal and designed architurally to show the artisans of the old time.

Opulence to an nth degree. This was a government office of the Ottoman Empire . Because they had to deal with basically to two segments of society, namely the Asian and European side, they had to have everything go in twos. There were two things of almost everything. Government dignitaries, if they wished to give some gifts, they always had to give 2 of each kind. A little confusing , but if you have visited other European inspired palaces, then this is twice the grandeur and twice the degree of flamboyance. In my opinion, this place should also be called the Crystal Palace. I won't tell you why to spoil the excitement. Another must see in Istanbul

This Palace re-defines the meaning of extravagance. Built in the nineteenth century as the Sultans replacement for Topkapi Palace, no expense was spared in creating this over the top residence. The admission price includes the service of a guide and the groups are admitted according to linguistics with most of the guides being either Turkish or English speaking. Unfortunately the acoustics of the building are not great and you need to keep very close to your guide if want to hear well. As you progress from room to room the decor and furnishing seems to get more and more elaborate and just when you think it can not get any more so you are led into the grand ceremonial hall which tops the lot and brings lots of gasps of wonder from the crowd. When you at last emerge from the palace with your mind full of images of 4 ton chandeliers and enough gold leaf to sink a battleship you can enjoy a stroll in the grounds and gardens whilst coming back down to earth and contemplating (for most) your own modest lifestyle.

Grand, impressive, beautiful. Worth visiting though it's on the other side of the city close to Kabatas. Grand impressive structure. Just the thought of Ataturk dying there gives you goosebumps. Park outside was colorful and nice to walk through. Though it's not on common sightseeing list for many, I would strongly recommend it.

Luxurious Ottoman Palace. A great way to spend a morningHighlights- Grand staircase- Trio of English crystal chandeliers (one is 4.5 tons)- Ataturk's suite including the bedroom where he died (the clock is set to 9:05 am, his time of death)- Gardens on the Bosphorus - stunning! Make sure to see the swan fountain, main gate and gates to the BosphorusDisappointments- Organized tour - not allowed to self-guide. Tour groups are large (60+) so make sure to stand near the guide if you're interested in hearing the commentary. Tours are only in Turkish and English so sometimes it's difficult to hear the tour guide over people translating for their friends. Also, very long wait for tour to start.- No photography - they say it's to preserve the furnishings but I think it's to move to tours along since they're on a very rigid schedule. Pictures are allowed in all the great palaces (Versailles, mansions in Newport, Windsor Castle) so surprising not allowed at the Dolmabache Palace.- No air conditioning - uncomfortably hot in the palace and the painting museum. I can't imagine the heat and humidity is good for the wood furniture or oil painting. They don't let people take photos to preserve the furniture but they let it sit in humidity?Regardless of the disappointments (which we knew before we arrived), Dolmabache is a must see. Easy to get to - train to Kabatas and a quick 2 minute walk.

Time when you go in!. When we went in late July it was really hot and busy, we on purpose went early to avoid the crowds and queues. There was just one tickets for both areas of the palace for only 30TL, and the tour took 45 mins. There is an English-speaking guide. You have to use the guide and cannot go around on your own. Fine for me. And 45 mins was enough time.It's not problem getting a ticket when you get there early and the sun when queueing outside not that hot. We got in after a wait of c.10-15 minutes on the 09:50 tour. I would recommend for you to go and see it, but it was close to unbearably humid inside (people came out drenched in sweat), and I found the place quite kitsch and not that beautiful. But it is still part of history, it is still very grand, and the grounds are wonderful and the setting on the Bosphurus is magical. Just go early!
Gorgeous!. Must see! We were not lucky enough as the Harem was closed on 30th of July but we enjoyed it very much and ended the visit by spending some time in the Painting Museum.

Never been to a better Palace. This is i can say my favourite museum in Istanbul. So many things under one roof. So precious ornaments, artifacts of history. The palace itself tells how magnificent the Empire was. From the hand weaved carpets to the handicrafts to it's chandeliers, nothing to take your gaze off. I better not write more but you to visit and see.

End of an Empire.... Fin de siècle... so it was; but what an empire and the building and contents reflects the grandeur of the age. OK; there are long queues (frequently) and the whole experience is by guided tour (sadly, but probably necessary because people in large numbers, these days need policing). Dolmabahce Palace was built to impress and it does - in part from chandeliers from the British Empire - a very serious tonnage of crystal! To put a historical perspective on things, Atatürk was essential to make Modern Turkey, though at Dolmabahce one feels (at least this reviewer did) sad at the passing of age of splendour. Dolmabahce keeps its promise.
Wow!. Amazing palace! Must see in Instanbul. Going near end of day to avoid the crazy long que worked well for us.

Not allowed to take photographs and taken through the Palace at speed!. We visited several "must see" places whilst in Istanbul. This one is in a spectacular location beside the Bosphorus, and is truly beautiful. We had already visited a number of places, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya before we went to this Palace and each time we were allowed and indeed encouraged to photograph it (without flash), however here it was totally different. You were not permitted to take any pictures inside the building at all, and I really couldn't understand why. The beautiful Crystal Staircase and numerous Chandaliers would have made memorable pictures but you were only allowed into the Palace with a guide, who despite speaking English, was very difficult to understand. There was also another man (?security) following the large group of people as we progressed through parts of the building. Whilst I think the Palace is worth a visit, compared with other tourist attractions in Istanbul, I think the no photograph rule was too much. It wouldn't have been so bad if I could have purchased post cards but the few that were available were really old and dated, pale and not worth buying.

Lavish Ottoman Palace on the Shore of the Bosphorus!. I've travelled to numerous cities across Europe and the Dolmabahce Palace has to be one of the grandest and most opulent palaces I've ever seen. Its interior is decorated with an incredible amount of gold ornamentation and number of gigantic crystal chandeliers, and it has one of the world's largest collections of baccarat crystal. During your tour of the palace rooms, you will also get to see quaint blue Iznik tiles, beautiful period furniture, and exquisite Ottoman porcelain. Doubtless, the Dolmabahce Palace will appeal to travellers who appreciate timeless beauty.

Amazing Place. We met with our friends to tour this magnificent palace. Most people tend to miss this beautiful landmark away from your better known tourist areas. We had a wonderful tour and got to see where the founder of modern day Turkey spent his final days. It is hard to express the sense of awe you feel when you see the amazing work of European and local artisans.

Must See in Istanbul. While most people have the Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia at the top of their must see list when in Istanbul, I would suggest that you make time to visit this incredible site. It is incredibly beautiful and well preserved. The lines to get in are significantly shorter and you don't feel like you are packed in like a sardine. You should visit the other places I have listed but don't leave Istanbul until you have had an opportunity to see this magnificent piece of their history.
Don't miss this one. Shows the opulence of the Sultans, especially in the later stages of the Ottoman empire. The guided tour is at times a bit rushed or stuck, but the overall tour is well worth it.

Royal richness!. The opulence of Dolmabahce palace surpasses the richness of all palaces I’ve visited so far. Walking through the corridors I felt like a fairy tale character who’s entered a palace and is amused by the display of wealth. From crystal chandeliers, gold gilded wall painting, valuable gifts received from other countries, furniture, upholstery to curtains, everything oozed richness. You can only imagine how the Royals must have lived.Like the above description implies, you can’t have enough but reality is that you have to rush through the visit. It is a compulsion to join the group tour with the guide rushing with the details. They host tours in Turkish and English every 30 mins. If you aren't up to speed and close to the guide you may not catch any information. The complete tour including the Palace and the Harem costs 40TL. The Harem isn't as impressive so you may decide to skip it. Do not forget to visit the clock museum and the crystal room. These don’t have extra fees. The compound has a well maintained garden you can sit in and enjoy the fountains and the Bosphorus.

Waterside Palace. On your guided tour journey you see the insides of the palace used right before the Ottoman Empire ended. Will see the largest crystal chandelier in the world (yes impressive!). If a sunny day out, then it's tempting to spend a sizable amount of time outdoors in the gardens by the sea.
charming. a must visit..unfortunately no photos are allowed inside. there is a guide there to explain abt every part.highly recommended

Great place, poor tour. Dolmabahce Palace is a true treasure. It appears graceful and elegant from the outside, but the interior is simply stunning. From the carpets to the ceilings it is filled with treasures. It is worth a visit.Unfortunately, the only way to see the palace is on on organized tour. The tour guide rushes through the tour, and an official in the back pushes you along so you can't actually soak up the atmosphere of the rooms. We were forced into a mob of about seventy people on our tour. The guide couldn't be easily heard or understood, and she went so quickly that you felt as if it was a race. This is definitely worth a visit. Be sure to check out the art museum that is part of the ticket. This trip would have been a lot more fun, however, if the authorities at the palace could do a better job conducting tours.

absolutely stunning!. this is a must visit in Istanbul... absolutely beautiful...wear comfortable shoes to walk around as there's quite a lot of walking to do..and in peak season , you might have to wait a while in que to get in... but after all the waiting and walking...its worth it all!

Very historical. One of the main attractions in Istanbul you have to visit this palace . It is interesting .they provide guides but you have to go in a big group no privet tours allowed. Don't miss the Hurim part of the palace too.

A spectacular palace without too many tourists.. I chose to visit Dolmabahce based on previous reviews. Having visited the major tourist sites in Istanbul it was nice to travel a bit further out (easy to get to by tram) and visit this decadent palace. From the beauty of the ornate gates, the walk to the palace through the gardens is beautiful. The main staircase and reception rooms full of antique furniture are magnificent. The world's largest Bohemian crystal chandelier is in the Ceremonial Hall has to be seen to be believed! Worth a visit but be aware to closing times and the fact that photography is prohibited inside the palace.

WOW!. This is a palace! Incredible chandelier, carpets, furniture etc. No pictures allowed and you have to take a group tour with a very large group! We were in the English speaking tour but as the guide was explaining things in English others would be translating to their friends/family in their language so that made things very annoying and hard to hear the guide.

place of opulence. so there are 2 guided tours, cost 40 lire for full admission including tours in the palace. positives: really opulent- sense of luxury like no other palace in Turkey- literally tonnages of crystal (stairs banisters, chandeliers)- silk furnishings (true to original design replaced every 30 years)- guides spoke good English- grounds are really good, can see it would be nice for a family day outnot so good; - toured Harem in a really really large group as we look the last tour of the day

An impressive palace, but herded like cattle. The Dolmabahce Palace is an important sight to catch if you want to understand the Ottoman Empire, but it's a difficult place to tour. First off you have to take a group tour, no independent wandering. Tours are scheduled for specific times and you have to wait in line. The tour begins on schedule regardless of how many people are in line....in can be well over a hundred! My suggestions to best manage the visit are: First get there at 9:00 am when it opens and enjoy the grounds while everyone rushes to the first tour. Clock the second and third tour times for Turkish and show up just before tour time, waiting in line doesn't give you any advantages. Why Turkish tour? Because you can't understand the English tour guide anyway, the group is MUCH smaller and you can actually fall back of the group and enjoy the rooms without a crowd of people in front and behind you. I took the palace and harem tours....both interesting. Also, FYI, you aren't allowed to take photos inside, I think it's more to keep the crowd moving. Also look out for the Crystal room museum and clock museum.....interesting and rarely visited by anyone....no tour required too. Worth the visit if you work around the rules.

Impressive building !!. Dolmabahce palace is one of the most beautiful palaces I have ever visited. The modern style combined with the Turkish art makes it unique. It's perfect for a two-day stay in Istanbul !

Ataturks last home. We visited the harem this year and it was done in a French style modelled after Versaille. The gardens where a pleasant area to stroll around. The sultans built it to replace Topkapi as their main residence on the Bosphorous.

Bad management. The palace itself is nice enough, but the way the museum is run really takes the enjoyment out of seeing it. After paying, you are informed that you cannot go in on your own; everyone must go with a guide. This means you will have to wait until the next tour. In our case, the waiting area was full of people so we had to wait outside in the rain. When the tour is ready, you go along with a big group. If you are short, you won't be able to see much at all because of the big crowd around you. The guide spoke English but with a very heavy accent that made it difficult to understand anything at all, especially since we couldn't get close enough to him to hear well. The group was pushed and hurried along past many things that I would have liked to stop and look at, then in other rooms made to wait while the guide spoke inaudibly. You are not allowed to take pictures at all, with the explanation that the flash will ruin the gold. The other museums around Istanbul all say not to take FLASH photography, but here there are employees standing all over to stop anyone from taking any pictures at all. Since we are rushed past many interesting sights and we can't take pictures either, it means that you don't get to see much at all. At the Topkapi Palace none of these seemingly arbitrary restrictions were in place and the whole experience was much more enjoyable. At Dolmabahce, you will only get a passing glance around through the crowd. All in all, unless you really want to see this palace specifically, it is not worth the time spent.

Great place , poor service. the outer environment was superb,the inner section was better than that !!I really enjoyed visiting this palace, the architecture of palace was amazing. but services was not satisfactory at all,they did not let you to walk through palace individually but in group ,a guide lead you through the palace and speak about palace in English as fast as possible !!! no way to understand for people with average knowledge of English . there was no leaflet about palace in different languages . we bought ticket for private residential area but in signs in the palace there were no sign of this area but Harem,I my self belongs to middle east but at that time did not understand what harem means and went through wrong entrance forced to wait 35 minutes for next round from Harem entrance.

Exelent Guided tour in English. Thank to the English guided Selamlık tour representative hansom men, i can not remember his name , he was excellent guide i can say expert guide. It is an amazing palace that you can visit in Istanbul.
Young boys. Dolmabahçe palace is a very beautiful and big palace. It is in Beşiktaş and you can see Bosphorus. Going is so easy and budget is not expensive.
Beautiful palace. Beautiful palace. It worth a visit. Be prepared for the cues and the bad temper of the staff. Even so is interesting to visit not only the offices but also the Harem
"Excellent ". This is a must do in Istanbul, especially to see the upgrade from the Topkapi Palace.Lots of detail and beautiful gardens.We can recommend the full tour.

Interesting but overrated. We decided to take both Selamlik and Harem tours as it was only a 10 TL difference, but it was a waste. Selamlik was fine, a bit fast, but the guide's English was fine, the palace is interesting, a bit too much gold and crystal, but nice. Issue was that the guide seemed in a hurry, we started 10 minutes after the other tour and in the middle of the tour we were all together. Harem tour was a waste, this part has nothing to offer, the guide shared in very bad English poor information in the beggining and few sentences after it, it finished after a lot of bedrooms not in so good shape. It is a nice place to go if you have seen other more interesting places and is ok to pay 40 TL. Otherwise there are nicer and cheaper places to go.

pleasant afternoon out. Visited this on the first afternoon of our break it was rather stunning we were part of a tour .I felt it was quite hurried would have prefered to linger and study what was in front of me the grand reception hall was totally amazing the roof was something else and the chandelier was huge if it wasnt guided touryou could easily spend 2/3 hrs here unfortunately no photography inside

Dolmabahce Palace. Beautiful place a must see, use the metro and embark at Kapatach station. The palace is about 200m walk from Kapatach.Piece of advice while using Taxi's in Istanbul, never hand a big note to driver keep the right cash on hand using small notes of 10 or 20TL. Unfortunately some drivers tend to cheat by switching big notes 50 to 5TL and it's your word against his, you lose.
Stunning. We had a very informative tour of this palace !Very well kept and lots of luxury & oppulence to take in !Woud not like the job of cleaner ! Especially when it comes to chandelier cleaning !

The most breath taking sight in Istanbul. This is a really special and must see attraction in Istanbul because of the wealthy furniture, the artistic walls, the big halls and especially the gardens where you can live in the early centuries.Every single detail is important and the bosphorus view is one and only precious sight to enjoy. You just can't stop wondering how all this is done.

Grand, Modern & Lavish!. Dolmabache Palace, also the last home of Attaturk is a grand but modern palace, Built in 1856, it has a lot of European architecture and interior. Only guided visits are allowed, you enter with other tourists as a group and palace staff give a 40 min to 1 hour tour.The interior is lavish, grand and modern with grand chandeliers, paintings, columns, grand staircase etc. a must see for tourists. :-)

Don't Waste Your Time There. The Palace looks lavish and romantic from the outside with its European architecture and a long extension over the Bosphorus shore. Accessible on foot from both Besiktas (Beshiktash) and Kabatas (Kabatash) and from Taksim Square (10-15 minutes).You are obliged to take either the English guided tour or the Turkish guided tour, but, unfortunately, taking either one is the same, because of the following:a- only 1 guide (a tight woman in her 40's) for around 50 tourist group, b- People near the guide would her, but the rest hear nothing,c- The guide talks in a weak wrongly-spelled self-adopted English that you would not be able to understand unless you get accustomed to her style,d- The guide doesn't care about whether you get the information or not. Just that you should not take photos, this is the real concern for these people. e- She runs through a restricted preassigned path in the palace within 30 minutes which is not enough at all. For all of the above, and for other reasons, spending a 30TL for this attraction is worthless :-( Avoid this touristic place because there are many better things to do all around.

Fantastic buildings and interiors. This building is in a beautiful setting with sumptuous furnishings.As independent travellers we had to join a large group of English speaking visitors and with about 50 people we often couldn't see or hear our guide as there were many other groups around.This really is worth visiting but suggest you join a trip with your own guide who is using an audio system so you can hear what your guide is saying as we feel we really missed out and were rushed around the rooms.

One of the "Must Visits" on your trip to Istanbul. This is a beautiful and magnificent palace. Its one of the attractions that is not included on the Museum card and must pay extra. I believe that for the tour the ticket prices are about 40TL and they only take cash at the ticket booth. Although the price seems a little high compared to some of the other attractions in Istanbul, it is definitely worth the price. A guided tour is included with the price with either an English or Turkish speaking guide. The English speaking guides spoke English reasonably well. One is not allowed to take pictures inside the palace. But if you are part of a big tour group, I saw people snapping pictures here and there when the guides weren't looking. Some of the highlights of the place are the many large and beautiful rooms, chandeliers, the bedroom in which Attaturk died as well as the queens quarters. Also spend some time on th grounds snapping pictures. You can get some scenic pictures by the Bhosphorus.

Opulence at its finest. This is more recent history than most sites in Istanbul, but no less important. I enjoyed this for a second time, but on this second visit, I did not pay to see the Harem section again, as that section was easy to take in on one visit. If you have the time, see all of it your first time. The views of the Bosphorus are amazing. Photos are not allowed inside, but bring your camera for beautiful pictures of the grounds.
very good. entry only with tourist guide as we were told.nice palace .paintings on roof were excellent.some artifact of elephants tusk were magnificent.

Breathtaking Beauty. On our last full day in Turkey, we visited this exquisite palace, which we did not know about before. This palace is absolutely stunning; both the interior and exterior. The interior is lavish and extravagant; absolutely dripping in expensive materials and metals. No photography is allowed, but the good thing is that you are taken on free tours around the palace and the tours are done in different languages, so you go on the one you want. The palace is right by the sea and the view is gorgeous and serene. Alongside the Palace there is also a small Clock Museum and other things that come included in the ticket you buy. This Palace is definitely worth looking at; the experience is unique and so special.

Not to be missed.. We took a Bosphorus tour, then went to the palace.The design is awe inspiring and it is difficult to absorb all of the beautiful attention to detail and historical information that is being presented. It is an attraction we will see again. You do need to go early because they only allow a certain number of visitors each day. Enjoy.

Beautiful building, flawed tour!. This palace, its treasures and the gardens are beautiful as is the location on the bank of the Bosphorus but the tour of the inside leaves a lot to be desired! First you have to wait for the tour which takes place at specific times and then you seem to be ushered with undue haste from room to room. There isn't time to absorb it all at your leisure as happens in other museums! Disappointing!!

Truly Grand Palace.. A truly magnificent palace, depicts the lifestyle of Ottoman Empire. Starting from the entrance the place is sheer luxury with beautiful lawns, fountains and buildings. Private tours are not allowed, however english speaking guide takes you around. We visited the official part of the building. The halls, staircases along with the fitting and fixtures need to be seen to be appreciated. If you have time its a must see.
Unmissable. This palace is really beautiful, I`ve been there in spring. But they have a lot of attractions and the crystals stuff are absolutely amazing.

A great palace ... but the guides were disappointing. A magnificient palace , very well maintained, maybe because the crowds are managed well, but the guided tour was a disappointment.The first guide who took us through the ceremonial hall , spoke good english , was attentive to our questions and seemed interested and knowledgable .But the second guide who took us through the residential part was hardly audible . He must have spoken a total of six sentences and was more interested in chatting with a group of friends. What a waste of time !! I wish they would allow private guides .Even the Acropolis museum in Athens does that and I saw no breach of discipline.There were several groups of school kids that day , as a result of which the toilets were in a bad condition with nobody supervising them. The shops in the museum were expectedly expensive and the umbrellas which we bought (because it started raining )broke down within five minutes of use.I got the impression that the tourists were simply being taken for granted ,

Beautiful grand palace. Opulence comes to mind when entering the grounds of this European style palace that rivals Versailles. You must join the guided tours that are in english or turkish with no photos allowed, but many were ignoring the requests, which was rather frustrating. There's two parts of the palace, the ceremonial hall and crystal staircase were definitely the highlights with a huge amount of skill taken and no expenses spared in creating these masterpieces unlike any other seen around Europe. We didn't pay extra to see the harem as we were pressed for time.

guide spoke too quickly!. Dolmabahce was great to see as it varies in style from Topkapi Palace. The entrance fee includes a guided tour, where the groups are too big and you cannot hear if you are towards the back. The guide spoke very quickly and didn't seem interested in what she was saying as she told us she had already done 5 tours that day. It felt like we were on a conveyer belt. We didn't get to see the Harem as the Palace was too busy and they had closed this area off (no discount was offered). The Palace chandeliers were amazing as were the furniture inside the rooms. Bring a guide book and read before hand if you are going to visit.

A DEFINITE MUST VISIT WHILE IN ISTAMBUL. I found this palace very beautifully kept , leaving all of us in awe.The furniture is all original and beautiful.There are no words that can describe the magnificence of itschandeliers throughout the palace.

A great palace ruined by a lousy guide system!. The Palace is magnificent and should be visited, but you cannot wander around on your own, there is no audio guide in any language, the guided groups are far too big, they only speak English (so sympathy for the other European language speakers on the tour), the Guide's diction/speed was not clever...so you end up hanging around, not being able to hear him/her and not really understanding the history! What a shame
Fabulous. This palace is a must visit..opulence and class..magnificent chandeliers, ornate gold work ceilings and the crystal railing on the staircase..it's very well kept and impressive .

Palace!. it is the main palace founded Ataturk to rule Istanbul after the Tobcapy palace
very elite with many halls

Pluses and minuses. Plus: You can take the tram from the Old Town, so if you are staying near Topkapi or the Blue Mosque its a short 3TL tram ride across the Golden Horn. Get off at the last stop and walk a couple of blocks.Plus: A truly "over the top" palace, including the world's largest chandelier. This is where the Sultans moved in the mid-1800s when they wanted to seem more European and leave the oriental excesses of Topkapi Palace behind.Plus: Contrary to some other opinions here, I would say 40TL for both tours is a reasonable price.Minus: No photography inside. This wouldn't be such a problem except that the available post cards simply do not do justice to the place. Very frustrating.Minus: At least the day we went, no credit cards were accepted at the ticket windows. Check on this in advance or make sure you have cash.Minus: It's worth seeing, but the tours are hasty, as some others have observed, and the groups are large enough that it may be difficult to hear.Plus: If you have time, after the palace you can walk back toward the tram stop and take the funicular up to Taksim and the shopping of Iskitlal Street.Overall, I would say Dolmabahce is a fascinating slice of late Ottoman history to do on your third or fourth day in Istanbul. It doesn't quite compare with the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi, Bosporus Cruise, etc.

Well worth a visit. Arrived at about 10.30. Joined the short queue and was in within 10 minutes. Gardens are very beautiful and lead you to another short queue waiting to go inside for the main palace.Again after 10 minutes we were inside with the English speaking guide(complete with our plastic overshoes) The group was large, perhaps 60 to 80 people, the guide spoke quickly and unless you were close to her it was difficult to hear.information was a little bit lecture like with hardly any interaction . As you are not allowed to wonder round alone or take any photos it does feel a bit rushed, but some of the rooms are truly spectacular and are worth seeing.keeping up with the guide leaves you with the option of following along quickly so you could hear or hanging around at the back and having a longer look. After the main palace you can pay a bit more on admission and going around the harem.only problem with this is that having already been round the very beautiful main palace the more basic harem is a bit of a anti climax, I would suggest going round the harem first,leaving the best until last. Overall a very pleasant experience and well worth visiting.

Structured tours - limited time - Harem section not worth additional fee. The palace is a nice counter to the old town andinternally looks more like a European stately home, however it is built of wood, shaped to look like stone, to keep its weight lighter as it sits on reclaimed land. It is nicely decorated and has some impressive chandeliers as well as an early example of underfloor heating. All visits are escorted and groups follow one another around on the same route - little time to stop and admire any aspects you want to view longer.We joined a separate tour for the harem (household) section - not substantially different from the main palace (as opposed to the Harem section at Topkapi which was a completely different experience). Group in Harem section was far too large for the single guide/escort, if he was sharing any points of interest we did not get them - it was more of a shepherded walk of people.If we were to go again would not bother with the Harem section.

Beautiful!. Versaille watch out! This palace goes hand in hand with any of the most beautiful palaces in France! The lamps are incredible! The work on the floors, everything! You'll feel like walking through a fairy tale!

My one touring mistake in Istanbul. We came across from the Asian side on a ferry and landed close to this palace and decided to have a look. Certainly an impressive spot and amazing opulence but here's the thingTooo expensive. 30tl for a 30 minute oversized tour. Not much time to absorb and no pictures allowed! Though the entire group started clicking away at conclusion in the ball room. Kind of a group protest I figured.With all the amazing things to see in this city I would dump this down low and do only if you have special interests or bags of time!

Worst tourist experience in Istanbul - really don't bother!. Worst tourist experience in Istanbul. Rudest tourguide I've come across - find another day job PLEASE! She seem to enjoy shouting at people if they so much touched their cameras. They led you to believe you can take some photos but when you get to the entrance you get herded like cattle inside. The woman absolutely screamed at this poor guy who couldn't speak English and said "what you don't know any common language!" Inside was quite run down in parts and under renovation - really don't need to be shown an old toilet either. All in all a waste a frustrating way to spend 2 hours. Honestly unless you enjoy being herded round by a rude tour guide and enjoy ostentatious Baroque decor don't bother!

Could be Better.... This is a lovely palace next to the bay in Istanbul. The palace is unique and the architecture its divine but its a protected place that is only allow to enter with a tour guide and photography is not allow within the palace (hate this kind of tours).The tour inside depends a lot in your tour guide so it could be a memorable one or a bust. For me and specially for my wife, the pictures are a must so the fact that the were not allow already put us on a bad mood. The place inside its magnificent and the gardens are well maintain. It worth a visit but you need to take a lot of patience with you.

Wonderful Palace!. Wonderful place, but the guide from palace was very rude! He was nit interested in explain internal rooms, seemed bored and fed up with us. Would be much better if the tour were by myself (got a english tour on 18th, june, at 10:15 am).

What a palace.... Despite i have seen alot of palaces before this one was an exception,wonderful antiques here and there...there stairs is amazing..,wished i could take photos for it.The tour is guided,takes approximately 30 minutes,the best is at the end,you will understand when you go there.You must go there,gardens outside palace is beautiful,with a water fountain,ducks and wonderful colored flowers....great view on the Bosphorus sea...

Wow!. I visited this wondering palace May 2014. The entrance fee is a lot more expensive than the mosques or museums in the Sultanahmet district, but worth your money. You can add the Harem section for reduced combined price of 40 TL (which I highly recommend). Be sure to allow 2 to 3 hours to finish both tours (both the palace and the harem have tours inside) and to walk in the gardens and the Clock museum. In the palace, all the formal areas are very beautiful and wait till you see the Ceremonial Hall - WOW! Note: to get to this palace, just take the T1 tram till the end - Kabatas. From there, take a 5-10 minute leisurely walk. Remember, in both tours there is a separate line for English, so be sure you are in the right line so you don't waste your time.

If your pushed for time dont waste your time. Sorry but this was a waste of time. We waited for 30 minutes for a English speaking tour. You can not go through yourself. You are not allowed video or photos. Our tour guides English was not very good. There was 50 people in the group, you could not hear what was being said.

Must visit!. I liked visiting this palace better than Topkapi Palace which is more like a museum than a palace now. This palace conveys the feeling how it was like to live in this place when Sultans ruled. There are a lot of people visiting so it was good we got our museum passes at Archaeological Museum. It was fun imaging how people felt like to visit Sultans in this gorgeous place. Must visit if you are in Istanbul.

Enchanting. Having visited in winter, we did not have to wait much for our tickets. It was not too crowded and the tour guides were great. The major downfall is that photos are not allowed. But very enchanting nonetheless.

Never on Sunday. Sunday morning crowds and inefficient organization are not a good combination. We had to stand in line while a mysterious logistic took place and then it was our turn to enter the main palace . We were not allowed to visit alone and our group could have been split in four . We couldn't understand the guide even if we could hear him but the palace was beautiful and grandiose . Too grandiose ! The mirrors and chandeliers got to be overwhelming along with the various furniture so pieces from different epoques and different origins . We could enter the royal hamams which looked intriguing from afar and devoid of glitter . The other pavilions were more interesting . The art pavilion has a beautiful collection of orientalist paintings and the clock pavilion was fascinating. The gardens were ample along the shore of the Bosphorous ,with beautiful fountains . Taking pictures was difficult , trying to avoid having renovation tarps and tourists in your frame .

A beautiful and unique palace with amazing garden of roses.... The entrace of the palace is big and the architecture is very nice, and impressive....Before to enter the palace, there is a fountain with swans statue, and around the fountain there are a lot of roses, which are very scented....The rooms from the palace are very nice, and the furniture is from different places of the world...Also the palace has the second biggest in the world crystal chandelier, made in England...After main building, there is a separate building where is harem, which is more feminine...So this is a must see place in Istanbul...

Amazing architecture. This palace is definitely worth a visit after visiting the sites in Old City (Topkapi, Blue mosque etc) since it really helps you to appreciate how the architecture was changing with time and how the Ottomons were trying to appear more 'european' with the palace interior. It was a big change to their previous palace architecture in Topkapi.

Fabulous Palace!. A fabulous palace and beautiful interiors. One of the most fabulous interiors I have ever seen! Talk about shock and awe and out to impress!! Over the top and a must see while in Istanbul. The downside is the tour was supposed to be 45 minutes but took about 20 minutes. The group was too big and the tour guide paid no attention to whether the group was all there, if they could hear her or get close enough to see what she was talking about. A cursory tour and very poor! So wanted to see more of this beautiful place but you were marched around at speed unable to take in all the grandeur and amazing objects. So many unanswered questions and missed opportunities to discover more about the palace and the Sultans. Tours were mandatory and you could not wander around independently or take photographs.

You are not allowed to walk around on your own, you have to join a tour.. I bought a ticket for both the palace and the harem. After waiting in line for 20 minutes they let a group of 50+ people in. Unfortunately you are not allowed to see the place on your own. You have to join a (huge) group with a guide talking about a bunch of boring, useless stuff about the place. If you, like me, want to check out the palace on your own, then don't bother. If you like to be forced to do a boring history lesson in a group of 50+ noisy people then you will have fun. The tour was supposed to be 45 minutes, I left after 5 minutes, and also skipped the guided harem tour altogether. You are not allowed to take pictures either.

Beautiful palace but the tour was a bit naff.... A really beautiful palace with some amazing chandeliers and interesting artifacts and symmetry. An interior designers haven. It was interesting, albeit a little creepy, to learn about the harems. I found the mandatory tour a little crowded and irritating as people were quite inconsiderate to the tour guides and spoke during their descriptions, took photos after several instructions that it was forbidden inside the palace. I am glad that I have been but would not return.

As the Gentleman Said.... A dear friend and world traveler told my wife and me about visiting the Dolmabahce Palace and I added to my list of things to do in Istanbul. Well, as the gentleman said, it was an interesting and enjoyable site to visit. We were fortunate in having perfect weather, a great guide, and a small tour group. But it was the palace itself that was both beautiful and interesting. I think it is important to have seen the Topkapi Palace Museum first (so that the historical context for this "new" palace is clear), but seeing both of them really is interesting and each is very "special." For those who have visited Versailles and Schönbrunn Palace etc., the Dolmabahce Palace is "different" and worth a visit even if one has become jaded at seeing pretty palaces!

A fabulous palace - definitely visit!. We hadn't heard much about this palace - possibly because it is a little out of the historical centre - but it is a must see. Take the tram to Kabatas and stroll up. It's 40TL for a combined ticket for the palace and the harem, which I would recommend. The grounds are lovely to stroll around, with fabulous flowers and overlooking the water. Yes, the tour is rushed but it's still more than worth it to experience the fabulous rooms and decor, and our guide did provide some interesting information. The decor and the scale of the palace is breath-taking, and very different from the other sights in Istanbul.

Endure the extravaganza to find a beautiful room in the end. This french styled palace is heavily decorated with layers and more layers of artworks and architectural structures of dubious taste as result of a desperate last display of wealth from the extinct sultanate. After a couple of rooms you feel like you are seeing the same thing over and over again. And then, when you are second guessing why you decided to take this tour, you reach the throne's hall and everything makes sense. The throne itself is not remarkable, but the hall sure is.

Magnificent palace - rushed tour. It is really easy to get to Dolmabahce palace, just take T1 tram to last station Kabatas, and just stroll along the coast for 6-7 minutes.If you want to avoid long queues you should arrive there early in the morning, around 9am.Ticket price for Dolmabahce palace is 30TL,for Harem 20TL, and you can combine both of them for 40TL.At front entrance , there are 2 different queue , one of the left is formed from tourist with their own tourist guide, and the queue on the right is for individual visitors.You will wait up to 30 minutes to get into dolmabahce, and then you will start your tour with their guide in English.Our tour consisted of about 40-50 people, who chattered loudly throughout, which was a problem, because tour guide didn't use mic, so we couldn't understand lot of things she was saying.Guide rushed us through each area so we had no chance to look at the paintings, the carpets, the artifacts :(Overall, it's magnificent palace ,poorly run , but it's worth to visit.

The FIRST thing you NEED TO SEE in Istanbul. The Palace is just amazing. The decorations,the location, the history, everything.You pay a bit more to get in (40 lira for full access) but it is worth it. In price you don't only have access to the Palace and Harem, but also a guided tour in English or Turkish. The guides are also very nice and open to answer you any question.Also, plan a little time to just walk around, relax and take awesome picture.

Little dissappointed. We arrived early, 9am. Outside the palace looked fab and the gardens were lovely. We joined a fairly short queue (about 20 people) which we thought was good. However after 30 mins we hadnt moved, but 2 very large groups had been let in already. People were starting to get a little annoyed. We were then allowed in after popping on our funny blue CSI shoes. In we went to be told we couldnt explore that we had to go on a guide tour which would take about 45 mins. By this time our group was about 50 people, the tour guide did not use a mircophone and did not speak very loudly, she did not let people catch up or gather round or give them a chance to look at things as we were moving (quite rapidly) through the Palace, alot of people including ourselves were grumbling about how the group was too large and we couldnt hear what she was saying and she was not allowing people to join the group before starting her talk about the next part. It ended up that we were inside for about 30 mins. Barely seeing anything. There was a lot of people complaining. We were then told the Harem tour was later. Again the same thing happened. Considering it was expensive to get in at 40tl each (there was 5 of us) I felt our money could have been spent better elsewhere, we paid 40tl each for a 30 minute rush around tour that no-one could hear.

que & que. organised chaos !! take a pre-arranged tour the only way to avoid queing for ages. Beautiful palace well worth the visit to see the splendor ans grandeur. Ask your guide questions as they are very knowledgeable ..

Stunning palace, but rushed tour. We visited Dolmabahce Palace last week and after taking in much of the Ottoman Empire's architecture, it was such a beautiful change to see something so stunning. It's definitely worth the trip and super easy to get to (Take the tram to Kabatas and walk 5 minutes).My only complaint was the mandatory group tours they take you on to go through the palace. Our first tour through the actual palace was good, and our guide was knowledgeable and attentive to the group; however our second tour through the Harem was so rushed and the tour guide behaved as if we were inconveniencing him by being there. We were part of the last tour for the day and the guide rushed us through each area, giving the information when only 5-10 people were in earshot (the rest of the 40-50 people were still trying to catch up). He asked people to be quite when they were walking and kept asking children who were walking ahead of their parents where their mums were, as if they had no supervision.It's definitely worth seeing the Palace, I recommend staying at the front of the tour so you can hear all of the information from the guides (since some won't wait for you).

astonishing!. We really enjoyed this palace. I would recommend going first thing in the morning because it gets very crowded. The palace is beautifully decorated and walking through I was in awe with the incredible detail of the palace. What an amazing place. I would go back a second time for sure!

Worth a trip over the Galata bridge to see!. My favourite attraction in istanbul. Worth going over to. Easily accessible from tram stop kabatas and a 2 minute walk down. We went first thing which was a good job as I imagine any later queues could get long and they don't rush about anything! Inside was beautiful. A guided tour was given, luckily we were atthe front of the group so could hearwhat the guide was saying. The tours are in large groups (maybe 40 people) A good place to visit before going over to the prince's island for lunch and a relaxing/lazy afternoon. (Ferry very near)

Gorgeous Building and Grounds. I do not know why this place falls to 31 on tripadvisor's list of attractions in Istanbul, it is a 'must see'. It is a very opulent place to see. If you are using public transportation, this place is a very short walk from Kabatas T1 tram station or If your already in the Taksim area there is the F1 Funiculer ("Tunel" is what the signs say) that runs underground and down to Kabatas. When I measured the distance on Google Maps, I thought it was much further, but the entrance to the palace is to the far side toward Kabatas station so it was a short walk. Because the tours inside are given in groups, you do have to wait for them to call your language: i.e. English... but I do not think I waited for more than 15 minutes total. In between the administrative tour and the harem tour there is a coffee shop/cafe that has nice sweets, cappuccino, turkish coffee, bottled water etc.

The best of the tourist attractions in Istanbul. I found this to be the best attraction as it was full of all relevant ornaments and furniture unlike the Topkapi palace, it was also the best ornate attraction which showed off the opulence of the sultans. Both the main Palace and Harem were escorted tours ( no option) which to be fair worked well and kept the queues down to a minimum and the guide gave some excellent information as you were going around explaining all the various rooms etc. There is a strict no photographs (camera) Video and or use of mobile phones during both tours of the palace and the harem which was unfortunately not acknowledged by one German woman, a Jewish man and I'm ashamed to say two rude British men! And unfortunately they where exactly the same during both Palace and Harem tours.The gardens where also very nice and well kept and we spent a good couple of hours in there overall.Entry for Palace and Harem was 40 lira per person between £11-12

A magnificent Palace!. A must see point in Istanbul where one can experience this spectacular palace. Words are not enough to describe! no cameras are allowed. All the clocks in the palace are have been stopped at 9:05 am as the founder of Turkey Ataturk died at that hour…

Trip 2014 turkey tour. Huge palace with beautiful chandeliers inside. Shows you the extravagance of the Sultans who lived then. Haram was great to c. Shows you the interior of how the kings lived with their families and many wives. Line is a bit long for the kids to enter that i disliked. Lovely place the palace is situated right alongside the bosphorous sea. I will visit the palace again.

the best in Istanbul. I enjoyed the tour to this palace more than anything else in istanbul. though this is a fairly new structure but its magnificent. Do look out at the time on all the clocks inside the palace. ask your guide the reason for it and you will be surprised.
A Visual Treat!. The palace is a breathtaking ornate wonderland that gives you a good insight into the life and mindset of the last sultan. Visually stimulating - can't wait to go back.

Over The Top 19th century European Palace. The Sick Man of Europe was trying to show he (the Ottoman Empire -- or the Sultan thereof) was not sick so BORROWED vast sums to build what is without a doubt one of the most over-the-top European (i.e. NOT Ottoman!) structures in the world and the moved there from the beautiful Topkapi Palace. Worth a visit, I suppose, to get an idea of how much bad taste money can buy but it should be way down the list of the top things to see in Istanbul.

Mixed feeling. This is the Versailles of Istanbul, a breathtakingly opulent palace in magnificent gardens, so how come it can't crack the top 30 attractions in Istanbul?Could it be that tourists who pay a sizeable entrance fee don't like to be herded through in groups of 50 by a barking guide who clearly wants to rush you through as quickly as possible, 25 minutes go to goodbye in our case. Could it be that tourists prefer to take their own photos and not be ordered to keep cameras in pockets in a bid to be pressured to buy overpriced picture books or DVDs of the splendours of the place.In short, amazing building, particularly the crystal staircase and ceremonial hall, but a lousy tourist experience for the money.

Grand imperial palace, gardens, and views. Like most historical and touristic places in Istanbul, it is crowdy and you should wait in long lines, even holding umbrellas and standing in the rain, but, in my opinion, it is worth it... Before you start your tour inside, they give you plastic bags to cover your shoes... You're not allowed to take photos inside (what a pity); The tour guide we had was very informative and funny; replying to all our questions... Everything about the interior and exterior of the palace is amazing (the Crystal Staircase, the chandeliers, the wide halls, the carpets, the hareem area, the fountain, the gardens....).

Magnificent palace home of the last Sultan. Fabulous palace in a magnificent setting. Gardens wonderful too. The interior was stunning, so opulent, reminded me of the Russian palaces.A city full of wonderful mosques and palaces etc. but this being a nod to European palaces like Versailles, is a contrast to the older edifices of the city.They give you plastic overshoes to wear which is very sensible.

Sultan latest Palace. what makes it different is that its relatively not so old so you observe the 20th century palatial life and objects. Beautiful place ,nice grounds and gardens on the Bosphorus for a enjoyable half day visit.

Magnificent Awe. This is one of the most beautiful palaces in the world! The architecture amazing! The crystal staircase, piano and lights are unbelievable! Every room was incredible, our most favourite was the ceremonial hall. Oh to be a guest here back in the day.

Location is cool . I liked it. And it is big. But the other palace and some of the other sites are more worthy of the time. This is something to do if you are there for weeks and can cover everything else and have some time left.

Beautiful location, crowded. You will need to queue to get in and once in you will need to queue again to get in as you are let in in groups to preserve the building. Worth the visit if you want to see something that is a bit faded and not national trust ified. Recommend you get there mid morning and buy a joint ticket. Then see the harem first and the palace after lunch when the queues go down a bit. Bet cafe is round the back of the harem. Bet toilets are at the front of the palace. Great photo opportunities across the bhospherous. Arrive by ferry for best photos of the building.
Wow. Amazingly beautiful. There are two lines--one for people arriving with a guide, and a much longer one to be assigned one of the palace guide. The interior is baroque and stunningly luxurious.

Beautiful gardens with a view overlooking the water. Yes, there are long lines. Yes, you can only take a guided tour and you can't take pictures inside. However, if you're in Istanbul, you really should visit this palace. The lines snake around the outside, and the wait is usually more than an hour. Once inside, there is another line to get into the palace tour. While you wait in line, you are required to put on booties for walking around on the palace floors and carpets. They have separate lines for tours in different languages.Inside, the palace is smaller than many of the comparable European palaces, but there is attention to detail and small intricacies that make this palace uniquely Turkish. The chandeliers are the most notable and amazing accessories.The gardens are particularly beautiful, and the view out onto the water really is royal. The sculptures are also fun to look at, my favorite being a lion fighting a crocodile in the garden.

Dumbed Down. We last visited this Palace a few years ago and the guided tours were very well done. It is now a question of getting a crowd (& I do mean, a crowd) round as quickly as possible. It is no longer possible to fully appreciate what a splendid place this is (& what a stupendous waste of money the Ottomans didn't have!), but such is commercialism.Still worth going and the queues were very reasonable (thanks to the tours being so quick), but you do come away somewhat disappointed.

A wonderful peek into the past. This Palace was built after Topkapi Palace in order to bring the sultan up to date with the grand European palaces. The palace itself is a wonderful display of architecture, design and Turkish luxury. Be warned that the tours of the palace and harem are guided ONLY; you cannot take individual tours and the queues are outside so if it looks like it might rain, pack an umbrella. No photography is allowed which is understandable but a real shame. Definitely worth a trip if you like architecture and/or history.

Oh, the queues!. On a Sunday morning, we spent 1 hour 5 minutes waiting to buy tickets, 30 minutes waiting to be taken on a tour of the official apartments, and 30 minutes waiting to be taken on a tour of the private apartments. The tours lasted about 20 minutes each. While I appreciate this is a must-see while in Istanbul, the queuing situation seems a bit out of control. My next visit will be in the middle of winter!

Beautiful Architecture. Good to visit this palace if you are interested in historical places. Palace was designed by french and italian designers to give it an outstanding looks. Long queue makes you feel tired to buy tickets and it takes another two hours to visit palace. However on exit of palace there is a nice cafe to get relaxed.

Exceptional palace but poor organization. This palace is with no doubt the most beautiful one to see in Istambul. However, one must wait to visit it in groups of sometimes over 30 people which makes it impossible to hear the little that the guide has to say. Moreover, the visit is done hastily and there is no time to really enjoy the place. Too bad. It would have been better to visit it with audioguides (as in Topkapi) but this is not available...

A most outstanding Palace on a most amazing position. A place worth visiting. Dolmabache is the new Sultan's Palace built at the most amazing situation, right on Bosporous. The most outstanding features of the Palace are the marvelous chandeliers made of thousand of pieces of Bohemian glass. You have to be there early as they are always long queues for entering the premises and make sure you have a sun hat and a bottle of water with you if the weather is sunny and warm!

Amazing!. It's totally worth seeing it, the palace is just gorgeous from the outside and even more beautiful inside, you get to see most of the rooms and the main room is jaw dropping. However I would recommend buying the ticket through one of those city tour guide agencies,this way you get to skip the long queues and you can learn more about the history of the palace...

BEAUTIFUL. This particular building was one of my favourite ones in Istanbul. The architecture was quite a contrast from the other buildings in the city, it was magnificent. Overlooking the sea, and the well kept gardens are quite an attraction. Although, it has mandatory tours but our guide was well learned and it was worth the wait. This should be a must for every tourist.

Ata-Turk museum. AtaTurk is the most important name in the history of Turkey and one of the most brilliant person in the history of mankind, mandatory visit place, I hate queue but it was well worth. Visited it in 2012

Must see even ticket takes long. It is worth visiting place . I liked the Architecture / up keeping of this Palace Very much .  Palace is overlooks the sea of Marmar and it's very close to the Taksim square. The palace is kept very clean and garden is beautiful.Its. an amazing artworks and construction techniques. A 4-1/2 ton chandelier looks grate .Visit in early morning at 8.30 am & stand in line to get tickets OR book through Tour operators and pay some premium to get instant Tickets .

Beautiful Palace - Unfortunate Mandatory Tours. The palace, hamam, the grounds and waterfront view are all beautiful. The peacocks are a special treat. Unfortunately, the only way to visit is by compulsory tours. I have never been anywhere where the guides cared less about imparting information. The tours are rushed and offer very limited info.
