It would be much better to be able to tour with an audio guide and some signage. Instead you see some beautiful rooms but they come to you largely without history and context. Our guide for the palace was vocal about letting us know we can ask questions, but her replies were all yes or no answers so no real insight there either. Our guide for the hamam was worse. They have put UPC codes on most items, but unfortunately, not too discretely and there are areas where you feel you are in a tag sale with all these tags hanging off things. A little care into how this palace is visited would go a long way.It is easy to get to (just a couple of minuted from Kabatas tram stop) and if you are ok with just seeing and not learning too much, it is certainly worthwhile as there are some beautiful rooms and the view is great. (Quite a lot of the property along the Bosphorous is private so this is a nice spot to enjoy it. If you are up for it walk your way up to the Bosphorous bridge and you will get another nice spot to sit and enjoy.)

Magnificent!!!. This palace is amazing. It overlooks the sea of marmar and it's very close to the Taksim square where a majority of the hotels are located. The palace is kept very clean and garden is beautiful. There are amazing artworks and construction techniques. The official ceremony hall is magnificent and hosts a 4-1/2 ton chandelier. I definitely recommend it. Our tour guides for both the Heram and the Admin building were fluent in English and very friendly.

New painting museum opened.... A portion of the Dolmabahçe Palace’s crown prince area, belonged to the sultan’s elder son "şehzade", has been turned into the National Palaces Painting Museum. Magnificent part of the structure has been dedicated to painter Ivan Aivazovsky who is considered one of the greatest marine artists in history. In the Turkish painters section, there are paintings by the second and third generation of westernized Turkish paintings such as Şeker Ahmed Paşa, Süleyman Seyyid, Osman Hamdi Bey, Halil Paşa and (the Last Caliph) Abdülmecid Efendi.

Not good guiding but beautifull palace. Maybe was my unluck our guide couldnt speak proper english.we had hard time to understand but it was funny especialy guide said 210 m. Instead of 210 cm. Anyway we had good views.hareem part was breath taken..and there is different price policy for tourist and local :(

Another palace but..... similar to European places, pretty, but last room of the palace is AMAZING !!!! You will spend 2 hours, no more. Make sure to have some food, snacks, cakes, drinks, etc in the restaurant on your way out , overlooking the gorgeous sea. Not expensive.

Afternoon trip to palace. Don't miss this spectacular palace. In my opinion, rivals the Topkapi Palace in beauty and elegance. Expect to wait in lines for the tours and bring a book like lonely planet to read more about the palace as the complimentary tours are mediocre. Consider catching a late afternoon bosphorous cruise to see the palace from the water. Overall, highly recommended!

"must" to see in Istanbul. The georgeous palace were 6 Sultans and Kemal Ataturk used to live.You can admire the impresive decoration of Sultan's and appartments, hamam and Harem.The palace is sourrounded by magnificient gardens. There is also clock museum and Crystal Pavillon with very unique crystal piano, chair and fountain.Visiting Dolmabahce Palace you can take a small braek and relax in coffee shop situated in "bahce"

Breath taking extravagance. Take the time to see this Palace. It is beautiful inside, you can just imagine high-class events occuring here. You tour in groups though, so once you buy a ticket, you are on the grounds of the place. Beatiful waterfountain and rose bushes and it's right along the Bosphorus River. But you do have to wait for your group to go in, so you wait in a line- outside until you can go in for the tour. No pictures inside, I had to purchase a postcard. The guides were really friendly and knowledgable. Enjoy the tour!

Another must see in Istanbul. During our visit to Istanbul this month, my daughter who is studying architecture insisted to add this palace to our tours. I was not convinced because it is relatively modern compared to other very old attractions in Istanbul. After the visit, I should admit that it is a master piece and shouldn't be missed while in Istanbul.Our visit included both the main palace and the adjacent Harem (wife) palace. Be prepared for long queues because the tour must be guided by a professional human tour guide (English or Turkish). The whole tour including the small zoo in the back garden took 4 hours.Although photos were not allowed, many visitors were secretly using their mobiles to take photos.The interior decoration of the palace specially the main hall and its dome are magnificent. The view of the Bosphorus from the palace was also charming. This palace is more luxurious than similar palaces in Vienna and Munchen.

Poorly Managed Tours. No individual sightseeing is allowed due to past unruly tourists lying on beds, sitting on antique chairs, etc for photos . Tours of up to 30 people per group are all guided either in English or Turkish. No photos are allowed to be taken indoors but many tourists at the end of the group sneaked in snapshots as the guide could not see them. Internal security was non-existent although all bags had to go through an X-ray machine at the entrance. Great if you are interested in old buildings and furniture, otherwise not much to get excited about. Cost to visit the whole palace is 40 lira. Palace is located right next to the Bosphorus where there are cafes and a restroom for free. Many places in Turkey charge 1 lira to use the restroom so save your coins. A tour of the main building takes about 45 minutes and the harem 15-20 minutes.

Fantastic decoration. This is a beautiful palace, richly decorated and housing the offices of Kamil Ataturk. The downside is that you cannot pay the [expensive] entrane fee by credit card - and they don't tell you that until you have queued for ages to get to the tick office: cash only! And you have to join a guided tour as you can't go round on your own. But depite these difficulties it is not to be missed.

Long queues, FAR too expensive, no photography!. So, you queue for ages - it costs 40TL to visit the two palace complexes, and then - once you get in - you discover that the tours are guided only (you are not allowed to wander around at your leisure) and photography is inexplicably prohibited! The chandaliers are certainly spectacular, though not worth the entrance fee, but it would have been nice to have been able to take some pics.

Breathtaking. I have visited the Palest Schönbrunn in Vienna and Versailles in Paris, but this was more than both of them! It was actually the Schönbrunn and Versailles plus a little more. Inside the building you get to see so many private rooms of the Sultans or later Ataturk and you can go outisde and take beautiful pictures in the garden or by the water. Just amazing! It is quite expensive (40Lira) BUT after I saw this I'd pay it again and again. Students pay only 5 Lira, but only with an INTERNATIONAL student card.

Nice place. Recently visited the place, the tour was previously arranged by "Plan Tours" which facilitated our quick entry to the palace avoiding the long queues outside. The tour guide was very helpful and provided us with interesting information about the place. The palace has very nice outdoors, and amazing views of the Bosphorus.

Amazing place. long lines but that is to be expected considering the number of people traveling to this city. They nay accept cash. there are only 2 windows to buy tickets from and the reason is crowd control. They can only take so many people in at a time. The tour guide had a soft voice and we could not really hear her. It would help to have a mic or give individual head sets. The harem which requires buying a separate ticket had a good tour guide and was very interesting . It is amazing that all the original items are in place. I don't think you can compare this to other countries such as Vienna or Paris. This was a different culture and time period and must be appreciated for what it is. Wear comfortable shoes, a hat, bring plenty of cash and enjoy .

Extraordinary place. You should try to get into this place, although it is not the easiest. We arrived around noon on a Sunday and the wait to get in was over 2 hours. So, we went to the cafe, right on the Bosphorus, for a snack. By the time we finished 2:45, the line had died down to 45 minutes. Be warned, though, the ticket office closes at 4 OR when their daily ticket allotment has been sold.We had an excellent tour guide, but were rushed through the bulding in about 45 minutes. Make sure you get close to the guide and stay with him or you won't be able to hear anything. You also can't linger or take pictures.The highlights were the crystal staircase and chandeliers, the room where Ataturk died, and the many reception areas. Really a stunning place.

Disappointing Dolmabahce Palace. We are two active mature well traveled females - visited on Apr. 15, 2014. Beautiful views of Bosporous and Golden Horn from terrace but otherwise disappointing if you've visited Versailles near Paris, Hampton Court or Windsor Castle near London or Schonbrunn near Vienna. Took English tour of palace 11 a.m. and harem tour at 12:20 p.m. Only guided tours - no free roaming inside palace rooms. Both guides had difficult to understand accents. What made it worse is the first group had about 80 people and the second about 120 (I did a rough count.) They didn't wait for the group to assemble in a spot where they began talking and the information they provided when audible or understandable was boring rather than humanly/culturally interesting. The highlight of the harem tour was seeing the bed where Attaturk died, not very interesting really. When we visited Topkapi Palace a few days earlier we were told all the harem furnishings were removed and sent for display at Dolmabahce Palace so we were anxious to see them there but there was no reference to that on the Dolmabahce tours. They definitely need to increase the frequency of English tours since they only offer English or Turkish tours. They need to make each tour group smaller and revise their scripts.

Might have been nice if we had got in. We went to visit in April and what shocked me was the attitude of the staff who did not seem interested in selling any tickets - there were only 2 of the 5 ticket windows in the ticket open and the woman in one of them was refusing to serve anyone who was not on a group tour so spent 98% of the time doing nothing and the guy in the other window was in no hurry either. Apparently they have decided to only sell a certain number of tickets each day but rather than selling the allocation and then closing they prefer to make people queue for hours and then shut the ticket office with no warning. I'm sure it is very nice inside although from reading other reviews the guides don't seem to give a crap either so go with this in mind and avoid peak season as you will probably waste the whole day queuing and not actually get in..

European Grandeur. The city is rich with history and melting pot of many cultures in the past as well as present. However this European palace was not built by European for European used. It was built and ordered by Empire's 31st Sultan, Abdülmecid I, and built between the years 1843 and 1856.More info here http://www.millisaraylar.gov.tr/portalmain-en/default.aspxEnsure sufficient time if you intend to visit both Selamlık (Official part) and Harem (Privy Chambers) .They have guided tour both in English and Turkish.Photos aren't allowed to be taken inside both areas.Highlight will be visiting Atatürk's room. Description from Wikipedia:"Mustafa Kemal Atatürk spent the last days of his life in the palace as his health deteriorated. He died at 9:05 a.m. on November 10, 1938, in a bedroom, located in the former Harem section of the palace. All the clocks in the palace were stopped and set to 9:05 after his death. Although this has changed recently and clocks are set to different times around the palace, the clock in the room where he died is still pointing to 9:05 a.m."

Great 2 hours visit to the palace.. In the last morning before my afternoon flight, we decided to spend it at the Dolmabahce Palace and we made the very right choice to see beautiful interior and amazing decoration. The only flaw was the accent of English guide which was quite hard to understand...Sit by the waterfront was such a relaxing moment. We were lucky that tulips are all around.

Wonderful with a good guide. I visited this palace with a group of friends in April 2014, having visited Topkapi Palace earlier in the day. Visiting these two sites on the same day was fantastic, but after reading the other reviews, I can't help feeling that this was aided by having an excellent private guide at each of them (i.e. not relying on the guide provided by the site itself). At Dolmabahce, our guide walked us through the main palace and then the harem, carefully explaining not just what there was to see, the source of many of the items and a brief history of how the palace worked, but we also obtained an explanation of the life of the last of the Sultans, his departure from the palace with the Crown Prince and the political situation at the time. If you are not lucky enough to have a private tour booked, it is still worth viewing - the gardens and the view are extraordinary, and highlights for me included the enormous carpets, the English fireplaces, the glimpses of the rooms (such as bedrooms) which were once occupied and the crystal staircase. Really quite an amazing building, the construction of which is unlikely to be repeated in this age.

So vast and beautiful. What a beautiful palace. Built after the Topkapi palace, this is where Ataturk stayed and passed away in the early 20th century. The grand halls and rooms with portraits lining the walls of the Sultans and a huge chandelier encrusted with diamonds and rubies sent from around the world. The grounds of the palace are huge also. I will add some photos for you to view int he coming week. A definite must see.

Complete disorganization!. Palace is definitely awesome and a must place to visit in Istanbul! But!I'm totally disappointed with the organization of the museum. You can buy tickets in cash only! And this is one of the most popular places in the largest city of Turkey! Lack of audio guides. A guided tour is also very short and poor, and unfortunately Turkish and English only. All other tours are with private guides only for a very different price. Photography and video are not allowed! When I was there the man was driven from because of it. In my opinion it's awful. The museum collects the money and in return not provides any convenience for tourists!

Magnificence. Frist of all this is a must see place for both foreign and native country tourists. It is better to have mesum + card. After you checked at the gates beautiful garden routes you to the main ceromonial part of the palace, called Selamlık. No free visits and personal photos are allowed. You have to wait a short while for the formation of approximately 20 persons groups for a dedicated guide to take you to the tour. This usually takes 5 minutes not more. However, be aware that sometimes you need to wait 1 or 2 groups since guided tours are in different languages and follow each other. Guides give very short but interesting information about both the building and living in the palace. You may miss some of them while you observing the magnificent ornamentation and the decoration. History and the imperial magnificence surrounds you until you come to the room in which Mustafa Kemal Atatürk spent his last days and passed away. Bed lining is a big National Turkish Flag and the clock on the small table is stopped at quarter pass nine, that is the time which Atatürk was officially anounced deceased. This room is very emotional especially for Turkish citizens. Last part of the main building of the palace is a huge saloon with incredible ornaments and a chandelier of 4,5 tons of metal and gold in halves. You need a time to relax your neck muscles after leaving this place since you always need to look up in saloon. More than 250 kilos of gold was utilized just for the ornaments here. After a short break at the cafe just in front of the Harem Section you may visit Harem in a similar manner, meaning guided group visit. This section is the main living area of Sultan and his relatives. Total visit was took 3,5 hours for us including cafe break. I advice this place for everyone visiting İstanbul

Glamorous Hotel. It's a must-see palace in Istanbul. Every detail in this palace were amazing.
Unfortunately, taking photos is not allowed inside.
We went there early on our second day so the queue wasn't that much yet.

As beautiful as Versaille. This place surprised me as the inside of the palace is beautiful but you can't take photos so I had no idea what it was going to look like. It is very decorated, like Versaille, lots of ornate furniture, chandeliers and beautifully painted walls. You can only go inside on a tour and we had to line up for about 15mins for the 45min tour but it was worth it. It is only a short walk along the water from the tram stop.

waaaaaaw!!!!. for me it was amazing....lovely architecture, lovely furniture, perfect outdoor areasproperly organized with tour guy in English and Turkishit is totally diferent from Topcapi Sarai, this one is newer and still has the furniture from the old daysAs I understood, it is mainly built by wood, and you can hear the sound of wood when you walk, specially on stairspersonally I recommend it, and if anyone asked me what to do in Istanbul, this will be in my list

Beautiful! Great view from the Palace!. The palace gardens are fantastic! You'll have to wait in the queue but the experience is worth it! The palace is a great portrayal of Turkish Empire's wealth; As you come out of the palace, take your time to have a sit at palace stairs and enjoy the Bosphorus view!

"Fabulous". Refinement art! To be able to describe this place I have to be a history art expert...So can't really allow myself to say much. Just that if you are in Istanbul and like Ottoman art, you should not miss this visit. However you can't take pictures and visit is guided as you won't be allowed to visit at your pace, but the guide we had was really an expert and with bits of humor so overall experience was highly appreciated. You can also enjoy the gardens and the Bosphorus view just all around the Palace. Don't miss it!

If you have time on your hands and Lira to blow. You can visit Dolmabahce Palace but it's not a "must" on your itinerary but simply something to do. 20 TL isn't cheap, either. The outside garden was much more impressive than the interior. I will start off saying that our tour guide was amazing, friendly, knowledgeable, to the point that this is one of the only places in Istanbul where we actually wanted to leave a tip (but he wouldn't take it). They provide a 45 minute Turkish or English tour. You have to be in a group as they do not permit individuals to walk around by themselves. The cons are you will have to wait in line to be rounded into a huge group of approximately 30 or more(?) people. Not everyone will be able to hear the tour and he had to spend a good amount of time telling people to not take photos almost at every point in the palace. The interior itself was so-so and a haphazard showcase of collections and gifts from different people over the years. They desperately need a proper curator that can make all the valuables make sense in a presentable fashion. The one part of the palace that was museum-like to have items enclosed in glass needs a cleaning, proper lighting, and dusting; the setup made it all very cheap. For those who are still keen to visit the location is close to the Kabatas tram station, no more than a 5-7 minute walk. Nice view of the Bosphoros.

Gorgeous Palace. This huge estate and palace is absolutely breathtaking. To begin you walk through a gate, which reveals a grand entrance and garden. Unfortunately you cannot take pictures inside, but it is still an amazing experience. While walking through the palace, you can almost see the sultans and concubines walking around it. You even get to visit one of the biggest ballrooms in the world, which literally put me in awe. Every room is elegant in its own way and every tiny detail was paid attention to when putting this building together. Make sure to take a close look at the floors, ceilings, fire places, and anything marble.

Poorly run. Funny, the middle-aged guy in the ticket booth looked so professional in his gray suit. I handed him a 50 TL bill and two 20 TL bills for our two tickets, which should cost 80 TL total. Ticket-seller gave me my tickets without looking me in the eye; he just sort of glanced sideways, waiting for me to leave. I stood there waiting for my 10 TL change without saying anything. Several seconds later, he got sort of a smirk on his face, like "Oh, shoot, I'm busted." And then he handed me my change. I hate to think that an employee at a place like this would deliberately try to cheat people, but that's exactly what we believe happened here. So be aware.The tour itself is poorly organized. (I am a volunteer museum tour guide back home.) They cram people into waiting areas where you have to put paper booties over your shoes--with few places to sit to place your booties, much less to sit while waiting for your who-knows-when tour. They don't allow photography on the tour, and readily admit that the reason for this is to keep people moving. We felt like cattle on a drive through the tour. The English tour guides were okay, but their English wasn't great and you had to listen very intently to understand them. I can only imagine how difficult it would be to understand if English wasn't your first language. Our first guide spoke in a manner of an angry schoolmarm. When the guides finish their tours, they say you can ask questions, but then bolt from the room within 30 seconds. Probably the worst aspect of this tour was that they don't bother to illuminate the lights on one of the prime jewels of the palace--the biggest crystal chandelier. I asked the tour guide why this was (the one question she took before bolting) and basically the answer was that it was too much trouble. (By the way, they do light up all the other chandeliers, no problem.)The palace itself looks rather worn with paint chipping, etc. Clearly they're not funneling their ticket money back into palace maintenance. The only positives I have for this place is it was interesting to see how the later sultans and early Republic presidents lived, and the scope of the palace was impressive. Oh, and the gardens were beautifully maintained. Maybe they should get the gardeners to take tickets and give tours.

Worth seeing, but also disappointing. It's a beautiful palace, poorly presented. Too many rooms are closed to the public, we saw many audience halls, but not much else in the main palace. I wanted to see kitchens, dining rooms, servants' quarters, wanted more of a sense of what they did in all the audience halls there were. Wanted to know how they lived. The harem was better, but it would have been nice if we could have walked into more apartments instead of just at the outer door. Same complaint about not knowing what the women did all day. The guides were not good. The palace guide kept giving us language lessons, the word in Arabic, in Farsi, in Turkish, in English, to the extent that he was too hard to follow, couldn't get the thread of his talk. The harem tour had to be with over 100 people so it was a guarantee not to hear what that guide was saying! He only talked to the people in his immediate vicinity. The gardens were gorgeous, tulips and pansies blooming and for a New Mexican, so much green grass! They just need to figure out how to make it more enjoyable and informative.

Impressive!. Having read mixed reviews of this place..... I must say it is worth a visit. If for nothing else .....just to see the incredible over the top decorations and furniture. What kind of ideas people/architects/ artist can come up with when money is not an issue.

A magic place from the garden. Standing on the outside at the waterfront was worth the entry. The view on the Bosporus and across the Golden Horn on to the old part of Istanbul was incredible.We visited as well the interior which can be done only by guided tours (included in the entrance fee). As there are tourists from many different countries, the tour language is English with accent...and spiced up with sudden expressions in other languages which are randomly known by the guide.So once you are adapted to his words, language and accent..... you get confronted with sudden words in Spanish, Italian, German and other languages which are know by the guide and supposedly meaning the same as the just said English word. People understanding these sudden word in their motherlanguage where similarly shaken up but had no clue why the guide suddenly mentioned for example "Venice, Venezia, Venedig" and then went on in English.Accept this as part of the experience.Some rooms in the interior are breathtaking, like the Grand Hall and the entrance staircase and worth the waiting.But I recommend warmly to stroll as well along the waterfront and enjoy the sun and the view and the ships passing by.The tour cannot be done by wheelchairs as there are stairs along the path.

Repeating history.... While we were in Istanbul we saw many attractions. The most meaningful was the white iron gates of the PALACE. My grandparents, who were from Istanbul, have pictures there when they were in their early 20's. Then my parents have a picture by the white gates, now my wife and I have our pictures there. Amzaing Palace and the way they upkeep it. A great sight to see. Worth the line.

must be seen. If you go Istanbul and you dont visit Dolmabahce Palace you haven”t seen anything.It is one of the most beautiful palaces i have ever seen.The palace has a beautiful garden too full of lovely flowers and trees.It is situated near the Marmara sea and the view takes your breath.The arhitecture inside is amazing.The tour takes about 50 min and if you visit harem put 25 min more.The guides explain all you see inside.So...enjoy visiting it!!!

East meets west in a wonderful way. This wonderful palace is obviously a showcase of power and wealth. It has been rarely used as an actual residence for the rulers of Turkey, instead this is where they would meet foreign dignitaries. The palace has a main part and a harem. You can buy tickets on site, from a small boot before the main gate. When we visited the place they only accepted cash and no cards. However, just a couple of meters away from the ticket boot, there is an ATM. You can only visit the museum with a tour, and before entering it, you must put on protective "bag-socks" over your shoes. Since the palace floors are mostly made of wood, they are trying to limit the amount of wear by limiting the tour durations. This is also the reason why you are not allowed to click pictures inside (their reasoning was, that if they let people click pictures, it would take much longer to complete the tour, thus exposing the palace to more damage by use). The palace houses a 4.5 ton chandelier, just before the exit from the tour through the main hall. Once you finish the main tour, you exit the palace through a souvenir shop. The prices in the shop are more than fair, and some of the things we were unable to find in any other souvenir shops that we have visited. If you have a ticket to the harem as well, after leaving the main tour, turn left at the exit from the building, hen left again. It's a relatively long walk, and even into the harem you can only go with a guided tour, for which you might have to wait. Please note, that outside the harem, there are two separate queues for the tour in Turkish and the one in English. There is also a cafeteria in front of the entrance to the Hareem, so if the waiting time is too long, you can relax over there.There is a wonderful garden around the palace. From here you can get a beautiful view over Asia Minor, just on the other side of the Bosphorus.The harem part of the palace was a rather big let down. I think you will not miss anything important if you skip this part, since you will only get to see bedrooms after bedrooms. They didn't let us enter the bathing area, which in my opinion looked the most interesting from afar.You can get to this attraction by traveling to the Kabatas station (with tram T1 or the funicular). From the station start walking in the "continuation" of the tram lines (towards the petrol station), on the right-hand side of the road. After about 6 minutes of walk, you get to Dolmabahce, and you will be first greeted by the clock tower in your right. The ticketing office is officially open until 16:30, but they reserve the right to close earlier too. The Musekart is not valid for this attraction.Unfortunately, the tour's quality strongly depends on your tour guide. Do not feel shy to ask questions, for even the guides who speak little know a lot about the palace. We have so far experienced 3 tour guides, out of which one one (the first one, luckily) was truly exceptional.

What a con!. This palace was formally used as government offices and it looks as if they have just cleared off and filled the vacant spaces with a load of junk furniture purchased at the bazaar. There were no memorabilia or displays showing historical scenes etc. The paintwork and general decoration was dirty/peeling/scratched and the crystal chandeliers were dull. The carpet was worn and tacked down to stop it tripping up visitors and overall I couldn't imagine anyone actually living there - it was like a run-down public school dusty smelly and slightly damp.You had to have guide to take you around as part of a party of about 20 and you couldn't hear what he said but it didn't really matter since it wasn't very interesting.My advice if you are short of something to do go and sit in Gulhane Park, far more interesting!

Worth seeing just to see the main Hall. I have been to see quite a few palaces and museums and while some parts of this palace are no different to the beauty of Tzarkoe Selo, the uniqueness of the Winter Palace or grandeur of Versailles the Grand Ceremonial Hall of Dolmabahce Palace left us speachless. It is worth doing the whole tour and visiting Domabahce just to see this hall.

My favourite museum in Istanbul. Dolmabahce was the recidence of president Ataturk. The palace is stunning: the chandeleers, the furniture, the ceilings are just wonderful. A turkish guide will present you the museum. This service is included in your ticket.And the view over the Bosphorus Strait is also very nice. The palace gardens are stunning in spring.I don't recomment visiting the harem. The Sarayi is just enought.

Discover the lot. Be there early if traveling in high season (or bring time for queuing), join the tours of the palace and the harem (where you are herded through, the entertainment value of which depends very much on the guide on duty). After that take your time, stroll around the grounds, see the crystal pavilion and the aviary. And if you are disabled and have the appropriate official document of prove, bring it with you and it is all yours for free.

They had one of the biggest chandelier in the world!. I liked the fact that there was a guided tour but you couldn't move freely inside the palace....and what if you had to use the bathroom?You had to finish the tour first and then they let you go out....Not really convenient

Grandeur by the Bosphorous. The styling of this palace hits you when you see the waiting area and the main staircase of the palace. Its class, decor and palatial grandeur is what personifies the lifestyle of the kings who lived here. The palace also has has 2 other entrances. One from the sea and other from the forest side which is now the upmarket Taksim area. The palace has crystal staircase imported from Czech Republic and porcelain from China. Absolutely brilliant carpets and chandeliers adorn the flooring and ceilings.It is a definite must watch if you are in Istanbul. Its easily reachable from Sultanahmet area by T1 Tram which ends at Kabatas which 2 mins walking from the palace.

Don't Miss!. Dolmabahce was beautiful, and worth the time and $. We did the harem tour also, and we were glad we did. This palace is much better than Topkapi!
Note: We got student discounts at the gate for our hs and college daughters even without the international student id!

Must see, amazing and very very very interesting. Till date, from all my travel, this has been the best palace I have visited. Its allowed only as part of a tour group and therefore, we could visit it as part of the Bosphorus Cruise Tour. I would highly recommend a tourist to visit this place

Interesting Place, Mediocre Tour. The tickets are fairly expensive (40tl), the wait is long and the tours are way too big. Impossible to hear the guide if you are at the back. It was a cold, rainy, miserable day and we had to wait in the rain for about 30 minutes. It is an impressive palace and gives you a real sense of what it was like to live there in the late 1800's and early 1900's. It's worth seeing, but go early and on a nice day. The gardens are quite lovely.
Classic - a must see top 10. Really great visit and loads of detail - we also extended by adding the Harem visit (far better than the Topkapi !) - beautiful place

Opulence. I was reading the negative reviews and have to agree that some parts of a visit to Dolmabahce are not very pleasant. The lines are indeed very long, it is quite expensive, photography is not allowed inside the buildings and the guided tours leave a lot to be desired. They will kill you with numbers and measurements, which no one remembers in the end. If you visit, you will wait to buy tickets, wait to start a tour of the selamlık, wait for other groups, wait for your fellow tour members to look at the rooms, wait to start a tour of the harem and so on. There is also a maximum number of visitors allowed every day, I think it's 3000 so tickets will sell out very fast. Organized groups and Turkish citizens are "privileged" and those lines will usually be shorter. However, once you get inside, you might understand these aspects. It seems that Istanbul takes great pride in this palace and everything inside and around it. It was the place where Atatürk died and he is revered. Also, the opulence is indescribable. Where else would you find a crystal staircase, ceilings of gold and the biggest Bohemian crystal chandelier in the world? Not a lot of places, that's for sure. So this palace is truly a great treasure. The details, both on the outside and in are absolutely stunning. There are things to look at in every corner of every room. The decor is simply marvelous, the riches are mindblowing. A 40-minute tour will leave you dizzy if you just look at everything. A palace of this sort needs to be well taken care of. Preservation and restoration - expensive. Cleaning the artifacts is not an easy task. One man alone simply cannot take down a 4,5 ton chandelier and clean it in a jiffy. Thus the 40 lire entrance fee. Thus the silly plastic shoes one has to wear so that the marble and carpets don't wear down. Thus the no photo policy as a lot of people act ignorantly and use flash all the time. Thus the organized tours as a lot of people simply don't know how to behave and will run around touching, grabbing or disrespecting. You can visit both main buildings or only one of them, depending on your interest, budget and time. The harem is not as impressive as the selamlık but I personally found it worthy of my time and money. It's a great look into the Ottoman Empire of the 19th century, as it is quite different from earlier periods.The gardens are beautiful in summertime and even in the fall. You can also get great looks of the exterior by taking a boat tour on the Bosphorus, you will pass by the palace and see it as a whole from afar.  Get informed before your visit. Check out opening hours and prices, get there early and get ready to wait. If I'm not mistaken, there is wheelchair access and I also saw a lot families with strollers. I think that if you keep an open mind and ignore the few imperfections of a tour, you will definitely get a lot from a visit to Dolmabahçe. I most certainly did!
Amazing jewel collection The second biggest diamond in the world. Long queues! But well worth the wait The room interiors are well maintained and the decor very bright and perhaps gaudy

Stunning palace. I have seen many palaces across the world but this one is genuinely stunning. Make sure you go early as you have to go on a guided tour....but don't be put off. The rooms are spectacular and there is plenty to see. Great views across the Bosphorus. It is only a short walk from the tram stop ..or ferry terminal and there is a good cafe.

A must see. We visited here on our first day of sightseeing mainly because it was raining! We are really glad that we did as it really is a fantastic place to go. Unlike Topkapi Palace, you could easily understand what it must have been like to live there in its hey day. The fabulous ceiling crystal chandeliers not to mention the crystal balustrades were something to behold and because much of the original furniture was still in situ the atmosphere resonated with the luxurious indulgence of its time. Included in the price was a compulsory tour guide and this was a big plus. Just a tip. Try to stay up front with the guide if you can as it is quite difficult to hear them if you are near the back of the group and sadly the guides do not have microphones. We went to Topkapi Palace the next day and were disappointed that there wasn't one there but also there was no real sense of who had lived there.Do try to get to Dolmabahce Palace if you can. It's easy to reach on the tram system and well worth the entrance fee. If this was an historic site in the UK, it would cost at least twice as much!

amazing but dirty museum objects. really expensive entry fee, nice garden with birds (even peacocks)all tours are only with a guide, quite a big one, so last ones are not sure to catch all infomuseum objects (chandellier, furniture) are beautiful but extremely dirty - this is shocking
Great palace. I am so impressed with the architecture of the palace. We were well explained about the history of the palace even though the visit time allocated only approx 20 to 30 minutes.

Immense palace with some impressive rooms. This is an incredibly sprawling facility and because of the enormous volumes of visitors it is not always possible to hear the docents explaining the many rooms. The gardens are remarkable e specially the view over the Bosphorous.

Expensive but must visit!. I have met many people who have been to Istanbul and have considered Topkapi palace as 'the' palace, but that is so incorrect! Topkapi palace has its own charm, but the grandeur of Dolmabahce palace is just too great! The good thing about the visit here is that it is accompanied by a compulsary guided tour. The ticket was 40 Lira (including Harem tour, which in my opinion is a must visit) which was most expensive of all attractions we visited, but the guided tour almost covered the cost. Great thing about this palace is that it was in use until recently and Ataturk's room has been maintained as it was! The palace has a beautiful entrace, and there is another entrance which opens in the Bosphorus (unfortunately you can't use it!) which adds to the beauty of the palace. The tour lasts about 45mins-1hour and there is no place to sit in between - so be prepared to walk that much. Forget the ticket cost, just go!

Dolmabahce Besiktas Istanbul,. The weather was quite miserable today; raining and cold with strong winds - but we vowed not to let this get in the way of our sight seeing. Having visited Istanbul a few years ago, we wanted to focus this trip on some of the things we had not seen or that we felt were worth a second look - first up was the Dolmabahce Palace There are two ticket options for the palace; the full tour which includes the palace and the harem, or a ticket for just the palace - we opted for the full tourWe were a bit surprised and disappointed to find that all tours of the palace are in guided groups I had visited many years ago and wandered freely. After only a short wait, while donning plastic overshoes, we were ushered into an entry hall - our group consisted of about 75 people, way too big for this kind of tour. After the first stop on the tour we gave up trying to hear what the guide was saying. The other big disappointment was that no photography was allowed inside the palace I tried a few non flash shots to test the strength of the anti-photo police and after the group was politely reminded of the policy I put my camera way. Even with all these annoying issues, I found the Dolmabahce Palace to be absolutely amazing - it is one of the most elaborately adorned palaces I have ever visited. The interior is filled with original furnishing left from the time of the last sultan - I suppose this has to do with the relatively "easy" transition from Ottoman rule to the Turkish republic, compared to counties like France for example.The building is basically divided into two separate functional areas; the formal Palace side where matters of state were attended - and the "family" side (AKA Harem which mean forbidden), where the Sultan lived with his mother, up to 4 chosen wives (any more than this had to live outside the palace but close by), other female family members and male members before they were circumcised; after they met the knife (at about age 10) they were considered men and had to go and live on the Palace side. Interestingly the sultan never actually officially married any of his "wives" so as to avoid giving them any legal standing they might challenge his power.Strangely, after finishing the palace tour which lasted about 45 minutes - we were required to exit the building, walk all the way around to the back, line p again, put on overshoes again and reenter for the harem part of the tour which lasted an additional 30 minutes.
Dolmabahçe Palace. This palace view is great location to in İstanbul.Very biggest palace very good palace. You can see to all bosphorus area in Bosphorus palace cafe

Should be in top 10 of Istanbul. We visited the palace on our last full day in Istanbul , we used the tram to get there which was great and very cheap, from tram stop it was only a couple of minutes walk. Not having seen or read much about this place, it proved a wonderful surprise on so many levels. Its setting right on the water is magnificent with it covering a huge area and many enormous buildings.As mentioned on other reviews the main building does have a tour, but this is the most flexible tour ever. You are not walked round the building, its more like snippets of commentary in a few areas, so please don't be put off by other reviews. The glass staircase and the lastmeeting hall are HUGE WOWS , especially the meeting hall with its 4.5 tonne chandelier.....make sure you balance your visit to Istanbul with palaces as well as mosques.....one of the highlights of our visit to istanbul

I Could Imagine it. The waiting was extremely long, the staff acted like they were doing us a favour but I decided to ignore that. Because this is still furnished one could see the extreme oppulance of that period. Especially since they were supposed to be broke!! We did the Harem which I enjoyed as well

Astonishing palace, rubbish tour. The palace is easily reachable from the tram stop of kabatas by foot. The palace and the harem are really magnificent and well kept, real gems. Unfortunately you have to join a compulsory tour with a guide to visit them. The tour is very rushed, like cattle at the market, there are too many people in each group and the guides are not really engaging or passionate. Really a pity, because it is one of the best palaces I have ever visited and it would deserve a better experience! Nonetheless it is worth a visit, absolutely!

Worthless guide, but great site. You're forced to take a guided tour here, which is a pity: our young, unhappy guide had such an impenetrable accent that at first I thought she was speaking Turkish, not English. It made little difference, since our group of almost 80 people made it impossible to hear most of what she said; what little I could make out was along the lines of "this chandelier weighs two tons and has 70,000 bulbs, and was made in London...." Although the 40 minute tour hustles you through without being able to see much of anything for too long, the scale, design and decorations of the palace are well worth a visit.

so nice place. so great well organized and the area around the palace so nice for staying in it and for photos, the tickets wasn't cheap but we like the plalace so much and the view to bosphorous was great.

Amazing Palace. This is my favorite place to visit in Istanbul. On a nice sunny day, spending time in the palace's garden is so much fun specially with kids. Also recommend eating at Saat Kulesi restaurant right outside the palace by the sea.

MUST SEE. One would think with all the mosques and the Topkapi Palace that there's just that much to Istanbul. No complaints there.. The Blue Mosque is beautiful (only on the outside) and the Topkapi Palace can definitely be missed but Dolmabahce Palace was spectacular beyond words. Sadly you aren't allowed to click pictures inside the palace but it is what you'd imagine royalty to live in. It's one palace I would love to live in.. not the Topkapi Palace. The Palace is famous for its crystal staircase, 90 kgs of gold used to decorate the hosting area and a 4.5 tonne chandelier. Also, do not miss the red Baccarat crystals. The palace transports you back to the Victorian era. Do not miss it for the world!

wow!. That's what comes to mind every so often in this palace: WOW! Luxurious item/construction material from the 19th century? You name it, they have it: mahogany, ebony, marble. Did someone say gold? Only 14 tons of it or so. It will leave you bedazzled. You are able to see the difference between the old and new turkey, between the illusions of grandeur of a falling empire and the reality of a new rising replublic. Great visit!
Worth the visit. Gorgeous place. It is getting old with time but worth the visit to see the Ottoman empire at its end.

Luxury to be enjoyed!. Surprisingly luxury, Ottoman Empire seems to spend all of its final glory, and money on this new palace. Although not as charming as the Tokpapi Palace, it is definitely worth a visit to enjoy those shinny and luzury decorations. The images of Mustafa Kemal Atatürk at the Harem are also nice. Beautiful garden s are also worth spending some time strolling. One reminder. The whole outlook is only visible from the sea. Therefore, do go for the Bosphorus strait cruise or other cruises in this strait area.

Turkish Versailles. The Eastern Europe's Versailles. Litterally. This Palace was inspired by the French Versailles. If I am remember well, the architects were sent to see how Versailles is done before they built this palace. Mabye not that spectacular, but it has its own beauty. Charming rooms, but unfortunately, you'll have to try and keep them in your memory well because the photography inside the palace is not allowed. But, you'll have an amazing opportunity to take a lot of pictures with its exterior. And it will be enough, cause the architecture is amazing. If you have a tour guide, you'll learn a lot about turkish history. The line to get in usually is long, but that's ordinary for every things worth seeing in the world. *Visited January 2013

Luxurious treat for the eyes!. The best thing I liked about this palace is that everything is preserved starting from cutlery, carpets, furniture to chandeliers!!! It has Europe's largest chandelier which is a must see!It is located at a walking distance from the nearest tram station. There are 2 sections of the palace viz., administration and harem. Tours are available in English and Turkish. (Arabic language is available only during particular season. Pls check beforehand if this is your preferred language!). The tour guides did have an accent so make sure that you stand close to him / her. As the tour is conducted in groups, you may miss out on the information if you are not within hearing range. The administrative side of the palace is much more impressive than the harem; however in my opinion it is worth to pay for the complete tour. Harem means the residence of the Sultan and his family. Point to note is that it is located right beside the sea; hence we found it extremely windy and chilly. If you plan your trip during winter then make sure you have adequate woolens on you. If palaces are your passion then this is definitely a must see!!!

Absolutely Spectacular. Never been in a more spectacular palace. Worth 2 Billion USD you can expect to see some extravagance. So Rich with History. The Views, gardens , buildings are just incredible .

luxury of a falling empire. In 1843, when the palace began to emerge from the horizon, it meant everything for Sultan Abdulmecid. It was the symbol of his new westernization policy and an extravagant show-off piece of his empire. It was built in completely western style and contained luxurious gifts from western countries. It would be amazing to see how the Muslims tried to make their empire part of the western world. The queuing takes quite a long time, but is definitely worthwhile. The guide was helpful. Do follow his instructions inside. The only thing that annoyed me was that no photos were allowed inside the palace. I could not record the masterpieces inside the palace with my camera. (There was an amazing stereograph in the largest hall of the palace.) But still, it would be a precious treasure for your memory, especially if you are a fan of history.

most beautiufl palace i have ever seen. this palace should gain some attention jsut as the other places ! it is beautiful really and everything is just jaw dropping ! although the ticket is more expensive then usual but it was worth it ! the tour was also okay and informative

Loved this place but the time was too short!. I really loved this place. It is very nice and they have kept most of the things in the palace and it makes it so interesting. But the time they let you see each room, etc. was too short. They should have guards everywhere in the palace so the leaders don't have to repeat themselves to stay together or you will be caught and in get into big trouble!!!! You have to rush in there, but i loved it so much that I went there twice.

If you like cream with your cream cake and a bowl of cherries on the top.. if you like ornate and if you like being hurredly herded from selected room to selected room and paying a lot of money to indulge in these passions then this is the place for you. Mildly interesting gardens. Two buildings - the main administrative and the Harem. I never used my ticket for the Harem (two still free for anyone). Too much orateness. But I did love the wooden parquet flooring. Only do if you really have seen everything else that Istanbul has to offer. Or stand and look at the main gates outside and imagine. Inside is just more of...lots more of.
Must visit!. Very beautiful palace. Make sure you also visit the harem area (request it when buying the ticket)...

Consider the opening hours. I had to try two time to visit the palace as I found several sources about its opening hour and the one which says that it is not open every day e.g., closed on Thursday is the valid one.The palace is beautiful really, the crystal candelliers are huge.Be prepared to wait a lot at every entrance. The whole palace is completely unheated, thus it is as cold inside as outside. There is no place to sit down so there will be no rest during the visit. After a 2-3 min sessions of introduction your guide is changed and it is repeated a few times till you get completely mixed with other tourist groups. The harem provides you with the visit of ~30 different rooms.All the furniture and relating items in the palace seems completely original, which downside is that some of them looks like very worn out. But it is at least much more lively than the deserted Topkapi palace.

ISTANBUL DAIRY. DAY 4. PART 5. This attraction in Istanbul is quite a distance from the more popular spots. We reached it by walking from Taksim square to the palace. The palace may be reached by tram or taxi from the old Istanbul area.As mentioned in previous reviews, the guides give a detailed description of every room and hall in the palace tour. It is a feast for the eyes- carpets, paintings, furniture and chandeliers. The guide had a very strong Turkish accent. Touring in a big group made it doubly difficult to understand her.Three things to look out for in this place are: The crystal grand staircase, the presidential bedroom of Ataturk which is surprisingly small and the world’s largest bohemian crystal chandelier which hangs on the 2000 square meter ceremonial hall. It is truly magnificent.

Compulsory guided tours don't help. Let's be honest, the whole place is amazing and it worths your time. To get there you will have to pay 40TL and to get inside you have to follow a compulsory guided tour which is really bad. Being there in winter was good because it's was not that crowded, in Spring the waiting time is terrible. The people running the tours hardly speak understandable English in such an environment, in a big group. Explanations are poor and it ends being a way to get people to walk fast.

Worth Visiting. Its definitely worth visiting as you can access most of the rooms in the palace. The crystal staircase and chandeliers were lovely. Ballrooms were grand and majestic. The fountain and gardens were quaint, and we saw some exotic royal birds, like peacocks near the external Crystal Palace. The views of the Bosporus are lovely. Tickets cost about 30 lira pp to see Palace only, don't think we missed out skipping the Harem. Dec is low season so queues weren't that long. Guided english speaking tours are large so stand at the front to hear the commentary clearly. We took the metro/tram which was convenient. ferry terminal to Asia is walking distance so try that afterwards.

Read about the palace before visiting. We visited Topkapi Palace before visiting Dolmabahce Palace. In terms of architecture, Dolmabahce Palace is clearly European influenced compared to the Ottoman-influenced Topkapi Palace.I visited Topkapi Palace with minimal understanding of Istanbul's history and because the palace is breathtaking, I was tempted to take a lot of photos and then just leave after I'm done.So before I visited Dolmabahce Palace, I decided to read about Ataturk, the Ottoman Empire and about Dolmabahce Palace. Trust me when I say this, it made the visit so much more meaningful than just blindly taking photos.The queue wasn't long at all. It took 5 - 10 minutes to buy the tickets. For reference, we visited in mid December and it was at 2pm.After we paid 30TL to see the palace (excluding the Harem), we were told there would be an English tour which would involve one guide and 30 tourists. The guide had a thick Turkish accent, but that wasn't really an issue. The problem was the volume (or lack thereof) of her voice. Combine her soft voice with the mildly noisy tourists, everyone else (especially those at the back) couldn't hear her.Again, that's when reading about the palace beforehand came in handy. Since we've paid 30TL (about GBP10) for the visit and the tour of the palace, it would be great to fully immerse ourselves in the luxurious palace atmosphere instead of being frustrated about being unable to hear the tour guide. Because I've done some reading beforehand, I wasn't too frustrated about being at the back and being unable to hear the guide.The palace itself is pristine and beautiful. The only area of improvement would be keeping the other tourists quiet and/or breaking up the tour into smaller groups instead of a large group of about 30 people.

Very nice place, not so enthusiastic tour. The palace is SUPER COOL! Very nice attraction worth to visit, but...There is no possibility for individual visit. There are Turkish and English guided tours hourly at a fixed time which was not up to our expectation. The tour was 40+30 mins (palace+harem) and both parts of the palace are huge therefore the groups have to rush through most of the rooms and halls with very little information given by the tour guide.

Most beautiful palace I have ever seen. I have been to a lot of palaces, but this one really impressed me. The chrystal chandeliers were so big. In the last hall (while entering, every second you are seeing more and more of the hall, your mouth will goes wider and wider, saying ooo, because it is so big and beautiful), there is the heaviest chandelier in the world, all made of chrystal. Shining, like the beautiness of this palace does! Go there and see it yourself.
oriental opulence. Definitely worth the visit, a spectacular dreamy palace! One might to wait long queus but it certainly compesates for them!

The Grand Hall!. This was much better than Topkapi. So much money spent to build this place. The main hall is breathtaking.It can be reached by getting the tram to the end of line 3TL and then a short stroll away from the stop. So don't get sucked into getting a tour or cruise to it.One hassle is that people on tours get priority into the palace. You also have to wait for a tour which the 1st was 9:30am. The tour is free though. So get there early!

My first palace!. History buffs will love this tour! I'm enjoying learning bits and pieces of Turkish history, and this palace is loaded with it! For those of you familiar with Attaturk, he died here, which alone makes this sight very important. Well worth seeing!

A Grand Palace. This is a pretty neat place to visit to see the lavish lifestyle this Sultans of Turkey use to lead. The Palace is grand in every which way from the entry way to the crystal staircase and the pure size of the palace. It is a great contrast to the Topkapi Palace. The history of the Palace is quite unique as it is the last Palace that was ever used by a Sultan of Turkey.I only got to see the Selamlik portion of the Palace. The Selamlik is the formal part of the palace. I arrived at 2:45 and the ticket window man was a bit short and told me the Harem portion of the palace was closed. Maybe it was lost in translation (he did speak english) but he may have assumed that I would not be able to join the 3 PM tour (which I did) but I could have done both tours. The Palace closes at 5. There were no lines and I walked right in and caught up with the tour. For an extra 10 TYL I could have seen the living quarters as well which the rest of the group did. I was a bit disappointed with that.There is not an option for a self guided tour of the Palace. The tours are led in English or Turkish and the groups are separate. That being said, the groups did meet as well as with other tour groups ahead and it can get a bit congested. The experience will depend on the people in your group and mine included pushy people.You are not allowed to take any photos inside the Palace which made the tour move along but outside is a free for all.Overall it is worth a visit if you want to see rooms with wall to wall marble and staircases lined with crystal. It also houses the largest chandelier in all of Europe.
Unique. Amasing gardens and buildings. We visited all rooms opened. There is a good english speaking guide. No photos inside the buildings.

Beautiful palace. With a lot of beautiful palaces and mosques to see in Istanbul, this one is worth the trip. It is pretty easy to get to using public transportation. The collections within it are amazing and the history it encompasses is very fascinating.

Really worth a visit. This is simply a great palace, but try to be early, in order to avoid long waiting time - we came as soon as it opened and waited only a few minutes, while other guests who came after 10 am had to wait often more than 2 hours until the finally could enter this great palace. This Palace is certainly worth to visit - but I personally think that the best time is in Spring, Summer to visit it - with all the flowers blossoming and being able to sit outside there - it was quite cold in December

probably the worst run tourism attraction I have ever visited. Queue after queue after queue. We did visit on 31st Dec but they only had one kiosk open despite a long queue which took 90 mins min. Perhaps this was deliberate in order to sell more hot drinks on a cold day but at least it was not raining. Once you get the tickets, you then queue to get into the grounds and then another queue up the steps into the main Palace area where you then need to put on plastic shoe covers. Guided tour was then a must so a further wait and then just a 40 min tour of a tiny part of the whole palace. Definitely not worth it. Tour groups also get special access and treatment.

A must see. This palace is not given much space in travel books or journals on Istanbul. However, if you have the time after visiting the major attractions in Sultanahmet, this is a must see. There may be a queue to contend with initially, and tour groups and locals seem to have priority, it is still worth it. The palace is fantastic. It costs extra to visit the harem but again it is worth the extra money. The detail in the walls and ceilings, as well as the furniture is mind boggling. It houses the world's largest chandelier weighing some tons. It iseasy to get to via the tram. After visiting this site, try wandering up to Taksim square which is a couple of kilometres away. Otherwise catch a bus- it is all easy. Also very cheap by taxi. When in Taksim, absorb the atmosphere. People and shops everywhere. A coffee overlooking the square is wonderful and not expensive. Also, seafood restaurants abound inthe alleyways off the main street. It makes a memorable outing for a day.

Majestic Tour, Guided Tour Groups Given Preference. We were very excited about visiting Dolmabahce Palace. Our enthusiasm waned slightly when we were queuing up for tickets. It clearly states that they regulate the flow of traffic, and preference is given to large tour groups as well as those who have reserved in advance. We were fairly early, around 10 a.m., but we still were in line to buy tickets for 30 minutes. Then yoou have to queue up again outsie the palace. Two lines form, one for tour groups and one for individual visitors. The tiur group line moves at an accelerated pace at the expense of the individual visitors. We were in line 30-40 minutes inthesecond line. There are no solo visits, no filming AT ALL. We have a Palace tour guide who made us soon forget the hassle of waiting in line and putting on booties. He spoke several languages, was acerbic, but funny. This tour lasted 30 minutes and was worth it. If you have already visited someof Istanbul, you will appreciate some of the art work with what the Blue Mosque area looked likecenturies ago, not to mention Hagia Sophia.

Luxury. This is the most luxury place I have ever seen in the world. It is a place where the Otoman Sultans and Ataturk had lived. This palace abounds of gold and luxury. You must not miss this place.

Beautiful palace. Although I have been to Istanbul numerous times I haven't got time to drop by Dolmabahce so I was happy to have finally found the opportunity to tour it at leisure. The palace itself was breathtaking and its architecture reminded me a lot of the western European palaces. There was a beautiful garden spread all around the property and we had fun taking pictures beside the idyllic fountains. The only negative aspect of this tour was the long queues waiting to enter the palace and the Harem buildings. Once inside, we had difficulty hearing our guide because of the huge crowd so I believe they should better manage the numbers of each group of people. The trip took about 2h and by the end of it we were exhausted but it was all worth it. This is no doubt a must see tour.

don't miss it. really nice,the interior and also the outside was great..I recommend to visit it in the early hours,to avoid the long waiting. For me,it is the most beautifull place in Istanbul,and it is worth every minute spending there...it has a great view of the Bosphorus. Only guided tours,you can't look around on your own.. Guides are on english and turkish,but they are fluent in english,speaking well. Don't miss it!

Dolmanbache Palace. This is one of the places that I have always missed on my previous trips to Istanbul and was glad that I managed to get there this time round . I would strongly recommend that if you have the time go and see this most magnificent building. We had an amazing time there and it was well worth the trip.

Quintessence of the future Spring. Armenian architect outside, oriental soul inside, waiting an old good Western buddy.. Here you can find mixed worlds and mixed times. Try to avoid crowded days. If you do so, the chance to admire calmly all you see around is pure gold. As did we.

The magnificence of the Ottoman Empire!. I've been to Versailles, but Dolmabahce is my favorite Palace in all Europe. It's preservation is great, I mean, it's not that old, but the furniture and the even the carpets are in perfect condition. The chandeliers are amazing, specially the one from Queen Victoria in the Ceremonial Hall, which is the final room visited in the guided tour. Guided tours are the only way to get in the Palace, but at the end it is better because they tell you the story behind the most important pieces of the Palace. My only complain is that you are not allowed to take pictures inside the rooms.

Go with a Tour Guide. Save yourself some time and hassle and go with a tour guide! You won't have to queue for tickets and you will get a very nice tour of the inside with good information provided. The palace is quite impressive. It is much larger and grander than I even imagined though. The furniture and fixtures are very well preserved and the descriptions by our tour guide made it all the more enjoyable.Be prepared to cover your shoes with the provided shoe covers and also to have to stop for a minute while another group finishes up ahead of you. It is the second largest palace (only to the Topkapi Palace.) I wouldn't recommend seeing both. Pick one and go with it! You won't regret it if you keep your expectations realistic.

Interesting palace. Spent the whole afternoon there. Visited the actual palace, the harem and the gardens. Luxurious furnished rooms, the harem looked different than I expected, based on paintings, but did have interesting items on display.

Don't do both tours!. It is a beautiful building, and it is nice to go inside. Don't waste your money on the 2 tours of both the palace and the haram, 1 will suffice as it is only guided. The wait was long as well to get into the guided tour.

price + guide. I don't want to criticize, but i think that there is many better places. The palace itself is quite impressive and split for 2 parts. For each part you need to wait in cold (December) quite long queue. Well, it is not the worst case. Prizes is different for Turkish and non Turkish citizens. If u are student (with ISIC) prize is quite reasonable, otherwise 40 TL for whole castle? (citizens only 20). I don't understand why i should pay more than Turkish citizens, but even there i am fine. Apart for that i am really unsatisfied with guides. At the first part woman with bad accent, which were not care whether someone can hear her or not. She only wanted to say what she must and was in permanent rush. Guy in the second part (Harem) was good until half of tour. Then he didn't guide at all and suddenly disappeared. We waited quite long for his instructions but nothing had happened!!
Turkish Baroque palace. This palace is in the baroque style, its symetric and it has beautiful gardens. There are chandeliers made by Czech glassmakers in Moravia.
very beautiful. it's located exactly beside the Bosfer strait . it's very beautiful . there are some guide that tell you about the palace.

Turkish baroque. I really don't want to sound spoilt or ignorant but the main features of this palace for me were the location and the park. If I compare the Dolmabahce Palace to the baroque palaces of France, Austria and Germany, for me it turns out quite unpolished. I admit, it could have something to do with the lack of sunshine in mid-December but I found the palace somehow grey and old.

Great visit !. We have visited many palaces around the world and this is one of the most impressive both by its content and the way the visit was organised ! We tried first to visit it on a Friday afternoon but we were told to try to come back on another day as it was very crowdy and our visit could have been rushed !  We then came back on a Sunday morning and not only was it quieter , it was also less expensive ! We did not wait for more than 15 minutes before joining a group for an English -speaking tour ! The guide was very knowledgable but unfortunatly did not have a loud voice so it was difficult at time to get all the explanations ! it was still a very interesting visit that lasted more than one hour!  After the visit , we sat down outside to appreciate the superb view of the Bosphorus and to wander in the gardens !

Must-see to understand the shift towards Europe. If you like over the top antiques you really need to see the palace. Magnificent crystal staircase, chandeliers and the biggest of the latter is the HUGE one given by Queen Victoria. Strongly suggest hiring a guide - an outside one charging by the day - because they can bypass the lines. They are long for this venue and you cannot go through without a guide - those provided by the venue take very large groups. Strongly suggest you have a private guide not just for this but for all Istanbul. Mine cost $135 a day - university professor.

Overwhelmingly repetitive. The rooms were gaudy and repetitive. Quite clearly the the Ottomans had lost the plot. The outside gardens were beautiful and the view of the Bosphrous from the outside was amazing

Europe Vs. Asia. It's quite amazing to see the Turkish craftsmanship of buildings and paintings by the European artists which makes a great difference to what we go to see in Asia. It also shows when an empire can preserve its work of art when there is no invasion from the outside the world. It's one of the must visit while someone is in Istanbul. The free guided tour makes it worth the entry fees and the wait as it without the information the wall painting and crystals are just good to see.

Rich interiors. This is palace by name and by nature. It was built to impress other nations and boy does it impress. The interiors are rich and well maintained. You have to wear shoe covers and be part of a guided tour. Regular times every half hour or so in English.No photos allowed inside. The tour of the palace is quick and in large groups. Thus not really allowing you to take everything in. I would have given the venue a 5 if it wasn't for this. Every entertaining room is luxurious in decoration and you get a feel for how the woman lived in their separate area of the place. Again check the ticket options as there is no signs to say there types with a turkey tour card, just the palace or Harlem and palace. A good three hours if you do everything. Although not large grounds. Well kept and some great views.

magnificent. It costed me about 21 usd but it was worth it, I went early in the morning to avoid the crowd, I chose the English guided tour, no extra fees is required for English guidance.the decorations inside the palace were unbelievable, the walls, the ceiling and everything, there is a hudge amount of crystals u will never see together in ur life, u can feel the age of this palace.

OK Visit. This is a very lovely property, with nice gardens, a beautiful land wall and an ok visit to the main part. However, the 45 minute tour is a rushed one with lots of people and little time to see anything. The highlight was the last huge room, with the over 4 ton chandelier, balconies, etc. Do NOT waste your time or money on the Harem; it's not worth anything. That tour was even more abbreviated and had nothing really that good to see. Pick a nice day and enjoy the views and outdoor parts of this place.

Impressive and well preserve palace!. I visited this Palace in the beginning of Dec'13. I expected a big queue but in fact it wasn't that crowded as i expected. The ticket to visit both main section together (Selamlık & Harem) is 40TL. "Selamlık" (30TL)A very grand and extremely luxury palace. Very well preserve and they remain all the furnitures and the original look of the palace back than till now. The tour in Selamlık section was great, and the tour guide really waited everyone arrive at the same point and start explaining the details of each place. She added a lot of other useful informations on the history of Ottoman and explained the reason they have to restrict the number of visitors in the palace. "Harem" (20TL)Harem is not as impressive as to compare with Selamlık. But the bed room where Atatürk passed away is in Harem. The clock in the bedroom where he died is still set to the time of his death, 9:05. Blue hall in Harem is the most impressive room in this section. The tour guide in Harem was really rushing us, and brought us walked through a lot of rooms without any explanations / He would only talk to the few people who able to catch up with him in the beginning of the group. He was more talking about himself how young he look, in fact he is 45 years old than talking about Harem. If you get the chance to go this section, make sure to ask as many questions as you can. "Crystal Pavilion" (FREE)Make sure you visit this hidden gems! It is small but its as impressive as the main sections. U can visit Crystal Pavilion for free once you visited either one of Selamlık or Harem. * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * Been to other Palace around the world, Dolmabahce Palace is one of the most impressive, well preserve and interesting Palace. As they remain the decorations and furnitures in the palace, giving you a better room to imagine life in the past, rather than in Topkapi Palace like a exhibition rooms.

Stunning, no words.... We booked a private tour and it was fabulous. The palace is stunning and we saw such a small part of the palace. I wish there was more to see. And no pictures were allowed. That to me was a downside. It was so stunning.

Huge, impressive, a must visit!. This palace is grand, large, and very beautiful. I much prefer it to Topkapi. I have been twice. However the tour during mu last visit (Oct 2013) was a little rushed. The grounds are wonderful, and the scenery of the Bosporus amazing.

Bad Memories. I visited the Place on November, it was great but very big, i recommend going it early morning, because it takes around three hours to see it all. unfortunately i was very tired and on my way out i drop it my camera. I went next day to ask them but they didn't find it. although it was nice but i was very upset because i lost my camera there

Huge, lavish rooms but repetitive and pricey. We visited the palace on a grey, wet day so it was good to be indoors. The entrance fee was 40 TRY per adult for a combined ticket to both the palace & harem.The procedure to enter the palace took some time because priority was given to organised tour groups, whilst individual visitors had to wait before being allowed to enter as a combined group, so that a guided tour could be given.The rooms inside the palace were enormous and lavishly decorated. It was interesting to hear some of the history about it's past occupants but after being directed from one enormous & lavishly decorated room to the next, it all became somewhat repetitive and dull. The palace tour was about 45mins and the harem tour was about 20 mins, the harem being smaller and a little less ostentatious than the palace.The gardens outside the palace are well tended and make for good photos. The palace location along the banks of the Bhosphorus is also impressive. Note that photos and videos are not permitted inside palace or harem at any time.To be honest, I would probably prioritise other Istanbul attractions above this, especially if you have limited time.

A bit repetitive but certainly worth seeing once. Touring this palace was a highlite of our Istanbul trip, my two daughters (11 and 15) loved it. It was built with the purpose of impressing foreign dignitaries back in the day and I imagine it did. Room after room of sheer opulence. One of the most gorgeous European palaces I am quite sure!

Huge. Stunning architect with breath-taking view.The palace is divided into two parts, The HAREM or Haramlek (reserved for women), and the SALAMLIK(reserved for men), their tours are also separated.I suggested you start with the SALAMLIK, and then go for the HAREM, at the end you could spend 5-10 minutes in the clock museum(simple and small)IMPORTANT: it's much better to go with a reserved tour so you'd join a smaller group.There's a lovely cafe just outside the beautiful building where you can relax and enjoy fresh food and lovely Bosporus view, there's also a cafe inside the palace close to the HAREM entrance.Enjoy

Truly Memorable. The moment you cross the gates and enter in the courtyard/ palace, you feel your presence in those times when it was well inhabited. The stateliness can be well visualized.Visiting the palace including the harem area will be something to remember and recall during solitude. A truly memorable place that need not to be ignored at all. Can be enjoyed alone or with group - both ways its commendable.

Tour Dolmabache. Amazing place- so much to see and shoyuld not be missed but now it is a tour you do not have enough time to really take everything in as you are rushed around to avoid mixing with other tours. Having said that we went as part of a Bosphorus day trip tour and our guide was lovely- he made it come alive.
Great palace. This is a beautiful palace,stunning architect,rich,colourful and wonderful Bosphorus views,I visited in November so there were no long queue.nice to visit ..

Strictly controlled by guide and guards - but a great cafe!. I tried three times to visit the palace on my last trip to Istanbul, and it was so crowded I could never get in! This time (November) there were no lines, but I should have taken the no-go's as a message. This is a good place to skip for several reasons: (1) It costs more than any other landmark building (for comparison, Dolmabahce was 40 TL while the Aya Sofia--far more interesting, historically significant and worthwhile--was 25 TL. (2) The tour is given in "English" but is barely comprehensible. The parts I did understand were not interesting, just dates and names without context. (3) Visitors must stay with the guide and cannot explore on their own or linger over points of interest.
