You're in and out in 40 minutes, no exceptions (though you are free to wander the grounds without time limit). (4) The palace is not in great shape: creaky wooden floors covered in threadbare carpets, crystals all foggy and dull, chipped paint, etc. A display of decorative household arts (teacups, comb and brush set, eg) was similarly unrefurbished and without labels for context. (5) Aesthetically unpleasing (subjective, I know) with a mixture of over-the-top western styles predominating (baroque, rococo) and so relentlessly symmetrical that no detail stood out as unique since it was always part of a pair or quartet of identical chairs, fireplaces, chandeliers, doors, paintings, etc. (6) Most visitors were required to wear protective booties over their shoes (I'm not sure why I and a few others were exempt). Whatever they were meant to accomplish didn't work because a gaggle of latter-day Cinderellas lost their booties along the way, leaving a trail of bright blue plastic littering our route.(7) Photos were strictly forbidden: to protect what's left of the grandeur? to censor proof of its decay? (8) The "filled gardens" had only one or two late-blooming autumn roses by a surprisingly modest-sized pool. Perhaps more impressive in springtime. On the plus side, there is a charming Bosphorus-riverside cafe on the grounds with a varied menu and reasonable prices. You don't need to pay for the palace if you only want to visit the cafe--just go through the security check.

Impresive.. This is a true palace. Still has a feeling of grandeur. As opposed to the Topkapi Palace that is not really worth the time. Anyone that has seen Versailles or the Hermitage will be a bit disappointed. Go early in the morning. Buy the tickets on line to avoid the lines. Take the main tour. Skip the "harem tour". Guides' English is tough to understand.

Great place, but horrible tours. Went to the palace today and while I do agree with all the nice words in other reviews here about the palace itself, I've got some mixed feelings. Yes, the palace is marvelous and yes, it shouldn't be missed. But the (required) guided tour is horrible. The tour guide on the first tour, the palace itself, was mumbling and we just couldn't understand him. The group was too big, with around 35 people you just can't reach everyone, especially when one doesn't even try. But okay, we thought; maybe this was an anomaly. However...the tour through the Harem was even worse! This second guide would not qualify as an English speaker anywhere, let alone as a tour guide. The group was much, much bigger this time, with 50+ people and he didn't bother to wait for everyone to arrive. Most of the time he'd already finished his talk when the latter half of the group arrived in the room. So truly, don't skip the Dolmabahce as an attraction but be prepared to receive no information at all from the guided tours. We had a Lonely Planet with us, which was quite detailed and gave us more info than both of the guides combined.

A must in İstanbul.,,. This beautiful Palace must be seen by every foreign visitor as it has full history and related all original furniture and the others.While visiting The Palace you will go through different parts of it and you will also see where Atatürk have passed away.His bed is still there and you are going to be in different mood.Recommended...

Great place, but horrible service. Went to the palace today and while I do agree with all the nice words in other reviews here about the palace itself, I've got some mixed feelings. Yes, the palace is marvelous and yes, it shouldn't be missed. But the (required) guided tour is horrible. The tour guide on the first tour, the palace itself, was mumbling and we just couldn't understand him. The group was too big, with around 35 people you just can't reach everyone, especially when one doesn't even try. But okay, we thought; maybe this was an anomaly. However...the tour through the Harem was even worse! This second guide would not qualify as an English speaker anywhere, let alone as a tour guide. The group was much, much bigger this time, with 50+ people and he didn't bother to wait for everyone to arrive. Most of the time he'd already finished his talk when the latter half of the group arrived in the room. So truly, don't skip the Dolmabahce as an attraction but be prepared to receive no information at all from the guided tours. We had a Lonely Planet with us, which was quite detailed and gave us more info than both of the guides combined.

Beautiful . So opulent and ostentatious! Was quite a site to see. Great views of the Bosphorous outside through the palace gates. Lines to get in as you can only enter on a provided tour group which gets congested as you get blocked up with the individual groups and the group guides which was annoying. Big groups so difficult to hear at times.

Queues and disorganisation mar an interesting place. Arrived early and given a 9.30 tour time but queued until after 10am - random other groups allowed to go in front of us - and when we did get in our guide was told to hurry us through so we got a very abbreviated tour. Harem tour was better - better guide and less frenzied pace. The palace is certainly opulent and the chandeliers are splendid but there was little sense of how it was used and what life was like - although that maybe because of the speed at which we went round.....

Sumptousness unlimited!. This palace is certainly an eye-opener as to the lives of the more recent sultans of the Ottoman Empire. It occupies a glittering position on the banks of the Bosphorus. No expense was spared in building and furnishing it an d it is a wonder to behold.

Brillant!. One of the best attractions in Istanbul. A spectacular palace. Really good tour guides. From the moment you walk up the grand staircase at the start you'll be blown away by the sheer opulence of this place. Closed on Thursdays so make sure you plan ahead. Allow a few hours. There are two seperate tours - one of the main areas and then another of the harem. You might have to wait half an hour or so in between the two tours. An easy 5 minute walk from the last tram stop (Kabbatas) on the main line.

One of the Musts in İstanbul.... Simply the best Palace to be visited in İstanbul on the European Side.Very easy to come by public transportation at a small fee.As all large groups are coming here at any time,so expect some waiting period for entrance.Fantastic view on the Bosphorus with magnificent surroundings.What a rich historical availabilities at the venue!Amazing...

Most spectacular Palace!. This Palace is one of the most underrated places in the World and Istanbul! I have been to most palaces in Europe and this is by far the most impressive. The only drawback here is the lack of organisation as people are rushed through entrance/rooms and no photos are allowed.I think there is nothing to be seen in the Haramlek and you can safely skip that part of the palace!

Beautiful Palace. Worth a visit. Huge palace and very opulent . Amazing to see . We toured with a group from our cruise ship and were very impressed by the beautiful rugs, lights , and furnishings in all the rooms. Intrigued by the simplistic rooms of the Ataturk and how humble his spaces were. Our tour included to harem as well as the gardens. The largest turkish rug in the world was beautiful . We toured on a holiday and the only drawback was the huge crowds due to this holiday. I you have seen the typical Blue masque, Haga Sophia and Topiika Palace, this should be next on your list.

worth seeing if you have time. The place is lavish and immense- GREED and arrogance in the heart of this sultan to build such a place at a time when Istanbul was economically empoverished is unthinkable.I did not have a personal guide - i don't know if it would have been better.I joined the guided in house tour --- there were about 40 of us. It was quick - we had stopped only 4 times for the docent to do her speech. Prior reading of the place PLUS the docent guided tour was Ok for me. But if you have no time to read about the palace i believe it is advisable to get a personal guide. You pay more on top of the entrance fee.Too dusty --- i feel the place needs a MAJOR vacuuming. I coughed horribly. If you have respiratory problem - be prepared. bring your inhaler or do not go.The 2 huge crystal chandeliers has lost its luster. needs cleaning. Some of the gardens are left in disrepair. Well, the huge place needs a lot of money to maintain.

Tourist trap. The Palace was marvelous - both outside and inside. A truly piece of art exploited and ruined by the Turkish government. What a pity.The only way to visit the Palace it's trough an expensive, overcrowded and ridiculously short guided tour.30 tl. to be packed with other 50 people, rushing through the magnificent halls and completing the visit in 35 minutes. Seriously?!ps: no photo allowed inside.

Peep into History. Its a beautiful palace,expansive and a treat to the eyes.But one needs to walk a lot so be ready for it is quite exhausting esp with young kids.Make sure that you get a guided tour which is not very large.We were only 4 members with an elderly tour guide who really had a good knowledge of history and made our tour interesting.The palace gives an insight to the life of royals,the luxuries and lavish lifestyles.The gardens overlooking the Bosphorous are lovely and one could enjoy some eats at a snack stall there.Take ample time in hand if you wish to enjoy the place.Better to book tickets online if possible or arrange them with your guide prior to your visit.

Don't waste your time. My husband and I went to Dolmabahce Palace with expectant hearts, deciding we will spend our last afternoon in Istanbul to look at some lovely architecture soaked rich in history. What a disappointing trip it turned out to be! Apart from the impressive exterior and spacious gardens, the entire experience was marred by the fact we had to be guided in groups to see the interior of the palace. "Guided" is an overstatement as most of the times, I felt like we were just herded like sheep in a crowded production factory. The guide spoke with a dispassionate voice, his annoyance with the group evident on his face. He truly looked like he needed to change his job! The group was way too large for him to manage and his information was only available to those who were at the very front. Many parts of the palace had small corridors to see certain rooms, so a large part of the tour consisted of waiting patiently for our turns to take a quick peek at the rooms and hurrying to try catch up with the guide who had walked on ahead. After a few cycles of this, the whole tour started to feel meaningless because we didn't get to hear any information, even the rooms started to look the same. Interests soon waned among many visitors within the group, people started talking among themselves, not bothering to look at individual rooms. We started feeling like we were stuck in a human jam - unable to accelerate or turn back or end the tour. After the tour ended in the main section, we deliberated if we should proceed to the harem section. "Maybe it will be better," we thought. It wasn't. It was the same procedure of jam-packed into a procession, except this time it was worse. The group was larger and it was clear they were trying to squeeze in as many visitors as they could. At the end of the tour, we walked past the guide - this time, a man who seemed more cheerful, informed and liked his job better. I wouldn't know though, I wasn't close enough to hear a single bit of information from him. Regrettably, I wished I had spent my last afternoon in Istanbul a little better.

Worth seeing but.... This is worth some of your time to see, but I would not rank it as a must see. The major downside is that ou have to be escorted around in a group (ours consisted of about 60 people). It was difficult to hear what our guide was saying, and what I did hear of her emotionless delivery suggested that she was repeating a well-worn script.We only lasted the first 20 minutes and left.\Do also note that the Istanbul Museum pass is not accepted here, and it costs 40YTL to tour the building.

There are better palaces in Istanbul. If you want to be shepherded around an at times rundown country pile and at other times over-the-top palace of excess, with no time to appreciate the good bits and a guide that can barely be heard, the Dolmabahce Palace is for you. Yes, there are nice views from the gardens across the Bosphorous, but that's not enough to justify the entry fee. The palace has no soul. Add to that the fact that you have to queue up to participate in a somewhat painful guided tour with 50 others, and we weren't sorry when it drew to a close. If you go, don't waste any more money on the extra Harem tour. The Selamlik tour is quite enough.

A Faded Jewel on the Bosporus. This palace has some of the loveliest gardens, and the biggest formal stateroom/reception hall I've ever seen! The chandeliers, the endless rooms, corridors with old paintings, artifacts, etc, and the crystal staircase are amazing. It's all faded and in need of renovation, but our guide told us there isn't enough money in the State coffers of Turkey to do the expensive upgrades necessary. Nonetheless, it's well worth the visit. Try to go in late March or early April, because the tulips gardens are a SIGHT to behold!

Breathtaking palace. No other historic attraction could demonstrate the might and glory of the Ottoman dynasty in its latter stages as much as Dolmabahce Palace. Built with a modern western architectural style at the time, the place is filled with precious items that give a glimpse into the lavish lives of the Sultans and their families. A must visit for anyone setting foot in Istanbul in my opinion.

OVER THE TOP - DO NOT MISS. As with Istanbul, this is extravagant, mysterious, and beautiful. The gates to the palace are a review in itself. The gardens are extensive, looking out on the Bosphorus. Inside, where you cannot take pictures, you will remember. Endless rooms of luxury where you can imagine diplomats coming and going. The Harem rooms are not memorable. The Ceremonial Room you will not forget. Go to the Museum shop for detail pictures. Professional photos are outstanding. Get tickets for both the Palace and the Harem. The Harem guide will give a thorough understanding of the Harem for westerners. Don't forget to have something in the Cafe behind the Harem. It is a charming respite after going through such opulence.

Beautiful. I thought from the pictures that this would be another "European" palace. LOved the lighting innovations using the mirrors, etc. Beautiful in all aspects of the palace. Of course the chandeliers took #1 place ---breathtaking even though we had seen Waterford chandeliers in England.

What a place. The last palace of the Ottomans in western design, personally i prefer the Ottomans style, however, it's great place to see put it in your list and try to come early otherwise be ready for a long waiting line for the ticket.
Note: It's not allowed to take photos inside the palace.

Wonderful Palace. I was on the fence about Dolmabahce Palace because it is a pricier tour at 30 TL and I knew you couldn't take photos during the tour but I am really glad I opted to go in. The tour itself was sort of terrible. While waiting outside for my tour time, a parade with various styles of Turkish military came up the path and performed for the crowd. The English tour consisted of around 50 people, most of whom didn't speak English so talked throughout the entire tour. When standing in back you cannot hear anything the guide is saying The palace has moments of great beauty mixed with moments of "dusty old house feel". The chandelier at the end of the tour is huge and beautiful. Don't try to take photos during the tour, you really aren't that stealthy and you will get yelled at and berated by the guide or guards. ("do you understand English? Then why are you taking photos!?!")(Very funny for me, not so funny for the guy trying to take photos.) The highlight, and only reason I am rating it a 4, comes after the tour when they release you into the grounds between the Bosphorous and the Palace itself. It is a great place to take photos or just to sit out and enjoy the weather. The cafe was also delicious, but be wary of the cats, they will climb on the table to get at your food even with you yelling and swating at them.

A palace with grandeur. I really liked Dolmabahce Palace. Honestly, I would not be able to advise anyone if he/ she has to choose between it and Topkapi Palace which of the two palaces is better. They are different and definitely worth visiting. In Dolmabachce the visitor is part of an organized tour that impedes the free walking around the halls but on the other hand the guide in English/ Turkish/ Russian can summarize for you a whole bunch of information that you will not be able to search yourself. We had the luck to have a fantastic guide during our tour.The palace is a bit distant from the city center, unlike Topkapi but there is convenient public transport (Tram 1) going there. The close proximity to the sea makes the palace more majestic.

Horrible tour. We had wonderful experiences in istanbul but this was not one of them. The rating is a comment on the experience rather than the site. Our English speaking tour consisted of about 50 people, mostly non English speakers, who chattered loudly throughout. The guide was bored and mechanical, and with such a large group we were never able to catch up before she had finished her spiel. We had no chance to look at the paintings, the carpets, the artifacts, all the myriad of interesting and beautiful things that flashed past us. The ways this tour is designed is really awful, and at the price, not worth the visit.

Dolmabahce sarayi. A must see in istanbul. The architecture looks much different than topkapi. 45 minute guided tour in the administrative building. great halls and lovely chandelier. photographs not allowed inside the palace. entry tickets sold at 30 TL. loved the place. lovely view of the bosphorous.

I missed it. i rate it excellent based on pictures, history and friends. I couldn't visit it because i knew it was closed on Monday and thursday and they omitted to state that also they close on Holidays. No one knew. Check before you go

Dolmabahçe Palace. We visited the palace on the recommendation of someone on our Istanbul tour, as the palace was not part of the tour. We were glad we did! The chandelier is something, as is one of the great staircases with crystal. We also enjoyed the Harem, the residential apartments of the family of the Sultan, which are a separate part of the Palace tour.

The Group was way too large for one guide to lead!. There were between 50 and 60 people in our English language tour and the guide never made an attempt to wait until we were all assembled before she started speaking. I regret not hiring one of the local tour guides who were offering their services at the palace's entrance. It cost our family of four 160 tl, one of the more expensive sightseeing attractions we picked and certainly the most disappointing.

Great site. This site is absolutely beautiful. a little out of the way from where we were in the old city section, but well worth the trip. It is extensive. but there is so much to see. Absolutely stunning views along the sea, amazing art and architecture. And all that history. We were very glad to get a tour guide with this one. You need to make an appointment or you wind up waiting. Our guide was able to get us in at the appropriate time, plus having someone explain everything there (and it is expansive) was a really good idea.

Not to be missed. We toured the palace in the afternoon when our ship docked. It was an easy walk from the cruise port to the palace.Each tour is led by a guide. Ours was great. She spoke clearly and the large group paid attention.The rooms were stunning and huge. A big plus is that the original furniture is in all the rooms were saw. The furniture and carpets were fabulous as well as the the huge crystal chandeliers.No photos are allowed but they have books in the gift shop.Only thing is that this palace is far from the old city and sites.If you have time see the palace!

Stunning opulence. We were lucky to have a tour just before the regular English language tour, as we had a guide with us. This meant we were not bumping into other groups as we went round and our guide had time to fill us in with some of the history. The rooms are out of this world, particularly the one where the chandelier presented by Queen Victoria is hanging. The palace is extraordinarily large and no wonder it led to the bankruptcy of the Sultanate. Such extravagance and opulence, quite breathtaking. The only thing I regret is that the State does not manage to keep it a bit cleaner. I was itching to take a duster to lots of the statues! I guess over 300 rooms take a bit of looking after.

history and art. The place itself is impressive. A lot of artfacts, carpets and interesting facts about the life of the Sultan and its harem. Also, this place used to be very important in the modern history of Istanbul, since the famous Ataturk had his office and residence there, too. A lot of diplomats were passing the gates of this palace, and many important subjects were discussed inside. Take into consideration that daily there are a maximum number of visitors, so in order to make sure you enter inside, check in morning. Opening time is 10:00. Also, Monday and Thursday Dolmabahce is closed. Reserve at least 2 hours for this palace.

Visit the Palace - Skip the Harem. Came here via cruise ship and as this was our 2nd time in Istanbul, we opted to visit Dolmabahce. From the Kabatas tram station, it is less than a 10 minute walk. They open promptly at 9 am and tickets are 20 liras including the Harem. However, if you don't want to see the Harem, it is 15 liras just for the Palace. I would recommend skipping it if you have already seen the Harem in Topaki Palace. The Harem there is better.The outside doesn't look too much but the interior really blew us away. Tours are guided and lasts 45 minutes. The Harem tour lasted 30 minutes and must be guided as well. The interior is gorgeous and it was really impressive. Definitely visit here if you have seen the sites in Sultanahmet before. You won't be sorry!

Beautiful exterior. Beautiful exterior, photos not allowed inside. Administrative section was stunning with amazing rooms, gorgeous chandeliers etc. Harem was disappointing - everything looked more gray and tattered, I'd recommend skipping this part.
another must see site. the display of artifacts is extensive and gives you a lasting impression of how the Sutlans and their entourage enjoyed the trappings of their postion

A rare jewel in Bosphorus. It is the most luxurious palace in the city. Only the Topkapi Palace rivals it.It is worth visiting it, although the guided tour are weak, expensive and full of restrictions. (for ex.: no photos allowed).Outside the palace there are many wonderful gardens and gates.

Very nice European style palace near the sea. Ok, so if there is any advice I'd want you to take away is to please visit this palace instead of trampling along with the Topkapi crowds. This is the palace to see in Istanbul as I've found the Rococo style quite "refreshing" after the simplicity of Topkapi. I've read reviews of people comparing it to Versailles, but I'd say they got carried away a little with the metaphors and epithets. Still it's definitely on the "to see" list for Istanbul. The location, just near the sea with it's beautiful baroque gates, magnificient stairs and exquisite Ceremonial Hall. However they do go out of their way to make you uncomfortable assigning you to a guide who's purpose I think it's to shepherd you as fast as possible to the exit. We got there early so it did not feel that was necessary, but I've seen the queue that was forming as we exited so yeah, it's definitely not possible to sit around more and look around by yourself.Also a strict NO PICTURES policy inside(which never makes sense to me as long as they don't care about blitz) and for this I pay them back by dropping the review score by -1. But do go if you have the chance!

Stunning Palace on the Bosphorus. This is certainly worth a visit. The last palace of the Ottomans just drools luxury with Baccarat seemingly endless. The crystal staircase is amazing. It speaks to a lifestyle long gone but let your imagination run and envisage what life must have been like! Suitable for all ages.

Nice palace, poor tour. Only guided tours available for 30TL. Fairly large groups makes it difficult to hear tour guide but it didn't matter as my tour guide was too dull to spark any interest from the group. You must wear plastic booties over your shoes, not allowed to deviate from the paths, no photos, no touching, etc. Considering the size of the palace, the tour is very limited and its over in 45 minutes. Yes the alabaster bathroom and 4.5 ton chandelier is impressive but the tour needs improvement.

A piece of history. Great palace for the last 5 Sultans and the great Ataturk leader.Great gardens and a nice tour guides that explain all the miracles of the Ottoman Imperium. Believed or not this great palace was built in only 13 years, started by a young sultan - 16 years old - and with 100.000 people working together.Must see it, in words is not very good way to explain what you can see.

European Style palace. Very beautiful garden ! Interesting history and legends. Construction of palace was made from Turkish sultan so to embrace European way of leaving. There is no need to be so strict with photos as these rules almost do not apply anymore to any European museum. You should visit !

excellent to visit ! totally worthy .................. amazing palace ! the guide speaks english clearly with the details of crystal ...........need to keep close to him to hear. worth to spend some time @ dolmabachce.
Atatürk was here. Interesting palace where Atatürk spent his last days and died. The guided tours are rather old fashioned and only in Turkish.

Great European- style palace, bad tour. Located on the banks of the Bosphorus, Dolmabahce palace is among the most famous and distinguishable sights in Instanbul. In contrast to Topkapi, this palace was built in western- style architecture and does not differ from royal palaces in mainland Europe. Built between 1843 and 1856, Dolmabahce has been the residence of Sultans until the end of the Osman Empire. After that, it bacame Ataturk’s seat of government and later, as Ankara was named capital of Turkey, Ataturk’s residence in Istanbul. It’s also the place where Ataturk perished in 1939. The clock in his former sleeping room still indicates the time of his death (9:05 am).Visitors to Dolmabahce palace should be aware that guided tours are obligatory. And this is my main point of criticism: I usually prefer to hire audio- guides or buy guidebooks in order to tour individually as this enables me to spend as much time as I want at an attraction. My tour guide was nice and probably knowledgeable, however the tour was rushed and I did not have any time to enjoy the beautiful decorations and furniture. In addition, there were so many people in my group that it was difficult to understand what the tourguide was talking. Besides that, rules for visitors are far too strict as taking photos is prohibited and everone had to wear protective sheets for shoes (what is not even the case at most medieval attractions).Apart from the interior, also the gardens should not be missed. I highly recommend to walk around the palace as the landscape gardening is an attraction by itself. As the palace is surrounded by high walls on one side and by the Bosphorus on the other side, one has to take a boattrip on the Bosphorus in order to see the façade of the palace. In my opinion, the most beautiful view can be enjoyed from Uskudar, a district on the Asian side of Istanbul. To summarize, I enjoyed my visit at Dolmabahce palace as the architecture, interior and gardens are marvellous and the place is of high historical importance. However, authorities should really change their strict rules for visitors. Given the high entrance fee, the tour was bad quality. These points of criticism make me rate it 3 star. Otherwise, a 5 star ranking would probably be justified.
Mind blowing!. The most opulent place you could imagine. Guided tours only, so keep close to the guide to hear the commentary.

Western Style Palace with Turkish Flair. I found this palace quite beautiful but given how many palaces I had seen in Europe in the preceding couple of weeks... it was just another palace even if it did have a bit of eastern flair. Plus you had to do a guided tour that was average at best. I did like the aviary though make sure you walk the grounds to find it.

Beautiful !!!. This palace is the second palace inhabited by the royal family of the Ottoman Empire. It was built when the empire was in decline and is very European in design and furnishings. The Sultan wanted to be like the Europeans, so ornate furnishings in the spirit of Versailles are found everywhere. The grounds are beautiful and well kept. Do try to see this site when you visit the city.

Poorly organised visits of a nice palace. Rather nice palace built in the XIXth century after the Napoleonic style. Extravagant halls with incredible chandeliers, French or British (4.5 tons: the biggest chandelier in the world!). The problem is the fact that you are not allowed to visit it on your own. You have to be part of a group, and you will have a guide, Turkish-speaking, or English-speaking. Our English-speaking guide (was is English?) was a woman who shouted at the top of her high-pitched voice to be heard (but not understood) by the roughly 100 persons in our group. I did not understand 10% of what she recited like a machine. Overall a disappointing visit.

Excellent architecture - so so tour guides. We visited Istanbul and went to the Dolmabahce Palace with friends on a weekend. It was a very busy weekend and wait to get into the palace building was a bit long. The palace grounds are very beautifully landscaped and viewing the building from the outside is worth in itself. However, once you enter the palace another world completely opens up. Opulence of the palace is astounding.However, the negative part is that you can only go through the palace on a tour and generally in large groups you do not have enough time to absorb the information or really look at things that might interest you individually.If you have a chance see if you can book a private tour. We went on a group tour and at times it was difficult to understand the guide or ask questions. It might be worthwhile to spend a bit more and enjoy the experience.

Should Not be Missed. This beautiful palace is often overlooked since reservations are required to visit it. It rivals palaces throughout Europe in grandeur and splendor. The beautifully preserved furnishings, carpets and chandeliers provide an important insight into how the Sultans lived. The palace is huge and only a moderate portion is available for viewing. Even so, more than an hour is needed to walk through the various rooms. Sadly, no photos are permitted while inside.For anyone with an appreciation of architecture, antique furniture or Ottoman history, a visit here is a must. While it does not have the extensive gardens and grounds of Versailles or Peterhof, its location on the Bosphorous and views of Istanbul make quite a beautiful setting.

Dolmabahce Palace. It's a wonderful palace just 10 minutes walk from Taksim Square located on the side of fantastic Bosphorous. The people guided to the palace are in large groups that sometimes you are not able to hear the guide tour explanations. The private tours have a kind of priviledge to the people who purchased tickets by themselves. But it values to be visited in any circumstances.

Don't go out of your way to see. I felt like i was looking at a palace that Liberace created. Go if you have the time but i wouldn't go out of your way. It reminded me of Vegas, gold gold gold gold and the biggest crystal chandeliers EVER. If your into super extravagence then go but don't expect a lot of interesting history to go along with this place.

European influenced Istanbul Palace. Just like any Europian palaces - Dolmabahce palace is just as grand and magnificent. This place is well maintained in fact we looked at my husband's photos taken 15 years ago to our recent photos and it looked exactly the same. Great work maintaining this place. The surroundings are amazing and very clean. You can easily spend half a day here!My negative comments are:- The lines at the ticketing counter is quite long and there is also a line to go inside the palace.- They take you inside the palace by groups, one is in English and the other tour is in Turkish and the wait could take hours! Not very pleasant on a very hot day.- Strictly No photos inside although we sneaked some lolTip: Avoid eating at their cafeteria outside the palace overlooking the river, it was bad and we got sick

The Turkish Versailles. We visited this site on our last full day in Istanbul. We paid to see both areas of the palace and while it was interesting and especially beautiful, I wish they would have taken smaller groups on the tour of everything and provided more history about the various rooms and the actual building of the palace. However, with that being said it is definitely worth the 40 TL to see this palace because the one massive chandelier and the room where it is housed is amazingly beautiful. The ceilings are so high that it made me dizzy when I was looking up. Definitely worth a visit.

Unmissable!!. We culd easily have missed thi off our radar if it hadnt been reccommended by a friend who used to live in Istanbul.Located on the Bosphorous, just 10 mins walk from Taksim, this was a fantastic half day out.Harem worth the extra £4 to see.Amazing chandalliers weighing up to 4.5 tons, symmetrical staircases & the most amazing fional room that takes your breath away. The Sultans sort of copied Versailles/Hampton Court/Peterhof Palaces AND MORE....Really strict about no photos inside, and will make people delete or confiscate you camera. Be Careful!!Great Experience. Unmissable, really

Great view. This palace is a great place inside and out, it's just few meters from kabatas tram station so it's easily accessed. the only thing is that for visiting the inside of the palace and harrem there is no individual visit and u have to wait for group tours, this makes it a long day at the palace, it took us 3 hours to see both harrem and palace so if u're planning to visit make sure you have time and don't have to be somewhere sharp. Enjoy :)

"wow" is all I can say!. I saw this impressive palace on the Bosphorus while on a boat cruise and really wanted to see it. A couple of days later, I took a tram (no need for bus or taxi) and joined a guided group tour. It was a big group and there was no mike but I stood close to the guide. Also, as other visitors said here, no photos are allowed inside - which is a shame - but quite understandable as it has a lot of delicate and expensive decorations. Nevertheless, this is one of the most beautiful palaces I've ever seen. Don't leave Istanbul without seeing the Dolmabahce!

Beautiful palace, bad visiting conditions. This is a very beautiful palace with a great position on the Bosphorus shore. The architecture and decorations are impressive and beautiful. Visits are allowed only in groups, accompanied by a palace guide. Unfortunately, our tour was disappointing: we could barely hear the guide's indications and no audio or printed information is offered. We were generally hasted from one room to another, so the entire tour lasts less than 45 minutes. From what we could hear, the information was generally limited to the size of carpets in each room and the fact that chandeliers are made of Baccarat crystal; little details about the life of the sultans living in the palace and too much details about the activity and life of president Ataturk. The palace is packed with policemen supervising the tourists. Tickets can only be bought with cash, they do not accept cards. If the visiting conditions would be improved just a bit, seeing this palace could be a wonderful experience.

Beautiful palace beside the river.. C1 ( 2013.08.11 ) There was very beautiful palace, and architecture in the palace was wonderful. This palace's tour was good because guide explained point to point. and big palace was very good everywhere I walked. Along the guide course, I enjoyed this palace with good feelings.

Impressive palace. Really impressive palace. The tour is guided, no single visit allowed, no camera allowed. When it comes to topic how to reach this place, you do not have to worry. We were staying in Sultanahmed area and we have been told to take tram T1 - direction Kabatas and then take bus. Do not bother yourself with searching the bus stop, we were just simply walking from the Kabatas and we were suprised how close it was. Dolmahable palace should not be missed. Interier, garderns, views are just great !

Not worth it, here's why. If you're into historical sites, this is a let down. The guided tour is horrible, it's basically in groups of 100, and our tour guide was mediocre at best. It's cattle time. It's a modern building relative to other buildings you'll see, so other than the size and a couple of marble floors, it's just a big building. Was a disappointment, especially compared to Topkapi Palace. If you're in town for 4+ days, sure, but if you're pressed for time this is one you can skip and not miss much

Wonderful setting. This building is an absolute feast for the eyes from the stunning gardens, ironwork and architecture to the luxurious and decedent furnishings. Ideally, it is a place to wander through at your own pace but sadly, you can now only follow a tour rep. The tour is not at a slow and leisurely pace but instead you are herded through like cattle and watched constantly by security guards to prevent you taking photos. Our guide had the tone of a mosquito that was so annoying, we kept dropping back and joining the Chinese tour as that was preferable! There is so much to see that it's not possible at such a fast pace to take it all in however, it is definitely a sight worth seeing and at least you can relax in the gardens.

Dolmabahce - The Crystal Palace. I loved this Palace, based on the European style of palace, crystal chandeliers in just about every room, wonderful furniture and colourful gardens. Ahmed our guide was excellent, and told us that the palace was built between 1843 and 1856. Kemal Ataturk passed away in his bedroom in the Palace. So full of history. It is situated on reclaimed land by the beautiful Bosphorus, is so well maintained and just beautiful. Would recommend it to all who can appreciate the finer things in life! I believe it has 285 rooms, 43 salons and 6 Turkish baths! No photos allowed, but postcards can be bought featuring all the magnificent rooms.

Amazing Palace with Beautiful Gardens. This is a must visit in Istanbul. A lot of tourists miss it out as it is not a main attraction but it should be. It is much more impressive then Topkapi Palace in my opinion. I visited with some friends on a Thursday we got a ticket straight away our tour started within half an hour. We spent the half hour walking around the beautiful gardens, taking pictures and taking in the spectacular views from the palace. Our tour guide spoke very good english and was extremely informative. The guide lasted around 40 mins but did not feel like 40 mins. The time passed by very quickly, It was one of the best places I visited in Istanbul. I would definitely visit it again and recommend it to future tourists a must see :).

Dry and dusty tour.. A tour of the Dolumbache Palace is no fun in August. The gardens are beautiful though, but the experience is one of bad tempered security people and a dry, dry tour. In my humble opinion the Dolumbache is not a world class jewel but the grumpy security guys insist on medical-type plastics over shoes. The Vatican Palace doesn't have them, the Louvre doesn't have them and no other place of interest has them in my experience. No photographs either. Ive lots of photos of the Sistine Chapel and no flash pics from the Louvre. There is little to photograph to be truthful, but by crickey the guards are aggressively alert to anyone trying. It's room after room of dry dusty furniture and half way through I was tired of the whole thing. It was August, it was hot ok, but its August in Paris and Rome with all their treasures. Later in the week we were in Naples. We walked around the Royal Palace unhindered by aggressive guards and rooms filled with beautiful objects and paintings........and no surgical foot covering.
Stunning Gardens. We didn't have time to join the tour but the Gardens are fantastic and the area with various birds(Peacock, Pheasant, Guinea Fowl, Bantams) was entertaining

poorly organized, poor tour. A recent Tuesday in August visit was most disappointing and quite gruelling. With temperatures around 37, we were forced to wait in a long queue for an hour, in the sun, to even buy a ticket, then again 45 minutes to actually enter the palace itself. It is only possible to visit in guided groups, and our group was 70 people (we counted). One could not hear most of what the guide said, and in any case, she only gave a brief introduction and then two stops en route and then thanked us at the end. It was more like a route march, in sweltering conditions, no time to stop and see anything or even read the few labels throughou the palace. Tours were provided in Turkish, Russian, and English. Naturally, the English tour attracted people of many different language backgrounds, and so part of the reason we couldn't hear the guide was that many people on the tour couldn't understand her anyway and resorted to chattering instead. Given the language mix of the visitors, at least that day, they should provide Arabic tours. But they should also train the guides in basics like facing their audience, and with a large group not standing at one end of it but closer to the middle. We then also toured the harem, and although that wait was only about 20 minutes, it was all the same problems. I found this all the more disappointing as I had visited this palace once before, February half a dozen years ago, and it was enchanting. Small group of a dozen or so people, no heat-stroke-inducing lines, and a wonderful tour with far more information and a well-paced walkthrough. I still recommend visiting, but it could be anywhere from a wonderful experience to a gruelling route-march, based on my two separate visits!

Truly breathtaking..could never regret visiting dolmabahce.. Many people skip dolmabahce as it isn't in the main area which I think is SUCH a shame! It is over the top ottoman style which makes you realise you are in Turkey and takes you to another time. Have been to dolmabahce a few times with different visitors and cannot recommend it more. Great to see after Topkapi palace to see where the sultans moved from. I actually had a "take your breath away" moment in the ceremonial hall(?) at the end. Go early in the morning and if you can tee it up with a visit to the Sunday ortakoy markets for lunch.

My favorite in the world!!!!. I dont lie when Im saying this is my favorite palace in the world. Its amazing, you have to be very patient the guides don't speak very good english so make sure you study it before. The visits are guided, and the palace is kept very much the way it was in the past. You cant miss it. Been there 3 times in 5 years.
Opulence. I've visited a lot of Palaces in my days but have never seen anything so luxurious and opulent. It's impressive and intimidating at the same time. I loved it!!

Wow- what a glorious place! Imagine living here in the past, a MUST SEE!!. This is the most excessively beautifully decorated palace I have ever seen. 14 tons of gold in gilding. 1 4.5 ton glass chandelier from England, multiple 2.5 ton chandeliers, crystal balustrades, massive reception halls. This is a must see in Istanbul.

Dolmabahce palace. We visited the palace this morning. We took on board the comments about queuing, and arrived at 10AM. There was no queue to get tickets. You do have to queue for the tour which was at 10.45 in English, but this was not too long.Once in the palace we agree that the guides seem disinterested. Due to the guide speaking English with a thick Turkish accent it was difficult to understand or hear him. We stayed at the front of the tour group whenever possible to hear him. Interestingly his English was perfect and clear when he reminded us on 3 occasions Not to take photographs!Having said this the palace is opulently grand and the gardens beautiful and well worth visiting.When we came out at 12.30PM the queue for tickets was very long, and estimated about 40 to 60 minutes. The palace is closed Monday and Thursday.

Beautiful Ottoman Palace. Well kept and quite interesting.Grounds are nice and location on Bosphorus sea front is lovely.Rooms are OK but nothing special with the exception of the Ceremonial Hall which is spectacular. However to control people congestion you have to be in a tour group and are hurried around. The tour guides try but you have very little time and 60+ people in the group. There is little to no information posted. Ataturk rooms could be the most interesting, but far to little time or information available to be appreciated. A final frustration is a No Photos rule.

Nice place, but no pictures or individual walks. The palace is very nice and grand. But you are not allowed to take any pictures. Also you have only group walks in the palace and have to keep in between the ropelines, so no individual exploration of this museum. After going through this palace we decided that the harem, that had the same system, was not worth it to spend another 1,5-2 hours and we skipped it.

Be sure to visit it!. Wonderfull palace ... everything and even more what u expect from it! Beautifull architecture and furniture. One thing though ... the guides are horrible and their english is even worse! So make sure u do your history research before visiting this palace and u will even enjoy it alot more!

dream from another era. The garden is a poem, the palace is old and full of precious items, furniture of the Otoman empire era and the personnel really look anxious in protecting the premises. You will be asked to wear protective plastic shoes the floors and the rags are hundreds of years old. Excellent!

The highlight is the Grand Ceremonial Hall. Dolmabahce Palace is great in 2 aspects: the fantastic location next to the Bosphorus and the Grand Ceremonial Hall. The moment I stepped into the Grand Ceremonial Hall, my jaw dropped at the awesome sight of the cavernous hall. The ceiling is very high with a chandelier weighing 4 tonnes which according to the guide is the largest in Europe. The ceiling and wall paintings, the columns and architecture of the hall are impressive. I agree with most of the 'Poor' and 'Terrible' reviews in TripAdvisor so I won't repeat those. I arrived around 3pm on a Saturday and I got my ticket within minutes. Compared to Versailles, the garden was not impressive and luckily, small so it was a short walk to the entrance of Dolmabahce. Near the entrance, everybody just waited and the electronic signboard will show the times for the next English- or Turkish-language tour and it was mandatory to follow a guide. They will allow private tour groups with their own guides. I waited around 30 mins and the crowd grew but the staff did nothing to control the crowd except to tell people 'no photography'. When the guide is ready, the crowd just surged forward through the guard scanning the tickets. The guide was showing signs of irritation because he had to raise his voice, to constantly ask people to respect the rules like no photography and sometimes even asking people to stop talking among themselves. People at the back couldn't hear him clearly or couldn't understand English properly so they talked amongst themselves. A Korean family even wandered off on their own and a security staff herded them back. He couldn't police everybody so some snapped photos. He even threatened to call the police if the culprits did not stop taking photograph (I am not joking!). The experience was severely marred when a toddler cried while he was speaking in the very impressive Grand Ceremonial Hall. The guide lost his temper and told off the parents. Is it not obvious that the root of the problem is the huge size of the tour group? I really don't see the rationale about no photography and the compulsory tour. In Versailles, Lourves and many European museums with famous paintings, photography without flash is allowed. The Dolmabahce guide explained that tourist could buy their postcards but seriously, the photograph of the Grand Ceremonial Hall inside their brochure did no justice to the grandness of the hall. The compulsory tour is the worst point of this palace. It is as if the administration was still stuck in the Hittite era and have not of heard of audio guides. Seriously, rent out audio guides to tourists, make them walk along red carpeted lanes (which is already the case) and cordon off areas (which is already done) AND allow us bloody freedom to roam. Make the guided tour non-compulsory and everyone, tourists and staff will be happier this way. Until then, I would suggest visitors to book private tour group to visit especially during busy period.

Apotheosis of Bohemian crystals. The Palace is an example of the Ottoman Empire glamour. The cost of the building was the equivalent of 35 tonnes of pure gold! It's a fantastic Palace with excessive luxury.It has unique features, like the baccarat crystal staircase and the famous Bohemian crystal chandelier, world's largest, with 750 lamps, weighing 4.5 tonnes. Up to now the chandelier was supposed to be Queen Victoria's special gift to the Sultan. But our guide said that after new research they found out that Turkey had paid for that. I can't know the truth. The fact is that it's very,very impressive.There is also a lot of history linked with the Palace and the deathbed of modern Turkey's founder and President Kemal Atatürk is among the historical exhibits.No photos are allowed inside the Palace and the tours run very quickly because there is always long queuing outside.Even so, the visit remains an unforgettable experience.The gardens are spectacular, with amazing gates and excellent views to busy Bosphorus. Visiting Istanbul, Dolmabahçe is a must.

Beautiful Palace that must be seen !. This is a must see for anyone going to Istanbul. The last palace of the then almost crumbling Ottoman Empire. The building was built to show that the Empire was still strong and was done with a lot of opulence and splendour. Our tour guide was fantastic and I would recommend him to anyone. His name is Serhat and he works for Istanbul Walks. Very knowledgable guide who speaks good English.

A spectacular Palace, very European and magnificent.. Dolmabahce was built in European style to compete to Versailles, so you can imagine the luxury it displays. It is simply magnificent. The sultans who inhabited it before 1923 left it in a hurry, so everything in the palace is preserved as it was during the Ottoman era. Dolmabahce was later the home of Kemal Atatürk, the father of modern Turkey. You can visit Atatürk´s chamber, and other marvelous rooms with spectacular chandeliers and carpets. There is gold leaf everywhere. The last room you visit, the Ceremonial Hall, has the biggest and most spectacular chandelier I have seen. The place is worth a visit. From the Sultanahmet area, you need to take a tramway (which costs very little) and it takes about 10 minutes at the most to reach the palace. It is not allowed to take photos inside Dolmabahce.

Beautiful Palace. The Dolmabahce Palace is centrally situated in Istanbul. Very easily accessible by public transport and near to Taksim Square. Queues were absent when buying tickets but took us approx 15 minutes to gain entry into the palace. Free guided tours of the palace. When purchasing tickets one should buy the full palace tour ticket which enables you to enter all parts of palace.Gardens are exceptional and views from palace grounds overlooking Sea of Marmara is quite a sight.

This is a Palace. We were advised to go early to visit this palace, as the queques can be long. We only had to wait about 10 minutes for the English tour, so we were lucky. The gardens and grounds are beautiful and you can take photos of the gardens and buildings and wander around there at your leisure. The tour is pretty quick and you do need to concentrate on the guide. We had some Asians speaking very loudly next to us and I had to ask them to "shh". We bought tickets for both the palace and the harem, which we all agreed was worth the price. The history is amazing and the palace is fabulous. Just a pity that you cannot take photos, but of course the postcards are available.

Be there early. Be sure to get to this palace right when they open. We had heard that it was best to be there early and boy am I glad we started our day there. We got right in, no problem. But as we were finishing and heading back out the gate, the lines were unbelievable. The palace really is nice though. Word of caution, they absolutely do not allow pictures to be taken. We had a guard following our group most of the time and he took a woman's camera away from her after he caught her taking pics several times.

Iconic place. Istanbul's iconic place, it is huge and extremely hot, as we visited in August; crowed of course. Luckily, we had a private guide who fast tracked us bypassing enormous crowds. Expect to queue if you have not booked. Avoid toilets if you can, absolutely disgusting. No flush....! Astonishing that with all the entrance fees, the Turkish authorities are incapable of maintaining such important facilities in working order. Nevertheless an important place to see, we'll maintained original features and I am glad we took the time to visit.

Nice palace, but be ready to wait… and get close to the guide to hear what he/she says!. Nice palace, but be ready to wait… and get close to the guide to hear what he/she says!During our last day in Istanbul, we decided to go to Dolmabahce palace. We did not think it was really worth it. We had to wait for the guide. We were a group of 50 for the « English visit ». The guide did not have any type of microphone or else… So either we were close to the guide… or we could not hear him. The visit (with the harem) took us approximately 3 hours (no choice there… we have to follow the group)… So… be ready to wait… and to adapt to the weather, as there is obviously no air conditioning inside (it was approximately 35-38 C when we did it…).

more detail tour needed. its is an amazing place..i wounder how the occupant used to remember their direction.. no photographs allowed.. they charge TL 40 for both the palace and hareem , and rush you around, the tour end at the far end of the palace then you have to walk more than a mile to get you back to the front entrance ,stroller not allowed..still it is worth to visit

beautiful. Absolutely beautiful place, with lots of crystal everywhere, including the balustrades of the staircase. No photography allowed inside though and we had to use plastic bags on our shoes to protect the carpets. Right beside the river. No wonder the Sultans chose this place as their last place to live in.

Grand But Would Have Liked More In-depth Tour. The comments on the extravagance and elegance were spot on. It is so much more decorated than Versailles. But Versailles' grounds are unrivaled. The tour is conducted by Palace staff and are indeed, rushed and not very substantial. There is so much history and I felt like they barely skimmed the surface. Am I glad I went? Yes. Would I recommend it? Yes, but perhaps do some of your own reading before taking the tour if you have the time.

Sultan wifes houses. This is one of the best othmani palacies in istanbul. It is devided into three sections, Sultan main hous, Wifes apartments and guests section. Tickests has three values for the three sections, for only tow and the cheapest is only for the wifes housed. It worth the time and money but lacks more workers to guide people. Make sue you ask before taking the line to ensure you are on the right one, as they have three lines every one is divided in to, for Turkish speekers and the other is for English speekers.

Beautiful but rushed. This amazing palace would be so much better with audio tours and do-it-yourself guided tours. The time slots for the tours are every hour but in summer the tour groups are WAY to big so it crowded and rushed to see, you can't linger to stare at beautiful object d'art

worth seeing if you have time. Over the top and very overly decorated said to have influenced the Versailles. The palace is large and rivals the great palaces in Europe. The main halls are decorated with massive chandeliers and ornate reliefs and paintings. There are great views of the Bosphorus from the interior chambers and the gardens are beautiful. The entrance fees are steep given that this palace is not as significant as the other sites in old Istanbul area.It is accessible and on the laststop of the T1 line.

They don't accept the Muze Kart. Beautiful but no photos allowed. They talked more about the things inside than about the histor. We went on an early Wednesday morning and had a short line and 10 min wait. They did not accept muze kart. This policy should be changed, and they should accept it. Beautiful to walkaround outside of palace. Beautiful articles but didn't go into any of the details or significance of each. Didn't address any of the historic decisions made from there. We overheard small, privately hired tour guides (probably from cruise ships) giving much better tours with more information. Our tour barely covered Ataturk's life in the palace.

Somewhat Over the Top. Based on many of the great palaces of Europe, Dolmabache was the Sultan's summer retreat on The Bosphorus.Incorporating a crystal staircase and four and a half ton chandelier, sent by Queen Victoria (how did she get that to the Post Office?) this is the type of place that would have made Lenin fume and Louis XIV homesick. Personal highlight was The Sultan's toilet. Like everybody else he just had a simple hole in the ground but his was much bigger and made of solid marble. A bit cold to crouch over I would have thought.

The most amazing place !. It is a royal, magical and breathtaking place with a beautiful gardens !! Don't miss Dolmabahce! You can also visit the caffee outside near the parking where you can sit near the sea and dream calmly while contemplating the beauty of Istanbul and the serenity of the Bosphore.

Dont touch anything!!!. Grand, expensive, luxurious and regal. Everything about this palace is large and hyper. This attraction is not at the heart of Sultanahmet, but should definitely be on your to do list. Expect to be marvelled by everything in the palace and take your breath away. But remember not to touch anything!! Enjoy.

We nearly missed this gem!. For some reason, this palace is not on everyone's list. Perhaps it is because it is not in Sultanahmet along with the other iconic attractions. We were a little bemused by the process when we arrived and eventually worked out that we could only see the palace as part of a guided tour. We had to don blue plastic shoe covers and wait our turn for about 35 minutes, and there was limited seating. The tours alternated between English and Turkish. There seemed to be some confusion as to who was on which tour. I suggest a sign in English should have directed people to blue booties and a sign in Turkish to some other colour, then we would have been immediately identifiable.I thought that the tour was too fast at the beginning but when you realised how extensive the palace was, and how many different rooms, it made sense not to dawdle. Be aware that there are lots of stairs. The European opulence (Baroque, Neoclassical and Rococo), made an interesting contrast with the comparatively sparse decorations of the Topkapi Palace. The pinnacle was the Grand Ballroom with its chandelier and very clever Trompe L'Oeil.There were lovely views from the windows of the Bosphorus accompanied by gentle breezes. The guides accent was a bit hard to understand which surprised us for such a prominent site but don't let that deter you. We were very glad that we had visited this palace.

Not to be missed. A magnificant palace, very well preserved and maintained, a must see while in Istanbul, the view on the asian side and the bosphorus is quiet amazing, sit on in the cafe outside after your visit, have a cup of tea and enjoy the view.
A must-do!. Even if you have little time in İstanbul you should spend some of it in Dolmabahçe Palace. It is different from other historical places, it is better than most of them.

Stunning palace ... too bad about the tour. Dolmabahce is a beautiful palace.  No money or effort was speared in its construction in the mid-1850s. The rooms are massive, wonderfully decorated and there are enough crystal chandeliers to light up a small town. Some of my favourites were the crystal staircase (the hand railing is supported by crystal spindles) and the incredibly ornate and large receiving room which opens up onto the Bosphorus. There are two tours a available - the Harem and the Selamlik.  You can buy a combo ticket which gives you access to both guided tours. If your time is limited my suggestion is to only do the Selamlik as it is on this tour you will see the grand rooms of the palace. The day we toured (a Friday) we took the 10:05am Selamlik tour followed by the 11:20am Harem tour (both in English). The Selamlik tour takes a out 45 minutes while the Harem about 30 minutes. I have two big beefs about the public tours - they cram way too many people on them and they rush through the palace providing only scant detail about the rooms, their significance and information on any artifacts (you are encouraged to ask questions).

Don't miss Dolmabahce Palace!. My husband and I recently visited the Dolmabahce Palace at the end of June. We considered taking a small group tour. All tour companies grossly overcharge for this visit. It is so easy to do independently. With the money you will save, you can buy yourself a nice souvenir. We took the tramway to Kabatas. Taking the tram is so easy and it is air conditioned.We walked along the water with the Bosphorus to our right. After about 5 minutes you will pass a mosque with very slender minarets. You have just about arrived! So easy. Plan on getting there prior to opening at 9:30 a.m. to avoid the crowds. You cannot tour the palace or the harem on your own-you have to take one of their tours. You will be amazed. The gardens are incredibly lovely. We had lunch nearby with a gorgeous Bosphorus view.

Impressive palace that did not impress me. True this is European style and in contrast to Ottoman architecture. But if you have been to Versailles in France, Windsor in UK or any imperial palace across the world than you can give this a skip. The entry ticket is ridiculously high for what it has to offer. There are some good views of Bosphorous but again nothing new if you have already taken the Bosphorous cruise. The gardens are nothing to talk about. Not sure why other reviewers are raving about it. On a hot afternoon the visit can be treacherous as the palace has no air-conditioning installed.

Interesting Contrast to Topkapi. It was great to see this European-style palace, especially after seeing Topkapi Palace. The rooms were spectacular, and our guides for bot the main palace and the Harem were extremely knowledgeable. The grounds are lovely, as well, and it's spectacularly situated on the Bosphorus. The only reason why I'm giving this a 4 instead of a 5 is that, while it's supposed to be open until 6, we arrived not too long after 4 and it was already closed due to a high number of visitors, so we had to go back the next day. I would recommend going in the morning to be sure you won't be shut out. Also, it is not self-guided, you must be with a group, so if you just miss one you will have to wait around for the next tour. I don't think it's a long wait, but we really didn't know that. Aside from that, it's good value for money, as the place is rather large and you get to see quite a bit of it, especially if you choose the combined selamlik/haremlik ticket, which I recommend.

If you have been to Aya Sofya , Topkapi Palace , Blue Mosque then this shoul bevyour number 4. Entrance fees are somewhat different in that a man and women pay less than 2 men or two women. Pay the extra to see the Harem Quarters (for 2 total 80!lira). When you walk into the court yard the beautiful architecture, magnificent grounds along with a beautiful oceanic view immediately hit you. Everything is immaculate and by the time you leave you will understand the fee structure to get in. You cannot wander around the inside of the palace by yourself. Tours are conducted in both Turkish and English. The tour of the main palace takes 45 minutes and the Harem 30 mins. Sounds quite a long time but the palace is massive and the tours were quite hurried. Beautiful furnishings inside along with amazing murals on the ceilings (68 bathrooms all of which have hole in the floor - yes even for his highness). Would have appreciated if a bit more time was spent explaining the furniture rather than the people. Make sure you set aside maybe 20 mins to walk around the grounds . There also is a rather beautiful crystal room which you can visit yourself ( we came across by accident). A overall a great experience.

French palace in Istanbul. This is a beautiful palace in Istanbul, and it is interesting to visit as it is built in a very different style than Topkapi and the other main tourist attractions. This palace was built much later than other places and has been done in a much more European style. You can visit both the harem and the business area of the palace, but it has to be done as part of a guided tour. Unfortunately, I very much disliked the tour. The guides were not well trained (in particular, they were very difficult to hear), and the tours were very rushed. You can't take pictures inside the building, so being rushed is doubly annoying because you don't have time to take in the grandeur of the rooms. The grounds are very pretty, and you can get some great pictures of the view from the sea gate along the river. If you have time after visiting all of the other main tourist attractions, I would still recommend visiting here, but I wouldn't come here at the expense of places like Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, etc. Also, if possible, come on a day that is NOT Friday or Saturday as those seem to be the days with the most tourists (I think that's when cruise lines tend to dock in Istanbul) so the tour may be smaller.

Beautiful palace. We visited the Dolambahce palace at around 12:00 and we waited around 10 minutes to buy the ticket. The entry fee for the palace is 30 TL (you can also buy ticket for the Harem for 20TL). You are given 45-minute guided tour through the palace and it is worth it!It is really outstanding! I surely recomend it

this is real Palace. here is the place we visit with Dilek Acikalin Turka, when we get there we see many peaples in front of the entrace of the palace and we think we will wait a lot but dilek gone to ticket office come after 3 munite later maybe than we get into the palace, how she did this than we ask her she said mellifluence, yes this is right because she is so nice and profesionel guide, we had realy good time in Dolmabahce palace.

Amazing... To enter the palace we must go through safety inspections, then we have to buy entry tickets. Sometimes backpacks are also not allowed to be brought together and are asked by security officers to leave the bag at a guard post. As always be queuing to get into the palace and visitors are divided in groups to facilitate the visit and by the staff. Visitors take a visit to the place in official ceremonies and activities that occur as living room, guest room, dining hall and the most interesting is the interior decoration of floor, wall and through to painting in every room. It is amazing. Unfortunately we are not allowed to take photographs inside the palace.

Beautiful palace. We went there for 9.30 ish as we heard about waiting 3 hours to get in! Luckily there were not many people at all at this time ooh hoo! As soon as you buy the tickets go straight to the entrance of the palace to wait for the guided tour- take photos of outside later as it tends to build up so quickly and you may miss the english tour! The guided tour is actually quite ok, I heard some bad reviews of this before but I think it was well explained! The palace is europian style, it is quite nice and the chandeliers ( apparently english crystals!) were grand. The outside is also quite nice. We didn't go to see the harem ( as we were skint by this time!) but would have loved to see it. There is a nice cafe outside the palace looking over the sea with lovely ice creams yum!

Worth a visit. Concerned by other reviewers about the crowds we got to the palace at 9:30am on a sunday (opens at 8:30am but we are in european time of late nights so didnt get there as early as i had hoped). English tour was at 10am so we looked at crystal palace and surrounds first. Thrilled that it was really quiet. About 15 people on our tour. Tour guide excellent. Took about 45 mins. Apparently tour guide said it is really quiet now as it is ramadan and the 'riots' which are both keeping tourist numbers down ( good for us i suppose). Didnt feel rushed. Really enjoyed. Last room takes your breath away. Definately worth seeing if you have time.

Amazing. Only downsides were lengthy queues for entry, but then my visit was on a Sunday, guided tours were a little rushed although very informative. Still,well worth the visit to see the beautiful interior and lovely gardens.

MUST see!. We made a special effort to get to Dolmabache Palace and were not disappointed at all. Be sure to get there to stand in place for a guide in the desired language. The only way to go through is with a guide. The last grand room is simply indescribable! My jaw was on the floor!

Royal :). I had not expected to visit Dolmabahce Place, but truly glad that I did... A complete different sense of architecture where the sultans lived. The palace is stunning in itz extravagent furniture, carpets , silk laden curtains and enormous chandeliers. The Dome in the main chamber was one of the best sights to see in Istanbul plus the gold that was everywhere.

Beautiful palace, poor tours. The palace is amazing. Definitely worth the visit but the mandatory tours given with the entrance fee was rushed and staff had poor English so we couldn't understand what was said. For the price they were charging - 40 for palace and 40 for harem, I would expect higher standards.

Spectacular place but the experience should have been better. We caught the tram to Kabataş (end of the tram line) for 3 TL then walked the 10 mıns to the Palace.The tours of the Palace and the Harem cost 40 TL for both, each about half an hour. They are both amazing and there is so much grandeur and opulence to see.But ... you HAVE to go with a guided group, and the group for the English speaking tour was so big and many times the guide either did not wait to start speaking, or we were so far back we could not hear. We felt rushed and did not have time to appreciate everything we were shown, and behind us came security guards hurrying us through. You cannot take photographs anywhere inside so there are no memories to keep. You wear plastic galoshes over your shoes to protect the carpets, which I can understand, but I have been on many tours of palaces and houses with valuable exhibits and don't see the need to be herded though as we were. And non-flash photography would not harm the antiques and furnishings.The grounds are lovely and the setting on the Bosphorus is very pleasant - you can wander here as you please, and there are a couple of cafes where you can relax and enjoy the scenery.

Great Archeticture. I visited Dolmabahce Palace in my last trip to the beautiful Istanbul. The palace consists of two main bulidings. The first one is where the Sultants have had their receptions and the second one is called the Harem Section, where the women and servants used to stay. You have to buy a full ticket to enter both buildings, other wise you'll not be allowed to enter the Harem Section. Individual visits are not allowed as well. There are guides in both buildings to organize the trips & make sure no-one touch anything in the palace. The guided-tour takes from 30-45 minutes in each building. I loved the palace as it shows the rich history of the city being the home of the last 6 Ottman Sultans in Istanbul. Great views over the Bosphours, too! Strongly recommended.

Grandeur Palace but don't use a tour guide. This palace is grandeur with crystal chandeliers and the works like receptions, living rooms, library and so on - probably similar to what Buckingham Palace looks like inside, The last sultan of the Ottoman Empire lived here and wow this place was just incredible. This is located on the banks of the Bosphorus River very close to where some ferries are located for Prince's Island trips. Next to the palace is a small mosque called Dolmabahce Mosque which is quite nice. It is highly recommended that you do this on your own accord rather than in a tour group which I did unfortunately. The tour guide waffled on and on and on for 3 hours and I lost the world to live and was desperate to get out of the palace but could not do so. This is something you can do within 1 hour easily without some person waffling on boring the pants out of you. Before you enter the palace, you have to put some plastic bags over your shoes/trainers so the place doesn't get dirty.

A feast for the eyes. We booked a private tour in advance, much the best way if you wish to appreciate the splendour of Dolmabahce. Architecturally it is nothing special, but the interiors are stunning. This palace is what other palaces could have been if they had not been stifled by the dead hand of good taste. If you have doubts about maroon and olive green, or pink and lime silks, or silver-mounted elephant tusks and crystal chandeliers, come and look and be liberated from the modern taste for half-hearted 'understatement'. Dolmabahce shows that you can combine an eclectic mix of styles to make a secular cathedral of sheer visual enjoyment. You just cannot believe how over the top it is, but it works!The only negative is that one cannot take photographs of the interiors, and without them so many splendid details will be lost to memory.

BEST PALACE IN EUROPE!!!!. It's just beautiful! The Palace is the most beautiful I've seen!, Each room has one spectacular chandelier, the details of the ceilings, stair rails, etc. are impressive. Here lies the world's largest chandelier. The palace is really well located and it is easily accessible from any point.

Do not go without a group!. 1st: You can not go into the palace on your own. You must be with a guide. The palace has regular tours, and you must go with one of them if you are not part of a group, and the tours can be very big.We did the palace as a last min. thing in IST., and did not know that we had to stay with a tour, a tour of about 50 or so.Because of the size, it was very hard to hear the guide, and wow, some tourist can be really really rude.It was almost impossible to see anything for more than a sec, before some one either pushed you to move along , or just stepped right in front of you.With that said the palace has some beautiful art work and crystal, it is a beautiful place.But never never go on your own, book a small tour thru an agency to get the full effect.

Yet another elite extravaganza. For once, we did not visit a site on our own, but saw Dolmabache Palace with a day tour. That may have influenced our experience negatively, since our time was strictly constrained. (We prefer to explore at a leisurely pace.) However, you cannot visit the interiors of Dolmabache Palace WITHOUT being on a guided tour, so you are limited to what you can see and how long you can linger. That was disappointing to me, since my career was in architecture and my lifelong interests are design, archaeology and the history of cultures. I thoroughly research the history of every place before we leave home, and am eager to see things in depth. When I get there, I want to walk slowly through, taking the time to appreciate it and take in its details -- not be herded through as quickly as people can be made to walk. I get it that confining people to tours must help protect a place from theft or damage, and hustling them through undoubtedly allows more people to visit each day without being so crowded. But many venues we've seen in other countries (such as Versailles, Matsumoto Castle and Schloss Nymphenburg, for just three examples) allow you to walk through large areas of historic palaces at your own pace -- and take photographs. Even in Istanbul, we were able to get in line at Topkapi Palace before it opened, explore the whole palace at our leisure (taking all the pics we wanted), and then leave when the tour buses started dumping their hordes at the door. Which leads me to the "No Photography" rule at Dolmabache. We used to think forbidding photography was a way to force you to buy the venue's own books and photos, or else it was to prevent possible damage to paintings and textiles by repeated flashes of light. Well, we missed seeing a Gift Shop -- if there was one -- and now you don't NEED to use flash to get good pictures. So, all we can figure is that continuing to forbid photography is a device to increase the speed at which you could hustle people through the place. If they can't stop to snap a pic, it'll be easier to keep them moving.If you are trying to decide whether to include Dolmabache in your itinerary, weigh it against something else you might want to do. Do you really need to see yet another display of ostentatious wealth -- that nearly bankrupted the country! -- or would you rather stroll through a charming waterside town like nearby Ortakoy or take a memorable day cruise on the Bosporus? (Also, be sure to inquire about handicapped access, if you need it. I did not see an elevator, only a monumental stairway, to get to the upper floor of the Palace.) We have traveled extensively all over the planet, and maybe we just need to stop visiting the palace venues, but to us, Dolmabache Palace was "just another palace." That is not to say it isn't worth a visit. It truly is extraordinary. The design, construction and quality of materials is top-notch throughout and the gardens are impeccably maintained. The workmanship displayed in all the furnishings is superb. The setting, right on the Bosporus, is one of the most dramatic of any palace we have seen.
