The whole place must have impressed the Europeans, which was the intent behind its construction. If you haven't already visited a number of palaces, you might find Dolmabache exciting and beautiful. It is. But what I remember most about it is not the gilded decor, the wonderful waterside setting, the 2-ton chandeliers or the Crystal Staircase. I remember the frustration of being rushed through it.

Baccarat crystal feast. If you love crystal you got to go and see this ....there are many beautiful things to see and interesting facts about the history and the people that lived here but for me it was about the beautiful chandeliers. Each and every one ( and there are many) leading up to the ultimate moment of seeing a 4.5ton baccarat crystal hanging from a gilded ceiling......it took my breath away. Such grandeur ....and the palace itself is such a magnificent building on the Bosphorus and there is a lovely cafe under the trees in the garden over looking the water - an oasis after an overload of beautiful things. Don't miss this one ...

Spectacular in every sense. In an earlier week's visit, Dolmabahce Palace was not on the itinerary, and so high on our list on this second visit. The Palace and the Harem fully lived up to expectations. English tours to both take place every half hour costing 30 Lire for the Palace or 40 Lire for both. The extra 10 Lire for the Harem is fully worth it. The guides are good but if you want to get the best out of the detailed history of the Palace and the Sultans who lived there, it is worth reading up a guide book in advance. The Palace is beautifully situated alongside the Bosphorus and the internal decorations are more opulent than anything I have seen in Paris, Versailles, Vienna or Prague. It emphasises the might of the Ottoman Empire which has been all but forgotten as so crucial to Eastern Europe and Mesopotamia for five centuries.

A great excuse to cross to the Asian side.... Get ready for long lines and beautiful sights... the Dolmabahce Palace is exquisite.From the rugs to the high ceilings this palace is full of history and marvelous rose gardens.I visited the Palace and then the Harem and to be honest was disappointed by the Harem - or maybe it was just the tour guides, they stuck to history and not to all the things you'd want to hear about the Harem.

Somebody actually lived here?. The second most impressive palace in Istanbul, and that is saying something. The chandeliers range between one ton and four tons, and are mind-boggling, as are the carpets. But it is the location along the Bosporus that kept surprising me: many of the "small" rooms have open windows and views along the water. Wow. There are two separate tours. If you can, take both tours (only one tour is allowed after 3pm because of time restraints). The ceremonial side is probably a bit better than the harem tour, but both are worth the time. It took us about 2 hours for both tours. The grounds are beautiful as well.

One more must see in Istanbul. Absolutely must see. A bit to the expensive side but worth it. Very close to the Kabatas tram stop. Have a chay afterwards at the cafe in the garden. Beautiful view of the Bosporus.

Palace with a view. If you stay in the old city, you simply take tram no. 2 to the end of the line and from there walk about 10 minutes and there it is. Make sure you go there on a beautiful day, so that you enjoy to the max the garden and surroundings. The palace is right by the sea, and if you took that trip on the Bosphorus already, then you know how big and attractive this palace is. It's certainly very adorned and opulent, it is meant to impress. And the oppulance starts from the entrance. You will most certainly like it, so take half a day to go there. It is a very popular TA and the tickets are fairly expensive. For the whole thing, official rooms plus harem, you pay about 60 TL. It's way cheaper if you have ISIC card. The official rooms are really somptuous, while the harem rooms are much simpler. You get a glimpse into the everyday life though, but if you want to save up money, just go to the official rooms and don't worry about missing anything out at the harem wing. Queues get rather long, b/c there's a tour every 20 - 30 minutes (one in Turkish, one in English) and you need to wait if you missed the previous tour. So be prepared to stand on your feet a lot or simply look for the plate that announces the tour hours: they're very rigurous about it. At the ticket office there's a sign saying the palace might close gates earlier to visitors if the visitor limit is reached earlier than posted opening hours. Enjoy!

Truly magnificent!. I'm glad I went to Dolmabahce Palace because it was one of the highlights of my trip. The tickets are slightly pricey and the queue is massive but it is definitely worth it! The tickets for Harem and Selamlik are separate. I would recommend visiting Harem instead of both. Harem offers free tour guide but the only downside of Harem is that if you need the toilet, you would not be able to join back the tour. Instead, you would need to wait for the next tour, which would mean waiting for another hour or so.

So beautiful but crazy line process. You should really go as soon as it opens in the morning to avoid the many long lines, unless you are with a tour group that seems to get to skip the lines. Lines for security, the ticket window, the entrance gate, the palace itself... You can only go into the palace with a guide, which was great so you can really understand the history. It's so beautiful, but it's a shame you are not allowed to take any pictures inside.

Highlight of my istanbul visit. I had not expected to visit Dolmabahce Place, but truly glad that I did... A complete different sense of architecture from the Topkapi palace where the sultans lived before coming here. The palace is stunning in itz extravagent furniture, carpets , silk laden curtains and enormous chandeliers. The Dome in the main chamber was one of the best sights to see in Istanbul.

Move over Versailles this is opulent. This is a palace that was built for the Sultans after they felt the Topkapi became outdated. This is a stunning example of extravagant opulence which most tourist miss. It is the best palace I have seen. The exterior and interior features are so ornate and the locals take exceptional steps to maintain this wonder. You cannot take photos( not supposed to), you have to wear covers on your shoes and tour the palace with one of their tours. Very controlled but you will see why. The chandeliers are out of this world and the ultimate chandelier a gift from Queen Victoria is just breathtaking. You must see that chandelier and the room to believe the epitome of opulence. The views from the palace which overlooks the Bosphorous are amazing. Note almost all of the clocks are stopped at 9:05 which is the time General Ataturk died in the palace. He is the founder of the Turkish Republic and beloved. Ataturk means father or Turks.

Fascinating opulent palace. I don't understand why this palace is ranked so low amongst Istanbul attractions. TO me it was one of the highlights of my trip. The queuing was annoying, especially in 30 degree heat. No individual visits are allowed so you have to queue in the sun until they are ready to start the tour. The advantage is that there is no extra cost for an audio guide and the guides are quite informative. Also it is not included on the museum pass. However I would thoroughly recommend a visit here, especially if you are interested in 19th century architecture.

Beautiful but some issues. The palace itself including the gardens is stunningly beautiful in a more European castle sort of way. We have a complaint about the guided tour because the group was way too large and the tour guide was nearly impossible to understand. It took us several minutes to realize that he actually spoke English. I have no idea what he was saying. The entry fee cost more than the Topkapi Palace and the Hagia Sophia but the tour was unfortunately pretty much useless. We did love the splendor of the halls and salons though. It was heartbreaking to see a lot of trash in the gardens. I actually picked up several plastic water bottles because I couldn't bare the sight of them thrown between all the lovely flowers.

One of the World's Best. Dolmabahçe Palace surprised me. I have seen most of the world's best palaces but it is right there competing for first place with the Peterhof Palace in Saint Petersburg. If you have time in Istanbul put Dolmabahçe Palace on your must-do list.As other reviewers have noted, get there early and even then, be prepared to stand in line. The day we went was Saturday and the daily quota of visitors was exhausted by lunch time. First, there is a line for security checkpoint, and then, a line to purchase tickets. After you enter the grounds, there is a line at the door to the palace waiting to join a tour. If you are reading this, you will want the English tour. The other choice is Turkish. Make sure you know which line you are in. Photos are NOT allowed in the building.

Don't miss it. Ok. So there is a fair bit of waiting around in lines. You can't take yourself around this palace - you must go with a guide. As the groups are about 60 people each stick close to the guide or you won't hear a thing. But - the whole palace is amazing. The exterior is just lovely and is right on the Bosphoros. The interior - WOW! It has to be seen to be believed. Don't miss the Harem either. It's worth the little bit more you have to pay for entry.

Beautiful palace. Beautiful looking palace. Looks great from the ferry and from the outside, there is a big park around it. Its a nice place to visit. Did not get much time to spend, so can't do justice to the place.

historical and new. this palace combines history and modern at the same time you would find amazing sculptures, chandeliers, stairs everything is super gorgeous, they ask you to wear a shoes cover to keep the place clean and unscratched, they offer tour guides speaking English and Turkish and after the mazing journey you would go through you can watch the amazing sea view and take pictures in the garden as they do not allow pictures inside

Dolambahce- Attaturk's wondeful palace. If you are in Istanbul you will enjoy visiting this great palace .Cristal chandeliers, big stairs, huge rooms wonderful decorated- a great palace of modern Turkye.

Stunning palace. This palace does not get the attention it deserves from tourists. 10 times more impressive than Topkapi Palace (although Dolmabahce is more modern). Ceiling in grand hallway is spectacular and the 4 1/2 ton crystal chandelier is gorgeous. This is a must see, since it's not nearly as crowded as Topkapi. Downside: if you get there late in the day, your tour will be rushed. Be prepared to cover your shoes (they provide the plastic covers) or remove your shoes altogether. Also, not really accessible for the disabled: lots of stairs.

Very rushed. The palace itself is very beautiful and if you have a bit of extra time in Istanbul there are certainly worse places to spend some time but I'm really not a fan of the 'guided' only visit that you must do to get in.Whilst I'm not against using a guide in certain situations, this format really didn't work at Dolmabahce. There must have been around 40-50 people in our group with a wait of around 25 minutes to get in. This meant that as we were at the back, it was very difficult to hear the guide in most of the rooms/corridors which can be quite narrow. We basically missed all the commentary and because there were so many people in our group there was no opportunity to actually spend some time studying the rooms or decor. There were a number of rooms we either walked past and could look in for 5 seconds or just walked straight by that I would have liked some time to actually enjoy. Even the largest and most spectacular rooms were moved through very quickly.The palace was impressive I just felt we really got moved in and out as quickly as possible and after paying 40 TL for the palace and Harem, to emerge after just over an hour having done both these tours was a little disappointing when I feel left to my own devices I could have spent double that time and actually felt like I got to experience the building.

Grandeur...and no delusions about it!. Wow. And after an hour-and-a-half wait to get into this palace on a Sunday morning (you're strongly advised to queue from 8am as the crowds are heaving by 9am), I would have expected nothing less than 'wow'! This palace is incredible. You are only allowed to go inside with a tour-guide as they take you around and explain everything from the crystal staircase to the palace's bathrooms. What you get for your money (or if you're lucky to get in for free like I was as I happened to go on the weekend of a public holiday) is a 45 minute tour of the reason why Turkey was almost bankrupted by this marvel and you can certainly see why.Room by room, the place itself is so incredibly adorned that you almost excuse the tour guide for being barely audible and seeming like he hasn't a clue what the scripted English he is spouting means. The tour is finished with a bang as you are led into the grandest room of them all - cue a chorus of gasps from all. Outside the palace is just as incredible. What a view. The immaculate gardens and the Istanbul skyline over the glimmering Bosphorus hit you in the face - this is prime location Turkish real-estate! Now, what's the price tag?

Breath Taking. This can’t be missed it is absolutely breath taking both the interior and the surrounding grounds. There are free guided tours with very short waits in line to enter as well they have a nice little café where you can sit and have a nice Turkish tea or coffee between the harem section and the official palace.

Overwhelming luxury. This beautiful palace was built toward the end of the Ottoman era. It borrowed heavily from European designs (French and English). Huge room after huge room with endless furnishings, carpets, priceless artifacts. Overwhelming.

A must see - beautiful. When we were planning how to spend our days in Istanbul - what to see what not to see we were very confused about Dolmabache palace - is it worth seeing or not..however we are glad that we did end up going there finally.Its the Palace that was built by the Ottoman rulers as their modern palace and as part of the reform to fit into the changing modern times.It is a very beautiful palace.As per the earlier reviews I had read we were aware of the long lines for tickets etc so we made sure we left our hotel early around 8.15am. We took a tram and got off at the kabatas station and from there it was a 5 minutes walk.The first line was for the security check and then the next one was for the ticket.To be frank if you get in the early the lines are not so bad and they move fast.Just ensure that you don't go to late as they have a limit on the number of visitors they allow in a day to avoid over crowding as the palace had wooden flooring and cant take too many visitors as told to us by our guide.Next there are again 3 lines at the entrance to the palace once you cross the gardens..one for Turkish visitors,the other for Groups with guides and finally one for English. These lines are there because they do not allow one to wander about in the palace you need to be part of a guided tour.So we had a great guide inside who took us around.I think she was very good given the situation.For convenience and security purpose they the guide needs to take about 30-35 people in one group.However our guide explained everything as well as she could with such a large group.One got to see some lovely Turkish carpets, European chandeliers , furniture etc. espl don't miss out the lovely art work on the domes and ceilings. Of course the palace also had a lovely view of the Bosphorous. Finally when the first part of the tour is over you can carry on if you have tickets for the next part which is the harem part.It has the personal rooms of the sultans and all the women in the harem.Again the same process is followed one gets a guide as per the language and they take you around.Not much to learn in that part of the palace but still was nice to see the way the rooms were.All in all a beautiful place.In total we were done in 2-2.5 hours.So if you like opulent palaces this is the place to see.The ticket prices were for the official part 30 TL and for the harem 20 TL and if you buy common ticket for both parts then 40 TL.

Beautiful architecture and scenery. The palace is a must see from inside and outside. The architecture is really amazing. You will be amazed by the gold and crystal decor and the red carpets. It mixes European styles with elements of the traditional old Turkish life. Photos though are only allowed in the gardens, however, you will be satisfied with all the beautiful scenery around the palace.
Beautiful. Beautiful place to visit in a stunning location with a view of the of the Bosphorous. Inside is beautiful & the gardens are lovely to walk around too.

Underrated Palace - Highly Recommend. If you like visiting castles, European palaces and French Chateaus, than this is the place for you to visit. If you like to visit typical Istanbul like places than this place can be skipped. This palace is very close to cruise ships, and you have to be patient there, because they offer group tours only, but the place is amazing, and grounds are beautiful and serene.

Well worth visiting, requires time. This is another example of the interesting culture and history of Turkey.Be prepared for a long walk and if you visit on a weekend prepare for a long wait as visitors tour the sight with a guide and groups are brought in every 15 or 20 minutes. Even buying tickets required a 20 minute wait in line. Although this sight is not a big a others in Istanbul, make sure you have 3 to four hours from beginning to end to spend on the visist.Also know that the palace is closed on Mondays and Thursday.Although it is one of the few places you are not allowed to photograph inside, it is well worth the visit.

Really glad I decided to go. On our last day in Istanbul, we decided to go to the Palace. It was a magnificent place. Everything down to the lamp in the garden was well-decorated. The English tour guide was not so easy to understand. He didn't speak English well, and he didn't make things better by explaining the same thing in different languages (French, Arabic, etc) one after another. I couldn't tell when he was or wasn't speaking in English. But overall, I think the Palace is an attraction that shouldn't be missed.

Absurd wealth and decadence. An unbelievable palace. This building is filled with massive chandeliers and gold lines the ceilings of the rooms. It is a completely jaw-dropping spectacle. It also shows a complete contrast with the palace the ottomans used for 400 years, which was filled with Arab tilework and architecture, which was all dropped and instead the palace was made much more European.

So Different from Topkapi. There's a stark contrast between this palace and Topkapi. Dolmabahce was built in the European style. There wasn't a hint of oriental influence in its design. It was the last residence of the Ottoman sultans, and the place where Ataturk lived and died. All the clocks in the palace have been stopped at 9:05, which was the time (AM) Ataturk passed away. We visited the palace with a tour group so we didn't wait in line for tickets. There was a slight wait at the entrance of the palace, to let the other groups out. Be sure to spend some time in the gardens. Both the front gardens and the back ones facing the Bosphorus were beautiful. There are many palaces in Istanbul, but in my opinion, Topkapi and Dolmabahce are the two worth visiting for their historical significance and architectural differences.

Magnificent chandeliers. This palace is worth visiting just to see the crystal chandeliers and crystal staircase, if for no other reason. The carpets, marble, porcelains are stunning. I was lucky enough to be on a small tour so our own guide explained everything. Yes, there is a security check, wait, and no photos are allowed inside. Toured on a Tuesday morning in late April. Far less crowded than the Topkapi Palace.

Formatted visit, no freedom to get aroun. I have been to this palace and it disappointed me. The visits are formatted: you are obliged to follow a guide that shows you a pre-defined circuit. Individual visits are not allowed and you do not have time to appreciate the objects and places. At the entrance, the first bad surprise: a total of around 2 hour of waiting: for security control, to buy a ticket (museum pass is not accepted) and for an available English speaking guide.The worst part was the line for tickets: there was only one person selling tickets. In fact, there were two ticket offices opened, but one was reserved for groups. However, not many groups showed up. Thus, the employee just waited, patiently for the groups and spent most of her time reading or talking instead of selling individual tickets! It was almost disrespectful with everyone that was waiting!Very little information is available during the visit and objects are shown randomly. You are obliged to pay attention to the guide, otherwise you'll miss it.Poor structure, lots of control. If you like to get around and take the time to read and appreciate the art objects, that's not the place for you. I'd avoid this place.

Amazing. It has 2 parts, Salamlek and Hareem parts, the salamlek is the most luxiouris one as it is the one the Sultans used to welcome the important people in it, and Hareem part is made for the ladies and children so it is a kind of homey decorated (comparing to the Salamlek part).. It is one of the main reason that the Ottoman empire has been fallen so I think it worth to be seen

Whizzed through. Like a Versailles Palace ..no real feel of Turkey at all .So if you are pushed for time give it a miss. You cannot visit individually ..you have to part of a guided tour in groups of about 30 which whizzes through at the speed of light and if you are at the back you cant hear a word the guide says especially as the next f=group follows on so quickly you have 2 commentaries fighting each other.The café on the Bosphorus is lovely though.

Istanbul's answer to Versailles. A lovely, lovely palace, with beautiful architecture and design. I enjoyed the tours, despite the snickering questions about harems from other tourists -- the guides were knowledgeable, informative and friendly. I got there around 2, and found that there wasn't enough time to explore the grounds properly as well as take both tours. Give yourself much more time.
Unbelievably beautiful!. Everything was so exquisitely detailed, such a beauty, I really loved the atmosphere. You could look at any direction and everything around was equally stunning!

Stunnning palace. This should definitely be on every tourist's 'to do' list.Pros: stunning interior with the most beautiful French/Bohemian crystal chandeliers. Gives a good picture of the style in which the Ottoman sultans lived. It is also easy to locate as it is only 5 minutes walk from the Kabatas tram station and a beautiful position next to the Bosphorous.Cons: Long queues and guided tours in large groups. It is not possible to wander around on your own which is slightly annoying, although probably understandable given the amount of glass on display! Some of the guides are better than others.

Worth seeing. We visited it in the busy period during the New Year, so it involved a lot of waiting. First, we waited for the security check, then we waited to purchase the tickets, and finally we waited to get in as all tours are guided.The waiting took us 2 hours in total, and the actual tour was some 30-45 minutes.At the entrance there is ticket pricelist. According to that, English guided tours are twice more expensive than the Turkish ones. If I recall correctly the entrance casted 40 TL per person. There are always people who try to sneak in, because they do not want to wait long lines, and no one is taking care of it, so that was annoying. I recommend early visit due to that long waiting, and due to the fact that visitors’ number per day is limited.Our English speaking guide was not so good. He looked uninterested and ill to be honest.However, even with long waiting (and we almost gave up), pricy entrance, and bad guide, it definitely worth to see this palace. I would visit it again – but this time I would chose some less frequent time, to reduce the waiting.

Worth visiting for the grandeur of the place. At first i didnt give much thought on visiting Dolmabahce palace but after we went there, i think its worth the visit. Like everyone have said, you a need a guided tour in order to see the place. We were lucky to see both the main palace and the harem, but we almost couldnt catch the last harem tour. My tour guide was a lady and she did explain the palace adequately but it was a tad too long, unlike some others that have said that they didnt get to linger around. The palace is considered well preserved with most construction still in their original state. For me the most breathtaking is the stairways with the baccarat crystal hanging down, when you look up it was just wow and the detailings surrounding the stairways, baccarat crystal and mahogany wood, were just extravagantly beautiful. Some of the rooms are really beautiful and the detailing added the extra oomph to it. Anyway it was awesome and not regretting going there at all just to see the crystals and its treasure.

A lovely place with a bad guided tour. Dolmabahce Palace is a gorgeous and worthwhile place to spend a day in Istanbul. The grounds are wonderful and the water views and landscaping make for a great escape from the bustling city. The guided tour is annoying but they make you go to see the inside of the palace which is also pretty amazing. We never made it to the harem but we felt satisfied with just one tour. Read the wikipedia page and just go at your own pace regardless. Don't bother trying to eat at the cafe - service is terrible.

Beautiful interiors, a highlight of Istanbul. We were concerned as other reviews had commented on how disorganized the staff were, but we had to go. We are glad we did. The wait to get in the main part and the harem (living quarters) was about 10 min. The tours move fast and the crowds are big. The quality of the experience depends on the guide. Our main building guide was pleasant and spoke loudly and clearly, while the guide at the harem mumbled and was of little use. The building is neat and fun to see where the sultan moved after Topkapi palace: different as night and day. It was moving to see where Ataturk died. Because of the crowds it is easy to run into annoying people who try to take pictures when it is forbidden, people who touch things when it is forbidden and people who do not stay on the carpet so they damage the floors. Worth the stress of waiting and dealing with people for whom the rules of good conduct do not apply. There is a great website with 3d tours of many of the rooms (search dolmabahce palace-3d virtual tour)

Poor Sultans. My guide explained this was built when the sultans were poor and trying to maintain their image to the world in the 19th Century. This palace is gorgeous. Not as big as those in Europe but equally impressive. Go early, the lines can get very long and crowded. Not very organized to enter and there can be some pushing. You have to put plastic covers over your shoes to protect the carpets.

A palace you don't want to miss. An excellent example of how a palace should look like. :) In order to fully enjoy it - go there before the opening time (9:00 AM), when there are fewer people. Otherwise, you might have to wait for 2 hours to get in (as we did).

Luxurious. Luxuriously decorated with the original furniture and carpets.The grand finale was the throne room, although the rest of the palace was also beautiful.My wife and I went mid afternoon, and the queue to the Palace was not too long, although we waited a bit longer for the Harem (45 minutes).

Quite impressive and worth seeing. Compared to the Topkapi palace, Dolmabahce is more interesting. It situated in the Besiktas and you have to cross the Golden Horn to get to it. As most of the palaces from Istanbul,this is also very big and opulent,with and impressive architecture. Unfortunately some of the rooms were closed to visitors but we saw Attaturk’s bedroom, The Ceremonial hall, The Ambassador’s Hall and the wonderful music-box which was bigger than I expected ( at a first sight I thought is a wardrobe). Also I loved the world's largest Bohemian crystal chandelier situated in the Ceremonial Hall and the Clock Tower. Everything was just fascinating and lavishly.

Breathtaking. Very opulent, luxurious, it reaches and even exceeds the goal of rivalising european palaces, very well preserved , it still keeps original furniture and decorations (as no revolution destroyed it!!).Though we spend too many hours queuing for tickets and for 2 entrances - museum and harem. The palace can be visited only on guided tours (which is understandable because of all this precious goods, decorations) , the guides rush people through the rooms, you don't have time to see and enjoy everything, their english is not very good and they are extremely careful that the visitors don't take pictures, which is understandable as they want you to buy pictures from the museum shop, but they run out of DVD's in the shop!

Why do they insist on a tour !. The Palace itself is worth seeing but why oh why do they insist on a guided tour. The groups are too large, they really (truly) rush you through so that you have very little time to absorb anything. Also the "Crystal Room" was closed but they don't tell you that ! Such a disappointment for a lovely building. Cafe at the entrance was the cheapest we came across for a tourist location.

Really disappointing!. After the breath-taking beauty of Haghia Sophia and Topkapi this was a real disappointment. The opulent palace is just too opulent to the point of bad taste and the guided Selamik tour a 45 minute rush past rooms we didn't stop for. When we did stop we couldn't hear the guide - why don't they give them microphones? Hardly surprising this extravaganzhastened the decline and fall of the Ottoman Empire.

beautiful gardens, great location, interesting guided tour. This palace is very easy to get to by tram from the historical centre. Buy a token for 3 Turkish lire at the kiosque marked "jeton" (at every stop). At the end station of the tram, get off and walk along the waterfront going east. The entrance fee is a little pricey, but get the ticket that includes a guided tour of the harem as well. The beautiful crystal balustrade of the main staircase, is worth the price of admission! The tours are a little too fast, but it permits more people to see the palace. The view of the strait of Bosporus is beautiful, as are the gardens. There is a nice cafe with outdoor tables. The bookstore has very interesting books in a few different languages.

An amazing palace. This is the new palace built in the 1860s when the then Sultan moved out of the Topkapi Palace. Take the tram to the Kabatas terminus and then a 5-minute walk beyond. Tours to both the Palace and the Harem are by guide only with no photography allowed - the Harem is extra. Both are conducted at break-neck speed (50 mins Palace; 25 mins Harem). We had to wait about 20 minutes for a tour of the Palace, less for the Harem (mid April). The English guided tours depends very much on who gives it: some guides have very accented broken English, others are much better with a wry sense of humour. The palace itself is a glitzy mix of east meets west - Turkey meets an over-the-top, money-is-no-object, European excess (an OTT Versailles) where nothing is done by halves: there is a 4-tonne chandelier; a Crystal Staircase (actually only the balusters are crystal); massive reception rooms. There is certainly a "wow" factor with a number of rooms. It is probably expensive for what it is and the grounds are a bit disappointing, except for waterfront views over the Bosphorus, but do include an aviary and peacocks. There is a cafe inside the complex near the entrance to the Harem (drinks & cakes only), but a better cafe in the outer gardens (outside the turnstiles, near the clock tower) which is very reasonable and much recommended (drinks, light meals, etc). Walk back to Kabatas and take the underground funicular up to Taksim Square.

Too expensive. The line wasn't too long but we had to wait a while for the English tour. We had to follow the tour group as they don't allow you to roam around the place. Amazing collections but didn't have enough time to appreciate and photography is not allowed.

Amazing palace, poor guiding. Difficult to know how to rate this. The palace is amazing and gardens are lovely , the former being very OTT but worth visiting. However... You have to be guided. Our guide escorted a group of some 40 people at a galloping pace and if you weren't standing next to him, as i was, I don't think you wold have heard much. I don't like guided tours as I usually get bored, but this was much too fast even for me, so I really felt for people who like to linger and ask questions. The harem is a let down, not least as part is closed at the moment. Of all the places we visted, this was the worst value for money.

Worthwhile when not crowded and for students. We visited Dolmabahce in March and enjoyed it. Since it was not crowded, lines did not take long and we were free to wander about the beautiful grounds and sit and watch the Bosphorus. The interior is both impressively ornate and repetitive. Very different from other historic sights, and far removed geographically as well. Tickets are expensive (40 lira including harem) but Student tickets with ISIC card are only 5 lira all included, which is a really great deal. We didn't know about the discount before we got to the gate, and would definitely have been disappointed had we payed sticker price.

3 queues? Seriously?. Visiting the Dolmabahce Palace was a dream, but it never happened! We arrived at 11 am, and we agreed leaving at 13:45, because we had to check out at 14:00.Once we arrived, the view was amazing, with a huge clock tower to our right and the magnificent entrance of the palace in the front. Standing in queue 1 wasn't too long, about 10 minutes, where our bags were scanned. But standing in queue 2 was a nightmare: we've waited for 40 minutes to get our tickets. I mean how can ONE person in the counter provide services to almost 500 visitors? The ticket price is expensive, I am pretty sure they can afford three counters!We went inside the high walls of the palace. There were a splendid garden with amazing tulips, an incredible fountain, trees, lovely cats, ... We walked around 50 meters through the front stairs of the palace: A THIRD ENDLESS QUEUE WAS WAITING FOR US! We waited like 20 minutes, and our turn never came. The organizer shouted: WE'RE TAKING 20 PERSONS EACH 10 MINUTES! Seriously dude? We're like 500 persons!It was already 13:15 so we left, without visiting the palace interior. Going there needs two steps:A) Book the tickets a day earlier, so you don't have to waste your time in the second queue! (the Palace closes on Mondays and Thursdays).B) Considering at least 3 hours to visit Dolmabahce Palace.The architecture of the palace is amazing, it combines the baroque and the rococo and gives a new identity for the whole building. The charm of the composition from the outside makes you go back in time and realize how professional were the executed details in old buildings.Istanbul isn't far from Beirut: I am going there back again, I will definitely visit the palace and be seduced with its "gold" interior charm.

So many lines!. I regret giving this place a less-than-stellar review, but if you have limited time in Istanbul, skip this place. The lines to get into the main grounds of the palace are not bad, but you will wait in a long line to get into the palace and then once you are out, you will have to wait for an even longer time to get into the Harem. We paid for both the Palace and Harem, but the line was so ridiculous for the Harem, we left. (I tried to get my money back for the harem tickets, but no go. It was long shot, I knew that.) Now, that said, the palace was quite lovely and we had an English tour guide who did give us some nice background into the palace (you are required to go through with a tour guide in the palace, hence the wait). If you do go here, I would skip the harem tickets. (Also, the bathrooms near the harem are not clean and only have the traditional toilets, which are the holes in the ground.)

Impressive palace, poor organisation of visits. The Dolmabahce Palace is a large and impressive building in a beautiful position. It is hard to describe it as being tasteful, but this is totally over-the-top Ottoman bling. It looks a bit like the sultan asked Ali G to do the interior decor. The state apartments have the famous crystal staircase and one of the world's largest chandeliers -impressive even if kept switched off. The harem apartments contain the rooms used by Ataturk for the last four years of his life, and so are iconic for the Turkish people. That is the good part.A place with so much going for it has been organised in such a way that I repeatedly apologised to my wife for suggesting that we go there. There are certainly enough members of officialdom to do the organising. An army of besuited ones, very dapper and looking terribly self-important are forever walking past the endless lines of plebs whose only claim to have a quick look is their payment of the rather high ticket price. The only reason that I disagree with the reviewer who said to go in low season is that we did and the queues were still ridiculous.We joined the first queue - for security - great, only ten minutes. Then we got through and saw the ticket queue - 45 minutes later we were privileged to part with our money. Still, we had queued for less than an hour in total. Then we saw the enormous queue for the state apartments, so we went to the harem apartments and joined the queue there. After another 45 minutes we were allowed to join the 30 minute tour. We then decided we had better get in line for the state apartments if we were to see them before the palace closed - after all we had only arrived at noon for something that should be a couple of hours! The queue took another one and a quarter hours, then we joined the 45 minute tour. Add walking time and the same again to take pictures in the grounds and our one and a half hour experience took up five hours.Even after an hour in the last queue, my wife said "shall we just give up and go?" Perhaps our mistake was not to do that earlier.As there is no shelter from the sun whilst queuing, I would not suggest doing this in the summer!Tip - use the toilet before joining each queue.Add our hour wasted hours to those of all the other people stuck in the preposterous queues, and just think what could be achieved with that time! The organisation is meticulous once you realise that it is for the convenience of the officials running the palace. It simply wastes huge amounts of other people's time, time to which they seem to attach no value at all. This is not a good attitude towards people.The tours are in Turkish or English. The bigger demand that day was for English. However, those wanting Turkish had to wait in the same queues until splitting right at the end. An even bigger waste of time. Having said that, you might as well opt for whichever tour has the shortest queue. The main functions of the guides were to keep people from wandering by themselves and stop them taking pictures. The harem tour was more informative - we now know more about circumcision as a result. The state apartments tour less so - the crystal staircase was not even mentioned - "This is an exhibition hall, it contains royal things" was the only comment for the room signed ""Exhibition Room II" (we never saw no. I) and had a display of posh stuff in a palace - we could have worked out that the object we were looking at was a big chandelier. But they did manage to stop people taking pictures.Somehow they did it so much better at Topkapi, and I cannot believe the visitor numbers are fewer.After our visit we took the funicular to Taksim Square and visited another palace - Simit Saray. OK, it's a cafe with saray=palace in the name. In contrast the queue was short at a busy time of day, we felt valued, the tea and cakes were really nice and we enjoyed it.This visit to the Dolmabahce Palace was the one thing we regretted doing during a whole week in Istanbul. Everything else was either very good or excellent. This could have been.

Such a beautiful richly decorated palace. Can't imagine why I missed it last time I visited Istanbul. I would say this is as beautiful as the Versailles in Paris except there is no garden here. Such grandness. Love the chandeliers! So beautiful. A must-see! Shame we cannot take pictures inside.

Amazing palace. Another must visit place in istanbul, bit far from the touristic area but its convenience to reach as it is only 200m from the final tram stop. Very beautiful garden, well maintain palace and its show the grandeur of the last ottoman period... Unfortunatrly no photo inside and if you have a big group of tourist behind you the guide in front tend to speak fast and give you a limited time to admire this palace.

World class must see. You should visit Dolmabahce Palace in conjunction with a visit to Topkapı Palace. Dolmabahce succeeded Topkapı as the seat of the Ottoman Empire in its final years. It's an easy streetcar ride from almost anywhere in İstanbul. Visitors are escorted in group tours in English or Turkish. Photography is prohibited inside the palace. The group tours take about 40 minutes.

Way too crowded and disorganized to be fun!. We debated about seeing the Dolmabahce Palace but all the guidebooks and blogs said it was a must-see. It was really interesting to tour, the grounds were lovely. But the long lines and chaos made it almost not worth it. I guess I am glad I saw it, but I can't say I would recommend it just because there are so many things to do and see in Istanbul that this takes up way too much time and is really frustrating and stressful.Pros: Interesting gardens with lovely grounds, they have an English tour of the palace - one for the rooms where the sultan's government and ambassador affairs took place (the Selamlik) and one for the living quarters of the royal family (the Harem). Cons: see below. Plus, it was built when the royal family was trying to be very European, so all the decor is over-the-top European paintings, Italian artists painting the ceilings, gifts from Gernmany, etc. Not characteristically Turkish like Topkapi Palace. What to know:1) Get there early - seriously. The lines are incredible. They only let 3000 people in daily and it sells out early. We stood in line for 50 minutes in the rain in the off season...just to buy tickets. You can buy a combo of both tours (Selamlik and the Harem) or pick one. 2) Once you are through the main gates, you can then wander the grounds and take photos3) In order to view the inside of the palace, you stand in line again for 45minutes or more to get in via a tour. The front entrance is the Selamlik tour and the way back entrance is for the Harem tour.4) You cannot tour the palace itself unless you are part of the tours - there is an English tour line and a Turkish tour line. They are included in the ticket price and are mandatory to see the palace. The English tour line took 45 minutes - 1 hour again on the off season. It was insane. You then are allowed to enter in groups of 30 or so and given a tour. The guides speak decent English, and kind of funnel you quickly through. Not a lot of time to look and cameras aren't allowed. 4) We finished the Selamlik tour (which is the one the guidebook said to prioritize as it has all the opulent entertaining rooms and chandeliers), and you exit the building and walk a few minutes to the Harem tour...and there was another 45min-1 hour long line to get into those tours. We tried to take the Turkish tour (way shorter line) because we only wanted to see the place, but the guard was uncharacteristically rude and let people in only if they spoke Turkish to him without explaining. So the lines are Turkish if you speak Turkish, English if you don't. End of story. We gave up. We were so sick of waiting in lines in order to pay to wait in more lines and then treated rudely and hurried through. I can definitely say not worth it unless you don't mind wasting an otherwise fun day in Istanbul. Avoid. Way better to take a Bosphorus boat tour and sail past the water facade and take photo because the facade is stunning!

Could also be called the Queuing Palace. Following tripadvisor reviews we got there first thing in the morning (10am), and still found ourselves queueing 5 minutes to get in past the security checks, another 10-15 minutes to buy a ticket, and then 30 minutes to get on a tour. But we were so lucky, by the time we came out the queue was several hours long. This place is so worth it though, the ceiling paintings are stunning, the crystals drip off the masive chandeliers, stair cases are impressive, This place should be number 4 or 5 on your list of things to do in Istanbul.My suggestion, as with others in the past is skip the hotel breakfast and get to the Palace as it opens, or soon after 9am as you can. The hareem is very good, but after seeing the main palace, it's like having to take a Mercedes home after driving all day in a Rolls Royce. So just get the ticket for the main palace, unless you like queueing. The restaurant just outside the main gate just begs to have a coffee/tea and cake over looking the river and a good place to compare the photos you didn't take inside.

Sumptuous. This palace is further away from the main tourist attraction in the golden horn but it is worth a visit. You can reach it by public transport (Tram or water taxi) and you are there in 15minutes from Galata bridge. The interior of the palace is magnificent, do not miss the Harem too. Unfortunately you are not allow to take photos or video inside but you can download photos from their Website using your entrance ticket.

The palace is really good but too crowded. We spent far more time in queues than visiting the building. However, if you have not too much time, you can skip the Harem. The main building is far better.And be aware that the visits are allways guided tours. You are not allowed to visit the palace by yourself.

Stunning interiors, especially the Ceremonial Hall. Separate tickets are needed for the main visit and the Harem, and in both cases there is an imposed guided tour - both require a heavy investment in queuing time, which can be testing if it is sunny (and be prepared for a clash of queuing standards amongst the various visitors). I guess the imposed guided tour is practical as there are too many precious objects to have people roaming around randomly... however, both tours gave you the feeling of being in a chain-gang, yet the guides on both tours were excellant.The last "stop" on the palace tour is the Ceremonial Hall; the guide built up everyone's expectations in the preceding room, and frankly, he was right to do so...

Surprise. After a weird walk from Sultanahmet to Taksim, my husband and I ended up at the palace. We had wanted to stop for a bite to eat @ the waterfront cafe, but as it seems to happen to us, we were ignored (approx 10 tables came in after us and were served, even after I went & requested a menu) - as this was the 4th time this has happened to us, we left. I had nut bars and water in my bag, so that was lunch. We had only purchased the main tour, but after seeing the inside, wish I had also toured the harem. This palace is beautiful & extravagant & worth the admission fee. The downfall is the line-up for the tour. I'm not sure what it is, but at every line up we have been in in Istanbul, where there were not rope controls, people just push their way into line. And we are here at off-season. But if you want a good example of the opulence of the Sultan's, this is it. Worth it just to see the chandeliers.

Like being ripped off and screwed over? Visit Dolmabahce Palace!. The experience of Dolmabahce Palace was a terrible ripoff and I felt repeatedly fooled by the management.1. LONG LINES: We had to stand in line 4 times for this one attraction! First, we stood in line for 20 min before the main entrance, in order to pass through a "security check" which is a total hoax. The "security guards" didn't care to check people properly but still made you wait. Then, in the inside area, we stood in line for another 30 min for the entrance fee. Now, as you would expect to finally be let in, you get to stand in line for another 10 min, until your guided group can enter the public area of Dolmabahce. The same happened after this first part of the tour, we had to wait in line for 10 min to enter the harem. So, I spent more time standing in line than visiting the palace.2. RIP-OFF: You learn the price of the tour only AFTER having spent half an hour with the standing in line for the nonsensical "security check". As a non-Turkish citizen, you pay the double amount, which is 40 TL per person (=18€) instead of 20 TL (=9€).3. POOR GUIDING: You can only visit in groups of ca. 120 people. So, effective guiding would be possible, even if the guides tried. The different groups are in constant rotation, which is really good for their sales and really bad for the air inside and for the space you have while being chased through like cattle (=none). You don't get to choose where to go, not even how fast or slow you want to go through. We had two guides, one of which was really arrogant and unfriendly and the other just visibly overburdened with trying to cope with a group of more than a hundred people with children and very different temperaments. 4. NO PHOTOS, NO CAMERAS: But the best of all was, that you were not allowed to take photos or take videos. The sights are really remarkable and for the pains and expenses that you must take, you would at least have expected to be allowed photographing. Istanbul has plenty of other attractions, so don't waste your time with Dolmabahce Palace. At least not as long as their management is so overtly incompetent, egoistic, greedy, unfriendly and useless.

This was the best place in Istanbul !. I am not kidding, this was the best. I like history and art, and this was more beautiful like Versailles. Reccommend this the most. This palace is located near a sea in beautiful exotic gardens.

Great Palace, and a must see. Visited March 2013, spectacular palace and a must see in Istanbul, you will see a 4.5 tons chandelier in the main meeting hall...unfortunately one cannot take pictures inside , but that norm in all historical royal palaces...extravagant furniture and chandeleers all over the palace....if you are going to Istanbul, make sure to plan a visit , and that has to be booked through a travel agents in groups only

Great site to visit, very beautiful.. This palace is so over the top with more extravagance and opulence than I thought you could cram in to any one place. We went mid morning, the lines to get in were not too bad but you want to get there early enough to make sure you are one of the 3000 people daily that can actually tour the interior.

Don't skip this place!. This palace is a very beautiful building & well worth seeing. I know some people were put off by the fact that you can't just wander around on your own & you have to be guided round but the guides are very knowledgeable & happy to answer questions so I thought it was good the tours are guided. I know the French people along side us were upset & left after being told there was no French speaking guide so you can go on the English speaking tour! Well, they did ask in English! We got to see the changing of the guard outside whilst we were visiting & this was very good too, although the soldiers were not te best I've seen when it comes to parade drill!Well worth the visit & I am really glad we found the time for it.

Better than expected, worth visiting!. We nearly gave this one a miss and I am so glad we didn’t. The palace is very interesting, ostentatious and grand, not to everyone’s liking but worth seeing. The guided tours were not that good but there is no other way of getting inside. The main tours is far superior to the harem tour, the latter is not really worth the time (if you want to see a harem section the one in the Topkapı Palace is far superior). The gardens here are nice and there is a small café in the garden where you can sit next to the sea, the views are great and the prices modest.The queues are long and build up, also there are two queues one for security and one for the tikcets, best to get there early if possible.

Magnificent. They only have guided tour, the queue to enter was about 30 -45 mins for English session. The palace is so pretty! The entrance fee is on the high side, but totally worth it. It's maintained well and grand!
amazing palace. this is the latest ottoman palace built with baroque architecture style, the palace itself is nice as well as its garden.. so better to visit in the summer :)

simply amazing. wow is the first thing you say when you walk in. The palace is very kept and you get to see how the royal family lived. The grandure of the palace is amazing. The best part big Chandeliers.Do not miss the Haram. The down side is that no photography is allowed. Only guided tours allowed, if you are not part of a tour group, then you get a guided group tour from the palace.

Guided tour bad organized. This palace is really interesting and nice to visit. Unfortunately the guided tours are not really well organized. We had problems already buying the ticket since the credit card POS was not working (but it could happen). The major issue is that you are in big group and the tour guide is really difficult to understand or he does not wait that you are there in order to start with his explanation. Moreover due of the size of the group and due to the facts that some people does not speak/understand English, they will talk during the visit and you cannot follow the guide.Anyway it is really worth to pay a visit at this palace.

Royal Palace Tour. Grandeur all the way - this palace was very European-ized which was a sign of the times and what the Sultan was trying to do, be relevant. Grounds are gorgeous and it is right on the Bosphorus - highly reccomend.

The last Sultan's residence. Located on european side of Istambul, both the white exquisite sillouete of the palace glitters proudly into the blue watters of the sea and its interiors and decorations express the power of the old turkish great empire.Go and visit Dolmabahce Palace!You'll pay the utmost 50 turkish lira to see the fortune kept inside.Mike & Marry

Amazing. Dolmabahce Palace is a MUST-SEE in Istanbul. The tram from Eminonu to Kabatas would take you there. The palace houses the world heaviest chandelier. There is crystal staircase. The dome in the Ceremonial Hall is magnificient. Unfortunately, photography is not allowed inside the palace. All visitors would need to wait at the main entrance hall until being led in by a palace officer.

Impressive Royal Palace of Ottoman Sultan. Although i prefer genuine places over fancy ones, butt watching the Ottoman Royal Palace for real was overwhelming, they took a good care of the place, so u feel the royal family where here not long time ago..The Sultan Palace (Salamlek) is most like office rooms with some sleeping rooms very vast & very royal indeed..Female Palace (Haramlek for Harim) is more like Home, elegant & delicate..The most interesting part for me the royal library plus the big hall with giants chandeliers, with the largest carpet ever, used to be for other kings receptions ..Of course touching any of the furniture, taking photos are forbidden.. Enjoy... Enjoy...

Pleasantly Surprised. My travel companions and I went to Dolmabahce Palace as part of an all-day Bosphorus tour, similar to other reviewers. We were not expecting the grandeur that awaited us as we had not researched this sight in advance.We were shocked at how ornate the palace was. The sheer size and volume of the decor was truly amazing. The ceremony room at the end of the tour is definitely a great finish. Truly an amazing spectacle.As also stated by other reviewers, you cannot get in without an authorized guide. While that may be a turn off for some, the nice thing about it, at least for my group, we were able to get in right away without waiting. The downside of course is not being able to linger and explore, but seeing it is better than not!

A Must See. Forget the Aya Sofiya, the Blue Mosque or Topkapi Palace, Dolmabahce Palace is the one place to visit in Istanbul. My partner and I visited it in January on a bitterly cold day when it snowed. We saw it as a part of a whole day Bosphorus cruise and were awed by its splendour and beauty!The sad part was that we were part of a tour group and had only a limited time in the Palace. Apparently, one cannot visit the Palace unless as part of a tour group. If you are not attached to a tour group then you will be assigned to one under the watchful eye of a guide as well as security officers.We appreciated the security measures, which will surely help to preserve what is a treasure trove of priceless art and artifacts. That said, it was a tad irritating that we couldn't take our time admiring some of the artwork and had to scramble to keep up with the group. The artwork was simply magnificent! Paintings, sculptures, crystal, chandeliers.... the list is endless. No visit to this beautiful city would be complete without a visit to Dolmabahce Palace.
Chandeliers. The chandeliers are the best part. Overall the palace while nice reminds you of one in France or other places in Western Europe and doesn't feel particularly unique.

Must-go in Istanbul. This place will make your jaw drop with how insanely rich the Ottoman Empire was. The tours are well organized and the guides are very informative. Overall a really good experience and a must-go attraction in Istanbul

Filled in Garden. The literal translation of Dolmabahce is "Filled in" because they took a side of the Bosphorus and filled it in to make a riverside palace of splendour and the second largest in Istanbul, still used for special occasions. The interesting thing is not that it is the most glamorous building in the world, it is that the world and his neighbour has contributed to the furniture and fittings to give a cosmopolitan feel. French architecture is complemented by gifts from England, Germany, India, Japan, Russia, United States and China. All prove that Turkey is and always has been a strategic meeting point for the countries of the world.

Don't waist your time!. Probably I was expected too much... The palace is on the shore of sea, beautiful view, clear water, you can see fish. That's all my good memories. The line for tickets was long, but only one kiosk was working.We spend over one hour in the line, the toilet was crowded...After one hour in line for tickets, we were waiting in sun another 20-30 min. in line to go inside the palace. Not impressed of exposition at all, and this crystal steps look good only on pictures. The palace is divided in two parts, and you should pay for harem separate, but it is the part of palace! After all, we were waiting in another line, to go to harem! Welcome to Turkey!

Yet another palace. Don't get me wrong, this is a place definitively worth seeing; my point being, there are other places in Istambul that should be prioritized in your visit especially if you are pressed for time or if you have seen other palaces in Turkey or in any other country.

Luxury. We spent half a day at the palace. There is a guide who will take you around in a group. Very interesting to note the luxury lives lived by the ottoman kings then, and later ataturk. He spent his last days here in the pink room, a section of the harem. The scenery is beautiful. The harem is not to be missed. Interesting to see where the women of the household used to live. Can't really imagine, as too many heads can create a mess. I particularly loved the original furnitures, the baths, porcellains,and the chandeliers that can be seen in the saloon. By the way, photography in the palace is prohibited. Nevertheless you'll be able to snap great photos outdoors. And do not miss taking photos with the 'royal' guards. You'll be able to see them marching in the area too.

Expensive!. It costs more than the Versailles! And.no photos inside, I would consider twice if it is worthy of the value! You cannot visit yourself, instead there is tours every thirty minutes, you need to follow the guides, the crystal lights are amazing,but not the rooms after visiting many other famous palace.

Amazing. It's a great place. You shouldn't miss seeing it. The gardens around are marvellous and the view over the see is great. If you go on a sunny day you would take gorgeous photos in the garden. Photographing is not allowe inside.

Human Herding. Interesting to see,some fascinating areas.We were in a large group.
The guide was unintelligible in accent and volume.He carried on through each room regardless of anyone at the back who hadn't got there yet,so do your homework if you're interested in the history

Expensive,but beautiful. We had a luck not to stay in a crowd for hours.In 10 minutes after coming we`ll get out tickets. Remeber, that there is a discount for students. It`s forbidden to take any photos inside the building,even inside the clock museum(I highly recommmend to visit it.It`s located near Harem). The entrance fee is quite high,especially for Harem( you`ll run with the guide through the building for no more than 15 minutes and will get absolutely no information). The view to Bosphorus from the terrace of the Palace is impressive. In general, it`s worth visiting, but I recommend not to visit Harem(it`s not worth the money paid for it).

Splendid !. Beautiful European style palace . We visited the palace with our private guide , so didnt have to go along the group of people with the palace guide. (our guide came with us through out the tour of the palace). it was disappointing that photography was not allowed inside.We loved the garden and it was Autumn season, spend so much time in photography.Overall it is a not to be missed visit if you are in Istanbul.

Touring the Inside of the Palace. Our tour of the palace was the best attraction in Istanbul. While some travelers have noted that photos are not permitted inside the palace, this is not correct. You can take photos inside; but, you must pay an extra small fee, when you buy your tickets, to be able to take photos inside (well worth the small fee). Both the inside of the palace and the gardens attest to the wealth of the Ottoman Empire, whose extravangance is exhibited throughout the palace.This is a must see, along with visiting the Church of Sofia and the Blue Mosque.

Just one WOW during the visit. Read on guide books that this is a must do in Istanbul as it shows how powerful the royals were back in the 13/14 century, how they spent every possible penny to build this palace. You can't take photos inside the palace but you can do so in the gardens. The only room that we WOWed that was the Ceremonial Hall which was just incredible.

Wonderful place. One of those *must see* places. It is full of history and art, so full of any pleasure for your eyes. There are two main parts of Dolmabahce Palace, and you should see - both of them. Words are not enough , you must go there !!!You could buy ticket for one or both parts of Palace, but my advice is to buy both.If you have student card, or <26- card- you will pay much less then is regular ticket. So, don't forget to hold your card.Special pleasure is a position of DB Palace...on the Bosphor... so when you are very tired after visiting the Palace, you could spend a nice time near the water in the caffe- restaurant .
opulence. The title says it all. Everything is opulent.The ballroom with the chandelier is more than words can describe.Not to miss if you go to Istanbul.
Wonderful palace. It defines luxury!! This is one of the best places you can visit in Istanbul! The gardens are filled with amazing flowers and the views are spectacular from the palace

very well organized. guided tour is included in the ticket price and everything is very well organized in pretty small groups so you can hear everything and get a chance to ask questions or so. if you go there, don't be cheap - visit the whole palace! it's worth it!

Beautiful European inspired palace. The Dolmabahçe Palace is a beautiful palace decorated in a much more modern and European style than the Topkapi palace. Unfortunately you can only visit on guided tours (included in the price) which means you can't take photos, but at least the tours are in English and are fairly interesting.Regardless I thoroughly recommend this palace as it is much better preserved than the Topkapi palace. But make sure you come early especially in the warmer months, otherwise you will be waiting a long time.

You really must visit Dolmabahce while in Istanbul!. You absolutely have to visit Dolmabahce when you are in Istanbul! It is a beautiful palace along the Bosphorus and wonderful to tour. SO WORTH IT! The Grand Ceremonial Hall/Ballroom is HUDE - the largest in all of Europe.

Visit only if you have time left.... This palace is beautiful and extravagant in many ways, though it is by no means unique to Istanbul and Turkey; you can find equally opulent palaces in many other places around the world. You have to join an organised guided tour which is dull at best, since the guides do not speak English that well and they do not seem the that interested in explaing much to the visitors. The most interesting parts of the palace come at the end, so you have to be patient!!! The park is nice, right by the Bosporus, but that alone doesn't really warrant the quite hefty (by Turkish standards) entrance fees. It's also quite annoying that Turks pay less, for some reason.

the great monument. This place it should be visited, u can’t stop in Istanbul and don’t see the gorgeous palace, architecture painting the hard work inside this palace. It contains a mixture and variety of art work.

Interesting site but depends on how bad your taste is. I agree with prior reviewers: we did not have to wait in line (went about 1:00pm on weekday), but we were herded through the palace in a big group. Guide was both inaudible unless you were very close to her, and she was unintelligible if you could hear her. Basically, she droned through a memorized script. Harem was slightly better in terms of the guide, but we were still rushed through it, with strict rules not to wander from the group and not to take photos.The palace itself is a monument to extravagance, wealth, privilege, and vulgarity. There is hardly a square inch of floor, ceiling, or wall space that is not adorned, in a fantastic mishmash of styles, designs, and colors. The only unifying theme is the abundant use of elaborate inlaid woods, prodigious applications of gold, miles of silk, and tons and tons of marble. There were long corridors of paintings, but we had no time to look at them. Baths were a feature and quite engaging.The cost for this sprint is 40 TL a person, making it one of the more costly sights in Istanbul. Depends on your budget, but whether you go inside or not, the exterior itself is worth a visit, sitting on the shore of the Bosphorus with a commanding view of the Asian side of the city. Might be fair to say the most attractive part of the tour is looking out and away from the palace at the other side of the river.

Awesome trip to the Palace.... On my 7th visit (I just realized that :D...) to Istanbul on my to Geneve last January, I managed to visit Dolmabahce Palace in Istanbul... One majestic palace, that is... Claimed to be the biggest palace in Turkey, residing almost 15.000 m2, this relatively modern palace was constructed between 1843-56. Many Sultans had lived here.. Several choices of tour are available and I took the Selamlik tour, or the administrative part of the Palace. It lasts around 45 minutes and you have to wait till the designated time with a guide, no individual tour, et no photos inside. If you're coming with your own tour guide et group, you'll get a priority. In less than 1 hours, I saw a lot.The inside is really lovely, too bad we cant take pictures inside... some are amazing while the rest need to be maintained. The heavily Turkish accent guide took us around. We saw the secretariat's room, entrance hall, noble room, crystal staircase, wood panels, noble floor, ambassadorial, waiting room, sultan's reception room, crown prince room, sultan's apartment, with ebony, mahagony, and walnut wooden floor panels , and of course french baccarat fireplace.. We also see the study room, library, and remarkable turkish hamam with carved marbles, and lovely, lovely view of the Marmara sea...I would love to spend so much time here :D The best part is indeed the grand ceremony hall..with biggest chandeliers, weight around 4.5 tons, great carpet, huge pillars, and special balconies for jurnalists et musicians. Picture yourself dancing around the room...or maybe not dancing, just roaming around :D... Btw, most of the information given by the guide are printed in the brochures...so, make sure you have one copy... In one of the rooms we saw collections of big paintings, dining sets in gold et silver! Crystals and many gem-tinted objects.. Vases, draperies and some other valuables are presented, but the information on those displayed objects are not always available.All in all....The interior is amazing...the surrounding scenery is also lovely.. don't miss it...

Impressive. We visited the Dolmabahce Palace on a Sunday morning in February and despite arriving quite early it was already very busy.We waited a little while outside to be admitted to the entrance hall and then some more time inside until the English-speaking guide was ready to begin the next tour. You can't explore the palace yourself and the guided tour takes 45 minutes. Unfortunately, due to the size of the tour group, I found it very difficult to hear what the guide was saying so I just settled for looking at the opulent surroundings. The rooms are vast and elegant with beautiful chandeliers, mirrors and furnishings. It's a massive collection of buildings, so allow plenty of time to explore the whole site. The Harem visit involves a separate guided tour which takes 25 minutes more and then there are the picturesque grounds with a large aviary and great views along the Bosphorus.There is a cafe on site but we chose to exit the grounds and go to a smart cafe/restaurant just outside, close to the clock tower, with a view of all the river traffic. The locals were enjoying traditional breakfasts of hard boiled eggs, olives, salad and delicious bread and it seemed to be something of a family social event.The admission fee is higher than some of the other tourist attractions in the area (40 Turkish lira for the palace and Harem) but you could spend the whole day exploring the site at your leisure.My only criticism is that the palace could do with some love and improvement - the carpets are getting threadbare and the silverware in the cabinets needs to be polished - it was almost black. A young boy in our tour group touched one of the window blinds and it actually fell off because it was in such bad condition.

Eye popping opulence !. Built late in the Ottoman Empire, it was designed to impress European ambassadors and the like. It is really amazing, with the palace being gilded in gold and exquisite paintings. The harem section is also impressive, although built more for comfort than to impress. Cost was 40 TL for both sections.

Unbelievably grand. This palace has to be seen to be believed. It is one of the most opulent places we have ever visited. It was not overly crowded and we were able to see a great deal of the complex.
dolmabache palace. beautiful well-presented palace with with well informed guides taking you around. Amazing grand hall. Beautiful water-front views. Well worth a visit.

Jaw dropping. One of the most beautiful  palaces  Ive ever visited. Its modern European-Ottoman mix of architecture and design makes unique among others.Wait till you see the grand ceremonial hall ;)The only downside is the guided tour time  which takes only 45 min in the main palace and 25 min in the Harem section.

Better harem here!. Our Bosphorus boat ride tour guide gave us the tip to see the harem rooms here, rather than at Topkapi Palace, because they are furnished and you can get an idea of how the residents actually lived. The Topkapi harem rooms are empty. The Dolmabahce Palace has amazing, huge crystal chandeliers and other decor to impress foreign visitors to the Sultans. There are beautiful views along the waterfront.

Sumptuous but a disappointment for photographers. The Palace is easy to get to, its just a few minutes walk along the river from Kabatas tram stop. It cost 30TL each to get in and for the tour, sadly you can not explore on your own and photography of any kind is prohibited inside the Palace building which is a real shame because the interior is stunning with wonderful chandeliers and art works includinga stair case with bacaret crystal banisters. The cafe on site gets very crowded and the only less than spotless toilet we encountered all trip.

Great palace. Awesome Palace, great location by Bosporus sea. One of the things you must see in Istanbul. I was disappointed when i saw that photos inside were not allowed. Our guide explained us everything about that Palace.

Last palace built. It was the last palace built at the end of the Ottoman Empire. You will see the Western influence compared to Topkapi Palace. This palace was also the location where Ataturk, the founder of Turkish Republic passed away.

Waste of time and money. I was surprised to find out that I didn't like Dolmabahce Palace all that much. If you are running out of time and want to skip something, this would be it. It looked like Europe threw up in the reception rooms. Way too much gilding and fake painted marble. Not worth the 30 TL price (40 TL if you buy the palace and harem ticket together). Also, if you are running short on time, be careful here because they only show the palace and harem by guided tour. Depending on when you arrive, you may have to wait for the next English tour. I went here right before leaving for home so I had to get to the airport. I thought I could just walk around by myself and so bought both the palace and harem tickets. I didn't get in to see the harem because the palace tour took too long. Honestly, I don't think the guided tour is very good, either. They didn't say anything that couldn't have been put on signs in the rooms. The tour talked generally about the use of the rooms and some of the furniture in the rooms. Nothing that you need a guide for.
A real highlite. One of the most impressive architectural ensembles in Istanbul and MUST SEE for every visitor in Istanbul.

Fantastic. We had a guided tour of this palace last week and due to it being a quiet day we had a guide all to ourselves. He explained everything to us and made it a very interesting visit. We have visited many palaces throughout Europe but i have to say that this is the most beautiful one of all. It is a must on any trip to Istanbul.

Beautiful but no photos allowed. Very beautiful museum and interesting, however very expensive and I was a bit underwhelmed. It is very European in appearance and the harem was really not worth seeing. The grounds are very pretty and nice to walk around and the guide is very informative. However they are very strict that no photos are allowed and if you try and sneak a pic they will catch you - be warned! the changing of the guard outside the palace is definitely worth watching.

Most Luxurious Living I've Ever Seen. I visited the Dolmabahce in December, so it was definitely the off-season for tourism. I didn't have to wait in a line to tour the Dolmabahce and it was comfortable inside. That being said, this was probably my favorite tourist site during my visit to Istanbul. It was absolutely mind blowing how intricate all of the wood work, masonry, and crystal work was throughout the palace. If I had to dream up a palace of my own, a lot of the features of the Dolmabahce would be present. You can't walk through the tour without pondering the enormous wealth the sultans must have had to build such a palace. Everything is covered in gold, marble, crystal, and pearl. Even little things like exotic woods embedded in the doors. If you plan on visiting any other palaces while in Istanbul, save this for last, because we went to see the Beylerbeyi Palace later in the day and it completely pales in comparison to the Dolmabahce.

Beautiful Palace on the Bosphorus. Great palace & harem with lovely furniture & furnishings.The long waits were a problem. More ticket sellers & guides might help.Restaurant was overwhelmed and there was no place to sit down.

Good to see!. It is a very nice palace and museum, you get to see 35 tonnes of gold!!I mean it was presenting all there is that was worth of riches and money! From the crytals to The world's largest Bohemian crystal chandelier is in the center hall, a gift from Queen Victoria of England.It is forbidden to take photos inside the palace, and it is a guided tour (from their staff).It\s very beautiful, it has a coffee shop outside, make sure you take a tea cup by the sea outside. We were there during the winter and it was REALLY COLD and yet we did have a tea outside! It was worth it :)I can imagine how beautiful it would be during the summer!ONE advice: visit this place VERY early in the morning or you will have a LONG queue!

worth visiting but expensive for what you get. it was a guided tour and the girl was explaining well, but I dont think its one of a kind , they are exagerating I guess... and you didnt have time to really look at the paintings or furnitures...go there if only u have extra time

Magnificent - a must see!. I absolutely love this palace - it is up there with Versailles and Petrohof Palace. Make sure you also visit the Harem. Everything is just so ornate and grand - the staircases, the chandeliers, just everything. The only sad thing is that you are not allowed to take photos! If short on time, visit here instead of Topkapi Palace!!

Glamourous Palace. from Sultanahmed we took tram to Kabatas and 10 minutes walk to this Palace. I recommended come early just before the opening at 9am to avoid the queue. Paid 40 lira combine ticket to the Selamlik/official part (30lira) and the harem (20lira). It was more pricey than any other attraction in Turkey, and you must join the group guided by the official staff to entry the Palace. Too bad we can't take picture inside. The crystal staircase railing, the biggest chandelier, the Sultan bath, the wall painting, and the whole building are stunningly glamorous..this is a Palace should be..
