nice palace musuem. you can visit one of the Ottaman palace and also have a coffee break at Bosphourus. it is near to Besiktas ferryboat station.

Worth for waiting a long queue. If you have a long queue, I could say it's worth for waiting. Good place to visit. Fantastic inside the Palace by the best official guide I've ever known. She described all information about the Dolmabahce Palace. What, when, where, how with a loud and clearly voice. Love to visit here.

Deserves higher rating but.... I would have rated this much higher but fact that entry is only permitted with a guide - they group of people per guide is way too many. If you are stuck towards the back of the group you cannot hear the guide. The guide completes the tour too quickly so that one has no chance to look at everything of interest.
European sultans.... This palace is magnificent! Like a Romanov palace, or French and Austrian palace. All that gold and crystal... and harem. You have to see it.

Very Interesting!. We were taken round on a guided tour - individual visits were not allowed - but the guide was very pleasant and knowledgeable thus making the visit much more enjoyable. This wasn't on my original list of sights to see, rather I was dragged there, but by the end it turned out to be one of the best visits we made during our few days there. Would recommend it to anyone with an interest in Ataturk and Turkish history, and it's worth going to see the opulent chandeliers and furnishings alone.

my fairy castle. The palace is very nice. Take time to visit it as it can get very crowded and the queue to entering the palace can take hours - first to buy the ticket and then to enter the palace as all visits are guided.

A place where golden means gold.. Too many details, impossible to observe carefully everything! The tours are guided and controlled, when you realize the visit is over: hand made wood floors, the decoration of the walls, carpets, chandeliers, furniture, paintings, fabrics; you really don't know where to look and it's impossible to see so many details.It's important to visit the harem and take in consideration when it was built.Beautiful gardens, nice view from inside and outside.

Significant historical site but a poorly presented tourism experience. Firstly, get there early as you need to get through three queues 1. Police bag check 2. Ticket booth 3. Entry to palace. You are taken through in a large (read very large) group and you follow a 'maze' through the palace stopping at various points to hear (in our case) a very unimaginative rote speech from a guide who lacked passion or interest. We had an English language tour which worked for us but not sure if everyone in our large group understood English. What should have been an amazingly interesting and rich experience turned into an ordeal and I was glad when the 'tour' finished. Whilst acknowledging the complexities involved in getting large numbers of people through a historic building as well as accommodating visitors from around the world who speak many different languages, I do think that the organisers need to rethink how they present and interpret this major historical site. Having said this it is still worth visiting just get their early I.e. 0900.

Warning to visit at opening or waste hours in line. Consider this to be more of a warning than review. Dolmabahçe Palace is an amazing piece of work, displaying the grandeur at the end The Ottoman Empire, mid 1800's. But and a very big BUT, plan to visit at opening time unless you're prepared to waste hours of your holiday, standing in line. We arrived at noon on January 2 and endured a 1 hour wait to pay for admission, followed by another painful hourlong wait to gain access to the palace and tour. You cannot walk through the palace at will, the tour, lasting about 40 minutes, is compulsory to control access. Given it's historical importance and popularity, the administration is woefully incompetent in it's site management. At other popular attractions around the world, a simple timed admission policy allows for a coherent manner of crowd control; not the case here. The groups of 50 or so, eventually merge into a single mass with the guides trying to talk over each other in the same rooms. Close to mayhem. Waiting to gain entry, we were fortunate the weather was beautiful for January, about 12 degrees C and sunny. Had it been the middle of summer with temperatures in the 30s (90s F) it would be unbearable, considering there is no shade by the palace entrance.Once again, Dolmabahçe Palace is a jaw dropping example of opulence; unfortunately I would only recommend worth a visit if you're able to go at opening, before the crowds. The administrators should be ashamed at treating their visitors in such manner and need to hire competent professionals who are able put into place, an admission policy which works. The current system is a total failure.I'm rating it 1 star due to horrible wait times and a total disaster in delivering a suitable visitor experience for a very high cost but the Palace is a 5 star destination. You have been warned!

Beautiful Palace. My idea of a Palace!! Just beautiful!! Crystal staircase railing, beautiful crystal chandeliers, also the largest crystal chandelier, a gift from the Queen. The furniture, paintings, decorating, designs, views of the sea. This palace is one of the most beautiful palaces I have visited. A must if in Istanbul. Beautiful gardens. Can't say enough about this palace. It was a perfect day, not crowded at all. The highlight of the trip!
Beautiful. What a stunning palace. Definitely recommend it to everyone visiting Istanbul. Entrance fees includes a group guide. Our guide was very knowledgable and funny.

Breathtaken but very crowded. this palace is just amazing♥ very beautiful chandeliers and you get to see one of the biggest chandeliers in the world. Breath taken and royal interior designes influenced by the Europeans. Loved the mix of gold and other colors. Very expensive to see both the main palace and the harem 40 TL. You will have guide for one big group. photo taken is not allowed. Very crowded and alot of impatient touriests who will push you around . Be ready to fight for your spot.

A different side of the Ottoman Empire. My family and I enjoyed the contrast of this palace to Topkapi. The public rooms are so over-the-top in opulence. Surprisingly, the Harem section was much less ornately decorated, whereas at Topkapi, it was the Harem that was the most spendidly decorated. My husband says that they need to light the giant chandelier for us lowly tourists!

Beautiful palace. lovely palace, nice gardens and magnificent sea view. We were lucky that that day they opened the bed room where Mustafa Ataturk died so it was cool seeing it. Cameras are not allowed inside the palace but you can still take pictures in the garden and while waiting in line. Make sure you go when its not so crowded, the lines could be really really long. If you go in with a tour company the lines are different. We didnt have to wait in line for the tickets and we only waited for about ten minutes to get through the entrance. Plus the groups are smaller than the tour groups provided by the palace itself so it was easier to listen to all the amazing facts and enjoy our time.

A must to visit, You can not miss it. It is magnificent; it is a must to visit.I had visited many palaces in different countries but this is one of the best.The drawing on the walls and ceiling are gorgeous.The carpets are great The chandeliers are " oh my god" wow.You really feel you are in a real palace with all the luxury that you find it whenever you go in terms of furniture, carpets,Really it worth seeing
Magnificent. A must see! Magnificent place. I suggest to be visited during spring when the magnolia trees in the yard blossom. The palace is beautiful!

Beautiful place to visit. A nice attraction; initially were hesitant to go as we had young children and we thought they would get tired. Luckily enough, the place held their - and our- interest. A big factor in this was probably the tour guide we got, who recounted interesting facts about the palace and its inhabitants, with bits and pieces of relevant history, etc.

Some lovely rooms. There are some really lovely rooms in the palace (both in the Selamlik and the Harem sections - combined ticket is 40 Lira per person). All tours are guided but the quality and quantity of infirmation is limited)
MUST. go early in the morning as the queues can be stupidly LONG. other than that, enjoy your time because its magnificent.

Modern Palace of the Sultans. This is a modern design on an old institution. Built after Topkapi Palace, this grand palace housed the Sultan and his clan in a more modern European influenced structure. Topkapi with it's dilapidated smallish rooms and uneven concrete walkways and hallways, contrast sharply with this modernist re-creation of the living quarters and domain of the Sultans of the Turkish empire.  Complete with giant chandeliers and 4 to 5 meter tall doors leading to spacious rooms, this huge structure sits along the Bosphorus sea. Admission includes a guided tour in English and takes about an hour. The harem guided tour also, takes about an hour and both can be purchased at the same time. Between tours, visit the small cafe and have some Turkish tea. (You might even see the peacock walking around) The elegance and shear size of the palace, along with it's informative tour is worth the slightly overpriced entrance fee. To get the full historical significance, it seems visiting both palaces is essential.  It is a short walk from Kabatas ferry terminal via either the funicular from Taksim or tram from Galata. After, spending the morning at the palace and grounds, you can get on the ferry and head to the Asian side of the Bosphorus. The ferry gives you great views without having to take the Bosphorus cruise.

Salamlek amazing. Haramlek not so interesting.. Seriously guys if you're planning on going there just go visit the salamlek. The decorations inside it are beyond discription, amazing and far too beautiful. The walkthrough would appear oring at first but when you come to the end you'll love the grand hall. It is the most beautiful hall I've ever seen. I actually never saw any thing like like it. Don't other going to the haramlek cause it's actually not that amazing. If you're interested in seeing Mostafa Kamal Ataturk's death bed then be my guest but other than that there is nothing really there to see. You'll probably enjoy the gardens and view from the palace. Enjoy a cup of chay in the café and get a souvenir on your way out. Very nice experience.

Like a princess... If you want to visit the palace you should go in the morning because the ticket line is very long..the tickets are not sold in advance..photography is not allowed inside so the big cameras can cause problems..the palace is so beautiful you feel like a king here..crystal staircases, golden gilded ceelings, beautiful view of the bosphorus..harem section is more simple but still ornate.if you have time you can visit the clock collection and the crystal pavillion.
Amazing !. The visit through the palace makes you feel like you enter the Ottoman way of life !!Drawbacks: visits are only in Turkish and English..

Dolmabahce Palace - Sultanate to Republic. It was built between the years 1843 and 1856 on the waterfront of Bosphorus. Ottomans shifted their residence from Topkapi palace to Dolmabahce and it remained their residence from 1856 to 1924 when Turkey became a Republic. Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the founder and the first President of the Republic of Turkey, used this palace as a Presidential residence during the summers. Ataturk spent his last days in this palace, where he died in 1938. It is a beautiful palace with a breathtaking view of Bosphorus.

rushed. Its an amazing place but you are herded like sheep - we eventually just let the tour group go ahead and admired at our own pace- the highlight for me was the bathrooms - but I wont recommend this palace as a "HAS TO SEE".

Impressive but very restricted. The guided tour of the palace was very nice with a knowledgable and friendly guide that spoke good english. We were dissapointed by not being allowed to take any photos and our group (the last of the day) was hurried through and not allowed to see a portion of the palace (een though the cost was the same as if we had). The tour was cut short and by the time it ended there was virtually no time to visit the gift shop. If you go be sure to go early in the day. If you are going to tour other city sites consider buying a Museum Pass.

Great palace, though very expensive to get in. I loved this palace, it's great and magnificent. Every single thing about it is majestic and beautiful. The only problem here is that you can't take pictures inside and they charge way more than any other place I've been to in Istanbul.

magnificent place. visiting this place is a must, a luxury palace of the sultans, this is the most beautiful historic place to visit in Istanbul don't forget to get a ticket to see the Harem where the sultan's family used to live, there is a crystal chandelier that weights 4.5 tons in the largest reception room in the palace.

One of the best palace to visit in Istanbul.. We visited the palace and Harem as two tours costing around $20 per person. Beautiful chandeliers, paintings by french artists, beautiful Grand Hall with world's largest chandelier was a great site. Taking pictures prohibition was the only draw back. The Harem tour was fun to see how these Sultan lived. It was very enjoyable history lesson.

Visitors treated like cattle. An interesting place to visit, but overpriced at 40 Turkish Lira (TL) for the complete tour, including the harem, which is merely the sleeping areas but does include Kamal Ataturk’s bedroom. Without the harem, the cost is 30 TL. Please be advised that you must see the building with a guide. Tours are offered in Turkish and English, but you’ll have to strain to understand the English. My group had about 100 people. The guide would get to a particular point and start speaking although most of the people had not yet reached him because they were still looking at a previous room or unable to move quickly because of the narrow corridors. This was a problem throughout the tour of the harem. When asked to wait until all the visitors had reached him, he said that he was not to blame. My impression is that he wanted to finish the tour as quickly as possible.

Such Opulence!!. Definitely visit this palace if you can. It is situated on the beautiful Bosphorus and is beautiful!! There is the tour of the palace and a separate tour of the harem. Both are very interesting and the opulence reminds one of Versailles, only fancier. Well kept and incredible! Worth the entrance fee and if it is nice there is a refreshment 'stand' on the front side on the Bosphorus! Also one by the harem. The Clock tower is beautiful as well as the grounds and at night the Mosque lights up blue and is striking!

A Treasure Trove in Instanbul. This palace is a must see if you are in Istanbul. It's easy and cheap to access from Sultanamet by tram to Katabas which is the last stop. The palace is just a short walk from there. Entrance is quite costly though, 40TL for two tours I.e. the main palace tour and the harem tour. You can tour just the main palace for 25TL and for many people that might be the better option because this area is by far and away the most spectacular. The Palace was built in 1856 and housed the last Sultans as the Ottoman Empire crumbled. Later Ataturk, the father of the Turkish Republic worked, lived and died there. The Palace is nothing short of spectacular. Be aware however that you must go on a guided tour there which is rather annoying because they tend to be rather large - around 50 people, so it's difficult to hear and you are rushed through. Also you need to wear overshoes to enter.

Makes Versailles seem quaint. It really is over the top and quite beautiful. The drag is that you can't see the interiors on your own, so you are on a tour which to me moved at a faster pace then I would have liked. While the tour gave you some information it was hard to get an opportunity to take your time to see everything. Also the tour seemed to have too many people so you either had to stay close to the tour guide and rush or take your time and see things but miss what the tour guide was saying.

worth a visit, but prepare for queues. They only allow no more than 3000 visitors a day, so you'd better come before the noon to be there. Traveling from Sultanahmet area, it's easy to take tram and get off on the last stop. The palace will be ahead of you, in a short walking distance. Taxi from Sultanahmet will cost no more than 30 TL, from Taxim/Pera - no more than 20 TL (never use non-metered taxi!).The palace itself is grandeur, really worth a visit, but personally I find their "only guided tours" policy very inconvenient and annoying. You always have to queue up and wait for the guide who takes groups of 50-60 people at one time, so you can't hear him most of the time. I can't understand why they don't allow self-visitors since there are care-takers everywhere inside the palace, so you won't break or mishandle anything. Despite the most reviewers, I would skip the harem part. it's mostly the same women apartments along the corridor, so there's not much to see. Could be more interesting if accompanied by a private guide who can explain you everything and tell some stories about the harem's everyday life in sultan times. If you go with a group tour - give it a miss.

Have to see it, but takes some time and effort. You can only visit this palace in groups, either organised groups, or individuals queing up for either a tour in English or Turkish, so you may have to wait 20-30 mins to get in. There are 2 tours, the Palace and the Harem. Aspects of the tour are boring in terms of the commentary, though each room has its own interest. And if you like your chandilers big, be prepared to be wowed when you see a 4.5 ton one. No pictures are allowed inside the place, so reckon on getting a book before or after. It is another sight where you have to put plastic protectors on your shoes.See Ataturk's bed complete with a Turkish flag silk duvet cover.

Put on your bucket list. Great palace designed by Garabet Balyan has a good combination of west and oriental built in the 1800´s. A lavish structure and a must when you visit Istanbul. Put this on your bucket list of things to do.

Amazing palace!. Visited the palace in November which is a great month as less busy. Nevertheless all entries are conducted by a guide either English or Turkish so we waited 15 mins for the English tour to begin. Our shoes had to be covered by protective covering (provided) before entering. Oh it was so worth it - it's mind blowing. The shear opulence of the crystal chandeliers (bacarrah and English crystal) was astonishing as we're the beautiful carpets and ornate furniture. I found it an emotional experience and worth the 50 minute tour. Would have excluded the harem which was an optional cost as it was an anti-climax after the main palace. Beware of taking a taxi from outside the palace to return to the Sultanahmet area as we were totally ripped off being charged over double the price.

Over-rated and over-priced. The Dolmabahce Palace was built between 1843 and 1856 and the last six sultans of the Ottoman Empire lived in this palace. It is also the place where Mustafa Kemal Attaturk died at 9:05 AM on 10 November 1938. Attaturk used the Dolmabahce Palace as a residence when he was in Istanbul although he lived in Ankara. Since his death, no one has lived in the palace; it was turned into a museum. There are no individual tours to the palace. There are two sections that can be visited: the Selamlik (or ceremonial) portion of the palace and/or the Harem-cariyeler (harem and concubines' quarters). The room where Attaturk died (which has been preserved exactly as it was at the time of his death) is included in the Harem-cariyeler tour. You can also buy a ticket called All Palace which includes both tours and is supposed to include the Crystal Pavilion and the Clock Museum. Unfortunately, when we visited in late November 2012, both of these areas were closed.This is one of the most expensive attractions in Istanbul and it is not worth the price. Apart from the beautiful chandeliers (primarily in the Selamlik area of the palace), and several beautifully painted ceilings and parquet floors, this palace is in sad need of a refurbishment. This is especially true for the harem portion of the tour. In spite of the high admission fee, no photographs are allowed in the palace and the guidebooks for sale are rather sad. A cheaper edition is really amateurish and the more expensive edition makes a very heavy addition to your suitcase. There are some postcards which show the highlights but even they need to be updated by a professional photographer. Our visit was really a disappointment.

A great must see palace. Wonderful palace! Majestic... you'll be amazed by the crystal / gold chandeliers.. by the quality rugs... the amount of photos inside.. but the top in this palace is the painted ceiling in one of the halls. The least i could say is AMAZING

Go prepared. This is a magnificent place to visit, IMO better than Topkapi. The Turkish people are justifiably proud of this site and there are a few guidelines to be aware of before you decide to go:it is 30tl to get in with extra charge on top of that for Harem and Ataturks bed chamber. It is closed on Mon and Thursdays. There is no skip the line, only 60 people get in at any one time, and the groups are ALL lead by a guide Turkish and English only I think. You cannot take strollers, you cannot take photos, and you have to wear plastic covers on your shoes. You will probably have to wait for your tour group to start. The tours are approx 1hr in duration.That's all the rules! Is it worth it, resoundingly yes in my opinion. It is beautifully presented in an amazing location and the rooms are breathtaking.

Amazing. Istanbul is the place where east meets west. Topkapi and Dolmabahce are fine examples of that plus old vs. modern as well. Entry fee to non-harem part is 30TL and harem is 20TL but if you buy both then it's 40TL. Upon entry, you are given to wear plastic on your shoes and photography is not allowed. Security will hook you up with set guided tours. These tours don't cost extra money. Castle has captured both Roman and Muslim architecture details nicely. It offers a very nice back drop to pictures so don't forget your camera and take a lot of pictures outside the palace.

Beautiful. Very beautiful building, it is very interesting to go around the rooms and the gardens . There is a big line of people at the entrance, so it is a good idea to buy tickets in advance , or book a tour .

Okay as palaces go. If you are a place fan then do go to Dolmabache. Its still a lot of endless shuffling along behind roped off aeas and less impresssive than some other palaces around the world. Personally this is not my thing - I had the same feeling when visiting the mansions in Newport Rhode Island

Awsome. What a place, what a sarayi as turkish say. Very special architecture lot of gold and crystals. Try to go early to get your tickets. No need for agency to arrange your trip just take the tramway until kabatas final station then walk for 10mn with bosphorus view, pay your ticket 40TL and enjoy.

EUROPEAN PALACE DOLMABACHE ISTANBUL. this palace is rival to versailles,or peterhof or buckingham palace in history, unlike topkapi that is asian in design...this is the european palace of the ottoman sultans...a eleborate and over the top palace, well worth the visit....see (the most expensive and largest chandlier in the world a gift from Empress of India Victoria)gold and gemstones, this was def too impress...if you have visited palaces like royal palace in madrid,versailles,peterhof,the kremlin,caserta buckingham,blenhiem and many others...this dolmabahce competes with the best of them in gold and luxury...turkish rugs in the thousand...be prepared for long queues....but this is worth the wait and money, take a bottle of water for the wait...essp in the summer months, and a guide is recommended...like topkapi the panorama from here looking out on the bosphorous is europe and asia,unbelivable impressive,awe inspiring...how this city of istanbul is not in the top 10 of tripadvisor is unbelivable...this city is unique, so large,so populated(15.5m)2012,eastern and western...and what other city on the planet is in europe and asia...

Worth waiting in line for. Be prepared that during summer the lines are long and if you are without tour, you might be waiting up to two hours there. When you already in you will be attached for free to Turkish speaking or English speaking guide that will tell you everything about the place.It's a great place to take pictures and get to know more about culture!

magnificent. just came back from istanbuland i dont have any words to describe what i saw!!!!!perfect...im from greece and suppose to be more connected with aya sofia but dolma bahce palace was something else..40 tons of gold in the wals and in diferent objects....the all palace was effect of the european rythms of buildings of 19 century...very expensive entrance

The Versailles of Istanbul!. Do not skip this palace, thinking that you have had enough of history! It is a masterpiece of its time. Built in the 19th Century, the Palace is exquisite. Right from the architecture, to the lovely chandeliers, it is absolutely amazing. We were about to drop it off our list reading that the ticket was expensive and it was just a 45 min guided tour, but I am glad that we didnt! the ticket is 40 TL (including the harem, while at Topkapi its 25TL + another 15TL for the Harem so its the same) Yes, its important to stay close to the speaker so that you can hear what they have to say... the speakers are good at answering your questions also. Its difficult to enjoy if you are travelling with young kids ( we went with 2 kids both under the age of 4), strollers are not allowed, you have to ensure nothing is touched and only a small section is open to public. HOwever you may take turns with your spouse, one takes the tour while the other baby sits.

Bring lots of patience, because its gorgeous inside.. A bit of history:Dolmabahce was the residence of the last sultan of the Ottoman Empire after closing Topkapi Palace. Architecture is amazing to see since it is mainly European styles like Baroque, Rococo and Neoclassical styles with infusion of Ottoman.Why rated low?This palace is definitely worth a visit! As with the other reviewers, there is no chance that you can avoid looong queues. Queing is already 2 hours worth of your time. You queue to buy tickets, and you queue once more because they only allow small batch of people to go inside the palace with a walking guide.Tips:- If you are a group, you can split up and the others are eating at the nearby cafe and bring something to entertain.- If you are alone, this a good time to chat with the other people. I've seen more turkish families visiting this place as well.- They restrict the number of people that come in everyday. If you arrive in the afternoon, chances are you are not going to get in before it closes at 3PM.- There is suppose to be an e-reservation system online, but it is currently not working. (http://www.millisaraylar.gov.tr/portalmain-en/default.aspx) Maybe in the near future.

The process is frustrating-spoiled this visit. The palace exterior is impressive-the inside is less so (gaudy, but interesting because of that). However, the process for seeing the palace left us frustrated. You queue to buy your tickets, then walk through to the gardens-which are lovely, with heat views onto the water. You then join another queue to get into the palace, we waited for 20 mins). You must go on a tour (of palace, and/or harem). The staff called forward all the Turkish speakers in the queue to enter, as that was the language of the first group. 10 mins later the one in English ran. We were lucky to get into our group-last folks through-otherwise we would have had to wait longer.Our group was large, perhaps bad luck. The fact that only Turkish, or English tours were offered, and you cannot go in unaccompanied was surprising. I felt sorry for the 90% of people in our groups that were not native English speakers, and some that obviously couldn't speak any English but were forced to trek round. There are no information boards, so if you are at the back of the group you probably won't hear well. The guide also needs to take you round quickly, so he was reduced to short pieces about the palace, which weren't very interesting-no anecdotes, just the bare facts. Not a criticism of him, more the process. He ended up speaking some Spanish to guests too.You cannot linger to look at anything, so have to move through with your group. We were totally fed-up and pressed for time, so decided not to go to the harem. We tried to get our money back- painful, exasperating and fruitless. The admissions desk manager was rude and disinteresting, citing the barcode on our ticket as the reason why a refund was impossible...it made little sense, but he stuck to it, whilst shrugging, and smoking. He sent us to the information point to deal with the issue, but phoned ahead to tell them to deny us anything. The woman there was helpful, and looked a little embarrassed by the whole thing. I didn't expect my money back, but by that stage I was frustrated - in for a penny, in for a pound! The only time we had a poor interaction in Istanbul.
You cant avoid queues. Nice place to visit, there are queues but unavoidable. The tour round is quick and uninformative so its not the best in Istanbul but worth it .

Glad we decided to visit on our last day... 1. How to get there: No need to go there by taxi, use tram, it is very close to the last tram station KABATAS, we walked north from there for about 7-10 min with our 5yo child.2. Time&fee: It closed on Mon&Thu, Fee: 30TL-palace only entrance included tour guided, 40TL palace+harem tour guided, kids: free. No photo&tripod inside the building, but yes for the exterior building and garden. (We bought reasonable price postcard with interior pictures at the gift shop after the tour.) We bought the palace only entrance, but lucky to get a special tour that included both palace and harem since we visited at the kurban bayrami holiday. IMHO, Palace section is better than harem, but Ataturk room is in the harem section. 3. Review: We join a large group people for english tour and wear plastic cover for our shoes. I had read reviews that complain about the guide, but we got a charming lady who speak very good english and give interesting information. True, Its a quick tour, under 1 hour, but still really nice. Unlike other main attractions in Istanbul that lack of interior furniture, in this palace we saw original interior furniture that used by previous sultans and Ataturk. The crystal staircase, beautiful paintings, huge carpets, and chandelier at the last main hall are fantastic.
Breathtaking!. Beautiful palace and gardens. You can see the place where famous Ataturk lived and died. Equipment of the palace is original and guides provide very interesting informations.

Visit. Great place to visit ,except you have to join a large group with a local guide and as we know Turks speak little to no English so it was very hard to understand what our guide was saying and you have to follow a given path

worth a visit. very organised tour with a guide. really worth seeing the palace. has a lot of rooms to see. the main room at the end is one of the longest room in the world some 25,000 sq ft. . really nice. english tour 11 a.m.

Dolmabahce Palace is the overlooked gem of Istanbul.. Pure opulence.A fantastic step back in time and treasures.The scale and grandeur of the palace and palace life is often overlooked by other sites such as the Sultan Ahmed mosque (the Blue Mosque) and the Hagia Sophia.Be sure to check opening times as on certain days the palace is closed.No cameras are allowed but the gift shop has very reasonably priced postcards.

A fabulous palace. Dolmabache easily rates as one of the best palaces outside Europe. A magnificent building with attractive collections and huge chandeliers is a must see place in Istanbul. The tours are a little hurried not giving enough time to appreciate the beauty of the place.

A must see in Istanbul. This wonderful palace was home to 6 sultans and is decorated and furnished so extravagantly it is easy to visualise how life must have been in those days. Lovely gardens and right on the banks of the Bosphorus

Top Sight in Istanbul, Incredible Decor. Dolmabahce Palace became the residence of the Sultans after they decided Topkapi Palace was too sparse. To give you some idea of the level of decor, they used 14 tons of gold leaf to decorate the palace. There's a mind boggling staircase made with balusters of Baccarat crystal and the Grand Ballroom has an English crystal chandelier that weighs four tons. The place is filled with beautiful carved furniture and paintings that recall the glory days of the Ottoman Empire. Kemal Attaturk spent his last days there and you can see where he lived and died. Dolmabahce Palace can be easily reached by taking the Old Town T1 tram to the end of the line at Kapatas and walking about 10 minutes along the coast. There are two tours, one of the main diplomatic area and one of the harem. The harem tour is a poor second to the diplomatic area tour, but I recommend buying a combination ticket (40 TL) and doing them both unless you are really pressed for time. Each tour runs approximately every half hour in English and Turkish. The combination tour ticket is also good for the excellent Palace Collection Museum which is a bit of a walk down the coast past the museum walls toward the Naval Museum. Even if it is a bit crowded I wouldn't miss the Dolmabahce Palace when visiting Istanbul.

Crowded but interesting. Usually a visit to Dolmabahce means that you have to join two separate guided tours if you want to see the whole Palace - the Harem and the State Rooms. However, on the day we visited they were doing a single tour of both areas at a reduced price. The tour groups are huge and on this day you could only opt for tours for either 'Turkish citizens' or 'tour in English' - there is no possibility of a self guided tour. The Palace is very opulent and the tour was interesting but at times it was hard to hear everything the guide had to say as the group was so large. You are not allowed to take photos inside the Palace but that didn't stop some people who actually asked us to step aside so they could take a better photo! The grounds of the Palace are beautiful and the cafe along the edge of the water has good food at reasonable prices.

Spectacular Opulence. This place is opulent in the European Style and is definitely worth a visit. The amount of lead crystal, gold leaf and silk here is mind blowing. We did queue for hours and we were rushed around on a tour which lasted 45 minutes, so it wasn't ideal, but we got to stroll around the gardens and enjoy the view of the Bosphouous after, so it wasn't a complete loss.

Dolmabahce..the filled in garden!. It was the best attraction of my last day in Istanbul yesterday...the tour inside the palace took us about 45 minutes. As yesterday was tge national day of Turkey we got lucky getting reduced tickets 30 TL for both Salamlik and Harem sections of the palace. Usually, it costs 25 tl each or 40 tl for both. You can take the tram T1 line get off at the last station which is Kabatas (pronounced Kabatash)...then walk like 5 minutes on the sea side to find first Dolambahce mosque, then clock tower and the entry to the palace. Last time to get tickets is 4 pm but they can close the kiosk earlier if the ran out of tickets as the palace has a qouta of 3000 visitors. There are some waiting time like 15 to 30 minutes at the door of the main hall enterance but the view of the garden makes it OK.The main architects were Armerinians...though you will find a heavy influance of French and British work with the furniture and ceilings. The Irish made crystal is a main theme in most rooms and halls, the main chandelier weights around 4.5 tones!!I was told that a third of the Ottman empire treasures were spent to build this palace that took 14 years to bring up.The Harem, our the main royal family quarter of the palace is very interesting section and it revokes the mental image that Harem was used to host concubines and a place for more "bodily joys".The only down side of the whole exprience is that video and photography is prohibited inside the palace.I will not go in details describing the rooms but will leave that as a surprise to feast your eyes.When done, you can enjoy a soothing drink or a meal by Basphourus in one of the couple of Cafeterias attached to the palace. The price for a tomato souo, Kefte plate (turckish meatball) and a Coca Cola was 18 tl.BY the way a USD is around 1.75 tl (turkish lira), rate varies from one exchange office to another so be careful.Taxies some times would rip you off by going through longer roads. The meter starts at 2.7 tl, so pls be alert. You are better off buying "Istanbul Cart" which goes for 7 tl for the card only and then you add credit. It works for all city transportations...mostly a ride would cost 1.95 tl for your planning.The tour guide was so professional and friendly. I believe her name was "Hande", she leads the English language tour. She has ample information on all details related to the palace and she kindly gave us some of her time after the tour to answer our questions.I wish I had her full name or contact to sebd her a thank you letter. If anyone is visting Dolmabahce this week can get us her full name and email address? We will be most gratfull!

Tours very crowded and overpriced. No option for self-guided tour. This is a rather expensive place to visit and requires waiting in line twice, once for the palace and once for the Harem. There are two lines for the palace, one for group tours (people who come in buses, etc) and one for individuals. Everyone in the Tour Group line enters first so if you wait quite a while and finally think you are going in, hope that a tour bus does not pull up. No shade to wait in so bring a hat or an umbrella. Tours are in multiple languages but you have no choice in the language. I ended up in an English tour but the guide had at least 50 people and was trying to explain things in multiple languages. Unless you were in the first 5-10 people, you will not be able to hear the guide and there seemed to be quite a bit of pushing to try to get to the front of the tour. One of the people in the group started yelling at the guide since she was upset that there was no description for most of the group but that didn't change anything. We pretty much marched through the palace with no time to stop and admire the decor. There was a second line to get into the Harem so more waiting. This group was a bit smaller and there seemed to be an effort to match guides with language of the tourists. I would have skipped this Palace if I had known of how badly managed this historic site was in advance of my arrival.

Beautiful Palace. For those who are interested in Turkish history, Dolmabahce Palace is important in terms of being the home of the last Ottoman Sultans before the Ottoman empire collapsed, and also the place were Mustafa Kemal Attaturk spent his last days. Regardless of who lived there, this place is amazingly lavish offering breathtaking decors, design, accessories and beautiful views. We had to pre-book a tour to visit the palace. It is worth the visit, and a must see if you have enough time in Istanbul.

Richer obscene. More modern than Top Kapi Palace and represents a later era of Othman Sultans.Very European style, baroque and rococo decorations and furniture’s.They built this palace to dazzle Sultan Guests and to represent Sultan's wealth in the most amazing way. Must Visit. Very long queues and high ticket price. There are other museums inside it. Main museum which called salamlek is the most important luxurious one.

not what i was expecting. i wanted to see some Oriental style inside and i found the same style you can find everywhere in the world almoust : barroque and rococco. If u wish to visit the Harem suppose part of the Palace you have to pay an extran fee.  You have to wait 2 times. Once for the tiket the second time to actually get inside.You cannot make pictures and there is a guide no matter if u wish or not :)  The garden is nice .

Please don't go here ........ Oh my goodness where do I start? Totally over-priced in comparison to everything else in Istanbul. We stayed in Istanbul for a week and 'did' 2 sights a day. The most expensive was Topkapi at 25 Lira each. Dolmabahce palace was 30 Lira for the state apartments and 40 Lira for the Harem. We went in to the state apartments. It's only by guided tour and you get marched round in 45 minutes and you get told virtually nothing about what you're seeing. Total waste of time and money - we were so shocked and surprised compared to everything else we did in Istanbul. They were also amazingly precious about their carpets - everyone has to wear protective shoe covers before you even enter the front door!

Rush visit- it doesnt worth the money. The place is nice, it is an European style palace where you can see how the sultans liked to show off their richness in some kind of a thacky way, very barroque and rococco like. The gardens are nice, so is the view of the Bosphorus.The down side of it is that you are obligated to visit it in a tour group. They make you almost run through the palace, the group is about 30 people and if you dont stand near the guide you cant hear what they say. Thay give a very fast explanaition (not very informative) and then rush into some other place. If you walk slower you miss the explanations and the guide of the next tour will catch you and ask you to walk faster.I definitely wouldnt reccomend it, at least as long as they keep obbligating visitors to make this fast visit. And it is kind of expensive (arround 30 TL without the Harem/ 40 TL with the Harem).There are plenty of other very interesting and nice places in Istanbul to visit.Not worth the time and the money.

Best of Istanbul !. Dolmabache Palace tells us about the life of Sultans and shows their wealth ! There was a long queue to get in the palace because only a limited number of people are allowed to enter at a time so we had to wait in hot sun. They also provide us with polythene shoe type packet to cover the sole of our shoe to protect their carpets. And also you are strictly not allowed to touch anything inside. But it is a must-go place and worth every penny !

Needs air condition!. Deep history, very pretty and expensive, perfect location overlooking the Bosphorus, yet all the glamour fades away when you start to sweat inside. The palace has not adequate air ventilation so in summer time it gets really stuffy and airless inside. For winter it is good. Second annoying part is you can see a fraction of the rooms. "Don't touch this, don't go there" mentality enables one to see almost every room from a distant corner. Palace is beautiful, presentation is poor.

A waste of time and money -- don't bother going. If you want to see a real palace, save your money and get to the Louvre, Pitti Palace, Villa Borghese, Vaux le Vicomte, the Biltmore, any of the houses on the Hudson, Hearst Castle, or the Jacquemart Andre. Anything but this heap of dust, large dull rooms with big chandeliers and no taste. Furthermore, you have to take a tour either with a tour guide, whatever large group you are traveling with, or 75 of your instant best friends for the next 30 minutes. The museum charges double for non-Turkish citizens, arguing that the 40 Turkish Lire (about $24USD) is because we tourists are rich. For that, we got rushed through large reception rooms and peeked into small bedrooms in the harem. Dust is everywhere. The tour guide provided almost no explanations of anything and since there are tours before and after you every five minutes, there are no opportunities to linger or ask questions. You have to pay cash, but there is an ATM near the ticket booth. Total waste of time and money.

There are different ways to see this palace. I read the reviews about the waiting time and poor guides so decided to take one of the many day trips which included a boat trip up the Bosphorus and a visit to the Dolmabahce Palace. We had our own guide so we were ushered through quite quickly and she gave an excellent overview of the history of the palace. Sure it would be nice to have your own private guide just to yourself, but that is not economical. I missed some of the commentary but this allowed me to inspect some of the artifacts at close quarters. As you cannot take photos inside the palace, why not buy one of the books that gives a complete history of the palace, complete with colour photos, either before or after your visit? A bit of planning can take away a lot of the frustration some people feel. The gardens are a wonderful place to sit and relax and watch the ships go by.

A Palace to Remember. Speaking frankly, I've never heard about Dolmabahçe Palace until very recently, as I believe most people haven't too. But if you are in Istanbul, don't miss it. It has has been the residence of six Sultans and Mustafa Kenal Ataturk, the father of the Turkish Republic, lived and died in this magnificent palace, that shows proudly the opulence of the Otoman Empire. Located in Besiktas, right on the Bosphorous, Dolmabahçe is a landmark of Istanbul, mixing the the otoman tradition and western influences. A visit is a must! Enjoy!

Bring time and stamina. Dolmabahce Palace is well worth a visit - but you need time and stamina. It took us almost an hour to get our tickets, we had to wait almost half an hour to get on to the guided tour of the first part of the palace, and another 20 minutes of waiting for our second tour of the Harem. I must admit that this is quite demotivating but the 285 rooms of the palace are really impressive and show another side of Istanbul. So take the time (you will need 3 to 4 hours) and enjoy!
A wow!. How could they build such a structure in so short a time is amazing. And a Harem to boot. The amount of crystal chandeliers is outstanding in a setting that is jaw droping.

Beautiful Palace, Terrible Tour. It's a real pity you can't visit this place on your own, or with your own guide. The palace is absolutely beautiful, it will take your breath away. The decor in each of the rooms, the chandeliers, the architecture - everything is exquisite.I'm sure there are very valid reasons why you can only go with a tour organised by the palace, but given that this is the case, they really need to make more of an effort to make the tours enjoyable. There were about 40 people in my group, which is far too many for any tour. Our guide clearly hated her job and was bored by it. She gave minimal information and rushed us through. I was one of the last in the group because God forbid, I stopped to look at everything we were being shown (I was in no way being slow though!). But the result was that I missed most of her guidance because she started talking as soon as there were about five people in front of her instead of waiting for the whole group. The tour was supposed to be 40 minutes long, and it took just 25. I learned absolutely nothing about the palace or its history, which is a real shame.I feel they need more frequent tours and much better guides to make this a truly great experience - which it absolutely could and should be.

Overdone. Interesting, but way too regimented. You are only allowed to go in groups, Turkish or English tour, so you have to wait in line for the palace and then again for the harem. Beautiful grounds, but really looks like it was built by the "sick man of Europe". Like Versailles, the over-the-top indulgent decor is beautiful, but not appealing, considering what the rest of the country was going through at the time. Go there after seeing Topkapi Palace for the history and only after you have seen everything else.

See how the Sultans live !!!. This was an amazing tour. Exploring the palace was brethtaking. Every thing there was so luxuriousgiving you the sensation of how spioled they were. I was overwhelmed by the tons of gold and silverused just to decorate a cieling. Unforfunately, photos are not allowed inside. But the gardens and yards and the entire outside of the palace is enough to make you remeber the who.e visit.Absolutely recommended

Lovely European style palace. This is a lovely European style palace. It was drizzling when we went, so they made us wear little footies over our shoes so the carpets wouldn't get dirty. No photos allowed inside, and we could only enter at set times with a guided tour. The groups were way too huge, and guides are heavily accented English, so it was kind of hard to hear what was going on. I noticed that the English sign had entry fees at twice the cost of the Turkish signs. For instance, we paid 40 TL each for the palace and harem, but it was only 20 TL for the Turkish tour. Craziness. Beware of the restaurant right outside the palace. Hustlers getting you seated, no menus in sight, and crappy, cold food. :(

Well worth a visit. Dolmabahce Palace was slightly out of the main area of Istanbul but well worth a visit. A beautiful building, in stunning grounds, with amazing views overlooking the water. Again like the rest of the attractions in Istanbul it was busy and we had to queue on several occasions. I think in retrospect it would definitely have been worth booking a personal tour to save time and get more information. The group tours were good and you got to see the whole of the Palace but there were about 120 per group so difficult to pick up all the information. Personally I loved this place and would go back, very peaceful.

An utter gem. Arriving at Dolmabahce Palace we were initially put off by a few things - mainly the price (35tl...actually not that expensive) and that you are not allowed into the palace without going on a 45min long guided tour. We arrived and then had to wait for half an hour to be taken in. Once the tour did start there were a few too many people on it and we couldn't hear what the guide was saying most of the time... We were starting to regret coming.However! Once we started looking around properly we were utterly stunned and could see why you need to be shown around. The palace is HUGE and has over 200 rooms, each immaculately decorated. The tour ends in one room (i won't give it away) which made my jaw drop. I always thought that was something that only happened in bad movies! This was perhaps my most favourite place in Istanbul to visit and worth all of the waiting around. IF you go, make sure you do the full tour and not just the harem as the administrative rooms are the best bit. Ottoman imperialism at its finest.

Complete waste of time. The price is 40 TL and it is a ripoff. You don't get to examine the many fine pieces of art work because they rush you through. The guide speaks inaudible English so most people do not hear nor understand her. Aside from the artwork, there is a sameness about every room.There are so many fine places to go in this city. This Palace is not one of them the way it is organized. Save your money.(No alcohol in the seaside restaurant.)

Well worth a visit. This great and impressive palace is a bt out of he way, but well worth it. It is about 5 min from the last tram stop so it is easy to reach. You need to go with the guide, so get here early since the number of people n group is limited. Also, they do no tell you where it starts, so go inside and wait by the stairs. Also, put on bags on shoes, you can not go in without them. The minus is that you are not allowed to take any phtos :(, However the guide knew s lot and was very funny so it was a great experience. Both sections are worth the wisit, but if you have to chose, skip the harem

Beautiful, easy to get to, spectacular. We thought this was an amazing grounds considering the location along the water and the ease of walking to it from the tram line. We showed up about 3:30pm got our tickets and were on the last tour at 3:50. The official tour is amazingly immaculate if you realize some of what you are looking at and take a few moments to poke your head into the roped off doorways that your tour guide will walk past. Our 3yo son kept saying "beautiful". We really thought the crystal staircase was one of the more impressive things. As far as the self guided tour people go, sure it would be nice. It would also be nice to do such things at the white house but you can't so take what you can get and enjoy it. We were allowed to linger in the final room as our 3 mo old acted up and a security guard forced my wife to take his seat so she could feed her. He discretely moved off and allowed us some privacy which was really nice to have the moment to take in the area but from what we could tell there was nothing forcing the people to leave, they just did.

Average palace, no photo-taking, visits are timed. If you go, it must be first thing in the morning to avoid long waits.. After a short walk from Kabatas station, I arrived at 8:30am and was 4th in line. After you buy your ticket, you walk to the palace entrance and wait in either the Turkish or English tour line. Tour groups seem to have a big advantage here. They seemed to have been able to reserve their times; so they went in before any of the individual travellers. The first English tour was pushed back to 9:30am, because we had to follow a half-dozen tour groups. You wear pink plastic covers over your shoes to protect the fine carpets.Because of its weak supporting structure, the palace can only hold 700 people at one time - so all visits are timed and visitors are hurried along. I had tried to visit the day before at 3:30pm but gave up when I saw the huge lines. If you decide to tour this palace, it must be the first thing on your agenda that day, unless you have some kind of reservation with a tour group.Our tour guide spoke good, but not perfect, English. We were a group of 50 or so tourists. I'm sure half the people had trouble hearing her. She mostly sourced the materials in each room. We only spent 2-3 minutes in each room. We walked through at least half the rooms without stopping on our way to the highlights. There is no time to appreciate the smaller details.As palaces go, this one is only average, well behind Versailles or Palacio Real in Madrid. There are 2 or 3 spectacular rooms and 2 incredible chandeliers. But there are also imitation marble columns made of stucco. This was truly an attempt for the 19th-century sultans to impress their Western European counterparts.Everyone says to skip the harem, which I did. The Topkapi Palace harem is far more historic. The gardens are small but beautiful. There is a nice cafe by the water, and next door you have the Naval Museum. You can take nice shots of the whole palace from the Bosphorus Cruise.If you only have 3 days in Istanbul, skip this entirely, especially since it's far away from the other sights and you can't take any photos inside. It's a Day 4 or Day5 activity at best. I believe it was 25TL for the main palace, an extra 15TL for the harem. Not a good rainy-day activity, because if you are stuck in the line-up, there is no cover.
a dream. go and see it and take pictures , take the tour with a guide to explain for you about many things inside that huge palace

Interesting mix of Western and Middle Eastern culture. The entrance to the palace is a big expensive given that you only spend 30 min inside the palace (you can spend as much as you want outside on the grounds). We didn't pay the extra fee to go to the Harem since we were in a hurry and had to decide which one we wanted to see. When you get a ticket (the lines in the morning are extremely long) you enter inside the grounds of the palace and then you have to wait in a second line for the next tour. All visits to the palace are with a guide, included in the price, and you are not allowed to take photos at all inside. The guides are schedules, so even if you arrive at 11AM, the next English guide might not be until 12; however, we found the guide not very necessary so one can go on a foreign tour and just look around because the only things they told us were "this carpet this, that chandelier that...". The interior was very interesting mix of Western and Middle Eastern culture and the great room was fascinating. However, I found the outside of the palace much more interesting than all the furnishing inside, although there were a few very interesting items.

Beautiful site, poor organization. Though the palace in itself is impressive, the visit is painful. We visited in July, it was extremely hot and we stood in line for 2hrs (arriving at 10am) to be able to enter. My husband & I took turns going to the cafe for ice cream with our children. Once we finally entered, we thought we would be able to enjoy the site, however, we were dissappointed to learn we could not visit the palace on our own and were mandated to wait for the English tour guide. We waited another 30mn (in the sun) and dutifully followed a bored guide with 40-50 other tourists. Given the lay out of the palace and how the pieces and certain areas are roped out, this would be an ideal setting for self-guided visits. It would also reduce the long lines at the entrance.

Beautiful Baroque Palace. A beautiful Baroque Palace blended with Ottoman architecture reminiscent of European Palaces. Located on the water's edge and is admired even more were seen from the Bosphorous.

Impressive place,average tour.. The building and it's history is very impressive. However the cost of 40 lira each for the full tour was not value for money. There can be long queues to enter, the english - speaking guided groups can be large. Our group was far too big. The guide could not be heard by everyone. The guide seemed bored , was not very informative and didn't wait for the tailenders of the group before speaking at each location. It was all rather hurried - too many visitors, too little time.

Dolmabahce Palace - Fit for a Sultan. This was a fantastic thing to see. Was there with a tour guide which was nice to be able to hear specifics on the palace. At the same time it would have been nice to have been able to take longer to walk around the palace. No photographs were allowed inside which was kind of a downer considering the grandeur of the location. One will have to put on shoe covers that are provided before entering the palace to keep the carpet in good shape ( I suppose). Items from the souvenir shop were few and far between, but were there nonetheless. This IS another Must See when in Istanbul.

Lovely Architecture, But No Self Guided Tours, Too much time in Lines, and was Rushed. There was a long line to buy tickets into the palace. We bought the additional ticket into the harem. You have to stand in additional lines to wait for the tours, which are about every 30 minutes. We got a perch at the café by the harem and the Turkish speaking tour was posted to leave before the English speaking tour. While we queued up 5 minutes before the English speaking tour was suppose to leave, they apparently took the English speaking people immediately after the Turkish tour which was early, so we had to stand there and additional 30 minutes. There was much of the harem roped off. The guide spoke briefly upon entering and then provided no additional information. It was rushed. We spent so much time doing he harem tour we didn’t have time to do the main tour. The harem tour at Topkapi Palace was much more interesting.

Dolmahbache. The palace itself is worth visiting, however tourists are not treated very nicely. When u pay so much price u would like to take pictures to preserve the memories, but that is not allowed inside the palace. The staff at the gate, and inside the palace is extremeeeely rude, the lines are really long and the guides take huge groups and rush you through the palace. If u are really interested to see the sultans' grandeur do visit, however be ready for the rudeness and the long wait!!

Dolmabahce Palace. Situated on the Bosphorus River, Dolmabahce is an impressive palace and definitely an interesting place to visit if you are in Istanbul for several days. Built in the European style the palace creates a feeling of opulence with its extravagant decorations and enormous chandeliers. The downsides of the visit to this palace is the cost to enter is 40TL to see both the main palace and the harem. It is probably the most expensive entry fee out of all the museums in Istanbul. If you have an ISIC student card however the entry to both is only 5TL. You then have to take a compulsory guided tour in large groups. While the information given on this tours is good you cannot always hear what the guide is saying especially if the people in your group are talking over the guide. Another downside is that you cannot take photos inside the palace.

over the top. It is very impressive, but also rather depressing to see the Ottoman Sultans attempts to rival European palaces with huge chandeliers and red carpets and to turn their back on all that was splendid at the height of the empire. Really kitchy mediocre Western paintings amidst rather tasteless ostentation. Go to Topkapi and the Renaissance mosques, but make this a lower priority.

How our betters lived. Not to be missed is the Dolmabahce Palace. It is splendid example of the lavish trappings of royalty in a beautiful structure on the banks of the Bosphorus. We're surprised that this site is not rated more highly. Among royal residences throughout Europe, this ranks favourably. As other sites in Istanbul, it gets very crowded, resulting in a long wait for tickets. Arrive first thing or investigate the possibility of reserving in advance. The visit is by guide only - at a good clip and rather mechanical.

Impressive palace. The palace was quite interesting and seems to be well preserved/restored. We waited 40 minutes to buy a ticket (30TL for both sections, using her student card out daughter paid only 5TL). Then it was another 25 minute wait for the tour. Parts of the palace were closed for restoration.The tour groups are quite large. The information was well presented. The halls are very ornate and well worth the visit. The gardens and surrounds are very nice.It is a short walk from the terminal station of the blue line metro.

Beautiful!!!. First day i planned to visit Dolmabahce Sarayi was very hot, maybe +36, and there was too long queue for tickets, so i decided just drink tea at cafe near Bosfor. Next day i came there early, at 10.00AM and took ticket very fast. Our group of tourists was not big, and our guide was very good. I cannot tell you about all those beautiful rooms of sultans, you should look by your own eyes.But everything was PERFECT!

normal. I have visit Dolmabahce Palace the last day of holiday. The tickes is quite expensive, but includes a guided tour compulsory for to visit interior of the building. A problem is not possible take a photo into palace and it is a pity. if you like historic buildings is to see the dolmache

Great Site. In terms of how much I liked the Palace I felt that it was definitely a much more fitting location for a Sultan and was quite the nice upgrade compared to Topkapi.But, in terms of how much I like the site itself I have to say that it was only ok. Being forced to move along with a group was quite constraining aside from the fact that no photography was allowed during the tour. When I got bored in the harem section I told the guide that I want to leave and I was told that would not be possible until the tour was over.
Excellent. Wonderfully OTT - includes the world's largest chandelier. You go round the interiors with guided tours. Totally worth seeing this crazy baroque palace

A wonderful palace for 3 kings and 1 president since 150 years ago. This palace is close to the sea, its wonderful structure and architecture is very fascinating. One should definitely visit this place in Istanbul. Do not forget to have your studentship card while buying ticket, since there is a very good off for students.

Very interesting and informative. The last residence of Ataturk and his place of death as well, this palace is beautiful and grand. To enter you must wait in line to get tickets which are 30TL, it is cheaper if you are a student but they only accept ISIC cards. after this take a stroll around teh gardens up to the palace where you will have to wait for a tour in either English or Turkish. There is no schedule anywhere so you might be waiting anywhere from 5-45 minutes. The tour is brief and insightful and you get to visit many of the rooms of the palace allowing you to imagine what life was like for the Turkish rulers. Definitely not a 'must see' but if you have time it certainly is beautiful.

Nation's grand palace. This is a superb structure and represents the place where the nation'd founder died. The chandelier is stunning. Book ahead or get there reasonably early although we went around 3 and the wait was only 5 mins. The guided tour is good but of course feels rushed as one wants to spend longer admiring the opulence that graces the palace. The views across the Bosphorus are gorgeous. There are a couple of cafes in the place and you can get turkish coffee and cake. I did see a lot of cats in the area which was rather odd. I guess the tourists must feed them. The same tram that goes to Sultanahmet continues on to the palace (it's the last stop).

beautiful place. after topkapi palace the empire starts to live in this place and Ataturk was died here that's why all the clocks stops at the time he dies. Turkish people loves this places because of him and visit every special day

A special place. for a nation that morns its founder, this is the place he died and the clocks set accordingly. You have to take a tour and depending what day and time you arrive you need to queue to get a ticket - my advice be there on opening time. Yes the Chandelier is worth the price alone and the final ballroom. Tours frequently. This is not as old as Topkapi but for me a better visual treat and a better experience and not as many people and a guided tour to at least learn some information. for the granduere =go!!!!

Beautiful Ottoman palace on the banks of the Bosphorus. Beautiful Ottoman palace on the banks on the Bosphorus which became the official residence of Attaturk until his death in 1938. There is a clock in his bedroom in the palace that is still showing 9.05 am, the actual time is his death. Highly suggest to have a reservation since they have daily limit of visitors (particularly during peak months). It is nice that the arrange the visitors into small groups to avoid overcrowding. The outside view from the palace towards the Bosphorus is stunning. No indoor picture taking is allowed in the palace thoughRestroom facility is only at the main gate/entrance, so make sure you use it before going to the queu/tour of the palace

Palace is a Highlight, but tour rushed. Don't plan to spend too much time at this 19th Century European-style palace built for the Ottoman Turkish sultan, except for the wait to get in. Lines are long and slow, from what others told me, but I went in late afternoon - 3:00, and the wait was less than five minutes. Tours of the Palace are rushed - you may have a minute (max) for each room, but the palce is magnificent, noteworthy especially for the largest chrystal chandelier in the world. Harem tour is separate. Beautiful grounds.
Beautiful Grounds. I prefer this palace to Topkapi. Its history is more recent and it isn't as flashy, though the chandelier is amazing!

We almost passed...glad we didn't!. When you combine both the palace and harem tours, you really get to cover this impressive structure. Be ready to be overwhelmed with the grandeur, even excess, of this location. Most meaningful are the more humble quarters of Kamal Ataturk, where he both worked and died. Excellent visit with knowledgeable tour guides!

A MUST SEE. If as a result of the huge entrance fees, you have to choose between Topkapi and Dolmabahce, go to the latter. It is the first palace where there are sooo much money invested in it, but there are not many kitschy things. The entrance fee for the palace is EUR 30, and for the Harem EUR 20. If you visit both- the price is EUR 40. However, we went only to the palace, so I am not completely aware of how the Harem looks like. In the price of the ticket, a guided tour is included, where one nice young lady explained to us the history of the castle. It is really amazing! Everything is made of crystals and gold. It is just beautiful. The best things about it, is that everything in the palace (except of one throne) is original. I was impressed by the way the people kept everything so to make it possible for us today to see it! GO TO THE DOLMABAHCE PALACE!
Amasing. Going there is a must see. If possible, find a private guide. Visit both parts, Selamlik and the Harem.

Seat of the last Sultan. This is the great white palace by the Bosphorus. This was the palace at the time of the last Ottoman Sultan. It is an very good shape inside, its carpets, furniture etc are all intact. So, you can get glimpses of the palace lifestyle going back 100s of years. It has to be seen. It is also the place where the founder of the Turkish Republic, Ataturk, lived and died during his last years. You ca visit his quorters and his death bed etc. Very interesting. A history lesson in itself.

Turkish Opulence!. We went to the palace around mid-morning, although there was a short queue, it took a very long time (compared to the other attractions) because there was only 1 ticket counter open even though there were about 3 windows available. Bring a hat as it can be quite hot waiting in a queue that moves very slowly...Once you get in, queue up immediately for the guided tour even although it was very tempting to take photos of the lovely entrance/fountain as the groups gets larger as the day goes on. Inside the opulence is breath-taking, unfortunately photo-taking is restricted- the guide will remind the group many many times.Strangely while queieing for the tickets, we noted the English version of admission prices is twice the price compared to the Turkish version- maybe it's due to the English-speaking guide (who knows)..Be prepared to spend at least half a day due t the waiting time, especially if you take the combined tour...

Ottoman Extravaganza!. Built in the mid 19th Century by Sultan Abdul Mecit this extravangant palace is Ottoman-European fusion architecture. It reflects a European fantasy of what is Ottoman and an Ottoman fantasy of what is European! Very delicious result. Who wouldn't want to while away the hot summers in this place, languishing in fountain cooled internal courtyards? Attaturk himself stayed here towards the end of his life. Access is easiest by water. The site is managed with military precision. You can't do an independent tour, you must take a guided tour. There are lots of queues, and rules about cameras and photos. In the wash up, this is a fabulous site to visit. It gives some insight into the excessiveness of the last days of the Ottomans. The site is not open year round, so check before you set out.
Totally worth seeing it.. My husband and I visited the castle today and loved it. The rooms are very impressive, the line was short, and overall the experience was very pleasant. Would go again.

Visit only the gardens. I really felt like I lost my time with the visit at this palace. The furniture and the carpets in the interior are not well preserved. You are not allowed to take photos in the interior. They have also a display there with precious objects stolen from the vassal countries (Including Romania) No comment for that.I liked the view from the gardens.

Feel like a sheep in herd. Palace is impressive and really shows what empire means.But way tourists are treated is terrible and awful. All impressions from palace was harmed by uncivilized tour guide and long lines everywhere.First you must wait to buy a ticket, then to enter in different parts of palace as well.Tour guides speak very poor English, no adequate sound, poor hearing if you're on the back side of groups. What if I'm not fluent in English, but German speaker or Spanish ? I feel myself like a sheep from herd with just once purpose - shear for money.We start claiming and response was - these are museum rules. Ok, fine, please publish them somewhere before to pay 40 YTL for ticket - may be we'll reconsider.Tour guides push groups to race and we have not enough time to see everything.Definitely will not visit again and will not recommend.

A Little Tired, Cursory Tour. Group tours only here. You'll be rushed through some fairly interesting historical details and see rooms filled with very baroque European furniture and fixtures. In the end, you'll wonder why you waited so long in line. Much of the grounds are in great disrepair, so you'll likely not want to hang around very long. The palace and grounds are monumental, but you get a better sense of this if you view it from a ferry ride down the Bosphorus.

Nice palace, but badly managed. The palace is very nice, no question, but the way tourists are treated is very poor. We had to wait in line for over an hour and when it was almost our turn to buy a ticket the ticket office closed for 15 minutes due to "overcrowd". It is expensive to enter and inside no bags are allowed. If you don't take your water with you from the baggage disposal and it's hot, prepare to pay double the price for something to drink. Tourists cannot enter the buildings on their own and have to follow a guide. Our guides rushed through every hall and room, did not speak English very well did not give us much time to see anything. Because there are not so many guides as there are tourist, you have to wait some more at the entrance of every building. In total, I think we spent more time waiting inside and outside of the palace than actually seeing the palace.If you want to go, go early in the morning (when they open), so you can avoid the lines. And take your own water inside.

In parts the most stunning interiors of any palace. Not to be missed.. We hopped off the city sightseeing bus very near here, but it is very accessible from the last stop on the Tram at Kabatas. It is the 19th century palace built for the Sultan and the royal family and court when they decided to move out of Topkapi. It sits on the shore of the Bosphorus like a grand European palace with interiors to match. Entry is costed according to what you want to see. So 40 TL gets entry to both the formal part of the palace and also the family quarters, or Harem in separate tours that are supposedly guided so you cannot wander around alone. But the "tours" are large groups with either an English commentary by the guide or a Turkish tour. In fact, the guide gives his or her spiel at a very few set points and then walks on ahead to allow the mob of about 40 to wander behind peering into rooms. At the entrances there were no leaflets in any language. More or less each room has a board to say what it was. No photography allowed inside. The decor and interiors are in places mind-boggling. No expense was spared. I lost count of the number and variety of crystal chandeliers and huge floor-standing candelabras. The largest in the palace and in the whole of Europe weighs over 4tons and was a gift from Queen Victoria of the UK and it hangs from the high dome of the grand Muayede Lounge (a misnomer if ever there was one) with its gold throne. The main grand double staircase has crystal balusters. And so it goes on. The tour may not be as the UK's National Trusts or great country houses would do do it, but I would not miss this treat.The grounds and gardens that open out to the Bosphorus are beautiful. The views are awe inspiring. Watch the timing if you want to see it all. I believe that 3.30 pm is the cut-off for buying a ticket to both areas. The whole place seems to close at 4.45 so again watch your timing to allow yourself time to enjoy the grounds and gardens and Bosphorus views.

Not really a must do. More luxurious than the Topkapi palace, the Dolmabahche Palace is the 'modern' palace and was home to 6 Sultans. Located along the Bosphorous, the view is just stunning. I wasn't very impressed with the interiors, beddings, linen, etc. maybe due to my exposure to Mughal opulence and the grandeur of Indian palaces. There is a guided tour that takes you through the main palace (which is the official wing of the palace) and the Harem (which is the residential wing of the palace for the Sultan, his wives and concubines). The palace has one of the largest crystal chandeliers in the world. And has a horse shoe shaped stairway that is called cyrstal staircase. The exteriors, the lawns, etc. are beautiful. Spend your time here. I enjoyed this more than the palace itself. Maybe the scorching sun and the long queues, the long waits for the tour to begin (once to see the main palace and the 2nd to see the Harem section), put a downer on my entire experience. But I personally believe there are better places to enjoy in Istanbul than the Dolmabachce Palace. Visit this after you have done everything else in Istanbul.

Interesting palace. The visit was worth it, however the 1.5hr wait to get the tickets to get in, in the sun, with no shade and only 1 person selling them was not good service.Shame not to be able to take any photos inside neither after paying 40 Turkish liras which was one of the most expensive visit done in Istanbul.A bit OTT in the decoration side, however worth it.

Where Attaturk died. Spectacular palace.Beautiful gardens overlooking the Bospherus. Fabulous crystal chandeliers and crystal staircase . All the clocks are stoppedbatbthe time Attaturk died. Well worth a visit

Great Experience. the palace has a great experience with a lot of sightseeing and treasures, it gives you the experience that you were living in that era and one of the sultan's family member, also the guide gives a brief description of everything.

Opulence in the extreme. This is a must see site. Every inch of the palace is filled with magnificent artistic details. From the crystal chandeliers to the crystal staircase, beautiful hand woven carpets, incredible paintings and gold gilded walls. Opulence in it's finest form. Go early when the palace opens to avoid the crowds. It is worth the wait. Enjoy!

Truly splendid. Probably one of the best kept and maintained places in Istanbul.
The history of the place has been preserved in a way which makes you feel going back in time.
Excelllent architechture and artefacts. Gives you a glimpse into the life of father of modern Turkey i.e Mustafa Kamal Attaturk.( visited May 2009)
Opulence. Check out the awesome ceilings and chandeliers !!! Especially at the end of the tour, the great big room with very tall ceiling,that ceiling was awesome!!! The harem was also interesting.
