Must see... In our first trip to Istanbul we haven´t been in Dolmabahce. This month we had taken a cruise that stopped 1 day in Istanbul and we decided to visit it. Knowing that it´s not easy to get the tickets and the lines are always big, we made arrangements with a local travel agency and it was possible to visit Dolmabahce first thing in the morning. Unmissable! The travel agency´s guide bought the tickets and guided us, so we didn´t waste too much time waitng outside. And the gardens are also worth viewing.
Go back in time... This palace is absolutely magnificent! You cannot stop looking at every single treasure this palace holds. The Ceremonial Hall will take your breath away!

Definitely worth seeing. Great inside look of richness of late Ottoman empire. Come before 10 a.m. and you won´t wait long in row(cca.20-30 min.) Good thing is that with ticket you get guided tour, but bad thing is the cameras are not allowed.

Queues. I visited in July and queued 90 minutes to get through security / bag search and the ticket queue. There was only one counter open (out of four) entry is 20TL for each part of the palace (apartments or harem) student discount on production of a valid ISIC card is just 5TL for both. There is no shade whilst waiting for tickets or indication how long the wait would be. Tickets cannot be purchased in advance to save time or avoid the heat. Apauling wait for tickets when only one counter is open. No photography is allowed. Tours only in English or Turkish. An Arabic tour would be helpful to Arabic speaking people. Despite people being told not to touch things, people do. Beautiful and over the top decor inside, breathtaking and well worth visiting. Disappointing when other people talk during the guided tours. Downside: ticket purchasing process and no shade. Goodpoints: inside decor. The apartments tour is the best. Can be reached by taking the tram to Kabatas.

In many ways, better than Topkapi. No, it doesn't have the panoramic views Topkapi does, and it's not as old. Some also say it's not Ottoman enough. But if you go to Dolmabahce Palace, you will enjoy the tour. The Palace is right on the Bosphorus, and the views are amazing. Arrive EARLY. I got there at 9:15 and didn't get a ticket until 9:50. I got on the 10:15 English tour. I was finished by about 11:45 after touring the palace and harem. The harem was really interesting, as it's fully furnished, unlike Topkapi. Be prepared for heat and wait time, but you'll get great photos (outside only).

Last Palace built in Istanbul, Turkey. Traveling to a Country ahead of a tour gives you the opportunity to venture out, see the City on your own and visit places that are not in the normal tour. Such was the case for my visit to Turkey. My friend and I went several days early and spent time in the Spice Market, the Asian side of Istanbul and a visit to Dolmabahce Palace. The Ottoman sultans moved from Topkapi Palace in "Old Town" to the new Palace on the Bosporus. It is styled more like the European Palaces. Be sure an take all the tours they have to offer of you will miss the Crystal Room and the Harem.
More than I expected. It is a really nice palace with a great guide either in English or Turkish. In my opinion the only bad point is the long time waiting. Go there first thing in the morning!

Beautiful European style Ottoman opulence. Definitely worth the visit! We took a tour and the palace was a stop on that tour, so I'm not sure about ticketing or hours. Our tour guide was great and just walking thought the palace (wearing plastic over your shoes!) was pretty amazing. The clocks, paintings, rugs, crystals, and gifts from other empires are beautiful. What an amazing place!! No pictures inside, but snap away outside! The history and the glimpse into a day in the life of an Ottoman Sultan is well-worth the stop :)

Great & amazing sightseeing. Great & amazing sightseeing palace in Istanbul .
You need at least 2 to 3 hours to cover it all .
You will see the most filthy & luxurious palace in the 18th & 19th century .
Don't miss it .

STUNNING!. You can't really miss a visit to this opulent Ottoman palace in European style.
Crystals, rugs, marbles, elegant furniture, history and high level art are displayed in this castle on the Bosphorus.

This is certainly worth a visit!. Start off early if you plan to visit the place & you still have to line up for tickets. They only admit about 2000 visitors daily (as of now). after 10 am, ticket line can be longer. The place can be visited in 2.5 hrs with a guide. You are not allowed to wander on your own. A combined tour of he palace & harem costs 40 Turkish Lira= 20 Euros (approximately). (Btw, you can forget about the cafe near the entrance of the palace if you want to grab a bite. The service was very poor. Nice views by the water, but horrible food choices & forgettable service!)

Versailles on Bosphorus. After the oriental charm of Topkapi Palace, see what the Sultans built to copy the opulence of the Europeans. Giant marble staircases, huge crystal chandeliers, vast reception rooms full of silk carpets and priceless porcelain. It is truly over the top! The location on the water is charming and it is fun to imagine life in such a place. My favorite room is the sultan's marble bathroom.

Beautiful, but go off season. I've been to the Dolmabahçe Sarayı twice, my husband a few more times. The first time around I was too ill to enjoy it properly but remember getting right in. The second time around was worse than the first time. I went early July 2012 in the morning and we waited 2 hours to buy tickets. They had 1 window open selling tickets and at some point when we got to the front of the line they closed the window for some reason. Note they also have different prices based on where you are from, Turkey or somewhere else. If you are from somewhere else you will pay more. We waited another hour to get into the actual palace. You have to wait for a guided tour and can't see it for yourself. THe tours are not very good. You can't hear the guides and they don't tell you much of everything. The groups are overly crowded as well, as they only offer English and Turkish tours you have all the other languages left to wonder what is going on. THe Harem costs extra but that was honestly the best part of the tour. During that tour is where you see Ataturk's room, and that is worth the price IMO. I suggest reading about the place before you go because you won't learn much about the place, especially the artwork. Overall what was only supposed to take us a couple of hours took nearly the whole day. It's not worth it. It's beautiful yes, but I suggest going off season so you can enjoy the place without wasting your whole day waiting. If you absolutely must see it, reserve at least the whole day for this during the tourist season.
Incredible. We stumbled into this, and so glad we did! It is away from the old town- take the tram. So worth it!

As sumptuous as Buckingham Palace or Versailles. Just a short boat or tram ride up the Bosporus at the water's edge. Fantastically sumptuous Palace with beautiful rooms - you have to see it to believe it. Baccarat chandeliers - one weighing 4.5 tons in the Ceremonial Hall, beautiful furnishings and carpets and this palace actually bankrupted the country in 1921 when Atatürk took over and he lived here until he died in 1938. Wonderful Harem section and beautiful architecture and gardens.

A Summer Palace. Such wealth and opulence in each and every room and can just imagine the lives of those who lived there. Gardens are peaceful and different and one can just picture the boats arriving with guests and treasures. Not to be missed.

Visit it BEFORE the TopKapi Palace otherwise you would be disapointment. The Palace is beautiful with wonderful views on the Bosphorus. It is an attraction to people interested in Europe Renaissance architecture. Nothing middle eastern about it. However, it is beautiful. From Chandeliers and stair rales of the best crystals in the world to ceiling paintings that appear to be 3 D in the grand hall. Everything in Dolma Bahce (the filled garden) talks about SUPER class of an empire that rules the middle east and the Eastern Meditaranian for more than 400 years.

Liberace's Dream Palace - Skip if Pressed for Time. If they would let you walk through the place on your own, it would be a good 20 minute excursion. But you can't. You have to take the guided tour. The guide was bored to tears and did not talk loud enough for the group to hear him. He actually pointed to a piano in one room and said, "That's a piano over there". That's the type of information he gave. "There's a piano. There's a chandelier". I can figure those things out myself. The place looks like Liberace (a piano player) decorated it. Gaudy is a good word for many parts of it. There are better things to do in Istanbul... as others have said, "Skip this if you are short for time". (And be forewarned: there are 2 separate entrance fees for different parts of the building)

Not enough superlatives for this place. I have visited many castles and manors in western Europe, but I believe this rivals them all for the top prize. The outside presents a strange (to me) air of faded elegance (much like the Ottoman empire itself), but it is the interior that really shines. It is easy to see that the last Ottoman sultan built his dream house "on the backs of his subjects" - he looted the treasury to build this masterpiece. The Waterford stair case spindles are jaw-dropping, as is room after room of silk furniture, exquisite ceilings and draperies. The " jewels" of the palace are its priceless Hereke rugs and the immense reception hall; never have I been more impressed with the scope and grandeur of a single room. Definitely worth a visit while you are in Istanbul.
Beauty in our door steps. This is a brilliant piece of architecture.It is in the new town close to Taskim Square.

Skip Dolmabahce, If you have time for only one Palace. If you only have time to visit one palace, I'd recommend visiting Tokapi Palace over Dolmabahce Palace. The wait to purchase tickets was nearly an hour, and once you enter the grounds of the Palace, you must wait another 15 minutes or so to join one of the Turkish or English-guided tours. While the palace is opulent, it was a sadly disappointing visit because the mandatory tour groups are much too large to truly listen to what your guide is saying. Also, it was a hurried tour, and she seemed as if she was hurrying us along, rather than acting as a docent, which also detracted from the overall experience. Perhaps because Dolmabahce was built relatively recently, but the Baroque, Baroque, Rococo and Neoclassical influences outweighed the traditional Ottoman architecture, and the palace disappointed in that respect, too. Oh, and one is forbidden from taking photos inside the palace itself.
wonderful palace, great garden. One of my favorite palace in Istanbul. The main gate, clock tower and definitely the garden, which is by the bosphorus must be seen.

Extravagant. I arrived around 10 pm so I was able to avoid a line to get a ticket. From what I've read the lines can be endless and during the summer it can get very hot, so I'd definitly recommend going as early as possible. They give you three choices for the tickets, you would want to choose the second of thrid (the second is 30 TL and includes a guided tour in the palace/official part whereas the third is 40 TL and includes the guided tour AND a tour of the home of the sultan and his family. If you choose the third option they will amongst others show you the bedroom where Atatürk spend his last days in 1938.) Unlike the Topkapi Palace, you can't walk freely in Dolmabahce Palace, you have to take the guided tour. They have tours every 20. minutes (every 5. minutes during very busy hours) You will be a group of about 35 people and a tour guide who takes you through the palace. You are not allowed to take pictures in the palace, which I found a bit disappointing. The place itself is amazing, a real-life fairytale! What impressed me the most was the chandelier weighing 4,5 tonns (it's the largest in the world.) There is also a cafe outside with a view of the Bosphorous and a souvenir shop. Overall well worth visiting.
Wonderful. I am actually not sure what was more beautiful in Istanbul; Topkapi or Dolmabahce but both show abundance and power of the Ottoman empire, in a very subtle and elegant way.

very opulent 19th century palace. a great insight into the life of a modern day Sultan! This palatial western style palace is beautifully furnished with sumptuous fabrics and furnishings in a magical setting at teh water's edge.

A palace museum with original furnishings. Dolmabahce Palace was constructed during the reign of Sultan Abdulmecid (1839-1861) and was completed between 1843-1856. It was inhabited from the year 1856 by six Sultans and the last Caliph. After the foundation of the Republic, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk stayed in the palace for 4 years impermanently, between 1927-1938. The palace was used as a Presidential House during the period of Ismet Inonu till the year 1949, & was opened to the public as a palace-museum with its original furnishings in 1984.The main structure is divided into 3 functional places - The Administrative Part where the country's affairs were discussed, The Privy Chambers (Harem) where the Sultan & his family were living & The Grand Ceremonial Hall where the Sultan received notables of the state. The palace has 285 rooms, 44 halls, 68 toilets & 6 Turkish baths. As a monobloc building, it is the biggest palace in Turkey.Functionally & architectually, the palace preserves traditional Turkish house design of a hall in the middle with rooms surrounded, nevertheless, the Western originated arts such as Baroque, Rococo, Neo-Classic were widespreadly used. Thus, traditional Ottoman Style & cultural elements were molded with a Western concept & as a result a new interpretation was obtained.The Hereke carpets which have been used to decorate the walls & the floor, the Baccarat & Bohemia crystals, the Sevres & Yidiz porcelain, gifts by various state leaders & paintings by Western artists are quite imposing & interesting.Not as crowded as Topkapi, this is a quiet and romantic place. It was pouring with rain when I visited (cold!!) but I am sure it must be nicer in summer time.

Impressive. A must see in Turkey . I was mesmerised to see the opulence and grandeur of the Ottoman empire . This extravaganza led to the decadence of the empire . Bought the ticket for Harem as well which was also worthwhile . It has the largest chandelier in the world . I would suggest to go early as the last admission is till 3 pm . The palace is huge . The guide spoke English and Spanish . But I could not hear him many times from the back as there were many people in the group . I would recommend to keep up with the guide and not to fall behind .
A real taste of how Turkey once was. So much is original and the restoration work is very high quality

Amazing palace - but chaotic service.... It's well worth going here... the interiors are pure opulence. However... you get the impression that you're not really welcome there. The service and queues are appalling - the guided tours are far too big to hear what the guide is saying.
However, even with all this - i'd go again!
not the be missed. this place is one of the best places in turkey , NOT to be missed , it's a shame taking pictures inside is not allowed, but it's for the good of the palace.

Excellent even though the queuing system is awful!!!. Wonderful attraction. You have to go into the palace as part of a guided tour. The tours alternate between Turkish and English, but the entrance into the main palace does not have segregated queuing so you become part of a rugby scrum to get in. We went in the afternoon and with one ticket booth open it took nearly an hour in full sun to get to the booth. I would recommend going early as there is a lot to see. Overall, great!!

WOW!!! Be prepared to spend a whole morning here and get as early as you can.. DO NOT GO IN THE AFTERNOON! The palace is huge and last admission is at 3.00 PM. Me and my boyfriend decided to go in the afternoon and could not get in even though the schedule refers 09:00 to 16:00 (and there is nothing else to see in the neighborhood). Take a tram to Kabatas and have a 10 minute walk to the palace. Be prepared to face long queues because there are only guided visits that start every 15 minutes in English and Turkish (make sure you stand in the right line). Harem and palace are separate sections (with different fees and discount if you purchase both tickets). You are advised to choose the palace if you lack time, but try not to skip the harem (Ataturk's room is here). Do not make plans for the rest of the morning. BRING A HAT AND SCARF to protect your shoulders in the summer or you will get a sunburn for sure.

Incredibly Impressive. I would rate this as a must in Istanbul. Its grandeur is seen through the entire palace, no expense was spared when building it and it shows through it's crystal chandeliers, crystal staircase and absolutely awe inspiring great hall, all fitted with delightful ornaments from around the world. You are not allowed to look around freely within the palace, and the tours are rushed slightly. This is not such a problem however if you look up its history or buy one of its books at the gift shop. The harem is very similar to the rest of the building, therefore unless your are keen you may want to miss this part out. Its grounds are also lovely to walk around and outside its gates is a cafe/restaurant overlooking the Bosphorus.
Interesting site. Palace is full of gorgeous crystal chandeliers. Many rooms of interest---beautiful grounds

A trace of the daily life of the Ottoman Emperor. No individual Touring, no taking pictures (obviously many actually do). you either buy a ticket for the main section or 2 tickets for both main & Harem It is a chance to feel the presence of royalty, the furniture is still intact and very cared for.The Decoration is beyond luxurious, the Harem section was more interesting to me (specially the area where you see the baby crib and toys) must see once. So many art works on the walls you dont have enough time to stop and admire but do keep your eyes on them some are very interesting as they portray Ottomans at wars (Islam forbids paintings of people, therefore this is rare and interesting to see)length of queues depends on when you go and how lucky you are. Make sure you are standing in line for the English tour (they offer Turkish and sometimes Arabic tours)

Over priced and a long wait. Without question, this is a palace, complete with Baroque and neo-classical influences. And it is huge, breathtaking and probably represents the last gasp of the Ottoman Empire. However. The queues are long, we had to wait 30min to get in and another hour to actually enter the palace. Individual wandering is not allowed inside, so there are two queues for guided tours, one in Turkish, one in English. The tours start app. every 15 min, but only 20 people or so are allowed in each tour. From what we saw of the line, either go really early or you may get lucky around lunch time. We toured the palace June 2. At this time most of the Harem section was under renovations, the Crystal Garden was closed and the Clock Museum was closed. Usually the Palace has 2 possible entrance fees, one just of the Palace, one for the Palace and the Harem. Given that the Harem was under renovation, they combined the fee and included the open sections of the Harem in the Palace tour. Unfortunately the fee was on the higher side at 30TL/person. Given that the tour was less than an hour and most of our time was spent standing in queues, I'd give this Palace a miss. When the renovations are done and the other sections are open, this may be worth it. But until then, you're better off touring through Beylerbeyi Palace for the same over the top Baroque Palaces. One last note, photography is not allowed inside.
european style palace. After 1876 ottoman empires starts to live in that palace. And the greates leader of turkey Mustafa Kemal ATATURK was died at this palace. It is closer the Kabatas tram stop..

Waay Over the Top. A palace built in the4 mid-19th century, this p[lace is quite a sight to see. It is a blend of Baroque, Rococo, and others, it is just way over the top. Opulent barely begins to describe it. Due to the nature of the place, one must take a "guided" tour, rather than wandering at one's own pace. Other than that small drawback, it is well worth a visit.

A must do. we were about to leave istanbul without going there ,but some friends that were in istanbul but on a different group told us that it's worth visiting so decided to end our visit to istanbul there.i had some posters that the security didn't allow go take them inside so i left them with our bags at a small room in the entrance

if you are between top kapi or dolma bahce ...choose 2. this is definitely a palace.i liked the gardens,the crystal stairs the rooms of the sultan and his son and daughters ,hmmam.you pay extra to visit the harem...but if you want to keep your money stick on the main palace.you can see really fantastic things
best palace. great location great architecture breath taking palace when in istambul it is a must

Truely Magnificent Palace. This is a "must see" in Istanbul as is certainly the most majestic, grand and royal palace having beautiful architecture and is right on Bosphorus so the view from Palace is just amazing. Had visited this palace few years back too and again in last September as is really wonderful structure which swiftly takes you to the Ottoman times. There is always a long waiting line so keep good time margin with you while planning a trip to this palace.

Palace on Bosphorus ...... Gorgeous Palace right on the waterfront. Looks like a long wedding cake, with a stunning arch/gate, The Sultan's Gate. Lovely fountain and statues of white lions in the gardens. Lots to see inside, including a Baccarat crystal staircase. It was used as a summer residence by Ataturk, and you can see the bedroom where he died, which has the Turkish flag on the bed. The clock in the room is set to the time he died, 0905. (Nov 10th 1938). Quite short opening times 0900-1500 exc Mon & Thurs. Don't get caught out, go early! Nice tea garden just outside of the palace by the clock tower.

beautiful palace - long wait. We went on a Saturday which may make the wait longer. They control the number of people waiting for tours at the line location and this further slows it up [we got there at 11:30 and didn't get in until 1:30.] The grounds outside of the palace and the views over the Bosphorous are lovely and free.

A baroque experience. Dolmabahce Palace is a conveniently short walk along the waterfront from the tram terminus. Unless you arrive very early, be prepared to queue. They only let in the number of people (20-30) who can be shown round by one guide. Tours are in English or Turkish, so there are 2 queues.The good news is that because you are shown round by the palace's own tour guides, this is one building that is thankfully free from ticket touts offering to help you jump the queue. The building has a special place in the hearts of Turks as it was here that Kemal Atatürk, the first president of the Turkish Republic, died in 1938. So not surprisingly Turkish visitors tend to be given preference.The building is huge and ornate. It was built as a replacement for Topkapi Palace by a 19th century sultan, who was determined to prove that the Ottoman Empire still had life in it; unfortunately to complete the building the vast sums borrowed sank the Ottoman economy into deeper gloom. However, you wouldn't guess this from the building which is over the top baroque from the entrance gate throughout all the suites of rooms, both public and private. When you are aware that the interior was designed by the architect responsible for the Paris Opera, it all makes sense. Whether it was in their public or private lives the Sultan and his family must have felt that they were living on a stage set. If you like baroque, then this is the place for you.The tour lasts about 40 min but the palace is so large that you are whisked fairly quickly from room to room. The guides speak excellent English and are delightfully polite; they are happy to answer questions but in groups of this size, it is almost impossible to go into anything in any detail. The fittings and furnishings are amazingly lavish and ornate. I would have liked to spend longer looking at the artwork in the corridors, but I needed to keep up with the group! The main areas that you will be shown are the huge public reception rooms and throne room, the Sultan's private apartment, which are almost as big, and Ataturk's suite of rooms.The palace gardens along the shore of the Bosphorus are attractive and well tended and a good spot to take photographs which you are not allowed to do inside.Our guide book said that there was a cafe/restaurant with views out over the Bosphorus, but the signs led us to a small cafe near the exit where you could take your drinks round a small fountain and fishpond. So don't expect a repeat of the facilities at Topkapi Palace.

Beautiful piece of architecture - foreign citizen pay double entry price !. Dolmabahçe palace is a marvelous piece of architecture - the garden and buildings are just fantastic.I went there with some friends (one of them Turkisch citizen).At the entrance we needed to pay the ticket : 1. Turkisch citizens pay only 20 TL2. Foreign citizens pay 40 TL !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!What the [--] : Is this 2012 ????I consider this as a great discrimination and I want to report this !!! OK I paid the ticket and could wonder the inside of this palace but the way they sell tickets is just acceptable .

Quintessential Extravagance. I'd like to start this review by addressing some complaints of other reviewers. Most importantly, expect a long line to get a ticket. You will likely wait 1-2 hours so get there early, around 9-9:30 (tram stop is very close). And yes, you will be forced to enter the palace on a tour (less than 2 hours), without exception. This however, is not a burden at all and completely understandable. They don't want people wandering around the huge palace, taking pictures (no photos allowed once inside) and possibly damaging the furniture, and thereby ruining the site for everyone else. I was more than happy to follow the very knowledgeable tour guide who was more than happy to answer your individual questions. If you do go, expect a highly extravagant palace. It was built during the decline of the Ottoman Empire (mid 1800s) in an attempt to dispel the rumors that the Empire was in decline and going broke. Also, it was built to replace Topkapi palace as the home of the Sultans. That is why the entire design is so extravagant. There is a beautiful staircase in the entrance hall and the posts holding up the handrail are made of crystal. Also, at the end of the tour is a giant, 9,000 pound chandelier. If seeing such things will sadden you, do not go and perhaps do not visit a palace in general. However, if you are able to appreciate it for what it is, then I highly recommend going. The gate is also very impressive, as is the clock tower nearby. Also, you may want to go to the port of Eminonu and take a 1.5 hour ferry in order to see the palace from the water. I did not enter the harm (additional fee) because I read that it is not that impressive. If you would like to see a harem, I highly recommend the one at Topkapi Palace.

The last stand of the Ottoman's.. This is a great trip out of the hustle and bustle of old Istanbul. It's easy to get here by tram followed by a bit of a walk. The palace itself is immaculate to every last detail. Once you get into the last reception room, don't forget to look up. The painting on the ceiling is a splendor. I loved that this was a guided tour and although your not allowed to take pictures, you can download spectacular professional ones on their website.

How the other half have lived. It is an amazing opulent palace next to the Bosphorus. The inside is just crammed with wonderful furniture, chandeliers, carpets and curiosities. There is so much gold and precious gems everywhere. it is a warren of hundreds of rooms all rich with mementoes of the lives of the people who lived here. The bed spread on Ataturks bed is fantastic, The whole place is stunning

The very best of the world.. DOLMABAHCE PALACE, to describe this wonderful palace will be quite difficult, here is the palace which clearly shows the power, the vastness and the impact the OTTOMAN EMPIRE had on the world. The palace is designed in baroque style, the sheer magnificence of the palace is completely breathtaking. The crystal staircase, the massive chandeliers, the marble structures, the red room, the blue room,etc etc are all a must see. What is surprising why this palace is not the first attraction of Istanbul, as this would by far be the very best palace in the world.

Interesting but not a must-see. The queues to get in are interminable: first you queue to buy your ticket (this can take hours and it is galling to arrive at the booth to find only one person selling, and explaining the details slowly over and over to each tourist); then you queue for your tour. There seems to be a charge to take in a camera - we did not get to the bottom of this, but I believe you are not allowed to take photos inside the palace in any case. NB Don't think it helps to arrive early: everyone says this, but in fact the queues were much shorter when we left around lunchtime than when we arrived. You have to put plastic bags over your shoes so be aware if you are elderly or not agile that there is very limited seating or space for this. I did not find much to interest me on the tour: the public rooms are very ostentatiously opulent (eg crystal bannisters) but don't as far as I know contain any particular works of art of merit. The private quarters were indifferently furnished and rather dull. Only the last room on the tour was particularly impressive - it was vast and plush and contained an almost comically enormous chandelier, a gift from Queen Victoria.We did not bother with the separate harem buildings (you do see some of the harem on the main tour).The setting on the water and the gardens are nice, but I think this place does not rank amongst the greatest palaces or gardens of Europe.
Dolmabahce Palace. Please do not hesitate, it is worth every lira, because in such beauty and splendor of what you probably have not seen anywhere.Recording and photography is prohibited.
ok. 2 hours' waiting ... only English guided tours, beautiful garden, view to the sea

Nothing special if you have seen other european palaces. If you want to see Dolmabahce, make sure you see it before Topkapi since Topkapi is way more impressive and beautiful than this one. This was the turks attempt at trying to be more European and if you have seen other European palaces, this is just ok in comparison.
A place that you have to go. When I visit Dolmabache Palace ,it was amazing see all place there.I will come back soon

A Beautiful place with the world's largest chandelier. The Dolmabahce Palace was built along the Bosphorus River in the north of Istanbul. They have a long line for tickets so it is best to get the Museum Pass so you can skip the line. Be sure to also visit the Harem, which shows off the private rooms that were used by the Sultans and their entourage. There are some amazing pieces of furniture, including large chandeliers.
Many could not stay here. But still great. After her foray into a different world from the entrance door.I liked it very much.Sea views are incredible. I did not get my eyes

Not worth the horrendous queues and pricey ticket. The palace is lovely and the room with the crystal chandelier, the largest in the world, has the wow factor but... Queues.It was a quiet time off peek sesaon. 30mins buying a ticket. Followed by 1:30 mins to get in the palace. Then 20mins to get in the Harem.The harem as very similar architecture to the palace so if you are tight for time then skip.The clock museum and crystal palace were closed.The queue outside was 4 times the length than when I joined, no cover from rain nor sunshine in any of the queues plus no seating totally unsuiatle for the elderly.The architecture is a baroque style that is more equalled in European royal palaces and even stately homes so not special to Turkey. I managed to beat the queue by attending one of the Turkish led tours through the Harem. I didn't miss much as the English tour through the palace had mistakes, e.g. says the crystal was for England when it was from France.I'd have a cheaper price for the gardens and then a higher price for the Palace to cut numbers and run faster tours through. Maybe have an cheaper expess tour and a pricer slower tour.

Dolmabahce palace- and mosque (Jami3). two attractions in one spota must visitthe palace will take you some time inside, and you must enter with a guided Tour ooperator whom speak various languages-mainly English Frrench German and maybe arabic ( not sure)45 mins approx in main palace-25 mins in hareem palace ( womens palace)you have to be there earlynow let me talk about the Jami3-mosque and its fascinating atmosphere its right beside the palace and ther is a nice cafe inbetween them you can rest your foot and have a toast sand. and a cup of orinetal tea and watch the sunset on the bosphurus sea, when you feel ok just get up walk for two mis towards the mosque..amazing interior decoration,serenty and try to see one of the prayers with the peacful sound of the Imam ( leader for the prayer) , the wall is decorated with the Prophet Mohamed Name written in gold as well as the Sahaba and Kholafa Rashedeen's name , and on the cieling a huge chandelier hanging. its a must visit mosque thats worth the try, to enter the mosque its free but the palace has ticket,mosque opens till late evenening and closes after the last prayers.. when you get out of the mosque, walk for 5-10 mins max you will see on your left hand the ferry boats that cross the sea to the asian part, take one and explore the anadol Side.

A Different Gem in Istanbul. Unlike the magnificent mosques of the city, the Dolmabahce Palace is unique since it was designed and built in perfect symmetry by a French architect at the request of the sultan who lived there. The decor and the design of the interiors are intricately done with huge chandeliers and crystal bannisters. Also, Ataturk died in one of the bedrooms here. The view is breath taking as it faces the water. The gardens are perfectly landscaped. Don't miss this beautiful palace.

A grand palace that needs some TLC. There are long queue waits for entrance tickets, and then another long wait to get into the palace as all the tours are guided.If you do not go on a private tour, then get there early (8hh30) as you will wait for ages otherwise.The ceilings of some of the rooms are starting to sag and they say that they will be closing these rooms soon for maintenance.Otherwise, it is well worthwhile.

incredible palace. as early as the entrance, you would know how grand and intricate the architectural designs are. once inside the palance, it is absolutely amazing (and also symmetrical as our guide kept emphasizing) its interior design and architecture rivals that of palaces in europe, only here have I seen Crystal balustrades, giant crystal chandeliers, intricate would carved furnitures and a lot more. again a knowlegeable tour guide would make the experience even more interesting. the view of the palace would be best taken by the strait on a boat ride. too bad no picture taking inside

Truly stunning !. Walking distance from Besiktas tram and bus station, along the shore of Bosphorus strait.You go from one hall to another and amazed by the crystal chandeliers, handmade Turkish carpets and all.. but wait until you walk into the Ceremonial Hall, you just don't want to move and feast your eyes with all the stunning interiors inside !

Not your ordinary palace. The palace is relatively small though this is one of those cases when size does not matter. Pay attention to detals, this this somthing you will not find nither in Madrid nor in Paris. For some unexplained reasons the palace is not highly recommended by the travel books. No doubt that this should be one of the top ten attrations in Istanbul.
Excellent palace. Visit there and see the history the row of visitors are long but it is valuable to waite
its a Palace. its a place build from ottmans in European style. its worth to visit

Palace. It was cool to see a palace.. the grounds were beautiful and our guide gave us great history. The only bummer is not being able to take photos inside... but they have tons of postcards that are better than my photography anyways...

Mesmerizing!. The palace is magnificent and a must see in Istanbul. The entire tour is a must - the main palace and the harem. All tours are guided only. The entire tour costs TKL 40. There is a small line to go through security followed by the ticket gate. Group tours get preference. Once you get your ticket, you go through the main gate and then onto the garden and a short walk up to the palace entrance. There is usually a long wait here as they wait for about 40-50 people to gather before setting them off as a tour group. Once again, pre-arranged groups get preference. The tour guide we got was very knowledgeable. The palace is amazing. The main ceremonial room is breathtaking. The palace tour is about 45 minutes. The harem tour is also excellent (20-25 minutes). There are cafes and restrooms at regular intervals. No pictures/videos are allowed indoors, which is a shame.In summary, don't leave Istanbul without seeing this gem.

masterpiece. One of the most beautiful palaces in Istanbul, overlooking the Bosphorus,. The manicured lawns, beautiful location, and well kept Palace with all its grandeur, and the rich history behind it.
Fantastic!. Harlem! Gloomy atmosphere, but you can feel some kind of isolated life of women in those days. Beautiful garden and sunny view of the sea!

Not a 'not to be missed'. It is a really good example of baroque style palace but it is not worth money & time. Palace was really packed with to many people trying to understand what the guide was talking about. Nobody had enough time to see many of the rooms. There are many other attraction in that timeless city.

Unsurpassable magnificence. Get there as early as you can. They take tourists in batches, and you have to join a group and go round with them. We were queueing for half an hour and believe me that was nothing compared to how long the people behind us would have had to wait. It's worth seeing round this palace, because of the elegant sumptuousness of its decorations and furnishings, all very much in the Marie Antoinette style. Huge rooms, chandeliers, furniture, curtains - awesome, really. You see the Sultan's marble loo, and I was intrigued to have a peep into Kemal Ataturk's private bedroom too. In a way despiute all the wealth and pomposity and over-indulgence in the trappings of power, I felt that the people who lived here can never have had a moment unobserved. Made me content to be a mere tourist . The situation is magnificent too, right on the Bosphorus with ddelightful gardens. In summer a pleasant environment. Less so perhaps in April..

Rushed. I think you have to be with a tour group to visit. I didn't see any individuals. We were with a group, but couldn't hear our guide. The docents rushed us through and were very unpleasant-glowering and frowning at us. The palace, while huge and quite grand(chandeliers to die for) was completely European. I was expecting something more exotic and other worldly. It was beautiful-lovely gardens-views were magnificent, but you can see the same palace in London.

Beautiful but average experience. The Dolmabahce Palace is without a doubt, grand and majestic. However, our experience in touring the palace was not tourist friendly. First, it takes so long to buy tickets, because you can only buy the tickets outside the Palace. Afterwards, you have to get in line again outside the main hall as you are waiting for a guide (you cannot go in without a guide). Our first guide was really snotty and did not elaborate too much on the palace history. The tour of the main part of the palace only took 40 minutes. The second part of the palace, the harem is another tour (which you have to pay for separately). This means falling in line again to wait for your guide. The harem took 25 minutes to tour. Our second guide was much friendlier, thankfully. All in all, the palace is beautiful, but the touring experience is not worth it. We spent 2.5 hours inside the palace grounds but only about 1 hour touring the palace itself. The rest of the time was spent falling in line.

Wow, worth the queues and rushed guided tour, this place is amazing. Still looking like the day the sultan was given 4 hours to leave this is a true time capsule... Stuffed full of furniture, paintings and decorations, it is more accurately an art museum. Though unfortunately you have to do a guided tour and it is too rushed to really appreciate it all, I would still say it is worth doing!
This also is a must-see.. Very beautiful interior and extrerior, built by the Bosporus sea, don't miss it. A huge chandelier and a crystal stair the highlights of this visit.

Not Worth the Time nor Money!. The Dolmabahçe palace is not worth the time nor the money— not even if it was free and I somehow got my time back. Don’t get me wrong, it’s beyond beautiful, but it was the most boring tour I have even been a part of. Visitors must take the tour— you cannot explore on your own. There are forty to fifty people all being herded along through the hallways trying to peer into rooms for a few seconds. It’s a shame too because parts of the palace are interesting and probably worth seeing if it was done under better circumstances.
Nice Palace. It is almost over the top, but it's historical value outweighs that. It is quite beautiful inside, decorated with lots of crystal. It is worth checking out for sure.

A historic turning point. The Ottoman Empire's last-ditch effort to join the club of European monarchies: flatter them with a totally over-the-top palace! Stunning and pompous, but with some wonderful artefacts nonetheless and with the most amazingly well-trained and well-informed young guides. The world's largest hand-made carpet lies dwarfed by the majesty of the world's largest chandelier, like a little rug in the midst of the most vast state room imaginable: thankfully all those dear concubines didn't have to do any of the cleaning!
Turkish Opulence. After the visit you must think about the turkish opulence and great empire they had. Luxury of the 1000 nights !!!

Must visit :). It is an extraordinary palace. What I really liked is the presence of a guide who explains each room in English that was very helpful to understand the story behind.Be careful because there are 2 tickets: one for the tour inside the palace, and the other is for the upper floor, with all the rooms of the palace including Ataturk's bedroom. Also don't go on a Sunday, it was extremely crowded and the queue was too long!I will definitely visit again someday since, I have not seen the upper rooms yet :/
Dolmabache Palace. Gives understanding of just how wealthy and set apart from reality the Sultans were... amazing works of art were gifts from visiting foreign dignitaries.

Nice. Worth the visit - BUT be prepared for long lines. Staff seems knowledgeable...however, you miss a lot of what they're saying because the tour groups are rather large and marched through rather quickly. No chance to tour on your own. This is the reason why I don't like those bus tours from city to city...

Cristal palace. My advice is if it possible to come to Dolmabahce at 9 am, because then the work begins, and thus avoid the crowds starting from 11th half.Tickets can be purchased at the entrance to the palace TL 20 and 20 for the harem section, 40 TL. Don't work on Monday and Thursday.Please do not hesitate, it is worth every lira, because in such beauty and splendor of what you probably have not seen anywhere.Recording and photography is prohibited.Dolmabahce Palace is located on the European side of the Bosporus Strait, the entrance to the Sea of ​​Marmara, between Besiktas and Kabataš.Palace was built during sultan Abdulmedžit I (1839-1861). Sultan officially moved into seventh June 1856. and that day this palace became the official residence of the Ottoman sultans.Dolmabahče was built according to the design Bajlan, and engaged in the construction of the prominent European artists ..334 rooms, 25 saloon.Style is a mix of baroque, rococo and imperial Ottoman style.Furniture, carpets, rugs are from royal factory in Herekeu, Turkey. Beautiful parquet floors, ornately decorated with massive mirrors, bathrooms, silk carpets, chairs covered with damask, Czech and English porcelain, silver, leather, gold, shiny English crystal chandeliers, one of which weighs 5 tone.Real crystal palace of a fairy tale with 600 paintings.The period of the reign of Sultan Abdulmedžita marked the gradual turning of the Ottoman Empire to West..This palace is breathtaking, see why ...

very dissapointed!. First of all, huge queue because only one desk out 3 was working. When you finally get the chance to buy the ticket you get the "nice" surprise of a more expensive ticket (actually double) for foreigners than turkish citizens. I managed to buy the ticket at around 3 and because there wasn't much time i had to choose between the harem and the palace. i went for the harem, which is what i wouldn't advise anyone to do , a waste of time of visiting some hallways mainly, as the access to the rooms was mostly none!!! A very rushed tour with a not so nice lady guide who when i complained about the restricted access to the rooms said that there is nothing she can do about it and turn her back and walked away!!! For the double money that you pay, this is the service you get!!!

A bit off the beaten track, but a real gem!. Not every visitor to Istanbul makes it to the Dolmabahce Palace, but is is one of the "must see" places, and if you have enough time in Istanbul it is worth the effort to get there. It is just a short walk from the main tram terminus!The rooms are well appointed, and you can only visit as part of a guided tour. There are English speaking tours almost every half hour, and it is worth paying the extra to visit the Harem part of the palace.You should allow a couple of hours to visit, and if you have access to a good guide book before your visit you will benefit from reading about the palace beforehand.

Beautiful palace. the grounds leading up to the palace are lovely, including the cafe/restaurant right on the waterfront. The palace itself is amazing-full of history. Easily accessible by tram which goes over the Galata bridge.

Ottoman Splendor. Jaw dropping in extravagance and worth the 1 hour queue to get tickets. The building is impressive beyond words, especially the main hall. Unfortunately the tour and tour guide left much to be desired.

Take care of this palace!. Interesting palace, with nice gardens and nice views of the strait, but I was disappointed because of the dust that was everywhere. They should take more care of the palace and old furnitures inside!

Beautiful interior - just a lot of waiting and NO PHOTOS. We spent 15 minutes to get through security, 1 hour 10 minutes to get tickets to go inside, then 30 minutes to start our tour. That was almost 2 hours of waiting!However, every tour is guided by a very professional guide in either Turkish or English (just make sure you know that you're going with the right guide), and the interior really feels like you're in a palace. Its a 1 hour guided walk, so try to be near the guide as you'll be with a group of 25 people.A big bummer was the lack of photography allowed. You can take pictures of the grounds which are stunning, but not inside. Big bummer.Quick anecdote: We thought we could avoid lines and go the Harem quarters. However the side entrance to the Harem was closed and there were no signs telling us this until we had walked all the way to the end of the palace. When we came back the line was longer :(Recommendations:-Go early, like 9am; we went at 1pm-Get in line straight away, don't try to go to the harem-take lots of photos outside and explore the grounds after-make sure your tour is in your language

Ceremonial Hall- not to be missed. A relatively quick conducted tour rushes you through room after room and corridor after corridor of faded opulence but at the end you enter the Ceremonial Hall which is out of this world in terms of impact- a great pity no photos allowed anywhere in this the largest palace in Turkey. You will see the room where Mustafa Kemal Ataturk spent his last days, along with many other spectacular chambers, salons, hamams etc etc. We paid for the separate Harem which is a good stroll round the block from the main Palace and not really worth the effort unless you are really keen on history and old furniture, decorations and period pieces. You leave the palace by a small shop with not a lot to sell when we were there. Hard to find water but there is a cafe and facilities round the back by the entrance to the Harem. Timed entrances- small groups and conducted- and you need to wear overshoes- which can be hard to get on when there are no seats and not all visitors are under 21!

A good choice if rain or extra days. Better seen from the outside than worthing the ticket to be guided inside, the Palace can be a good option only if heavy rain or extra time after you visited everything. Of course, unless you are a captive fun of royal places and royal families. But even though.

Worth visiting, beware of opening hours. Beautiful palace in great setting along the Bosphorus. The palace only does guided tours, either organized privately or with one of their tour guides (included in entrance price). The guide assigned to us was friendly, knowledgeable and her English was excellent. The website and brochure say that the palace opens at 8.30 am. We arrived at 9 am to avoid lines, only to find out that the first tour in English was at 10 am.
one cold day. it is close to the sea and when you want to have a trip to see islands can visit here

Only tour allowed. Everyone has to follow the tour when inside the palace. The great hall was truly amazing, especially with a 4-ton chandelier hanging down from the very tall ceiling. No photos allowed inside though!

Stunning setting for a Sultan's palace. We only had time for a visit to the Harem but it was well worth seeing with fabulous French and Venetian glass chandeliers. Each room more splendid than the last. When we eventually emerged into the sunshine we were not hurried but had time to linger in the beautiful gardens by the Bosphorus. Enchanting!

A national treasure. One of the most beautiful palaces in Istanbul, overlooking the Bosphorus,. The manicured lawns, beautiful location, and well kept Palace with all its grandeur, and the rich history behind it.

Crowded and not that impressive. I took my father here a few years ago and we were really disappointed. We knew it was going to be crowded and didn't mind. There are lots of tourist groups and you need to join a group and go with a guide, so solo and small group travelers may have a bit of hassle organizing that. Our guide seemed really bored and just rushed us through, but we didn't mind as it was similar to, but not as impressive as many other sites.

Extremely interesting. This is a very nice addition to your Istanbul vacation. The palace is not only beautiful, but extremely well maintained and is amazinglycurrent for it's age and background. The tour also allows you to cross the Bosphorous and to go into the aisian side of the country. The tour lasts about 11/2 hours and is well worth the $40.00 price. We stopped on a hill for pictures after the tour and had tea and took many charming pictures of the area. Go for it!
Overpriced. A speedy tour from a guide who spoke very poorly, and at cost far higher than any other attraction

beautiful palace if you like east meets west feel. Loved the Palace. The location on the Bosporus is beautiful. You can just imagine dignitaries arriving by boat. The Crystal staircase and "worlds biggest crystal chandelier" are magnificent. Dolmabahce Palace was built to add a little more western feel than the previous Topkapi Palace which was made for the Sultans and their harem. It seems no expense was spared and yet the old habit of sitting against the walls was a hard habit to break. If you pay attention to the seating arrangements you can see that conversations were more one sided. I loved the western slant that they gave the palace. I found it more interesting than the Topkapi but, the harem's quarters and the jewels at the Topkapi should not be missed. Call for times and guided tours, they seem to change a lot.

A must. Don't forget to visit this attraction, not close from Sultanameht, but very important. You will see something very special. Visit are ordered by groups. I recommend to visit with a group as the visits are very stricts, in terms of time. Exquisite pictures and decoration.
Great rezidence of Osman sultans. we've visited Dolmabahce Palace and would say it's a great architecture monument - the rezidence of Osman sultans.It's a great location on Bosporus
Must visit palace. we very much amused that how they built and maintain this in old era. thousands of tons of gold and excellent art work. Also see the room where Kamal Ataturk spend his last day.

Not worth the price.... This is the last place where the Sultans ruled from. I know it's a historical landmark and I shouldn't say this but it's not truly worth it. If it was cheaper to get it then ok, but it's really expensive compared to other sites and it's not even half of what you get elsewhere. The tour guide was hard to understand, people were distracted and talking to each other because they were bored and that made it even harder when you try to hear what the tour guide is saying. It was not a good experience. You won't be missing much if you don't go, seriously. There are better things to see in this city.
Beautiful!!!. It's really a beatiful palace, luxurious and worth to see all cristals, carpets, marbles. Very nice for a walk by The Bosphorus too!

Lavish. I really enjoyed the tour of the Palace. we also toured the Harem Palace where Ataturk spent his last hours. The gardens are beautiful to walk through as you watch the sun glint off the Bospherous waters.
a great example of the grandeur of the Ottoman Empire. really impressive palace! Very disappointed that photos were not allowed at all inside the palace --- even without a flash)!

Fabulous palace and Bosphorus view. The palace is breathtaking. As a Turkish citizen, what I thought the first moment I saw the palace was "Now, I understand where all Ottoman money went to"... The palace is huge, yet most of the parts were closed for restoration purposes. The worst thing about the palace is there is only guided tours during which you can see even less of the palace.
Very good. A must see, loved the crystal chandeliers, but dont go on sundays its very crowded.

Very bad marketing policy for foreigners. Attention to the entrance fees for foreigners: Is 40 Ytl instead of a 20 ytl entrance fee for TC (Turkish citizens). When I have asked why do they make this difference, I was answered with: "Lady, move away from the line, others are waiting. 40 YTL or leave!". The palace is very nice on the outside, it has some luxurious rooms, but when you go further it goes from a magnificent palace and becomes just an usual place to stay for the sultan and his harem.... in my opinion it's not worth the price or it's just different from the palaces that i have visited in Western Europe. i am usually not writing reviews, but I thought that this would be helpful for the ones that otherwise wouldn't know what to expect, because of the website doesn't give information like what exactly you are going to visit or the xenophobe attitude that you are going to encounter in Dolmabahce's stuff attitude and the major different in prices!

Oppulant and interesting. When we went to this attrraction, I went with the idea in mind that this was the palace that brought down the Ottoman empire. It was definitely oppulant and extravagent - the crystal staircase, the amazing chandeliers. You can't take pictures inside the palace or the harem. You can only go through with a guided tour (which were pretty good and offered only in Turkish and English) which they split up and charge you separately for each part - the general palace, then the harem. You will want to see both and not feel like you've missed out on anything. I was a little suprised that some of the palace and harem were consistent with other mid to late 1800s residence that i"ve seen before with furnishings and wooden floors, etc. The great ceremonial hall in the palace is massive and rivals some of the larger mosques and churches we saw. The harem (or personal apartment and family apartments) is interesting and each room is adequately marked with signs and descriptions. We also stopped at the cafe and bathrooms in between the tours - the cafe is a little overpriced but sufficient. We also spent some time in the clock museum in between the tours (since the tours run just about every 30 or so minutes) - which was more interesting than I expected. Overall, an interesting site and a must stop on a visit to Istanbul.

Palace fabulous....but the staff...... This is not cheap to visit. 40 TL for non Turkish, and 20 TL for Turks. OK That's fine (bearing in mind that I live in Turkey, it's one thing I would like to see ajusted!), and having paid, I and my two friends had to wait a further 15 minutes until we were allowed inside...in the "English Speaking" party. My two friends who are both Turkish and speak excellent English took exception to being told (with all the other Turkish speaking crowd) that this party was for English speaking people, and TURKISH ARE NOT ALLOWED IN! Well, after a heated arguement in Turkish, my two friends were allowed in with me, and the Palace, it must be said is beautiful. However, both the guides and the security staff are officious, and need a few lessons in customer care. I was not impressed.

another palace!. this was a really beautiful place both grounds and interior are amazing and you really feel immersed in the history of the place, tours are only with a guide so no long queues and space to walk around . the only negative was that we could only see certain rooms and I wanted to see everything!
Luxurious. Everything. This was one of the best tours. This palace has a lot of French influence and the pieces you see are magnificent.
Dolmabahce. A must to visit. This is always on my list of historic places
Modern Palace of the Ottoman Emperors. Built around 1856 and still used for state occasions, this palace gives a glimpse of the lifestyle of the latter day emperors.
Too expansive for foreigners. The entrance fee was divided in two sections: 20 TL for turkish people and 40 TL for foreigners. So we decided NOT TO VISIT the Palace

Palace amazing, tours a let down. Dolmabache is amazing - a big contrast to topkapi and it's great because it has alot of the originally furniture etc. I did all parts of palace - the harem etc. You have to go on guided tours of the palace and can't take any photos in particular areas. The only problem is that the groups were so big that we couldn't here the guide & they weren't monitored enough so some groups went fast & others too slow & ended up on top of each other so I didn't enjoy that aspect. But the palace itself is amazing!

My favorite plase.It is wonderful. That plase will take the time because It is full off history....... My favorite plase.It is wonderful. That plase will take the time because It is full off history......

Ostentatiousness at it best. The ostentatiousness of this palace can rival Versailles. But I loved seeing it! The fact that the sultan starved his people to build this though is really sad. But a must see.

Western rather than Eastern. We have so many stately homes in Britain that it might be a bit unfair not to go overboard. The other delights in Istanbul were Eastern influence and novel/new whilst we compered this with our culture. Some parts were very opulent.

A disappointing guided tour. You can only visit this palace as part of their guided tour which is offered in English if that is what you require. We were organised into a group of perhaps 40 people. We were given minimal information by the English speaking guide about the artefacts on display. Even in the Exhibition Room, the items of silver and porcelain in the glass cases were not labelled with their provenance.It was only afterwards in the palace shop that I discovered from reading in what was essentially a 'coffee table ' book that these items originated from the Sevres and Limoges factories. One of the chandeliers had been a gift from Queen Victoria but we were not told this in the tour. The guide frequently said the crystal in this part of the palace was all English but again no mention of the workshop from which it originated. Likewise some of the vases were ignored but they did have some noteworthiness as evidenced in this book through which I browsed. We visited because it looks superb from a boat on the Bosphorus and i think that is probably the best view.
Beautıfull palace...... if you like to see one of the best palace on the Bosfhour this is the place must visited...

Wonderful and well worth the time!. This was a wonderful palace. We were very surprised at how lovely this palace was after being disappointed in the Topkopi Palace. The tickets were a little pricey, but the grounds were well kept and the palace was in good shape. The crystal chandeliers were amazing.
a typical ottoman palace. a typical ottoman palace a bad taste reproduction of a european palace but it worths a visit.

Tickets are too expencive. Enter only with guide. You are inside only 45 minutes so in my opinion tickets are too expencive. If you want to see private rooms of sultan you have to buy separate ticket, so you pay two times. Very nice rooms if someone likes French style

A must see. Provides an insight of the extent and wealth of the Ottoman Empire at its height. Recommend that you get there early to avoid the crowds as only a limited number of people are allowed in at a time. Do not miss the harem add on
Busy. Very enjoyable day out. Guided tours available in a variety of languages to tell you about the history of the Palace

Westernized Palace with Ottoman Harem. We were there this March, with a guided tour, which truly was quick, and there are many line ups everyday. The Palace is beatifull, but unless you visit the a harem it is just another palace, with the diffirence of having the 2 biggest chrystal chandeliers of the world.It;s still very well taken care of, and livable as it isnt that old.The harem which opened up this year, is the only thing that gives it the Ottoman touch, we liked. I would definately visit this palace, and I think it's worth the entrance fee The grounds and garden of the palace are just breathtaking especially with it being right on the waters of Bosphoros.

Ottoman palace in western outside. While the inside is quit Ottoman because there is a harem part and a men's part, the chandeliers, stairs and architecture are western. The garden is beautiful and has a lovely view over the Bosporus.

Strangely fascinating. Guided tours only! In peak season this must cause long waits, but the tours seem to alternate English and Turkish. You also get to pay and queue twice as the "public" part of the palace is a different ticket & tour to the harem (private apartments). Full of OTT baroque splendour.

Amazing!. The tour books say get here early and they're not kidding - I'd suggest in time for the first tour. The ticket sales booths are slow and arduous and if it is summer, you're stuck in relentless heat.You need to have the time to spend here, because inside all tours are guided with English and Turkish speaking tours rotating. Again you get caught in a queue in the sun, for what can be hours on end.The views are amazing and the garden nice to wander around.The opulance is beyond imagination in some areas - I'd never realised that Turkey would have such wealth and jewels. I'd recommend the Harem as well worth seeing if you have time.All the rooms were furnished symetrically which was quite an odd concept.

Not worth a visit if you are only in Instabul for a short time. No doubt this palace is magnificent and historical and is an important monument, but:1) prices are a bit high (students take your ISIC cards, it is only 5 TL then)2) you can not visit the place on your own, you have to follow a guided tour 3) the guides (both in main part and Harem) hardly talked at all during the tour and just rushed us through the rooms at maximum speed possible 4) the palace is in fact a great example of "europeanisated Ottoman" style, but on a such a speedy visit, it gives an impression of "just another palace" in Baroque/Rococo style
Breathtaking. Dolmabahce Palace was my best discovery in Istanbul. Trying to describe it wouldn't do the justice.The Palace is simply stunning.
Another Glimpse ... Another glimpse of private lives of the Sultans and Ataturk himself, the amazing thing i liked about this place, its smell ! somehow it smells like my grandfather's house :D

The No 1 place to visit in Istanbul. We visited many sights in Istanbul , all of which are wonderful, but for me this was the best .the place is just amazing , hundreds of rooms , all furnished exactly how it was when the Sultans were living there , unlike , for example the Bahia palace in Marrakech where all the rooms are completely empty . The guide was very good , which I was pleased about after reading earlier reviews . The Harem is worth a visit and so is the collection of clocks . Truly unmissable .

Not to be missed. No trip is completed to Istanbul unless you have seen this place.I have talked to people in the cue who have seen this every year.If you going in peak summer time better prepare for long cue.5 minutes walk from kabatas tram station.

Long lines and huge groups. I would call it superficially impressive. The building seemed to be a place built to make Turks feel a little more European. Columns were fake, but there were many impressive chandeliers and entry ways. The haram could easily have been skipped, saving a person 10TL - nothing there was half as impressive or interesting as the actual palace and it was just another line to wait in.The biggest problem with this place is the size of the guided tours (you must be part of a guided tour) and the lines. Thankfully we went on a cold Sunday morning and there was only one group tour there before us and a couple other individuals. We did not have to wait in line for very long to get tickets but it was pretty silly that there was only 1 ticket seller working - the other one was for group tickets only but no one came to her window the entire time we were in line & she sent people back into line if they tried to come to her booth. Once in we had to wait in ANOTHER line outside in the cold. The next tour was in 30 minutes so we walked the grounds. The tour group ended up being a good 50+ people - too many to have in one group along narrow corridors. They should have split the group. The same thing happened for the Harem, over 50 people and a 30 minute wait even though we were there on a non-crowded day. The only reason we liked the tour at all was because our first guide was friendly, had a great personality, and his voice carried very well. We spent 3 hours there, about half of it was waiting in line. I can't imagine if we were there at a busy time or, even worse, during their heavy tourism season!

A beautiful Palace on the Bosphorus. Absolutely amazing! The palace grounds and main buildings are stunning and adorned with priceless antiquities and Turkish national treasures. The carpets and tiles are particularly of interest. The entrance fees are not much and you can choose to view the harem as well. All tours are guided with a group of about twenty and the main palatial residence can be viewed in under two hours. No pictures are allowed inside but they can be taken on the grounds.

Wonderful!. This beautiful palace is a must see for lovers of history or fine architecture.I didn't know what to expect but this is probably the most beautiful building of had the pleasure of visiting. Joining a guided tour you get a brief history of the rooms. I loved it so much I bought the book.The only downside is that you have to go with a tour guide so you don't get to linger long in any one place but I'd happily go back for a second look.

Cool palace, pricey. This place was kind of pricey - I believe it was 30 TL to for the main part and another 20 TL for the harem (which we didn't do). It was neat to see and its grounds are very beautiful, being right on the Bosphorous. The insides are cool - your typical palace stuff (lots of riches all around). I'd recommend going, but it wasn't mind-blowing.
a great place to visit. If you are a history buff and don't visit this place while in Istanbul you miss an opportuity of a life time
Dolmabahce Palace. Its one of the best palace in Istanbul and where ATAURK has died.

Main Palace Worth it... the haram a bit redundant if you've seen others. The main palace is so well kept with the incredible chandeliers, furniture, crystal staircase, turkish baths and art. You can't take photos inside, but some were doing so. There aren't any self guided tours so you need to wait for either the english or turkish tour which leaves every 30 minutes or so. While you're waiting you can go see the crystal room and take photos outside in the garden and the bospherous. After you finish the main palace have enough time to grab a tea at the cafe and make it quickly into the haram (which is an additional fee). This area we walked through quite quickly as a large group and were rushed quite a bit.... not a big deal but good to know if you like to linger, read and look you'll have some trouble here.

Wow - So Extravagant!. This is one of the most luxurious palaces I have ever visited. The Sultan sure did live well. All those rooms and the furniture and paintings and the crystal and chandeliers - wow! The decor inside was just breath-taking. The statues, foutains and rose gardens outside were also beautiful! They had little rest area in back with chickens and peacocks walking around; they will pose for a picture.Note: There may be a wait to get in and you have to wear baggies on your feet. There are no pictures allowed inside, not even without a flash; they are strict - they will take your camera from you.
Glittering Prize. An amazing palace to visit. Full of treasures from the Sultanate, and just stunning in every way. The baccarat crystal staircase and the chandeliers take your breath away

Relaxing, gorgeous & historical tour on the shores of the Bosphorus. If you don't want to embrace the crowds at The Blue Mosque and Sophia Hagia, then this tour is great! Beautiful grounds and gardens located on the stunning shores of the Bosphorus. About an hour tour is given in Turkish or English of the main palace and then another shorter tour is conducted of the harem building. Pictures inside the buildings aren't allowed which is dissapointing, but they must do it for a reason. The lighting in the buildings is impressive and you can tell that everything is original. I really enjoyed the tour and relaxing in the grounds afterwards - great photo opportunities in the courtyard.

A bit different to the typical. A more European feel to this grand Palace. A bit tricky to get to but wonderful building, the main stairway and grand ceremonial hall were the highlights to this palace. 40TL for a whole palace tour was the most expensive sightseeing i done.
A real Palace. I wish I was one of the princess that lived there.... you have to visit it.
A must see. It's the equivalent of Versailles for Istanbul. Beautiful palace in baroque style. Don't miss the mosque before you enter.
one palace views two continents. this is great, in this place you can see both continents, with the great bosphorus view..

Hire a private guide, take my advice.. Hiring a private guide will get you out of the organized cattle herd and allow you to enjoy this place the way it should be. For security, you can not get in this place without an approved chaperone. You can join the organized groups that flow through on a schedule OR you can get your own guide and take your time, ask questions and dwell on the interesting points that draw you. I chucked as watched the stunned looks on the faces in the big groups as they tried to keep up with the packs. Go get your own guide.

Decaying imperial spleandour at it's most fragile.. Worth the trip - it's a short walk (5 mins) from the tram stop. It is only possible to view on a tour which felt unbelivebaly rushed. We were whizzing past rooms full of history and not stopping. We were also shepharded into some 'display' rooms and made to wander through the porcelain/unpolished silver collections before re-joining the whistle-stop tour. It was far too rushed. Our guide said 'here is the crystal stair case' and then we were marched up it and into the next room. No time to really observe or appreciate. Our guide was fun but we felt very much that we were on a conveyor belt. Also, really weirdly, you have to put plastic covers over your shoes before entering. This is odd - and slightly dangerous - slippy plastic; carpet; quickly walking down stairs...I have never encountered this anywhere else in the world (including Windsor castle!!). We were walking on 'tourist' carpets anyway and the guide has his shoes (un-covered) on...so why did we have to dangerously glide round?! The toilet/cafe facilities are quite primative (only place in Istanbul I saw a squat toilet). A good companion to the Topkapi palace and a worth-while visit.

Absolutely the best. This place was really worth of visiting. Not only a museum with showcases, but so many rooms were originally furnished. It was amazing, how you could even feel the ancient life all around you. Tickets were a bit expensive, but don't miss this one!

We enjoyed this visit more than we thought we would.. This palace helps to add to your sketchy accumulating knowledge of Turkish History. From the last of Turkish ruling aristocrats to Ataturk. The Palace is in many ways still in a natural state from Ataturk's days with the decor. We were surprised with many of the rooms overwhelming treasures.It is a treasure in itself and worth the visit.

A must.... If you are in Istanbul, you must stop by here, its a must visit while in the city. I love that you are no longer able to take photographs inside, its makes it even more special. Just go and see the amazing interior, chandeliers & how the royalty lived back in the days.

Best Palace Ever. This palace is the living place of few Ottoman kings and after them Ataturk.The palace is glorious, Surrounded by a beautiful garden . It is a must see. There is a Harem section which is not as beautiful as the palace but you may want to take a look.Entry fee for palace 30 TL , Harem 20 Tl and both 40 TL.

wonderful place ! must see !. magnificent and luxury palace. This palace is totally different than the Topkapi Palace because it is European style designed. Topkapi palace is turkish & ismalic style designed. Armenian artists worked mostly. Baroque style design.

extravagant. wooooooooow, GREAT palace, i never thought i would see such a chic luxurious place in my life, from the chandeliers to the carpets to the antiques, curtains every corner and every room had some thing different and amazing , definitely a MUST SEE place

A Turkish Versailles. As a medievalist, I didn't expect to like this 19th C. sultans' palace all that much, but was amazed. It is very much like Versailles both with mirrors and French style furniture. You can visit the upstairs harem, and all through the palace see how the sultan would greet diplomats, visiting dignitaries etc. There is a purposeful symmetry to the palace. As you walk in, everything on one side will be matched by the same thing on the other. It was very much designed to impress as a visitor approached the sultan. The porch area that leads out to the Bosphorus gives you a magnificent view.

WOW!. Rivals the great palaces of Europe...of course, it was built to do so and exceed them. Dolmabahce Palace certainly comes close. As it is newer than the other European palaces, it is in fabulous shape and well cared for throughout. The Baccarat grand staircase and the massive chandelier were both breathtaking. The price is steep, but I found it well worth it. The group I was with was awed as well.

Not to be missed. This is a palace that is a must see. The sultan spared nothing in the building and decorating of this magnificent palace which is situated directly on the Bosphorus. The grounds are also spectacular. My only complaint is that the tour moved too quickly making it difficult to really look at the artwork and incredible treasures. If you did, you ended up at the end of the group and then could not hear the guide. There is security behind the group so you cannot linger. Because there are many school tour groups also visiting, be sure to get there early. There is an small extra charge to go through the harem which was definitely worthwhile.

Fit for a king.. This place was breath-taking. So well maintained and well decorated with tons of history. A bit costly (40 TL/person) but it is definitely worth the money. Sadly no photographs are allowed inside.

Beautiful palace!. I actually prefer the Dolmabahce to the Topkapi Sarayi. If you have to choose one or the other, come early to the Dolmabahce and see the amazing crystal chandeliers and staircases here!

I'd you have extra time, go see this palace. First, let me say that I only paid the student price of 5 lira for this palace. If I had paid the 60 lira I would have been disappointed! The palace itself is fantastic - I can see why it bankrupted the empire! But the tour was lacking - just being herded in and out of rooms with very little explanation. It's an interesting place but don't expect much from the tour. The gardens are amazing though!

unexpectedly magnificent and luxury. Before visiting the palace we thought there should be some Islamic features that can be found in Topkapi. I was really surprised by its European style. We all screamed when seeing the big chandelier in the ceremony hall as well as the stair handrails which are made of gold. We didn't expect we can find such a western-style palace in Turkey! It is definitely understandable if you find this palace more magnificent than the Palace of Versailles in Paris and the Schonbrunn Palace in Vienna. Nevertheless if you are tired of luxurious palaces that can be found all around western Europe, I will suggest the Topkapi instead as it has more Islamic and Ottoman features.
