After all, Topkapi is more 'traveller-friendly' as it is in a walkable distance from Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque. Another kind reminder is that if you go with children, remind them not to touch the antiques. The staff there are quite rude to visitors who do so.

Interesting example of sultan's way of living. It has two tours Selamlik (main palace building about 45 min) and Harem (private harem apartments buildng about 30 min). Both are guided in groups only (different languages starting in every 15 min), no any audio guides/individual visitng. If you don't have a lot of time take Selamlik for sure, Harem can be missed as it's not so much impressive. Surrounding is nice with garden and direct Bosphorus' entrance.

Luxury everywhere you look. Amazing, after passing the police control you really should invest in buying the photo ticket and get a lot of space in the memory of the camera because you are about to see something spectacular. You will be asked to cover your shoes, please don't be angry to do it! this place owns amazing huge and beautiful carpets, be nice with them. I have visited this place already 2 times, duringg summer is great cause the exit meets the Bosphorus in the most spectacular view I ever get since I arrived here. I loved this place so much.

Beautiful inside and out. I paid extra to see the Harem which is an interesting insight into what life must have been like for the many wives/women of the sultans. The grounds surrounding the palace and the various buildings all hold many treasures. I would suggest you give at least 3 hours to this outing at least as dependent on the time of year queueing can get a bit lengthy and slow. But still worth the effort and time.
Enchanting!. The Palace itself was quite beautiful but even the grounds are awesome as well. The only down side was that you're not allowed to take photos inside the Palace.
Imperssive. This palace is very impressive and something which Turkish people proudly suggest as must-see. It is worth to compare male and female (harem) parts of the palace.
Must See. Stay away from Haram and don't waste money on it. Palace in itself is a MUST SEE and one of the best in Istanbul.
Fine if you have the time, but follow it with the Naval Museum. The chandeliers and staircases make up for the fact that it looks as if the whole edifice is falling apart.

Opulence at its peak. We have seen Windsor and other European style palaces so I was not very sure while visiting this one whether it was going to be worth it or not..We were not disappointed.This palace is not much for history as much for its opulence and wonderful views.Chanderliers and glass works are the best I have seen anywhere. Entrance staircase is amazing.Cameras are not allowed inside though I did see quite a few ppl sneaking in the pics,in case u are interested in that.We took a tour and were not bothered much by queues(Also as it was winter off season though there was XMas crowd.)..If you want to go on your own then you can buy the ticket (there is per day visitor number limit) and stand in queue for the tour by palace guides.Individuals are not allowed entry without them.Palace guards are everywhere but we did not feel much rushed.Also as its a more of view palace rather than hear and read one. For tours there is a seperate queue.It did help us move faster than the non tour queue but am not sure how good it would be in peak seasons.Best way to avoid queues is to go to palace in the mornings.Definitely a must visit after you are done with SultanAhmet regular attractions.For tram users stop would be Kabatas.Also Princess island fairy goes from Kabatas so you can come here in the morning and then visit the islands.

Excellent, except for the queues. The palace was in the same area as our hotel, so it was a short walk to it. Once we got through the security we had to line up in a 2 hour queue to get to the ticket office(only 1 open). Once through the entrance gate of the palace we had to queue up again to enter the palace with the obligatory guide. A guide group consisted approx 50 people. Still though it took about half an hour again to get from the ticket office into the palace. The building was magnificent! Beautifully decorated and well maintained. We bought a ticket for the harem as well. An extra 20 minutes queuing went along with that. Again: splendid building and acceptable guidance by a friendly Turkish lady.

A highlight. We loved Istanbul, but this was a favorite among favorites. I had never seen anything so splendid. The tour was efficient and informative. The art and decor will blow your mind. It is also a lesson in excess, since it was being built as the Ottoman Empire was crumbling.
Amazing garden. Very big place,very nice garden and awesome view...

Nice palace, but tour was to rushed. The palace is quite nice, but the tour felt rushed and was not informative. You can only go through the palace on a guided tour. The tours are available in Turkish and English. You have to choose between the Harem and the official parts. If you want to do both you have to wait twice for the tour and also pay more. We choose the Harem tour which takes about 30 minutes. We had to wait 45 minutes outside in the cold. There were about 50 people on our tour, which was too much for my taste.
Perfect. Definitely a must in Istanbul, perfect location and a great place to see on the bosphorus

Beautiful, although you're rushed through. Guided tours are mandatory and the goal of the guides is to get you out of there sooner rather than later. Aside from this nuisance, and knowing that you'll miss more than you'll see, this is a wonderful western style palace. The grand room is spectacular, probably one of the largest out there. Worth the wait in line for sure. They don't let you take any pictures and couldn't articulate why.

Elegant and opulent reminder of a past Ottoman era. The palace is rich and ornate and full of interesting historical detail. Is was the last place for the revered founder of modern Turkey, Kemal Ataturk, and they have taken care to preserve the palace. The facade is best appreciated from a Bosphorus cruise. The guard pacing by the gate along the strait is a good photo. The tour is a bit rushed and there is no time to linger, and that is a shame as it would have helped to better appreciate the palace.

AKA "Debauchery Palace" - quite a site to see. Really an unbelievable place - such excess & opulence. I also highly recommend seeing the harem side of the palace. Unlike the harem at Topkapi palace, the rooms here are furnished & fully displayed so you can get a good idea of what life was like. Both the main palace & the harem can only be toured with a guide in a group. We visited off-season but the tours took place very frequently and the guides were helpful. It is located away from the main Istanbul historic district, but if time allows, I would recommend seeing it.

ONE OF THE MOST BEAUTIFUL PALACES. One of the most beautiful Palaces in the world, the Dolmabache Palace is a must see... 40 tonnes of Gold and 40 tonnes of silver line every inch of the Palace interior.....Photography is stricYly prohibited inside....hence it is a place where you have to have to see it with your own eyes to believe it... You will also get to witness Turkish own version of London's famed Changing of the Guards ceremony.

Better than Tokapi in my opinion. I really enjoyed touring this building. Now perhaps it would be even better during summer, but at this time of year there were very few other people. The style was very European based but to hear the hisotry and see how they lived and the chandaliers were amazing.Highly recommend.

very rushed. It took more than 2 hours to get in and we were rushed through the palace within 1 hour.Not sure why there is only one ticket window when the queue must have held a couple of hundred people - literally took us 2 hours to get tickets.More waiting after this as you are not allowed to wander through the Palace yourself. Official tours (part of the entry fee) are scheduled and you are made up into a large group and walked through some areas. No chance to enjoy the surrounding or ask detailed questions.A pity as really beautiful (this was the Ottoman's answer to Versailles , France) . Worth seeing but if pressed for time, would avoid this in favour of the Big 3 - Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Haggai Sophia

Beautiful palace in Istanbul. The Dolmabahce Palace was actually our favorite site of all that we visited in Istanbul. It has a spectacular location on the shore of the Bosphorus, has beautifully landscaped grounds, and the palace itself has been well maintained. The last emperor who lived here fled in the 1920's and then was used as Ataturk's "base" in Istanbul until he died in 1938. Furniture remains inside the palace that is typical of what would have been used during the time that it was occupied. This palace is enormous, and is more extravagant than any other palace or museum we have visited. There is a huge ornate staircase with Baccarat crystal spindles as well as the world's largest chandelier at 5 TONS! The ceremonial hall where this chandelier is located is pretty spectacular in its own right with beautiful 118 foot high domed ceilings. We walked through the palace quite leisurely with our tour guide, but there are many guards that make sure that you stay beyond the barriers and don't take pictures. It was a shame not to be able to take photos inside the palace, but there is a small gift shop where you can purchase postcards that show many of the highlights. It's definitely worth a visit while you're in Istanbul!

Poorly guided tour. This was our most expensive tour ... about $22 per person for Palace and Harem. Guides seemed intent on rushing us through and had little of value to say. The place was not crowded, so there was no excuse for the rush. The building are traditional European palaces in style, with lots of oppulence. Not enough time to see any details because of the rush! Worst of all, no photos, and little in the way of postcards to see what we missed. A disappointment!

A big change from other Istanbul sites. It is a western style palace of the sultans. It is very beautiful and includes original furnishings in all the rooms, something that you don't see at Topkapi Palace. We went on a tour from our cruise ship so I don't know what tours are available onsite. It is a fascinating place. We saw all of what would have been the original public areas as well as parts of the harem area. Theoretically we had a tour scheduled for a specific time but when we got there the lineup inside the grounds was long and time consuming. The tour time meant nothing. Having said that I felt it was worth seeing as a complete contrast to the other major sites in Istanbul.
very nice plalac. I think it was a modern palac(21th) buitt in 19th centurey

wealthy palace on the Bosphorus. Nice palace to visit.Took us almost an hour to get in although very low season, ticket office very slow, after that waiting for obligatory guided visit. No pictures allowed. Tiicket price double as high for for non Turkish visitors.We visited the palace and the harem, in last part also the rooms of Ataturk so worth the extra tour/costs. Very nicely decorated, interior worth a fortune. We liked the palace but would have prefererred a non guided trip with an audioguide, security everywhere and groups are that large that info by the guide is not clear all the time.Take at least 3-4 hours in low season for the visit.

Western-like most luxurious palace of the sultans. Must visit.. The Royal Palace of the sultanates of the last Ottoman-Turkish Empire is a sort of devotion to the west. After all, seems much more a French palace than the official residence of a leader of a nation at that time mainly Muslim. A must see that in order to prevent crowds, should be made early in the morning. Beautiful palace, with detailed classic architecture, gorgeous gardens, rich interior with very luxurious decor and nice views to the Bosphorus.

A Big Surprise.... Located on the shore of the Bosphorus the Palace is easy to get to using the main tram to the end at Kabatas and walking about 5 minutes to the palace grounds. After spending the time in tiled mosques, Topkapi Palace Museum, and Aya Sofia, this was a total surprise! It has no ornate Ottoman feel usually connected with Istanbul's historic Sultanhamet area. Instead, it is a lavish European style palace commissioned by Sultan Abdulmecid II sinking millions to rival the richest palaces of France. There are 285 rooms filled with 14 tons of gold, 6 tons of silver and massive ornate crystal pieces. We had scheduled a morning to visit and were so glad we did. You must be part of a tour which leaves every 15 minutes or so and though we were there off season, there was a line. I'm told that reservations are necessary during the summer when the major tourist crush is on. If you want to continue the tour into the harem area, it is an additional tour and fee.

Long wait, bad guide. I waited 45 minutes in the line to get my ticket, then 40 more minutes to get in. The english speaking guide had terrible pronunciation, it sounded more like turkish. Nobody in the group could understand well what he was saying.

Stunning 18th Century European-style Palace. To take in some history, you can walk downhill from Taksim towards Besiktas, until you hit the Bosphorous. You will find the Dolmabache Palace to your left. This tourist attraction should not be missed. There is a 10 TL fee each for the Palace itself, as well as the Harem section. Harem is similar to the main palace and can be skipped if you are short of time. Guided tours leave every 30 minutes and walk you around only some of the rooms and halls of the 300+ rooms in this palace. Almost all rooms look stunning and yet, different, on account of the tapestries,carpets, furniture, and the grand chandeliers. Since the palace is not too old, it has been very well maintained and one can see it in its pristine condition. Guides speak good English and are very helpful. The Grand Reception Room has a huge chandelier and is the most opulent room in the palace. The harem section has a separate entrance and is similar to the main section. You can also get great views of the Asian side of Istanbul from the palace grounds.There is also a small cafe on the grounds, where you can sit and relax after the long walking tour(s). Since you cannot take any pictures inside the palace, do visit the palace store and pickup some postcards (2.5 TL for 10).

poor organization. first of all I would like to point out that my review will be about organization of this place. so - we went there with friends after spending beautiful morning in the cafe near Bosphorus just a 5 minutes away from the palace. when arriving we bought tickets (20TL per person for both palace and harem). and then the waiting started. you have to wait to get into the teritory. then you have to wait to get into the palace. we waited around one hour. its impossible to go inside palace just by yourself - there are just guided tours (separate for Turkist speaking and other nationalities). they write on the desk at what time is next tour, however that does'nt save you from the waiting as it is not written on the ticket. palace itself is breathtaking and definetely worth to see. tours - too short and fast. basically you go trough the palace pretty fast receiving some basic information with no possibility to stop and have a closer look if you like something in particular. after palace you can go to harem. and there is the same - waiting (a bit less than at the palace) to get in and guided tour. after waiting for so long we didnt have energy to take a look at other exibitions or to take a walk in the park. wrapping up all that was said before - beautiful place with unfortunately poor organization.

Not worth the wait. Majestic and opulent place. Showed the way of life of the early rulers of Turkey. It was a bit of an anti-climax due to the long queues caused by the disorganized system to visit the palace. If you are pressed for time pay extra for a group tour which includes the palace as one of the places to visit in the city as they do not have to queue. As we went as a couple it took us 1.5 hours and there was another 45 mins wait for the tour to start where we were herded like cattle by the palace's official guide. No photos and no touching of anything along the way which took about 45 mins. If you are pressed for time and unable to stand in line for a long time I would suggest you give the palace a miss as there are better sights to visit in the old city. 20 lira for the official apartments and 15 lira for the harem.
Majestic Palace with stunning view of Bosphorus. We took the English tour. Very informative. You are allowed to take a flash-less pictures inside.

stunning architecture and late 18th century design. ticketing office higly inefficient but, once inside, it is an awe inspiring experience and a peak into the lifestyle and psychology of the ottoman sultanate, 20TL per person for political quarters and harem

Majestuous palace with flowers gardens. The palace has a special meaning for turkish people as it is in this place where Attaturk died.There is an excellent organization in this palace beacause guides explain to each groups the history of every rooms.The minus point is that u CANNOT take pics inside and the queue is VERY long to access to the entry guichet.It is very pleasant to walk with ur half around theses gardens.
4th Greatest palace in the world. This was the highlight of our trip, it you don't see anything else, see this

ostentatious. Get there early! There can be a long waiting line to buy tickets at the one (!) quaint ticket window. That's just to get into the grounds. There's another wait, on the palace steps, to join a "tour group." This isn't really a tour, as a group of about 40 is much too large. It was more like herding folks through and making sure they don't touch anything. The tour leader didn't explain much, so if you're really interested in finding out about the palace, it's critical to maneuver yourself to be in step with the guide so that you can ask questions. Great views of the Bosphorous from the windows and outside on the grounds. The Palace itself is beautiful, with a great variety of chandeliers and other ostentatious trappings of wealth. The recommended length of visit is pegged at 1-2 hours, because it likely will take that long to get through all the lines (though this visit was on a Friday in early September, so maybe it might be less crowded later in the year.)

Reminder of Versailles and other western palaces. The palance is well maintained, and very nice to visit..there are no individual visits, basically people are grouped and a guide will take them through some sections talking about the palace..The palace itself is very nice on the inside, whether the carpeting, the chandeliers, the paintings...the harem was ok, nothing spectacular, and the guide was not very engaged, he was not very enthusiastic.

Breathtaking!. Dolmabahce ranks as the most outstanding landmark I encountered in Istanbul during my visit last August. Overlooking the Bosphorus strait, this prodigal palace, which served as the home for the last six Ottoman Sultans, is nothing short of an artistic jewel!The "stuffed" imperial gardens, originally a bay, merge beautifully with the eclectic architecture and the bosphorous background. The lavish interiors, ornamented ceilings and pending chandeliers will not disappoint you! The peak of the experience lies at the ascending of the grand staircase leading up to the ceremonial hall pierced by its 5 ton crystal chandelier! Our guide pointed out that it took servants 6 months to clean the chandelier after each ceremony!I must also mention that it is a must to be accompanied by a professional guide to take the tour inside the palace. A well-informed guide will really make your visit to the Dolmabahce a very enjoyable one since there is a lot to share about the history of the palace, the ettiquettes of ceremony and the secrets of inperial life!I strongly recommend this site to anyone who has ever set foot in Istanbul!

2nd time visiting and still amazing!. This my second time visiting this interesting palace. The different rooms and the way of living such as going to toilets, reading, cooking...etc. I like going to the old days by going to these old and ancient places, it is like going through the time machine! Nearby the palace is the famous Ortakoy suburb on the European shore of the Bosphorus, which is vital place full of small shops, cafes, restaurants and many people gathering.

Worth the visti. I visited the palace one afternoon and it is worth the 3 hours and USD15. For the visit you have a palace tours, you are going in groups that start about every 30 minutes, either in English or Turkish. The rooms are beautiful and the center hall with probably the biggest crystal chandellier in the world is worth the visit; when you first walk in you are not expecting something so amazing. The harem is nothing extraordinary, but for 30 minutes you could spare the time. The jardens are good picture spots, you can not take pictures inside the palace, and they enforce the rule.

Beautiful palace - appaling organisation, left feeling cheated!. Queued for over 30mins to buy a ticket (only one ticket booth for huge line of people waiting). We chose the palace + harem ticket which was a little more expensive but we wanted to see both aspects. First stopped in the cafe as a sign said the tour was likely to take 2 and a half hours. The cafe offered stale bagels with no option for a topping at all, or a cheese sandwich, we opted for this. Was a piece of rubber cheese sandwiched between cardboard bread. Horrible! Then came the 30min queue to get into the palace. They let people in in 'batches', assigning approx 70-80 people per 'English speaking' tour guide. Due to the large numbers the guide had to address, we rarely caught the information in each room from start to finish, he was very quiet and speaking with a very heavy accent. The bits of info I did catch were saying 'this is the harem room. The harem room is where the Sultan brought his harem' - not all that enlightening. The palace was extremely hot - obviously not easily rectified but I think if they let people walk around at their own pace instead of as a huge group it would be more comfortable, they could offer an audioguide as an alternative. There were no leaflets in English at all. My husband was ushered out of a couple of rooms when they felt he was taking too long. Most of the paintings had a little area below them which was clearly meant for an information sign, but there were none. The building itself is stunning - amazingly opulent and gorgeous, but would be improved if things were given a dust and a hoover... All the huge amounts of crystal would have far more impact if it hadn't been covered in dust, and the silverware as well. We'd paid extra for the harem tour but this never happened, and the overall tour lasted 45 mins (this was actually more than enough for us, but it was clear that the tour had been cut short). We left feeling a bit cross and cheated!

Great place to offer a more modern yet historic view of Turkey. Dolmabahce is a superb place to visit because it gives tourists a more modern insight into Turkish history. It provides a nice balance from the amazing historical and more ancient locations in Sultanahmet for instance. It is absolutely beautiful, for one thing. I had 2 tour guides. The first one, in the Administrative part of the palace was one of the best tour guides I have ever had bar none. He was simply fabulous and provided our group with an amazing amount of historical information, interesting tidbits, etc. He loved language and would say specific key words throughout the tour in several languages. The 2nd guide, the one in the Harem, offered almost no information or friendliness. It was a strange juxtaposition between the two. Two warnings: They are closed on Thursday- I tried to go on Thurs. last time I was in Turkey and didn't read ahead and got there (of course I was disappointed...and rightfully so-this is an amazing place to see!) with the gate closed. It is very very hot in the house. Granted I was there in August, however it was almost unbareable, so drink lots of water before going and dress accordingly! There are not a lot of open windows in the palace providing a breeze. I think this palace in many ways exemplifies a lot about modern Turkey through the art, architecture, furniture and by who lived there. It is an amazing combination of styles from around the world, and it melts them together beautifully. If you get a great tour guide, you are in for a real treat!Also, I would suggest, if seeing either the Administrative or the Harem, and you were to only choose one (b/c you have to pay seperately), I would actually choose the Administrative even though the Harem sounds sexier and more interesting. It is actually NOT that sexy and it is far less interesting. I would definitely advise seeing both, but that is my 2 cents for you if you only choose one.

If you love sight seeing, luxury and history, this is the place. Dolmabahce is a magnificent palace. I actually liked the outside more than the inside. Outside is big space with fountains, grass, statues, and the palace is over looking the sea, its just a magnificent view! They have the soldiers that stand with a gun and don't move for a long time, it was fun watching them.The palace isn't really crowded, so there isn't a long wait like the other places in Istanbul.Inside, they take you on a tour with a group of people. When we got there, they said there will be two tour groups, one in Turkish and one in English, so we joined the English one. You aren't permitted to go off on your own to any place, or touch anything. On the inside you can see the different rooms they had, the gifts they took from other countries, and really nice paintings hung on every wall. It's a place full of history, diamonds, and gold!It was really exciting for me, since I've never been in a palace before.I felt like I was in a movie when I saw the big round stairs with the red carpet. But they only permitted us to see some of the things in only one building, and there are SO many buildings in it, its really dissapointingOutside the palace is a great place to take pictures, since it isn't permitted on the inside. There's also tables overlooking the sea outside, and you can order from a small dinerThe people there are really kind, and the money is totally worth going and seeing itWe had some old people who didn't want to walk, so they just stayed in the tables outside and didn't pay to go inside.If you've never went to a palace, I really advise you to goIf you haven't, its still a fun experience

if you like opulence and greatness, the Dolmabahce Sarayi is the place for you. Situated 5 minutes walk from the stop of the "Tramway" in Kabatas, if you like opulence and greatness, the Dolmabahce Sarayi is the place for you. With a breathtaking view of the Bosphorus, this huge palace with its hundreds of rooms and halls, will leave you stunned with some of its details. The gilded carvings, crystal work, the reception hall and some rooms of the harem will hurt your eyes with so much wealth. In the gardens you can take a pleasant walk. But not everything is beauty and wealth on a visit to this palace. Isn't open every day, so is better you find when it´s open. Try to go as early as possible. To avoid the excess of visitors simultaneously inside the palace, the number of entries is controlled, it would not hurt if they were well organized, but they aren´t. It was a rare example of clutter that I found in my stay. This results in queues to buy tickets on the outside. After we acquired the tickets and we think we are already saved, again queues to enter in the palace. All tours are guided. Even the tourists alone have to wait for a guide and when he comes, may have some difficulties in english language. This also would have no problem if the visit was not at lightning speed. A word of advice, go get yourself leaving behind your group to better appreciate some of the pieces that are truly magnificent. Do not worry about what the guide has to say, if you want to know more about the palace buy a book, or go to the gift shop, and do as i, buy a CD withe photos. Photos aren´t allowed inside the palace. Despite all it's worth.

A different look at the Ottomans. An amazing palace, poles apart from the other Ottoman palace - Topkapi. Very European and grand. A must see. It gives an eery reminder that the decline of the Ottoman Empire began soon after this move.The Dolmabache Palace has its own compulsory guided tour. (BTW you're not allowed to take pictures inside) We took it near closing time and they literally rushed through it without giving us time to enjoy or appreciate the treasures of the palace. Specially true of the magnificent artwork it houses. Taking about closing time, the signboard said 4:30 but apparently it is 4. Anyway we were in the queue by 3. It took us 1.15hrs to reach the ticket counter and though there were about 15-20 people left the authorities decided they wouldn't let us in. Only after some Turkish people in the line protested, after a wait of 30 minutes we were let in. Unfair we thought. We had after all stood in line for over an hour. So go early and take in the wonders of the palace.BTW there is a wonderful place to eat in the grounds. It is on the shores of the Bosporus and offer stunning views. Though the menu is limited, the prices are remarkably low compared to Istanbul's other tourist attractions. Anyway you're going their for the views.

Most over-the-top palace you could ever dream of seeing. Do not miss this one-- it just gets more and more ridiculously opulent and is completely worth the time and money. A 4.5 ton chandelier, for crying out loud, amazing! Grounds are also gorgeous. Tips:1) Arrive before 9:45 AM. The queue is an absolute joke if you don't get there early enough. You'll seriously laugh when you see the ineffeciency of the ticket booth. Also, plan to be done around noon-- the tours take quite a bit of time.2) Do buy the combo ticket for the Harem. However, be prepared for a very different experience for that part of the tour. It is not as opulent and I was kind of burnt out on beautiful rooms by then, but it's quite cool to see the apartments of the Sultan's many wives (and so strange to think of them all living there like it's The Bachelor or something)3) Bring your student ID if you have one-- most places in Turkey require a Turkish student ID card, but for some reason four of us were able to use our US student ID cards and got in for 1TL each intead of 20TL (!). Again, the ticket booth is a joke.4) Consider taking a bus from the nearby station up towards Rumeli Hisari (fortress on the Bosphorus with awesome views)-- check out the tripadvisor reviews for it, totally cool and only about a 45 minute bus ride away from Dolmabache

Beautiful and historic place, deserves a visit. The Dolmabahçe Palace was finished in 1856 and was the official otoman imperial residence from 1856 to 1877, and then from 1909 to 1922. It is the third largest ottoman palace in Istanbul. It is located by the Bosphorus with wonderful views. The main building (administrative area) is the most interesting one, with the crystal staircase and the Muayede Hall with the largest crystal chandelier in the world (4.5 tons and 664 candlesticks). The other buildings are also worth a visit, but if you are limited in time, choose the administration building.

Mixed feelings. My yesterday visit to Dolmabahce palace left me with mixed feelings. The good part was the magnificence and the beauty of the palace. We were taken back in the sultans' times and we realised the opulence and luxury they lived in. Even my 8 years old son was impressed and not for a second bored.Personally I would have liked to see the kitchens too ,to make an ideea about their cooking style (and scale !)On the downside , their organising (or rather lack of ) is horrendous. We queued outside the main gate to get inside ,then to pass the security check ,then to buy the tickets (20 YTL), then to get inside the palace , then to be allocated a guide (compulsory ) and finally to visit the harem. No joke , we waited in the fierce sun in total 3hours and a half !!! and the visit itself lasted nearly one and a half hour. Honestly ,so many waiting times , on a torid day , ruined my mood and my day . At some point I lost interest because I was so tired, overheated and frustrated. And the staff was rude and shouting ,like they were guarding the Heaven's gate. Inside the palace we were given an "English" speaking guide . I don't know how knowledgeable he was because I could 'nt understand him on the rare occasions when I could hear him.All in all the palace is beautiful and it worths a visit. If the management could organise the things better and get rid of the compulsory guided visits ,the wholle experience could be more enjoyable.

Fascinating. Highly recommended and now I know why. First of all the queue was unbelievably long, the good thing about going with a group is that you can take shifts standing in the queue. Fortunately there was a parade at the entrance which kept us entertained as we waited to get in. Ticket is for 20 TL and you aren't allowed to take pictures but it was a feast for the eyes. Apparently they take small groups with a free guided tour like every 15-20 people at a time so there is plenty of time for you to look around and enjoy. Rooms were impressive with all the luxurious furniture, chandeliers, paintings...etc. The gardens around the palace are beautiful and there are entrance gates right on the sea. It's said that President Obama, when visiting Istanbul, entered the palace from one of sea gates, as he took a boat. Lucky him, he didn't have to stand in that queue!! The bathrooms there are clean.

beautiful. Make sure you go early to avoid the long lines. And make sure you have plenty of time ahead of you. You must queue to get in, then queue to really get in the building to see the administrative portion (you can go in only every 15 minutes with a guide) and then you queue again to get in the harem section (again with a guide). All in all, I think it was worth it but like I said, make sure you are in good shape and bring a hat because you may very well wait in the sun for a long time.Of course, the decoration is amazing, they tried to copy Versailles and succeeded.There is a very nice terrasse along the Bosphorus where you can eat a little something with the greatest view ever!
GREAT ATTRACTION. Great place -the Sultans new palace. Go early to avoid tourist.. better to go with a guide as you can enter faster. Wonderful chandelliers and history.

Over the top - and very rushed. An impressive palace, showcasing the opulence of the Ottoman Empite. Go early, or face long lines, driven by one ticket window! You are required to wear plastic shoe covers, and use take a "guided" tour, as you walk from room to room, although the "guide" was so far in front of the group, the last half of the group had no idea what she was saying. Fortunately, the group behind caught up with us, so we tried to tag along with them. Do visit the harem section.

Worth a Visit. I enjoyed my visit to this Palace, especially because all of the furnishings of the Ottoman Sultan were relocated here in the late 1800s so Topkapi Palace is largely empty. The crystal staircase and massive chandelier were beautiful, and the grounds were picture worthy. Unfortunately, you can only visit the Palace with a tour guide, which means it is the luck of the draw as to how informative your guide will be and how fast the tour will go. Ours felt very rushed—the guide has us in and out in 40 minutes whereas the description said it we were paying for a 60-90 minute tour. The cost was 15 lira per person, which is about 7 or 8 euros, or 10 USD.

terrible waste of time. If you go make sure you have LOTS of time. The lines are endless. First to get through security, then for the ticket office where 1 (yes one) attendant sells tickets to the entire crowd. And after you get in then the line to actually get into the palace is long also. NO viewing on your own, you must be guided through the place and they let 35-40 people in every 5-10 minutes or so.The place itself is an exercise in bad taste. How to bankrupt a country in the poorest possible taste. There are so many beautiful things to see in Istanbul. Dolmabahce is not one of them!Is is full of the most expensively crafted ugliness bought from all over the world by a sultan aiming to prove his worth and western orientation, just before the empire ended.Spend your time in the Topkapi in stead, or the Rustem Pasha mosque or the Chora Church, Or the Sakip Sabanci museum, but dont go to the Dolmabahce.

See how the rich live. This is the last palace built by the Sultans. It sits right on the Bosphorus and has amazing views. It is well worth the visit and price of admission.When you buy a ticket you have a choice of which areas you will see. Get the one that gets you in to all the sections. Unlike most of the other museums, you are only allowed in the main house and the harem in tour groups. So check the schedules. We did it backwards in that we went to the harem first and then did the main house. That was fine and we missed nothing. The first thing you will notice is the scale of the harem is impressive. Everything is bigger than you would expect. The materials and workmanship is incredible. It is very obvious this house was built for a king. The flow of the harem also makes a lot of sense. Mustafa Ataturk died here and his room is kept the way it was on the day he died. The main building is just as impressive as the harem, but on a larger scale. There is crystal every where you look. The carpets and wood floor are incredible. Especially when you consider they are 150 years old. If you go, try to stick near the tour guide as they don't speak that loud and you will miss stuff if you can't hear them. At the harem they mark your ticket when you take a tour, but they didn't do that at the main house. I would take the tour twice, once to listen to the tour guide the second time to take in all you missed on the first tour. There is also an aviary on the grounds. They have some guinea hens and peacocks running around loose. What I thought was interesting is that they also have cats running around loose and they don't go after the hens. They also have a clock museum on the grounds. Besides the large number of clocks in the main buildings they also have a large collection in this building. I love all things mechanical and I would have spent a lot more time in this section, but the family is not into clocks and they moved along quickly. One thing I found annoying is that in most of these buildings you are not allowed to take any pictures when you are inside. Not sure why, but I wish I could have gotten some shots of the clocks. I don't know the schedule, but they do a regular change of the guards in front of the palace. It only takes a few minutes and it's neat to see the routine they go through. I would also add try not to be the dumb tourist, like the ones I saw, who jumps in the middle of their exercise to get a picture. The soldiers took it all in stride, but it must be annoying. This is well worth the money spent and you can easily spend half a day at the palace. Once you are done you can easily get to Taksim. I will warn you that if you walk it is a steep uphill walk.

Masterpiece of Urban Evolution at Ottoman Empire. This imposing palace has been home to Ottoman Sultans as of mid 19th century. Up until then, Topkapı Palace has been the residence for the sultans, still bearing the medieval life style and thus not meeting the mondane needs. Dolmabahçe Palace, in that respect, is part of the modernization attempt of the royal family in architectural terms. Visiting the Palace without knowing the background information might be very superficial. Indeed, you can visit the Palace only with obligatory tours, either in English or in Turkish or with a private guide. I recommend you opt the private guide alternative where you can get access to more detailed and correct information. Under normal circumstances, an appropriate tour can take up to 4 hours whereas, official tours are limited to 1 hour which is too short to see it all. Gardens are beautifully kept with birds and ducks and peacocks around. It's forbidden to take pictures inside. I recommend wholeheartedly to visit this palace, a living splendor at the decline of an empire.

Beautiful interiors and a must to see. The palace is great inside and I absolutely recommend to anrybody interested to see fantastic interiors. It is right that the tours could take longer to give visitors more time to appreciate all the beauty but on the other hand this would cause very long ques to get there. I like the current way much better. Staff was OK, no reason to complaint and I found 20 liras just reasonable for such a beauty. One should think of the costs of maintaining such monuments before complaining how expenseive it is...Although I would probably score a bit lower, I give full starts to at last partly offset the previous negative score which makes the palace rank very low among other to do's. Should I follow the ranking here, I would miss it which would be a bad mistake. I put it into top 5 and a must to see in Istanbul.

Amazing palace but obnoxious staff. This place is inevitable.Huge.Beautiful.Incredible because of the somptuousness of the furniture, the carpets, the rooms, the architecture.BUT there are some BIG problems :1) you can't visit by yourself. You have to follow a guide. You have the choice between a visit in Turkish or in English.If you pick the English one, you'll be a group of 60 or more. You can't really hear the guide. The guide starts speaking but you can't see him/her because you are in another room and there is no more space to fit in the room where he/she is speaking.You can't stay in the room to admire it correctly. You have to move permanently.2) No booklet available in English. Only in Turkish.3) no information in the rooms or in front of the showcase. You don't know what you see. And you can't ask your guide because she/he is far far ahead. 4) he staff in charge of the security doesn't know anything about the pieces in the room and is very, VERY unpleasant.5) the price is not cheap : 20liras.To summarize, the site is amazing, but the visit offered and the nastiness of the staff spoil a lot your discovery and enthusiasm...

Take the Selamlik Tour and Don't Miss the Crystal Pavilion. I visited Dolmabahce Palace in December 2010 and I have to say I preferred Topkapi Palace being authentic Ottoman, not a sumptuous European palace replica as Dolmabahce. Anyway, Dolmabahce is worth visiting. The only way to see the palace is guided tour in Turkish or English. I recommend visiting some 2-3 hours before closing time because tours are not too long at this hour and you see and hear just as much as you need (at least in my experience). Palace has two sections: Selamlik (State Rooms) and Harem. You have to buy separate tickets and I recommend that you buy the ticket only for the Selamlik tour, because there you see the most representative public part of the palace with Crystak Staircase and Ceremonial Hall. Harem was a private section, it's more modest, and 19th century European style furniture you can already see in Selamlik section. You save money and time this way.Of course, walk through the palace garden is wonderful, and also a sea view. You shouldn't miss the lovely Crystal Pavilion in the garden which is a real pearl. Taking photos inside is not allowed even without a flash.

Welcome to the Bling!. Be prepared to be shocked and awed when you enter the Dolmabahce Palace. It has plenty of history stored up inside with an overpowering dash of ostentatiousness. From a 4.5 tonne crystal chandelier to a crystal staircase. With 285 rooms and 46 halls, the tour will wind on for what seems like forever. The facts keep coming, but there isn't a loo in sight. So a tip would be avoid drinking a lot of water before you enter. And another tip would be to go with a guided tour as they are the only way of getting inside the palace. Finally, if you want to photograph inside the palace, you will require a special permission. Ensure you get that in advance. For more detail hit:http://gotheredothat.wordpress.com/2010/11/28/intense-istanbul-day-2-cruises-and-palaces/

Impressive. Really worth a visit. Nice gardens, great location right on hte Bosphorus. The inside is a real proof that the sultans were having too much money and nothing to do. You will dozens of huge rooms with crystals and gold. It is crowded and very hot inside during summers.

Incompetence perfected. First things first, while myself and my girlfriend gained entry to the grounds of the Palace, we did not make it into the Palace proper. If it's a review of the attraction you seek, then I must direct you elsewhere. If you're at all interested in how it came to be that we got in, then promptly left, indulge me.Joined a queue for the ticket office that snaked this way and that with it's 'tail' a couple of yards from a third of the way up the 'body', hence joined the tail and watched as countless people came through security and joined the 'body' of the queue, usurping those of us (like myself and my beau) stupid enough to have taken our places correctly. Eventually losing patience with the scenario which was seeing others lop 30mins+ off their waiting time, myself and my girlfriend 'readjusted' our place ahead of numerous interlopers, provoking a furious response from a few others in the queue. I'll spare you the details, suffice to say that it should have been the queue skippers and the inability of the attractions' staff to either provide barriers for appropriate queueing or to police the queue, that should have been the objects of disaffection.Eventually (c.80 (yes, eighty) minutes later) reached the front of a queue which was hundreds strong to find a ticket office staffed by one person. To describe this lack of staffing, lack of care, lack of involvement with the paying customer and lack of service as 'unsatisfactory' would be an understatement akin to saying that Rafael Nadal is not bad at tennis.Paid and entered.Made our way through the gardens to the Palace itself to find... another queue. Also lengthy. And not moving. Language from me that decorum (and the moderator) prevents repetition here and a decision (as time was short - I write this from the airport lounge) to just give up.The entry ticket was time stamped and, having spent about 10 mins or so on the premises, it was necessary to seek a refund. This, a straightforward and reasonable target, would not have been realised were it not for the kind assistance of a member of the Turkish 'Museum Police' to whom we turned in desperation. TL20 is not a lot of money, but it's a tidy sum for nothing in return.This attraction was the last of ten we visited during our Istanbul break. It encapsulated the very worst of the attitude of the Turkish Tourist Board towards the people bringing their custom to the country. That is, as long as you hand over the cash, then waiting times, unruly queues aplenty, and a total indifference to customer satisfaction is of little importance.A real shame. A city filled with interesting things to see, seemingly overseen by grasping incomptetents.

Dissapointing in a way, nice chandelier though. I'm not sure whether to recommend this visit or not. On one hand, it's got some things worth seen, on the other, there's so many down sides that I don't really know.Pros first, it's a nice palace, beautiful building, great site by the bosphorus, beautiful chandelier (4,5 ton one) in the ceremonial room (the last room you see), other beautiful lamps, the very nice gardens and the cristal staircase are, I guess, the pros.On the down side, it's expensive, again, as the Topkapi palace, you have to pay for the palace and for the Harem separatedly, 20 TRL for the Palace and 10 TRL (I believe cause we didn't pay it) for the Harem. It closes at around 4 pm so be there early because it goes with a tour guide. Tours are done in english or turk only, you have to put some bags on your shoes and in august, with the heat, it makes your feet sweaty and unconfortable. No pictures under no circumstance on the inside and the guide we had, eventhough was a nice man, spoke not so good english and I couldn't understand most of what he said, also beeing a large group, you were either close to him or wouldn't hear anything. Also there was four people right behind us with someone translating what the tour guide said to french that really made it impossible to follow.The palace is magnificent on its side and on the furniture, well the little we saw. To me, it felt like they took away all the important furniture and placed all the rugs, chairs and sofas they could find scattered around the rooms. It felt like everything they had there, had been put there for display purposes. So unreal. We never saw the room where Ataturk died and instead we visited rooms and rooms full of chairs, libraries with no books etc.If you take the tram, line 1, to the end (kabatas) then walk for 5 mins you will reach the Palace, The entrance is on works at the moment (August 2010) but it's still easily reachable.So it's really up to you, whether to visit it or not.

Spectacular - well worth the trip. The Dolmabahce Palace is a little way outside the usual tourist part of Istanbul (Sultanahmet) but it is easy to get to - just take the tram to the end of the line at Kabatas, and it's about five minutes walk further on.I found it really spectacular, and probably better value than the Topkapi Palace - entry fee 20 lira for the whole thing, including guided tour. The Ceremonial Suites are stunning - huge chandeliers, grand staircases, hundreds of paintings and thousands of ornaments. The only drawback is that you have to go through as part of a tour, and the one I went on was conducted at a rather rapid pace.The Harem is less interesting and perhaps a little shabby. On the day I visited people were allowed to wander through at their own pace, which was good.There are also good views onto the Bosphorus and a nice cafe. The palace is quite close to the Istanbul Modern art gallery, and the two attractions make a good combination.

Great palace. Although the guided tour was very quick the palace is worth the visit for its decoration. Tickets cost 20TL/person.Very interesting to see it after visiting Topkapi (previous residence of sultans), bearing in mind that in the middle of the 19th century, the Ottoman Empire was considered as being a part of Europe.

Go To Beylerbei Sarayi (Palace) instead - a 'mini' Dolmabahce. I loved Dolmabahce Palace, unlike many of the Westerners, who sounded a bit superior and arrogant, but can acknowledge the problems in touring the site, especially in high season.  As an alternative, could I suggest the Beylerbei Palace on the Asian side, just next to the bridge from Ortakoy? It's a bit harder to get to, but a scale model of Dolmabahce, and I found the guides very nice and informative. As well, I have never found any lines (every time I come with friends to Turkey, at least 12 times [I've been to Istanbul 77 times!], I take them to Beylerbei). Incidentally, I'm not Turkish - I live in Jerusalem, Israel.

A wonderful example of bad taste. This is one of the most absurdly overdecorated and chintzy buildings I've ever seen, but it is still very impressive, especially since the furnishings are original and obviously very valuable. While the building is impressive, the guided tour (the only way to visit the palace) is not: one would expect better for 20 Lira. The guides' English is poor and the tour is so fast that there isn't much chance to see anything in detail. I would suggest reading up on the 19th-century Ottoman court before visiting, so you know what to look for and can more or less ignore the guide. Unfortunately photography, even without flash, is not allowed.

Has issues, but is still a thumbs up. Having read the other reviews, I can certainly understand and appreciate some of the negativity towards this attraction. However, my jaw is still dropped after seeing the Ceremonial Hall and a number of the other rooms in the palace so for that reason, I would give it a marginal recommendation.Given their current setup, it is really going to depend upon your guide if you have a good experience or a bad one. For the tour through main palace, our guide was pretty lively, pretty understandable, and pretty entertaining so there we had a good experience. It doesn't hurt that the rooms are magnificent.In the Harem, our guide was bored and not understandable at all. Furthermore, quite honestly, the Harem rooms are not nearly as exciting so if doing it over again I would skip that portion of the palace.As a comment to the Palace itself, they should either have more frequent tours which would mean smaller groups (our group was really too large), or they should have audio guides so that people could move along at their own pace. The mandatory guided tours is a bit outdated.

Visit after Topkapi Palace. Its interesting to think that the ruling family moved from the ancient traditions of Topkapi to what then must have been the ultramodern and luxurious Dolmabahce Palace. Its is without doubt way over the top in its excessive use of gold leaf and crystal and I am sure must have given visiting dignitaries a few giggles when they arrived from Europe in the late 19th century! Reminded me me over some of the over the top buildings currently being built in the Arabian Gulf.

Stunning. Just entering the Muayede hall with the 4.5 tonne chandelier is breathtaking and worth the entrance fee in itself. But the whole palace is a must see place. A guide (not optional)takes you throught the palace and you need to keep up and close if you want to hear what is said.

Overdressed wedding cake. The staggering opulcence of this palace may be impressive, but I found it very shallow and artificial! It looks like an overdressed wedding cake ... totally out of place and nothing Turkish about it! It costs 20YL for the guided tour! And a guided tour is the only way to visit the palace. Our English group was a huge group and the poor tour guide (who tried very hard NOT to be friendly) gave info in an off-handed manner to those closest to her. After the first few rooms most group members lost total interest in what she had to say and it didn't bother her much. Though the info she gave was very informative and rich in fact. We didn't do the harem ... apparently not worthwhile. One positive thing is that one does see a lot of the palace at a reasonable price ... but do you really want to see endless passages ... But the view from the palace across the Bosphorus is worthwhile. My advice ... go to Europe and see the real thing! Who wants to see mock rococo in Turkey.

DO NOT MISS THIS........... This is by far the best attraction in Istanbul in my opinion. The blue Mosque has all the publicity but this Dolmabahce Palace (Dolmabahce Sarayi) is one not to be missed. The palace is so grand and beautiful. One has to experience it for themselves. You also get free English speaking guide which is a nice touch.

My Fav In Istanbul. WOW a must!!!!!!!!!
BREATHTAKING i loved ittttttttttt
u see alot of interesting things and u find urself imagining how the sultan lived there!
also loved the area around...
u have to go!

Deception. This visit was quite a deceprtion. You have to wait and to queue everywhere. First, in the middle of august, full saison, there was only one place opened to buy ticket.After that, you have to wait the next visit, because you MUST join a group. You can't be free. So, one more time, you wait.When you are in a group, the guide walks and speaks too fast, you don't have the time to see details. And if you are at the end of the group, there are gards who say you, not kind at all : "Join the group ! Join the group" just like if you were a dog.So, I would not recommand to visit thos place. It's nice, but you can't appreciate it because of the awful organisation.

Very poor tours.. As someone who has visited many palaces and stately homes in the U.K. and elsewhere, having to have a guided tour is often a bit of a chore, stopping you from browsing at your own pace etc. It can, however, sometimes be a revelation - opening your eyes to things you may have missed.Sadly, the only revelation about the tours of this place are how bad they are! Having paid 20L for the main palace tour and a further 15L for the tour of the harem (you can't go around unsupervised - I think that is the best word for the feeling you are given) we had expected some sort of quality level of guiding. Unfortunately, that was not the case. 40 or 50 people in a group with one guide is not good enough, particularly when that guide speaks quietly or lacks interest.Our tour guide of the main palace was just about O.K. - the tour was still too quick, you missed things if you didn't get near the front and at some points we were told nothing more than the very basics; but frankly the tour of the harem has to rate as the worst I have ever had - we were rushed around by a surly guide who seemed to have no interest in being there and less in actually saying anything. Her task seemed to be to get the group in and out as quickly as possible. By 2/3rds of the way through our tour, we and several others in our 'group' had become detatched from our guide, who had simply disappeared ahead with anyone who could keep up. In the end we exited the place perhaps 25 minutes after entering in the midst of a Turkish speaking group (they have tours in Turkish and English) who also seemed shell shocked by the pace of the tour.The harem lacked anything special to make it worth a visit on its own. Combined with the main palace and in particular the main ballroom it is fine as a building of interest and perhaps worth a visit, but frankly the guiding detracts considerably from this as a venue for someone wanting to enjoy an excursion. I would recommend the Topkapi way ahead as a site and the fact you don't get marched around by disinterested guides an absolute bonus.

waste of time. Don't bother with this tourist trap. It's expensive to get in. Guards arbitrarily let some people enter with backpacks and make others check in theirs. The tour guides are the worst I've ever encountered. One - a tall, thin, bald man - was barely intelligible and kept barking out orders for guests not to talk with each other while he was prattling on. He also got verbally abusive to a elderly woman who complained to him about not understanding what he was saying. Another guide - a slim woman - was much nicer but had absolutely no useful information on the rooms she was guiding us through. "This was used by the sultan's wife" was about the level of information be could provide. When asked for more information she became impatient. Her goal seemed to be to get the tour over as quickly as possible. Which suited me fine since her tour was worthless. Unless you have done your reading in advance about this place save yourself the ridiculously high 20 YTL entrance fee and go somewhere - anywhere - else.

Exquisite luxury - but not very Turkish. I quote a previous reviewer: "Our tour was in acceptable English, but there was no time to linger or even look at most of the palace - guards were following behind and constantly moving us along. The guide had difficulty answering questions about material outside the scripted tour."  I bought the "camera tag" and took quite a number of photographs, but they were rushed because the guards were pushing the group along so fast. There was no time to examine some of the gorgeous objects in any detail and, as another reviewer noted, some fabulous objects of art were not well displayed. What should have been a delightful and educational experience was diminished by the feeling that all the guides wanted was a high thruput and they cared little about the people "in the pipeline". I rated my experience as high as I did because of the wondrous objects and decorations in the palace which I was able to see and photograph. Frankly, I got more out of later examining my photographs in detail than I did when I was actually there in the palace - a sad commentary.

Over the top but a great place to see. Located on the Bosphorus Shore the Dolmabahce Palace was built by Sultan Abdul Mecit who in 1843 commissioned the building of this new palace. It was to be Ottoman-European Palace that would wow everyone, the designer for the Paris Opera was used to decorate the interiors and in 1867 the palace was completed.Entrance fee into the Palace is broken up into sections e.g. just the palace tour, the palace and harem, crystal palace ect. If you wish to take photos in the palace there is also another extra fee, they will give you a tag for your camera, HOLD ONTO IT! as I found I lost mine and another person on the tour also had this occur when you attach it to your camera, the ribbon isn't very long and comes undone easily.The Palace decoration is over the top. Being designed by the designer for the Paris Opera it is very French in deco in both the fabrics used, the paintings and chandeliers. I opted to go on both the Main Palace tour and the Harem Tour, if you do this by a combined ticket as it is cheaper than buying both separately. When you go to the main entrance of the palace they have a board stating what times the tours are. You can only go through the palace on one of these tours which are operated by the Palace. When I was visiting there was a Turkish tour and an English tour written up, I don't know if they do this in other languages. On the tour there was about 30 people. You have a guide who speaks extremely good English, and provides you with information about all the different rooms. You must walk only on the Red Carpet to help preserve the palace. Everything in there is ORIGINAL, and I couldn't believe how beautiful some of the items are in many of the rooms. The tour does seem to drag on a bit however when you come to the final room (the main hall) were the tour ends is wow, the painting of the ceiling, the chandelier everything in this room is amazing and very over the top. The Harem Tour was I felt a bit more rushed than the main palace tour, and is alot shorter, you do see the living quarters of concubines, wives and mother of the Sultan but after you see a couple of these it does get a bit boring. You do however on this tour see were Kemal Ataturk lived when he spent time in the palace and the room were he died. All the clocks in the palace are stopped and have been set at 9.05am the time that Kemal Ataturk died, so don't set your watch by any of the clocks.On the site there is also the Crystal Palace, which unfortunately when I was there was under construction. I believe that this is also another fee to go in, however the guard let me go and have a look for free (there are two other rooms in this area) and he was also very nice to inform me of the long corridor that leads from this area to the main palace which you can peak at through a crack in the doorway. The Crystal Palace is located next to the aviary. Also there is a very nice Clock Museum off to the left when walking to the Harem which I came across which I enjoyed. The day that I went to visit the palace it was raining, and be aware if this is the case you will have to put covers (which they provide) over your shoes. If you have time this is a great palace to visit however Topkapi is much more the "Turkish" palace were as this is very similar to palaces that are in Europe. To get there catch the Tram to it's last stop and then just walk about 5 minutes to the palace (much easier and cheaper than a taxi). I wouldn't go on an organized tour to this palace as it's easy to get to, and a tour will cost you twice the price for exactly the same as what you can do yourself.

A bit disappointing. While our tour of the Dolmabahce Palace was comprehensive and conducted in almost faultless English, we were disappointed with the atmosphere inside and the way that they didn't seem to show the Palace off to it's best effect. In particular, there are a huge number of very impressive chandeliers as you walk round, but many of them were not illuminated, which left them looking a bit grey and dull. The decoration and fabric of the Palace is also quite impressive but just not shown off very well, which meant that we left with the feeling that the Palace was a bit cold, grey and could have done with a really good clean! As an example, the enormous ballroom contains the biggest chandelier I've ever seen (a few tons in weight), but it wasn't lit..it just didn't do the rest of the room justice!

a must. not crowded as topkapi, perfect guided tour (english) and interesting western style furnished rooms. Quiet and romantic place. Please notice we visited Dolmabahce in April (cold!!) It must be nicer in summer time.
